UPDATE - While this item is much more than I initially wanted, now that I've used it for a couple of weeks I find that you can use it to merely count steps. The rub is that it can't manually be reset to zero (as it you want to record the steps or mileage of a hike). It resets automatically every midnight. Of course you can get the the answer with a little simple math. It's much larger than I like (previous ones have been much, much smaller) but overall, I think I might have been too harsh in my initial review. Just know what it is you're getting.

I expected much more given the critical acclaim. I started out enjoying it because I thought the characters were clever and the wit dry, but it quickly became a boring muddle of nothing. And the banter stopped being clever anyway. I don't understand the high praise of those critics actually read the book.  If they only read the premise and a summary, their praise makes more sense. Based on the later, I expected to love it too.

I loved this book.  I could see from the start how it was going to play out, but I still enjoyed every minute of it. Lots of fresh humor and some heavy issues, although I did not read it for "The Issues."
works fine. I use it for my laptop that has only two (very closely spaced) USB ports.

I've been a long time fan of JP and have read every one of her books. I found this one uneven and the ending so far out I wanted to toss the book against the wall. I enjoyed the characters, especially the spunky young Jenna and the psychic; I enjoyed the present/past development of the story (I know many readers don't like this, however):; I even enjoyed much of the elephant stuff although I admit I did skim some of it. But the story didn't hang together and there were wild leaps of logic and too much random chance. It starts as one kind of story, turns into something else, then turns again. If you like woo-woo, it might appeal to you. If you love elephants, you'll enjoy that. If you like mystery, there's something there for you too. Because JP was the author, it was well written and amazing in places, but over all the novel fell short of her usual very high standard.

If I could give more than five stars, I would. This is a fantastic, informative and very readable book about Sharyl Attkisson's experience as a CBS reporter, and should be a must read for everyone. She focuses on a handful of more recent stories (which was interesting reading in itself because we all followed these stories) and uses them to illustrate how corporate and government interests/pushback influence what is covered in the news and how it is covered. The station's own bias (and that of the "star" newscaster) also plays a big role. The end result is that stories thoroughly and painstakingly researched and developed by a reporter (using on the ground and inside sources) gets tweaked, rewritten, watered down, and changed to the point that it is meaningless at best. And that's assuming it ever makes the news. It's frightening to me as someone who has counted on the press as an unofficial fourth branch of the government - to keep an eye on things and bring us the truth.  In a democracy/republic it's vital that citizens know the truth about what is happening and it government and the media collude to obstruct the truth, we have state control. I doubt anyone actually wants that.I'm always skeptical of the news I see and read, but will be even more so now. I also found the book informative about the process. I hasn't realized reporters had to pitch stories, get approval, write them, get approval, have them edited, and then either rejected or altered. Eye opening on many accounts.

An interesting premise and well plotted, but I didn't particularly like or care about any of the characters. The author's writing is very distant, non-dramatic (action often summarized rather than played out on the page). This makes for a quick, easy read but doesn't involve the reader in the story in any emotional way. This is my first book by this author and based solely on this book I wouldn't buy another, but I have read good reviews so I'll probably take a chance on one more.

A basic small town detective mystery but without character or anything else that drew me into the story, made me care or kept me turning the pages. There are a lot of characters and the writing is choppy and hard to follow.

I have enjoyed other books by this author, but this one annoyed me for playing so blatantly on torn-from-the-headlines emotion and a sickeningly sweet and maudlin resolution. It's like a made-for-TV movie that's supposed to be a tear-jerker.  But it reads quickly, and I did enjoy 10 year old Jenny and her resourcefulness.
quirky but fun. A light read with some clever insights. I enjoyed it.  I also enjoyed What Alice Forgot, but didn't like The Husband's Secret, which others have liked.
This is a delightful, quirky story that kept me involved, made me pause and think, and left me smiling. I enjoyed the characters and the writing style.

This is a too long book about unlikable people doing stupid things. And it's badly written.  I've read a handful of Barclay's other books, and while they weren't deep or nuanced, they were readable and better than this one. Was this even a serious attempt at a novel? I am sorry I wasted the time on it.

This book was okay for what it is, which is a feel-good collection of stories about the experiences of people who "died" and returned to life (A near death experience). But there is no real analysis, no exploration of the experience of people of other cultures, no in-depth attempt to find answers. People's experiences were the standard stuff we've heard before - a white light, feelings of peace and love etc. Is this really heaven/life after death or simply the electronic pulses of our bodies shutting down? Why are all the visions similar to the Christian vision of heaven? What about evil people - are their experiences the same? How are these visions any different from what we experience in our dreams? (some of my dreams have the same elements as these visions). I was expecting a deeper analysis and I was disappointed. If all you want is feel good fluff, it's an okay read.

This book reads as though it was written with the hopes of being made into a movie. It's a Blow'em Up, non-stop action (all unrealistic) "thriller" that Hollywood seems to think people like.  Maybe they do in movies, but in a book it comes across as ludicrous. The details don't always add up, people do stupid things, and the author follows the formula of making things worse and worse for his heroine - to the point that by the end of the book it became a parody (and tedious.) As others have noted, the bad guy is so bad (and competent) that he's a joke, and there's way too much torture and cruelty for my taste. I can envision a book about a group of stranded tourists and both their interactions and the struggles to survive - in fact I have read several like that that I've enjoyed. Not this one. Although I do give the author credit for researching plants and animals in the jungle.

This is a poignant, powerful, thought-provoking novel, at times painful but always engrossing. I found the story grabbed me from the start and kept me turning the pages -- although I would force myself to stop at times and appreciate what I'd just read. I don' t understand the negative reviews of this book. The characters were not always sympathetic but they were true to the author's portrayal of their histories. I also enjoyed the author's specificity of particulars about the time period.

I found the premise intriguing - what is it like for a mom who suspects her son of murder - and I was looking forward to reading this book, but in the end was disappointed. I didn't like any of the characters much (except, surprisingly, Tucker who is the suspected son). There's a lot of railing and flailing by the characters, saying the same things over and over, and it wore me down. I had trouble keeping track of Tucker's relationship to each of the missing girls and felt there were too many names thrown around without any sense of who they were. The writing lacks subtlety and the characterization is flat. There's one chapter that stands out for being totally and intentionally misleading to the reader, and I found that cheap and annoying. I also found the "discussion" (such as it was) about terminating a pregnancy so bland and unemotional as to be bothersome. I'm fully pro choice, but it's not the same sort of decision as "shall we have chicken for dinner or pizza?"The book is not particularly well written, but it's a quick read.

I was hoping for more subtlety and nuance but it is still a readable enough book, although I find the rave reviews hard to understand.  Lisa feels responsible for her friend's daughter's disappearance because the girl was supposed to come home from school with Lisa's daughter and spend the night. But Lisa's daughter got sick that day and wasn't at school. The girl is a teenager - she never called her mom to say I am not spending the night after all? Lisa, and the town, keep beating Lisa up over this. Yes, she would feel guilty, but not to the degree she does, and it got tiresome. As did the missing girl's aunt, who is over-the-top nasty and cruel. Other girls in town have been kidnapped and let go the next day, after being abused. POSSIBLE SPOILER - It was clear to me that Lucinda's abductor was someone different, and I had a pretty good idea how it would play out. (the "twist" at the end is one that has been used on numerous occasions.)  END SPOILER  I liked the fact that it took place in the Lake Country of England and I think the flavor of setting was well conveyed.

This is less a mystery than a coming of age story set in gritty town in the Ozarks.  The chapters alternate between Lucy (the daughter who never knew her mother) and Lila (the mother who disappeared early in her daughter's life), and a handful of other characters.  I found the constant jumping around of viewpoint and generation hard to follow at times, especially because all the other characters are present in both generations. I sometimes feel that by writing about "poor, hard-luck folks," and orphans, and victims, and abusers etc, authors imbue their books with an air of importance that is somewhat artificial. It annoyed me here, especially because the characters were largely cliched. And I found a lot of the characters' behaviors unbelievable. Nonetheless, I did enjoy the book and want to see how it all worked out. Not convinced I'll try the author's next book, however

I found this book interesting enough (once I got into the story, which took awhile) but it was also irritating. The main character is an ex-FBI profiler, fired for being a drunk. She's been sober now for 4 years and works as a PI. She is called in the a homicide detective in a case of serial murders of young girls (not my favorite topic.)  Would a city cop really call on a private, PI for help? Not easy to swallow. There's a lot of forensic focus but nothing really new. The author threw way too much "PC, aren't we cool" stuff into the mix - sleuth is Chinese (although nothing made of it except author can check of box for "unusual" character), her parents were addicts, she was taken in by her grandparents who were murdered, then adopted by a family that also adopted a Black boy, who is now also gay.  Way too much. Labels don't make a character, and I felt this was manipulative on the author's part. The PI's partner is a computer guy, and while I know some of them are good, this guy is over the top. He can get information that probably isn't even on computers and all in an instant. It's an okay book, certainly readable enough, but nothing that would make me say it's a must-read or lead me to search out other books by this author.

This is a strange book, and one that wouldn’t have appealed to me based solely on a plot summary. But I found it captivating. The ending was a bit too quick, and something of a let-down, but I enjoyed the reading of the book and had trouble putting it down.

I enjoyed this authors early books, not so much some of the later ones – too much chic lit life-style stuff (a little is fun and I get the character, but after awhile it overwhelms, and bores, me). But I really enjoyed this book.  I agree with readers who found Allison unlikable (short-sighted, weak and whiny), and her husband was a flat, one-dimensional and not really believable character) but I found the story interesting and engaging. I don’t understand addiction and this book helped be get a handle on how people fall into it. I wouldn’t recommend it as a book about addiction however, but as a quick, “entertaining,” read.

The author tries to write in the style of Scott Turrow, Sheldon Seigal, Steve Martini, but doesn't come close. It's first person, present tense, which I actually enjoy but sometimes bothers other readers, but his real problem is that he can't tell a story. The writing is decent enough and the plot could have been compelling, but the characters are flat and indistinguishable, and the story plods along at an even pace of words filling the page with nothing to interest the reader (me), nothing to draw me to any of the characters, no tension, nothing but a steady boring pace.

This is a decent, enjoyable enough book, but it's not a great book, or a deep book, or a book with complex characters. The characters are stereotypes and the story predictable. It's the sort of book Oprah might have gone nuts over - poor, put upon people staying strong and finding a happy ending. I think anytime there's a book about hard times, there's a tendency to think it's significant and meaningful. This book has an interesting historical aspect, and the plight of modern foster kids is one I'm familiar with and which deserves exploration in itself, but this book was more interested in playing on the reader's emotions the way a TV drama might than developing a complex story. I did enjoy reading it, however.

This author previously wrote mysteries under the name Kathy Hogan Trocheck. I liked her mysteries and am not as big a fan of romance in general. Her romances follow a predictable pattern - -  plucky young woman, divorced or recently broken up, broke or down and out tries to make a go of it in a new business which involves houses, antiques, weddings, flowers, whatever. There’s opposition from someone, often family, and a hunky male who falls for her without even knowing her. The humor and character development were a bit flatter in this book than in some of her earlier romances, but it was a decent book for light summer vacation reading.

I’ve enjoyed this author’s previous books, but thought this one fell short. A handful of characters muddled around, carrying on meaningless and boring conversations (the author giving voice to her opinions?), and nothing happens. Two sisters - but no conflict or tension. A mother and daughter - a little tension hinted at but not seen. A love affair - sort of, but again with no significance or conclusion. A main character who is trying to figure out where to go with her life, though she does nothing and isn’t particularly likable. A series of arsons which end up meaning nothing and going nowhere. The write up hints at divisions within the community - locals vs. summer folks. This could have been an interesting and meaningful element, but it actually is never developed at all. It stuck me as a book the author began with a few vague ideas that she never got a handle on. It’s like she needed to get the book done and couldn’t decide herself what it was about.

I loved this book, and am confounded by the number of critical reviews. I found it a fascinating and compelling, and even delightful -  though it deals with a gritty, seamy (and sometimes steamy) aspect of life in 1876. The author did an outstanding job of creating sense of time and place, and in creating colorful and believable (if not likable) characters. It wasn’t until the end that I realized it was based on true events, and the author had done an incredible amount of research to get the time and place right. I loved Jenny, who is clearly the sparkle at the heart of the novel. Blanche was a bit off-putting, but I can understand how she did what she did in order to survive. She was tough and eventually humanized.The book starts with the murder of Jenny. In roughly alternating chapters the book moves forward as Blanche tries to discover who killed her, and from the beginning when the two women met up to the moment of her death. I found the structure easy to follow (unlike some readers - and I don’t like to work at my reading either) and think it added greatly to the structure of the novel.I loved Room (also by the author). This is a different kind of book entirely, but equally impressive. It’s original and sharply developed.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book (and I didn't particularly like her first one.) I liked the voice of each of the characters, the stories of how they met and married Taylor, and the interactions following his death. It was the sort of book I hated to put down and couldn't wait to get back to. It's not a traditional plot driven mystery, although I found the ending satisfying and the questions about his death compelling enough to interest me.

This is a hard book to review because I suspect while many will enjoy it, many others will find it confusing and just plain nutty. I did enjoy reading it, while also realizing it is not at all a realistic, textured character story OR a real mystery. There are a number of character viewpoints and stories, all coalescing around a weekend music festival for high school students. I enjoyed spending time in this world but I'm not sure I'd seek out others by this author if her subsequent books are of a similar ilk.

Burke has done better books than this. In fact, this was pretty bad. I did finish it, but I skimmed a lot. I didn't have much interest in the main character, no interest whatsoever in the woman who disappeared ten years ago, and found the plot so convoluted and twisted and full of boring detail that what little I did find interesting about the book was outweighed.

I've read and enjoyed all of Scottoline's books. I was drawn to this one by the concept - father trying to win the good graces of his son let's him drive home from school. When there's an accident, the father decides to take the blame, and then decides to flee and not report it at all.I did not like his choice then or through out the book, but that's really irrelevant. I often read books where I don't agree with the actions of the characters. What bothered me was that none of the characters seemed believable, there was no one I was rooting for, the plot twists and setbacks were unrealistic, the choices of the characters were nutty, and the ending was too quick and came out of nowhere. A good concept that could have been a great book (think Jodi Picoult). Readable enough for a plane or beach afternoon, but not a book that resonates in any way.

The book is divided into three parts, the first two being two different versions of the same story (sort of). I found the first part fascinating, wondering what would happen to the characters, being repelled by the actions but also captivated by the atmosphere created. In the second part I marveled at how the same events were depicted and the author's skill in melding them, but also felt a little tricked. It's easy to create a wonder world of intrigue if you don't ever fully answer for it. The third part is a happy, Hallmark movie type wrap up, and to my mind, not an integral part of the story.  The book was very readable and captivating, but I ended up both admiring the author's skill and feeling cheated.

When I really enjoy a novel, as I did this one, (or visa-verse) I like to read the reviews of those who didn't share my reaction. I fully understand what the lower star reviewers say about being predictable,having 1%er issues, and a fairytale wrap up ending, BUT it's the authors style of writing and observations along the way that I loved and kept me interested. It's a book that stopped me at times to admire a phrase or an observation, much like I stop to admire a flower or a dog at play, and while I often hate trite, happy-ever-after-endings, I was drawn into the world of the book not to mind.

Like other reviewers, I had some problems with this book but in the end found that overall I thought it was very good, and a bit different from other books (although on the surface quite like Room, as others have noted). In the first part, "below," a young girl, Blythe, is kidnapped and hidden away in an old missile silo by a survivalist. My immediate reaction was "not another kidnap book" but I soon realized that it wasn't. Dobbs, her kidnapper, was the school librarian and while he's cruel in keeping her, he does go out of his way to get her "everything she could want." Years pass. She has a baby who doesn't live, and then another who does, who grows to be a teen. Blythe had more or less given up hope of ever getting free and has tried to make the son's life as full and normal as possible while being held captive underground.The second part of the book, "above," deals with the world they encounter when they escape. I was expecting a homecoming with family tensions, troubles adjusting etc, but instead they find a world collapsed and the few survivors living in primitive ways and worrying about gangs and autocrats. Again, I resisted at first - this wasn't what I expected, nor was it the kind of book I usually read. But it was captivating and won me over.The strength of the book, to me, was the writing. Morley conveyed strength and horror in vivid ways without resorting to cliches. It was unpleasant reading in many parts because of what Blythe lived through, but her determination and bravery kept me rooting for her. My biggest problem with the second part was that in all the horror above, she finds good people and even goes home and finds people she knows. In that regard it reminds me of Alas Babylon, a book from years back about life after a nuclear disaster in which people all cooperate and fish and live simply but makes the life sound almost appealing. I wouldn't want to read a book that was all bleak, so I understand why authors do this, but it also annoys me  bit.Bottom line, very good book.

There's a lot going on in this book - possibly too much. The story concept is captivating - Eve is the mother of a teen son with a rare and deadly disease that doesn't allow him to come in contact with UV light so he stays holed up in his room during the day (going to school by computer) but prowling the neighborhood at night. His older sister tends to wild behavior, unknown to her parents, possibly because the family's attention is on the son. The father commuted to DC for work, coming home only on rare weekends - the marriage is rocky. The Eve hits and kills her best friends daughter, and hides the fact because she can't afford to be in prison with no one to take care of her son. The entire neighborhood grieves for the "missing" daughter and a supposed prowler. The trouble I had was that each thread then went off in many directions and there were a lot of characters so the full arc of the story is never realized with the suspense or depth that it could have been. Eve was not believable to me, nor was she likable. Because it's written in first person (which I generally enjoy), the author engages in endless observation and detail.But all in all, it was a good book, although not a page turner or particularly moving.

I hate to give a Laura Lippman novel three stars. I have loved most of her books. She's a talented writer and usually gets things right. This time out, not so. I was never engaged by any of the characters or the central story. I didn't care where Felix went or if he took his girlfriend with him, or even who killed her. I think the problem was the way the book was structured - too many points of view, too many changes past and present, too much jumping around - and all without a compelling enough story to carry it. I didn't like the characters, and didn't find anything that drew me into the story. It seemed disjointed and flat. If you're a big Lippman fan, you'll probably want to give it a try to see for yourself, but if you haven't read her other books, don't start with this one.

I did not read the Oprah edition (didn't even know there was one). I've enjoyed this author's previous books, and I enjoyed this one but not as much as I expected to given her past books and the subject matter. Once I realized it was based on real events I found my interest growing. I did enjoy the peek into life and tensions in the pre-civil war period and the historical perspective. I also enjoyed the story line(s), but I felt the story tended to wander and that detracted from my enjoyment. Worth reading, but don't expect to be wowed.

I got this for when my niece and nephew visit.  They are currently 5 and 2 and tall for their ages but this was still a bit big for my nephew.  Not that it stopped him from having a great time scooting around on it.  My niece, the ever cautious one, enjoyed this but was not ready for the drifting with the hand break.  Once my nephew gets another inch or so on him I think this will be his favorite method of transport.  I love that with the low center of gravity they are less likely to turn over than on the normal tricycles.My sister and I each had one of these when we were little and used them non-stop for several years.  They were so much fun.  It makes me happy that they are still around for the next generation to play with.  As far as assembly goes, it wasn't difficult and we had it together in a short period of time.  I would still do it prior to giving it to the kids because it takes just long enough for impatience to set it.

I’m having a hard time determining how to rate this transformable laptop.  I’m so torn between how close it is to what I have always wanted and how far it is.  So here are some bullet points.What I like:1) The physical design, everything is sleek, light and everything is easy to access.2) I didn’t find myself frustrated with the keyboard.  Although it is smaller than a normal keyboard I had no issues with it.3) The mouse pad was functional and didn’t require a lot of adjusting to actually be workable (my other laptops took a while in settings to get the mouse set up properly when first bought)4) The initial set up wasn’t hard, and didn’t take long at all.5) This is actually a very sturdy device, I expect it would hold up well in a book back or through frequent travel.6) The touch screen is nice, I enjoyed using it for both drawing and app based surfing.What I Don’t like:1) In the initial setup I found myself having to sign up for tons of different things – clouds, storage, sign up for this, blah blah blah.  And much of the time I wasn’t even sure what I was signing up for and why.2) The Windows Operating System that comes on this is garbage.  I don’t know what Microsoft is trying to do here, but I hate it.  On top of this OS eating up just about all of the horsepower in the computer, it certainly isn’t user friendly.3) You can’t upgrade this at all, no bigger HD or added RAM4) I believe it is an OS issue – but it isn’t speedy at all on the internet.  Massive internet cruising is not speedy in comparison to my phone, laptop or crappy work computer.  Since this is the only thing I have that uses the new Windows, there is a good chance that is the issue.5) Limited storage space – I had hoped to use this for artwork, but because of the limited storage capacity (for installing programs etc.) I cannot load my different graphics programs to work with.6) Expect to have to store everything on the cloud, and for that to be slow because of the slow wifi.I really wanted this to be perfect.  Very few things are.  This laptop is much closer to what I have been hunting for.  In fact this might have actually been almost 100% there if it hadn’t been stunted by Windows 10.  I am going to have a more tech savvy friend attempt to install a different OS on it to see if that makes it better without breaking it.

My friends and I got together to play this game - we had just botched an attempt at playing the Myst boardgame (we really should have all fully read the directions before playing that one) and were looking for something to play that didn't require us to spend hours going through the instructions.  We pulled this out and skimmed the directions like normal.I have only seen a few episodes of the show, two of the people we were playing with had never seen it at all, and the others were die hard fans.  Having not seen the show didn't seem to effect the enjoyability of this game.  Once we got going and got the hang of it, this was a lot of fun.  We were all different biker gangs competing for territory, guns, drugs etc to see who could end up with the most money at the end of the game.  On one hand it reminded me a bit of Risk, where you are trying to get the most usable territories and hold them so that you can expand from a strong base.  However there is a lot of negotiation and tactics involved.  Our group had a great time playing and we will certainly play again in the future.  Because of the imaginary violence, drugs and other adult things, I wouldn't advise playing this with your children.

This thing is awesome!  How awesome?  I made my coffee in the morning and then forgot it on the counter at home when I left for work.  At lunch I ran home to let the dogs out and grabbed the coffee to pour it out - when I opened it the coffee was still warm enough to be consumable.  I also like that it is dishwasher safe and easy to clean not only the inside, but also all of the lid where you would put your mouth to drink out of.  I plan on purchasing a second one of these because I like it so much more than the other mugs I have been using.

This review may sound a bit gross – you have been warned.So, one of my dogs was nice enough to get into the garbage the other day.  What I know was consumed involved eggshells, coffee grounds, moldy cheese and half of a Wendy’s black bean burger.  Other items may have also been involved.  I know these items for sure because they were not salvaged from the mess until approximately 12 hours later when they reappeared out of my dog in the middle of the night all over the carpeting.  Now don’t worry, they came out in the same direction they went in.  Still, now I had percolated coffee grounds, eggshells, bile and moldy cheese saturating the carpeting.I admit that with it being 3am on a work night I did a minimal clean up job and went back to sleep.The following day I got out the carpet cleaner and used platinum pure for pets that Amazon had sent me.  I was surprised that it completely extricated everything from the carpet.  I had expected to still have some discoloration from the coffee/bile combo, but it was 100% gone.  Two thumbs up to this product for saving my deposit.  The scent of the cleaner was nice without being overpowering and the carpet was left very fresh and clean.  After drying the carpet still looked good.  I would definitely purchase this in the future.

This thing is adorable.  Who doesn't love the idea of Darth Tater?!?!  My sister and I had Mr. Potato head toys when we were little, and they still resurface at my parent's house for the next generation to play with.  What made me happy about this is that Darth Tater is the same high quality long lasting make as the Potato heads of my childhood.  With all of the current toys seeming like they were built to break, it is nice to come across a toy that is built to last.  This also comes with a nice sturdy carrying case to keep all of Darth Tater's things together when not in use.  I highly recommend for potato head and Star Wars fans.

So I'm not a male, but I figure a razor is a razor right?  And the last three times I've gone to the store I've accidentally purchased the same wrong razors that I can't stand.  So I figured that these couldn't be any worse than my accidentally made stockpile of crap razors.These are neither the best nor worst razors I've used - they aren't as sharp as some of the other razors I have tried but they also weren't as uncomfortable to try to maneuver around certain areas as the crap razors I have.  I did notice that they don't sell refill blades (at least not yet) so you will be throwing away the handle after every use... but wait, some of the female razor heads do fit on this handle.  So if you don't mind orange, grey and pink, you can refill them.If you find these at a good price I wouldn't hesitate to get them, unless you have sensitive skin and are a guy.  I'm told that men need sharper razors to keep from getting red bumps, so these may not work all that well for you unless you have skin like leather.  For the ladies doing you legs, these are fine.

Our Animal Hospital has roughly 25 employees, countless clients - and a single bathroom that we all share.  Out of courtesy it is understood that if you suffer from gastrointestinal distress - you are not to come into work that day to prevent the suffering of others.  There is nothing we can do however to keep our clients from bombing our bathroom.  We have filled the bathroom with various air-fresheners, scented candles and the like but we still have to struggle at times to keep the odor down.  Enter Poo-Pourri: you are supposed to spritz this into the water once before making a nasty.  Our staff has this down pat and thinks that a miracle has occurred.  Unfortunately well meaning clients use it as an air-freshener and spritz multiple times into the air.  This can cause a cloud of scent that could quickly overtake you.  The receptionists who are label maker junkies have now created new instructions and relabeled it "1 pump in water before you make a 2." this seems to have helped client compliance.This stuff is amazing - we have far less stress on the staff from having to put up with smells that did not issue from our patients.  Thank you poo-pourri!

This is another huge men’s watch.  It is very heavy and attractive, but you have to be the kind of guy who likes big oversized jewelry.  I personally would not consider this look to be a professional or dress watch.  It’s more of a sports watch or casual watch.It says that it is water resistant and appears to be okay for wearing it in the shower or a pool.Sizing this thing (along with it's gold colored counterpart) was a nightmare, I don’t know if that is because of the thickness of the band or what, but I ended up just giving up and paying the ten dollars at a jeweler. Once it was properly sized he was able to wear it comfortably but he did mention that the weight took a bit to get used to.At first we thought that the other dials on the watch were decorative only but we realized that the buttons were just so hard to push that they weren't triggering the dials to do what they were supposed to.  I hope that this will loosen up over time so that they can actually be used.

This is a huge men’s watch.  It is very heavy and attractive, but you have to be the kind of guy who likes big oversized jewelry.  I personally would not consider this look to be a professional or dress watch.  It’s more of a sports watch or casual watch.  It says that it is water resistant but beyond wearing it in the shower or a pool, I personally wouldn’t take it snorkeling or SCUBA diving.Sizing this thing was a nightmare, I don’t know if that is because of the thickness of the band or what, but I ended up just giving up and paying the ten dollars at a jeweler. Once it was properly sized he was able to wear it comfortably but he did mention that the weight took a bit to get used to.  The smaller dials were hard for him to see and he admitted that he would probably never use the stop watch part, though we did play around with it. The buttons were hard for him to hold down (he’s a bit arthritic) to use the smaller dials.  Once we had everything set up and the watch sized, he was happy with it.  If you like a large watch this is a good deal for the current price.

My nephew enjoys this - it's essentially a boat, with a shark face, and two characters who ride on it and sword-fight.  The boat rolls around and the movement causes the shark mouth to open and close, and if the characters are plugged into their little holes on the deck of the boat - they sword-fight.This is where it gets rough.  Getting the character's pegs into the holes in the boat can be a challenge for a parent, making it extremely difficult for a little one to do on their own.  So the blessing you get as a parent - when you pull this out of the box and discover that it is already assembled, doesn't need batteries, and doesn't sing - is negated by the fact that you will have to keep popping these little characters back into the holes because your tiny can't do it on their own.My nephew is younger and was very very excited to just push the shark boat around, with or without the figures.  My niece however wanted the figures on and off about every 30 seconds.  The toy is fairly sturdy and other than the swords that can break/be lost/swallowed - this should be around long after the kids have outgrown it.

This is not a game you can get out of the box and get right into playing. I opened the box and was surprised at how big the box was to have so little stuff in it.  After starting to read the directions I realized that it is to hold all of the expansions that you can purchase as well.  Apparently there are quite a few.  So having no idea how to play this game, I sat down and started reading.  There is a lot of reading and unless you have played before, I suggest reading (and maybe rereading) all of it because it's fairly complex.  I had hoped to play a single player game to get the feel of it prior to bringing friends in on it - I didn't realize that this is also a LONG game.  You will want to dedicate a table to it - I would not set it up on the kitchen table if you plan on having dinner there in the next 5 hours or so.  Also this game builds from one round to the next so you will want to either make up your own character sheets on paper, or print the pre-made ones off of their website.Basically you pick a hero, and you make a hero deck for him.  Then you set up the Adventure and Adventure Path - then each of the locations has it's own deck.  Somewhere in the location decks is the big bad guy you are trying to get.  You travel around closing out the locations to find and trap the bad guy.  Along the way you acquire powers, weapons, and other assorted gear.  This is not a simple game by any stretch of the imagination.The artwork on the cards is good - though much of the print is very small and some of the cards seem cluttered.  I hate that they want you to write on the character cards - so I decided to do that on separate paper rather than write on them.  Also I don't like that there are so many expansions to keep the game going with your same character.  But, as I said this is a fun but complex game.After two days of trying to figure out why I wasn't understanding the directions when it came to application - I discovered that my box actually came without at least one stack of necessary cards.  I have contacted customer service in regards to this (I could not locate a phone number for Piazo but did find an email address of a person titled "customer service") I will update this review to let you know how customer service handles the request.***UPDATE***So the Piazo Customer service lady was super prompt, within 24 hours she had responded back to me.  She told me to ask Amazon to replace it, and if for some reason they wouldn't to let her know.  So I emailed Amazon and within 2 days had my replacement.  It was about a week later we finally had a gaming night so we were able to actually play the game.  While it was fun - the game is VERY rules heavy.  There is a lot of complexity and different things that were not clear so we made up our own house rules and wrote them down.  We ended up having a great time playing the game that night, but I don't see that it has the re-playability of a game like Munchkin or Castle Panic.  I am glad I have it, we had a great time, but I don't know that I would spend the money to re-buy it if it disappeared.  Still the artwork is good and they clearly put a lot of thought into the game.  I just felt that the complexity ended up causing us to spend more time trying to figure out what we were supposed to do than just enjoying the game.

This is a silly little book with very entertaining fun art that the little ones will love.  The poor Princess wants one thing and ends up with another - a chubby little pony with a habit of stinking up the place.  It's silly and fun, though it isn't one of my niece's favorite books, it's a decent selection to add to her collection. Some other people had issues with the spitballs and the gassy pony - I didn't because it was all done in a lighthearted way.  And anything that keeps kids wanting to read or be read to is great in my book.

This is a very healthy food to feed your pets if they need to be on a fish based diet.  In case your pets have never been on a fish based diet before I will tell you that this bag does smell strongly of fish.  I have never had any issues with my dogs smelling bad after eating a fish based food - but one of my co-workers who has a great dane said that it made her breath unbearably fishy so he had to switch her to a different protein.Wellness is a very expensive brand of food that many Veterinarians I have worked with highly recommend.  This specific food is no different.  I personally don't care for the smell of the food and my dogs don't have any allergies so I don't need to keep them on it.  I will most likely keep them on a Duck or Bison meal, but should they require the whitefish - this would be one of the frontrunners.  The protein content is appropriate for dogs and the other ingredients are also very good.The full ingredient list (from their website - which did match the bag)Whitefish, Herring Meal, Salmon Meal, Menhaden Fish Meal, Peas, Potatoes, Dried Ground Potatoes, Canola Oil (preserved with Mixed Tocopherols), Pea Fiber, Tomato Pomace, Natural Fish Flavor, Ground Flaxseed, Spinach, Vitamin E Supplement, Broccoli, Carrots, Choline Chloride, Parsley, Apples, Blueberries, Kale, Sweet Potatoes, Taurine, Mixed Tocopherols added to preserve freshness, Zinc Proteinate, Zinc Sulfate, Glucosamine Hydrochloride, Chondroitin Sulfate, Calcium Carbonate, Niacin, Ferrous Sulfate, Iron Proteinate, Beta-Carotene, Vitamin A Supplement, Copper Sulfate, Thiamine Mononitrate, Copper Proteinate, Manganese Proteinate, Manganese Sulfate, d-Calcium Pantothenate, Sodium Selenite, Pyridoxine Hydrochloride, Riboflavin, Chicory Root Extract, Yucca Schidigera Extract, Vitamin D3 Supplement, Biotin, Calcium Iodate, Vitamin B12 Supplement, Folic Acid, Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C), Dried Lactobacillus plantarum Fermentation Product, Dried Enterococcus faecium Fermentation Product, Dried Lactobacillus casei Fermentation Product, Dried Lactobacillus acidophilus Fermentation Product, Rosemary Extract, Green Tea Extract, Spearmint Extract.This is a naturally preserved product.And the Guaranteed AnalysisCrude Protein  Not less than  34.00%Crude Fat  Not less than  16.00%Crude Fiber  Not more than  7.00%Moisture  Not more than  10.00%Calcium  Not more than  2.10%Phosphorus  Not more than  1.45%Vitamin E  Not less than  400 IU/kgOmega 6 Fatty Acids*  Not less than  2.00%Omega 3 Fatty Acids*  Not less than  0.80%Glucosamine*  Not less than  250 mg/kgChondroitin Sulfate*  Not less than  200 mg/kgBeta-Carotene*  Not less than  5 mg/kgTotal Lactic Acid Microorganisms*  Not less than  80,000,000 CFU/lbSo you will notice that the Protein content is higher than most over the counter dog foods - if you have any concerns please contact your Veterinarian and find out the appropriate calorie intake and protein % for your specific pet.  As it stands, if you can tolerate the fishy smell - I recommend this product.

I purchased her to use in our pathfinder campaign where I play a female Half Drow Rogue Sniper.  I thought I would like her more than I do - First I don't paint my mini's so I can't comment on how easy or hard she is to paint, or how well she holds paint.  I do use them for gaming though, and she came with a lot of bits and pieces that had to be removed in order for her to look halfway decent.  The Bow is very fragile so transporting her requires putting her in a small box to get her to and from games.  What I didn't care for is that aesthetically her face looks very odd.  I like the body and the bow but it's almost like the face is a mask with odd proportions.  Still she works for the campaign and didn't cost a ridiculous amount.

Beautiful socks! They fit me well and are a lot of fun to wear.  The only negative I can say is that the leg portion of the sock is very thick, but the foot portion (were most of the wear occurs) is not as thick and they are already starting to show a little wear and get thin spots.

I love these socks, they crack me up, are colorful and seem to be well made enough to last for a while. They are thicker than I expected which is a good thing.  The profanity is well hidden under the shoe so as long as you're shoes are on, no one knows your mantra for the day.  I will be buying more of these.

I love these socks, they crack me up, are colorful and seem to be well made enough to last for a while. They are thicker than I expected which is a good thing.  The profanity is well hidden under the shoe so as long as you're shoes are on, no one knows your mantra for the day.  I will be buying more of these.

I purchased this to use for our Pathfinder campaign as my Teifling Rakshasa-born Ranger who happens to have a tiger as her animal companion.  I thought this would be perfect as her main weapon is a bow.  From looking at the picture I assumed that these were on the same base - they are not.  Instead they are two separate figures (which works out better when playing).  The problems I have is that they both require a lot of work that I was hoping not to do in order to be usable.  I don't paint my minis and I don't have any tools for messing around with them.  The tiger (or lion or whatever) has a large metal chunk hanging off the bottom making it impossible to keep him standing.  It is too large to use a scalpel to remove and I don't think a kitchen knife would work either because of the thickness.  I'll have to talk to the guys at the game shop and find out how to make him stand up.  Now the actual ranger - she has lots of extra nibbly bits that I think I can remove with the scalpel.  I prefer to just get these things out of the box and play with them, but this is the first time since the 90's that I have bought new minis, and I could have either forgotten all the work they took - or just gotten lucky back then.  Either way, it would have been nice for the two of them to at least stand up out of the box.

I purchased this from a local gaming shop to use in our Pathfinder Campaign as my Tiefling (Rakshasa-born) Ranger.  I was looking for a tough female with a bow, and this fit the bill.  I don't paint my minis (not yet at least, I'm too afraid I will ruin them) so I can't speak to how easy she would be to pain or how well the paint sticks.  What I can say is that she didn't require any trimming out of the box, stands on her own and unfortunately the long lower end of her bow is warped out so that it appears more like a staff than a bow.  I haven't been able to get it to bend back properly, though I'm considering putting her in some boiling water for a while and then trying to reshape it.  On the whole I spent two dollars at the game store to get this figure and am quite happy with my purchase

Wellness always makes very high quality and very pricy food.  I was sent a VERY small bag of this food to try.  I didn't know 2lbs bags were even a thing.  When I opened it, I realized that this is a soft kibble.  It looks like little brown Slim Jim pieces and the consistency seems like play-dough. I mixed a bit of this in with my boy's regular food.  They seemed very excited and dug through their food picking this soft kibble out and eating it first. After skimming the ingredients I determined that much like the other Wellness band foods, this appears to be made of high quality ingredients.  Unless your dog has bad teeth, I am not sure why you would feed a soft food.  I certainly wouldn't pay extra for a soft food because - unlike cats- dogs generally do get dental benefit from eating dry food. I don't think I would feed this regularly to my boys (they are both 50lbs dogs so it would be expensive as well) but with the resealable bag - I have been using this bag as a giant bag of training treats.  This has been very successful because they like it, it's healthy, it's already in small pieces and although it is a little greasy feeling, it wasn't so bad that I wouldn't put it in my pocket.So I wouldn't buy this as a regular food for my pets (unless there was a medical reason for them to have a soft kibble) but I might buy the small bags of this food to keep using as training treats.

I don't know how to review perfumes - I work in an animal hospital, so smells are categorized as: Good, Bad, Don't buy that again, Covers Bad smells well, Needs Cleaning ASAP, and Needs a Doctor ASAP.  Perfumes don't fit well into those categories.  People are able to say that some of them are woody or list different scents within a perfume - I am not that person.I do like the scent of this perfume, it isn't overpowering and it seems to last all day.  It also isn't overly childish smelling, nor does it smell like "little old lady."  What I don't like is that you can't get the spritzer to do just a little bit - quite a bit comes out when you spritz it, much more than I want.So I really like the smell of the perfume, and I'm not a big fan of the volume that the spritzer puts out.

These are training treats - so they are small cylindrical treats that are to be given while training.  These had a very strong smokey odor and were surprisingly greasy feeling.  My dogs enjoyed them, but I had an issue with them.  If I am out working on training my dog to do something - I put the treats in my pocket.  These were too greasy to keep in your pocket and your hands and clothes stink of fake smoke flavoring once you are done with them.  I think for now I will stick with the dryer, easily breakable treats for training.  These would be fine to use in the house if you are just dolling out treats at random.

I received one of each of the flavors - and promptly placed them on the snack table at work.  Two days later I asked the girls what they thought. Our clinic has about 20 employees and almost all had tried these, some on graham crackers, some on fruit, some on cookies, and some just would grab a spoonful on the run.  I asked what they each thought of it - there was not a negative statement made.  The interesting thing is that they each had strong favorites though they weren't the same.  Most of them seemed to prefer the Speculoos, though both Cookies & Cream and Graham cracker had their fans as well.  I personally preferred Cookies & Cream, though I found all of them to be tasty.  I personally prefer the nutellas as a spread (which I put on pancakes) these would not replace that in my kitchen.  But as a fun little extra these would be great for parties.

I have an Acer computer without many bells and whistles on it.  It does have (much to my dismay) Windows 8.  Apparently VideoStudio Ultimate X8 does not like Windows 8.  Three crashes during installation made me almost give up.  Finally I managed to get it installed with a lot of help from the internet and when I opened the program it looked fine.  Very much like the other programs I have used - top right is the display of the video you are creating, top left are the tools, center is series of layers you can add - but then it crashed.  I rebooted the computer and started it up again - I could see the dashboard and - crash.From the fleeting view I saw of this program, it appears to have the same setup as all of the others - I cannot however, get it to work on Windows 8 without crashing so I cannot attest to the speed, tools etc.

The look of this case is great - very sleek and professional with it's classy grey leather appearance.  The case fits the phone well however the sides are flush with the face of the phone.  This means that there is protection for the sides and back of the phone, but the face is left unprotected.  Granted it did come with an adhesive screen protector - but still, I minor lip on the edge of the case would have made everyone feel a little safer about the face.Still, it is a very attractive case.

My dogs are the destroyer of toys - especially squeeky ones. I bought two of these and it has now been several months and they are both still intact.  My younger dog loves these - he prances around with his head held high squeeking the ball and hurling it down the staircase with gusto.  I highly recommend these to others who want to buy toys for their dogs but don't want to have to replace them daily.

I bought this as a gift for a friend who is an avid bird fanatic - she has an iPhone 4S and at first it appeared that this was made for the 5 and would not fit her phone. Then we discovered the little inserts that made it fit perfectly.  She has since then been able to take some amazing pictures of the birds that she sees.  She couldn't be happier.

I had to return this watch - unfortunately it is so large and bulky that you have to have very large arms for it to look right.  It was larger than the watch I had purchased for my boyfriend.  On top of this it felt cheaply made - perhaps the one I received was a knock-off? I generally go with Invicta watches so this was my first purchase of this brand and I was not impressed.  It certainly wouldn't have held up for very long.

I have used Pantene products on and off for several years.  I always enjoy the smell of their products - and this conditioner is no different.  In fact I couldn't see what was different between this and most of the other pantene products, they are all nice smelling, excellent for dry hair but leave a bit of a film on the hair that can build up over time so I swap out products every bottle.  As far as color preserve I would assume that would be more important in your shampoo than your conditioner because the shampoo is the one that can strip the color from your hair.  If you enjoy the Pantene line and have colored hair, this should be right up your alley.

I'm not sure what I was thinking when I picked this - I guess mainly it was out of curiosity.  I have an iPhone 5c, an iPod and an iPad - I figured there must be a good use for a thing like this. I wasn't sure what I was expecting - but this certainly wasn't it.  What came out of the box was a little square that is slightly smaller than a deck of cards.  After some tugging I discovered that there are two cords that wrap neatly around the box so that they stash away completely.  The problem with this is that the cords are also only 4 inches and 1 inch long - so you don't have a lot of play with this thing. Also the "phone stand" took me forever to get to pop out - it took two hands and a ton of wiggling to make it happen.  I thought I was going to break it to make it come out.So once I got that all figured out I charged it up - that happened very quickly.  Then I plugged in my phone and nothing happened.  After reading the very sparse instructions I discovered that I have to download an app on all of the different electronics I want to hook to it.  The app was free and downloaded quickly.  So I hooked up my iPad and in less then a minute 89 pictures were transferred. I was not able to download any music or audiobooks from the iPad to the LINK. So I hooked up my iPhone and quickly backed up 400 pictures and 10 videos (2-3 minutes and it was done) but again, that was the only option to go from the phone to the LINK.When hooked up to my computer I was able to charge the LINK from the computer and drag and drop files onto the LINK most of which I was able to transfer and then locate on my iPhone rather easily.  I had more trouble with the music.  The reality is that I can't think of what I would use this for other than possibly as a portable charger when I cannot get to an outlet.  I could just as easily back all of the same things up to the laptop I already have and not pay extra money for this device.  I guess I am just not the target market for this item.

I like the Natural Balance brand of dog foods, for an over the counter food they seem to have high quality and an attention to ingredients  - I have never used any of the "rolls" of food from any brand so I wasn't quite sure what to expect when these arrived.  Now I wish I had been recording it on my camera.  I was sitting on my bed opening the mail and pulled this roll of food out of the envelope it arrived in.  My fat dog quickly hopped onto the bed, grabbed the roll and ran off.  I chased him down and retrieved the roll.  I went back to the bed to continue opening the mail.  I set the roll next to me and watched out of the corner of my eye as my fat dog crept back into the room and comically grabbed the loop hanging off the end of the roll - slowly pulling it out from under my leg and trying to creep off with it.  I grabbed the roll and took it back.  He then began making all kinds of howling protests.  At this point I was laughing because he would never have seen one of these before - I couldn't smell any odor coming off of it, but he was convinced that it was for him.  I hadn't planned on giving him any of this - mainly because he is on a diet to lose weight.  My other dog needs to gain weight so I had planned on adding this to his food for the extra calories and to encourage him to remember to eat.Yes I work in Vet med, and yes I know better - but within 30 minutes of this being in my house I ventured downstairs to let them sample it.  Mainly because it had occurred to me that I would not be allowed to sleep until my fat dog had received at least one bite.  When I opened it I was a bit surprised - I had been expecting it to be more of a paste or a pate - instead it was more like a giant crumbly slim jim.  I was ill prepared for this and ended up with dry meaty crumbles all over my hands and counter top from attempting to cut it into one small taste for the fat dog, and a good sized portion for my skinny dog.  After doling out their portions - they both were thrilled.  This must be some good tasting stuff.  Even my skinny dog ate this and then continued on to finish the rest of the kibble that he had left in his bowl for the whole day.Health wise, I could see this being a very beneficial way to feed dogs with bad teeth who are not surgery candidates.  Or dogs who are missing a large number of teeth.  I could also see using this as a special added on treat or to entice picky eaters to consume more.  I probably wouldn't use this as an only food, though it appears to be formulated to do so.  I like having my dogs on dry kibble for their teeth. I am glad I tried it, and down the road if it ever fits into the needs my dogs have for feeding; I would not hesitate to purchase it.  Right now we don't have a need for it apart from as a treat.

The four stars for this are only because this is a paperback version of what should be a hardback only book.  I have owned this since I bought at beat up copy from a comic book store back in the 90's when I was in high school.  I spent countless hours staring at the artwork in this book.  I enjoy art but only the paintings of Yerka have fascinated me to this level. If I could afford it, I would have his artwork hanging in my house.  I could only dream of creating visuals as stunning as some of the ones in this book.  Each has such a feeling to it, and evokes such a sadness and wonder at the same time that I almost can't describe it.  Some day I will find a more comprehensive version of this book and it will be mine.  And if I win the lottery I will buy some of his actual work.

I have one dog who loves to eat, and one who only does it to survive.  I didn’t put this food in their bowls, instead using it in their puzzle ball, and other smart dog treat dispensers.  It was quite a hit – both dogs LOVED this food as a treat, and with it being very healthy, I didn’t mind giving it to them.Neither of my dogs has a food allergy, but I attempt to give them healthy yet inexpensive food.  I liked the ingredients and the caloric count in this food, and I liked that they thought it was good.  I didn’t care for the price.  I work at a veterinary hospital and this food is more expensive than the prescription diets we sell. If this food was available at a slightly lower price point – I might consider making the switch for my guys.  As it is I will probably keep them on their current food and use this for the puzzle ball.If you have a dog with a food allergy, I would consider this food in your food trials.Per the company website and the info on the bag:Ingredient Listing/Guaranteed AnalysisPotatoes, Duck Meal, Duck, Canola Oil (preserved with natural mixed tocopherols), Potato Protein, Potato Fiber, Natural Flavor, Dicalcium Phosphate, Salt, Salmon Oil (a source of DHA), Calcium Carbonate, Flaxseed, Potassium Chloride, Choline Chloride, Taurine, Natural Mixed Tocopherols, L-Carnitine, Yucca Schidigera Extract, Vitamin E Supplement, Iron Proteinate, Zinc Proteinate, Copper Proteinate, Ferrous Sulfate, Zinc Sulfate, Copper Sulfate, Potassium Iodide, Thiamine Mononitrate (Vitamin B-1), Manganese Proteinate, Manganous Oxide, Ascorbic Acid, Vitamin A Supplement, Biotin, Niacin, Calcium Pantothenate, Manganese Sulfate, Sodium Selenite, Pyridoxine Hydrochloride (Vitamin B-6), Vitamin B-12 Supplement, Riboflavin (Vitamin B-2), Vitamin D-3 Supplement, Folic Acid.Guaranteed AnalysisCrude Protein 21.0% minimumCrude Fat 10.0% minimumCrude Fiber 3.0% maximumMoisture 10.0% maximumCalcium 1.0% minimumPhosphorus 0.8% minimumDocosahexaenoic Acid (DHA)* 0.01% minimumOmega-6 Fatty Acids* 1.7% minimumOmega-3 Fatty Acids* 0.5% minimumMetabolizable energy 3435 kcal/kg, 375 kcal/8 oz cup (calculated).

One of my two dogs has ballooned up in the weight category after starting his anti-seizure medication.  We are now on a strict weight loss diet.  My other dog is still in training, so we have to use a lot of treats to keep him on the right path.  Because I’m not a jerk, we have been trying to make sure that the fat dog feels that he is getting treats too.  The Goofball gets a treat; the fat dog gets a carrot.  So when these arrived, I wanted to check on the ingredients and calories to see if it was an option for fatty to eat as well.  I may have overlooked it, or it could be under the amazon sticker that I couldn’t get off very well – but I couldn’t find the calories on the bag.  So I went to the website:Metabolizable energy 3570 kcal/kg, 11 kcal/treat (calculated).Chicken, Peas, Vegetable Glycerin, Garbanzo Beans, Cane Molasses, Gelatin, Chicken Fat (preserved with mixed tocopherols and citric acid), Natural Flavor, Dried Cultured Skim Milk.Guaranteed AnalysisCrude Protein 14.0% minimumCrude Fat 7.0% minimumCrude Fiber 5.0% maximumMoisture 25.0% maximumI went ahead and gave them to both dogs.  They were thrilled.  Apparently these are quite tasty.  I liked that they were a good size and could easily be broken into smaller portions for training versus just giving a whole one as a treat.  I also liked the limited ingredients and that these had an odor (one of my dogs is big on food with a strong odor) but it wasn’t an appalling odor.  I had no problem putting a couple in my pocket for a trip to the dog park – without any concern that the stink would permeate my coat.I recommend these for healthy treats for happy dogs.

I generally wear Bare Minerals eye shadows that I apply with a brush – but I always love trying new things.  I hadn’t used a palette in years so I was excited to see how this would work.The colors are quite complimentary to each other so the palette works well.  The set came with instructions on how and where to apply each of the colors to achieve the pictured effect.  This did not work for me.  First of all, these are not a cream as it implies – these are instead a moisturized powder.  The applicator included was essentially worthless.  I do like the double sponge applicator but this one was not worth including.  I used my fingers and will most likely use my brushes going forward.  Because of the strange moisturized texture of the powder – it all sort of mashed together when applying.  Attempting to get the defined color on the picture was all but impossible.  Part of me wanted to make one of those “Nailed it” pictures for my Facebook (The ones of what the professionals did and then my pitiful attempt next to it).  I still managed to get a fairly good look going with it, though once applied the colors were far lighter than I expected.  The powder looked good, it didn’t chunk or flake, or crease up when I opened my eyes.So I went to work – and by lunch all that was left was my eyeliner.  I ended up having to reapply every few hours.  The “Long lasting” part didn’t really hold up for me.  The good thing is that the case seals very well. You don’t have to worry about bringing it with you and the thing popping open in your purse.I liked the simplicity of the great colors all matched together in a palette.  I didn’t like the included applicator or how quickly the makeup was gone.  If I had a young daughter starting to get into makeup, this would be something I might get her – but I will go back to my regular routine.

I grew up in the 80’s and 90’s – but I did not use VS shampoo or conditioner, and neither did my mom.  So I have no strong memories of this scent that many others do.  The scent actually reminds me of Luden’s cherry cough drops.  It is an attractive candy like scent that is not overly strong.  I was a little confused as to why the main selling point of this product seems to be the scent rather then what it does for your hair.  This seems to be focused on just your regular daily wash and condition; if you have needs beyond that you may want to look into their other products.  I have been using this for about a week.  I think it is (at this point in time) well priced for a daily conditioner and will work well for people who don’t need special conditioner (dry or oily hair.)  I personally have dry hair so I will most likely go back to my heavy moisturizing conditioners, but wouldn’t think twice about using this if my hair decided that it didn’t need the more expensive conditioner.

I have never played Castle Panic, and hadn't played Munchkin in years.  This game is a blending of the two.  The people I played with had never even heard of those games.  It took us a while to work through the rules, I would definitely say that as a group you have to work through learning how to play. Then it becomes much more fun.  The objective is to either individually or cooperatively keep the castle from being overtaken by monsters while still coming out top munchkin.  It was highly enjoyable once we figured out what we were doing. This is not a 15 minute game, expect to spend some time playing.  I also wouldn't get it for kids under 10... they would be able to play but I don't know that they would really enjoy the nuances of the game.As we play more I will add to the review.  As the game is, if you have a group of people for a game night - I recommend this game.

My Niece loves this cute little tea set - mainly because of the colors.  You can't actually add tea to this set as the cups have holes in them and the teapot doesn't open. The teapot does however - sing and talk and make sounds which you can change by the switch on the bottom of the teapot. This alters the level of the songs and sounds that it makes from 6month old up to 18month+.  My niece is 4 and thus older than the recommended age for this play set, but she enjoys it none the less because it is cute and holds up well to her little brother.  Recommended for the little ones who enjoy tea-parties and have parents who can tolerate singing teapots.

Let me start by saying, this is the only game we have for the LeapTV system, so some of the technical complaints may actually be the system and not the game.I got this for my 4 year old niece and 1 year old nephew.My niece enjoyed the game, her mom and dad like that the game is educational and requires her to move around (but not run).  They can interact with her by offering guidance, watching her play and coaching her.  She is 4 and was able to figure out how to use it on her own.  There were some software issues but in the end she had a great time playing.Pros:- other than long loading times, adults were the only ones to notice the cons :)- she was able to figure out what to do and how to do it, which made her very happy- the audio was clear and had simple easy instructions- the games had educational components to them - matching shapes and colors, sorting things by what they do etc.- there was no way for her to lose, which kept her from getting frustrated (and she is easily frustrated)- somewhat active, requires standing and moving but not jumping or running.Cons:- EXTREMELY long loading screens whenever you select something, at one point my niece thought she had broken it because it took so long to load- Video quality isn't great, my brother-in-law is guessing about 10-15 frames per second.- At times it was slow and laggy, often stuttering.- The first time they launched the game, the menus weren't there so they had to exit and start over.My Niece really enjoys this game.  Because of the issues we encountered, I would wait until you can find it for 10-20 dollars which is in our mind, closer to the actual value of the game.  For the little ones it can be a great time shared with the family, provided the adults can stand to wait through the excessive load times.

The Webber 6479 grill press does just what it should.  Solid with good heft, it absorbs a lot of heat.  Paired with a 12” skillet, this press makes dandy panini sandwiches without adding yet another appliance to your kitchen.Simple, good results, less clutter.  Five stars.

If you need a way to get your retriever to the dog park, but still have the back seat of your car hospitable for humans, this is the answer.This cover is the best solution because it coves the entire seat, floor and front seat backs.  The panel across the front seat backs creates a barrier that discourages your dog from passing between the seats to join you in the front.Installation takes a couple minutes and basically consists of attaching the built-in straps with quick release buckles to the four outer head rests on your car.  Small puffy tags sewn to the back of the cover can be stuffed between the backseat cushion and backrest to keep the cover on the seat instead of just hammocking between the front and back head rests.  Another set of tags attach with snaps to the sides of the cover.  Stuffing these between the rear seat back edges keep the cover from drooping at the sides.  There are even velcro straps to attach to the rear seat belts.  I’ve never needed those, but they stay out of your way if they aren’t needed.There are also pass-troughs for the rear seat belt buckles, if your dog will be sharing the back seat with a human friend.  These pass-throughs seal completely shut with velcro when not in use.Another nice touch is the side flaps that fall down the sides of the rear seat cushion.  When it comes to dog hair, more coverage is always better.I do have a couple gripes.  The cover is advertised as machine washable, but a large tag sewn on the cover states it should be cleaned with a damp sponge only.  Formosa confirms these covers are washable and I have washed mine three or four times with no ill effects.  The plastic buckles make a racket in the dryer, but cause no harm.The cover is quilted fabric that looks durable, but is a loose enough weave that dog hair sews itself in easily.  Some of this hair comes out when the cover is washed, but most stay.  This cover may keep your car looking nice, but the cover itself will get ugly.  While this cover has a plastic backing, the quilting goes straight though the backing, so thin liquids—like pee—may seep though in small amounts.  I would expect it to hold vomit or poo completely off the upholstery.My cover developed a small flaw.  I emailed Formosa and they responded the next day and solved my problem.  It seems like this company would like to build a happy customer base.This cover has helped me a lot.  I have a new car.  My old seat cover helped keep hair off the seats, but my dog often moved it out of place, creating a mess.  Even when it was in place, it did nothing to prevent hair on the front seat seat backs and armrests when my dog would stick his head between the front seats.  I bought this cover after I spent a day trying to get hair out of my back seat.  Now my seats and floor are free of hair and dog smells can be taken out and thrown in the washing machine.Finally, my dog likes it.  When he sees me installing it, he gets excited that he gets to go somewhere.

The Esky series coolers are Coleman’s entry into the super cooler market.  Several companies make super coolers, but Yeti is the best known brand.  Coleman has followed the formula almost exactly.  2” or more insulation, recessed rubber latches, gasket in the lid, tie down points, rope handles, even a Bear Resistant Certification from the Interagency Grizzly Bear Committee.But the Esky has a few tricks of its own.  It has a textured exterior to hide wear and scratches.  The Esky comes with a cutting board that stashes under the lid.  That cutting board and the walls of the cooler have a antimicrobial coating.  The Esky does not have molded in handles.  Where they would be, you’ll find bottle openers.  The Esky’s drain is all plastic, but seems strong and is fully recessed.Yeti offers a 5 year warranty on its coolers, so Coleman warrants the Esky for 6 years.  And, of course, they are made in the U.S.A.Coleman rates the Esky 55 as being able to retain ice for 6.83 days.  How well any super cooler will retain ice depends more on how well you pre-chill both the cooler and the contents, and how you pack it.  The Esky should certainly perform as well as the best of the super coolers with it’s 2” side insulation and 2.5” top and bottom insulation and really good gasket design.Do you need a super cooler?While at first glance it seems like super coolers like the Esky are just stronger, better built coolers with better insulating properties, they really are a different breed of cooler meant for a different uses.To get the really long ice retention from a super cooler, you must first pre-chill the cooler.  That means sacrificing a bag of ice or two to the cooler the day before you intend to pack it.  If you just toss some beers and a couple bags of ice into a super cooler and a regular cooler, you’ll find the regular cooler will keep ice longer than the super cooler.  Why?  Because the super cooler has so much insulation that needs to be cooled down before it starts retaining ice.  If you pre chilled the coolers then checked them five days after packing them, it’d be a different story.Super coolers are better built, but they’re heavier too.  The Esky 55 weighs close to 35 pounds!  Also, you won’t find wheels and telescoping handles on a super cooler.  Luggage wheels aren’t grizzly proof.So if you want to want to stop at the Quickie Mart and get some pop and ice on the way to a day trip to the lake, use a regular cooler.  If you’re staring down a hurricane and need to be ready for a week-long power outage, use a super cooler.

My first dog was wild for his Greenies, and insisted on having one everyday.  My current dog likes these Freshmint Greenies very much and likes taking one to his favorite spot and chewing it up at his leisure.  The trouble with Greenies, then and now has always been the high price.  This pack is $18 as I write this.  With 12 regular size treats in a pack, that’s $1.50 per treat.  Give one treat per day and that’s $45/month for dog treats.I can’t say that I find much improvement in my dog’s breath or teeth after chewing Greenies regularly, so I consider these as just a treat for my pup.  I love my dog, but my budget these days dictates that Greenies are an occasional treat in my house, not a daily one.

The variety I’m reviewing is Smoky Applewood BBQ Chicken with Bacon.  This skillet sauce is just BBQ sauce.  While the prep is easy and the results OK, I really can’t tell any difference between this and a (much cheaper) bottle of BBQ sauce.The sauce is thinner than what you’d expect from a bottle.  The taste is somewhat sweet, but not as sweet as a honey or brown sugar BBQ sauce.  I didn’t detect any bacon flavor and wouldn’t know there was any bacon if not for the label.  There were certainly no bits of bacon as shown in the picture.If you want BBQ flavor, I’d suggest picking up a bottle of your favorite variety from the supermarket at a much lower price than this packet labeled “skillet sauce.”While the BBQ didn’t win me over, I would like to try the other varieties.  As far as I know, you can’t just buy a bottle of Sicillian sauce.

This headset is an odd duck.  First of all, it is not Apple compatible.  But the description makes this pretty clear.  I looked around on the Sennheiser website to find the Apple equivalent and there isn’t one.  The news isn’t all bad for Apple users.  Only the volume buttons don’t work.  Click to pause or answer, double click to advance a track, long click for Siri—all that still works.I have two big gripes with this headset.  The first is the quality issues.  The headband holds the wire for the right hand ear bud.  It’s not uniform, and there’s glue squished out in places giving a sloppy appearance.  A headset with an MSRP over $100 should have better quality control.My other (and bigger) gripe is that this headset is totally non-adjustable.  The earbuds themselves are very large, and if you want any bass in your music at all, you have push them into you ear.  Once you do, they stay in place well thanks to the stiff headband.  My ears are most comfortable with small cushions.  I can wear mediums just fine, but smaller cushions are the most comfortable for me.  These Sennheisers aren’t just uncomfortable; they hurt!  I can tolerate them about ten minutes, then they have to come out.  If you can’t tolerate a dime stuffed in your ear, these are probably too big for you.The sound quality is okay.  I may have been too distracted by the pain to hear any greatness.  The wire is a highlight.  It’s a flat wire and ribbed.  It’s stiff enough to resist tangling.  It also resists making noise in your ears.  The headband, however, makes a a lot of scraping noise if you look up or wear a dress shirt with a collar.These are not for me, but if you have an Android and huge ear canals, they may be worth a try.

Somehow, it has become tradition in my house for our dog to get his morning treat when I go to the kitchen to get my morning coffee.  When my dog first tried these treats, it took him a few sniffs to decide that he likes them very much.  I took a poll of the dogs at the local dog park and all of them liked Bear Biscuits very much too.  (Hint, if you do this, take a limited number of treats.
