You won’t get any peace until you can show you have none left.)These certainly have a much stronger smell than the usual crunchy biscuit.  It makes me think they have a stronger flavor too.  Each biscuit is smaller than the typical crunchy biscuit.  I think they’re small enough and healthy enough that they could be used as training rewards.The label says these are the same treats that are given to bears in zoos.  I don’t see how that makes them better for dogs, but my dog collects his two treats and heads off for the living room carpet for his breakfast snack.  I can hear the crunching from the kitchen.I’ve reviewed other dog treats for Amazon and given some otherwise very good treats bad reviews because they were stupidly expensive.  Amazon has these treats for $3.49 for a one pound bag as I write this.  At that price, I think they’re a great value.

When it comes to K-cups, there are two popular options for regular, unsweetened ice tea, Liptons and Luzianne.  Of the two, Liptons makes a much stronger tea.  I like both, but in my book Lipton wins.

This is a neat little lunch kit that holds a lot of food, and really does keep food hot or cold for hours.  The bottle is also insulated and keeps liquid cold quite a while.  (Mine still had ice after 6 hours.)  The food box holds a liter, and the drink bottle holds a half liter.This is a complete kit that along with the food box and bottle comes with a plastic fork, knife and spoon that are about the same weight and quality as high end disposable flatware.  A surprise I wasn't expecting was a small clear plastic plate that matches the flatware.  The top of the bottle also has a cup.  It all fits very snugly in a zippered case color matched to the set.  There's a place to put a paper napkin.  That and maybe a few ketchup packets is all you're going to get in there.The people who made this set are serious about leak proofing.  The bottle will leak if you don't screw the cap down firmly enough.  If you do screw it down firmly, nothing will leak.  The food box secures with a strong clamp on each of the four sides.  They prevent any possibility of leaking, but are stiff both to open and to close.  Given the cap and the clamps, people who have arthritis may need to look elsewhere.This set is easy to care for.  Everything is dishwasher and microwave safe.  (Hint: the plate makes a dandy spatter cover.)  The case is washable, but if you want to avoid washing the case, your dirty utensils will fit in the food box.I have two gripes.  I wish the bottle were bigger.  A half liter is not very much for me.  And the adjustable shoulder strap is only long enough if you're a 5 year-old.This is a neat (literally) way to tote your lunch.  Keep in mind this only provides one food compartment.  But if that fits your needs, this is a compact, well insulated and absolutely leakproof way to pack a pretty substantial lunch.  Five stars.Update:  Spoke too soon!The base of the food box split apart after the fourth or fifth cycle through the dishwasher.  It was on the top rack.  The cover on the base separates from the insert.  Once that happens, the clamps can't work rendering the whole thing useless.  I noticed that the Amazon description reads "hand wash only" now.  That's not gonna happen around here!

This is just a basic hand mixer.  There are only three speeds: fast, faster and “fling batter into the next room.”  There is no slow speed, so make sure you’ve got the beaters in the bowl and vertical before you turn the mixer on.  The wire beaters and high power do a good job of beating down lumps.  Every surface of the mixer that’s likely to get splattered is smooth and easy to clean.  The beaters eject with a lot of enthusiasm, so make sure you’re aiming at the sink before you hit that button.Cuisinart sells different beaters for this mixer, but the wire beaters are good for most jobs.  I think buying a bunch of accessories for this mixer defeats the basic nature of this mixer.  I only use a hand mixer occasionally, and a basic model is what I need.  5 stars.

Printer manufacturers sell their printers cheap so they can make money on the replacement ink cartridges.  That is why your printer manual warns you against buying generic cartridges or using a refill service.I've used these Vivamart cartridges in my Epson 8C180 all-in-one printer for over a year now with no problems.  When these cartridges get low on ink, they shut down unexpectedly, ruining the page you're printing at the time.  But the really cheap price is worth this occasional hassle.  4 stars.

I wanted something to decouple my center channel speaker from my TV stand.  A four pack of Model 1 Vibrapods did the trick.  These aren't a miracle, but the sound is a little cleaner now that the entire TV stand isn't trying to deliver dialog.The best thing about these are the reasonable price.  In the rarified world occupied by audiophiles, a power cable can cost $5000.  Here's something that makes a significant improvement for under $25.A good buy and sound improvement.  5 stars.

Fresh ’n Clean shampoo is good, basic shampoo for dogs.  We have two dogs in our household, a young short haired dog and an elderly longer haired dog who suffers from all kinds of skin allergies and itching.  Fresh ’n Clean works well for them both.  Our elderly pup still itched after his bath, but perhaps slightly less.  Bathing him with a shampoo containing Aloe Vera makes me feel a little better, anyway.The scent is pleasant and really does last a long time.  Even weeks after, I caught a slight whiff of it when the dog wet his fur from licking himself.The 1 gallon size is convenient, but also a problem.  Trying to handle a gallon jug while corralling a dog who doesn’t want a bath can be a challenge.  Also with the gallon size, it’s easy to pour out a lot more than you really need, wasting shampoo.  A pump is a good idea if you’re going with the gallon jug.Nice, long-lasting scent; easy on my elderly pup’s itchy skin and a fair price with free shipping.  5 stars

The CandyShell AMPED is a standard Speck CandyShell case with a tiny acoustical horn moulded into the silicone layer of the back of the case.  Speck claims that this horn will make the iPhone's built-in speaker twice as loud.  There have been other horn set-ups for the iPhone before, but the ones I have heard of were built into docks.  This is the first horn built into a case that I know.Does it work?  Yes!*****Enter Geek Mode*****To prove it, I get to break out my sound level meter and do some experiments!  Part of how loud the iPhone sounds has to do with whether the speaker is pointing at you or not.  The AMPED case effectively moves the speaker from the bottom to the side of the case, so I made measurements with the bottom of the phone and the side of the phone aimed at the meter.  I used the opening chords from Tom Petty's "Runnin' Down A Dream" with my iPhone 5S volume turned up all the way.  I maintained a distance of 12" from speaker to microphone.  Here's what I found:naked -- bottom, 76dB; side, 73dBCandyShell case -- bottom, 78dB; side, 74dBCandyShell AMPED case -- bottom, 75dB; side, 82dBI have no idea why using a standard CandyShell case would cause the iPhone to be slightly louder.  That was a surprise.  If you compare a naked iPhone with its bottom pointed at the meter to iPhone AMPED with its side pointing at the meter, the increase is 6 dB.  A 6 dB increase is considered by many to be the point where audio sounds twice as loud.  So the AMPED case passes the twice as loud test.*****Exit Geek Mode*****Speck claims the AMPED case makes the iPhone sound clearer.  What I can tell you is that the AMPED case boosts midrange frequencies.  With the AMPED case on, the iPhone sounds like the transistor radio you had in the `70s (without the static).Aside from the sound, the AMPED case has the pluses and minuses of the regular CandyShell case.  It offers great protection for your phone, but the glossy surface of the case itself scuffs ridiculously easily and looks old within a couple of days.The AMPED case is thicker to accommodate the horn.  When the speaker is playing, the back of the case vibrates, tickling your hand.  The thicker back does not interfere with the camera or the flash.  I was concerned that the new speaker position would be easy to block while holding the phone, but the grill is large enough that it's hard to block enough of it to make a big difference.So the Speck AMPED case trades a little thickness for louder sound from the built-in speaker.  For me it's a great trade.  5 stars.

I’ve panned other dog treats I’ve reviewed recently because they were so darn expensive.  And while you can’t really compare Beggin’ Poppers to the treats I reviewed before (they were dental chews) they are at least affordable.  There are about 50 treats in each package, so a four pack is about 200 treats.  At Amazon’s price as I write this, that’s about 17 cents each.  I can handle that.My household’s two dogs like these.  They work well with Kong chew toys.  Hide them inside the Kong to create a fun puzzle to entertain your dog.  I didn’t have much luck with the snout launcher built into the lid.  It does work sometimes, but can fling treats far and in unexpected places like behind the couch or in your eye.  It’s cute though, and ups the fun factor for your dog.I took the Beggin’ Poppers to the dog park to see if my dog’s friends like them.  They did.  I gave them out to about 10 dogs (with their owner’s permission) and all the dogs liked them.  They all asked for more.  I was the most popular human at the dog park that day.An economical treat for dogs that they really enjoy.  Five stars.

This is a role playing game with battles and quests, things to collect and all the thing you’d expect.  But this is South Park.  It’s not just a role playing game with South Park characters plugged in.  This is the whole town, the whole cast, all the humor, the whole show made interactive.  The core cast is here, of course, but also all the side characters are here as well.  The cows, Mr. Kim’s “stupid Mongorians,” Big Gay Al and Mr. Slave, Al Gore, the Visitors and Mr. Garrison’s penis on a mouse are all here.  One quest is to find Jesus.  Need a new attack?  Roshambo is an option.  Walk into any building and pay attention to the music.  It’ll be a classic from the show:  “You almost make me forget all about….  TACOS!”You play the part of the new kid.  Your main mission is to make friends.  You mostly do that by completing quests for all the other characters.  All the kids in town are role playing a medieval game that forms the frame work of the game.  All the adults are oblivious.This is a game that you figure out almost entirely by playing it.  The game helps you out along the way.  Early in the game if you try to talk to Cartman’s Mom, Cartman will say “Don’t talk to her.  She’s not part of the game.”My one grip is a technical glitch.  While you’re in battle, it’s almost impossible to select your weapon from an extremely twitchy interface.If you like South Park, and have ever thought it would be neat to walk around there for awhile, this is as close as you’ll ever get.  5 Stars.

We have an incontinent dog.  We also have tile floors, thank goodness.  What we have discovered is that mopping just smears the mess around.  You need something that will pick-up the mess, and that’s what the FloorMate does.The FloorMate has brushes that “scrub” the floor, along with cleaning fluid and a vacuum that sucks it all back up.  It works exactly the same way most carpet cleaners do, but it’s for hard floors.The brushes and the nozzle snap off for easy cleaning.  The tanks lift off easily and snap back in just as easily.  This model has larger tanks than the base model and comes with two sets of brushes.  One for tile and one for hardwood.  The base model comes with one brush for general purpose use.We leave ours sitting against the wall, ready to use the instant an accident occurs.  The one flaw is that when the brushes become saturated with water, it takes time for them to stop dripping on the floor.  It’s not a problem until you’re done cleaning.  Water seems to flow much longer than you wanted.This machine has been a lifesaver for my home.  5 Stars.
All floss picks claim to be break and shred resistant.  These actually are.  A fold away guard exposes a surprisingly sharp pick.5 stars.

This is a good tape dispenser for those of use that only seal packages occasionally.  The dispenser covers the tape roll completely, so you can store the dispenser loose in a drawer without it collecting debris along the sticky edge.  The cutting edge works well enough for infrequent home use.  in short it stores as well as it works.  5 stars.

Amazon is doing something confusing here.  The "color options" boxes change more than just the color, they change the type of cover you get.  While most of the covers are made of TPU, the flexible, tough material that most iPhone cases are made from, others are "back covers."  Back covers are made of crystal clear, but brittle, plastic.  They're called back covers because they don't cover the top or bottom edge of the phone, just the sides and back.The crystal clear plastic certainly allows the beauty of the iPhone to be more on display.  The cover is extra thin and as close to invisible as a case can be.  But I wouldn't trust this case to protect my phone on impact with a sidewalk.  Also, the clear plastic scratches easily.  I think this is a good option if all you want is protection from everyday scuffs and scratches.I agree with other reviewers that find screen protectors frustrating.  I put them aside and count on the raised ridges of the case to protect the screen.  This case only provides raised ridges on the sides, not on all four edges like full cases do.Attractive clear plastic or tough TPU?  My big gripe is that Amazon makes the choice confusing by putting their "back covers" on the same page as their full cover TPU cases.  Make sure you're ordering the one you want!

The Jabra Revo is a wireless headphone/phone headset with good sound quality that surprises you with plenty of really cool features.These are rechargeable phones with up to 12 hour run time between charges according to Jabra.  My pair played continuously for 15 hours before a pleasant voice started announcing in my ear every 10 minutes that the batteries were getting low.  (Connection through bluetooth, volume about 80%.)  They played another hour and a half before giving up.  I was glad about this, because it means that the 12 hours Jabra claims isn't just for a brand new battery.  No charger is included.  You charge with any available powered USB port.The cords included with these phones are cloth covered, beefy-looking and attached to easy-to-grip plugs.  The center of the right ear cup is a button that does all the things you think it does.  The ring around it though, is a surprise.  Jabra calls it a "turntable touch control" and if you've ever used an iPod with a click wheel, you already know how to use it.  Run your finger around it to change the volume, double tap the leading edge to jump a track ahead, and so on.  Neat.  Literally, because there's a lot of functionality here without littering the phones with fidgety buttons.These phones connect three different ways.  The way you'll probably want to use is bluetooth.  Pairing is easy, especially if your phone uses NFC pairing.  Even if it doesn't, you need only put the phones on, hold the off/on/pairing switch in the pairing position for 3 seconds and follow the instructions that Jabra's friendly female voice starts speaking in your ear.  It only took a few seconds to pair with my iPhone 4S.If you want to go wired, Jabra includes a standard mini plug cable, complete with a multifunction button as well as a USB cable.  To listen though the USB cable, the phones must be powered on, and you must choose them in your computer's sound menu.These phones sound fine.  The bass is nice and warm if not terribly deep.  There's not a lot of detail, but the overall sound is well balanced and pleasant.Everything about these handsome phones, from the packaging to the cables is cool.  All the features work well and are actually helpful when you've got your hands full.  There's only one downside.A card that comes with the phones has a scan code that directs you to the Jabra app for your device.  Once you download and launch the app, you're prompted to enter your unique code (also found on the card).  The Jabra app is an alternate music player that taps into your existing music library.  Jabra has partnered with Dolby Labs for digital sound processing.  The app offers a graphic equalizer with all the usual presets as well as a "Dolby Processing" switch and a "Mobile Surround" switch.  Dolby processing is mostly a drastic mid-bass boost, turning the well balanced Revos into thump cans.  The mobile surround switch muddies up the sound, but doesn't produce any kind of convincing surround.  My advice is to forget the app, the Jabra Revos sound a lot better without it.Aside from the app, there's a lot to like about these handsome phones.  Cool features, cool design, cool phones.

I recently bought a vintage stereo receiver and needed an FM antenna.  The original dipole was lost long ago.  This Terk fits the bill perfectly.  But I think Terk makes a mistake when they claim this antenna will outperform simple wire antennas that come with most receivers.  In most cases it won't.The box and description say that you can lay this antenna down to make it directional.  That would give it an advantage over stock antennas, but the instructions don't mention it at all, nor are there any markings on the antenna to show what the direction would be.  So unless you want to map out all the stations in your area and spend a day experimenting, don't plan on getting any advantage from it.What the Terk FM+ will give you is a reasonably stylish and good performing antenna for use in a metro area.  To get better than this you need a roof top or attic antenna.  Those of you out in the boondocks might want to invest in an amplified antenna.

I thought this was going to be an entirely new toothbrush from Oral-B, but it's just a new head on a familiar handle.  Frankly, I think the older round heads are better.The Deep Sweep heads have bristles that move back and forth, so they go up and down against the gum line. That's what I prefer, but there are a couple issues.  The biggest, in my opinion, is that this brush head is huge!  The head is a full 1" long and " from bristle tip to back side of the head.  I have a big mouth (so I'm told) and even I find it awkward to navigate this monster to the back of my front teeth.  If you have a small mouth, pass this brush by.The other thing that bothers me about this brush head is the stationary bristles.  Looking at the brush head, the light blue bristles at the tip and the white bristles are powered.  The dark blue bristles are stationary.  The manual says you can use this brush like you would a manual toothbrush.  So this is a manual/powered hybrid toothbrush?  I'd prefer to have all the bristles fully powered.If you like the idea of a powered toothbrush that brushes up and down against the gum line, by all means try the Triaction 1000.  If you dislike the brush you can simply swap to any of the familiar round heads that Braun has sold for years.  Even if I don't care for this brush head, this is still a high quality tooth brush with a wide variety of replacement brush heads.  Just have a big mouth.

When I moved into my new house a few years ago, I installed a bunch of outdoor landscape lighting.  I went a little nuts.  Front yard, back yard, two porches, an atrium, all-in-all over 30 fixtures that use these little G4 base 10w and 20w 12V bulbs.  I quickly discovered that these halogen bulbs are a lot less reliable than the 7w wedge base bulbs I had used before.  What is more, at around $6.50 for a two pack at the local builder store, they are also a lot more expensive.I found these bulbs on Amazon a few months ago and have been using them ever since.  While it's true that you occasionally find a dud that goes dark in a matter of weeks, that's every bit as true of the bulbs you buy at the store and pay over $3 a bulb for.These bulbs kinda saved me.  I spent a lot on landscape lighting and was backed into a corner with bulb replacement costs.  Finding these bulbs made it feasible to keep my lights.  Five stars.

I'm a fan of wood toilet seats, they're a bit more comfortable than plastic, in my humble opinion.  Less cold on touch down, and just more substantial feeling.I also sit on the lid occasionally.  Drying my toes fresh from the shower, for instance.  With a plastic seat, the lid flexes.  A wood lid is as solid as a chair.The slow-close feature is a neat novelty if nothing else.  I never had a problem with pinching my fingers--or, um, anything else--with the toilet seat.  And I never had a tendency to slam the seat and make noise, so this solved a problem I didn't have.  You can push the seat down with your hand, so it doesn't get in the way if you had a spicy lunch and need be seated in a hurry.The Easy-Clean hinge is great.  Being able to pop the seat off without tools makes cleaning both the toilet and the seat easier.  One tiny snag:  When you put the seat back on, you have to make sure the hinges are oriented the same way.  If they're not, you have to adjust them.  Not a big deal, but it does take a bit of effort because of the slow-close feature.The other big feature of this seat that is not mentioned on Amazon's product page is the Sta-Tite mounting system that keeps the seat from wobbling back and forth and loosening over time.  This feature includes a cool installation feature, break-away nuts.  When you're tightening the seat hinge during installation, the the part of the nut your wrench is on breaks off when the torque is correct.  The break-away part leaves another wrench-able nut behind for when you want to uninstall this seat.  This is really nice for those of us that want to get a good tight fit, but don't want to risk cracking the porcelain.This is a great seat so far.  It's very comfortable and solid.  It feels so tight it's hard to imagine it loosening.  Only time will tell how durable this seat is.  After all, this isn't solid wood, it's molded wood.  I don't know exactly what that means, but it's a sure bet if moisture gets to it, it will degrade quickly.I'm a good test subject for this seat.  I'm a big boy, about 225LB and I like to take hot steamy showers with the door closed so I don't steam up my bedroom.  It's January 2013 as I write this.  I promise to update if a problem develops with this seat.  But for right now, I love it.

The Prexiso laser distance meter works fine and is accurate (as far as I can tell), but I think you'd be better off buying a stand alone meter.The device cradles your iPhone 4 or 4S without a case, so you'll be taking the case off each time you use it.  The software is free through The App Store.  The first thing you notice is that you have to click through a lawyer's disclaimer each time you start the app and each time your screen locks.  Launch the app, acknowledge you are using a class 2 laser.  Pause to write down a distance, acknowledge you are using a class 2 laser.  Someone says hi, acknowledge you are using a class 2 laser. It's annoying after awhile.My biggest problem with the Prexiso is that the same touch screen that makes the iPhone a joy to use as a phone is a pain in the neck in a device such as this.  I'm a one-handed person, so it's probably worse for me than it would be for you, but trying to not drop the iPhone (scary--no case!), not block the laser, keep the laser dot where you want it and press a virtual button you're not looking at is time consuming and awkward.This is a slick device, but a flawed concept.  For the same money as this unit costs, you can get a stand-alone laser meter of similar accuracy.  Unless you want the geek factor (Bet your Blackberry can't do this!), a stand-alone unit would be a better bet.

Here's a new idea, instead of a stapler that uses brute force (yours) to drive a staple through a stack of papers, make a stapler that works like a tiny staple gun.  Press down on the EVO against a surprisingly light spring until, pop!  The staple is driven through the papers using velocity.Paper Pro has an all-plastic construction making your old Swingline look old.  It's set-up for desk use, but the base is sculpted away around the middle making it comfortable to use hand held.  The Paper Pro is supposed to be jam-free.  All I can say is I haven't had a jam yet.  This EVO is rated to staple up to 15 pages, and I thought this would be the thing I would call the Paper Pro out on.  But I just happened to have 16 20 lb. pages and the EVO punched right through.One gripe.  You can't unfold the Paper Pro, for example, to tack a page to a cork board.  But for stapling papers, I love it.

First some corrections.  This unit does NOT plug into AC.  It is strictly a 12V car adapter.  It plugs into a 12v outlet and has a standard USB jack.  NOT a micro USB.  The Apple sync cord is 3' long, NOT 4'.This is two products.The car USB adapter has a high quality, solid feel.  It snugs into a 12V outlet securely, makes solid connection and sits fairly flush with the dash so I can still use my cup holder.  A green LED above the USB outlet shows when the adapter has power and makes orienting the USB plug foolproof.  A lip around the outer edge makes it easy to pull the adapter out even though it sits close to the dash.  Someone put some thought into this unit and I appreciate it.The other half of this product is a nice heavy USB to Apple iPod/iPhone 30 pin connector.  Not beautiful, but it seems rugged and reliable.  It's short, so you won't have to deal with extra cable tangling with your feet while you drive.If you don't use an iPod/iPhone, Belkin offers the adapter as a stand-alone accessory.  Mine is going to be a permanent fixture in my glove box.Simple, easy to use, inexpensive and reliable.  5 stars.

This Circulon Ultimate pan is a combination of a wok and a fry pan.  While many combinations mean compromises, this pan offers the best of both formats.My household has a bad cook (me) and a good cook (not me).  For a good cook, this pan offers even heating and a tight fitting lid that increases the steam inside the pan.For the not-so-good cook, this pan offers a lot of forgiveness.  The high sloping sides mean that this pan holds a lot for a 12" pan.  My measuring cup says the Ultimate holds just under 5 quarts.  So even if you're making 3 quarts of stir fry, it's easier to stir and still keep food in the pan and off the stovetop.  Food doesn't stick, so it's less likely to scorch.  Speaking as a serial scorcher, I really appreciate that.  The handle is grippy and easy to twist for sliding the contents out of the pan.  This pan fits in the dishwasher standing on its side straight across the rack (not diagonally), so it takes little space in the dishwasher.The non-stick surfaces of this pan are supposed to be tough enough to stand up to metal utensils.  Only time will tell.  For now, this pan is big on the stovetop, small in the dishwasher, easy to handle and kind to my smoke alarm batteries.  Thumbs up.

My last flip type belgian waffle maker didn't last long.  This waffle maker has a higher quality feel to it.  The flip mechanism feels a little sloppy, with play in the mechanism, but it doesn't feel like it's about to break.  That's what did in my last flip waffle maker.  The front of the VillaWare waffle maker has only one knob with a power button in the center.  The knob is lightly ratcheted and the power button feels substantial.  It's feels more like the switch gear you'd expect in a good quality car rather than a kitchen appliance.  There are no visible wires other than the power cord.I made waffles for the family this morning, and they came out fine.  Evenly done and tender inside.  There was no hint of sticking.  I used cooking spray as suggested in the instructions.  The one criticism I would make is to replace the words "low" and "high" around the control knob with the words "fluffy" and "crisp."  A beep sounds and the light around the power knob shines steady when the iron is ready and when your waffles are done.  Waffles cook fairly quickly.  Clean up is easy as nothing sticks.  Overflows flake off cleanly and the drip tray catches the rest.I did discover that the casing around the plates ding easily.  I don't remember anything falling on the waffle maker or banging into it, yet there's a little ding that wasn't there before.  It's just cosmetic and doesn't effect operation, but darn it, it was brand new.  Oh, well.Flip type Belgian waffle makers are just fun.  This one seems to be a higher quality one.

This is really two products, the little 3M projector, and the Roku Streaming Stick.The 3M projector is a fun little gizmo that projects standard definition images, 480P, on any convenient wall or ceiling.  This is as simple a projector as is possible to make.  There's only one input, the HDMI//MHL port; only one knob, the focus wheel; and just a few buttons: power, volume up & down, menu and info.  This simplicity makes it both easier and more difficult to set-up.  There's no elevating front foot or keystone correction.Most video projectors--even very cheap ones--have a screw adjustable front foot so the picture can be projected higher onto the wall.  Doing so results in a picture that, instead of a rectangle, is a trapezoid that's wider on top than bottom.  So, there's usually a keystone correction control that returns the picture to square.  Since this projector doesn't have that, it must be positioned exactly perpendicular to the surface on which it's projecting.  That limits you quite a lot when it comes to placement.The projector is preset to shoot upwards so that the bottom of the image is slightly higher than the surface the projector is sitting on.  That's good.  Also good is the flat surface on the back that allows you to stand the projector on its backside and project onto the ceiling.  Unfortunately, since it's preset to shoot at an upward angle, if you put this little guy on your nightstand pointed at the ceiling, most of the picture will end up smeared on the wall behind your headboard.  Sorry to keep harping on this, but this projector really would be a lot more fun to use if you weren't constantly trying to find a position that works.Video and audio quality are just OK.  Video quality is adequate but not stellar.  The built-in speaker can produce about as much volume as an iPhone.  This little guy isn't meant to be a replacement for your home theater.  It's meant to be fun, and it is.Among internet TV services, Roku is the 800 pound gorilla in the room.  Roku says they've got 600+ channels to offer.  To use Roku service you first have to sign up with a credit card.  Once Roku has your credit card info, address and phone number, they'll allow you to activate the streaming stick.  Some of the channels are free and ad-supported, like Crackle and most of the news channels.  Most of the movie and TV channels are pay-per-view, like Amazon and Vudu.  There's also monthly-fee subscription services, like Hulu+ and Netflix.  Aside from that, there are games and screen savers you can buy.The Roku Streaming Stick is the standard Roku box reduced down to a dongle that plugs into the back of the 3M projector.  But unlike the projector which can work with any HDMI or MHL input,  the Roku Streaming Stick can only work with this projector and two TVs made by Insignia as I write this.  The Roku streaming stick is a brand new product (I'm writing this in Oct. 2012), and may very well work with a lot of products in the days ahead.Once the Streaming Stick is set up and connected with your wi-fi and once the battery is charged, this becomes a very cool gizmo.  You can stream video anywhere within range of your wi-fi without so much as a power cord to worry about.  I'm planning on projecting a scary movie onto the side of the house Halloween night.Battery life is about 1 hour 45 minutes at standard brightness and 2 hours 50 minutes on "Eco" mode.  3M's instructions are scant and error ridden, but the projector is easy to figure out.  The remote is a miniature that's a chore to use, but works well and aim doesn't seem to be critical.  That's good when you have a lifetime habit of aiming the remote at the screen.Overall the 3M projector and Roku Streaming Stick are a fun combo and a little frustrating too.  It's ultra portable, but you can't take it on a camping trip (no wi-fi).  The Roku stick can steam high-def 1080p images, but the projector can only display standard definition 480p.  You can project onto any wall, but you've got to find a leveled surface at just the right height for the projector to sit on.  I think the projector by itself would be a good companion to an iPhone or iPad with an adapter cable.  Together with the Roku stick the 3M projector's a neat toy, but just a toy.

Oral-B makes six different brush heads for their electric toothbrushes.  This one, the "Precision Clean," is their most general use head and is the one they include with all their toothbrushes.I like the frustration-free packaging.  Oral-B uses different packaging for toothbrushes and heads they sell on-line as opposed to the ones they sell in stores.  You get a plain brown box sealed with a plain white label that slices open easily.  Inside are four brush heads each in its own tiny 3 " long blister pack.  The cardboard back of each blister pack is perforated so you can just punch the brush head out.  These tiny packs won't take up much space in your bathroom drawer.I wish Oral-B would provide a cap with these brush heads, but that's my only gripe.  These are genuine Oral-B brush heads in frustration-free packaging at a fair price.

I've been a Sonicare user for a while now, and I wanted to see how the Oral-B Healthy Clean Precision 1000 stacks up against my Sonicare Healthy White Easy Clean.  Both are basic rechargeable electric toothbrushes with few fancy features, but a emphasis on cleaning ability.The Sonicare is a more aggressive toothbrush, while the Oral-B is gentler.  Sonicare seems to acknowledge that it's toothbrushes are aggressive because it gives them a feature called Easy-Start that ramps up power over the first 14 times you use the brush so you and your gums can get used to the punishment.  No such feature is present or needed for the Oral-B.  Instead of vibrating up and down against the gum line, the Oral-B's brush head oscillates rapidly.  It is supposed to pulse as well, but it must be too subtle for me to see or feel.  The overall feeling is a little rubbery.The other thing I noticed is that the brush head is thicker than the one on the Sonicare, meaning you'll need more room between your teeth and cheek when brushing your side teeth.  The distance between the tip of the bristles to the back side of the brush head is ⅞" vs ⅝" for the Sonicare.  It's not a problem for me, but I can see it might be an issue for someone with a smaller mouth.  It may also be the reason Oral-B doesn't give you a cap with your brush heads.I prefer the Sonicare, but I want to point out some advantages of the Oral-B.  First of all, it's cheaper.  As I write this, Amazon is offering the Oral-B for around $50 as compared to $66 for the Sonicare.  The replacement brush heads are cheaper too.  $25 will buy you a thee pack of Sonicare brush heads, but a four pack of Oral-B heads.  And while you seldom see Sonicare heads discounted, my local BJ's has six packs of Oral-B heads for under $30.  That's less than $5 per head.  That's a big savings over the life of the brush.  I've been guilty of not replacing my Sonicare brush heads as often as I should, just because they're so darn expensive.  $5 per head makes me feel better about chucking old brush heads in the trash.Speaking of brush heads, Oral-B offers a wide range of them.  The owner's manual lists eight different heads you can buy.  There are brush heads for people with sensitive teeth, wearers of braces, people with crowns and bridges, people who want to whiten and more.  My local BJ's has floss head brushes for $32 per six pack.The Oral-B comes in an easy-to-open box.  All the packaging is cardboard.  No frustrating plastic clamshell that needs to be cut open with scissors.  I'm all for eco-friendly, frustration-free packaging.  Well done, Braun.By the way, if you take the Sonicare out of your mouth while it's running, it'll fling toothpaste and saliva all over the bathroom.  That's not recommended with the Oral-B either, but it makes a lot less mess.  Sounds kind-of silly, but about the third time you have to clean your bathroom because you were careless when you swapped your toothbrush from one side to the other, it starts to seem less silly.My gut feeling is that the Sonicare cleans better, but I have no evidence to back that up.  Either brush will clean much, much better than a manual brush.  The Oral-B is gentler, cheaper and has more options for people with sensitive teeth or dental work.

Almost There...The Philips In.Sight home monitor offers a neat and inexpensive solution for remote home monitoring in an innovative and noninvasive hardware package.  Or at least it will, once the bugs are worked out.To use this system you'll need an iPhone or iPad, and a Wi-Fi network at the place you want to monitor.The actual hardware is neat.  Small at only 3 ¾" high with the base, it easily hides among the knick knacks and stays unobtrusive.  The base is neat too.  The monitor and base form a cup and ball socket that are held together with magnets, so the monitor is free to be positioned in any direction.  A wall mount is included, and the magnetic base can be ceiling mounted.  The AC adapter is simply a USB power adapter.  A thin, white unobtrusive 8 foot cord connects it to the monitor.As neat as the hardware is, the software is clunky.  The In.Sight monitor works with iOS devices along with the free In.Sight app, available in the App Store.  I'm using this camera with an iPhone 4S running In.Sight software version 1.9.2.  My monitor firmware version is 35057.  My early experiences with this app and the monitor operation in general were discouraging; the app would fail to find the monitor, or the video would fail to load or the app would quit unexpectedly.  Though the first couple of days were rough, since then operation has been much more reliable.  Maybe I had a bug that worked itself out.  Still, there are tell-tale signs that this was a new product that had a difficult time in development.While you're watching a monitor though your iPhone or iPad, you have buttons available to save a still picture or video.  Still pictures go to the camera roll on your phone, but videos get uploaded to your YouTube account.  This isn't working as I write this.  Philips' FAQs section on their website says there's an issue that Philips and YouTube are working to resolve along with an apology for the inconvenience.  This is the biggest issue I can see, no video recording.You are supposed to be able to view the In.Sight monitor from any web browser, but when you call up the web page, you get a big fat error message.  (Update:  The error message is gone and replaced with a message saying "Web view available end of July").There are discrepancies in the instructions that give away the revisions this product must have gone through late in the game.  Nothing that will trip you up too badly, just things like menu items being in a different place than indicated and, yes, the mention of an Android app that doesn't exist (yet).Finally, I have to say that the In.Sight app is cumbersome to use.  It is slow and has to go through a few steps before you can see anything.  Philips made it all automatic (you don't have to enter passwords or anything) but if you're in a hurry, it's frustrating.  If you're viewing a monitor and want to go back to a menu, you have to wait while the app is "Stopping Streaming."  A lot of the latency is caused by encrypting the video stream so the teenage hacker down the street can't tap into your bedroom camera, so maybe that's a good trade-off.While the service to use this monitor is free, you are limited to 5 minute viewing sessions.  You can have an unlimited number of sessions, but if you want longer sessions, you must upgrade to premium service and pay a $25 annual fee.  I was worried this would mean the In.Sight app would nag me constantly to upgrade, but it doesn't.I could go on listing all kinds of minor complaints like crappy video quality.  (I know this is a security camera and not a memory maker but, yeesh, I didn't know they still made cameras this bad).The promise of a great product is there.  Audio and video alerts work just fine, are highly adjustable and reliable.  Push notifications work well, but arrive about 20 minutes after the fact.  There's a lot to like here.  Imagine being on vacation knowing if someone broke into your house, there'll be video of it waiting for you on YouTube.  Software revisions will turn the In.Sight from a frustrating device to a super useful one.  And we are talking about Philips here.  Not exactly a fly-by-night company.  I believe they will get this right.  They just should have done it before they released the In.Sight.UPDATE:  Well, I'm still waiting for them to get it right.  The inability to record video has been addressed with a change to Dropbox as the video service used.  Unfortunately, the software updates required to make that change has broken a bunch of other stuff.  I can't watch video from my iPhone anymore.  Calling up a camera just produces a still picture.  This is the case even on very fast wi-fi connections.  Occasionally the frame will refresh at intervals of once every 30 seconds to 2 minutes, but mostly you just see a freeze frame.  Audio still streams.  I could go through a laundry list of bugs, but it's easier to say that the only thing In.Sight's software does reliably is crash.  If Philips intends to fix these bugs, they're keeping it a secret.I'm disappointed to say that my belief that Philips would step up and turn the In.Sight into a reliable device may have been wrong.  Not recommended.UPDATE to the UPDATE:  I spoke a day too soon.  Philips just released an update that addresses a lot of the bugs.  The app is still clunky and frustratingly slow.  The picture quality is still awful.  But the system now works like it's supposed to, even if it's still buggy.  I originally gave the In.Sight 3 stars, then reduced it to 1 star.  Now, I'm giving it four stars.Update number 3:  Well it worked for a couple days.  Now it's quit completely.  The app told me today that there was a firmware update for the monitor.  I went though the update process and ended up with the same firmware revision I had before.  Still, the monitor worked for a few minutes, then quit.  I've reset the monitor and gone through the reinstallation process three times, deleted and reinstalled the iOS app once and generally spent way too much time trying to coax this thing into working.  I quit.  into the junk box it goes.

This little pedometer is hard to fool.  It has recorded every step I've taken it along for, as far as I can tell.  I have a limp, but that hasn't thrown it.  The instructions warn that car or bicycle rides may cause inaccuracies, but my 5.7 mile commute in moderate stop and go traffic in my Honda Civic didn't result in a single step counted.  The treadmill at my gym said I walked a mile, and this little pedometer agreed.  Furthermore, it identified those steps as aerobic steps, in contrast to all the other steps I'd taken that day.Tri-axis means not picky.  This little guy comes with a clip, but you don't need it.  It's a lot easier to just chuck it in your pocket and go.  This little guy has a cord attachment point, but I think it would be handier if it had a key ring.  You could just ignore it until you want the information it's been collecting.  This pedometer saves all the information it records for 7 days.  The step count resets at midnight everyday.Once you've set up the Omron with you stride length, height and weight, it keeps track of steps, aerobic steps, distance, calories burned and steps per minute.My middle-aged eyes could use a larger display, but other than that, this is a great little pedometer.

I've used a Tripp-Lite line conditioner for years now.  I recently bought this unit to replace it so the old unit can do duty elsewhere.  I installed this unit on my home entertainment center.  Good thing I did.My house has developed a bad neutral.  If you're not familiar with this, it can cause all kinds of weird electrical problems.  In my case, when I turn on the microwave (or another appliance) in the kitchen, the voltage goes up in my living room.  Lights flicker all over the house.  It's a mess.  Luckily, my neutral line is not gone completely, but iffy enough to cause voltages in my house to vary between about 105 and 140 volts.  A repair is scheduled in a few days.  In the meantime, I'm keeping most of my electronics unplugged.  At least I can still watch TV at night because of the Tripp-lite standing guard.It's interesting to watch the Tripp-lite work.  When the voltage goes out of range, a relay inside the unit trips to bring the voltage back to normal.  Indicator lights on the front let you know whether your voltage is low or high.  The relay is loud, but if it's clicking a lot you have a problem that you should look into.My older unit is keeping my office computer safe.  My house mate works from there and would be in trouble if he was suddenly unable to work while my house waits for repairs.  Compared to the older Tripp-lite, a 1200 watt unit, this unit is bigger with a plastic case instead of metal and much lighter.If this unit serves me half as well as my older unit, I'll be well pleased.

If you care about sound quality more than features, you might like this Denon AV receiver.This is a 5.1 surround receiver, meaning it can power a left, right, center, left and right surround and a subwoofer.  I'm never going to have more than that, and I doubt most people will either unless they have a dedicated theatre room in their homes.  That makes 7.1 receivers a waste for most of us.Speaking of waste, like some other manufacturers, Denon has eliminated some features that used to be standard.  There are no "B" speakers, no component inputs, no analog audio output and no AM radio.  In short, everything you wern't using anyway is gone now.What you get instead is 4 HDMI inputs plus one on the front, an ethernet port, 5 sets of good quality banana terminals for speakers, and a USB port on the front for your iPad/iPhone or flash drive.  Useful stuff.  I especially like the front mounted HDMI port.  When my friend comes over with his Xbox in tow, I don't have to dig behind the receiver to plug it in.This receiver is new for 2012, and as you'd expect it supports all the current standards.  HDMI supports 3D and audio return channel.  Also new this year for Denon is a revised on-screen menu system.  It's simple and clean and easy to use, but the set-up assistant feature is a bit silly.  You're supposed to plug in the power cord and HDMI cable to your TV so the Denon can walk you through steps such as plugging in the HDMI cable from your Blu-Ray player into the Blu-Ray HDMI input on the back of the Denon.  Big help.  Set-up assistant is more helpful when you're establishing a network connection and using the included microphone to adjust sound settings automatically.Like other network AV receivers in this price range, This model has no wi-fi.  To use network features, including the much-hyped AirPlay feature, you must run an ethernet cable to the receiver.  That's not practical for me, and I bet it's not practical for most people.  TVs and Blu-Ray players have wi-fi now.  Why are receiver makers lagging behind?  You can add wi-fi to these receivers with an Apple AirPort Express and probably other routers too.  It'll cost you cash and cable clutter.Where the Denon doesn't skimp is on sound quality.  Denon promotes its discrete circuitry, simplified signal paths and anti-vibration chassis and they do make a difference.  I can say that the Denon does sound better to me than the run-of-the-mill Sony, Pioneer and Onkyo receivers out there.  I suspect  this Denon sounds similar to Sony ES and Pioneer Elite receivers, but I haven't listened to confirm that.  The Denon always sounds unstrained and well balanced, rich and detailed.So, if you want to spend your money on sound quality and don't care as much about features, take a look at the Denon 1613.

This handsome TV features a thin bezel and modern look, ease of use with attractive menus and very good picture quality.Set UpLike all other flat panel TVs, once you unbox the set, you'll need to assemble and attach the stand.  LG's stand seems a little flimsy.  There's some give when you touch the TV and the manual gives specific instructions on where you should grab the TV when you pivot it on the stand.  I've had no problems, but a more substantial feel would be comforting.When you first turn on the TV, it takes you through a few easy steps to set it up.  Pairing with the remote, joining your wi-fi network, choosing your energy saving preferences and the like.  My TV also found a software update once it was connected to my wi-fi and prompted me to upgrade.  Easy.Performance and The FlawI'm a TV production veteran of many years.  I'm really picky about picture quality in some respects, but don't care a bit about some of the things some TV reviewers seem obsessed about.  What you can see with test signals isn't very important.  What matters, in my humble opinion, is what you are seeing when you sit down to watch.  Are you watching the movie or watching how your TV performs?  The LG's picture quality is very good, but there's one Flaw that takes me out of the moment and makes me pay attention to the TV.The LG 6700 uses LED edge lighting.  It results in splotchy light leaks around the perimeter of the screen.  The Flaw is visible during dark scenes and in a darkened viewing room.  How bad is it?  It's invisible 99% of the time, but when the movie ends and the credits come up, there's those glowing globs around the edges.  When the hero goes into the haunted house with a flashlight, there's those ghosts all around him.  Turning on the Energy Saver feature, which reduces the backlight when the room is dark, lessens The Flaw somewhat.It's pretty easy to overlook The Flaw since the LG has a great picture otherwise.  Good, well saturated color, plenty of contrast and good brightness.  3D performance is stunning.  If you want to change something, you'll find every adjustment you can think of in the settings menu.  So overall, I rate the LG's picture very good despite The Flaw.This LG is one of the many new TVs that use glossy screens.  Glossy screens give a more vivid and colorful picture than non-glossy screens, but at a cost.  They are much more reflective.  Is a glossy screen for you?  Pretend your TV screen is a mirror.  If you're sitting on your sofa looking at that mirror, would you see a strong light source, like an unshaded lamp or a window?  If so, you'll prefer a TV with a non-glossy screen.This LG's audio performance is mediocre.  There is an EQ built-in the settings menu, but using it to boost the bass makes little difference.  The speakers just can't reproduce it.  While the audio is fine for dialog, I think LG assumes you'll use a sound system if you care about fidelity.3DThe LG uses passive 3D glasses.  They produce a good 3D viewing experience and have an advantage over active shutter glasses in that they are much cheaper to buy, don't use batteries, and are universal among brands.  Next time you see a Real D 3D movie in the theatre, hang on to your glasses.  They work fine with this TV.  You get 6 pair of 3D glasses with this LG.  Your local Best Buy carries additional glasses from LG and Real D including kid sizes and clip-ons and high-priced premium stylish ones.Here's the part of the review where I expected to dismiss the 2D to 3D feature.  The LG, like many new BluRay players, will synthesize 3D from regular 2D content.  Darned if it doesn't work pretty well.  It's not as good as real 3D, of course, and you probably won't use it that much.  (Are you going to start watching CNN in 3D every night?)  But for a few choice programs, it's surprisingly good.There's a button on the remote that toggles 3D on and off with one button press.  All in all, LG has done everything possible to make 3D simple to enjoy with a minimum of fuss.  Push the 3D button, put on the glasses and eat your popcorn.Smart TVThis TV has apps, just like your smart phone.  There is no longer a menu where you adjust picture and sound settings.  There's an app that does that.  There are apps to switch inputs, search for available video you can download, browse the internet, turn 3D on and off, display media from your smart phone or computer, display the user's manual and on and on.  21 apps come preloaded on the LG, and you can download more.  Most of those are gateways to other content, including a lot of children's programming.  Most are free.You can get to the apps you've installed through the My Apps menu, or through the home screen which also has a "Premium" menu where you'll find Netflix, Hulu, Vudu, YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and more.  The "3D World" menu has a number of streamable 3D programs.  Most menu screens keep the program you were watching when you entered the home screen boxed in the upper left corner.  You can select it to close the menu and return to your program.LG's operating system seems rock solid, but some of the apps are buggy.  The internet browser, for instance, seems impressive at first with tabbed browsing and flash installed.  But some websites will lock it up, even to the point where it's difficult to make the browser quit.  And while flash is present, using it will bring a warning that you're using an old version and it won't be supported for long.  Another app, AccuWeather, gave me a face full of error messages when I tried to add Fort Lauderdale to my favorite cities.Still, LG has sent out at least one update since my set was built, so there's reason to believe the bugs will get squished eventually.Media Link allows you--theoretically--to view your computer's media files on the LG's screen.  It requires a third party app, Plex, to be installed on your computer.  I have a MacBook, and the Apple version of Plex crashed immediately when I launched it.  No Media Link for me!The RemoteLG has gone its own way with the remote control.  Instead of a wand with a zillion buttons, you get a wand with a few buttons that works like a Wii controller.  You wave it in the air to move a cursor on the screen.  It's clever, but I have gripes.First of all, the buttons are mostly surfaces flush with the face of the remote.  Also, there is no light or glow-in-the-dark lettering on the remote, so when it's dark, you're left to fumble about on a seemingly featureless wand.  I don't know how many times I've moved the cursor over the icon I want, then pressed the button only to have the muting come on.  That's the button directly below the select button.While you're waving the remote around, it stays on.  When you're still for a few seconds, the remote turns off.  So if you're perusing the menus and pause to read something, the cursor will disappear and you'll have to shake the remote to get it back.  When this happens over and over, it gets annoying.  Also, if you take a swig of your drink, then bump the remote when you put down your glass, a big red cursor pops up on the screen to spoil the mood your movie was trying to build.While I struggle with this remote, everyone else in my household like it.  Pointing at icons on a big screen is much better for them than searching for the right button on a crowded remote.  Ordinarily, I put the original remote away and just use my universal remote.  Not this time.  Everyone but me wants the LG remote.  It stays on the coffee table.  But I'm not out of luck.Even though the LG remote is an RF remote, the TV accepts IR signals, so my universal remote will work with it.  Well, up to a point.  I can navigate using arrow keys, but there is no button to call up the "home" or "My Apps" menu.  The upshot is that I'll be able to do all the non-smart functions with the universal remote, but apps and on-line content will require the LG remote.The Bottom LineThe LG is a smart, easy-to-use TV with a lot of really cool features.  Picture quality is very good and highly adjustable.  Plus it's a handsome piece of hardware with its thin frame and nearly all-glass face.  Yes, I have a few gripes, but there were plenty of cool surprises to offset them.  Five stars.

I like this Swingline shredder.The Swingline works like other sheet-fed shredders, but the new idea here is the Stack-and-Shred concept.  Instead of feeding paper to it, you use it like you would a dishwasher or washing machine.  Open the lid by pulling on the release that looks like it should be pushed like a button, stack your papers in the tray and push the lid closed to start the cycle.Just like a dishwasher, you have to understand a little about how the machine works to get the best results.  If you put a glass in your dishwasher open side up, it'll just fill up with dirty water.  Similarly, when you're loading papers in the Swingline, keep in mind the position of the feed rollers.  If you stack a bunch of standard size sheets in the tray and then decide to put in an envelope, place it so the rollers will grab it when its turn comes.  If you put in stapled sheets, when the bottom sheet gets grabbed the staple will drag all the other sheets in with it causing a jam.Just like every other shredder, shreds fall in the bin directly under the cutters, making a pile.  Pull the drawer out and shake back and forth to knock down the pile before a big job.My Stack-and-Shred has worked flawlessly, never jamming (except when I wanted it to, more on that later).  I've fed it folded sheets, wrinkled sheets, torn sheets, small sheets, envelopes, legal sheets folded over and more with no problems.  Only card stock threw it off.  The rollers couldn't grip it.  It's quiet.  It goes to sleep automatically (basically it just turns off its power LED), has a huge 5 gallon bin and is always ready.I did intentionally jam the Swingline.  I loaded an old instruction manual about " thick in the tray that I knew the Swingline couldn't handle to see what would happen.  Well, jams from the load tray can be pretty ugly.  When you open the lid, than cuts power to the cutters and rollers, so you can't use reverse mode to help you pull jammed paper free.  It took me several minutes of tugging to finally pull the jam free.  Keep in mind that I caused a really huge jam and you would only get a jam like that by trying.Silly stuff:  This shredder comes with one paper bin liner.  If you like it you can go to swingline.com and find that they're priced at $14.95 for 20, but they are not available!  The Stack-and-Shred 80X is supposed to handle staples and paper clips, but once you have the instructions in hand, they tell you to remove them "to extend the life of the product."  The "80" in the name refers to the number of sheets the tray is supposed to be able to hold.  At 3/8" to the max fill line, I doubt you could get 80 sheets in there unless you are shredding brand new copy paper.The Swingline Stack & Shred 80X can shred 6 sheets at a time at the throat and has an 8 minute duty cycle with a really long 90 minute wait between those 8 minute cycles.  Also, the shreds are about 7/32" wide x 1 ¾" long.This isn't the heaviest duty shredder for the money out there, but who cares?  When the machine is feeding the sheets for you, you don't really care if it does them one at a time.

I kind of expected to be underwhelmed by earbuds built by a computer accessory maker that claim great sound quality.  But there's no denying the sound these things produce.  The sound is rich and detailed and nicely balanced.  The bass is deep but not at all boomy (a huge peeve of mine).  Highs soar and the midrange vocals land right where they should, neither buried in bass and treble or pushed out and nasal.  Sound snobs like me better learn some new brand names.I do have a few quibbles with the way these work with my iPhone.  iPhone earbuds and earbuds designed to work with iPhones use a tiny mic/remote hanging a few inches below your right ear.  It's easy to find without looking and easy to operate by feel.  Logitech separates the mic from the controls which are further down the cord.  You must look to find it and once you have it in hand, you'll find yourself feeling around for the button unlike Apple style controls where the whole thing is a button.  Once you find the button, you'll notice it's squishy and less clicky than brand A making it harder to double and triple click.  Also, the Logitech controls have a volume thumbwheel on it, rather than controling the volume output by the phone.  I'm guessing this was done to make these earbuds universal rather than just Apple compatible.  If the controls aren't the best, at least they work, and they work with a wide range of devices.The five sizes of silicon ear cushions that come with these earbuds is really a nice feature.  I was able to maximize noise isolation, comfort and sound quality by experimenting with different sizes.  It makes quite a difference.  Turns out I'm a XS.The case is just a plastic clam shell with a stressed plastic hinge, but it's silicone lined on the inside and works just fine.  Logitech says their flat cables resist tangles.  I'm not sure they're much better than other good quality wires, but they're certainly better than Apple's awful, tangle-prone wires.If sound quality is important to you, I'm betting that you'll really like these earbuds.

I like this wallet. One neat trick is that if you open it and set it down on a hard surface, it'll stand there with your cards fanned out for easy retrieval and replacement.I've had mine for several months now, and it's holding up well. I was concerned that the latch would wear out, but that hasn't happened. It has gotten a few scratches from being in my pocket with my keys.You should be aware that you can't carry as much in it as you can in a fat leather wallet. Money has to be folded into quarters to fit. And if you drop this wallet on a hard surface, the contents will scatter.Still, I like this wallet for it's small size, sleekness and refusal to absorb sweat and odors.Update: Be sure you are getting a genuine Ogon and not a knock-off.Mine is about three years old now. The clasp is still as firm as the first time I used it. I've dropped this wallet, overstuffed it and generally abused it and it has held up well. Much of the finish has worn off from scraping against my car keys, but otherwise this wallet's been great.

This is an interesting device that will keep you informed of the energy usage by the appliances in your home.  It's an intriguing idea and would be valuable asset if it weren't so darn cumbersome.  This thing is 12" round making it too big for a permanent installation almost anywhere.So first of all, this device is only for iOS users.  If you qualify, and you have the space for this thing, here's what the UFO Power Center can offer:The best thing the UFO does is report--to two decimal places-- how many watts each device plugged into it is using.  Reporting down to the hundredth of a watt is a bit silly when reported accuracy is +-2%.The UFO can act as a remote switch.  Except that there is no override--or any controls at all--on the device itself.  So if your roommate wants to turn on a lamp he should wait for you to come home with your iPhone to do it?The UFO can eliminate power draws from electronics in stand-by mode.  You can assign one of the four outlets on the UFO to be a "master" and one or all of the others to be a "slave" to that master socket.  When the component plugged into the "master" socket stops drawing power above a certain threshold, the slave sockets are shut off.  That stops the small power drain than some electronics consume all the time.  But keep in mind that some components need that trickle of electricity to keep their settings.  This is less common in newer electronics, but check anyway.  Still, anything with a clock, or a DVR that needs to record even if you're not watching, or anything that loads and maintains a programing guide will be undone by the lack of standby power.Also, keep in mind the UFO itself draws 1.9 watts.  If you're using it to stop a 1.5 watt drain, you're behind by .4 watts.Also, keep in mind that the UFO is not a surge protector.  The instructions make a point of telling you not to plug it in to a power strip, so if you go by the rules, you'll be giving up surge and noise suppression.Finally, you can schedule each of the four outlets to go on or off on a daily basis, or set-up a one-time switch.  Again, not overridable by a person not holding the iPhone with the Energy UFO app in it.The software is slick and it is interesting to see how much juice any given appliance uses.  And looking at the website you can see how proud the company is of the UFO's Italian design.  But honestly, where would you install this thing?

The Speck Candy Shell Satin case for the iPhone 4/4S is an improvement on the regular Candy Shell cases, in my humble opinion.  The "Satin" part of this case's name refers to the finish on the hard parts of the case.  It feels slightly rubberized and softer than the other Candy Shell cases.  It's not rubbery enough to cling to your pocket fabric, but completely changes the feel of the case.The big thing for me, though, is that this case looks a lot more sophisticated and expensive than the non-satin candy shell cases.  I have the black/gray case, and it seems to say, "I'm the grown-up here."  That's probably not true of the garish purple/blue or the red/white cases, but it is true for the black/gray one.  If you agree, well that's too bad because I already have the black/gray Satin case and I don't want your iPhone to look identical to mine!The Candy Shell Satin has all the qualities and flaws of the other Candy Shell cases.  They fit snugly, protect well but don't add a lot of bulk and they don't get in the way when you're trying to plug in headphones or a dock connector.  The one thing to look out for is the very thin edge of the case between the home button and dock connector.  It can break, so avoid stress on that area.  Also the non-satin Candy Shells were very prone to scratching.  The Satin seems less prone, but I'll have to use the case a little longer before I know for certain.

This case is my favorite.  This is the revised version that has a larger opening for the camera so that the flash doesn't bounce off the edge of the case and spoil the picture.This is a one piece case, the silicone and hard shell are molded together.  To protect your iPhone, Just press it into the case.  It fits snugly and feels secure and solid.  The silence switch is a little harder to reach.  (For me that's a good thing.)  And all the other switches feel pretty much the same.  Not nearly as rubbery as you'd think.  The front glass is protected by a raised rubber ridge all the way around.  The connector opening is nice and large.  There is no silly cut out to display the Apple logo on the back of the phone.  I think that's a plus, but that's just my opinion.This case strikes a balance that I like between protection and usability.  There are more impenetrable cases out there that have the silicon layer on the outside, gripping your pocket fabric every time you reach for your phone, and rubber plugs you must hold out of the way whenever you plug in the dock connector or headphones.  This case makes me feel like it probably won't be a disaster if I fumble and drop my iPhone on the sidewalk, and that's what I was looking for.One quibble.  The case itself scratches fairly easily.  You'll need to carry it in another pocket than the one your keys are in.Update:  The case broke.  The very thin part of the case above the connector opening is also where you tend to grab the case when picking the phone from your pocket.  The shell layer snapped on one end of that very thin cross member, but the silicone is holding it in place.  I still like this case, but be aware this is a vulnerable spot, and don't put pressure on it.Update to the update:  I bought another Speck iPhone 4S case.  This case came with instructions for removing the phone, asking users to pry the top out first so the rest of the phone can "angle out easily."  I guess I'm not the only one to break that very thin piece at the bottom!  I would add that you should avoid grabbing that very thin part of the case when plucking the phone from your pocket.BTW, the new Speck Satin cases are extremely attractive in my opinion.  The black case with grey silicone is very handsome indeed!  Much more sophisticated looking than the candy shell.

Ooh baby!  This is the one I want!  This chair is absolute comfort.  This chair looks a bit pricey on paper, but I'm absolutely thrilled with the comfort and support it brings.This chair came packed poorly in one big box.  the base, center strut and hardware bag was in the bottom of the box covered by a sheet of cardboard and then the main chair assembly.  There was also a sheet of foam just laying there not cushioning anything.  Nevertheless, my chair arrived in perfect condition.  The only instructions included are assembly instructions.  Kinda strange because putting it together is the easy part.  Press the casters into the base, put the strut into the base and then all of that into the bottom of the chair.  That's it.  You might need help if you can't lift somewhat heavy things.There are no instructions for operating the chair.  Looking at all the controls, I felt like grandpa trying to operate a Japanese toilet for the first time.  Here's a rundown of the adjustments available.  On each side of the chair there is a knob with a paddle just behind it.  On the right side, the knob adjusts the recline tension and the paddle adjusts the chair height.  On the left, the knob locks the recline in whatever position it's in when you locked it while pulling the paddle allows the seat bottom to slide forward and back.  underneath each armrest, just forward of the support, is a button that allows you to adjust the armrest up and down.  under the base of the armrest support is a flip down lock that allows the armrest to move in or out.  The seat back adjusts up and down by simply lifting it up.  It ratchets up as you lift.  When you pull it all the way up it releases so you can lower it again.  There may be other adjustments I'll discover later, but for now, I think that's it.  Once you know where things are, it's easy to use.The fabric seems a little too light to be called "carob" but I like it.  Overall, an A+!

I really like this oven.I live in Florida where it doesn't make a lot of sense to fire up your main oven for every job.  Being able to throw a frozen pizza in this little guy makes for a more comfortable home.I like the size.  It's big enough for just about any job you want to give it, but takes no more counter space than it has to.  And I like the speed.  Since this is a convection oven, it's a lot faster than a regular oven.  So if your pizza says to bake for 22 minutes, you better start checking it at 15.  Things can and will burn, and the mess can be ugly.Toaster ovens aren't vented as much as full-sized ovens are, so if you burn something you'll get an ugly smoked door and window.  I've had a little luck getting some of the smoke damage off with Magic Eraser, but it's tough.  So it's really best to remember that this is a fast convection oven and take care not to burn anything.  One other thing; the top of the oven gets very warm.  If you leave a loaf of bread on top of the oven while it's in use, you'll be cleaning up melted bread wrapper.Like all toaster ovens, this one is hard to clean.  Once the crumb tray or roasting pan are soiled, they're stained for life.  Hey!  Oven makers!  How 'bout putting a non-stick coating on those pieces!This little oven bakes surprisingly evenly.  If you look for uneven cooking hard enough you'll find it.  For instance, the pizza cheese under the heating element will be a little more brown.  But it's slight enough not to be a problem in my opinion.  I've used this oven for frozen pizza, frozen french fries, meatloaf, broiling french soup, bagels and, oh yes, toast.The one quibble I have with this oven is that the knobs are a bit stiff and fairly smooth which makes them a little hard to use if your hands are wet.  The timer knob has a "stay on"  setting left of the "off" position.  This has fooled a friend of mine who cranked the timer all the way to the left trying to turn the oven off.  Good thing there's a pilot light right under the timer knob to show absolutely whether the oven is on or off.  My confused friend simply pulled the plug rather than burn the house down.Good friend.  Nice oven.

As a Mac user, I was anxious to give the Seagate FreeAgent GoFlex Desk a spin.  My good friend recently tried one with his iMac to hold his iTunes library and had problems.  I recently tested the Seagate Expansion external drive and found it to be reliable and glitch-free, and thought the GoFlex drive would be a slightly more deluxe version of that problem-free drive.Unfortunately, that's not what I found.I installed the provided software, choosing to use the drive as a Mac and Windows compatible drive.  Doing this installs Paragon NTFS for Mac.  Paragon is a driver for the Mac that allows it to read and write files on a drive formatted with a NTFS partition for Windows computers.  I rebooted and found my rock-solid, reliable MacBook replaced with a clunky crash box.  After struggling past two crashes and reboots, I was handed my very first ever kernel panic!  The culprit was the Paragon driver.  I got up and running long enough to run the uninstall software for Paragon, and my MacBook returned to it's usual self.  Whew!Though my computer crashes were over, the drive crashes were not.  The Seagate GoFlex will run from nine minutes to 2 hours then simply freeze.  I though it might be going to sleep, but the drive continues to spin and the lights stay lit.  It simply stops responding.  It will not even eject.  The application using the drive at the time will freeze, and any application you may try to launch that polls the drive--Disk Utility or Activity Monitor--will freeze and be unable to launch.  The only way out is to unplug the drive without ejecting, and then plugging it back in for another few minutes of use until it locks up again.  This is identical to the problem my friend had with his GoFlex on an iMac running Snow Leopard.  I am running Lion on a MacBook Pro.I have reformatted the drive, reinstalled Seagate's software and uninstalled Seagate's software all with the same results.  I have checked that I have the latest software from Seagate, and I have checked that this Seagate is in fact supposed to be compatible with my computer and OS.  Seagate says yes.  I've looked for help on Seagate's trouble shooting pages where the bulk of the advice is to check the cables.  And I've looked to Seagate's forums where I found others that have similar problems, but no one that had an answer.This seems to be a problem for Mac users only.  I plugged this drive into a friend's netbook running Windows 7 Starter and the Seagate happily served up video for hours on end with no hiccups.  My advice?  If you have a Mac, or think you may ever have occasion to transfer to or from a Mac, stay away.Yikes!

I'm one of those guys who saves all his change and cashes in occasionally for an unplanned payday.  I broke my glass jug that I used for the purpose and went looking for a replacement.  If you save a lot of coins, glass isn't really the best choice because of the danger that heavy coins will break the glass.  Ceramic shards are much less dangerous.I was charmed by this little pig, from his cute little face to his curly little tail.  The glazing is plenty good enough with consistent color and no bubbles.  The non-skid feet do a good job of keeping him firmly planted.  My only worry is the plug which fits a little loosely making me wonder if it will hold when the pig is full of coins.Based on my experience, I'm gonna guess this little guy will hold about $250.  (That's IF you don't ferret out the quarters!)  I'm on my way to an unplanned payday someday.

Straight leg jeans does not equal (or, at least, it should not equal) skinny jeans.  I ordered the correct size and I've had other Lee jeans in that same size that have fit beautifully, but this style did not flatter me at all. It seems best suited for young, willowy girls or women. If you are a mature woman with hips that actually curve and legs that do not boast a significant "thigh gap," this style may not be for you.

I'm a real admirer of Donna Leon's writing.  I love her characters -- they are so expertly developed that they seem to acquire a third dimension -- almost rising out of the pages.  I could pick Guido, Vianello, and the Vice-Questore out of any crowd -- no problem!  I also admire Leon's writing style.  It's clean prose but very evocative. Her plots often involve timely subjects, treated with respect and intelligence.  Falling in Love is, like its predecessors, an excellent novel in many regards. However, in my view, it's not as thoroughly superb as many of her previous works.  For example, it has an uncharacteristically slow start. The pace does gather speed eventually.  The seed of discomfort is slowly sowed,  gradually grows into a threat,  and finally bursts forth into terror and murder. I have concluded the slow start was a deliberate device to show how adulation can become obsession; how obsession can become madness..  While the process may be gradual, fear can grow exponentially. Yet, after having so deliberately constructed the mood, after building an action-packed sequence that ratchets tension to a fever-pitch, Leon suddenly stops writing.  I was so disappointed at the abrupt ending, particularly since so many questions remain unanswered.  We know "who", but not really "why."  We certainly don't learn what happens next, or how the victim emerges from her ordeal To me, it's an unsatisfying and annoying way to end a psychological thriller.  In my opinion, it's an unworthy way to treat readers who have invested  time, money, and good faith in an author's work -- not to mention the emotional energy that we invest in the characters.  For this reason, I think this is only 3 1/2 stars.
Unusually comfortable shoes for dress occasions and quite beautiful, too.  The heel is not too high for long-term comfort but is a good height for formal dress. Love these shoes!!

Oh, this is a gorgeous gown!  It's difficult to describe the exact color, but I'll do my best -- it's an unusual shade for formal wear.  I don't expect to "see myself" in multiple iterations at the big event I am planning to attend. The gown is just that "different."
