The lining is a medium steel gray and the net overlay is an ashy-gray/brown (with more emphasis on the brown) -- the result is a mutable shade of taupe in some lights, and a slightly bronzy-gray in others -- but the over-all result is simply lovely.  The beaded embellishments are perfect for it -- more concentrated on the bodice and around the neckline, but gradually tapering off down the skirt.  The godets in the skirt move gracefully and the fit is spot-on for size.  It's a very flattering design and the color is, I think, an attractive choice for many women. The skirt is long, however -- I am 5'7" and even with heels on, I needed to have the skirt professionally shortened by over two inches.  That added an extra $60 to the cost of the gown. A final point: I was concerned about finding shoes that would go well with this gown -- silver wasn't right, and black looked too harsh -- but I found a perfect match in Adrienne Vittadini's Surya Dress pump in a pewter-gray (also on Amazon).

This is a study plastic tag that does not "jingle" on my dog's collar.  It is clearly and boldly inscribed with our personalized details so that, should it ever be necessary -- Heaven forbid! -- whoever finds our dog would have no trouble reading our contact information. I've purchased other tags (aluminum) that are harder to read (even when new) and the inscriptions soon become rubbed down and blurred.  I don't anticipate a similar problem with this dog tag -- at least, not for quite awhile. It's a good product that serves a good purpose.

This is an absolutely gorgeous work or art! The photo does not do justice to the intricacy of the stitches or the 3-D aspect of the composition.  The photo certainly does not capture the depth and gradations of the many colors of silk used to "paint" the scene.  It is framed in a simple black frame and matted in a neutral colored mat which enhances the art. The colors "pop" from within the frame. The simple choice of frame and neutral mat also makes these artworks fit into a variety of decorating styles - from contemporary to Asian-inspired to traditional decors. I am delighted with this purchase.

After using this cleaner for several months, I am reducing my original review to an edited 2 stars.  Here's why:  Yes, the DC59, marketed as the "Animal" cordless vac does an outstanding job of extracting animal hair from carpeting and upholstery.  I should know. I have 4 big dogs.  Mind you, they are not long-haired dogs, but they do shed, of course.  Still, the problem is not with the power of this little device, but its "finicky-ness."  Despite being made for the purpose of removing pet hair, my machine often gets clogged up and refuses to work. What an annoyance that has become!  Let me clarify that I use my Dyson Animal Ball vacuum cleaner for my regular heavy duty vacuuming (it's a wonderful, dependable workhorse) and the cordless vac for small touch-up jobs; eg, entry hall rugs, etc. But picture this scenario, if you will: you've just started working on an area rug with a cleaned-out canister, but seconds into the job, the machine starts making a very loud, whirring noise, closely followed by a halting "stop-and-start" action of the roller and the motor..  While you're wondering what in the world is going on, you notice the blue light on the side of the canister is flashing, and very soon the motor stops completely. A 4x6 area rug is only half cleaned.  This is happening to me all too often for my liking. It happened again today and the last time I pulled the cordless vac out to use.  And yes, I clean it thoroughly each time after use.  Amendment -- I clean it during use as well, for the canister fills up very quickly.  But this issue of blockages can occur anywhere in the device. When the situation described above occurs, the device must be disassembled and the hunt begun for the source of the blockage. I have even had to take apart the roller from the floor apparatus. I have never had to do this with any other of my vacuums (even the cheap one of my student days).  Why am I doing so with a Dyson now? Why am I doing it almost every time I try to clean with it?  This is not acceptable for any product. And this is certainly NOT why I paid a substantial amount of money for a top-tier product.  Indeed, the big reason I plunked down the money for this vacuum is because of my previous positive experiences with other Dyson products -- all of which have performed beautifully -- and because I wanted the quick convenience a cordless vacuum promised -- and not another time-consuming challenge in my life.Regarding the battery: Some reviewers think the charge doesn't last long enough, but I find that the charge (about 20 minutes or so) is sufficient for me to do my main level, high-traffic area rugs and still have some "juice" left. Mind you, you don't have to go over and over the same area in order to get it clean with a Dyson, so you are done more quickly than with most other vacuums (assuming, of course, that you haven't had to stop work to de-clog it).A final thought: Even though my machines are all deemed "Animal" -- it's hard to empty the pet fur from the canisters and around the filters.  Some kind of thin, soft brush is needed to clean it properly.  I see from my Instruction Manual that such a brush was to have been included, but alas, it was not in my case.  A bit of improvisation should do the trick, however.

This is a magnificent, multi-layered, and shamelessly romantic perfume. Gardenias feature heavily in this perfume but their sweetness is tempered with the spicy edge of sandalwood.  It is like a garden after a night rain -- the fragrance is intoxicating. I love it but would suggest using a light touch for daytime wear and perhaps a more generous application for a special rendez-vous.  It's magical!

I have a vacation rental property -- let me assure you I have purchased multiple sets of cookware.  Previously, I had been lucky to get through a 4 month rental season without having to replace the pots and pans.  They receive heavy use and, often, a good bit of abuse . . . which brings me to the T-fal cookware.  This set has held up exceptionally well and it's well into the second year of use.  It is dishwasher safe (a huge plus), and reasonable use of metal utensils won't damage the finish (unless someone decides to carve meat while on the pan, of course). I have a gas stove in this house and I have found damage to previous cookware resulting from renters using too high a flame, but so far, the T-fal has held up very well. In my experience, no non-stick cookware is a lifetime investment.  Replacements will be necessary at some point, but even with hard use, I have been very happy with the T-fal Hard Anodized cookware.  I think it's the best performing non-stick on the market (and I have tried a good many -- and some that cost quite a bit more.) I'm sold on it.

I'm a Southern cook and my family loves fresh, slow-cooked collards and mustard greens.  I am also a busy woman who appreciates good products that can save me a bit of time in the kitchen.  I don't always have time to monitor a big pot of greens on the stove, so I've turned to my trusty slow cooker and, on a whim, tried this seasoning mix.  It is really quite a good substitute for creating a flavorful "pot likker" broth when you just don't have the time to devote to the process. My family raved about the results; I saved time and effort -- that's a five star win for this seasoning mix, in my book.

I bought these glasses for my husband as a gift and am very pleased with the heftiness of the glasses. However, I'm less impressed with the way the insignia is designed -- it is a metal disc that is merely glued to the glass. That makes these other-wise sturdy glasses delicate "hand-wash only" items, which rather defeats the purpose of everyday glassware. My husband likes them a lot -- so that is an additional "plus" in their favor. Practically speaking, I just dislike having items I have to remember to keep out of the dishwasher.

In my opinion, this is a scarf for cooler - not cold -- weather. I purchased it thinking it was a lighter, more summery scarf than it is.  Though the fabric is not heavy, it's important to note that the scarf is about twice the width of other warm-weather infinity scarves and that makes it bulkier to wear (and thus warmer) than I wanted for this time of year.  Also, despite realizing that monitors can distort colors, the site photo suggested to me that the colors were more vibrantly-hued than they really are.  It is an attractive pattern, but the colors are too muted for my taste -- some might even subjectively call them "dull." Even the black of the background is not as intense as the photo suggests on my screen. I love bright colors against a dark ground but this isn't really "It." Again, the scarf seems to me to be better suited for the Autumn color pallette, as well as for cooler temps.  Though I'm rather disappointed in the scarf, I still like it enough to keep it and wear it later in the year.  3 1/2 stars would be accurate.

I purchased this project bag as a birthday gift for a friend.  I have my own Lantern Moon project bag in another pattern and I have found it to be very useful and convenient in transporting a ball of yarn, the row counter, and a few other small items.  My friend, a fiber artist, was thrilled with the gift and especially praised the beautifully detailed patchwork border that graces the top of the bag.  The bag is well constructed, light-weight, but sturdy enough for its purpose.  If you are a knitter or crocheter -- or knows someone who is -- this is a wonderful accessory to have.

I think this is probably a 3 1/2 star novel for me.  I stress the "for me," because this sort of thing is such a subjective assessment.  Andrea Frazer's main detective and his partner are rather an odd couple -- a device that has become rather tired. DI Falconer is an often grumpy, fastidious, middle-aged bachelor who still deals with nightmares of his childhood under the thumb of the very formidable Nanny Vogel. His Detective Sgt. is a sloppy, happy-go-lucky family man.  I much prefer the DS. The author injects a dose of humor whenever possible, which is something that is often lacking in mystery novels.  While I don't object to that at all, I feel that sometimes the humorous situations seem awfully contrived and occasionally ill-timed. Mind you, the laughs are a counterpoint to a series of murders associated with a secretive religious sect. As I say, the light-hearted moments don't always work. Within the spectrum of British mystery novels, I'd place this novel pretty much in the middle of the road.  It's not grisly, macabre, or wallowing in gritty realism.  There is no profanity and any sex alluded to is not explicitly described. It's sort of a Midsommer Murders kind of offering, set in a vanilla-flavored British village.  The plot has a few surprises, though the prime suspect crumbles pretty quickly at the end.  Still, it's an enjoyable enough read.

I have read all of Clara Benson's novels and, generally, I like them.  They do vary in quality, I think.  Mind you, each was written for the author's own enjoyment and were only published after her death.  She seems to have been playing with different literary devices, scenarios, characterizations, etc. -- all of which is more than fair enough -- and some novels have succeeded better than others.  The Trouble at Wakeley Court is my least favorite because it's so predictable and two-dimensional.  The general time period for her novels is 1920s-early 30s. I'm not sure when this one was first written but it has a naive (and rather disparaging) notion of eastern European culture and political affairs.  The plot revolves around a teen-aged girl, the daughter of a Grand Duke, who is the heir apparent to a fictitious eastern European country, Morania This tiny nation is embroiled in constant border strife and political intrigue with an equally fictiitious neighboring nation, Krovodar.  When the Grand Duke learns of a Krovodarian plot to assasinate him, he sends his beloved daughter to boarding school in England, under an assumed name, for her own protection. Unsurprisingly, the Krovodarians have their spy network up and running and follow the young girl to England.  Enter Mrs. Marchmont, who has been tasked by the British government to "keep an eye on things" at the boarding school.  It's implausible from start to finish, and a number of the characters are absolute caricatures. However, as with all of Benson's works, there is a great deal of period charm and a couple of successful characterizations (most notably, Angela Marchmont's god-daughter, Barbara, who featured in another novel -- she seems completely real and quite refreshing. For "cozy" entertainment, it is still an enjoyable enough read, but the pace is sluggish, and the whole premise is pretty implausible.  I would recommend Benson's other novels before tackling this one.

I'm very happy with these earrings.  They are a rather uncommon shade for a gemstone, leaning more towards orange than the red that they are described as being. I'd call them a terracotta with brown undertones.  I emphasize the color because: 1) they aren't what I first associate with the color red (for me, that's an apple red) and 2) they aren't a fake-looking bright orange, either.  If you are paying for real gemstones, you want them to look natural.  And these do.  As to size -- the site says to expect a minimum total weight of about 1 carat. But mind you, the density of gemstones differs, so the carat measurement is not always a useful estimator of size.  I'm not a jeweller and I can't accurately address the weight of the stones I received, but as to their size, they were a bit smaller than I had expected. (Despite my caveat above, I had used my diamond engagement ring as a way to "guesstimate" the size of the individual studs --- the 5 mm length that the site describes is just too hard for me to visualize.) I had expected stones about the diameter of a standard No. 2 pencil eraser.  Mine are a bit smaller than that, but I must emphasize that they are still big enough to make a visual impact. I wear mine as a second set of studs, higher up on my ear, so these are perfect for my purpose.

This is expensive but I feel that it's worth it, especially when I think of what I've spent on other products only to abandon them when they failed to deliver.  Deep wrinkles are not a problem for me and neither are dark circles, so my review addresses only the puffy incipient bags that have been "growing" under my middle-aged eyes.  Many of the previous eye creams that I've used did a fine job of moisturizing the eye area but they were too rich and heavy and, thus, seemed to make the puffiness worse.  I did find a product to moisturize the area that I liked -- it's a Vitamin C eye gel and very light weight.  But still, the puffiness -- while certainly no worse -- was not much better, either. And so, in desperation, I tried this product, based on its many positive reviews. I'm no chemist, but I reasoned that the caffeine in the tea would be helpful in reducing the swelling.  After trying this product for two weeks, I can see an improvement in my under-eye area.  I doubt that there is any cream that will act as a "magic wand" to erase the puffiness, but this one has certainly made enough of an improvement that I am very pleased, indeed.Update; I have been using this product for over 6 months now -- and I still believe it to be the best eye cream I've ever tried.  (And it lasts a long time, too!)

I am a big fan of C. J. Sansom's Shardlake historical mysteries.  This is yet another triumph.  The author has chosen a fascinating era (Reformation England in the reign of Henry VIII) and he treats the history with respect.  This isn't a simplistic approach to the Protestant/Roman Catholic religious struggle but a nuanced treatment of the complexities of the times and how those issues affected the lives of ordinary people. Lawyer Matthew Shardlake, now a prestigious Sargeant at Law at Lincoln's Inn, has been asked by a powerful personage at Court to find a missing religious manuscript which, if it fell into the "wrong" hands, could mean the death of another Queen for treason and an ensuing shift in the balance of political power at Court. Reluctantly, Shardlake agrees to help, thus becoming ensnared by a mare's nest of intrigue, spies, and murder.  Against this backdrop, Shardlake must revisit his own thoughts on faith, friendship, and honor. It's a long book -- no quick read -- but it is rich, detailed, complex, and fascinating.  As with Sansom's earlier works, I was reluctant to see this novel end.  That's the highest praise I can offer.

This is a great building block in one's 3-season wardrobe -- it can go casual, professional, or dressed up, depending on the accessories. I purchased this dress to go with a white suit jacket that I already had -- it looks so crisp and sophisticated. But I was also delighted to see how well it looks on its own.  On me, the fit is a bit loose for the size.  I exchanged it for the next size smaller and it fit beautifully.  I'm very pleased with this purchase.

I have never thought of myself as a Birkenstock person.  I am definitely in the pretty-spangly-jewelled-sandals-for-summer-camp, but sometimes, needs must.  I have recently had leg surgery that has meant, during the recovery time , that comfort and support in my shoes is an imperative.  I am astonished at how good these sandals feel -- from the very instant I put them on they felt great -- and now there is a wide array of choices in color and, increasingly, in style.  No need to sacrifice good looks in footwear for extraordinary comfort. I purchased the silver metallic sandals and, with a bright new pedicure, I'm still ready to sparkle at the beach or around town.  Once I'm back to dancing gigs again, I expect I'll keep reaching for these sandals when I have to be on my feet a lot. Or maybe, just 'cause I like them. One important note, though, these tend to run a bit large. Thanks to other reviewers' helpful comments, I ordered a size smaller than I usually wear and they fit perfectly.

LIke Margaret Frazer's other Dame Frevisse mysteries, The Boy's Tale is excellent.  It is well-researched historical fiction at its best. The author creates a vibrant world for the reader within the confines of a medieval Benedictine convent.  The characters are beautifully wrought, complex, believable, relatable; the plot is well- constructed and keeps the reader guessing and the setting is evocative and unusual.  The irony is that within the walls of the convent, deliberately created to keep out the world, an entire other world thrives with many of the same rivalries, conflicts, and jealousies that exist outside the convent's walls. Despite the nuns' best intentions, however, the outside world still intrudes -- in this novel, it intrudes suddenly and violently.  How Dame Frevisse handles these unbidden secular realities, manages to investigate several murders, and maintain her spiritual grounding is rather marvelous.  It's a compelling mystery and I highly recommended it.

This scent does not disappoint --- I have vivid memories of my high school years in central Florida where orange groves were still prevalent.  In the spring, the heady scent of orange blossoms on the breeze was magical.  So often, distilled fragrances leave something to be desired -- but not this one.  It conjures perfectly the sweet, light scent of orange blossoms.  It is not heavy or cloying.  As with other citrus oils, the scent doesn't linger as long as some other scents do, but no matter -- this is memories in a bottle.  Love it.

I have tried so many eye creams and serums and until now haven't been thoroughly happy with any one of them. I don't have problems with dark circles or deep wrinkles around the eyes, but as I've gotten "less young," I've developed puffier eyes, especially in the morning. A number of the eye creams that I've used did a good job in moisturizing the eye area and discouraging wrinkles, but some have been so heavy and greasy that I feel they've made the puffiness much worse.  I stopped using them for several weeks and, sure enough . . . Still, I don't want to leave this delicate eye area unprotected.  Oz Naturals Eye Gel goes on lightly; it's not greasy; the puffiness has not worsened but has improved overall.  I use it twice a day and it does not pose a problem with eye makeup.  (Some of my previous creams caused mascara to smudge under the eyes.)  In general, this product is so good that I've recommended it to my friends.

I collect cookbooks -- lots and lots of cookbooks.  My favorite genre is the modest, spiral-bound collections by local churches and community organizations. They provide not only some wonderful "real" recipes, but reveal such a friendly window into the local traditions and communities themselves.Thus, I was excited to get my hands on this Community Cookbook by Southern Living which is meant to cull some of the best recipes and features from those little local gems. Scattered throughout this book are a number of side-bar "chats" concerning interesting related topics and hints, and a good array of "real" Southern recipes from real Southern cooks. Five stars for that. An effort was made to recreate the neighborly quality of the originals. The graphics and page lay-outs are cute and unpretentious, but in my opinion there's too much emphasis on the graphic design and not nearly enough on the readability of the text itself. Someone was really wedded to the  "optics" of the book -- and it succeeds in offering an artistic vintage "feel". But a cookbook is of little practical use if one cannot easily read the recipes. That seems a fairly obvious concept, but in this case, I believe it was often overlooked in favor of artsy typescript and spidery fonts.  A multiplicity of different font types is used throughout the book (some which are meant to look like script, suggesting a hand-written recipe -- cute, but not clear).  Also,the pages are printed in different pastel colors -- very pretty -- but some of these background  colors make the type even harder to discern.  In strong natural light, there isn't a big problem with the type, but in a real dinner-time scenario with the book sitting on the counter and artificial light and shadows from cabinets factored in, it's frustratingly hard to read. I have good eyesight and do not need to wear prescription glasses, but I cannot easily refer to some of these recipes without moving the book to a direct light source or grabbing the pair of magnifier glasses I keep around for detailed work.  And that is not appreciated by a busy cook -- at least, not by this one.  In fact, this is so annoying a problem to me that what should be a favorite "go-to" resource has been significantly reduced in its usefulness to me. 1 star, then, for the poor print.  As to the recipes themselves, they do represent a nice variety of the old and new.  There are a few really stellar recipes included, such as Gumbo Z' Herbes and Crook's Corner Shrimp and Grits, (both chef-submitted recipes,) and believe me, they are absolutely awesome! There are also a number of predictable and somewhat-tired standards present, like Pimento Cheese,  banana pudding, and congealed salads -- recipes that one will find in any and every self-respecting southern cookbook. On the other hand, there are also some newer variations on traditional themes, like Hoppin' John Salad and Slow Cooker Pork and Pinto Chalupas. Further, there is a sprinkling of recipes that reflect the vibrant, changing demographics and cultural sharing of the New South; for example, Tempura Dill Pickles and  West Indies Salad. 4 stars for the array of recipes. Like all of Southern Living's productions, the photography is first-rate --absolutely luscious -- another 5 stars for that. I'd have preferred more photos (or even more recipes -- there is a treasure-trove of good cooking in those little spiral cookbooks upon which to draw material) -- and far less of the cuteness. Overall, then,  I'm settling on 3 1/2 stars. There are some really good aspects to this book but the readabiity issue is a major drawback for me.  I hope any future editions will rectify that problem.

We received a gift of Dallmayr coffee in a gourmet Christmas basket and loved it.  It didn't last long.  The flavor was full-bodied but oh-so-smooth.  We decided to branch out and try some of Dallmayr's other varieties.  The Dyawa Antara is also excellent -- robust, but not acidic.  It's just as delicious first thing in the morning as it is as an after-dinner treat.  Highly recommended to those who savor their coffee.

Oh, this is elegant and evocative! It's an old favorite, rediscovered.  It's a curious thing: I saw a review by someone who thought it was "an old lady's" fragrance.  I'm not quite sure what scent that reviewer might be thinking of -- but it is clearly a negative connotation.  Nothing is farther from my mind when I wear this perfume! It's so exotic and mysterious -- and sensual! It's quite unlike any other perfume that I am aware of.  There is a "powdery" aspect to it, but it's certainly not of the canned talcum variety! I think of green, mossy scents, mixed with spices and aromatic woods.  I first wore this scent as a young woman and I received so many compliments on it.  I'm not an "old woman" yet, but I started wearing more floral scents for a number of years.  I "rediscovered" Mitsouko and wondered what was I thinking to stop making this my signature fragrance.  It's lovely and so singular.

Beautiful! The item arrived swiftly and very well packaged.  The plate is a stunning example of fine parian china -- light, translucent, and deceptively delicate looking (but it is strong and durable).  If you are an admirer of Belleek, this bread plate will be a fine and practical addition to your collection.

I'm not a big bath oil fan, generally.  I hate the residue that oil leaves in the tub, so a product has to be pretty special for me to want the extra clean up effort after a hot bath.  This is worth it, I think.  The fragrance is clean, herbal, pleasant.  I've heard it called "medicinal" -- I wouldn't argue with that assessment, though I personally don't perceive it that way. Scent is such a powerfully emotive thing -- we all  react differently -- but EOV strikes me as having more of a spa-like connotation. "Clean" is the adjective that keeps coming to mind, as well as "relaxing." If you don't want the hassel of slippery tubs -- you can still use this product right after a shower. Just lightly apply the oil to still-damp skin. Why not 5 stars instead of 4? That's my personal bias against bath oil.  It does leave a slippery residue in the tub; however, in this particular case, I like the product enough to put up with it.

This is a stunner! The colors are magnificent, jewel tones -- not garish, but rich and beautiful. The wool is wonderfully soft and tightly woven.  I gave this throw as a Christmas gift and the recipient was over-the-moon with it.  Very highly recommended

The general consensus of the whole family is that Season 2 is even better than was the excellent Season 1.  If you enjoyed the first season, you 'll be enthralled with the second.  The actors are terrific, but seem even more comfortable with their characters.  There's a seamlessness about them --  you don't see the actor, but each character is vibrantly alive.  This is particularly true for Travis Fimmel, who manages to convey so much with just a swift, fleeting expression in his eyes. The drama is tightly woven, combining history, legend, human insight, powerful action, suspense, betrayal, and deep, personal conflict -- all with a backdrop of the most glorious scenery imaginable.  It is a powerful, excellent series.  It must be said, however, for those who are sensitive to violent portrayals -- this has graphic violence in abundance. You must use your own best judgment on this issue, but know that  what is portrayed is not done in a gratuitous manner. It is not meant merely to shock; but rather, it is appropriate to the subject matter. But it may not be appropriate for you or your family.
Love these coasters!  The stone effectively absorbs the condensing moisture from glasses and the William Morris designs are bright and very attractive.

I've reviewed a number of Ann Cleeves' novels, and I have liked them all very much, indeed.  The George Palmer-Jones series, of which Murder in Paradise is the second offering, is quite different from her more famous Vera Stanhope series.  One of the things I admire most about Cleeves' work is her incisive observations and detailed, plausible characterizations.  This novel certainly has those qualities in abundance.  Next, there's her ability to create environments so real, they are almost tangible.  The sparsely populated outer islands of Britain come alive in her works (I also recommend her Shetland Island series).  Cleeves and her husband are avid ornithologists and she has visited and, in fact, worked on some of these islands before her writing career took off.  Her experiences are transformed into very evocative settings for many of her novels.  I heartily recommend any and all of her books (I haven't yet read one that I didn't enjoy).  Focusing on Murder in Paradise, I would say the reader is in for a treat.  The standard mystery gambit of the secluded setting, such as a country house cut off from its neighbors during a terrible storm, is transposed by the author into a small, outer island -- home to a great many birds,  a lot of sheep, and a very few crofters.  A young English nurse marries a man from Kiness island.  Entranced by a magazine's featured article about Kiness being a veritable "paradise," Sarah agrees to move with him back to the island and take up the life of a crofter's wife.  The reality is not nearly as romantic as Sarah imagined, though she gamely makes an effort to succeed in her marriage and in her new environs.  Soon after her arrival, the first death occurs on the island, then a second one soon follows.  Police from the mainland are ill-equipped to deal with the investigations and prefer to write them off as either an accident (in the first case) or as the result of alcohol-fueled island in-fighting. But George Palmer-Jones, retired Home Office official who liaised with the police forces, is also on the island. Palmer-Jones is an ardent "twitcher," or ornithologist.  He is quite convinced the deaths are linked and is asked by one of the local families to find the truth.  He asks Sarah, as the only other reasonably neutral observer on the island, to help him out.  Already a bit bored, she agrees. Not surprisingly, their probing questions ruffle a lot of feathers. Will Sarah ruin her own future by aiding Palmer-Jones? There is a good bit of atmosphere, psychological insight, an impressive creation of the crofter's world, and some quiet, but potent, suspense.  Action is a relative term here.  There isn't much in the way of overt action, but it's there on a more cerebral plane.  With very limited resources, Palmer-Jones gets to the truth of the matter.  This is an intelligent novel, with a more lanquid pace than some, but it keeps the reader's attention focused and compels the pages to turn. It's a very good choice.

First of all, let's deal with the negative. Yes, monitors vary and it's hard to determine color from the "sample" swatch that the manufacturer provides, but here's the thing: the lipstick I bought is called "Cognac" -- not "Island Orange" or "Vivid Tangerine," or such like.  So I thought I was getting a deeper shade, with some brownish tones.  When I opened the tube, I was so pleased to see the color I thought I was buying.  However, when I applied it on my bare lips, it went on as a much brighter orange than the tawny/coppery color in the tube. The difference is so extreme on me that I don't think I"ll be able to use this product at all. That is a disappointing two star problem -- at best. I am reminded of that curiosity from the drug store of my teen years -- the "magic lipstick" that would change color to suit your "perfect" shade. This Borghese one, at considerably more cost, doesn't do me any favors by turning orange, either. Still, the way the lipstick glides on,, and the way it feels when on the lips, is rich and luxurious -- five stars for that.  The basic product is a good one. However, I would suggest trying out these colors at a department store, if possible, before purchasing, to make sure you will be happy with the way the color looks on your lips.  And finally, I really wish companies (clothing and cosmetic companies, especially,) would make an effort to name their colors appropriately. What color, pray tell, does "Malibu" indicate? And "Cognac" isn't a tropical orange.  How tough can this be? Combined score would be a 3 1/2.

If you want to amp up your meal, these chipotle flavored panko crumbs can do the trick.  I have used them in a variety of recipes, but perhaps my favorite is to use them in my go-to gazpacho recipe.  They have a good kick to them, but are not overpowering.  They are not always easy to find -- many of my local grocery stores do not carry this flavor, so I rely on Amazon to help me out.

I'm a big fan of the Near East Taboule mix.  It couldn't be easier to create a good, basic taboule.  The flavors are well balanced in the spice mix, but with a noticeable presence of mint. To dress it up even more, I simply add some chopped mini cucumbers, perhaps a diced yellow bell pepper, and halved grape tomatoes. Even easier:  add some prepared bruschetta, and crumbled feta (not traditional, I know, but oh, so delicious).  The results always garner glowing compliments.  I have also found this to be a great choice for potlucks -- I always come back with an empty bowl.  This mix is a pantry staple at my house.

Clara Benson wrote during the Golden Age of British Mystery.  Her novels are charming as period pieces and as cozies -- but they typically don't offer much in terms of depth, sophistication, action, or even much suspense.  The Riddle At Gipsy's Mile is par for the course.  The characters are the most interesting thing about this novel, but even they are rather two-dimensional.  The plot revolves around our amateur detective, Mrs. Marchmont, an intelligent lady of rather secretive background, who stumbles upon yet another dead body. (She seems to find quite a number of them in the series).  The problem with this one is that the face has been destroyed (this is an unusually gruesome detail for a Benson mystery) and identification is difficult.  Mrs. Marchmont and the irrepressible Freddie Pilkington-Soames come to the rescue by conducting their own investigations.  Strangely, Scotland Yard doesn't seem to mind. . . As I say, this is a rather naive series, but it still makes for some mildly pleasant reading.

I'm very happy with my purchase -- the color is rich and elegant. I love it and the staying power is good. I'm less thrilled with the applicator tip that bends too easily for my liking.  The lip stain is thinner than a gloss so that makes application a little bit fussier. The wobbly applicator doesn't help matters.  A lip brush is good to have on hand with this lip stain.
I am pleased with my purchase; the bowl is small but it's well carved and the quartz is clear.  It makes a charming little dish for rings, a blossom, or a seashell from the beach.

Perfumes are such subjective things to rate that it seems almost unfair to try.  What smells heavenly in the bottle may not "wear well" on one's skin; and we all have our own preferences.  Having said this, I do like Grand Amour a lot -- it's a romantic, but not overly heavy floral scent.  I am a big fan of Annick Goutal's fragrances in general, but for me, Le Matin d'Orage and Gardenia Passion are my personal favorites.  Despite the sweetness of honeysuckle and lily, Grand Amour has a crisp edge to it, that's just a bit tart -- rather like the first bite of a green apple.  That's not an unpleasant thing, but it is a bit of a surprise.  This sharpness soon mellows on my skin, leaving a classic, heady, floral perfume.  Very nice, indeed.  If floral scents are your cup of tea, then I think you'll be pleased with it.  I have made numerous purchases of Annick Goutal perfumes via Amazon and have been pleased with each one.

I'm very happy with the quality of this garden flag.  After some unusually severe weather, the colors are still as bright as when first I purchased it.  The material is strong and is not fraying, regardless of the heavy winds we've been experiencing.  It's not often when a product exceeds expectations, but this one does.

It looked really cute in the photo, but the reality was not so great. It does fit, as expected, for size, but I'm just not all that happy with it.  It's a subjective point, but I feel uncomfortable with so many gathers in the sleeves -- (they didn't seem as exaggerated in the photo) --  thus, making me feel like I'm wearing football pads.  I also don't care for the texture of the fabric.  It drapes well, but it's thin and not woven as tightly as it should be. It can be too revealing in certain lighting  (a slip is definitely needed); ultimately, the fabric just doesn't feel very good to me.  The neckline is not secure and attaches only at the top of the waist band.  On my figure, it tends to gape open, so I've had to secure it with a snap closure. The color (purple) is a nice, deep shade, not too bright, and easy to wear.  .

This may well be a 5 star fragrance, for those who prefer more intense, opulent scents -- or for those who know exactly what they are buying -- but it's not at all what I expected from the product description.  As a result, I personally feel like this is a 3 star purchase for me.  I was searching for a new, warm weather scent -- something light and either softly floral or citrus-y.  I had heard great things about this fragrance, but I couldn't find an available tester in the department store to try out this scent. (Sadly, it seems that testers are disappearing in many stores, making it so hard to gauge how a fragrance might wear on each individual).  Instead, I had to rely on the product description which starts out by naming light, fresh essences, like pear, ruby red grapefruit, geranium, etc., with medium notes of rose and peony.  Hence, I thought this was what I was searching for. It isn't.  Instead, it is a complex, heavy scent -- not unpleasant, but rather overwhelming on me.  The product page suggests it is suitable for day wear.  I'm not convinced of that, unless one uses a very light hand in its application. It strikes me as far more appropriate for a romantic evening out.  It is a statement fragrance.  I'm compromising with 4 stars.

I have read a number of the Sister Frevisse medieval mysteries and have enjoyed them very much, including The Prioress' Tale.  Historical fiction is a passion of mine -- a "busman's holiday" sort of thing.  As a historian, I am particularly appreciative of the amount of research Margaret Frazer does for each of her books and the dividend to the reader is a lush, three-dimensional world that this gifted author creates as a result of her attention to detail.  Each of Frazer's plot lines revolve around a particular individual -- a sort of representative member of a medieval community: an abbot, a prioress, a midwife, a huntsman, etc.  It's sort of a modern mystery nod to  The Canterbury Tales, and illuminates the lifestyle and experiences of these people.  Further, the "detective" in each of these novels is Dame Frevisse, a very curious and intelligent nun from a small Benedictine priory. Dame Frevisse is an engaging character, a spiritual woman who is not unaware of the temporal world and must often navigate between the two realms.The tensions and moral quandaries she experiences in these endeavors is fascinating.  In The Prioress' Tale, Frevisse has a fraught relationship with her prioress, Domina Alys, who is a demanding, harsh, and often manipulative woman -- a woman with a ruthless personal ambition to build the priory into a richer and more "important" spiritual house (or, perhaps, simply as a monument to herself?)To this end, Domina Alys favors her kinsmen in a power struggle with another prominent landed family over disputed lands.  The presence of these armed relatives in St. Frideswell puts a terrible strain on the small community of nuns and on the meagre food stores they have accumulated.  Intrigue, violence, and murder ensue and it's up to Dame Frevisse to find those responsible and help steer her beloved convent back to it's true and peaceful purpose.  Like every other of her novels, the author peoples it with fully-developed and credible characters.  If you enjoy intelligent historical novels that are well-researched and boast polished writing -- The Prioress' Tale is an excellent choice, but truly, any of Margaret Frazer's novels will do the trick.

This is a vibrant print with great detail and texture.  The fabric is soft to the touch, with a linen-y feel.  For a vintage or a classically romantic bedroom, this is a wonderful choice. Highly recommended.

I am delighted by this dress.  The cut is quite flattering and the fit is spot-on for size.  The material is a jersey-like man-made fabric which is wrinkle-resistant and has a fabulous drape.  This is a great choice for travel.  I'm not over-the-moon about the graphic print but the colors are very attractive and, given the way this dress flatters my figure, I can deal with the mosaic pattern.  Highly recommended.

This bag is perfectly acceptable for the price -- but it's not "knock-your-socks-off" great.  I tend to spend substantially more on the bags I use often, but my purpose in buying this one is much more limited.  I wanted it to go with a color-blocked dress that boasts a stripe of hot pink at the hem.  As this is pretty much a one-off  occasion, I didn't want to spend a fortune on a matching bag.  This one fits the bill quite well. I have no problems with it.  It is a man-made bag, not genuine leather, but it is a good facsimile. Again, I chose the hot pink color, which is vibrant but not garish. It's a good medium sized bag, with sufficient room to take all the essentials plus glasses case, phone, etc.  All in all, I'm pleased with it -- just not blown away by it.

This lip stain is a rich, gorgeous shade.  Though it is a neutral, deep brownish color, there's a reddish tint to it that, when on the lips, makes them pop with intense, fashionable color.  It is a thinner liquid than I expected, however, so while it feels quite light to wear, the down-side of that thinness is that it's a little bit harder to control its application.  This is made worse by the applicator tip, itself.  It is flat on one side, pointed at the end, and it bends too easily for my liking. I find it a little less user-friendly than I would have expected from YSL.  Nevertheless, this is not a deal-breaker -- just keep a lip brush handy and you'll be good to go. I give 5 stars for the color and the staying power of this lip stain, 3 for the application; hence, 4 stars over-all.

I've read all of Anne Perry's Victorian novels and am a big fan of her work, in general.  Her earlier works are vibrant, absolutely alive with period detail and color.  They boast a swift tempo with action and suspense harmonized with romance and emotional insight. Her main characters are complex people who develop over time into seasoned and mature persons, credible and likable. The author's typically winning formula hasn't quite come together in this latest novel, in my opinion.  Indeed, her last several novels seem to be more languid and formulaic.  I wonder if Perry is simply getting bored with these characters and this time period?  Death on Blackheath seems tired and often turgid to me. There is a lot of repetitive inner musings by Pitt and not much in the way of real action or suspense.  As his investigation gets bogged down, so does the novel.  Pitt, the recently promoted head of Special Branch has been called in to investigate the sudden disappearance of a housemaid in the home of a naval weapons expert. As the naval race between Britain and Germany was gearing up at the end of the 19th century, it was feared that the maid's disappearance threatened dire implications for national security. That should have provided a tense and urgent scenario for the reader, but somehow, this book never really got off the ground for me.  There were so many thwarted avenues of investigation, not a lot of action, and Pitt's wife Charlotte, a spirited and clever woman who has played important roles in his earlier investigations, has a very limited role in this one. I think a number of Perry fans will find this novel not up to her usual standard, but as every Perry fan also knows, a ho-hum Perry novel is still better than a good many others.

While the basin of this birdbath is attractive,  my objection is to its over-all "design." The glass basin is affixed with glue to a disc of metal (about the size of a silver dollar) that screws into the narrow stand.  Well, within 5 minutes of putting it together, the basin came apart from the disc and fell onto the patio.  Amazingly it didn't shatter, but it is unusable as designed. You can put NO pressure whatsoever on the basin. Period.  I put my birdbath into loosened potting mix in an over-sized patio pot -- so you know I didn't have to put much effort into inserting the birdbath into the soil. In fact, I used the stand and my foot on its base to insert it.  The only "pressure" on the basin that I used was to straighten it -- apparently, that was sufficient to snap the glue seal and it soon tumbled to the patio.  I'm less than impressed with the flimsiness of this design.

Heads-up, folks! If you are tempted to buy the bundled group of coffee maker, water filter and permanent gold coffee filter featured on this page, please note that the cone filter (049-33) does NOT fit the Krups KM9008!  I discovered this the hard way -- I simply assumed that the featured filter was offered because it fit this machine and thought I'd be saving myself some shopping time by ordering it along with the machine. This machine requires a basket type filter and not a cone filter.  (I found that a standard Mr. Coffee gold basket filter for 8-12 cup coffee makers fits this model.)  As to the machine itself -- I am delighted with it -- it's very easy to operate and solves the problem of different "coffee times" within my family.  No more sludgy coffee sitting in the warming carafe. I noted that one reviewer complained of the temperature of the coffee produced, but I have found it to be piping hot even after it's been in the machine for close to two hours. Bottom line is this machine produces a delicious, hot cup of coffee. I think you'll be pleased with it.

I agree with the reviewer who said the title alone was a bit off-putting.  I had visions of "Brenda Starr, Reporter" with a modern, Swedish twist --but I was wrong.  This is a solid, well-crafted mystery with intriguing scenarios and some fine acting.  Malin Crepin does a very good job at making Annika Bengtzon come alive as a multi-dimensional real woman. The character development and fresh plots won me over as well. Without giving anything away, the first episode was a fascinating insight into the Nobel laureate selection process -- and what can be at stake. I haven't seen anything quite like this setting before.  So, there is a freshness about the series which surprised me.  I recommend it, especially to viewers who have enjoyed other quality Scandanavian mysteries like Irene Huss, Varg Veum, or Maria Wern.

I'm a huge fan of Lotus Moon's Vita A complex and on the basis of that, I tried the Pumpkin Enzyme Peel.  In no particular order, here are the pros and cons. First of all, there's the scent -- for me, I found it to be overwhelming.  I smelled like a Thanksgiving pie. Yes, that's a great scent when wafting from the oven, but it isn't what I want slathered on my face for any prolonged period of time.  Secondly, there isn't much product for the price.  I was surprised at how little was in the jar. They are quite clear that it's 1.5 ounces, but that's a bit hard to visualize.  It's a paltry amount, in my opinion, for a product that is meant to be used rather thickly all over the face and neck. Third, the results were pleasant -- my skin felt really good and smooth, but I've had similar results with other masks and scrubs -- for less money. There was nothing especially remarkable about the results I experienced from this product. The biggest plus, though, is that it's a natural product, made with integrity and without the addition of a lot of weird chemicals.  You can feel confident about that. While I'm torn between 3 and 4 stars, on the basis of the final "pro" -- I have to go with 4 stars -- and a caveat about the heavy fragrance.

These are very attractive, cork-backed placemats.  Let me be clear, though: they are not standard dinner-sized mats. While the dimensions were given (in millimeters), it would have been helpful to have included in the description the words "luncheon-size" or have given the measurement in inches, as well.

This is a great dog coat.  It has a water-resistant and wind-resistant outer shell and a warm fleece lining.  What I appreciate even more is that it is designed to accommodate a wide range of breeds.  Small, medium, and large size offerings don't necessarily tell you much if you are trying to fit a broad-chested dog. Neither do suggested measurements from collar to tail. I have a boxer/bull dog mix and he is really hard to fit.  If I find something that fits around his chest, the coat then hangs off him in the back and on the sides.  That would make for a terrible mess on his walks.)  The design of this coat, however, allows for extra girth around the chest by providing a wide (and longer than most) velcro band to customize the fit. I can then choose a size that better fits his over-all body size, too. Finally, the piece de resistance: he's now the best dressed dog on the UNC campus. Go Heels!

After a fair bit of research, I purchased this oximeter for a family member who suffers from clinical sleep disorders.  He has already completed a medical sleep study but was encouraged to keep monitoring his oxygen levels at home.  It has proven to be a really useful (and reassuring) piece of equipment. It features an alarm that sounds if oxygen levels drop below a certain level. Further, t registers and records important data which can easily be transferred to a laptop for long-term storage and analysis. With a click of a keystroke, all that information can be emailed to one's doctor.  That's been such a great help. The 4 stars, then, are not for the overall efficacy of the device -- it works perfectly when properly worn.  The problem is that the finger sensor can become dislodged if one is a more energetic sleeper.  I understand this is a general problem with many of these devices and our choice of this model took that into consideration. The wristband and the shorter cord that connects the sensor to the monitor seemed to make for a sturdier connection and a better bet for less disruption of data than other models offered.  Still, it sometimes comes loose during the night, anyway. The other finger clip monitors (especially the plastic ones without silicone cushioning) can be quite uncomfortable and they certainly can come loose or get knocked off during sleep.  Finally, with regard to relative costs: this is a more expensive model than a number of home-use oximeters on the market.  Depending on your purpose for purchasing this kind of device (e.g., sports performance analysis), you may not need to spend so much on an oximeter. For our purposes, though (the accurate data collection, ease of storing and conveying results, and comfort level of wearing the product throughout the night, etc.,) this was a very good choice. I'd give it 4 1/2 stars, if that were an option.

I had had my eye on this necklace and was delighted to receive it as a Christmas gift -- it's lovely.  The labradorite slices are well chosen for color and flash; the longer length of the chain makes this necklace very versatile. It can stand alone or be grouped with other chains for a more opulent look.  I would give it a full 5 stars for looks alone, however, I must mention that the chain is very fragile.  Within less than a day of ownership, as I was wearing the necklace, a link either broke completely or came dislodged from its neighbor and the necklace slid off -- 2 stars for that. The links are so tiny and delicate that it was impossible for me to try to reconnect them.  I contacted Amazon and they immediately sent me a replacement necklace (a sparkling 5 stars for customer service!). The second necklace was even prettier to me (the stones had more of the blue coloration that I love in labradorite.) I've been wearing the new necklace and have had no issues with it at all.  Overall, then, a solid 4 stars.

Okay, I was really skeptical from the outset. I've tried other pillow sprays that were supposed to promote gentle, sound sleep and while they smelled lovely, they did nothing to help me drift off.  This one did.  Let me be clear -- I do not suffer from chronic insomnia or any medical issue that causes sleep disruptions. Instead, I have those occasional nights when everyday problems, worries, and stresses seem to gang up on me and I toss and turn.  Of course, I wouldn't recommend this product to treat clinical sleep issues, but for "one of those nights" that we all have now and again, I found it to be genuinely helpful.  It doesn't make you sleep. I haven't noticed that I feel suddenly terribly drowsy -- but the next morning, I realize that I did, indeed, fall asleep pretty quickly the night before and stayed asleep.  It's been a stressful few days recently, and each evening that I've used this spray, I've experienced some gentle sleep help.  The night that I didn't use it, I went back to my restless, wakeful tossing.  I'm pretty astonished, but I'll be buying another bottle of this stuff soon. I hope it helps you, too.

I connected several strands together for a gorgeous garland for my Christmas tree.  The crystals caught and reflected the tree lights beautifully.  The individual crystals are multi-faceted and connected to each other with metal jump rings.  This makes it very easy to connect the strands.  Though the jump rings are fragile, I had no problem with any segments coming apart.  I'm very happy with this purchase and recommend it to others.

Over the years, I've thoroughly enjoyed Elizabeth George's Inspector Lynley mystery novels. I've admired her writing and looked with anticipation to her next offering in the series. Therefore, it's hard for me to believe that I could be as disappointed in one of her books as I am with this one. The pace of the action gets bogged down with many highly-detailed descriptive passages; further, established characters are suddenly behaving out of character.  This is especially true for the singular Barbara Havers. Her behavior now seems so implausible, out of control, and outlandishly unprofessional that it beggars belief. (And, speaking of improbabilities -- the aristocratic Lynley has developed a fascination for women's roller derby, no less!!! How very bizarre!) There are new characters who figure prominently in this novel but it's hard to care much about them. I suspect this has something to do with an over-abundance of descriptive detail. For the first time ever with an Elizabeth George novel, I got bored and had to put the book aside. Frankly, it was hard to get motivated to pick it up again.  A good portion of the novel takes place in Italy, one of my favorite places. That should have proved delightful reading (shades of Donna Leon and Christobel Kent) -- but it did not. In addition to the seemingly endless descriptions of Lucca (which seem better suited for a travel guide than a mystery novel), George inserts many Italian words and phrases into her writing. Yes, Italian is a beautiful and lyrical language and I appreciate that the author might have wanted to give her Italian chapters an authentic flavor; still, I'm afraid she only managed to break up the flow of her prose. For those of us who don't speak fluent Italian, it gets annoying. It is not always clear from the context what all the words mean. Does one stop reading to go online for a translation? Or say, "The heck with it!" and plow ahead anyway? In any event, it seems to be a pretentious affectation by the author.  If you have not yet read any of  Elizabeth George's works, please don't start with this book.  Her previous novels are so good, so well-written and richly nuanced that I find it hard to believe this is the same writer at work.  Sadly, two stars are the best I can muster for this one.

I'd award this product 2 1/2 stars, if that were an option.  It's definitely not "okay" in my book but it's better than 2 stars.  I have been using ceramic butter crocks for years and finally had to retire my old one only when I dropped the bottom reservoir and it broke.  I thought the marble would be a good sturdy choice while keeping the water and butter even cooler than pottery would do.  It's also an attractive piece.  It became quickly apparent that I'd made a mistake.  Until I broke my old butter crock, it never leaked or left a ring on my counter or table.  This marble one does.  I can find no hairline crack in the marble -- it appears to be all of one piece -- yet it still leaves a significantly wet ring  where ever I place it.  I'm guessing it "sweats" and that's what is responsible for the moisture.  I now leave it on a small saucer (not really a great look, but it solves the problem).  It's the day after Christmas and I can't be bothered to stand in any more lines to return this item at the post office -- but I will be retiring it soon and returning to the good old ceramic crock.

DC has never quite had the same success with team comics that Marvel has.  Marvel has the Fantastic Four, Avengers and X-Men, all of which have been running more-or-less continuously for five decades (except for an early '70s hiatus for X-Men).  DC has the Justice League - which has had its gaps - and to a lesser extent, the Teen Titans and Justice Society, but none have really had the runs that Marvel's team comics have had.  Among DC's lesser (in terms of ongoing success) comics are the Outsiders, Challengers of the Unknown, Metal Men and - the topic of this review - The Doom Patrol.The Doom Patrol consisted of three superheroes:  Robotman (human brain in a robot body), Negative Man (who could project an energy being from his body) and Elasti-Girl who could grow or shrink as needed (mostly growing).  Leading them was the Chief, a super-genius in a wheelchair, and occasionally assisting them were Mento (a telekinetic who was also Elasti-Girl's boyfriend/spouse) and Beast Boy (a green teenage who could take the form of various animals).Volume 2 of the "Showcase Presents" series has issues 102 to 121, the last of the original series.  In these issues, the Doom Patrol takes on various strange villains but their archenemies are the Brotherhood of Evil who seem to appear in around half the issues.  There are also backup stories providing backgrounds for Robot Man, Negative Man and Beast Boy.As anyone familiar with comics history knows, a pivotal change in the industry occurred with the 1961 appearance of the Fantastic Four.  This and the other Stan Lee/Jack Kirby and company creations at Marvel brought a new level of storytelling and characterization that DC would take a long time to catch up to.  These Doom Patrol stories appeared in the late 1960s and show DCs gradual adaptation to the new comics world.  There are some character development and multi-issue story arcs which show some growth in DC's writing from the simple kiddie fare of earlier days.  On the other hand, the writing is still rather simplistic and the characters not all that interesting.In short, this is not the DC has to offer.  It's not awful, and credit should be given to DC for at least starting to evolve, but in general, this Showcase edition (which I'd rate a low three stars) is perfectly okay to skip.

Certain novels have great first sentences.  Aric Davis's Rough Men is not one of them. In fact, I liked it so little, I wondered if I was in for a bad book.  Fortunately, things picked up.  (For the record, the first sentence was "Alex pushed the magazine into the Glock, pulled back the slide to verify the still-chambered round of .45 ACP ammunition, and then hit the magazine release again."  It's a sentence that does promise action in the near future, but is awkwardly written and has too much gun details, which distracts from the meat of the sentence.)The novel begins with Alex Daniels - essentially a young hoodlum - participating in a bank robbery which turns into a slaughter of the bank's employees and patrons.  Alex himself is killed by one of his cohorts after witnessing something he shouldn't have seen.Will Daniels, Alex's father, has overcome his own troubled past to become a semi-successful writer.  When he hears of his son's death, he has to confront his own subpar parenting and the fact that Alex was a bad seed.  Both for revenge and to atone for his own sins, Will decides to seek Alex's killers and attend to them himself.  To do this, he needs to ally himself with an ex-crime partner who he left previously on bad terms.This is a taut little thriller (less than 200 pages) that shows that Davis can tell a good story even if his writing is a bit off at times.  Plot trumps prose here, and the result is a reasonably entertaining book.

Although generally a serious field, science - or more properly, sciences (biology, chemistry, physics, etc.) - has often had a tongue-in-cheek side.  For example, calling quarks "quarks" and giving it qualities like charm and strange shows a bit of whimsy on the part of the scientists who proposed the names.  Phil Edwards takes the humor potential of science to the limit with his book, Fake Science 101.Designed as a mock textbook, Fake Science 101 offers looks at astronomy, biology, chemistry, Earth Science and physics along with insights into the life of a scientist.  As with the best humor, there's usually a bit of truth mixed in with all the jokes, but you'd be hard pressed to get any sort of real science education from this book; of course, that really isn't the point.The point is to make you laugh, and while Edwards doesn't hit 100% of the time, he's successful more often than not with his jokes.  That's all that's required to make this a five-star book.  If you have a fondness for science, you will likely find this to be a very funny book.

A decade or so back, Stephen Cannell - a successful TV writer and producer - started writing a series of novels.  Now, Dick Wolf - the force behind the Law & Order TV shows, among others - is following the same path with his debut novel, The Intercept.  How does he do?  Okay, but not much better.The story follows Jeremy Fisk, an NYPD detective who deals particularly with intelligence work for counterterror purposes.  As the story begins, he bucks the higher-ups to pursue a terrorist in a minor prologue to a much bigger story.  Mostly taking place after the death of Osama bin Laden, Fisk finds himself coping with a bigger, more mysterious threat.The new terror plot begins with the attempted hijacking of an airplane.  The hijacker is quickly stopped by passengers who will soon become major media heroes.  Fisk, however, suspects more, and starts pursuing another passenger on the plane, a Saudi art dealer who seems to have disappeared.  Was the original hijacker merely a decoy?  Fisk believes so.As would be expected from a veteran TV writer and producer, Wolf knows how to tell a story, but there's little to recommend this book above plenty of others in the genre.  The characters, led my Fisk, are relatively uninteresting and rely a bit on stereotyping(all the cops are good guys, even if some are a bit bureaucratic; virtually every Islamic character is a terrorist or terrorist-sympathetic) the plot is generally familiar, and when there are twists, they are often borderline implausible (much of the terror plot depends on a whole bunch of factors occurring perfectly).If you don't read many thrillers, this may be a decently entertaining book.  For veterans of the genre like myself, however, The Intercept is strictly a been-there-done-that book that may not be substantially flawed (and merits a low three stars), but offers little that's not done better elsewhere.

If you're a mathematician by trade, education or inclination - or if you just enjoy science - then the periodic table is a thing of beauty.  It puts the universe in order in a wonderful fashion, giving it a logical basis that didn't exist prior to the table's creation.  It even successfully predicted elements that hadn't been discovered.  Theodore Grey's The Elements celebrates both the periodic table and the individual elements that make it up.After a few introductory pages that explain how the periodic table is constructed, the book dedicates two to four pages on each element, providing a few paragraphs about the significance of the element along with some nice pictures of the element either in pure form or in a compound or in some object.  Of course, with later elements (the very short-lived elements), there is very little to show or discuss.For each element, Gray provides some vital statistics (like atomic weight or density) along with graphical representations of the electron distribution, atomic emission spectrum and temperature ranges where the element is solid, liquid or gas.  Fanning out the pages will show that these ranges fluctuate based on atomic number and are not merely random.If you are into science, this is a nice book, but it may not have all the details you'd want.  It is more of an introduction to the foundation of chemistry, something to teach newcomers with nice illustrations and often humorous text.  Despite all the versions of periodic tables he shows in the book, the one thing I found Gray omitted was a complete table showing all the elements by symbol.  Nonetheless, this is a fun and informative book that is good for all ages to learn more the stuff of which we are made.

There is a minor classic of film noir called They Live by Night, a couple-on-the-run story with Farley Granger and Cathy O'Donnell.  Outside of a general association by genre, this movie has nothing to do with Dennis Lehane's similarly titled Live By Night, his semi-sequel to The Given Day.The earlier book followed Danny Coughlin, a well-meaning cop in post-WWI Boston.  This book follows Danny's younger and wilder brother, Joe, who, as the story opens in the 1920s, is a minor league thief whose heist of an underground card game will have far reaching repercussions:  not only will it entangle him with mob boss Albert White, but it will also romantically link him with White's mistress, Emma Gould.A series of mishaps will get Joe thrown in jail and Emma apparently dead (I say apparently because no body was ever found, and in a crime story, that rarely equates to death).  It isn't all bad; Joe will get involved with White's chief rival and eventually will take over the Florida crime operations of the rival, primarily rum-running during the Prohibition Era.The bulk of the story deals with Joe's rise to power in Florida, an area which is a change-of-pace for the Boston-centric Lehane, but one that the writer handles well.  In fact, in terms of the things you normally look for in a crime story - character, plot, etc. - Lehane does well, which isn't surprising because he is one of the great mystery writers of today.  You don't really need to read The Given Day first, but if you're new to Lehane, you will probably want to read it after getting a lot of entertainment from this book.

If you took all the active comic strips that have been around for decades, virtually all of them are pale shadows of their former selves.  Garfield, Blondie, Family Circus: they all may be institutions, but they are not that great.  There is only one exception to this rule, and that is Doonesbury.  Why this is the case is amply demonstrated in Brian Walker's Doonesbury and the Art of G.B. Trudeau.Walker (the son of Mort Walker, creator of two other institutional strips, Beetle Bailey and Hi & Lois) has written several books on comic strips and is something of an authority on their history.  In this book, he takes us through the history of Doonesbury which started its syndicated run in 1970 (prior to that, it was only published at Yale).  At first, the art was crude, but the characters offered deeper satire than typically found on the comics page.Yes, strips like Pogo and Lil Abner may have had political satire, but Trudeau used real political figures, not thinly veiled parallels.  As biting as the humor could be, he still centered his strip around the characters:  at first, the key foursome of B.D. (the conservative football player), Mark Slackmeyer (the campus radical), Zonker Harris (the easy-going hippie) and the title character, Michael Doonesbury (the eternal loser).  Eventually, many more characters would join the cast and the key characters would evolve and develop depth (except, of course, for Zonker, whose chief quality was that he was incapable of real change).And that's the key difference between Doonesbury and B.C., the Wizard of Id or Heathcliff:  Doonesbury changed over the years.  The characters changed, the art changed and there were even bits of seriousness mixed in with the humor.  Characters married, had kids (who also married), died and were seriously injured, as when B.D. lost his leg in Iraq.  Ground would be broken by the then controversial introductions of gay characters, extramarital sex and other topics.All this is chronicled in this book, which features a history of the strip, plenty of comics and a whole heap of other supplemental art work.  If you're a fan of Doonesbury, this is a must read.  If you aren't yet, this book demonstrates what you're missing.

When you read Proust or Faulkner or perhaps an in depth history about turnip farming, it might be expected to take a while to finish the book.  On the other hand, a mystery novel should be a generally fast read; Peter James's Not Dead Yet, however, turned out to be a much slower read for me than it should have been.This is the eighth book in a series about Brighton, England's Detective Superintendent Roy Grace, all of which, like Charlaine Harris's Sookie Stackhouse books, all feature the word "Dead" in the title.  I have not read any of the other books, so it's possible that some of the points I raise below were covered in earlier books.The book begins with the discovery of the torso of an unidentified corpse found at a chicken farm.  While Grace and his team investigate this crime, a second task comes to light:  the singer Gaia (who bears more than a passing resemblance to pop stars like Madonna and Lady Gaga) is coming to town with her entourage to film a movie.  This brings out various bad guys, including a man desperate to get his girlfriend Gaia's role in the movie (and figures killing her would clear the spot); an obsessed fan who can switch from love to hate very quickly; and a screenwriter who feels that the movie's script was stolen from him and is intent on revenge.These two separate plots will tie together in certain ways, but there's also a bunch of subplots that contribute little to the main story.  Grace has to deal with a vengeful ex-con as well as his very pregnant fiancee; his friend and subordinate finds himself between a bitter soon-to-be-ex-wife and a love triangle in which he is the invisible third wheel.  Then there is the subplot about Grace's wife, Sandy, who disappeared a decade ago and who he's trying to declare dead so he can remarry; of course, any mystery fan knows that if a person disappears but no body is found, she is not necessarily dead.  There are some basically unsatisfactory answers provided about Sandy, but the subplot generally goes nowhere (I have a feeling that this storyline is designed to extend over several books).So there's a little too much going on, but more than that, certain flaws stand out.  Too many of the characters, particularly the potential bad guys, are a bit too one-dimensional and come off more pathetic than evil.  One of the potential killers disappears from the story without ever impacting anything.  And most gratingly, the final plot twist relies on one of the most tired cliches in suspense fiction (which also involves lying to the reader).Despite the sometimes muddled writing and weak characterization, the story did pick up in the second half of the book, and I probably would have given it three stars, but the final plot twist - which is almost unforgivable in a writer of James's experience - makes it drop a star.

As the adventure strip dies off of the comic page, it is nice to look back at a time when the genre was at its peak, with Alex Raymond's Flash Gordon among the tops.  Following in the footsteps of Buck Rogers, Flash Gordon would wind up being the superior strip, with fantastic tales that have rarely been equalled on the comics page.Volume 6 of the collection starts out mundanely enough.  Flash, his girlfriend Dale Arden and friend Dr. Hans Zarkov are on Earth (having returned in the previous volume).  Written in 1942 and 1943, this gives Flash a chance to fight for America in a WWII parallel against an evil dictatorship that is unnamed but clearly a Nazi Germany substitute.  Of course, Flash, his friends and the virtues of democracy have the ability to overcome the dictatorship's navy.A lack of radium (necessary for fueling the ray guns that Flash had brought from Mongo) gives Flash, Hans and Dale an excuse to return to that alien world.  A crash landing will put them far from friendly faces and into an insurrection by the evil Prince Brazon against the vain but beautiful and kindly Desira.  This conflict will take up the remainder of the volume.If there is one shortcoming in this book, it's that there is no Ming the Merciless, for whom Brazor is not that great of a substitute.  Still, this is another fun collection of strips again showing that the comics page of yesteryear offered more than its contemporary equivalent.

As a young elementary school student, perhaps the most illicit material of all was Wacky Packs.  Rumors prevailed among the first grade set that owning or displaying the stickers were grounds for expulsion and/or arrest.  Of course, that just made them even more intriguing, although the myth would eventually fade, replaced by the fatal consequences of eating Pop Rocks (especially with soda).In a way, the somewhat subversive nature of the Wacky Package stickers probably added more to their appeal than the stickers themselves.  Relying on puns, some rather weak, each sticker parodied a particular product.  Even before picking up this book and revisiting them, I could still remember some of them:  Crust Toothpaste, Head and Boulders Shampoo and Drowny Softener.Revisiting the stickers is also a glimpse into the commercial world of 40 years ago.  Many of the products spoofed remain familiar today: Quacker Oats, Rice-a-Phoni and Shot Wheels are easy enough to figure out, but it escapes me what Fooey Mold Rush gum, White Fowl cigarettes or Sweat Hard soap were take-offs on.Perhaps as interesting as the stickers is the fact that Art Spiegelman, one of the most noted comic artists of today (and a Pulitzer winner for Maus), was one of the people behind the Wacky Packages.  I think that this book will not rate very high for those who didn't grow up with the stickers, but for those who did, the nostalgia value is worth the full five stars.

I am thrilled to have 10 of these cases to pack power tools and other shop items in. They are a perfect size for hand held tools. The beauty is that, with the handle folded down into a cavity on top,  they compactly and securely stack on top of one another, making it a breeze to see and locate what you need, on the shelf in a shop or garage environment. There are alignment ridges on the bottoms and tops, to allow each case to nest securely on top of one another. On the latch end, I use HVAC metal foil tape, as a label below the latch, upon which I write one to three words to describe the contents (with a black Sharpie marker). That way, with one glance, I can spot and pull what I need off the shelf, without opening each one to locate what I need. And being "ammo" cases, they are extremely heavy duty and sturdy, and capable of holding and carrying plenty of weight without compromising the case. In a word....Indispensable.

WOW. Is all that I can say about this movie. I saw it on ABC in 1979, when I was blown away by how Kurt Russell nailed this part, 2 years after Elvis died. It was Dick Clark Productions who decided to chronicle Elvis's life, shortly after his death, and enlisted John Carpenter to direct it. This television movie, which garnered 3 Emmy nominations, including best Lead Actor for Kurt, along with an all star supporting cast, has stuck indelibly in my mind since the night I saw it, and I was absolutely thrilled to see it finally released on DVD, from the original master recording. At the time of release, the movie was the highest rated television movie ever aired.  Kurt was only 27 years old when he performed this role. And it was a role which he hoped would lift him above his typical Disney movie roles. As he hoped, it ended up proving that he was capable of much more mature portrayals, than the light-hearted and squeaky clean characters in all of the Disney films, for which he was known. Ironically, Kurt's first appearance in film, as a child, happened in Elvis's movie, "It Happened At The World's Fair", where he was instructed to kick Presley in the shin. And following his brilliant portrayal of Elvis, John Carpenter decided to cast him again 2 years later in Kurt's second attempt to establish himself as a serious adult actor, in the action/sci-fi movie, "Escape From New York", and then again 2 years later in the dark comedy "Used Cars". So, Elvis was the spring board which thrust Kurt into the actor that we all know and love.The story line in this movie ends in 1969, before Elvis's personal and professional decline, followed by his triumphant rebound and eventual death.Other actors in the film included Elvis's actual confidant, Charlie Hodge, who appeared as himself in the film. And Kurt's real dad, Bing Russell, played the part of Elvis's supportive father, Vernon Presley. The role of Priscilla Presley was played by Season Hubley, whom Kurt actually married in 1979, a month after the airing of the movie in February of 79 (and having a son together, prior to their divorce several years later).The entire time I was watching, I could not believe my eyes or ears. Elvis was a alive and well, in Kurt's body :-)  Kurt has Elvis's voice and inflections down pat. Close your eyes and you would swear Elvis himself is speaking and singing. This movie was extremely well acted, sung and produced. You will be mesmerized from start to finish and I found myself wishing it would go on and on (in awe of Kurt's portrayal), even though I am not a rabid Elvis fan.
