I absolutely loved Elvis in his much more edgy rock and roll days. I never cared much for the Las Vegas orchestral turn in his career, with the exception of some of his songs from that era. And I loved it when Elvis showed his true "old" self in the NBC television production "Elvis: 68 Comeback", during the segments in which he appeared in signature black leather, with his band members, in acoustic renditions of his earlier and greater hits.  Elvis had not appeared on stage in front of a live audience since 1961, prior to this NBC Special, which is a "must have" DVD for any Elvis fans.The timing of this movie's production and release, was bittersweet, in that we all felt disappointed in, and sorry for the visible decline we saw in this huge icon in music. He had grown to be overweight and a mere shadow of himself, as a victim of his own success and excess. So it was healing and refreshing at the time to see Kurt take the stage and embody the character that many of us grew up to know, and wished that Elvis could have retained into much later years of his life.A couple of other sidelines to this is that Kurt was the voice of Elvis in Forrest Gump. And in 2001, he played the role of an ex-con, Elvis impersonator, planning a Las Vegas heist, in the Kevin Costner vehicle "3,000 Miles to Graceland".

I want to first caution about potential charger damage, which many might not be aware of. Obviously, we are all aware that dropping a cell phone into water, will ruin it. But what I did not know is that if you accidentally allow the charger tip (the end which plugs into your phone) to be submerged in water, it will ruin the charger. Which is what happened to me. Unplugged it on the counter top, which had a bowl of water sitting near by and without looking, I tossed the end aside, after I removed it from my phone, and it landed in the bowl of water. I immediately dried it off and tapped it on the counter to dislodge any water that might have been left inside the tip. Then waited for it to dry and then tried it in the phone. It was dead. And I could not revive it. Thus my need to order this replacement.Regarding the review of this new charger. Works perfectly and appears to be a genuine Samsung part.

When this protective port cover broke on my phone, I was very excited to that there are replacements available, which are critical to protecting the phone from potential water intrusion. By viewing Amazon reviews and going to YouTube, I found that replacing this part is very easy and simple, by removing the back of the phone, where you access the battery. You can see the small screw(s) that hold this cover in place, and can easily proceed, with a very small tipped screw driver, to remove the broken tab, to replace this new piece.And this Amazon merchant, East Coast Supply, sent it promptly through the mail, without any shipping charges or postage charge. Hats off to them.

I want to first caution about potential charger damage, which many might not be aware of. Obviously, we are all aware that dropping a cell phone into water, will ruin it. But what I did not know is that if you accidentally allow the charger tip (the end which plugs into your phone) to be submerged in water, it will ruin the charger. Which is what happened to me. Unplugged it on the counter top, which had a bowl of water sitting near by and without looking, I tossed the end aside, after I removed it from my phone, and it landed in the bowl of water. I immediately dried it off and tapped it on the counter to dislodge any water that might have been left inside the tip. Then waited for it to dry and then tried it in the phone. It was dead. And I could not revive it. Thus my need to order this replacement, which came as part of the package to replace the charger that plugs into the wall.Regarding the review of this new charger. Works perfectly and appears to be a genuine Samsung part.

I have an Arrow electric brad nailer, which only lasted through a short term project, nailing crown molding and base boards. It worked great when it was working, but without warning, right in the middle of nailing a strip of baseboard, it simply would not fire anymore, after going through one fourth of a box of brads. I was not able to claim warranty because I only used it to test it once, upon purchase, but then let it sit in a box until I got around to a project that it would be good for, which happened to be beyond the warranty period. So, if I was doing a review of the Arrow electric, it would not deserve even one star, since it was virtually new, when it malfunctioned. So, why mention the electric? Well, I obviously needed to replace it and was certainly not going to buy that brand again. However, I saw this nailer pop up as a free Vine product and thought, "Well, Arrow owes me one, so what the heck."  Upon receipt, I was impressed with the apparent durability and build quality. It appears to be well made and does not have any cheap plastic parts on it (almost all metal). So it should endure moderately rough handling. Its feature set is very minimalistic, so for those who are looking for a greater measure of control over the finished project, there are better nailers out there. If you are a DIY at home, kind of person, this will function very adequately, as long as you do not have an underpowered compressor. I also do not expect any malfunction issues with this since it is not electric. Pneumatics are pretty fool proof, since air is doing all of the work of driving brads (not an electric device which malfunctioned for reasons which are harder to troubleshoot).Negatives are: (a) Lack of any documentation or instruction manual. Although it is a very simple and intuitive tool, there are those out there, who may have never used one of these before, and need to know where and how much oil to put into the tool. (b) At the top of the motor housing (head), is a knob which can be turned...so what the heck is that for? Is it simply an air exhaust outlet which can be rotated 360 degrees to direct exhaust air where you want it to go, or is it there to adjust the pressure in order to set the proper "drive depth" for your brads. It would be nice to know, without having to experiment to find out. (c) There is not a rubber tip attached to the contact point of the nailer, so you have to be careful about how hard you press against more delicate surfaces (soft wood, or painted wood). You could leave a dent or scratch the paint. (d) Not too much of an issue, in the general scheme of things, but there is a lever on the forward face of the nail housing which allows you to open the head to remove any jammed brads. This is impossible to release by your bare fingers. You have to use something very sturdy, such as a screwdriver to pry it open. I guess the positive to this, is that there is no way it is going to accidentally open, and it insures that the brad to be fired is pushed firmly against the inside firing rail. (e) I have all of my tools in cases, for efficient stacking in my shop, so it is a big negative that you will have to go out and buy a case to house this in, which adds to the overall cost of the tool, and makes you consider buying a slightly higher priced competitive model, which almost all, come with cases.Other observations: (a) When you release the loading chute and pull it back, there are two different "stacked" cylindrical "brad  head" receiver slots that guide a variety of brad lengths into the chamber (6 different lengths being...5/8", 3/4", 1", 1 1/4", 1 1/2", and 2"). And each of these two "tubes or barrels" have a hole in the working end of the head, through which you can see the short or long brads in the chamber. When you get down to almost empty, a red interior sleeve becomes visible, indicating the need to load some more brads. So that is a helpful feature. (b) The nailer trigger won't fire, unless the spring loaded tip is depressed against your work surface, so that is the main safety feature, which is common to all pneumatic nailers. However, unlike framing nail guns, you can't rapid bump fire this tool, without pulling the trigger. But, that is not how one uses a brad nailer anyway, so that is not an issue.Overall this is an adequate tool for the "around the house" jobs it may be intended for and I would venture to guess that it could also be very adequate for commercial work, as long as the compressor has sufficient capacity to keep up with trigger pulls. Bottom line is that this tool becomes a bit more expensive than justified, when one considers the need to buy a case to store it in, along with potentially better feature sets on other nailers, such as DeWalt, Porter Cable, Ridgid, etc. while also factoring in their features and their "included case".

These are not what I expected. They are very light material, meant only for clustering packed items into separate bags within a suitcase, for organizational purposes, when you go to unpack at your destination. Although somewhat functional, I would not order them again. The two smaller sizes are not really good for much of anything.

I am very pleased with the quality of this oven's results using frozen pizza (DiGiorno, 11" diameter Tuscan Chicken, which had a regular crust with a slight rise to it). I cooked it on the Thin/Regular setting, and it came out great. Crispy crust, lightly browned and the cheese on top had a slight browning with crisp texture. Please realize that the maximum diameter of pizza, to fit, is 12" but in some cases, if you are at this limit, then the pizza will be very close to the interior sides and back of the oven, and might cause the perimeter edges to get more done than the center. This will also happen in a regular oven if you have pizza shoved clear to the back or off to the sides, picking up radiant heat from the oven's metal cavity, so this can't be considered a fault of the oven. Just be aware that your best results will be with pizza slightly less than 12" diameter. I have not yet tried homemade pizza in it yet, but I followed the instructions, which recommended preheating the oven for 5 minutes, for regular pizza and thin crust. My DiGiorno came out perfect.There are four heating elements which run parallel to the face of the oven. There is an extremely high intensity single bulb that runs across the center of the bottom of the oven, which does most of the heat delivery. There are also 3 horizontal, evenly spaced, lower intensity bulbs running across the top of the oven, which are designed to heat the toppings and brown the cheese. I noticed that these do not come on, when preheating the oven with the lower bulb. Makes sense, since the preheating is meant to insure a crisp and done crust, by not only preheating the oven's interior, but also preheating the ceramic tray that the pizza will rest upon, when placed in the oven. Unlike one reviewer who complained that  his oven was still scorching hot, 30 minutes after shutting it off...this is simply not true. When my oven was done and the timer clicked down to zero, and shut off, I came back 15 minutes later and could comfortably place my hand on top of the oven's exterior. There are five heat settings on the control knob (bake, frozen snacks, thin/regular crust, rising crust, and deep dish), so you have a variety of options which basically vary the intensity of heat. With experimentation, you should be able to find the "sweet spot" for your favorite type of pizza or other baked items. I do like the fact that in the summer, I don't have to heat up my wall oven and the kitchen along with it. Simply use this oven instead. There is a 30 minute, rotary count-down timer which activates the power to the oven. You are instructed to turn the timer to "just beyond 10 minutes" and then back to the time desired for anything cooking under 10 minutes. My only "wish list" suggestion  would be for the manufacturer to put cord-wrap retention hooks or posts on the back side of the oven, to manage the cord when not in use.There is a black ceramic slide out tray, which goes into the oven with the smooth side up (although I don't know what is ceramic about it, since it is a metal tray which seems to have a black powder coated surface on  it). This tray can only be positioned in the center of the oven, where the guide rails hold it in place. the clearance from the tray to the upper curved edge of the oven is 2.5" high and you probably would not want to put anything in the oven that is taller than about 2". The pizza goes directly onto the tray. The tray handle has a catch-hook on it to cradle the tray safely, to remove it completely from the oven, but you have to use the flat, leading edge of the handle's working end to grab the wire frame leading edge of the ceramic tray, to pull it half way out (with no danger of the tray falling out of the oven, when pulled half way out). At that point you slip the handles hook onto the edge of the tray and pull the tray out completely, from the oven, to slide the pizza onto a cutting board. Very simple and functional, but some people have complained that they could not engage the handle's removal hook with the tray fully seated in the oven. They are not using their "thinker", to understand the mechanics of tray removal. Totally efficient and practical hardware. The only assembly required was screwing two black threaded posts into one side of the oven or the other, which are resting points for the handle that removes the tray (you decide whether you want the handle stored on the right or the left side of the oven). The power cord is 42" long, if that information is helpful in determining where you may want to place this oven in use or as a countertop decor item.I find the design style to be very pleasing and looks great, on the counter, with the arched top and brushed stainless steel surface.

Great little storage solution, ideal for a dresser drawer. These are quite small so don't expect to be putting anything of size into them. The snug little clips that hold several together are a smart idea as well, because you can not only use them sitting upright in a drawer, but you could also nest several of them and place them on their sides on top of a dresser for an organizer. Good little product.

This does exactly as promised.... will not leak when turned sideways or upside down, even under pressure of squeezing the bottle. You must depress the orange button to pop out the mouthpiece. You can then tilt the bottle up and either squirt the liquid into your mouth or place your lips to the mouthpiece. Very functional and effective for active folks who want to throw this into a backpack or other carrier, without worry of leakage.

I got these to give to my daughter/granddaughter, primarily based on the cheerful and bright design. The only distinctive thing about these, if it is at all important is that they are PBA free. But realistically, absence of that chemical in plastic only makes sense if you are talking water bottles, from which chemicals might leach into the liquid. In this case it is irrelevant, but I guess it is fashionable today for consumer companies to throw buzz words out there, like the ridiculous "gluten free" labels you see on things that, by their very nature would never contain gluten to begin with (like gluten free water...haha). Not detracting from this product, but seems a bit silly.The mats themselves are high quality, although a bit thin. The main thing that I notice as a minor negative is the back of the mats is very smooth and slick, which means they easily slide around on the surface of the table. If I were to change anything, it would be to texturize the backs to minimize this with fidgety kids scooting their plates around.I recommend them based on appearance alone, as a very bright and cheerful place setting, which makes them ideal for festive occasions such as birthday parties, etc.

I got this unit because I have pain flare-ups in one of my knees, when exercising. I have only used it once in that area and it seemed to alleviate the pain, although I don't feel that I have had a chance to really test this unit adequately to offer much of a review. So I will add to this as future discomfort arises, which will allow me to test it more thoroughly.

I just received these, so I can't speak to the long term durability, of being exposed to the sun, in an outdoor environment. I know that some vinyl or plastic items will dry up and crack over extended periods of use. The fact that they are a silvery white color, should aid in reflecting the sun's rays for longevity.However, these seem to be pretty well made. The backside of the vinyl is lined with a felt type material, for some reason. It adds to the thickness and tactile feel of the material but not sure if it is functionally needed. They slipped easily over my power boat trailer wheels (back side of the covers being "open" for easy mounting on the tire) and there are two plastic grommets on the lower backside corners to run black braided cords through to cinch the covers down. The cords have to be tied in a knot on the back so that is a little tricky. Would have been nice to have a spring loaded button tension clip to cinch it down (like elastic bands at the bottom of ski jackets). Not a big deal, but worth mentioning.  On some tires, the fit may be snug enough to forego use of the tie down cords.This also comes with a "same material" bag to store them in, when not in use. And has a drawstring to close the bag and hang it somewhere in the garage.A year from now, after much exposure, it will be interesting to see how these hold up.

I thought I would try this EDT since one of my daughters wears Euphoria for women, which I like very much. This EDT has a pretty subtle finish. You almost can't detect it after about 30 minutes. On my skin it has a slightly fruity scent, and a very soft odor, somewhat like baby powder. I am not sure that I am all that fond of it. I have been wearing Armani Aqua Di Gio Essenza, which is absolutely outstanding, with its extremely fresh smell (like you just hopped out of the shower). And it lasts all day long, and well into the evening, from a morning splash. When measured against the Aqua Di Gio, the Euphoria doesn't even come close. No contest. My ultimate measure of a cologne is comments received from females who might receive a hug, upon greeting, or my girlfriend. Without exception, like clockwork, when I am wearing Aqua, they always comment, "Wow, you smell so good. What is that you are wearing?" And of course my girlfriend always says "you smell so intoxicating".But after wearing the Euphoria for a couple of weeks, I have not received one comment from the same above. Which pretty much says it all. The Euphoria is a pleasant smell, with nothing about it that might be a "turn-off", but it just doesn't stand out among many others out there. And as an EDT, it does not have the strength in odor, that it should have. Although something such as a cologne, ends up being a very subjective thing, with different odors appealing to different men and women, so this EDT might be the perfect odor for some men. It just does not ignite a spark for me.

This is a very nice looking table cloth, from a style standpoint. BUT, it is far too thin and allows whatever it is sitting on, to be somewhat visible because the cloth is too thin. You can do better at a big box store, as far price versus value are concerned. If it had a higher thread count, I would wholeheartedly give it 5 stars, but this is a design flaw that negates its appearance.

My son in law is a "trouble shooting" electrical systems engineer for Learjet, and I gave him this battery tester as a gift, since he also rebuilds cars and motorcycles. So he is  knowledgeable in many mechanical disciplines.  Within minutes of trying this out, he was immediately impressed with its intuitive simplicity.  First of all, the small printed manual that comes with it, was very well written and easy to understand (even for a novice like mysefl, with no experience).  By reading the manual, it explains exactly how to do various tests AND what the results of the test mean. So the manual does not assume automotive experience or knowledge.The manual includes the following instructions and/or cautions (with visuals of the tester's screen to clarify:1)" Hook Up":  requires you to enter the temperature of the battery at time of testing.  So you  may need an infra red temperature gauge, especially if the battery has been under load while the engine is running.  If the battery has been sitting idle in the car, then you can probably enter the ambient temperature, unless your car has been sitting out in the sun, raising the temperature of the engine compartment.  If you have the battery clamps reversed, on the battery posts, it will screen flash an error. Also, if you do not have "sound" connection to the posts, it will tell you to "Check Connections".2) "Battery Test": After entering battery temp, if the battery is above 180 degrees, you get a warning that "Battery is too hot to test safely".  At which point you are taken back to the main menu, to wait for the battery to cool down.  If the battery temp is ok, then you next select the battery type, such as "Standard"  vs. AGM and within those two categories, you  get to pick "Starting" or "Deep Cycle".  Next you enter the rated CCA of the battery, which will then pull up a summary screen.  When that is done, it will start the test. And if the reading is below 7.2 Volts, it will ask you if it is a 6 Volt battery.3) As it goes through the Digital Pulse Load test, it removes the surface charge, and has a status bar at the bottom of the screen, indicating progress of the battery test.4) One of the following test results are displayed on the screen: (a) Battery passes testing and can return to service. (b) Battery did not have sufficient remaining capacity to pass tests, and battery should be replaced immediately. (c) Battery is good but needs a charge before using. (d) Battery did not have a sufficient charge for the Digital Pulse Load Test, so you need to charge the battery and then test again. (e) Battery passes testing, but is near the end of its life. It is ok for mild climate, but may not start vehicle in hot or cold conditions.5) After the test is completed, you can print out the results on an infrared printer (optional purchase item, if you are using it in a shop environment to share with customers.Bottom line is that this is an awesome product which is definitely INDUSTRIAL strength. Extremely "durable build" with an Otterbox style rubber enclosure to protect it from rough handling in a commercial garage environment. It also comes with a couple of terminal post adaptors. One for side post terminals and one with top post terminals. They recommend you use these for the most accurate test results. If the price fits your budget, don't hesitate to buy this because it is worth every penny. Although I also suspect that this will have greater appeal to mechanics who can get the most use out of it on a daily basis. For the average consumer who may only want to test their car battery, as needed, and infrequently, it might not be as desirable.  All a matter of perspective and need.

I have had several of these, in varying forms and found this one to be especially handy when cutting through wood that had some nails embedded in it. Great blade and worth the money when you are not sure of what is hiding within something you are cutting. I also used it t sheer off some nails versus having to pull them.

If you are giving these as a gift, they come in a very nice black clamshell style box, within another black box to be wrapped. These are dainty and just the right size (large enough to be noticed), but not to big for the earlobe. They do not look cheap in any way (classy actually).  I was particularly impressed with the radiance and iridescence in the "opals". The hot pinks, blues and turquoise greens really come to life when light catches them and I noticed they react to light very readily. In other words, they are "on fire" at every angle. The heart shaped outer ring has just the right amount of sparkle and bling to complement the radiant colors of the stone. I gave them to a middle aged friend and she really loved them. And I have seen her wearing them on several occasions. She added that they are comfortable to wear, since they are very light weight.

I bought this due to it being under a hundred bucks and wanted something very lightweight, which this one is. However, it is a cheap  piece of crap. My first clue was after assembling it. Every time you try to lift the vacuum off the floor by the handle, or pull the handle towards you to vacuum in a backwards line of travel, the entire vertical portion of the vacuum slips right out of the receiver in the base. So there you are with the upper portion of the vacuum in hand and the vacuum head resting on the floor. COME ON, Eureka. Only a friction fit ?... with no retaining clip or push button snap to hold the darn thing together?  I now notice this complaint in many Amazon reviews. This is simply careless and lazy product design/engineering, in which I doubt seriously that quality control ever used the vacuum to witness this blatant oversight. What I had to do to remedy this was to drill a small pilot hole through the (upper portion) sleeve connector, and the female sleeve receiver in the base (vacuum head), and then drive a small sheet metal screw through both, to make a solid connection that would not allow them to come apart. So get out your drill and screw driver if you don't want your's detaching with every use.The other thing that sucks on this vacuum is that the small, hard plastic wheels, which the rear of the vacuum rides on, keep popping out of the slot that holds them in place. You're ok if you are simply going forward and  back in a straight line, but if you try to go at an angle, especially on tile floors that have any kind of grout indentation in them, those wheels will pop right out of their sockets. They are easy to put back in, by flipping the base upside down and snapping them back into the base, but again, lousy engineering.Another thing that happened with mine is that the rotating carpet brush in the head, broke in half, right in the center. Totally puzzled about that, so I suspect there may have been a defect in the injection mold "pass" for my particular brush. I went to Eureka's website to see if I could purchase a replacement and none are available, so I returned the whole vacuum.As far as vacuuming function, it does do a decent job, however the dust canister fills up very quickly, so it is a good thing that it is removable for frequent dumping. I can't speak to the issue that other 1 star users have complained about (losing its suction velocity over time), since I did not keep the unit long enough to see whether it went downhill after repeated use. I only used it about 5 times before returning it for a refund. Another minor detail or irritant, is that the corrugated hose which loops at the top of the handle, does not seat as positively as it should, in the recess at the top of the handle. Mine kept falling forward, which in no way affects the performance. Just not as tidy as it could be.Bottom line is that this is priced under a hundred bucks for a reason. If you think about it, this manufacturer probably has a hard cost for manufacturing this unit for somewhere between 20-30  bucks, in order for retailers to sell it at the price point. That won't buy much in the way of quality or engineering. So realize that you are getting what you pay for. If you want extremely light weight (one of its biggest positives), then this is the one for you. If you want to risk parts falling off, and/or breaking, then you have been forewarned.And P.S. to Eureka.... just because you respond with a tap dance of concern, to all one star reviews, on Amazon, with an invitation to contact Eureka customer service, does not alter the fact that this is a cheap piece of junk, which you should simply remedy by going to your production design department to request some minor product or tooling changes to insure that parts don't separate or fall off in normal use. FIX IT, instead of giving lip service to blatant design flaws.

If I could give this vacuum 10 stars, it would easily deserve it. What I was not expecting was the superior design and build quality, with which this is made. Everything is well thought out, with extremely durable parts, of unusually high quality. My first clue was pulling the telescoping wand out of the box. My goodness....extremely light weight stainless steel. From that point on, I was not surprised at all, with the other components. So, here are the things that make this vacuum so superior.PROS:** Stainless steel telescoping wand which allows you to effortlessly slide it in and out (like a trombone), to set the absolute best height between your hand and the floor, which totally negates back strain (I am 6'-2" and can maneuver this wonderful thing in a totally upright posture without hunching forward or leaning down). And the glide action in the telescoping wand is as smooth as silk, with a self locking, spring loaded finger button which engages the adjustment depression stops, in the upper wand, every 3/4", for 19 click increments, from short to long. So it telescopes in a manner that the distance from the handle to the floor attachment is 48". Then, by depressing the spring loaded finger clip (located at the top of the lower wand section), you can shorten this distance, for shorter people, to 32".  This wand flexibility is EXCELLENT for doing, not only basic floor vacuuming, but also upright tasks, such as vacuuming drapes and upper surfaces, near the ceiling. Use the short telescope for close up and the full extension for getting cobwebs, etc off of the ceiling. Very versatile.** The handle (which is raised up, off of the top of the wand, kind of like a gasoline pump handle, but open at the back end closest to the user) is sized and positioned perfectly, for comfort and maneuverability of the wand and vacuum head. Besides the main power button on the canister, there is also a convenient thumb-activated, on/off button on the handle, which disengages the rotary brush in the vacuum head, for those instances when you move onto solid surface floors and don't wish to change the suction settings, or when you simply want only suction on the carpet, without the brush rotating. Very smart and handy feature.** The vacuum head swivel at the base of the wand, works the same way as a Dyson Ball. Turn the handle to the right or left and it causes the brush head to turn and travel in the same direction, right or left, that you moved the handle. This minimizes the amount of arm effort needed to redirect the path of the vacuum head. You can stand in one place and cover a lot of area, back and forth in wide sweeps, without moving your feet. And the fantastic thing about the swivel head, is that, by rotating the handle, so that it is at the 3:00 or 9:00 position (while at the same time, lowering the wand down, close to the floor, you can  get under any furniture or obstructions which have a clearance of only 3" above the floor, which is the height of the rotating brush vacuum head).  You can also twist and turn the handle in either direction, underneath furniture (sofas, buffets, etc), to easily move the head, in all directions, to get to all of the surface areas to be cleaned, under obstructions. I was pleasantly surprised about the ease and utility of this function, especially since I have some very heavy wood furniture, which can't be moved to clean under. Instead, I have to get out a dust mop, on my hands and knees. Well, not anymore. I can't do that with any other vacuum. Another feature which adds flexibility is that, not only the vacuum head swivels, but also, where the flexible suction hose snaps into the canister....the hose can rotate 180 degrees, which aids in not having the hose fight you, by getting into a twisted bind, when you maneuver the wand and the canister in different directions.** Suction settings are versatile, with 6 different levels of suction. The lowest suction level will allow you to vacuum drapes and sheers without sucking them into the vacuum. And the air velocity can be increased to the maximum setting, for hard surface floors. And if you are on thick carpet which might be resisting your wand movement, you can simply dial back the suction setting so that it moves with less resistance. Very user friendly and consumer-centric.** The canister is not only gracefully beautiful (I got the Mango Red), but the wheels glide effortlessly on every surface, including deep pile carpet. All three of the small wheels swivel independently within cleverly designed, larger molded casings, so no matter where you go with the wand, the canister follows you effortlessly like a shadow, without any need to tug on it, as if it were a Great Dane on a leash:) The canister can glide flat on the floor, or it can sit upright and stationary, since the back of the canister is a flat surface (for when you want to use the wand for things up higher and don't want the canister rolling freely). This feature also allows upright storage in a closet, taking up minimal space. The main power switch is located at the back of the canister and is a foot-activated switch, about the size of a cell phone. Next to that switch is a "same size" switch which activates the self winding power cord, to retract it back into the unit. The other nice feature of the canister is an ergonomic handle on the front, which allows you to easily carry it in one hand, while carrying the wand in the other. Unbelievably, this canister is so light that you don't even feel that you are carrying anything. It only weighs 8 pounds. And the wand and head assembly is also around 8 pounds, so when you are carting the whole affair, from room to room, or up and down stairs, you are only dealing with 16 pounds total, but equally split between two hands.  Worth its minimal weight, in gold.** There are several options for filters. The hinged access door to the inside of the canister is easily opened, which reveals the vacuum bag (which some might view as a negative, since many vacuums today, use a reusable, removable plastic debris container). The vacuum bag readily snaps into a bag cradle, with absolutely no effort. And then when the door of the canister is closed, it automatically seats into the opening of the vacuum bag. So there is no struggling with slipping the bag over a vacuum tube and securing with elastic bands. Its all automatic.  Inside the canister is a small pre-filter, which protects the motor from debris, and then there is a larger exhaust filter which is a 4" x  8", single sheet filter, under a removable screen, which keeps particulates from re-entering the room. The unit comes with this basic particulate filter installed, with the option to remove it in favor of an included "plastic framed" HEPA 13 filter for those with allergies, in need of a higher level of filtration (this filter resembles the air filters on most automobiles). The dust bag appears to be relatively small, so I do not yet know how much vacuuming I can do before replacing it. It folds over on itself inside the canister and may expand more than it appears at first glance. The canister also has a sensor on top, which alerts you, when the bag is full, and on the border of not being able to accept any more debris. The bags for this unit are G/N type bags.** The retractable cord is 19' long so it gives plenty of room to operate from a single wall outlet, versus running around the room to find the next convenient spot to plug it in. And when the product description states it has an operational range of 29', what they are telling you, is that you have the 19' of cord, from wall outlet to canister, and then you have an additional 10' of reach,  with the wand itself. So you can go out as far as 29' from a wall outlet, to reach the limits of the vacuum head. This vacuum is rated at 1200 watts, and with the rotational brush activated, it pulls 12 amps, according to the manufacturer info.** Attachments are pretty straight forward and typical. Three small attachments are a small vacuum head, a round brush head and a crevice tool, all of which store on a bracket, which snaps to the base of the vacuum hose, where it enters the canister. Besides the rotary brush vacuum head, there is also a large hardwood floor attachment, which you can switch out. It features soft bristle brushes around the perimeter of the head, which have varying heights of bristles, so it doesn't just push dirt out of the way, when vacuuming, and allows debris to enter the suction zone of the head.CONS:** This is so minimal that it is probably not worth considering in the general scheme of things. But you have to replace vacuum bags, which may be a turn off for some. But the tremendous utility of this vacuum in all other areas, offsets this minor inconvenience. And the only other negative about this feature is that the replacement bags are more expensive. For the genuine Meile bag kit purchase, you  will spend around 18 bucks on the replacement kit, which includes 3 bags, as well as replacements for the other filters inside the canister (main motor filter, standard exhaust filter, and a replacement HEPA 13 filter). So, on the surface it may seem like a lot, but one has to consider the  cost of the other filters which come with the bag kit.** The only other minor negative is that this vacuum is not going to store as compactly as many other vacuums, since the hose and wand have to be dealt with. The canister itself, takes up only 10" x 8" of floor space, in a closet, and stands 18" tall, when set upright.  The telescoping wand (collapsed to its shortest length) with the vacuum head attached is about 34" long, end to end, but can be broken down even further, by detaching the vacuum head (taking it down to 22" without the head). The head can easily be stored on a shelf, out of the way. The other component, for storage, is the flexible vacuum hose which has the integrated handle at one end, which is 6' long and could be draped over a bracket in a closet, thus shortening its needed clearance to 36", when hanging.  Maybe these dimensions will help those who may have limited storage space.All in all, this is one of the finest, well made, and well thought out products which I have had the good fortune of experiencing. So, if the price does not deter you, I can assure you that the quality and function will easily justify itself, in this German engineered, and manufactured product. This is obviously a  product which had a lot of "hands on" involved in the engineering phase, translating functions into true usability. I can't find a flaw in its design, at any step of the way. Kudos.

In the past I have used straight line shavers, such as the Braun, which gave me closer shaves than rotaries, such as Norelco. So this is the first rotary which I have used in a long time. Right out of the box, I tackled a two day growth. I have pretty stiff whiskers and this shaver took them down to a smooth face in just a few strokes, so it does work very well. The heads are spring loaded so they follow the contours of your face. I also have a combo goatee and mustache and the only negative I noticed, was that the shaver tugged on or caught some of the short hairs around the perimeter of my goatee, which causes insignificant discomfort. Thus I will stay away from "real close" and simply finish off the tight edge around the goatee with a safety razor, to get up close and clean.The shaver is also very light weight and comfortable in hand, so no complaints there. It also has a lithium rechargeable battery which supposedly has a longer "power holding time" and it is listed as good for 30 minutes of shaving before it needs to be recharged. I can't attest to this benefit since I have not gone thru a charge recycle yet. It also has a pop up trimmer for sideburns which works as it should.All in all, as rotary razors go, this one performs well in the "close shave" department. Time will tell, as to its durability over time, especially as it relates to how many times it can be recharged before its battery runs its course.

The reason I selected this set of mugs was for the European flair in the artwork and design and the streamlined look of the curve. The quality is first rate and the white porcelain finish is flawless, both inside and out. And the image appears on both sides of the mug. One thing I find appealing is the generous space within the handles. I can place three fingers comfortably within the handle, minus the pinky finger.The size is ideal for a large cup of hot chocolate and I find the 14oz. size to be great for cups of soup, chili, etc.And although the smooth rounded design at the bottom appears that it might not be stable, that is not the case. In addition, the mugs are microwave safe.So, if you a drawn to the appearance and the artwork on the mugs, then you will not be disappointed.

I have had this router in my home for 4-5 years now. I bought it after reviewing comments in "geek" discussion forums, which universally mentioned and praised this router. All of the sophisticated users who are far more technologically knowledgeable than I, had nothing bad to say and all praised it for its consistent signal output and range. I have a rather large, multistory home and have the router in an upstairs office. The signal is robust in every corner of the house and I can actually use my computer throughout my large yard and have even been able to navigate online with my devices within my car, out in the street. I have experimented with driving a short distance from the house and still get a durable signal. Obviously, with this capability, you want to password protect access to your wifi, since this thing does an incredible job in its performance and range.Over the past several years, I have had friends who were experiencing signal drop and connection problems with two other well known brands, which they were using for their wifi. I suggested they try this one and they have been absolutely delighted with the switch. All problems have gone away and I told them the good news is that this will likely be the last router they will ever have to buy, unless technology changes so much that a new paradigm shift, renders this technology obsolete.As you can see, there are three outbound antennas to "spread the juice" in various directions. although I have never had to tweak their rotational position. I am not sure that is even necessary, but the magic may be in the fact that there are three, along with the fact that D-Link simply makes the best router in the business.So don't hesitate for one second on this one. It is the gold standard for function, durability, performance and being absolutely trouble free for a very long time in use.

The primary reason that I decided to rate this item, is the fact that I have had it for a couple years now and it is used daily to interface in the car with my iPod into a cassette deck. It has worked flawlessly for all of this time so it is primarily a testament to a well built or well executed product. You will not regret the small investment which will return big dividends in satisfaction.

I looked at dozens of fountains, focusing on style and the water effect. This one is extremely classy. There are small sealed lights in the two lower vases, which cause the sides of the vases to glow slightly, since the plastic is semi translucent (due to its thickness), which is not at all noticeable until it gets dark, so this provides a very impressive, unexpected appearance, when the sun goes down, providing a wonderful counter balance of vase illumination, in conjunction with the bulbs illuminating the upper bowl and the water falling out of it.Some reviewers complained about water splashing out of the lower vases but this only happens under three potential conditions. First, it is critical to use a level in both directions (north/south and east/west, resting on the rim of the upper bowl) to insure that the surface which your fountain is resting on, is totally level. Using a level, I positioned shims under a couple of corners of the base of my unit, to level it. If it is not level, then the water will not pour equally from the two upper spillways and the flow will not hit the middle of the water pools in the two vases. If it is out of level and off center, then water can hit closer to the edges of one or both of the vases, causing it to splash over the edge....easy to prevent. Second, if there is a strong breeze, of course the wind will blow the spilling water out of its intended path. And third, you might have to adjust the pump velocity to decrease the water flow, as a potential source of splashing, although I found the two aforementioned conditions to be more likely to cause splashing.I did find the assembly instructions to be not quite as clear as they could have been, but a little common sense and logic can get you there. Mainly realize that you are to run the two electrical cords for the light bulbs, immediately from their vases and into the large round downspout tube in the reservoir, as well as the cord from the pump which sits at the bottom of the reservoir. They are not to reside within the water reservoir. So all of the "excess" cords/wiring are supposed to nest within the bottom of the unit, on the ground or pavement. Of course there is a "mouse hole" cutout in the base for the power cord to exit the unit, towards an outlet.One valuable feature of this fountain is the fairly large reservoir which basically includes most of the structure behind what is visible, so I only have to refill it every few days (depending upon how much it is flowing...evaporation).Do not let the reservoir run dry, since it will ruin the pump. Two things will alert you to low water condition. First, the level of water will be noticeably reduced in the upper bowl, along with reduced waterfall flow, But more importantly as an "early warning", the water entering the base of the upper bowl, from the pump, will start to exhibit small air bubbles with the water flow (a bit of frothing). That is a definite sign that you need to add water and it alerts you well in advance of being critical.I am extremely happy that I chose this unit over many other designs, although I really wanted to spend about 50 to 75 bucks less. So I am glad that I ignored my original budget desire, because this one is well worth the extra money for great design, features, and function. I get extremely positive comments from guests, who now want to get the same unit.Oh, by the way, some earlier reviewers complained that the factory production molds created a visible vertical seam in the middle of the front of the two lower vases, but that problem has been addressed in the units being sold now, so not an issue.

Sometimes the simplest concept can be simply brilliant in it's execution. I absolutely love this innocuous little product that started out in its early life as a camera holder, many years ago, which you could wrap around any stationary object which could accommodate the device's bendable arms which are infinitely positionable.This device does one thing extremely and simply "WELL". Hold any phone, any camera, or any media player in a way that is extremely user friendly. I have a Samsung Galaxy 5.0 Player (which is not a smart phone, but is of the same dimensions as most). What makes this device so versatile, and which is not readily apparent, are the "grippers" which are spring loaded "fingers" which telescope out of the frame of the unit which attaches to the tripod. At first glance, upon receipt, I thought to myself, "darn it...my player (or iPhone, or any other similar device) will not fit this thing since the holder is not wide enough. Then I noticed that one side of the spring holder "fingers" slides out to accommodate whatever width of device you want it to hold  BINGO. No problem. This expandable holder threads into the spider tripod base to hold your device, with an adapter that comes with the unit.There are enough adjustments for swivel and angle to satisfy any desirable viewing/using angle. Although the product photo on Amazon shows the 3 feet in a fairly upright orientation (which is not the most stable for "touch and go" usage), you can spread or bend them out much flatter to provide a more stable base to eliminate tipping over. You can also use this same bendability to tilt the unit back into a very "reader friendly" viewing angle for easy "hands free" navigation with your device. I can press and swipe to my hearts content in moving through screens on my device, with it sitting 6"-8" above the resting surface that it is on. Feels like someone is holding it up for me, at an angle of my choosing.In addition, the same things which make it functional for smart phones or media players, also apply to cameras, with the standard universal threaded bases, which this is designed to accommodate. And don't forget that in any situation, this tripod does not have to sit on a counter top to be effective. You can literally bend and squeeze the flex legs to any object, vertical or horizontal, such as a door jamb, stair railing, post, etc. It will grab onto anything up to about 6"-8" wide or thick.Love it. Love it. Love it. No brainer purchase.

For over 10 years, I have had the same species of birds building a nest behind my basketball goal, mounted directly to the side of my house above the overhead doors, in the driveway. There is just enough room between the siding and the backboard of the goal to allow birds to fly in for the most protected bird nest area on the planet. I have tried every conceivable method for trying to keep them out, since every year produces another crop of baby birds that call this home and then come back the following year to produce their offspring. Many times I just wanted to blast them out of there.I have used chemicals, fake owls, shiny strips of foil, etc. everything recommended on all of the sites that advise such a thing. Then on one site I experienced the ah-ha moment, at the suggestion of netting. WOW. In all those years, I was looking for a way to scare them away or make their environment unpleasant with chemicals. But the simplest solution was to physically preventing them from entering the area they wanted access to.So I bought a 14' x 14' package of the BIrd-X 3/4" mesh and stapled it to my siding around the basketball goal, with absolutely no possible access points for the birds to enter. GOLDEN SOLUTION. The minute that it was in place the birds could not enter and within 2 days of prevention, they no longer even try...Taking up residence elsewhere.The hardest part for me was trying how to attach the netting to the house, since the netting can be difficult to work with, when it is unrolled. It gets tangled on itself. So I had to create a stable frame to hold it while moving into position for attachment. I went to Home Depot and bought several 10' long strips of what they call "Lattice", which is basically very thin wood strips which can accept staples from a hand activated "Arrow" staple gun. I stapled the netting along the factory cut edge, every 6" to hold it in place and then rolled the strip over on itself to run another series of staples along its length. This firmly attached the mesh to a single wood strip, which allowed me to walk it up to the ladder to attach above the backboard, by using an electric carpet stapler (but in the absence of that, you could simply tack it into place with very small finish nails). With the 10' wide mesh, now hanging from the siding above the goal, I then proceeded to attach a bottom 10' strip of wood lattice to the mesh, below the goal. I used two 6' step ladders, spaced 8' apart to rest a 12' 2x4 on the top. The 2x4 gave me a solid surface to hold the bottom lattice piece in place while I stapled it to the mesh, the same as I did the top piece, rolling it several times to insure a fool proof connection. I then stapled (nailed) the bottom piece to the siding below the goal and the hard part was done. The only thing left, was to staple (adhere) the mesh along the vertical edges, With lap siding that is 10" tall, I cut 10" long strips of the lattice to staple to each individual piece of vertical siding, using a level to insure they were in perfect alignment for visual balance.Mission accomplished. Absolutely no more bird intrusions.What was accomplished in a fairly labor intensive effort to eliminate birds from bombarding the sides of my house and my cars with bird poop, undoubtedly will be very easy to accomplish with a minimum of effort, to protect fruit trees and vegetables from incursion by simply draping this mesh over the protected object.Flat out....it works. Birds can't get to it.

This item came relatively well packaged with very thick foam insert protectors in each corner to hold the pit, nested and centered within the box. Although, upon opening I did note a very slight deflection in the rim, where it might have experienced some impact along the middle of one of the sides of the box. The manufacturer could avoid this by putting some foam protection all the way around the copper rim to keep the edge of the rim 1/2" to 1" away from any impact points. Although, I remedied the slight bend by placing the bowl face down on the kitchen floor and stepping on the area with my foot, which straightened it out, so as not to be noticed. And even though I was able to do this, does not mean that the copper bowl is thin or flimsy. It is very hefty and robust and will not be damaged through regular use.The frame and legs are very strongly constructed with thick steel, so the unit is not flimsy in the least. I give it high marks for being well made.Tip:  When bolting the legs to the frame, I found it easiest to set the frame ring on its edge on top of a table so you are not bending over to assemble. Place a pencil or something small like that, on the table where the ring touches the table to keep the ring from rolling and rotate the ring so the holes in the frame for the leg are at the 7:00 to 8:00 position. This is the most user friendly position for inserting the bolts through the frame to align with the holes in the legs. IMPORTANT...one reviewer commented that the holes on one of the legs did not line up with the frame. I too, thought I had run into the same issue, but found that if I inserted both bolts and only turned them a couple of turns to get them started, it solved the problem. Because the holes in the frame are larger than the targeted holes in the legs, allowing some wiggle room to get them both started. I had originally tightened the top bolt snug, which appeared to force the bottom bolt to have to go in at an angle that would not thread, so when I backed off the top bolt, the wiggle room in hole spacing allowed the bottom bolt to go in with ease. So tighten them both real tight, only after getting them started loosely in the holes. Also, there is no chance of stripping the bolt heads since they are tightened with an Allen head tool, which comes with the unit.If I would suggest anything of the manufacturer, regarding construction, it would be to get closer on tolerances for the fit of the spark guard screen. Regarding the unit I received, the diameter of my screen was 1/2" smaller than the diameter of the depression in the rim of the bowl that seats the screen. The diameter of the screen needs to be slightly larger than it is, because I notice that when I place the screen in place, with it all the way to one edge of the rim of the bowl, the screen's rim barely misses the rim ledge on the opposite side of the bowl, allowing the screen to sag down a bit below the edge that it is supposed to rest on. I might add that this does not in any way make it non functional for what it is designed to do, resting on top, to arrest sparks, since I simply scoot it over enough to center on the rim of the bowl.As far as looks go, this is a beautiful fire pit. It looks impressive in a casual or dressed up back yard setting. The mission style is very classy and has elicited very positive comments from our guests. Some reviewers have commented about the copper changing color. That is the nature of copper, to change its patina through oxidation. My dad was an architect who designed quite a few shopping centers, in which they used copper mansard roofs as decorative treatments along the facades and I remember commenting to him, as a youngster, that it was really cool, how bright and shiny they were, when construction was finished. He advised that they would not be like that for long, since the objective in using copper was to allow it to weather to a much more subdued look.  So, if it is important to keep the shiny copper penny look, you are going to have to get out the copper cleaner and burnish it back to its original look from time to time. Or, as my mom used to do, back in the 60's, with her copper bottom Reverware pots and pans was to squeeze lemon juice onto the bottom and sprinkle salt over it. Then scour it with a cloth or abrasive sponge. The combo of salt dissolving into the lemon juice, quickly brought the bright copper back to life. Its possible that copper cleaner might work around the rim, where the heat of the fire has not altered the metallurgical properties of the copper as much. But the copper cleaner may not do anything where intense heat has altered the characteristics of the metal. At any rate the visual focus is on the fire and the classy looking stand. And although the copper changes color, its main attribute is that it will not rust, like thin steel bowls will.Another reviewer commented that the round fire grate which the logs sit on, has warped through use, from intense heat. This also happens in all of the Weber charcoal grills, for which you can find replacement round grates in all different sizes in hardware stores and all of the big box home improvement stores. So, that is an easily replaceable part, several years down the road, if needed or desired.The bowl is roomy, at 28" across and 7" deep, with the screen standing another 5" higher at the peak, allowing 12" total clearance at the peak, which is deep enough for several fire place logs which you can stack pyramid style if desired. And I like the fact that there are 5 small holes in the bottom of the unit to allow water to drain. Although possible, I doubt that the holes are big enough to add air circulation for the fire. The fire pit comes with a fitted vinyl cover to protect the entire unit from the elements. There is a 1" wide elastic band sewn into the perimeter of the cover which holds it snugly in place (much better than any of the bbq grill covers). It remains to be seen, how well this cover holds up to extended exposure to the elements, since I have had 4 or 5 expensive bbq grill covers that seemed to be heavily constructed but started cracking and deteriorating within 3-5 years, in the sun.On a final note, due to the heavy duty construction of the frame and legs, with closed weld points everywhere, rust over a long period of time will not be a threat, because any that might occur, will only be cosmetic, and easily addressed with Rust-Oleum flat black or semi gloss. Same true on the spark guard screen.You will not be disappointed with this fire pit. Very functional, attractive and large enough to satisfy. In the past, I have had some of the 50 to 100 dollar fire pits from "Wally World", which are much more shallow and with steel bowls that rust out within 2-3 years of use, and this is far superior in every way.

My credentials: Former owner of a chain of large dance clubs (in Atlanta, KC, Augusta Georgia, Omaha, and Wichita Kansas) with patron capacities varying between 1,000 to 3,000 people in each. We spent massive dollars on elaborate sound systems in each. Equipped with MacIntosh amps, Crown amps, UREI equalizers, JBL, and Cerwin Vega speakers (when they were all at the top of the food chain in quality). In addition to being an audiophile at home, I do recognize good sound when I hear it. Regarding consumer brands in this category, I am totally "brand" agnostic and do not have allegiance to any one over the other. I could care less, since I let my ears be the judge.For the past 15 years, I have lugged around the most incredible portable sound system (a monster of a boombox), made by JVC, called the Kaboom. Absolutely nothing rivals it's incredible output, with 2 side firing 6" subs, and 2 forward firing 3" mids with embedded tweeters. It puts many home component stereo systems to shame. It has on board equalization for bass, mids, and highs, so I have been spoiled, however, this thing weighs too much to justify use in many mobile situations. Thus I went in search of a "decent" small speaker that I could use in hotel rooms, kitchen, outdoor bbq, pool parties and other outdoor get-togethers. Not expecting to fill an area with home component sound, but certainly did not want the hollow "tinny" sound, which is put out by most MP3 player speakers.I contemplated a purchase, reluctantly, for about 6 months, with repeated trips back to the big box stores to convince myself that these small portable speakers are justified at $150 to $200. Hard to stomach since you can get a pretty decent bookshelf speaker in that price range, which sound a heck of a lot better. Ultimately, within that price range, I narrowed my choices down to the UE Boom, JBL Charge, and Bose Soundlink Mini since all other brands (including Sony, iHome, and Dr. Dre Beats Pill 2.0) were definitely lacking in fullness of sound and simply sounded cheap. I do have to say, however the the XL Pill from Dr. Dre was a very impressive, hands down winner, with very solid bass and volume, but not at $300.I kept coming back to the UE Boom, due to its overwhelmingly positive reviews. Seems like the majority of reviews raved about three things. a). Its battery life, arguably 15 hours, depending upon individual experiences (b) the fact that it can go "really loud", and (c) being water resistant for outdoor activities which might jeopardize other brands. I decided against the Bose, because Bose retail store displays prohibit side by side comparisons, with their locked down pads and physical restrictions against being able to plug in your own player. So, I simply could not tell whether the Mini had decent volume. The store display would not go above a certain volume which did not seem to be as loud as the competitors on the backside aisle displays. Although I did notice that it had a more full range of sound than the UE Boom. Of course, Bose is famous for boosting the low end bass spectrum to deliver what many might consider to be a "fuller" sound. But I was worried that it might not be loud enough at 15-20 feet away, in a backyard setting, so it was out of the race.On my last trip in, to purchase, I had pretty much decided on the UE Boom, but I had this nagging doubt about it sounding a bit too shallow and harsh with most of its volume dedicated to mids and highs (even though they were pretty natural and "uncolored"). I brought my Samsung Galaxy 5.0 player into the store to give it a good test drive since I had a great 7 band equalizer in my player software and could challenge the UE with a wide range of music genre's. The EQ helped some but I still could not achieve a satisfying balance with some low end to fill it out. Then, by sheer chance, I spotted a speaker at the end of the shelf display, which, I had not previously noticed since I never saw it in Amazon keyword search results for these small bluetooth speakers, and thus, did not consider it when looking for brands to compare. This speaker was the TDK A33. I used my mini stereo headphone cord on the Samsung and played specific songs, in R&B, Rock, Country, and Jazz, switching from the UE Boom to the TDK and back, in the store setting. Without question, the TDK sounded a heck of a lot better than the UE. It had impressive "on the shelf" bass response and made the UE sound pretty hollow and flat, with it's "nothing but mids and highs". I felt it was still hard to really evaluate due to the store setting, with ambient noise and large volume of open space, so I purchased both to take home for a test drive in a more natural setting.Took both into the kitchen, bedroom, and living room, switching the player's line signal between the two, multiple times on each song, to insure my ears were not deceiving me. The UE did not come close to the TDK in delivering a full and pleasant range of sound. I next went out into the back yard, since the biggest boast for the UE is that it gets really loud, when you need it to. So that was a concern, as to whether the TDK could measure up. And to my surprise, with both units maxed out on volume, I could not tell the difference between the two, except for TDK's much richer sound range. So, within 10 minutes at home, the decision was made, without any hesitation or doubt. If you want great sound, under $200, nothing compares to the TDK (which will cost you around $130). I have since taken it with me to several friend's houses, who have some of the other brands and they immediately comment on how much better it sounds, than their units.Having made the choice in favor of the TDK A33, based on sound quality alone, I will admit to some pros and cons, but am willing to take my chances, since I know my ears would have buyer's remorse every time I turned it on, had I gone with alternate choices. The following are issues which are raised in some of the negative reviews for the TDK. Although the number of 4 star and 5 star ratings for the TDK (500+) are right in line with the same number for the UE Boom, with both brands having an overwhelming number of 4 and 5 star over a minimal number of 1 and 2 star (21 for the TDK), so I feel the odds are in my favor regarding the few negatives.TDK Cons: The UE has a 2 year warranty and the TDK only has 1 year. Matters little to me, since I suspect that if there is a component failure, it will probably occur fairly early on. Most of the 1 star reviews of the TDK complained about the unit becoming inoperable within its first month or so (OK, then replace under warranty). But again, a very small percentage, compared to the hundreds of 4 and 5 star. But if that is an important concern, then buy an extended warranty since the TDK is 50 bucks less expensive, most everywhere.TDK Cons: The UE claims to have a 15 hour battery life and reviews in actual use, seem to be mixed, on the actual achievable, depending upon volume level being run. The TDK only claims 6 hour battery life, so that is a point in UE's favor. My experience with the TDK is 5-6 hours if running inside at 50-70%% volume, within an enclosed space, however, outside, I tend to max the volume, for listening within 20', and I get about 3 hours that way. But since I am close to outlets, I simply plug into an extension cord and don't worry about it.TDK Cons: The UE appears to be pretty robust in its tolerance for moisture, such as actually dropping it into water, etc, so it probably has a leg up in that department. The TDK is water resistant, meaning it can take getting rained on or splashed on, but not able to be submersed. So, if I accidentally leave it outside when it starts to rain, I won't have to worry about it being ruined. And I do not plan on taking it kayaking, floating, or canoeing, where the UE might be a safer bet.BIG TDK Pro... on Sound: Absolutely no contest, with the TDK delivering much better sound than the UE Boom. The TDK has two forward facing 1.5" drivers for mids and highs and and two 3" rear passive radiators, linked to a 2.5" forward facing subwoofer, to deliver a very pleasing full range of sound, in such a small package. I have no idea what drives the UE but do know that it has no "bass" presence. When the ultimate test is done with the ears, there simply is no reason to consider anything else in this price range. After all, I want a speaker that does justice to the material and is the most pleasing to the ears. Tip, to further enhance the punch from the impressive little TDK speaker....be aware that bass, in any speaker of any size, is enhanced whenever a speaker is closer to a wall or within a more confined space (such as an open cabinet recess), to radiate the bass sound waves, so, whether I am outside or inside, I try to place the TDK within about 6" of a wall behind it, which intensifies the bass. This has no effect on the UE Boom, since it has no bass presence to begin with.Misc Points regarding the TDK only....There is an auxiliary "in" port for wired connections, coming from any source that has a stereo mini output (i.e. headphone jack). Although there is no auxiliary "out" on the TDK, to send signals to any other device. Other than wired "input" you obviously can send wireless Bluetooth signals to the TDK, which also doubles as a wireless speaker phone, paired to your smart phone. Which might be convenient to use in the car for phone calls. Charging the TDK is only done with the AC line cord from an outlet. There is an "outbound only" USB port, to charge other devices while you are listening to the TDK (or have it on, but with no signal being sent to it, or volume turned down, if you want silence while charging something else). The manual says the TDK will charge other devices through the USB, when it is "on" and plugged into an outlet. Since I have not tried it, I don't know whether the TDK would charge something through the USB port, if it is not plugged in. Also, in the distant future, if and when the rechargeable batteries run their course and no longer hold a charge, they are replaceable, unlike some electronic devices which have sealed systems. There are instructions from TDK on how to remove and replace worn out batteries. This will not happen for quite some time, since these types of batteries typically go through hundreds of recharge cycles before wearing out. I do not believe the batteries can be replaced on the UE Boom, since it is a totally enclosed system, for its water repellent attributes.At least purchase the TDK along with the UE Boom and try them at home, side by side, and let your ears be the judge, without online "brand fans" hyping their favorite, at the expense of what will please you. You will not be disappointed with the TDK, and in a true side by side comparison, I do not see how anyone could favor the UE Boom over the TDK, based on sound quality alone.

My credentials: Former owner of a chain of large dance clubs (in Atlanta, KC, Augusta Georgia, Omaha, and Wichita Kansas) with patron capacities varying between 1,000 to 3,000 people in each. We spent massive dollars on elaborate sound systems in each. Equipped with MacIntosh amps, Crown amps, UREI equalizers, JBL, and Cerwin Vega speakers (when they were all at the top of the food chain in quality). In addition to being an audiophile at home, I do recognize good sound when I hear it. Regarding consumer brands in this category, I am totally  "brand" agnostic and do not have allegiance to any one over the other. I could care less, since I let my ears be the judge.For the past 15 years, I have lugged around the most incredible portable sound system (a monster of a boombox), made by JVC, called the Kaboom. Absolutely nothing rivals it's incredible output, with 2 side firing 6" subs, and 2 forward firing 3" mids with embedded tweeters. It puts many home component stereo systems to shame. It has on board equalization for bass, mids, and highs, so I have been spoiled, however, this thing weighs too much to justify use in many mobile situations. Thus I went in search of a "decent" small speaker that I could use in hotel rooms, kitchen, outdoor bbq, pool parties and other outdoor get-togethers. Not expecting to fill an area with home component sound, but certainly did not want the hollow "tinny" sound, which is put out by most MP3 player speakers.I contemplated a purchase, reluctantly, for about 6 months, with repeated trips back to the big box stores to convince myself that these small portable speakers are justified at $150 to $200. Hard to stomach since you can get a pretty decent bookshelf speaker in that price range, which sound a heck of a lot better. Ultimately, within that price range, I narrowed my choices down to the UE Boom, JBL Charge, and Bose Soundlink Mini since all other brands (including Sony, iHome, and Dr. Dre Beats Pill 2.0) were definitely lacking in fullness of sound and simply sounded cheap. I do have to say, however the the XL Pill from Dr. Dre was a very impressive, hands down winner, with very solid bass and volume, but not at $300.I kept coming back to the UE Boom, due to its overwhelmingly positive reviews. Seems like the majority of reviews raved about three things. a). Its battery life, arguably 15 hours, depending upon individual experiences (b) the fact that it can go "really loud", and (c) being water resistant for outdoor activities which might jeopardize other brands. I decided against the Bose, because Bose retail store displays prohibit side by side comparisons, with their locked down pads and physical restrictions against being able to plug in your own player. So, I simply could not tell whether the Mini had decent volume. The store display would not go above a certain volume which did not seem to be as loud as the competitors on the backside aisle displays. Although I did notice that it had a more full range of sound than the UE Boom. Of course, Bose is famous for boosting the low end bass spectrum to deliver what many might consider to be a "fuller" sound. But I was worried that it might not be loud enough at 15-20 feet away, in a backyard setting, so it was out of the race.On my last trip in, to purchase, I had pretty much decided on the UE Boom, but I had this nagging doubt about it sounding a bit too shallow and harsh with most of its volume dedicated to mids and highs (even though they were pretty natural and "uncolored"). I brought my Samsung Galaxy 5.0 player into the store to give it a good test drive since I had a great 7 band equalizer in my player software and could challenge the UE with a wide range of music genre's. The EQ helped some but I still could not achieve a satisfying balance with some low end to fill it out.  Then, by sheer chance, I spotted a speaker at the end of the shelf display, which, I had not previously noticed since I never saw it in Amazon keyword search results for these small bluetooth speakers, and thus, did not consider it when looking for brands to compare. This speaker was the TDK A33. I used my mini stereo headphone cord on the Samsung and played specific songs, in R&B, Rock, Country, and Jazz, switching from the UE Boom to the TDK and back, in the store setting. Without question, the TDK sounded a heck of a lot better than the UE. It had impressive "on the shelf" bass response and made the UE sound pretty hollow and flat, with it's "nothing but mids and highs". I felt it was still hard to really evaluate due to the store setting, with ambient noise and large volume of open space, so I purchased both to take home for a test drive in a more natural setting.Took both into the kitchen, bedroom, and living room, switching the player's line signal between the two, multiple times on each song, to insure my ears were not deceiving me. The UE did not come close to the TDK in delivering a full and pleasant range of sound. I next went out into the back yard, since the biggest boast for the UE is that it gets really loud, when you need it to. So that was a concern, as to whether the TDK could measure up. And to my surprise, with both units maxed out on volume, I could not tell  the difference between the two, except for TDK's much richer sound range.  So, within 10 minutes at home, the decision was made, without any hesitation or doubt. If you want great sound, under $200, nothing compares to the TDK (which will cost you around $130). I have since taken it with me to several friend's houses, who have some of the other brands and they immediately comment on how much better it sounds, than their units.Having made the choice, based on sound quality alone, I will admit to some pros and cons, but am willing to take my chances, since I know my ears would have buyer's remorse every time I turned it on, had I gone with alternate choices. The following are issues which are raised in some of the negative reviews for the TDK. Although the number of 4 star and 5 star ratings for the TDK (500+) are right in line with the same number for the UE Boom, with both brands having an overwhelming number of 4 and 5 star over a minimal number of 1 and 2 star (21 for the TDK), so I feel the odds are in my favor regarding the few negatives.Con:  The UE has a 2 year warranty and the TDK only has 1 year. Matters little to me, since I suspect that if there is a component failure, it will probably occur fairly early on.  Most of the 1 star reviews of the TDK complained about the unit becoming inoperable within its first month or so (OK, then replace under warranty). But again, a very small percentage, compared to the hundreds of 4 and 5 star. But if that is an important concern, then buy an extended warranty since the TDK is 50 bucks less expensive, most everywhere.Con: The UE claims to have a 15 hour battery life and reviews in actual use, seem to be mixed, on the actual achievable, depending upon volume level being run. The TDK only claims 6 hour battery life, so that is a point in UE's favor. My experience with the TDK is 5-6 hours if running inside at 50-70%% volume, within an enclosed space, however, outside, I tend to max the volume, for listening within 20', and I get about 3 hours that way. But since I am close to outlets, I simply plug into an extension cord and don't worry about it.Con: The UE appears to be pretty robust in its tolerance for moisture, such as actually dropping it into water, etc, so it probably has a leg up in that department. The TDK is water resistant, meaning it can take getting rained on or splashed on, but not able to be submersed. So, if I accidentally leave it outside when it starts to rain, I won't have to worry about it being ruined. And I do not plan on taking it kayaking, floating, or canoeing, where the UE might be a safer bet.BIG Pro on Sound: No contest, with the TDK delivering much better sound.  It has two forward facing 1.5" drivers for mids and highs and and two 3" rear passive radiators, linked to a 2.5" forward facing subwoofer, to deliver a very pleasing full range of sound, in such a small package. When the ultimate test is done with the ears, there simply is no reason to consider anything else in this price range. After all, I want a speaker that does justice to the material and is the most pleasing to the ears. Tip, to further enhance the punch from this impressive little speaker....be aware that bass, in any speaker, is enhanced whenever a speaker is closer to a wall or within a more confined space (such as an open cabinet recess), to radiate the bass sound waves, so, whether I am outside or inside, I try to place the TDK within about 6" of a wall behind it, which intensifies the bass.Misc Points. There is an auxiliary "in" port for wired connections from any source that has a stereo mini output (i.e. headphone jack). Although there is no auxiliary "out" to send signals to any other device. Other than wired "input" you obviously can send wireless Bluetooth signals to the TDK, which also doubles as a wireless speaker phone, paired to your smart phone.
