**I received an ARC for an honest review.**I loved Jesse's story! I have loved all the books in this MC series but I was really looking forward to Jesse's.Nurse Bell. I was curious as to who would ultimately be Jesse's woman and I love that it was shy sweet Nurse Bell. I also love that they continuously called her Nurse Bell. I loved Bell. She is so sweet and such a great female lead. At some point I would have labeled her a pushover but considering all that she went through and all they her family had been through she is just genuinely thoughtful and selfless. She puts everyone's needs above her own and Jesse is no different. Even when he is constantly pushing her away she always relents and lets him have his way. I loved the way she responded to Jesse and l loved that she kept fighting it. I also loved that she just didn't easily give into him. I loved the relationship that they built and I loved they they grew to respect each other.I didn't love how Jesse constantly tried to hurt her while hiding himself away. But I did like that I got to understand the man behind the early smile and cheesy pick up lines. The flashbacks alone are enough to make anyone's life a hellacious one but that is not all Jesse had to endure in his lifetime. Hiding behind his smile is how he coped with all the crap that was constantly suffocating him. I love Jesse so much more after this book.Now I am gonna touch on the subject of Paige, Bell's sister that disappeared six years prior. I just did not see something like that touching the sweet Nurse Bell, but I am so glad that there was somewhere she could go when law enforcement had failed to move forward. I love that the Rebels are an MC that are willing to take care of their family no matter how new to the group they are. This most definitely one of my favorite MC series and I look forward to more.This book is a definite MUST read and so is the series!

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**I LOVE PERKINS VALE!!! That is all!Okay kidding...I LOVED this book in the Legendary Rockstars series! This is my favorite tale of The Nights thus far.This book was so well written and so were the characters. I loved that this series has a modern take on classic takes, but I love that it has an antiquated feel to it. I love the play on names that the author continues throughout this series. I love the modern time troubles that have the old world feel to them. I like the creepy characters because they make each tale unique. I love that this book takes place during the time as the previous one takes place. That we get to know what Perkins was up to while Lansing was making such a mess of his life. I also love that Perkins Vale seemed to complete his quest but I wasn't without struggle and plenty of time passing.From book one of the series we know that Perkins is not your usual rockstar and that he is looking for a girl from his teenage years. I like that throughout this book it seems that everyone knows who his mystery girl is but they had never crossed paths, except for those two fateful times. Even though it upsets him to know that she had been within his reach I think it makes for such a great story. I immediately fell in love with their relationship from the beginning.I loved that Perkins was riddled with question but I loved him even more for his patience. I loved Hollister right off the bat and I knew once she opened up to Perkins that their relationship would be amazing. I was right. I loved every push and pull I their relationship. I loved every truth revealed between them and I loved Perkins willingness to forgive and love Hollister regardless of how he first felt hearing her truths. Hollister is definitely fitting with the rest of the leading ladies in this series. She is such a loving and giving person even though she had something so precious taken from her. I loved her need to give back and take care of women in need. I also loved her tough exterior but I loved even more when she accepted the protective nature of Perkins.I guess I really just loved this book and I am looking forward to more of this series!

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**Wow!!! This is the best book of this series yet! I am so in love with Talia, Donovan, Jeremiah and even Allan. You will meet all of the most important men in Talia's life and you will fall in love with them just like I did. We even meet some characters that I can not wait for more of their stories to unfold.So, we met Talia in books one and two of The Affair Series as Laurie's best friend. I knew that I would love her from those books. I liked her personality and her devotion to her best friend. She was definitely a rock in a Laurie's rough patch and that spoke volumes of the type of person she is. I fell in love with her even more at the beginning of this book when she is a woman just trying to make a living doing what she loves and at the same time trying to take care of her father and everyone else she feels the need to help. I felt for Talia when she was feeling the weight of all her problems and the way she was so overwhelmed in trying to deal with everything by herself.During a pretty stressful time for Talia she gets a blast from her past, Donovan Lore, the man who changed her forever. I am immediately drooling over Donovan Lore and all his sexiness when he just shows up into Talia's center. I like that he is someone that she never thought she would see again because his is tied to one of the kids from her center. I like that just before he makes his first appearance she was just making comparisons between the troubled kid in her office and the man that once held her heart.Getting to see all of their relationships grow from the start of this book until the end was so great. This book is off the charts sexy, sweet and pretty funny at times. I like that the characters all evolved in some way, because it made for a better read and it really helped connect me with the characters and their story. I definitely want more of this series!
I loved this book and I can't wait to read the second one. If you would like to read my full review find it on my blog shanoffsaysdotcom

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**This was a quick and sexy read. I like the relationship of the two main characters as well as their relationship with their friends and families. I am glad that Lauren got to have a real relationship with her family all because she found the man that would stand up for her.Jackson is one sexy guy. I loved his confidence and definitely his swagger. He is such an honest and to the point kind of guy and that made him all the more appealing.I loved Lauren’s sassy attitude and her need to say whatever she is thinking. I liked her immediate attracting to Jackson and the fact that she could not ignore it. I also liked how she was with her friend Myer and with Jackson’s family.Sexy and quick read. I enjoyed the pace and the overall storyline.

** I received an ARC for an honest review.**I have recently read a few series and ending and I feel like I keep saying this, but this was a great ending to the Bliss Series. I am so glad that Dr. Noah Taylor finally got his story and that he found love. Although I want to shout out who his woman is I won't.BUT...I will say that she is oh so awesome and oh so funny. I loved her personality right from the start and I loved how she tried to keep strong and ignore all of the "Walking Dildo's" advances. She started out so so strong, but of course started to bend as he turned up the charm. I really liked that even though she had been through some pretty crappy things in her recent past, she didn't let it define her and she always did what was best for her. I think that she could of been a little more forthcoming with what she was struggling with when it came to those closest to her, but I can also understand that she didn't want to burden anyone with what she assumed would eventually fade away.We get to see a whole new side of WD. After this book I can no longer just define him by his extremely blessed member, I have to give him credit for his really awesome personality. Not only did he surprise me with his excellent boyfriend skills but he surprised me with how much he matured in this book. Don't get me wrong he is still the fun loving Noah, but he is oh so much better when he finds someone he wants to share his life with.These two characters together are sexy, sweet and funny. I like that the humor of this series did not lessen but it grew especially with (insert name here) and her family. I loved the witty remarks that were traded even while some pretty heavy stuff plagued (insert name here). I liked that the other characters from the previous book in the series are a constant in this book. Everyone makes an appearance and we get to see what is going on in their lives. The epilogue gives a great little glimpse into all of their Blissful futures...even Satan gets a shout out ;)Loved this book, loved the characters and I especially loved that everyone finds their Bliss.

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**I really really really enjoyed this book in the Willow Bay Series. I love that each book is so much different than the previous ones. From the start I was wondering if Sadie would keep her place in Emma's life and therefore in the band life too. I am so happy that both Sadie get their story.So, for the blurb we know that what Sadie though was her happily ever after was not at all her HEA. I had a feeling that Braden was not going to be in her life for the long haul after the scene at the New Years Party in Never Too Late. I am so glad that things came to a head with that and that Sadie took the initiative to start over with her life. I am also glad that the person she went to for help was Ezra.Ezra is just so easy to love and I loved him for the very beginning. He is a great brother, friend and eventually a really sexy lover. I really hated that he was so stubborn and denied both himself and Sadie what they both wanted the most, but I loved that when his finally was ready to reveal his feelings he did not do it in a small way but a really big way. So so sweet that Ezra.I loved how their relationship was hidden, because it seemed to make it that much more intense but I also hated the strain it put on Sadie. But it did make her face her long suppressed feeling, well both of them really.All the previous characters make an appearance in this book and I love that we get more of their stories too. The fact that all of them are still such a close KNIT (that is for Maddox) group is a really great thing about this series. I like that their lives are all still progressing and changing but they are all still very committed to being friends and family.I am really looking forward to Hayes' book...I can not wait. I am going to cut this off before I give anything else away. I hate spoiler reviews and this one is already on the verge of being spoilerish. I definitely recommend reading The Willow Creek Series.

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**I will start this review off by saying that I LOVE every book in this series and this book was an excellent end to a SENSATIONAL SERIES.From the beginning, in Sound Advice, we met Tricia Carter and her long time boyfriend Trent Walker. I loved her character from the start because of her selfless personality. She did so much for her family and she was just always genuine in who she was each and every time we see her. Over the last few books we got the sense that she wasn't happy in her relationship with Trent and boy what an understatement that was. I did not see the pretty heave stuff that came of that relationship coming. I just thought that her and Trent were simply in a rut and too comfortable with their relationship, but that could not be further from the truth. When it finally is revealed what all Tricia went through in her relationship with Trent it was heartbreaking, because she kept it all to herself, all because she did want to ruin someone who was already ruined to begin with.At the beginning of Sight Words Tricia is just starting a new school year, at a new school, and with her newly single status. She isn't all that hopeful that the will find new love in the small town of Elk Rapids and she is even less hopeful when she keeps running into Trent. But that all changes when she looks out the window of her classroom and watches the physically fit man play basketball everyday and the same time.Leon Ramirez. This is the first appearance of "King" of the whole series. He is new to town and has his priorities already lined out. Take care of his sisters and lay low, but he can't take care of his sisters without financial stability so he works not one, not two, but three jobs to take care of his sisters when his mother and father are forced to leave the country. He struggles to keep the afloat and he is working so hard to follow his fathers orders. He tries to stay under the radar, but it is hard when your are in a small town where everyone knows everyone. Not only that but the chemistry that he feels between him and Ms. Carter. He tries to fight it, because he knows he can't risk bringing her into his life.I loved that Tricia was such a genuine person when it came to wanting to help the Ramirez family. Even though Leon was constantly pulling and pushing her away. I enjoyed the build up of their relationship over the period of time that the Ramirez Family lived in Elk Rapids. The connection of Leon and Tricia was great to watch grow from how it started to the way it ended up. I loved every bit of their story because it felt real and never far fetched or rushed. There are so many things that are going on in both Tricia and Leon's worlds and when they all come to light it is so much easier to understand what makes them both tick. I enjoyed both of them as individual characters and I LOVED them as a couple.I said before that this was a great in to a great series and do recommend this whole series as a must read. LB Dunbar does an excellent job of drawing you into Elk Rapids and into the Scott and Carter families as if you grew up with these people all of your life. I fell in love with Jess and Emily, Ethan and Ella, Jacob and Pam, Gavin and Britton, and Tricia and Leon. I loved that in every book all of the previous characters made an appearance and I kept falling in love with them more. This group of people are such good friends and are always there for each other. It is a heartwarming series with fantastic and easy to love characters.

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**What an emotional read.This book starts off with a little glimpse into the past and what sets the pace for the rest of the book. When we meet both characters they are both lost in life, they both feel something lacking and one knows what it is while one has no clue what is about to hit them. Even though Nolan is living his dream and had accomplished so many things he still feels somewhat numb and empty. It isn't until he is back in his hometown and sees his Little B after six years. When he left he thought that no contact would be best for her to move on with her life but it didn't turn out like he thought.They see each other for the first time in six years and Brooklyn's suppressed feelings for Nolan return with a force, but Nolan is so confused by his attraction to his Little B and his need for their friendship to resume is most important to him.I really enjoyed the push and pull of both characters and their emotions. I liked that there was no insta-love with them (well on both sides)  and that it took time to grow their relationship again and make it stronger than it was. I loved that their friendship aspect always took priority over anything else. They always made time for each other and tried to help one another with what is going on in their lives. There is a lot going on, emotionally, in this books. At times it felt like it was a little too much but it all worked out for the best.At some point I thought thing would never line up for Brooklyn and Nolan, but neither of them were willing to give it up. I liked that they both refused to lose the relationship even if it meant they would never be able to be together as a couple, they knew they needed to always remain friends. But I did like the way this book ended. So many things came full circle fro them and the possibilities for their future are endless. I know this is a standalone, but I would not mind more of these two characters in maybe a flash forward novella.

**I received and ARC for an honest review.**What a beautifully emotional read. I LOVED this book. At first I had bit of trouble getting into it because I was constantly waiting for THAT point. The point where everything would change for Bailey. I kept asking myself "how will it happen?".Will Major not be as perfect as he appears?Is he a crook and gets arrested?Did he cheat with a stripper?Will his grandparents not give their blessing and in turn he doesn't want to marry Bailey?Does he die?Does he just leave her at the alter?Why is this book called Happily Ever Never?What is it that happens that drastically changed a Bailey's life?I was just obsessed with needing to find out that once I did I didn't think that I would be phased in the least. I WAS WRONG!!! I was phased...a lot. I cried, real tears and I am tearing up thinking about it all over again. What's more is that the last half of this book is so emotionally packed. I could not believe how this book turned around for me. I never thought I would connect with certain characters and I just couldn't see how some characters could connect with each other. Especially after the first half of the book.During the first half of this book I found Bailey a bit annoying and hard to root for, but I also knew she was super stressed with her upcoming wedding and meeting her soon to be husbands extended family. She was also on edge because her fiancés best friend was such a tool and she never knew what he was going to do. But by the second half of this book I was in love with Bailey. I was amazed at her strength and her ability to see the silver lining. I loved that she put the past in the past and was there to make someone feel loved and not alone. I love the person she turned into.So much sadness and heartbreak in this book but there was also tons to smile on by the ending. This book is fairly short but the flow and pace are very easy to follow and I love that it progresses easily.Only read this book if you have a box of tissues handy.

3.5 STARS**I received an ARC for an honest review.***I also bought the book and read the purchased book for review.*I really liked the premise behind this story and I liked the two main characters. It just seemed that the story had few inconsistencies and didn't seem fully developed for me. It just fell somewhat short for me in the overall storyline.BUT, it was pretty steamy and did keep me drawn in wanting to find out how things would go for the two characters. I was curious as to what haunted Drake's past and when it all came to light if it would ruin the life that he worked so hard to overcome. I was really curious as to how everything would work out for Gabby, but it seems that nothing was ever mentioned of her aspirations of being an author in the ending of the book.This book and story had potential and but it was also lacking of many things for me to give more than 3.5 stars.

3 Stars**I received an ARC for an honest review.**This book fell short for me there seemed to be a lot of things going on and I never felt a connection with the storyline or the characters.I loved Ledger but I just could not finish Mason and Callen was tough for me to connect with. I liked who he was a person and soldier but all of his conflicted emotions were hard for me to connect with. Same goes for Quinn. I just could not get a grasp on her. I also just never got that spark between the two either.The story could have been better but the flow of everything was just off for me. I hate writing this but it is my honest opinion.

**I received an ARC for an honest review.**This is a quick and sexy read, but it felt a bit lacking for me in a lot of areas. I know that this was meant to be a fast pace novella, but I just never felt the connection with the two characters. I felt that the way things started out was a bit of a reach, but I did end up enjoying the story overall.I just felt that a little more time could have been taken in cultivating the relationship between Jack and Jenna, mostly from the past. There was mention office flirtation and stuff but it just wasn't enough for me. I also thought that there could have been a little bit more of a separation between the two names of the men in Jenna's life, Jax and Jack were just too much at times and cause a bit of confusion.This little novella just didn't do it for me, but that does not mean it isn't for you or someone you know.

I just got two of these chairs and am very pleased with them. They were very easy to put together, requiring absolutely no tools whatsoever. The instructions are just a one page set of numbered pictures which you barely need as the assembly is pretty much common sense. It takes about 5 minutes to put a chair together.The cushions on the chairs are very thick and comfortable. Even the armrests, which appear to be hard plastic, are actually a cushiony foam material which is great for your elbows while still remaining easy to clean.What I like most is that the entire chair is adjustable. You can adjust how tall the back is. The armrests have two adjustments. One adjustment allows you to determine how far apart they are sideways from the seat cushion which is great for people who are thin or wide. The other adjustment allows you to determine how tall the armrests are set. So a tall person can set them to a higher setting than a short person.The chair has three additional settings. You can control the seat height (how far the seat cushion is from the floor), the chair back (how far it leans back), and the chair's tilt (this determines whether the chair pitches forward or backward). If you leave the chair back unlocked, then the chair acts like a rocker chair.These chairs are listed as high back chairs; however, I think they're more like mid back chairs. They do not overpower the room like the high back chairs I'm replacing.I bought two chairs to go in our computer room and have just ordered a third chair to go with a third desk. These chairs are my third set of chairs for that room. Our first set of chairs had a very similar upholstery fabric as these chairs which held up very well. Our second set of chairs were high back leather chairs that fell apart almost immediately after buying them. I'm hoping the upholstery on these chairs will perform as well as the upholstery on our first set of chairs. I also like that these chairs do not have any buttons to fall off.I am very happy I found these chairs. I've been looking for new chairs for a long time, but wanted something that combined good looks with comfort without spending a fortune. These chairs seem to have the perfect combination all the way around.

Finally, a dark colored cave for tanks with dark substrate! These caves are loved by all of my cave dwelling fish, as well as my shrimp. Best of all, my Pelvicachromis (aka Kribensis) love them!Because the caves have an open bottom, you can push them into the substrate as far as you want to make the caves larger or smaller. This allows cave dwellers to arrange the substrate inside the cave the way they want which is a normal part of the breeding process. For my kribensis, I like to push them almost all the way down so that just a tiny hole is left open. The female krib will pick the cave and then rearrange the gravel to make the opening just perfect for her. This gives her a sense of safety so she will breed and care for the eggs and fry.I've been looking for a dark colored cave that looked attractive in my planted tanks for a long time, and this cave is perfect. I started out with 3 caves and just bought 3 more. No more ugly clay pots! They look great in the tank and don't detract from the beautiful colors of the fish.UPDATE: My Pelvicachromis clearly love these caves! One pair mated and have successfully raised the fry. They're about 3/4" long now. The other pair have had two sets of fry, but aren't as good at parenting so they've lost both sets. However, they're trying for their third set of fry so maybe they'll do better at protecting them as they gain experience.Even though I still have other caves in the tanks for my Pelvicachromis fish to use, they most definitely prefer these caves. I'm not going to bother buying any other kind of cave from now on. These caves are a definite winner! Just bought 5 more for a 90g tank I'm converting over to a planted tank! I'll probably get even more for that tank over time.

I spent a long time reading reviews of stain removers before buying this one. I must admit, I was skeptical. But I'm a believer now!I had tried to clean dark stains from my an area rug years ago to no avail. Nothing I did would even budge the stains. Then health issues prevented me from cleaning my house, and everyone just gave up cleaning. I'm better now and trying to deep clean through about 3 years of filth and stains.Considering I could not get these stains out before all this happened, I had very little hope I'd get them out now. I even found a replacement rug. But before spending $1,000 on the replacement rug, I decided to try to clean my old rug one more time.The steam cleaner wasn't even budging the stains, using hot water with an oxyclean formula cleaner. That's when I grabbed my bottle of Folex cleaner for the first time. I read the instructions, and they seemed too easy, but I had nothing to lose. Imagine my surprise when it actually worked!!I started spraying stain after stain after stain and they were ALL coming out! I was getting so many stains out that I rubbed my fingers raw so I switched to using the back end of a toothbrush. The rug is indigo blue with a beautiful cream border, and that border is now just as pretty as new! I'm about halfway through cleaning it, but I've done the worst part (the high traffic area). There are just a couple more stains to get out, but I feel confident it'll get them.I hope they never stop making this stuff because I will never stop buying it. I finally found something that actually works!

I wanted something to keep my prescription medicines organized and locked up, but all of the normal boxes intended for those purposes did not fit my needs. So I took a chance on the Ape Case, and I couldn't be happier!The height of this particular case is perfect for prescription pill bottles. I can put about 30 prescriptions bottles in a case (5 rows of 6 across) which is quite a few. The case comes with padding on top and bottom which fills in the gaps for smaller bottles so they don't fall around when you pick up the case and move it. There's also padding that you break away to shape for the items you're storing so if you have fewer bottles to store, you can use the padding to fill in the gaps to keep things organized. This means you can label the lids, stand them up in the case, close the case, and then move it around without the contents getting jumbled around. When you open the case again, everything is just as you put it.While the case comes with a key lock, the latches have loops which can be padlocked, if desired. I also like that it's metal and not plastic.I looked all over for something to lock up prescription medicines, and I think this case is the best thing I've found. It's even better than the cases I've seen designed to lock up meds. It's the perfect size and offers a lot of flexibility of use.

I had basically given up on using super glues before trying this one. When other super glues worked, they were great, but they often did not work. Even worse, they would dry up quickly, making the entire bottle wasted. However, Gorilla Glue has exceeded my expectations. It has worked on everything I've tried without the drawbacks I've encountered with other super glues.I have used this glue for well over a year now, and it continues to be good! The bottle has about 1/5 of the glue left in it so it looks like I'll be able to use most, if not all, of the entire bottle. I couldn't be happier!

I bought this fan a couple of years ago and now can't live without it. I'm buying another one so I can keep one in my bedroom and one on my covered patio. It is quiet enough to use while sleeping. It puts out so much air, it offers instant relief. It does a better job than the ceiling fan on its highest setting.I'm using mine even with our central a/c set at 74F. I still get hot with the a/c, but this fan instantly cools me off. It blows strong enough to actually offer relief even when outside.I cannot recommend this fan enough!-------------UPDATE: I am downgrading my original review from 5-stars to 4-stars because I found another fan that I think is much better. The fan I prefer is the Honeywell Fresh Breeze Tower Fan with Remote Control, HY-048BP which is also available here on Amazon for about $10 less.Differences between the Lasko and the Honeywell fans:Air-Flow: The Lasko wins out when it comes to the amount of air that is blown. So if the most important feature you want is air flow (and not temperature cool down), then the Lasko would be the better choice. However, the Honeywell isn't that far behind when it comes to air flow, and it offers many other features that I have found to make it a far better fan than the Lasko.Cooling: The single most important difference that I prefer with the Honeywell is that it has a thermostat that allows you to set a temperature for the room (in 2 degree increments). That does two things: First, the fan blows colder air into the room. You can actually feel the temperature difference! Second, you can optionally set the fan to automatically turn itself on and off based on the room temperature. When the room temperature is above the temperature you set on the fan, the fan automatically turns itself on, cools down the room, then it shuts itself off. This is the same behavior as that of an air conditioner!Noise: The Honeywell is also a quieter fan; although, I must say that both fans are very quiet. The noise made by both fans comes only from the sound of the rushing air which is unavoidable. But since the Honeywell uses colder air for cooling while the Lasko uses high velocity air for cooling, the Lasko makes more noise.Remote Control: The Honeywell includes a very nice extra feature of a remote control that is missing in the Lasko fan. I have found the remote control to be a wonderful tool as I can alter the fan's setting quickly and easily anytime I want. Sometimes I will change the settings if I'm drinking something cold which chills me for a few minutes. I use the remote control every day because it's just so convenient.Dependability: I have owned both fans for at least two years and have found them to be highly dependable. So I'd say they are basically equal in lasting a long time.Price: Surprisingly, the Honeywell runs about $10 less even though it has more features. This is one time when you don't get more by paying more.Other: Otherwise, both fans are basically the same. There are other small differences, but they don't matter much to me. The Honeywell has a filter that some people may find preferable, but I don't think it's good enough to make much of a difference. Both fans offer multiple speeds and can be set stationary or oscillating. You can direct the air flow up or down somewhat on the Lasko, but not the Honeywell. The Lasko is shorter and has a more solid base footing so it's less likely to be pushed over by children or pets, but I haven't had any problems with the Honeywell being knocked over. So there are some minor differences, but I didn't find any of these features to sway my preference between the two fans since my main focus is on the fans' cooling abilities and the Honeywell's cooling abilities is so superior that it makes all the other differences insignificant.BOTTOM LINE: If you are wanting to push a lot of air around, get the Lasko. If you want to cool down the room or yourself, then get the Honeywell. I especially recommend the Honeywell for people who get hot while sleeping at night!

At the bottom, I've updated a couple of comments now that I use the iLap for my MacBook Pro.I bought my iLap in July of 2006 for my PowerBook G4.  I was having problems with my PowerBook being unbearably hot when placed on my lap so I decided to give the iLap a try.The iLap has surpassed my expectations.  I feel absolutely no heat on my lap from my PowerBook even though I use my PowerBook many hours at a time, every day.  The hinged front and back cushions offer enough flexibility that I can use the iLap in many different positions, such as sitting up or laying on my back on the couch.  I also find the cushions offer enough support that I don't have problems with discomfort from the weight or metal of my PowerBook or the iLap itself.I have not had the slipping problem others have reported.  My iLap came with 4 rubbery pads that grip the PowerBook very well.  If I do notice any slippage, all I have to do is clean the pads and the feet on my PowerBook, and the slippage stops completely.  I have to clean it maybe every 2 or 3 months which is very reasonable.  I constantly walk around with my PowerBook on my iLap, and the grip is so good that I have to be careful to remind myself that they are not truly attached because I sometimes find myself not holding my PowerBook as securely as I should.  So far, in 8 months of use, the iLap has not allowed my PowerBook to slip even with my occasional carelessness.The iLap has held up very well after 8 months.  The cushions have not degraded, the front cushion remains firmly attached (although, I usually don't take it off as there's no need), and while I'm sure the cushions must be dirty by now, you wouldn't know it by looking at it.  I have used a lint remover on the cushions a couple of times to clean up cat hairs when my cat thinks my closed PowerBook is her personal warmed napping spot, but that's about as much care as my iLap has needed.I have found my iLap to be so good that I take it everywhere I go, including finding ways to put it in suitcases when I go out of town.  The hinged front cushion helps greatly when packing it, and it's stood up well through many plane rides in the front pocket of suitcases that were checked in.I can't say enough good things about my iLap.  It is one accessory that I find completely indispensable for my laptop usage and comfort.  It receives my highest of recommendations, especially considering how well it's held up for so long.UPDATE: I have now used my same iLap for 2.5 years! I still can't live without it! I have had a MacBook Pro for about 1.5 years now, and continue to use my iLap with it. I finally did run into slipping problems as the rubbery pads hardened with age. But I found a great way to resolve this issue.When I bought my MacBook Pro, I immediately put it in a clear hardshell case to protect it. To stop it from slipping on the iLap, I simply put velcro on my hardshell case and on the iLap. Now the MacBook Pro stays put without any slipping at all no matter how I position it.If you give velcro a try, I suggest putting the soft side on the Mac's case and the hook side on the iLap itself. That way when you take your Mac somewhere in which you don't take the iLap, the velcro on the bottom isn't a problem.I also wanted to comment that I ended up removing the cushion in the front of the iLap, and I have found it to be very comfortable on my lap without it.I've used Macintosh computers since 1986, and this is one accessory that I have used the longest. I cannot be happier that I bought it.UPDATE 2: Wow, I ran across my old review and just realized that I've been using my iLap for over 5 years! It's still doing great! I'm now using it with my 3rd computer, and still can't imagine being without it. I use this thing every single day for many hours each day. Amazing value to get this much use out of a product. It's still just as good as ever!

Quality of the hardware looks good.  The App is also very intuitive.  The connection process is needlessly aggravating and takes many tries.  You really have to mess with it to get it to connect.  I have lots of experience pairing bluetooth devices, and I think iDevices got something wrong here.
These are really too small.  I will keep looking.  Doesn't survive a single showering either.

Sticks out too far.  You don't need points that big for most jobs.  The ones I pulled out from the windows were much smaller.  I had to add glazing to cover these large points up, which closed off the viewable window space and made the glazing line more visible from the inside.
I want white pepper to be tasted, not seen.  I bought by the name and not the look.  Just take a look at the picture.  That's not white pepper.  It's green pepper.
Best hot sauce I've tasted.  Real heat - and real flavor.  Amazing depth - not just heat and vinegar.  Great for sauces and marinades, but try it on scrambled eggs if you dare....

I bought a few of these from HD, and I've lost one already.  Half the LEDs are out, and it's flashing.  The frost melted off one side and you can see clear in.Geek speak time:  This is probably poor thermal management design as evidenced by severe discoloration of the base.  This part runs too hot - basically destroyed itself.  Fins are too small for this design or design is too electrically inefficient for the package they chose.LED's aren't green if they fail early and become landfill.

My favorite LED light bulb so far, and I've tried multiple brands including Cree and Ikea.  Warm light, bright as advertised, and it's shaped exactly like an incandescent.  Many lamps and fixtures don't play well with funky shaped LED or CFL bulbs.  This works perfectly.LED > CFL:Longer lifeHigher energy efficiencyRuns cooler.  Some CFLs you actually get discoloration of the base from too high temperaturesInstant onMuch better light distributionShaped like a light bulb.  Ice cream cones can be problems for some lamps that grab the outer surface of the bulb.LED<IncandescentNot dimmable (at least not this one)High up front costsLED>IndandescentMuch longer lifeMuch higher efficiencyRuns much cooler

If the food you're eating tastes like lime, it's too much.  Less is more with citrus or vinegar.  Should be just enough acid for the dish to "pop", and not a bit more.  Love their products, but I won't be replacing this one.

What one should expect in underwear.Doesn't bunch upDoesn't ride up your legCoolComfortableNice enough looking for the occasional presentation to the opposite genderDurableI can review all but the last point, because this is a new review.  All other boxes are checked ;-)These are the best boxer briefs I've ever owned.  I've tried Hanes, Costco, Adidas, Merona, Champion, and a few other brands.  None compare to these CK's.  I will never change brands if they keep making them like this.These are comfortable all day, and they feel cool.Undies Ranking:1. CK (this review)Runner up: Merona (Target) - great and super cheap, but not produced any more3rd - Costco - yeah, I said it.  Best value.4th - Adidas - not bad.  A bit goofy looking5th - Champion - Material too thin and bunches up6th - Hanes - just awful.  Bunches up, not cool, not comfy,  and poor quality material.I have not tried the boutique brands.  It's only underwear after all.  But I'm satisfied CK is best of the best.

I was expecting this blower to get rid of  leaves and freshly cut grass.  What I wasn't expecting was branches 1/2-3/4",  caked on grass and helicopters cemented to the sidewalk from the last rain to be also dispatched.  I never even used turbo mode.I really appreciate the quiet.  Thanks to Ego, I don't have to wear hearing protection when I mow or blow off my sidewalk.I LOVE this blower -worth every penny!!

I'm sorry, but I don't want to spend the counter space or ridiculous money for a decent stand mixer.  Enter this little baby.I've used this for a half dozen times only, but I'm nothing but satisfied so far.  It's plenty powerful, the whips are sturdy enough, and it feels like a good build quality.  I expected a really cheap feel for the price, but I was pleasantly surprised.The speed ranges are good, the cord is plenty long enough, and I can actually stand the thing up with the whips still in so I can scrape the bowl.You really can't go wrong for 'once in a while' general baking needs.

Quiet.  Compact for a full sized keyboard.  Great action.  Stylish.  Stays put.  I bought two of them.  Best rubber dome keyboard I have ever used, and I have used LOTS of keyboards.Mouse is responsive and has excellent range.  Wheel is smooth and quiet.  Many mice have gritty feeling wheels.  Not this one.Love, love, love it.
Old tech.  Loud keyboard.  Poor action.  Almost garish looking with the transparent ring around it.Returned it for the MK360, which is a far superior keyboard in every respect.

I tried the Chana Masala.  This was the worst recipe I've ever tried.  Over salted and absolutely bland tasting.  Coriander, cumin, and chilis.  That's pretty much it.  Some times less is more, but this time less was so much less.I think I just wasted my money.

I've tried Teflon, stainless steel, anodized aluminum, properly seasoned cast iron (almost 'the one'), ceramic (totally not 'the one'), and a bunch of other formulations.  I have NEVER had a non stick pan that was really non stick until now.  It feels like it's coated with silicone and sprayed with Scotch-Guard.  It's simply amazing.It's a perfect size for cooking mains. What's not to like?  I cannot wait to try their other sizes for omelettes and what-not.

Great nonstick quality for a few months, then it turned into a very sticky pan.  Worse than properly seasoned cast iron.  About the same as stainless steel. Even when using spray oil (Pam) on this pan, scrambled eggs stick like glue.I hate wasting things, but this pan is going into the garbage.  Good bye Thermolon ceramic, hello Tfal plain ole' non stick.If you don't cook regularly, this might work for you.  If you want your pan to last a few years and you use it at least a few times a month, I'd recommend to take a pass on this product.

Does the job perfectly, even on large lemons.  Easy on the hands too, but if you want all the juice you do have to do some of the work with the tool.  Very good build quality, materials, and fit and finish.  If you cook with fresh citrus a lot, this is a must have unitasker.  It literally shoots out the juice, so be careful with the aim.And to think, I used to squeeze lemons and limes by hand.  What a waste of time and money.  This tool is very fast, and it wastes nothing.  What remains is a funny looking inside out rind.

Cooks up quickly, and has a very fiendly, mild taste.  My go-to brand for tabbouleh.The plastic jar is very nice.  No more bags for me.  The bags have a way of leaking out, or you have to transfer it to another container.On the other hand, the prices on this site for this product are significantly more than local boutique stores.  You should save your hard earned money and shop for this product elsewhere.

Good quality, but a bit gnarly in my tabbouleh.  I much prefer the Roland brand, as it's a bit rounder tasting and doesn't 'bloom' in the bowl like Bob's.  Bob's almost reminds me of a fine barley in texture.

An excellent design vs the old teardrop style.  It holds much more water, you don't have to take the lid off to fill it, and it has a flapper over the water spout.  Sturdy and space efficient.  Excellent value.
Never shuts off, even with no motion over a sustained time.  Defective.  Will return
Doesn't fit the 14" lightweight cast iron Joyce Chen wok quite right.

Great functional kitchen shears.  Very tight fit, no problems with the dishwasher.  Kind of funky looking, but they've grown on me.  Love the pointed tips - makes it easy to cut exactly what and where you want.  Lots of uses where knives would be normally used, e.g. cutting parsley.  They stick to my knife magnet just fine.
Great ladle.  Sturdy and easy to find.  Love the flat front.  Nice to see people are still innovating simple kitchen gadgets.

Lasted one cleaning, and it's ready for the garbage.  That's OK, but the replacement pad costs nearly as much as the entire setup did to begin with.  The whole thing is going into the trash can - scrubber, handle, and pad.  Better that than any more of my money.  There are far cheaper ways to clean.

If you know cast iron skillets, you know the benefits and care and feeding requirements.  An examination of the grates themselves shows they are definitely cast iron - extremely heavy.  But it's not really porcelain coated, whatever the marketers would have you believe.  A proper porcelain coating is smooth.  These are anything but.I just replaced the old porcelain steel grates with these grates.  The new grates make perfect grill marks.  They also have the ability to conduct heat into the food faster.  The steel grates basically just hold the food off the fire - they don't help cook the food.If your grates start to rust, you're not seasoning properly .  You have to coat the grates with oil over the entire surface periodically.  I cannot imagine that coating they call porcelain will hold up that long.  But if you are willing to live with the little bit of extra maintenance, you can basically get food that tastes like it was made on a charcoal grill.Like a cast iron skillet, if you take care of these grates, they will never fail you.  They will outlast the rest of the grill.

Pros-it works well.  no more weekly cleaning of toilets which I do not use.fast installation - about a minute and a halfno leakagevery easy to check remaining amount of tablets (you have to pull off the lid)Cons-bowl clip-on mounting feature was not well thought out and may interfere with proper fitting of the lidthere is a chemical smell.  while not exactly a Holiday Inn swimming pool, you can detect it even from the next roomWorkarounds/Hacks-use 1" spa bromine tablets for replacements which are a tiny fraction of the pricekeep the cover down to deal with the smell (I guess you should do this anyway)zip tie the body above the water line to the main filler tube, away from moving parts.  this will prevent the lid from rocking due to poor fit.

This one has a very nice finish.  It's not perfectly smooth - it has a very fine ridged surface.  I believe this helps to keep food from sticking.  I always start with a bit of peanut oil, and I've never had anything stick.I've had noodles and chicken stick to seasoned carbon steel woks before.  The Tfal nonstick wok I had was great for nonstick, but it couldn't be warmed up over medium (believe it or not).  That's not real stir fry.  The steel wok I had was functional, but it looked quite natty after a couple of uses and the handle worked loose.This wok is my go-to for stir fry and a great saute' pan for many things besides stir fry.Finally, remember with any cast iron cooking product to clean WITHOUT soap and finish with a light coating of oil from a paper towel to prevent rust.  This will keep the seasoning in good shape.

I really wanted to like this TV.  Great brand with a long history in making LCD displays, great price, nice looking.  I have its little brother at my office so I already knew the UI.  But I don't watch movies at work, and I couldn't notice the problem with a delay between audio and video.  This is especially noticeable on the B's and M's on the speaking parts.I first noticed it on an external BluRay DVD player, which was brand new.  Then I tried a Roku and of course the internal smart TV.  Problems everywhere until I tried the X Box.  I used the component outputs from the X Box 360.  Hmmm.After reading the forums, they basically said to turn off all the video processing or put it into game mode to speed up the video decoding.  This did help, but it was still noticeable.  I thought about just using the X Box to relieve the CPU in the TV from decoding the HDMI, but component out s a dying technology.So, I took it back to the store where I bought it.  The crew was incredulous, so they set it up with a DVD player.  The process was painful, as it took them nearly 10 minutes.  Finally, they got it running and two of the three people from the store who were apparently just there for the entertainment of it all said - yep, I see it, and walked away.  The third guy gave me my full refund.My lessons learned.  A great display brand does not necessarily a great TV brand make.  Slow video processing on HDMI inputs can cause the audio to be decoded much quicker than the video, resulting in a lip synch problem.  Since most sources don't allow you to set a delay, you have to deal with the problem in the TV.Which is where my story ends.  I picked up a Samsung 6300 series in its place which does not exhibit the problem at all.  It even has a programmable audio delay.  Nice touch.  It also has Amazon Prime which the Sharp did not have, which is one of my favorite streaming sources.

These are the most comfortable business shoes I've owned.  Lots of travel and lots of walking. I've even ran in these shoes two miles!It's  hard to find loafers that don't slip, and these fit the bill. They look great, too.But alas the most brutal winter in memory took its toll on my old pair. I'd also worn the tread smooth. I would have kept them otherwise.1/19/2015 update:  I'm going on my third pair.  I wear them for work, play, and travel, and I keep wearing out the soles.  Other than that, they seem to be able to last forever.Update:  Moving to another brand.  Impossible to find this one in my size.  Sole tread wears out in 6-8 months of moderate walking.  New shoe:  Rockport Style Leader Bike 2.0 Slipon.  Every bit as comfortable with a better tread.  We'll see how that works!

Ouija Exorcism is about what you'd expect for a straight-to-DVD horror flick. I tried to give the movie a chance, as you can sometimes find hidden gems among low-budget horror movies, but it disappoints.The good: The cinematography has its moments, there are a couple lines of funny dialogue, and the story just barely scratches the surface of Jewish exorcisms (something rare in horror movies).The bad: The audio levels change way too much. You find yourself turning up the volume just to hear what's being spoken, only for it to be too loud the following scene. The lighting effects aren't consistent. The movie contains too much filler of weak dialogue and subplots involving relationships. The acting isn't anything special. The special effects and "demon" voice sound effects are lame. And aside from a one or two "boo" moments meant to startle the viewer, the movie just isn't that scary.If you're a diehard fan of movies related to demonic possession, it might be worth watching. If you're a casual fan of horror movies, do yourself a favor and pass on this one.

Loveworks isn't exactly a how-to book on marketing, but it will absolutely offer the inspiration needed to excel in advertising. The core concept of the book isn't new: people make purchases based on their emotions, rather than logic. But Loveworks provides 20 case studies of how different companies were able to create amazing foundations of customer loyalty. The type of love for a brand that makes consumers look past premium pricing, ignore competitors, and maintain that support if a company makes mistakes.The author spent 25 years working for one of the world's leading ad agencies. Which makes Loveworks a treasure chest of real-world examples of how businesses were able to successfully convert their target audience into diehard supporters. What's great about the case studies is that they're backed up with statistics which prove "Lovemarks" is more than just marketing theory. You're given a clear sense of what each company accomplished as the result of their Lovemarks-based advertising campaigns. And although the case studies all reference the author's former ad agency's (Saatchi & Saatchi) involvement in these campaigns, it doesn't come off as boasting or self-promotion.Can you benefit from reading this book if you don't work for big brands like Nike, T-Mobile, Pampers, or Cheerios? Yes. Loveworks is concluded with a simple four-step process that can be applied to any business. Although the case studies all involve well-known brands, the main concept of Lovemarks can work for anyone, even small businesses that don't have a recognized brand. So even if you're familiar with advertising psychology and emotional appeal to customers, the case studies will inspire you, and open your eyes more on connecting with your audience.

I've developed and promoted hundreds of websites over the last 14 years, and have made millions for my clients. I bought this book to see if there were any useful new copy writing tips, or to let newbies know if it's helpful. But at best, it's a brief primer of recycled ideas that may only help point new copy writers in the right direction.Pros: The book mentions a few basics of writing copy. This includes how to write a headline, how to organize text, making copy easy to skim, and writing in a conversational style.Cons: The book is basically a small pamphlet with a lot of fluff and filler. None of the writing techniques mentioned are original. The book barely scratches the surface of these writing techniques, so newbies to copy writing are seriously missing out on how to make the most of these methods. I also can't help but notice that most of these five-star reviewers have only reviewed one product (this book), give vague/brief reviews, or don't seem to be writers.Bottom Line: Even if you're new to writing, this book wouldn't help you much. There are other books available that provide more info on how to get results from writing good copy. Books that helped to improve my client sales and leads over the years include: Ca$hvertising, The Copywriter's Handbook, Words that Sell, The Everything Guide To Writing Copy, and Content Rules.

If you're a fan of pre-reggaeton ragga rap by artists like El General, or 90's urban Latin music when "underground" (later called reggaeton) was blowing up in Puerto Rico, you'll enjoy this single. The beat samples same of the same sounds from popular ragga rap tracks going back to '89, and Aldo Ranks spits in the trademark Panamanian dancehall style.

I've developed and marketed hundreds of websites over the last 14 years. So I'm always looking for new tips, or curious to see how thorough internet marketing bookies for newbies are. While "Get the Click" has a few useful (but recycled) tips for people new to website promotion, I felt the book could have offered much more info.Pros: Get the Click offers a limited primer to newsletter signups, identifying target customers, and writing website text to encourage sales.Cons: There's only about two dozen pages of actual techniques, with frequent double-spacing. It's almost as though a few different blog posts with lots of fluff were slapped together into a pamphlet. The "formula" described in the book are techniques that have been mentioned in other web marketing books - but in much more detail - over the last 5-10 years. I also found it questionable that the author's own business site is not optimized for Google, and doesn't use any of the techniques he promotes he in the book. It's also odd that every account that gave this book five stars all happen to review the same e-books, all giving five-star ratings with vague reviews. Smells like paid shills.If you are new to internet marketing, I don't think this book would be helpful. There are significantly better, more thorough books available for less money. Even if it's a free Kindle download (I paid $9.97 for the paperback), you'd get more out of reading books like Ca$hvertising, Words that Sell, The Copywriter's Handbook, Likeable Social Media, Content Rules, and The Ultimate Web Marketing Guide.

Student of the Game isn't Noreaga's best work, but it's still an album fans should cop. I've been listening to his music since the CNN days of War Report, and while my preference is for his old stuff, much of what's on the new album is trademark NORE: street life, sex and drugs.As with all of his albums, N.O.R.E. is highly listenable, even if he's not trying to be especially lyrical. He acknowledges this on Camouflage Unicorns, spitting "I'm the Lefrak king, I don't care what you say to me, say I don't make sense, cool that's okay with me."  Where he shines is easily "Built Pyramids", which coincidentally has the best beat on the album thanks to Large Professor. You can also expect some vintage N.O.R.E. with "Faces of Death", which feels a bit like a continuation of "Banned From T.V." Four minutes, no hook, just N.O.R.E. going hard on the track along with French Montana, Swizz Beatz, Raekwon and Busta Rhymes.Student of the Game has a mix of guest features ranging from longtime artists (Scarface, Pete Rock, Havoc) to a few that have only recently started to get a buzz. The only unusual thing about the guest spots is that Lil Wayne only did the hook for "She Tried", he doesn't drop any verses for the track.Most of the beats are good, a few I wasn't feeling. Amazon obviously doesn't list them, but the beatmakers for the album are Cookin Soul, Illa, Inf, Pharrell, SPK, Pete Rock, Charlie Brown, Scram Jones, DJ Thoro, Hazardis Soundz, Large Professor, and Jahlil Beats. Standout beats on the album are "What I Had to Do" by SPK, "Built Pyramids", and "Camouflage Unicorns". The last of which has Nore, Havoc and Tragedy Khadafi dropping bars over a music box sample and a dusty beat (samples "Love Story" by Henry Mancini, same as Immortal Technique "Dance with the Devil" if it sounds familiar).One of the few complaints I'd have about the new album is the number of skits and filler tracks. The album is 19 tracks deep, five of them are skits/fillers. I can maybe understand showing props to Victor Cruz and Kevin Hart by putting them on the album, but I have no idea why Scott Disick (Kourtney Kardashian's baby daddy) is on the album.Overall, Student of the Game is worth copping. Sometimes he stretches it thin to make words rhyme (or not at all), not every guest feature is on point, and a few beats aren't suited for him. But I still enjoy the new album, and it's an overall step up from Noreality. If you've been a fan for a minute, you'll like the album.

As a movie fan in general, I enjoyed Filly Brown. But as a longtime urban music journalist, I also appreciated just how true to life this movie was.  What makes Filly Brown stand out from movies like Hustle and Flow or 8 Mile is both how it deals with women in urban music, and having a female lead that offers a powerful performance.Filly Brown tells the story of Majo Tonorio, a Latina rapper who dreams of performing for huge audiences.  The Los Angeles MC builds her buzz rapping on the radio as Filly Brown, but her desire to get signed gets put into full gear because of her family. Filly's mother (played by Jenni Rivera) is serving a ten year prison sentence, her only hope for early release depends on whether Filly can come up with fast cash. What follows is a story of desire, manipulation, and redemption.Despite having a low budget, Filly Brown was shot well. But what really stands out about the movie is the cast, a mix of film veterans and new faces. Gina Rodriguez puts on a terrific performance as Filly Brown, with a voice and intensity that made her a great choice for the role.Edward James Olmos adds some seasoning to the film, and is reunited with Stand and Deliver alumnus Lou Diamond Phillips, who plays the hardworking father of Filly and her younger sister.  Film and TV star Emilio Rivera plays Mani, Filly's protective uncle and boss. California rappers Cuete Yeska and Baby Bash add new faces to the cast, with H-Town artist Chingo Bling adding some needed humor to the film as Filly's manager.Despite this being her first feature film, Jenni Rivera (RIP) offers a moving portrayal of Maria, Filly's drug addicted mother doing hard time.  Rivera ditched her trademark stage glamor for a prison uniform to deliver a haunting and memorable performance.  Her scenes are convincing, bittersweet considering Filly Brown will be the only time she appears in movie theaters.As far as the movie's inside look at the urban music game, Filly Brown scores for realism. Hip Hop managers are left hanging when labels strike backroom deals. Female rappers are often denied mainstream attention if they refuse to compromise their artistic integrity. In this case, Filly succumbs to the pressure of "sexing up" her image and lyrics to land a record deal for a fast payout to help her mother.The movie isn't flawless, of course.  Filly Brown offers more than a couple character types common to other movies, which gives several scenes a recycled feel. There are also one too many subplots, which threatens to muddle the film as the end approaches.Overall, Filly Brown succeeds. Its lineup of actors, surprisingly good Hip Hop soundtrack, and tear-jerking ending all make it a film to remember. Although the film features a variety of established Latino actors and artists, it's a movie that anyone should be able to enjoy. Definitely worth getting on DVD or Blu-Ray.

Few movies start out with as much promise yet failure to deliver as The Devil's in the Details. What could have been a memorable film with a veteran cast of actors is instead a massive disappointment.The Devil's in the Details tells the story of a soldier struggling with PTSD, kidnapped by a drug cartel in an attempt to use his family to help smuggle drugs into Mexico. Combat veteran Thomas Conrad is tortured as his wife and child are held hostage, while everyone's fate depends on the cartel's tasks being performed on schedule.The only good news about this film is that is features a variety of experienced actors. But that's not enough to redeem all of the problems that plague what had the potential to be a memorable crime thriller. As for the bad news, there's plenty of it.The movie involves a number of flashbacks, but unlike Slumdog Millionaire or Pulp Fiction, the non-linear approach doesn't do much for this film.  It's filled with tiring dialogue and scenes that seem to go on forever.  To distract you from the pointlessly long scenes, the camera is always panning around, and there's too much atmospheric background music.  Most of the action is off-screen until the movie is almost over, and the torture is unnecessary considering the cartel's hostage plan can work without it. The ridiculous coincidence of what Conrad's family members do for a living is already hard to swallow, let alone the pointless complicated smuggling plan.Raymond J. Barry and Ray Liotta bring some talent to the film, but are totally underused. Emilio Rivera steals the show as the devilish kidnapper, but sadly his performance will go unnoticed since this film will get little attention.  As for the main character Thomas Conrad, I have no idea why Joel Mathews was cast as the lead in this movie. He had only been in one full-length film plus a short by the same director; the 12 year old playing his daughter actually had more screen experience. His performance was just terrible.Any tension that isn't wasted in the movie builds up to a twist, and it's a weak one. As the seemingly relevant flashbacks continued, I was hopeful that a dark spin was coming a la Session 9 or Jacob's Ladder. So when the twist is revealed (and it's not original), you're left saying "Wait... that's it?" It's such a let down that you're forced to believe it's so brilliant and subtle that you missed something. Well, you didn't.The only reason I'm not giving the film one star is because of Emilio Rivera, Raymond J. Barry, and Ray Liotta. The sole special feature is a 12-minute behind the scenes featurette with cast interviews. Watch this online before you consider buying the DVD or Blu-Ray. If you're a fan of Emilio Rivera or Ray Liotta, it's worth watching online once, otherwise give this one a pass.

The original score for Cocaine Cowboys was composed by Jan Hammer, the same musician who created the theme for Miami Vice as well as the TV show's weekly music.  The album has almost all of the original music from the movie, including the second track which was the sample for "Cocaine Cowboys" by rapper N.O.R.E.One issue I did have is that the song that plays when the documentary's title pops up and the intro credit rolls isn't on this album, and it's a song that some people may specifically want. Look up "Cocaine Cowboys Theme Song 01" online and the first result is a video with an incorrect mixtape cover. It's neither on the Rick Ross mixtape nor the official movie score album. Also, the full album download price for only six songs at 17 minutes of music seemed a bit high. I understand the pricing for individual tracks, just seems like the full album cost should have been lowered. But overall, this is a good soundtrack, and worth buying if you're a big fan of the documentary.

This is a good compilation of old-school style Bachata. Just keep in mind that despite the album title, these are mostly songs from early 2012. Even though I prefer modern Bachata (Prince Royce, Aventura, Xtreme), I still enjoy the traditional sound from time to time.What's great about this album is that most of the artists are established, unlike some of the compilations with just a bunch of unknown Bachateros. "I Love Bachata 2013" has Yoskar Sarante, El Chaval, Frank Reyes; a good number of artists with hit songs recently and going back to the 90's. You also get a bit of the modern Bachata sound thanks to tracks like "Por Mentira" by Grupo Vena.  My only complaint would be that a few songs such as those from Kiko Rodriguez, El Chaval and Luis Segura are from 2011. At least two of the songs (by Truhanes and Emocion) were on the radio back in 2010. So just know that it's not all 2013 music.This is a good collection of songs if you like the older Bachata style. The entire MP3 album on Amazon costs less a Starbucks Frappuccino, so there's no reason why you shouldn't buy it now if you like Bachata.

If you're looking for established Bachata artists like Romeo Santos, Prince Royce, or Hector Acosta, this album may not be for you. But if you want some good Bachata from groups that are still underground, DanDote Bachata 2013 is a decent compilation of songs.Most of the songs are enjoyable, which is a surprise because many bachata compilations of unsigned or up and coming artists aren't that good. My only real complaint is that you can only tell who the different artists and groups are if they shout their own name out, otherwise the MP3s don't mention the specific singers.  Even though the album isn't Aventura-quality, I can listen to a playlist of all the songs on repeat, except for the title track "Dandote" (terrible off-key singing).Aside from the poor title track, and the record label misspelling the album name on the cover, I thought this was a decent collection of Bachata songs. Overall it's a good album considering the artists are mostly unknown.

Fiesta Latina is a decent compilation when the price is less than $4.00 for an MP3 album download, just don't expect more than a couple of big name artists.  Out of 21 tracks, about half are from late 2012 and 2011, so it's not exactly all 2013 songs.If you favor Dominican music, there are five Merengue tracks and four Bachata songs. The rest of the album is mostly Latin Pop, and a little bit of Spanish Reggae and Romantikeo. The best song on the compilation is easily "Echale Salsa" by Ciclon Cubano, but it's also from 2011, so it's not especially new. The one track that should have probably been left off of the album is the "Gangnam Style" track by Miss Evelyn, it's just outdated now. Most of the artists on this compilation are from the same record label, so you're not really going to get any recognized artists. At only 20 cents a song, it's worth getting as a playlist.  It was about what I expected for an affordable tropical music compilation.

Fast Five adds an interesting twist to the Fast & Furious franchise, leaning more towards heist flick than a street racing film. Universal Studios has breathed new life into the series by switching up the formula, and Fast Five won't disappoint action junkies.Fast Five reunites Dom Toretto (Vin Diesel) with cop-turned-racer Brian O'Connor (Paul Walker) in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro. Diesel reprises his role of Toretto, this time on the run from a high-octane federal law enforcement team led by Luke Hobbs, played by Dwayne Johnson.Complicating their situation further is Brazilian drug kingpin Hernan Reyes, portrayed by veteran actor Joaquim de Almeida of "Desperado" fame. The only way to dig themselves out of their hole is to pull off a final caper to the tune of $100 million, aided by a variety of former series characters.What makes the latest addition to the Fast & Furious franchise a success is the amount of adrenaline injected into the film. Fast Five is chock full of tense moments, fast cars and shootouts. Adding a bit of levity to an otherwise hardcore action flick are the duo of reggaeton artists Don Omar and Tego Calderon, who return to the series with comedic relief in tow. Tyrese Gibson, Ludacris, Jordana Brewster, Sung Kang, and Matt Schulze also reprise their roles to offer a sense of familiarity to viewers.Fast Five's musical score is a mix of high-energy tracks with greater variety than other soundtracks from the franchise. The film's score doesn't feature as much American rap as earlier films, though it makes up for it with the inclusion of urban Portuguese-language songs from Brazil. International music ranges from Rio's rap to Brazilian Funk, plus the infectious "Danza Kuduro" by Puerto Rican reggaetonero Dom Omar, who returns to the film as the pessimistic Rico. Fast Five is the third film of the franchise that composer Brian Tyler contributes to, with songs ranging from cinematic to industrial rock.There are two elements of the film that stand out. The first being the too-good-to-be-true clash between Dom and federal strike team leader Luke Hobbs. The two reaching their inevitable on-screen collision hits with the force of a scud missile soaked in testosterone.The other element is the final car chase of the film. Gone are the intricate CGI shots of the mechanical workings of the cars involved. But what Fast Five loses in computer imaging, it makes up for with hardcore driving. The ultimate chase scene in the movie is far from what you've seen in other heist flicks, and is sure to please even the pickiest of action junkies.That's not to say that Fast Five is Oscar-quality, of course. To truly enjoy this film, you have accept in advance that this isn't Shawshank Redemption. While much of the cast have experience in film and television, the majority serve up average acting at best. I'm a huge fan of Vin Diesel's movies (Pitch Black FTW), but he looks all of his 44 years in this film, and his acting ability hasn't improved much. While he and Paul Walker both are well-suited for action flicks, don't expect profound performances from either of them. Diesel is given more of an opportunity to flex his acting chops in Fast Five, with it's emphasis on relationships and heartbreak, but I honestly wasn't too moved.Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson carries the greatest screen presence of the entire cast, giving off an air of intensity that resonates throughout every scene. But that being said, he wasn't given an opportunity to show off any real range of emotions in the film.Despite Fast Five having it's fair share of action and suspense, the film does drag on a bit longer than necessary with it's runtime of two-plus hours. While the film's conclusion is fairly clear, it's also given an open-ending that paves the way for the franchise's sixth effort, and the possible return of a significant character from the series.Overall, Fast Five is simply a fun watch, a guilty pleasure if you're a fan of heist flicks or action movies in general. If you're a motor head, you might be a bit let down at the abandonment of the franchise's original formula, though the change still make for a welcome spin on the series. Definitely get the Blu-Ray to own one of the better movies in the series.

Abducted is about what you would expect for a movie made for TV.  The film was first broadcast on Lifetime as "Layover", but the name was updated apparently so that the DVD might appeal to a broader audience. The DVD cover features a member of the cast (Tara Erica Moore), but it in no way reflects any parts of this movie. For the most part, Abducted is a cross between "Taken" and "The Devil Wears Prada."Abducted follows the story of a pampered executive of a luxury hotel chain who constantly mistreats her personal assistant. After her plane trip is diverted by bad weather, the mean-spirited exec ends up at a cheap hotel in Detroit. She becomes tangled up with Russian sex traffickers, and it's up to her assistant, her security chief, and the FBI to save her.The good news about Abducted is that it's actually shot fairly well by a first time director, with good lighting and color correction.  Which is a surprise considering this was a film by Asylum, responsible for such past gems as "Snakes on a Train", "Transmorphers", and "Titanic II" (I'm not making this up). Film veteran Lauren Holly does a decent job as the snarky executive, and most comments from women I've read seem to be excited by Joe Lando being cast as the exec's security chief.The bad news about Abducted is that it isn't any different from most low-budget movies that go straight to DVD. The story isn't very memorable, most of the acting is average at best, and a great deal of what happens in the movie is laughably unrealistic (the clues about the abductor's hideout in particular).As a Lifetime Network movie, Abducted is noticeably geared towards a woman audience, but I think guys like myself could still enjoy. Amazon doesn't list the rating, it's TV-14 for violence (no nudity, occasional b-word). Overall, it was shot better than I would expect, but it's still not remotely what you would expect to see in theaters. It's solidly average, yet worth watching once. Just don't expect a fast-paced or very memorable hostage flick.

For being a noticeably low-budget flick that was destined to go straight to video, Conned is a halfway decent crime thriller. But a mostly inexperienced cast and average writing is what separates this film from other low-budget cult classics.Conned tells a story of scheming, power grabs and betrayal in the Boston crime underworld. The film follows a variety of two-bit dysfunctional criminals that square off against one another and the police, leading up to a fixed horse race that could potentially leave someone rich.The good news is that Conned has a bit of good cinematography, and some of the shots are slick and clever. The shootout and robbery scenes are okay, considering the budget.  It also offers an interesting twist on crime flicks, which is the introduction of a heist crew and other characters that communicate in American Sign Language (those scenes are subtitled). For this being only the second directing gig by Arthur Luhn, who himself was born deaf, he did a decent job with the shoestring budget he had to work with.The bad news is that Luhn tries too hard to style Conned after Guy Ritchie movies. The emphasis on cleverly-named characters, the type of music used, and the shooting style are noticeably influenced by "Lock Stock & Two Smoking Barrels" as well as "Snatch."  Too many members of the cast were either first-timers in film, or had little feature film experience, so the performances are partly what would keep this from ever becoming a cult classic like a Ritchie/Tarantino flick. Aside from a few funny moments (like the "gamma rays" running joke), there's nothing special about the film's dialogue or story in general.There area also odd changes in the film's look from scene to scene. Interior shots like those for the intro are great, as are a couple of interestingly-lit shots (warehouse scene, billiards scene), but some of the exterior shots look like they were filmed with a handheld cam with no color correction done in post production.Overall, Conned is worth watching once if you're a fan of crime movies. Because this is a low-budget flick by a guy that was a newbie director/writer at the time, you also have to cut it some slack. So don't expect "The Departed" by any means, but it's better than your average straight-to-Redbox or Netflix crime movies. Amazon doesn't list the film rating, but there are shooting deaths, cursing, and nudity. Give this one a watch before you decide on buying the DVD.

Barrio Tales is a horror anthology that seems to be modeled on 1995's "Tales From the Hood" but with a Mexican spin. If you're a fan of campy horror, at least one of the film's three stories may satisfy, but Barrio Tales is otherwise not a memorable flick.The anthology is tied together by two American teens that venture to a Mexican border town in search of drugs. Just as with Tales From the Hood, a creepy storyteller spins several dark tales to his audience.The first story, which involves revenge through black magic, drags along far too much. It's filled with weak dialogue, and missed opportunities as far as how the payback on the wrongdoers is administered.  The third story deals with a group of rednecks that abduct Mexican day laborers in order to torture them, but the volume is turned up a bit too much on how the characters act.The best offering on Barrio Tales is easily the second story about a cannibalistic taco truck owner. It's certainly predictable from the start, but it's also very campy without apology. There's a decent bit of gore, and the murderous taco chef adds some dark humor with his over the top persona. So if you're a fan of campy or shlock horror, "Uncle Tio's Taco Truck" makes Barrio Tales watchable.The biggest difference between Tales From the Hood and Barrio Tales is that the Spike Lee flick offered stronger messages, and had a much better wraparound. With Barrio Tales, the tie-in with the narrator isn't surprising. For being a low-budget flick, Barrio Tales is about on par with most straight-to-DVD flicks. If you're a diehard horror fan, it's worth watching once.  If you only casually watch horror movies, or stick to theater-quality stuff, you might want to pass on this.

A Very British Gangster is one of the most underrated and beautifully-shot crime documentaries available. What distinguishes this documentary from most others is how it's directed. Far from the typical gritty hand-held guerrilla style of documentary work, this film is filled with brilliant cinematography and effective crane shots. The British rock soundtrack is an excellent backdrop to footage of the seedier sides of Manchester.Dominic is no Tony Soprano; despite the flashy suits and manicured appearance, his home life seems to be fairly working class. Where Noonan loses credibility is with his entourage, which is almost exclusively made up of teenagers. It calls into question not how dangerous Dominic is, but if he's as powerful as others make him out to be.It's still impossible to deny his family's reputation, as the film reveals Manchester's major reaction to the death of one the infamous Noonans.
