There's romance in the offing (albeit somewhat tritely: The daughter of his parents' murderer is now a banking executive, and Grayson needs to secure a business loan), there's a chance for Nightwing to show off his sleuthing skills, and there's extreme tension (here's where the book really shines: Nightwing's status as an outlaw hunted by a police officer with a grudge keeps the book's plot swiftly moving).The creators here deserve credit for several bright spots in Nightwing. First, in this age of endless comic tie-ins, it's nice to read a collection that stands on its own. Second, it's wonderful to see Gotham City and its gritty cityscapes depicted here. While it doesn't quite strive for the heights of the great Brubaker/Rucker Gotham Central stories, it hits some of the same notes, which is nice. And third, as this collection shows, Nightwing's solo book is a treat for comics fans who like a solid storyline without superpowers.-- John Hogan

Joseph Joffo's amazing real-life story is depicted in this graphic novel suitable for teens and younger readers (as well as adults). Joffo was born in Paris in 1931, and he and his brother faced a great deal of pain growing up Jewish. When their parents realize it's no longer safe for them in France, they decide to flee, and their journey causes the two brothers to act bravely in the face of a horrible looming threat.This is not a quick read. It's a densely packed comic that does not scrimp on story or details. It is intense (but not too intense for young readers), and it is thorough. It's also very educational, perfectly suited for young readers: a map depicts Joseph and his brother's travel through Europe, and a glossary at the end reveals the meaning of several French terms. There's also a segment about France under the occupation, which gives readers a simple overview. This powerful book is well worth exploring for readers of any age.-- John Hogan

Karl Stevens spent several years as the official cartoonist for The Boston Phoenix, drawing amazingly realistic renditions of people and creating small slice-of-life profiles of wit and profundity. His award-winning series came to an abrupt end, however, after he depicted a character offering some rather harsh criticism of Bud Light.That panel, along with all the others, makes it way to this nice collection. It's a shame that Stevens calls this book Failure, because it's unequivocally a great success, one that has such demented treasures as Pope Cat and other talking animals, weird dreams featuring Prince and Michelangelo, profound and profanity-laden discussions about life, and more. This isn't a structured narrative, but instead a collection of free-flowing thoughts and images, almost all of which are enjoyable for their gorgeously depicted simplicity.-- John Hogan

Opening on the morning of President Obama's inauguration in January 2009, Rep. John Lewis's memoir, March, is a powerful recollection of a man's life growing up in a changing world.The son of a sharecropper, Lewis grew up raising chickens, a time that still affects him powerfully. (As a boy, he even preached the Bible to his captive chicken audience.) He even keeps a collection of chicken statues in his Washington, D.C., office. It's clear that Lewis never forgets the past from which he came.It's a heartbreaking past. March is a tribute to the courage of those who fought, spoke out, marched, and sat down in the front of the bus at a time when virtually any act could lead to arrest...or far worse. Seeing just how painful and awful it all was makes it all the more poignant when Jim Lawson tells Lewis, in 1958, "Do not let them shake your faith in nonviolence--love them!"Lewis and co-writer Andrew Aydin (who works for Lewis handling telecommunications and technology policy) frame the book as a conversation that Lewis having with a mother and her two sons, who have shown up at his D.C. office. Their questions lead into Lewis's narrative and give him ample opportunity to recollect his life story, from childhood onto first meeting Martin Luther King Jr. and getting involved with the nonviolent movement. The art, from Nate Powell, is stunning and some of the best of Powell's career. He evokes a mood that is reverent and powerful and perfectly suited for Lewis's gentle retelling.March is a wonderful recounting of a horrible time in American history. Its beauty as a graphic novel stands in sharp contrast to the sad nature of its contents, but that too makes the book all the more remarkable.-- John Hogan

Gather the family around the radio and marvel at the amazing exploits to be found in The Thrilling Adventure Hour!Created by the writing team of Ben Acker and Ben Blacker, The Thrilling Adventure Hour is a trip back in time to the classic days of radio programs that delighted entire families. The pair, who met while working together writing TV shows, created the program in Los Angeles, where it is acted out by top talents before sold-out audiences. The comic version, written by the two Bens and illustrated by a slew of talented comic stars, lives up to the stage program's stellar reputation.It's a fun throwback to a much simpler time (there are even cigarette ads --- fake ones, to be sure --- strewn throughout the book). There's an air of olden times on every page, much to the delight of readers.The book opens with the adventures of Sparks Nevada ("Marshal on Mars"), who has some unwanted assistance from an unlikely --- and unwanted --- helper. We plunge ahead with Phillip Fathom, a deep-sea detective, and then meet other heroic chaps, like Colonel Tick-Tock, Captain Laserbeam, Jefferson Reid, and even Amelia Earhart. Each story is fun; none overstays its welcome.The best tale is saved for last. Frank and Sadie Doyle are the booziest couple to ever see dead people, and they're also two of the funniest. Their dry wit takes the book to a lively end with the undead and leaves the audience clamoring for more. Here's hoping for another volume soon.-- John Hogan

Wendell, the kid at the center of The Reason for Dragons, is tough to figure out. He's not given an age, but he seems to be about 13 or so. He doesn't get along great with his stepfather, but his stepdad isn't a bad guy at all. Wendall's mother also seems to be a pretty good mom...maybe a little busy and distracted, but still good. Wendell's father is deceased, and apparently, while alive, he was a very good man. And therein lies the problem. Wendell is trying to emulate a hero who died before he could ever really get to know him and trying to live up to some very high standards...at the expense of learning to just be himself.Chris Northrop writes this charming book that is decidedly unpredictable. Jeff Stokely's squiggly yet vividly detailed art helps capture the dual tones of Renaissance Faire levity and coming-of-age seriousness perfectly.Northrop's story bounces in many directions, giving parts of his story time to breathe. He opens with a scene about Warren's stepfather --- a scene that seemingly has very little to do with the main plot of the book, and one that many other writers would have left out. It's these little storytelling jaunts that offer many of the pleasant surprises in The Reason for Dragons.When a misunderstanding causes Wendell to run away, some local bullies taunt him into venturing out to an allegedly haunted Renaissance Faire grounds, where he meets a knight who claims to be fighting an evil dragon. Is he delusional? Is he real? By the time Northrop answers this question for us, we've been charmed.A few short stories close out the book, each one giving further insight into the characters and making us hope Northrop has reason revisits this dragon world again soon.-- John Hogan

The wonderful Percy Gloom ("slow to courage, quick to nausea") returns to learn more about his seemingly immortal life and to discover romance with the beatifically rumped Miss Margaret.Despite being hundreds of years old, Percy Gloom is delightfully nave. He's a bit plain looking, too. A little simple-minded, too, but there's nothing wrong with that. In this second volume, he is coming to terms with his extreme longevity while also falling far Margaret, to whom he's given not only his heart but also a trinket that was handcrafted by his mother. But when he falls into one of his centuries-long slumbers, he finds himself waking up in a strange new world...one without Margaret.It's clear from the beginning that Percy Gloom's story is a fable, and as such, the joy here is in watching Cathy Malkasian's gentle, humorous, and heart-filled story unfold with simplicity --- and also with profound truths. Of course, you will come for the beautiful story, but you will probably linger for the gorgeous artwork. Malkasian's deft touch draws the reader seamlessly from page to page, eyes filled with wondrous sights. You'll fall in love with Percy Gloom.-- John Hogan

It's been about 70 years since Belgian artist Peyo gifted us with the Smurfs, the cuddly blue scamps who took America by cartoon storm in the '80s. Now, Papercutz is releasing an anthology collecting the first 15 Smurf adventures, translated from French and presented in their full-color glory.At nearly 200 pages, this is a fun tribute to these enduring icons. Several of the first episodes of The Smurfs animated show were based on these original stories. This sturdy hardcover volume is full-color and perfect for young readers as much as nostalgic older ones who fondly remembering growing up with these guys. You'll also learn, if you don't know it already, the story behind the purple smurf. Good fun all around throughout these pages.-- John Hogan

Ariol makes his American debut in two new collections from Papercutz. The books, Just a Donkey Like You and Me and Thunder Horse, are French imports by writer Emmanuel Guibert and artist Marc Boutavant.The two colorful collections each feature multiple short stories starring the lovable little blue donkey and the various animals that fill out his life (a pig for a best friend; a dog for a teacher; and a heifer, of course, for his crush). The books are hilarious and charming (adults will enjoy reading them almost as much as kids).Guibert's work here is delightful. After all the serious connotations in his previous works (the amazing The Photographer and Alan's War, for example), it's a pleasure to read these simple, silly stories. Kids will love them, as well as Boutavant's pleasant drawings.-- John Hogan

Back in the 1990s, a semiautobiographical comic series named Minimum Wage began. It depicted both New York City and the 20somethings who lived there with brutal clarity and utter charm.Minimum Wage represented a new indie age in comics. The classic comix of the '60s, '70s, and early '80s gave way to a new breed of auteur, one that was bold and daring yet not always as outrageous. Indie comics became less rebellious and more mainstream, more easily attainable, and as such, they mirrored other pop-culture artistic movements, like the birth of grunge rock or the (later to come) burgeoning of mumblecore in film.What makes Minimum Wage so lovable (and readable) is its easygoing affability as it documents the New York City love affair of Rob and Sylvia, two 20somethings trying to advance (or start) their careers while navigating the city.Rob Hoffman is a thinly veiled pseudonym for Bob Fingerman, the writer and artist behind the story. Fingerman makes it clear that the story of Minimum Wage is only semiautobiographical. Much of the elements are based on truth and real-life events, but they're not necessarily true in and of themselves. What is true, however, is the capturing of the vast aesthetic of New York City in the early to mid-'90s, a unique time in the city's history and one perfectly transported to and brought alive on the page.Fingerman's depictions of young men and women struggling to get ahead and to forge a path as adults is true to life as well. There's plenty of sex (and nudity), but it's certainly not graphic. It's simply honest. So are the various storylines, like dealing with an unplanned pregnancy, falling in love and then doubting that love, meeting the friends and parents of those you date, and simply trying to figure out how you fit into all of this life you've begun to create.Maximum Minimum Wage is packed with extras, so it's a treasure trove for old fans and it's a lovely adventure for new fans. Extras include an intro from Robert Kirkman (of Walking Dead fame), tons of pinups from a slew of creators, a cover gallery, behind-the-scenes glimpses from Fingerman, a working script of an issue that never came together, and much more. This is a worthy tribute to a classic '90s comics, and if there's any justice, it will introduce a whole new generation of readers to Fingerman's seminal work.-- John Hogan

When we last left everyone's favorite delinquent-turned-schoolteacher, he was about to be bludgeoned to death by masked bikers who had been hired by Miki Katsuragi, one of his more belligerent new charges. Fortunately, Onizuka has more lives than an army of cats and more toughness than a solid steel wall. Of course he could put the girl through the ringer for trying to have him killed, but that would accomplish nothing, so he opens up to her like she never thought he could, feeling he may have gotten through.However, things do not stay peaceful for long. Due to her abuse of the emergency call he has been using to summon her father (a high-ranking cop), he has turned a deaf ear to any future calls. And in true Boy Who Cried Wolf, or rather "Girl Who Cried Pervert," fashion, as soon as she decides to go out late at night, a seemingly handsome guy is shortly thereafter revealed to be a kidnapper and abducts her. He has been collecting young girls and women for an illegal pornography service, one that drugs the girls and films them being raped with someone wearing whatever the highest bidder wishes.As Onizuka learns of her kidnapping, he immediately spreads the word to his former gang friends and another bike gang and puts them to work, stopping any van similar to the one that took her away. Before leaving to search himself, he literally takes the case to Miki's father by plowing right into police headquarters, where he is working on the very case his daughter has been caught up in.With gang, police and teacher all working to find the criminals, there may not be as much success as one may think, but maybe Ms. Shiratori can help Onizuka tip the scales in their favor. The race is on to find Miki and save her before she is scarred for life, and we all know Onizuka won't rest until he plants his foot in that pretty boy's face.-- David Gromer

There's so much to love about Kazu Kibuishi's epic, thrilling Amulet series. It pulls inspiration from so many wonderful places (Star Wars, obviously, and Tolkien's works, but other fantasy epics as well), but it also remains an original and thoroughly enjoyable series that stands truly on its own.In Prince of the Elves, Kibuishi lets his imagination fly free, taking young heroine Emily further along her path as she attempts to master the powerful stone in her possession. Emily and her companions, including her brother Navin, are at war with the Elf King, who is about to acquire a new stone that could allow him to finally conquer all of Windsor.Kibuishi wastes no time getting into the heart of the action, and five volumes into the series, we are not even close to getting tired of watching these battles unfold. And we're certainly not tired of seeing Kibuishi's beautifully lush artwork; he's only getting better as the series moves on. As a storyteller and writer, he's also growing. Little flourishes throughout show the immense character growth he's imparted to the various members of his story. It's a welcome treat, especially since this is a pivotal volume in the series in terms of revealing answers to long-lingering questions.Amulet is perfect for kids, but the story is incredibly fun for teen and adult readers as well. It's hard to imagine any comics fan outgrowing something so unabashedly entertaining.-- John Hogan

Let's just call this: Brian Azzarello and Cliff Chiang's current take on Wonder Woman is the best version of the Amazing Amazon in years. Decades, even. It's simply that good.Chiang's art, already so good in the previous volume, Blood, reaches new heights here. Diana looks beautiful, proud, strong, sinewy, exactly as she should, and his keen eye for portraying the supporting characters (a Sandman-esque band of gods and demigods, as well as a pregnant human woman named Zola unwittingly carrying Zeus's child --- and therefore marked for death by Hera) shine through here. Eros, Hermes, Apollo, Poseidon, Hades...all are given modern updates with robust verve. (Eros in particular is a favorite, now wielding guns rather than a bow and arrow...things have changed for this pantheon.)The events of Blood saw Wonder Woman and friends avoid a war between the gods, but their victory came at a harsh price: her friend Zola and her unborn child were taken into Hades' underworld, seemingly forever. Guts pits Wonder Woman against Hades (and Hera, and others) as Diana travels into hell to rescue her friend...if she can.Azzarello's work is sharp, cynical, funny, jaded, and simply engrossing. Page after page flies by, and the synergy his work shares with Chiang's is wonderful to watch. It's a delight to see Princess Diana finally restored to her great potential. I hope this series continues for a good long time.-- John Hogan

For months now, the industry has been buzzing about the epic graphic novel Anomaly. Epic? It's enormous. 368 pages enormous, not to mention how massively oversized it is (opened up, it has more than a 32-inch wingspan; not the kind of book that's easy to read on a crowded subway).What Anomaly lacks in convenience it makes up for in storytelling and art. Co-creator Brian Haberlin has his hands in both pieces, writing the story along with cocreator Skip Brittenham and supplying art along with Beirrod Van Dyke. All told, it was a project that took the creative team years to assemble...and, interestingly enough, the creative work is still going on, even after publication. This being a fully realized 21st-century graphic novel, Anomaly is not just a book, but an interactive experience (although it reads just fine as a standalone book). Readers are invited to enhance their experiences with Ultimate Augmented Reality, an app that can be downloaded for free. Pages in the book that are "live" can then be scanned by the reader's mobile device, which makes objects on the page not only 3D, but also interactive...meaning readers can play along and take on some pretty cool monsters and machines on the pages.What makes Anomaly more fun than all of this suggests, however, is that it's not just all bells and whistles (the bells and whistles are very cool, though). The sci-fi story focuses on a dying world overrun with corporate greed, as all nations and corporations have been merged into one behemoth known as The Conglomerate. Humans vie for scarce resources.Our protagonist, Jon, is a former Enforcer for The Conglomerate and has now been disgraced. To redeem himself, he undertakes a seemingly simple mission of safeguarding a Conglomerate executive's daughter as they sail off to make first contact with a world that may be inhabitable (and may offer more resources to plume). This being a sci-fi novel, you can imagine that things go wrong. When they arrive on the planet, the group is faced with remarkable challenges from the planet's inhabitants and must battle for survival.While the story is not groundbreaking, it is solid and entertaining. The art is exactly as you'd expect: static in that computer-generated way, but with very cool depth and color. But when it comes alive through the app, it's a nice experience.Reviewed by John Hogan

It's been 50 years since Madeleine L'Engle's classic A Wrinkle in Time was first published, and as part of the anniversary celebration of the award-winning children's book, FSG has published Hope Larson's graphic-novel adaptation. It shines in glorious blue, black, and white hues, faithfully adapting an epic tale that multitudes of people hold near and dear to their hearts. Of course, as everyone knows, like and equal are not the same thing: So is it an audacious attempt to transform a classic book into something other than what it originally was? No. It's a beautifully respectful companion to the book, a loving tribute that visually captures the stunning adventure in all its trippy wonder.For many young readers, A Wrinkle in Time introduced the wild concepts of quantum physics, tesseracts, moving through space and time, and much more. The book is filled with incredible concepts (couched in late 1950s/early 1960s mindsets); reading it now is like a time-travel adventure in and of itself. That Larson (Chiggers, Mercury) is able to capture not only the style of the novel (she wisely preserves much of the original dialogue), but also the style of the era that gave birth to it is a tribute to her great skills. Her artwork complements the story perfectly, capturing the goofy beginnings (such as when Mrs Whatsit drops in for a late-night visit early on and quite promptly sprains her dignity) and the later dangers and threats (the Black Thing and IT).The message and central themes of the novel are preserved, of course. The novel's marriage of scientific and religious concepts are perfectly intact. 50 years after publication, the novel still shines and captivates. Now, there's a graphic novel shining along with it.Reviewed by John Hogan

Have you ever thought to yourself, "Gee, I wonder what it would be like to be a little kitten"? Well, wonder no more. Chi's Sweet Home gives us an up-close look at the life of an adorable kitten named Chi (not to be confused with the girl from the hit manga Chobits), following her throughout her everyday life. And the funny thing is, you always know what Chi is thinking (or saying) when she meows, which really got me to thinking, "Is this how most cats think in this situation?" Who knows?Everybody thinks the life of a pet is tedious, simple and repetitive. Well, not this cat! Chi leads the reader through the life of a cat one short story after another. Chi has all kinds of adventures in her home and in her neighborhood, whether she is alone or together with her best friend, Cocchi, a male cat with an arrogant personality. Whether it's something as simple as looking for attention from her family or looking for something to do around town, Chi is always having fun. They say cats have nine lives, but I would say Chi doesn't need them - all she needs is one, because no matter how many close calls she ends up in, cats always land on their feet, both literally and metaphorically.Konami Kanata all-color manga is a must-read for all cat-lovers. The use of watercolor is a breath of fresh air to anyone who has been immersed on black & white manga for years. This is definitely a manga that will be loved by both children and their parents, thanks to super-cute Chi!Reviewed by David Gromer

This second volume of Durarara!! not only follows our friend Mikado Ryuugamine, but multiple other characters as well. More insight is given in Celty's situation, including her own partial account of how she became a Dullahan. She allows us to look into her past life, what she originally did, but we never get to see what her head and face looked like. That, however, is nonetheless revealed in this volume, so take heed.On Mikado's end, he is compelled to volunteer as one of the two representatives for his class, alongside Anri Sonohara, whom I think Mikado has taken a liking to, though he doesn't show it very well. He even comes upon her on the street as she's being bullied. Initially intending to ignore it, he quickly changes his mind, thanks to a helpful shove from Izaya Orihara, our delightfully crazed friend who has more attitudes than Rich Little and changes them at the drop of a hat. We also meet another interesting youth, a man Mikado was told to never get involved with, Shizuo Heiwajima. He is incredibly strong, and more volatile than the Incredible Hulk, but that's just my opinion.We later find out whatever became of Celty's head --- a pharmaceutical company was keeping it for study and conducting tests on it. Apparently, however, due to the obsessions of the younger brother of one of the company's top scientists, the head was surgically attached to a body and given life. We even find out the identity of the said body, as it's being chased by Celty in the middle of a bid to reclaim what it rightfully hers.The creators of this manga started off strong, and they are still going strong. The same characters now have some new things to contend with, especially that superpowered bartender, Shizuo! The saying goes, "the more the merrier," and things are getting more fun every time I pick up these books.Reviewed by David Gromer

In the wake of the Flock's battle in and escape from New York City the Flock encounters something that makes their blood chill while en route to Washington, D.C.: flying Erasers. It seems every time the Erasers come after them, there is always a most unwelcome new feature to them. During the ensuing dogfight, Fang is seriously injured, forcing the Flock to leave him in the care of a human hospital.During Fang's stay, an FBI agent appears and strikes a deal with Max: shelter in exchange for a chance to "learn about the Flock in noninvasive ways."Naturally, Max doesn't want to decide until Fang is healthy again, but during the night, Max witnesses a horrifying sight: she sees herself as an Eraser when she looks in a mirror. For now, she passes it off as a hallucination, and when Fang fully recovers the next morning, Max decides to take Anne up on her offer. Anne brings the Flock to her home, a farmhouse on 50 acres of land containing everything they could ever need to live in peace. However, as they explore their new home, watching from afar is a certain Eraser who knows Max very well!This is not all, as our heroes make more discoveries within a short time: that Angel's dog, Total, can speak English, and that Max now haves the ability to fly at the speed of light! While on a late night excursion to the city, they begin to investigate clues to Iggy's home, but to no avail.Affairs do not improve for them very much, as Ari reveals himself once more and attacks the Flock. Will things ever get easier for them?Despite it being a graphic novel, so many things happened in this volume, I felt like I was reading a full-length novel. Narae Lee certainly has a way of bringing James Patterson's brilliant and imaginative creation to illustrative life. Anyone who picks up this series will not be disappointed, only becoming more engrossed with each passing installment.Reviewed by David Gromer

Many discoveries are made in this volume of Maximum Ride. A couple of them are good, and the rest ... no so good, and one of them comes when Max is right in the middle of a date! Wait - Max had a date? Yes, she met a nice boy in the previous volume named Sam who wanted to take her out. Still, regardless of how nice Sam is to her, she refuses to soften, as she feels the entire Flock is, due to living with Anne like normal humans.Soon, Max's haunting image of herself as an Eraser becomes too much to keep hidden any longer and she tells Fang everything. He comforts her in her time of need - what a guy! As the two investigate a lead they happened to come upon, they find a woman who is the spitting image of Iggy, possibly his birth mother. Around the same time, Iggy and Gazzy come upon some startling information. Until two years ago, their school was an insane asylum, The Standish Home for Incurables. The name says it all, doesn't it? I bet the principal of this school used to be a part of the asylum - it would explain his hatred for some certain students.After giving it a great deal of thought, Max brings the Flock to an abandoned bat cave (not to be confused with Batman's favorite hiding place) to voice her concerns to them - that they must leave Anne's place, lest they become soft. However, due to the overwhelming desire of several of its members to have a real Thanksgiving dinner, she folds and settles for leaving after that. Following a very peaceful holiday, the entire Flock escorts Iggy to his parents' house for an old fashioned family reunion.Good times don't last, and the situation starts going downhill fast on many fronts. Treachery is afoot, and it approaches from all sides, so the Flock is in for the tensest times of their young lives. But if Max is destined to save the world in the future, she must stay vigilant. The question is, CAN she stay vigilant with all the chaos happening all around her? And what will happen when a clone of Max shows up?Action, drama, suspense, intrigue and comedy collide to make another excellent addition to James Patterson's Maximum Ride résumé.Reviewed by David Gromer

It's not easy being a spinster in Victorian Era London, but for Alexia Tarabotti, it's a nightmare. She is a preternatural, a being considered to be "soulless," and capable of reducing supernaturals, such as vampires and werewolves, to mere mortals by making physical contact with them.It all started when Alexia is attacked by a roaming Vampire and kills him. If that had been as simple as it gets, there wouldn't be any need for a panic. However, this is not the case. Lord Maccon, werewolf Alpha, is sent by Queen Victoria to investigate, but of course, he and Alexia fight like cats and ... werewolves.Though initially not interested in getting involved in this supernatural affair, Alexia is quickly engulfed in a shady plot involving an unknown menace, one which is definitely unnatural, but seems immune to her powers. Add in the natural frictions between Vampires and Werewolves and stir well, and you've got a prime recipe for chaos. Bring that to a simmer, and add a touch of natural comedy, followed by a drop of unexpected romance between Alexia and Lord Maccon and you've got a thrilling story full of intrigue, violence, and love.Then, there is the fact that the most important events of this volume take place on the night of a full moon, a.k.a. the worst time to be a werewolf. It is a good thing Alexia can turn werewolves human again with her touch, because what would happen if she was pitted against the one she loved in his most ferocious incarnation? And if she makes it through that experience, what will follow? Certainly not a wedding, right? Right?!This story started out as a beautifully-written novel series by Gail Carriger, and has now found its way into the manga world, thanks to the REM and Yen Press. The book is a little bit larger and thicker than your average manga, so you can expect that much more substance packed into it. This manga touches on the evil that mankind is capable of committing - the non-supernatural humans. It's a story of trust across boundaries such as race, nature, etc.Reviewed by David Gromer

These are the best set of utentils I have ever owned. The handles fit your hand comfortaby and they are nice and sturdy. Not to mention how attractive the handles are, beautiful green with a heart! They also have a built in stand, which becomes extremely handy. You don't have to worry about getting out a plate to set these on or having them drip all over everything. I hope they come out with more items. I did get these items for free in exchange for my honest review.

These are absolutely beautiful! They are nicely packed so they aren't tangeled, just make sure you keep them that way! They look extremely expensive and really added an elegant touch my new tree. I just ordered more I love them so much!

This is an extremely quick read about Samantha taking her kids shopping for Christmas decor. Which never really gets finished, I think it was thrown in just to make the book seem cheery. Then we learn about Samantha's "angel". I wish the book flowed a little better, or was developed to be beneficial for the story.

My family writes on a chalkboard to keep us motivated throughout the week. It's actually pretty cool and actually does work. However I hated it being my time to write on it before. Touching chalk is one of my least favorite experiences. (I know i am weird) However with these markers you don't have to worry about that. The color is bright and true to what it should be. You don't have to worry about the dull faded version of color anymore. Now when you pick your color you can be sure that it will truly be the color you expected. My favorite are the green and pink. I did buy these for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion. When these run out I will definitely be buying more.

book 1:Samantha Moon is a story about a woman who is turned into vampire. But she still manages life, she quits her job and becomes a P.I. and raises her children. But things get a little messy with the case shes working on. Her investigation skills also let her know her husband is cheating on her. I love this book, its unique and keeps your on your toes. I've previously read other books by this author and knew it would be a great read. Glad I waited until he had multiple books out in this series so i can do a straight a read through!book 2:I am hooked! Samantha Moon is attacked by a vampire 6 years before the first book, and was turned. She quits her job as a cop and becomes a PI. In book one we follow her relationship with her husband that turns sour, then her relationship with "Fang" and Kingsley a werewolf. In book two we pick up where we left off. Each book has contained Samantha working a case as a PI and also her blossoming relationships. This book ends on a major cliffhanger, so I am grateful there are quite a few more books to go in the series before I am caught up. If your looking for a unique paranormal read this series is for youbook 3:I have read other books by this author and enjoyed them. So I decided to buy the entire series up to this point, boy am I glad I did. This series is about Samantha Moon, Vampire, mom, and PI. Each book is about a different case she is working, but also centers around her home life. In this book we cheer Samantha for overcoming her horrible husband's gauntlet. But then deeply saddened by her other personal issues. I wish the author went into more detail about the case she was working, how Maddie knew to reach out to her in the first place, etc. The book ends on a major cliff hanger, which would be killing me had I not waited to start this seriesbook 4:the series does need to be read in order for complete understanding. In this book Samantha moon is hell bound to save her son. We get to meet an old vampire who wants the same amulet that she needs. the book brings Kingsley back into Samantha love life. This book had more action in it then the others have. I also think it's refreshing that she's finally opening up to the people that she trusts. Excellent read excited to start book five today.

the series does need to be read in order for complete understanding. In this book Samantha moon is hell bound to save her son. We get to meet an old vampire who wants the same amulet that she needs. the book brings Kingsley back into Samantha love life. This book had more action in it then the others have. I also think it's refreshing that she's finally opening up to the people that she trusts. Excellent read excited to start book five today.

I have read other books by this author and enjoyed them. So I decided to buy the entire series up to this point, boy am I glad I did. This series is about Samantha Moon, Vampire, mom, and PI. Each book is about a different case she is working, but also centers around her home life. In this book we cheer Samantha for overcoming her horrible husband's gauntlet. But then deeply saddened by her other personal issues. I wish the author went into more detail about the case she was working, how Maddie knew to reach out to her in the first place, etc. The book ends on a major cliff hanger, which would be killing me had I not waited to start this series.

I am hooked! Samantha Moon is attacked by a vampire 6 years before the first book, and was turned. She quits her job as a cop and becomes a PI. In book one we follow her relationship with her husband that turns sour, then her relationship with "Fang" and Kingsley a werewolf. In book two we pick up where we left off. Each book has contained Samantha working a case as a PI and also her blossoming relationships. This book ends on a major cliffhanger, so I am grateful there are quite a few more books to go in the series before I am caught up. If your looking for a unique paranormal read this series is for you.

This series is highly addictive and does need to be read in order for complete understanding. We follow Sara on her journey from meeting her husband to having their first children. Sara has the ability to dream walk, which can sometimes be a nightmare. Each book entails a different dream by a different character. These stories are highly addictive, the only downside is they tend to jump a year or two in between. Definitely worth the read! I listened to the book on audible, the narrator did a great job, but I still hear the original narrator in my head!

Samantha Moon is a story about a woman who is turned into vampire. But she still manages life, she quits her job and becomes a P.I. and raises her children. But things get a little messy with the case shes working on. Her investigation skills also let her know her husband is cheating on her. I love this book, its unique and keeps your on your toes. I've previously read other books by this author and knew it would be a great read. Glad I waited until he had multiple books out in this series so i can do a straight a read through!

I purchased this item not because of my snoring, but because of allergies. It is so hard to breath at night! This puts the perfect amount of pressure and opens your sinus cavity up. Plus the ones that are too big for me can be given to someone else. Great product, just wish the case was a little firmer. I purchased this item at a discount in exchange for an honest review.

Peppermint essential oil is great for waking up in the morning, it gives you a little bit of a jump start when coffee just doesn't work anymore. I make my own lotion and use this in my morning routine to help me become alert and focused. This product is 100% peppermint essential oil, no other fillers or products are added, which is a must if you want the best.I  have bought peppermint in the past that had other chemicals in it which smelled OK at the beginning but after a week started turning and ended up giving you a really funky product. I know that that will not happen with this product. I was fortunate to purchase this item at a discount in exchange for my honest review. You do get a lot of product for a small cost, I will continue to order from go pure.

I am completely and totally addicted to essential oils, not to mention lavender is one of my favorite smells. It is calming and peaceful and tranquil and reduces/remove stress. I have bought lavender essential oils before that were not 100% pure and they had a slightly chemical smell to them. That is definitely not the case with goPure's. This product is 100% lavender, no additives no fillers. As soon as I open this product my headache started to go away immediately ran into my bedroom and put a few drops on my pillow. This in the past few years has become a must have in my life and by far this is the best smelling lavender oil I have found. I will continue to buy this product, I was blessed and purchased this item at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I love big fan of essential oils and all of the ailments they can cure naturally. I have been using tea tree oil body wash for years. It really helps with my troubled skin, I suffer from ingrown hairs breakouts etc and the tea tree oil really minimizes my issues. However if you buy body washes already mixed there are tons of other chemicals in the product and they have started to limit the power of tea tree oil. I have started to make my own body wash at home and add tea tree oil into it. Using this brand I know I'm getting 100% essential oil, no other filters or additives and therefore I am getting the best product and results possible. I will continue to buy from this company. I did have the chance to try this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review

I have to say I'm a big fan of essential oils and not using as many chemicals. I have started to make my own cleaning supplies due to all the harsh chemicals and odors but I can no longer stand. I mixed this essential oil into one of my homemade cleaners to give it the fresh citrus burst. This is pure essential oil no added fillers or fragrances. I will be buying more from this company in the future. I did buy this item at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I have a slight obsession with essential oils. However I want the best I can buy, one that is not filled with anything other than the actual oil. Immediately upon opening this I was impressed because it came with the glass dropper. The bottle is nice and dark so you do not have to worry about the oil spoiling as you do with some that come in a lighter bottles. Immediately upon opening this bottle I got a nice strong frankincense odor. I immediately put it to use in a hand lotion that I whipped with shea butter and vitamin E. By far this is one of the best essential oils that I have found, in this brand is much better then the other frankincense oil I have. Will definitely buy more from this company. I got this item for free in exchange for my honest review.

I purchase this item at a discount and exchange for my honest review. There are two mouth guards inside this case, they fit easily into your mouth. If you soak them in really hot water almost boiling and then put it into your mouth it will tighten up and adhere better to your specific mouth. In one spot it is a little tight on the back of my gums on my rear molars. It's going to take some getting used to but in the long run I think it will be worth it.

this is a quick entertaining read about a woman named Lily who is diagnosed with cancer at age 29. Due to her past experiences with a cancer and the rare form of cancer she has she decides to decline treatment and live life. the story takes quite a few twists and turns I enjoyed her live out your dreams attitude, even though it was somewhat selfish. at the very end of the book everything rapidly changes direction, you could see it coming and it was a little predictable. the ending seemed a little rushed and forced in one chapter we learned what took us 10 previously. however I do think overall the story was entertaining and does proves that sometimes you have to live for you.

I hate having spray foil every time I want to grill. With these I don't have to worry about food sticking, or wasting foil. I save calories from not adding more oil to my foods, which also saves money in the long run. Let me state I am not the best at remembering to spray the foil, so I ended up with food stuck to the grill, so now you have to scrub the grill along with your wasted dinner. Plus the clean up is a breeze, these wipe off when the soap. I purchased this item at a discount in exchange for an honest review.

This is a cute quick read about a young woman who came into her witchy powers on her 16th birthday. As you can imagine she has a few mistakes, and of course continues to try to correct them. I thought the story line was entertaining, I wish the author would have changed up the spells a little bit, they sounded identical to The House of Nights.

I have recently started making my own soaps/lotions/body washes etc and have fallen in love with essential oils. I had never tried thyme essential oil, but have cooked with the herb for years and loved it so I figured why not?! Immediately upon opening this oil you get the strong earthy and to me refreshing scent of thyme. It is not over powering but has the ability to center you based on smell alone. I have read where most people you it to gain focus and mental clarity, which I can see after one smell how it would help. I have to admit I am used to buying bigger bottles of essential oils, but this one will last awhile, a little goes a long way. I had the honor of reviewing this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

Item arrived quickly and as described by the seller. I have used shea butter before, but never in its raw pure form, its always been mixed with other ingredients. I am trying to take better care of myself and after becoming a gluten free vegan ten months ago I have started reading the ingredients on everything. Let me just say you would be amazed at what all goes into products, and for no reason other than a filler. It's disgusting what we have allowed to go into our products! I am excited to make my own lotions and soaps with this product. The product is naturally really thick so you just have to warm it up and add your oils for lotion. You get a lot of product in this order, my only complaint is the container it is in is really quite flimsy. But its not much of a concern for me since I will be putting my homemade products into a different container after making them. I did purchase this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.
I bought this item for my sister, was a little disappointed in the quality. It looks like any other sleep mask, not quite sure what the benefit of it is, hopefully my sister enjoys it!

This bag made three dozen tamales, which is perfect for me (I made spicy black bean tamales and it worked perfectly with one pound of black beans soaked and cooked and one 6 oz package of husks). I was impressed that they wrapped the bag in an additional plastic bag just in case it leaked. Will buy again.

Item arrived quickly and in perfect condition. It contained enough husks for 4 dozen tamales. Almost all of them were big enough for tamales, I think i threw away 4 that weren't. Very minimal cleaning was needing (corn silk). I will be buying these again anytime I make tortillas. I will admit the bag scared me at first, it looked very small, but once you separate them and then soak them they really plump up!

This is a very quick read about the author's struggle to find a doctor truly willing to help her. I can relate to the struggle, I went through three different doctors before finally taking my health into my own hands since they no longer wanted to help. My struggle lasted six years, within two weeks of doing things my way I felt alive and that I had the quality of my life back. This is something everyone should read, don't trust the people that just want your co-pay, I spent over $10,000 and got no where. You know your body better than anyone else. Just trust it!

After purchasing several different psoriasis cream and lotions I can tell you this one is by far the best. I got the product this morning and put on a light coat which quickly absorbed into my skin and instantly reduced the itching. I have never had anything including cortisone relievemy condition. And I couldn't believe that I did not have a greasy slimy feeling while  applying this lotion. Most lotions I have to immediately go wash my hands because of that feeling however that was not an issue with this product. I have great hopes for this product and can't wait to see what the long term effects are since after one use I am seeing results. I did have the opportunity to purchase this item at a discounted rate  in exchange for an honest review.

This story was quite unique, but just seemed a little too dreamy for me. Our lead breaks up with boyfriend after thinking he was going to propose. Immediately we meet her ex who she still loves, of course you know where this is going. I think the dreamy and over the top part came with the addition of the tv series that fell exactly in sync with the story. I enjoyed the story, just wish it would have been tamed a little.The other thing that bothered me was the timeline, it jumps from past present to future and back again with NO warnings! You end up quite confused a few times.

I read this book before it's new revised edition, and just now finished re-reading it in it's new format. The story line is fast paced about a woman who thought she had her life figured out, only to have it turned upside down. I think the author has a refreshing and unique story line. I enjoyed all of the characters, flaws and all, they came to life in front of your eyes and developed with the story. Overall I have to say I enjoyed the new version of the story, the lead character is a riot, I completely understand and appreciate her take on so many things. If you are looking for a read that has its serious life changing moments while also making you laugh, this book is for you.

The tahini I have been buying in the local store has been highly disappointing, no flavor and the price it outrageous! I took a chance on this great deal expecting to find the same lack of flavor, only to be surprised. This tahini is a lot thinner than the ones I have bought in the past, more like olive oil consistency than the thick paste. The flavor is out of this world! It's extremely rich and decadent, and you don't have to use much since it has such a robust flavor. Will definitely buy again!!

BOB WELCH-GREATEST HITS: Six stringer/soulful singer Bob Welch bridged the musical gap betwixt Fleetwood Mac's Peter Green-helmed blooze-saturated beginning and the snappy, crackly pop of the Lindsey Buckingham/Stevie Nicks mega-years. Best remembered for Big Mac's mesmerizing chestnut HYPNOTIZED and the sublime original version of SENTIMENTAL LADY, WELCH scored straight out of the solo chute via the ethereal album FRENCH KISS. That exquisitely crafted debut boasted a smartly streamlined LADY remake (featuring warm vocal colorization from Christine McVie, who also figured prominently on the original), plus the infectious follow up hits EBONY EYES and HOT LOVE, COLD WORLD. Later discs yielded diminishing returns, although the irresistibly hook-laden THREE HEARTS and the Pop 40 shoe-in PRECIOUS LOVE remain pristine highlights in his catalogue of coolly rendered chestnuts. Welch may be a "Where Are They Now" candidate these days, but this all too brief anthology showcases an underrated rebel rouser who had integrity, charm, and chops to spare.RATING: THREE HEARTS

CANNIBAL & THE HEADHUNTERS-GOLDEN CLASSICS: One of the first Latino groups to score a hit single, CANNIBAL & THE HEADHUNTERS were not only one hit wonders, they were one album wonders. Sixties preservationist label COLLECTABLES has re-released LAND OF 1000 DANCES...named after their Top 30 cover of CHRIS KENNER's name dropping jam  later successfully covered by WILSON PICKETT and the J. GEILS BAND...under their GOLDEN CLASSICS moniker. You'll also experience nonsense novelty NAU NINNY NAU, an inevitable 1000 DANCES knock-off, plus solid covers of MOTOWN staples SHOTGUN and MY GIRL, LA BAMBA, BOY FROM NEW YORK CITY and JAMES BROWN's OUT OF SIGHT, which, while hardly usurping the originals, bristle with frat rock energy, soul power and skin tight three part harmonies. FRANKIE GARCIA's lead vocals even grace a couple of dreamy ballads, the polar opposite of HEADHUNTERS DANCE PARTY, a loose, horn-lacerated lo-fi treat. CANNIBAL & THE HEADHUNTERS made the most of their shot at the brass ring, turning in a swingin', solid effort that bears up to repeated spins half a century after the fact.RATING: THREE NA NA NA'S

JR. WALKER & THE ALL STARS-GREATEST HITS: Soul blaring saxophonist/singer/bandleader JR. WALKER will always be best remembered for a pair of monster hits at opposite ends of the musical spectrum...the incredibly raw dance floor blaster SHOTGUN and the smoothly rendered WHAT DOES IT TAKE (TO WIN YOUR LOVE).  One of the few MOTOWN artists that led his own band THE ALL STARS, the former AUTRY DEWALT also covered many chestnuts from that label from MONEY and COME SEE ABOUT ME to HOW SWEET IT IS (TO BE LOVED BY YOU), stamping each with his raw and swingin' signature  talents. HOME COOKIN', SHAKE AND FINGERPOP and PUCKER UP BUTTERCUP are further smokin' examples of WALKER's total command over a good time groove, sweaty, irresistible singles with funky choruses that compel the listener to shout along, while CLEO'S MOOD is a slinky, sassy instrumental helmed by WALKER's seductive sax breaks. Too often forgotten in discussions of MOTOWN's greatest acts, when it came to good time "party down" groove-ology, JR. WALKER & THE ALL STARS were always at the top of their game.RATING: FOUR REEDS

VAN HALEN-THE BEST OF BOTH WORLDS: A beloved hard rock band distinguished by two distinctly different eras...one helmed by smarmy, soulful howler DAVID LEE ROTH, the other by his straight laced replacement SAMMY HAGAR...VAN HALEN finally gets a double dip anthology worthy of their legacy. Too bad one platter wasn't solely devoted to each vocalist, if only for comparison's sake. ROTH's lecherous, overly theatrical attack on YOU REALLY GOT ME, DANCE THE NIGHT AWAY and PANAMA doesn't mesh well with VAN HAGAR's more generic WHY CAN'T THIS BE LOVE, RIGHT NOW and POUNDCAKE (the band's brief, still-born GARY CHERRONE phase is completely ignored completely). Throughout the ruckus, EDDIE VAN HALEN's nimble-fingered fretboard histrionics, brother ALEX' thundering drums and bass player MICHAEL ANTHONY's high harmony vocals are the common denominator and there's no question that the DLR stuff is a lot more engaging and fun...although HAGAR enjoyed the stronger solo career before and after VH. In spite of three medicore live tracks and an equal number of "new" songs (all fronted by HAGAR), BEST OF BOTH WORLDS ponies up  a helluva lot more classic bombast than the spotty BEST OF VAN HALEN released in 1995.RATING: HEADBANGERS

HOLLYWOOD VAMPIRES-HOLLYWOOD VAMPIRES: Having logged nearly half a decade as Shock Rock's Godfadda, ALICE COOPER's new super group HOLLYWOOD VAMPIRES (named for a mid-seventies drinking club whose membership  included KEITH MOON and MICKEY DOLENZ) comes off better than might be expected. Flanked by  guitarists JOE PERRY and JOHNNY DEPP (who's already played every other conceivable role), this euphoric party platter kicks off via an ominous narrative from horror icon CHRISTOPHER LEE, and RAISE THE DEAD, an appropriate title given the covers of rock's "gone too soon" elite that follows. Rather obvious LED ZEP, DOORS and WHO reboots (plus SPIRIT's I GOT A LINE ON YOU, which The Coop has previously tackled) are offset by the more interesting choices like T-REX chestnut JEEPSTER, SMALL FACES' quasi-psychedelic ITCHYCOO PARK, and a dark regurgitation of LENNON's COLD TURKEY. Throughout, COOPER's sleazy rasp still sounds born to belt archaic anthems...there's even an update of SCHOOL'S OUT with a few bars of ANOTHER BRICK IN THE WALL tacked on for good measure. Guests include SLASH, BRIAN JOHNSON and JOE WALSH, but this is ALICE's gig all the way, right down to the finale MY DEAD DRUNK FRIENDS, a fitting nightcap for a hell-raisin' night out with the boys.RATING: FOUR QUICK ONES

COUNT FIVE-PSYCHOTIC REACTION/THE VERY BEST OF COUNT FIVE: 99% of music fans have never heard anything from San Jose's COUNT FIVE aside from their Top Ten '66 hit PSYCHOTIC REACTION, the coolest rave up THE YARDBIRDS never did. The true classification of a "One Hit Wonder", all of their follow up singles tanked and they never recorded past their debut album, which is included in its entirety on this collection, plus bonus cuts. Unlike most garage rockers of the era, the majority of their output consisted of band originals (mostly from guitarist SEAN BYRNE), not a batch of predictable covers. At least two of the three remakes are fairly daring choices...CURTIS MAYFIELD's authoritative YOU MUST BELIEVE ME and the obscure WHO track OUT IN THE STREET (they also roll out a stutter free replica of MY GENERATION). This is merely competent, minimal chord rock and roll, fronted by singer KENN ELLNER's snotty snarl and BYRNE's six string outbursts...suffice to say they are better remembered for appearing onstage in high collared vampire capes than anything beyond their big hit (which punk wackos THE CRAMPS had the smarts to revive two decades later). Kudos to reissue label COLLECTABLES RECORDS for keeping the memory of out-of-print artists like COUNT FIVE alive.RATING: THREE COUNTS

THE JONESES-HARD: The Boston music scene is littered with shoulda/coulda/woulda been contenders for stardom...THE FOOLS, DUKE & THE DRIVERS and THE STOMPERS to cite just the tip of the iceberg. Least known of all may well be THE JONESES, whose '90 platter HARD benefitted from some Bean Town airplay, but is now lost to time. These guys boasted a good pedigree, axe slinger BILLY LOOSIGIAN having backed up punk godfadda WILLIE ALEXANDER (another unsung hero) and soulful singer/guitarist DAVID FINNERTY, whose previous band ROAD APPLES scored a Top 40 pop single with LET'S LIVE TOGETHER in 1975 (reprised on HARD in near metalized fashion). In a perfect world, STEPPIN' OUT, A LITTLE LOVE and DON'T YOU KNOW deserved to become FM classics still be played on AOR stations today. Welding the professional hard rock crunch of BAD COMPANY with the bloozey attitude of HUMBLE PIE, THE JONESES' hooky, pile driving din never made much noise outside of New England circles...but for those of us who lived there in 1990, memories of HARD still resonate in an exciting, secret place next to our NERVOUS EATERS and LYRES platters.RATING: FOUR ROCKERS

THE INCREDIBLY STRANGE MUSIC BOX/60 SONGS FROM THE CRAMPS' CRAZY COLLECTION-VARIOUS ARTISTS:  A kooky, kitschy collection of two minute cult classics that inspired punk upstarts THE CRAMPS, THE INCREDIBLY STRANGE MUSIC BOX serves up sixty slabs of eclectic groove-laden weirdness which could only have come from the early daze of rock & roll. Swingin' surf, exotic instrumentals, low fi sci fi, rockabilly rave ups, jivin' jungle jams, dance craze ditties and creature feature clap trap figure prominently in the musical makeup of freak-out front man LUX INERIOR and axe slingin' sex kitten spouse POISON IVY (both rabid record collectors). BO DIDDLEY and THE VENTURES may be the biggest stars on board here, but JIM (MR. MAGOO) BACKUS' seductive chuckle-fest DELICIOUS!, JERRY NEAL's unhinged cartoon assault I HATES RABBITS, and the BUDDY BOW blow-out TWISTIN' IN THE JUNGLE all leave their manic mark...and who can resist the urge to sample twisted titles like STUTTERIN' CINDY, HERE I AM DRUNK AGAIN and ALI BABA'S BOOGIE? After digesting the weird, wonderfully wacked-out wares of THE INCREDIBLY STRANGE MUSIC BOX, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out where CRAMPS originals like NATIVES ARE RESTLESS and TEENAGE WEREWOLF evolved from.RATING: FIVE COLLECTOR'S ITEMS

THE CAROL BURNETT SHOW-CAROL'S CRACK UPS: For decades, we've been subjected to a thirty minute syndicated version of the hour long CAROL BURNETT SHOW (under the title CAROL BURNETT & FRIENDS), favoring comedy skits over the elaborate musical productions inherent to every original episode. In spite of the slightly misleading title, these are full length episodes (meaning you get song and dance numbers mixed in with all the funny stuff) of the greatest variety show of all time. It's also fun to relive the entire Question and Answer periods that opened each program (often trimmed to mere seconds in syndication), not to mention CAROL's sentimental closing song, signature "ear tug" and autograph signings by her special guests like HELEN REDDY, JACK CASSIDY and ANDY GRIFFITH. Of course, BURNETT, HARVEY KORMAN, TIM CONWAY and VICKI LAWRENCE bring their immeasurable talents to the party throughout (with an able assist from last season regular DICK VAN DYKE). But CRACK UPS gives a fuller, long forgotten picture of the CAROL BURNETT SHOW...namely, rarely seen complete  episodes of spellbinding magic from an era when Saturday night was truly worth staying home for. For those of you looking for "Crack Ups", there's a nice bonus section that includes a fittingly hilarious segment called Breaking Up...Is Hard Not to Do.RATING: FIVE REDHEADS

DELBERT MCCLINTON-LIVE FROM AUSTIN: An unstoppable whirlwind of heatsinker harp blasts, raspy roadhouse yelps and the occasional ceiling-peeling scream, blues/country/rock champ DELBERT MCCLINTON is in his element  on LIVE FROM AUSTIN...in front of an appreciative audience on the concert stage. The juke joint juices start flowing early on this 1989 outing as the Lubbock, Texas legend mixes cocky covers of RNB gems like LIPSTICK TRACES and STANDING ON SHAKY GROUND with heady original tunes MAYBE SOMEDAY BABY, I WANNA THANK YOU BABY and B MOVIE BOX CAR BLUES (which THE BLUES BROTHERS immortalized on their debut). He's no slouch with a slow-burner either, channeling OTIS REDDING's passionate pleas in I'VE GOT DREAMS TO REMEMBER with the gusto of the well seasoned show man he so obviously is. This sizzling set of suds, sweat and cheer wraps up with the rowdiest take on YOU ARE MY SUNSHINE ever waxed and MCCLINTON's lone Top 40 pop hit, the hot-steppin' funk-fest GIVIN' IT UP FOR YOUR LOVE...a euphoric, soul-strewn last call that won't soon fade from memory.RATING: FOUR SAWDUST FLOORS

THREE DOG NIGHT-THREE DOG NIGHT:THREE DOG NIGHT's explosive self titled platter ranks as one of the finest debuts of its era, a tone-cool combination of sharp, edgy vocal harmonies and exquisite cover tune taste.  This sizzling 1969 set kick offs in style with a grandiose Top Five interpretation of HARRY NILSSON's starkly drawn ONE, followed by more faithful versions of TRAFFIC's HEAVEN IS IN YOUR MIND, THE BAND's organ-driven CHEST FEVER and the NEIL YOUNG chestnut THE LONER. RANDY NEWMAN, whose MAMA TOLD ME NOT TO COME would be a future chart topper for the group, TIM HARDIN and JOHNNY "GUITAR" WATSON also get the patented 3DN treatment. The triple threat white soul belting frontline of CHUCK NEGRON, CORY WELLS and DANNY HUTTON has never been bettered in pop music, complemented by the rock steady backing of guitarist MIKE ALLSUP, keyboardist JIMMY GREENSPOON and rhythm section of JOE SHERMY and FLOYD SNEAD. Culminating with a scorching read of OTIS REDDING's passion play TRY A LITTLE TENDERNESS (CORY WELLS at his unhinged gospel-stoked best), this exquisitely remastered album makes an excellent starting point for fans who'd like toexplore THREE DOG NIGHT beyond their played out copies of GREATEST HITS.RATING: FOUR DOGS

SOUTHERN CULTURE ON THE SKIDS' 2007 tribute COUNTRYPOLITAN FAVORITES is all over the musical map...a dash of pop, a dollop of blues, a splash of rock and lots of tasty twang. As might be expected from the North Carolina trio that previously resurrected the nearly forgotten chestnuts THE NITTY GRITTY and HOUSE OF BAMBOO,  SCOTS' taste in oldies is as exquisitely funky as RICK MILLER's greasy six string sizzle/down homey vocals and MARY HUFF's soul-drenched, sex kittie pipes. On the Nashville side of the coin, RENO & SMILEY's NO LONGER A SWEETHEART OF MINE and LYNN ANDERSON's  ROSE GARDEN get no nonsense work outs, while CLAUDE KING's saga WOLVERTON MOUNTAIN is kicked up a notch via the fragrant fire of HUFF's achingly gorgeous yodels. The rock repertoire runs deliciously deep...is there a KINKS track more suited to SCOTS' quirky sense of humor than MUSWELL HILLBILLY?..toss in T REX, BYRDS and JOHN FOGERTY obscurities and that swampy SLIM HARPO tongue-twister TE NI NEE NI NU and you've got a barn-burner of a roadhouse set list, Bubba! This is the most effervescent "South of the Border" tribute since DWIGHT YOAKAM's superb UNDER THE COVERS a decade before.RATING: FIVE HOT SCOTS

NAZARETH-HAIR OF THE DOG: A full half dozen platters into this Scottish quartet's existence, 1975's HAIR OF THE DOG broke 'em though to the masses via a full throttle melt down of the oft covered ballad (by ROY ORBISON and THE EVERLY BROTHERS, among others) LOVE HURTS. The scorching super nova title track (often referred to as SON OF A BITCH due to that line's frequent appearance) showcases DAN MCCAFFERTY...maybe the rawest, most explosive screecher in seventies hard rock...in all his ranting, unhinged glory. Radio hits aside, NAZARETH also scores big via the bloozey WHISKEY DRINKIN' WOMAN, thundering ten minute dirge PLEASE DON'T JUDAS ME, and a balls out take on BEGGAR'S DAY, absolutely the hardest NILS LOFGREN has ever been rocked. So much of the band's catalogue of volcanic, indispensable material...GONE DEAD TRAIN, GO DOWN FIGHTIN', RAZAMANAZ, NOT FAKIN IT', HOLIDAY...never saw the light of day on FM radio (or if they did, not for long)...HAIR OF THE DOG stands loud 'n proud as the one audio assault even casual NAZ fans can say they've taken a tasty bite out of.RATING: FOUR DOG HAIRS

DWIGHT YOAKAM-UNDER THE COVERS: Country maverick DWIGHT YOAKAM has always worn his wide ranging musical influences on the sleeve of his rhinestone Nudie suit...he's scored hits with covers of QUEEN's CRAZY LITTLE THING CALLED LOVE and CHEAP TRICK's I WANT YOU TO WANT ME, and released an entire album of Bakersfield chestnuts by his idol (and occasional duet pardner) BUCK OWENS. 1997's cleverly titled UNDER THE COVERS finds the hip guru of honky tonk reinventing THE CLASH's punk-pop anthem TRAIN IN VAIN as a punchy bluegrass ditty, tripling the tempo of THE STONES' country rocker THE LAST TIME and playing SONNY BONO to husky-voiced SHERYL CROW's CHER on BABY DON'T GO. Best of all may be his finger poppin' lounge lizard take on that under rated KINKS oldie TIRED OF WAITING, complete with big band horn blasts and funky BOBBY DARIN undercurrent.  A straight run-through of NORTH TO ALASKA segues into a bluesy "T" FOR TEXAS jam (kudos, as always to PETE ANDERSON's earthy guitar licks) to cap this project off in style. All-covers platters are as common as ticks on a hound...leave it to an innovator like YOAKAM to make it work beyond anyone's wildest dreams.RATING: FIVE PAIRS OF RIPPED JEANS

BATMAN-THE COMPLETE THIRD SEASON: By its third and final season, the once unfathomably popular BATMAN had its budget slashed, was reduced to one airing a week (no more intricate cliff hanger traps) and got played for laughs more than ever . The main difference of course, was the addition of COMMISSIONER GORDON's self assured librarian daughter BARBARA aka BATGIRL, who looked as fetching in her skin tight purple outfit as JULIE NEWMAR (replaced by a snarling EARTHA KITT this time around) had in her cat suit. The welcome return of FRANK GORSHIN as THE RIDDLER only emphasized how weak the new crop of arch criminals invading Gotham City were...MILTON BERLE's horticulturist heavy LOUIE THE LILAC and JOAN COLLINS' ear-melting SIREN were about the best of the lot...but the less said about LOLA LASAGNA, NORA CLAVICLE and a three episode LORD FOGG arc the better. The once elaborate hideouts morphed into nothing more than simple props on darkened stages, while the plot lines, especially ones involving the JOKER (flying saucers and a surf contest with BATMAN to name two) were the most outrageous yet. In spite of the Caped Crusader's staunchest efforts, this is where the wheels finally came off the Batmobile.RATING: THREE BATGIRL CYCLES

DAVE EDMUNDS-SUBTLE AS A FLYING MALLET: Few artists carried the retro rock torch higher or more convincingly than its ultimate revivalist, Welsh rocker DAVE EDMUNDS. Boasting one of the coolest titles in album history, SUBTLE AS A FLYING MALLET is a charismatic hybrid of rockabilly, RNB and other pop styles...hardly a surprise from the man whose biggest hit was an echo-laden reboot of HUEY "PIANO" SMITH's Big Easy gemstone I HEAR YOU KNOCKING. The acclaimed producer (he's twisted the knobs for everyone from FOGHAT to DION to kd lang) recreates PHIL SPECTOR's famous "wall of sound" on DA DO RON RON and BABY I LOVE YOU, gets his twang on via the traditional folk saga BILLY THE KID, and lovingly channels his idols THE EVERLY BROTHERS and CHUCK BERRY. For a change of pace from the "virtual jukebox" set list, EDMUNDS, who plays almost every instrument here, lends his high lonesome pipes to the pretty ballad SHE'S MY BABY...written by a certain NICK LOWE, with whom he had a highly influential collaboration as the oldies-inspired super group ROCKPILE a few years later.RATING: FOUR MALLETS

BACHMAN & TURNER-LIVE AT ROSELAND BALLROOM: Gearheads, rejoice! RANDY BACHMAN & FRED TURNER, the creative half of that powerhouse seventies foursome BTO...are alive and well in this 2010 concert reunion. All the old sledgehammer classics are on loud 'n proud display, with BACHMAN's GUESS WHO era juggernauts SHAKIN' ALL OVER and AMERICAN WOMAN lobbed like soul-searing grenades for good measure. TURNER's gruff, banshee wail has weathered surprisingly well over time, as stoked rundowns of LET IT RIDE, ROLL ON DOWN THE HIGHWAY and NOT FRAGILE will attest. Tasty guitar slinger BACHMAN, a much more subdued vocalist, antes up the chugging AM anthems TAKIN' CARE OF BUSINESS and YOU AIN'T SEEN NOTHIN' YET, wisely avoiding the uppermost notes on his hardest rocker STAYED AWAKE ALL NIGHT. B & T's well oiled machine bogs down only when obligatory "new tunes" are trotted out...perhaps the hoarsely croaked sludge-fest WAITING GAME should have been all left off the set list altogether. During their seventies hey day, BTO never released a landmark concert souvenir along the lines of DEEP PURPLE, FOGHAT or KISS...LIVE AT ROSELAND goes a long way towards rectifying that...albeit a good three decades after the fact.RATING: FOUR GEARHEADS

THE WHO-MEATY BEATY BIG & BOUNCY-Covering the singles oriented era before they unleashed WHO'S NEXT, one of rock & roll's most perfect rock albums, MEATY BEATY BIG & BOUNCY rounds up fourteen gemstones from THE WHO's incredibly fertile late sixties period. MY GENERATION, PINBALL WIZARD, I CAN SEE FOR MILES and MAGIC BUS may be the best known landmarks here, but equally amazing are the wry lyrical landscapes explored on SUBSTITUTE, I CAN'T EXPLAIN and I'M A BOY, easily some of PETE TOWNSHEND's wittiest, most cutting work. JOHN ENTWHISTLE, the underused GEORGE HARRISON of the group, spits out the sticky tale BORIS THE SPIDER (his signature "in concert" song for decades), while A LEGAL MATTER shows the high pitched TOWNSHEND to be just as interesting and capable a lead singer as ROGER DALTRY. There have been literally dozens of WHO collections shoved down the public's throat over the decades...but none captured the band's incomparable power and raw rock & roll spirit more eloquently than the aptly titled MEATY BEATY BIG & BOUNCY.RATING: FIVE BOUNCES

TESLA-REAL TO REEL:  A natural extension of their top selling platter FIVE MAN ACOUSTICAL JAM...an unplugged concert of band chestnuts HEAVEN'S  TRAIL (NO WAY OUT) and THE WAY IT IS mixed with covers of CCR, STONES and BEATLES material...REAL TO REEL unspools like a better than average afternoon with your favorite classic rock radio station. Always one of "Hair Metal"'s more palatable exponents, the quintet tackles the underexposed gems such as URIAH HEEP's STEALIN', THIN LIZZY's BAD REPUATION  and UFO's ROCK BOTTOM, coming across like the best Saturday night bar band you ever boogied your beer belly to. Trouble is, it's all a little TOO perfect, right down to JEFF KEITH's vocal simulations of JOE WALSH, ERIC CLAPTON and STEVE WINWOOD and the carbon copy instrumental arrangements...only the staunchest TESLA supporter would say these outshine the originals, but it's a helluva lot of fun nonetheless. A second volume trots out further seventies treasures by everyone from BTO and ZZ TOP to AEROSMITH and BLACK SABBATH, once again sidestepping the most obvious choices. REAL TO REEL serves as a testament to TESLA's roots and influences...not to mention, it's a damned fine rockin' party mix.RATING: FOUR REMAKES

BATMAN-SEASON 2, PART 2: While largely maintaining the frenetic fun of the first half of season two, BATMAN was starting to show chinks in the old Bat-Armor at this point. Legendary character actors abound, notably ELI WALLACH as the third (and least chilling) MR. FREEZE, MAURICE EVANS' Shakespeare-quoting, balloon toting PUZZLER and WALTER SLEZAK's CLOCK KING (not to mention his LIFEBOAT co-star TALLULAH BANKHEAD in her final performance as BLACK WIDOW). For the first time, "double trouble" team ups come into play...THE PENGUIN joins forces with both THE JOKER and MARSHA, QUEEN OF DIAMONDS in separate three segment story arcs, while MICHAEL RENNIE's suave SANDMAN cuddles up to JULIE NEWMAR's delicious dominatrix CATWOMAN (always BATMAN's most interesting, fleshed out foe). The stunt casting of the GREEN HORNET and KATO (VAN WILLIAMS and BRUCE LEE) is inspired, even if ROGER C. CARMEL's portrayal of COLONEL GUMM in the same adventure is not...meanwhile, JOHN ASTIN's lone shot as THE RIDDLER falls flat (as if anyone could fill FRANK GORSHIN's ballet slippers). Nonetheless, this was the series' last gasp at greatness...the elimination of cliffhangers, most of the budget and the introduction of a certain high-kicking sidekick were waiting in the wings for Season Three.RATING: FOUR BAT CLIMBS

BATMAN-SEASON 2, PART 1: The first half of BATMAN's sophomore year adds an ever growing list of baddies...the colorful gimmick by which the series lived or died each week...to the core cache of CAESAR ROMERO's maniacal JOKER, BURGESS MEREDITH's cackling PENGUIN and JULIE NEWMAR's skin-tight seductress CATWOMAN (FRANK GORSHIN's deliriously hyperactive RIDDLER is sorely missed). The normally reliable ART CARNEY falls flat as THE ARCHER, CAROLYN JONES channels MORTICIA ADDAMS for MARSHA, QUEEN OF DIAMONDS, and LIBERACE's evil ivory-tickler CHANDEL is inspired stunt casting if nothing else. Much more memorable are CLIFF ROBERTSON's bullet-headed cowpoke SHAME, scene-chewing SHELLY WINTERS as MA BARKER, VINCENT PRICE's brainy, pun-spouting EGGHEAD and OTTO PREMINGER's eyebrow-raising turn as MR. FREEZE (which ups the kitsch ante on GEORGE SANDERS' first season appearance and puts ELI WALLACH's later take on ice). Obviously played less close to the vest this time around, the cliffhanger traps are far more elaborate (making their escapes all the more incredulous), celebrities pop out of windows during every Bat-climb, and CHAD & JEREMY have their singing voices "stolen" and held for ransom by CATWOMAN. As BURT WARD's easily excitable BOY WONDER might exclaim, "Holy hilarity!"RATING: FOUR BATARANGS

THE ART OF MCCARTNEY-VARIOUS ARTISTS: PAUL MCCARTNEY's legacy as one of rock's premiere songwriter/performers has long been established...in fact, there have been many decent interpretations of his work over the decades by artists such as ARETHA FRANKLIN, JOE COCKER and FATS DOMINO. THE ART OF MCCARTNEY is far too long, predictable and star-studded to be effective as a tribute, and might have come off better if it zeroed in on all BEATLES or all WINGS material, instead of both. Unabashed Fab Four disciples like JEFF LYNNE and CHEAP TRICK turn in faithful, but utterly faceless performances, this double platter's most common issue; only roots rock icons TOOTS HIBBERT, B. B.KING, WANDA JACKSON and WILLIE NELSON approach their assignments with anything resembling "re-boot". ALICE COOPER comes off surprisingly unrecognizable on ELEANOR RIGBY, BILLY JOEL has never sounded shabbier on his pair or turns at bat, and STEVE MILLER, while passable on JUNIOR'S FARM, transforms HEY JUDE into a drawn out, dung-encrusted joke. It's hard to accuse BOB DYLAN, DEF LEPPARD or KISS of anything other than mediocrity here...suffice to say, no one betters SIR PAUL at his own game...at least no one resurrected any MICHAEL JACKSON duets.RATING: THREE WINGS

THE CAROL BURNETT SHOW/ULTIMATE COLLECTION: THE CAROL BURNETT SHOW spotlighted television's most versatile comedienne; she portrayed dozens of memorable characters including CHARO, GLORIA SWANSON and JOAN CRAWFORD take offs, plus brain-dead secretary MRS. WHIGGINS...as opposed to LUCY, who always played "LUCY". Whether busting out rubber faced slapstick, duetting with stars like JIM NABORS and JULIE ANDREWS, or wittily fielding questions from the studio audience, this former GARY MOORE SHOW standout could do no wrong. Flanked by the best bunch of "second bananas" in history, BURNETT's secret weapon was HARVEY KORMAN, who could play anything from Hollywood has-beens to fussy floorwalkers and German dictators...but couldn't keep a straight face around mischievously unpredictable ad-libber TIM CONWAY. Straight man/stud LYLE WAGGONER and the redoubtable VICKI LAWRENCE (whose crotchety southern matriarch MAMA earned a series spin-off) rounded out the dream cast. A beloved potpourri of glitzy BOB MACKIE wardrobes, elaborate film parodies and game guest stars, THE CAROL BURNETT SHOW was the last and arguably greatest of all TV variety programs.RATING: FIVE TUGS ON THE EARLOBE

PABLO CRUISE-THE BEST OF PABLO CRUISE: If you crossed the more serious side of JIMMY BUFFET with MICHAEL MCDONALD-era DOOBIE BROTHERS, you'd get a pretty decent idea of the carefree California soft rock PABLO CRUISE had to offer in the late seventies. Smooth, clear voiced crooner/guitarist DAVID JENKINS (who later turned up in the country super group SOUTHERN PACIFIC, which featured two actual DOOBIES) and soulful keyboardist CORY LERIOS share in helming the hits, from earnest smash LOVE WILL FIND A WAY and funky sing-along WHATCHA GONNA DO to disco throbber I WANT YOU TONIGHT and sunny throw down I GO TO RIO, one of PETER ALLEN's most popular compositions. BEST OF collects everything a casual PABLO CRUISE fan could want or need, marred only by a pair of instrumentals, one of which, ZERO TO SIXTY IN FIVE goes nowhere fast in spite of its title. Here's an almost perfect soundtrack to share with a pitcher of margaritas on a balmy "sick day" away from the rat race...PABLO CRUISE has you covered.REATING: FOUR SUNBEAMS

THE MOVERS-BLUES THAT MOVES: A stone cold case of "truth in advertising", 90s upstarts THE MOVERS compared favorably to another New England bred set of boogie brothers, ROOMFUL OF BLUES, who also specialized in horn-vaccinated mash ups of swing, RNB and jazz. Led by earthy, energized belter DANNY VITALE and a trumpet/trombone/sax attack appropriately dubbed THE SMOKING SECTION, THE MOVERS deliver a tasty TGIF soundtrack, never letting up through fifteen tight tracks of dance party antics. Half the fun of BLUES THAT MOVES is the band's impeccable cover tune taste...JOHNNY "GUITAR" WATSON's oft-tackled TOO TIRED, THE FABULOUS THUNDERBIRDS' early morning tribute WHY GET UP, BIG JOE TURNER's rollicking BOOGIE WOOGIE COUNTRY GIRL and BOBBY "BLUE" BLAND's greasy AIN'T THAT LOVIN' YOU all get work outs that will inspire any listener to jump, jive and wail. To paraphrase that giddy godfather of swing blues LOUIS JORDAN, if you can't get up and move to THE MOVERS..."Jack, you're dead!"RATING: FOUR MOVIN' GROOVES

KEEP YOUR SOUL-A TRIBUTE TO DOUG SAHM: No individual better exemplified Texas' vast roots rock richness than DOUG SAHM, pivotal member of 60s hit makers THE SIR DOUGLAS QUARTET, 90s country supergroup THE TEXAS TORNADOS, and a highly respected artist in his own right. A who's who of like minded genre-jumpers take a tasty trip through his blues/country/soul songbook; while no one quite beats the master at his own greasy game, it's a ton of fun to hear 'em try.
