So if you have dry skin, and especially if you have very dry skin, this product will not perform well for you. For myself, I would only rate it one or two stars because even when used as a mid-day "boost" to the skin, it just doesn't have any sort of lasting effect.But for a friend with oily skin, this was a satisfactory product. She didn't see any long-term effect to her skin, but appreciated that it gave a little moisture boost without leaving her skin feeling greasy.

In the months before his death, Walt Disney unveiled his plans for an Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow (called EPCOT for short), a centrally planned city that utilized the latest technological innovations to create a new kind of urban center.  Developing a city may seem far-fetched for a man best known for his innovations in animation, but author Sam Gennawey traces Disney’s interest in urban planning and designing public spaces from its roots in his backyard steam train and the design of his Burbank Studio all the way through to Disneyland and beyond.  Along the way, the reader is introduced to failed projects, like a proposed ski resort, as well as the successes.  Walt Disney died before his proposed city could be built, but Gennawey extrapolates what may have in Florida today had Disney’s plan been carried out as he envisioned it.I found this book to be absolutely fascinating and eye-opening.  As a frequent visitor to Disneyland, I’m very familiar with Main Street USA, the “land” at the entrance to the park.  It has an old-timey, classic appeal and as you walk down the street, toward the Sleeping Beauty Castle, it’s a comforting and calming experience.  Sam Gennawey explains many of the architectural tricks and cues that help create this experience for guests, and as I read I found a new appreciation for the care and attention to detail that Disney and his Imagineers devoted to the appearance and layout of the buildings.  As Gennawey continued to other areas of the park, I mentally followed in his footsteps.  He also talks about some of the innovations Disney brought to his theme park, like the dedication to preventing litter and maintaining the appearance of the buildings, and how his ideas spread to other parks and eventually became standard practice.I also loved reading about lesser-known Disney projects.  We’re all familiar with the phenomenal success of Disneyland, but I’ve only heard of his proposed Mineral King project in footnotes or asides.  It was a proposed ski resort, to be located near Sequoia National Park in the Sierra Nevada mountain range.  I hesitate to call it “Disneyland in the mountains” but in many ways that’s exactly what was planned.  The resort was to be an entertainment destination, with wilderness lectures, outdoor activities, restaurants, a conference center, and planned ‘attractions’ similar to the ones at Disneyland.  The project was eventually shut down by the United States Forest Service after protests and a lawsuit filed by the Sierra Club.  As a Disney fan, I’m so curious about what Mineral King would have been like, but as a Sierra Club member I’m also horrified at the thought of the impact of the described resort on the environment just outside one of the most beautiful parks in California.  It would have been interesting, but I’m glad the decision was made not to go with the Disney proposal.Of course, most of the book is devoted to EPCOT.  I really enjoyed Sam Gennawey’s projection of what EPCOT would look like if it had been completed; it’s a great thought exercise that showcases Disney’s creativity and his forward-thinking. I certainly enjoy the EPCOT theme park and what it offers today, but neither it nor the Disney city of Celebration really encapsulates Disney’s vision.  Anyone who has enjoyed walking around Disneyland or the Magic Kingdom, admiring the architecture and the themed lands, will learn a lot from this book.  Those who are curious about the urban planning and want to explore a centrally-planned city will also find it difficult to put this book down.

All her life, sixteen-year-old Gwen has believed that her cousin Charlotte is destined for greatness, while she is fated to live an ordinary life.  That’s how their family raised them.  As the inheritor of the time travel gene, Charlotte has been trained since birth so that she can pass undetected through the past.  But when a dizzy spell sends Gwen jumping through time, a secret society for time travelers scrambles to prepare her for her role as the Ruby.  Her reluctant assistant is the mysterious Gideon, a young man who spent his entire childhood preparing alongside Charlotte.  The more Gwen learns about her abilities and her fellow time travelers, the more questions she has about the secret society and the decisions made in the past.Ruby Red is a German young adult series, translated by Anthea Bell into English.  It’s a fun adventure romp that neatly manages many YA tropes: an ordinary girl who discovers she’s actually super-special, a brooding hero whose initial dislike of the heroine turns to love by the end of the first volume, fancy dresses, and a gal pal to giggle and gossip with.  The time travel and the secret society are explained very thoroughly and help to distinguish the story from other YA novels.Gwen is a fun narrator because she’s such a believable teenager.  She is a bit flighty and not terribly bright, and she’s quick to fall into a new crush.  Her ordinariness contrasts sharply with the destiny assigned her, and her attempts to adapt to her new life are entertaining because she is often so giggling and cavalier about it.  She’s a bit silly, but the story needs that humor because everyone else tends to be so serious.Although the fact that she can see ghosts and has underdeveloped psychic powers…well, I’m curious to see where that’s going.One of the things I don’t like about the book is that it really doesn’t stand on its own.  Most of the book seems devoted to setting the stage for a big, grand adventure, but that never comes.  Gwen has a couple of exploratory trips into the past, but certain scenes from the beginning of the book hint at something huge that never comes.  When the book ends on a cliffhanger, it’s a little frustrating because nothing much has happened yet.  But irritated as I am by this fact, I also want to hurry up and find the next volume of the series so I find out what happens next, so perhaps Gier picked a winning strategy by cutting things off before the going got good.

Jane Seymour may not be the greatest beauty of Henry VIII's glittering court, but she and her long-time sweetheart Will hope to wed.  But as setback after another pushes their wedding date  away, Jane begins to despair of becoming his wife.  Her loyalty shifts to her mistress, Catherine of Aragon, whom she serves with great devotion.  As the king's attention shifts from his wife to the temptress Anne Boleyn, Jane's family rises in power as her brother Ned seeks a solution to nullifying the marriage between Catherine and Henry.  By the time Catherine is deposed and Anne Boleyn has been set upon the throne, Jane is resigned to her role as spinster.  But when she least expects it, Jane at last finds love where she never intended.This is my first time reading a Carolly Erickson book.  Although several of her biographies came heavily recommended to me, it is this novel that I start with, and it has so turned me off this author that I don't know if I'll ever pick up another one of her books.  When an author uses real historical figures and places in their books, I expect the story to follow historical events to some degree.  Now, I'm no expert on the life of Henry VIII and his queens but this novel consistently ignores the most basic facts of Tudor England.Some of these breaches are more egregious than others.  One of the most guffaw-inducing are multiple references to the “Maiden's  Bower”, a sort of secret harem kept hidden in Henry VIII's castles to service the king's every sexual whims.  WHAT.  I've never seen a mention of such a thing in any history of the king's court, because Henry VIII never needed it.  In addition to his infamous collection of wives, Henry VIII also had several mistresses over the years.  For the most part they were daughters of his nobles, and there was always an element of romance to the affair.  He didn't have a posse of prostitutes waiting in the wings – if he had, there'd be a lot more royal bastards running around.Another inconsistency is that Jane Seymour's brother Thomas completely vanishes from the story, a disappointing decision given how pivotal he is to later English history.  Her brother Edward is given a fair amount of attention, and both his first wife and himself figuring prominently in Jane's life, but Thomas doesn't even rank a bedside appearance at his father's deathbed.  Curiously, Edward's second wife Anne Stanhope never appears either, despite there being evidence that she and Jane Seymour were close.At one point, a sweating sickness sweeps through London, killing many.  Anne Boleyn is one of those struck by the disease.  This is fact.  In an attempt to heighten the drama, Erickson has Boleyn fall ill while in seclusion with Catherine of Aragon and nearly tossed out the window to her death by a guard to prevent the spread of the disease.  The aging queen intervenes, sparing Anne's life and personally caring for her in her illness.  It's total romantic twaddle to show Catherine at her best and Anne at her worst, and feels forced in the worst possible way.Many of the characters' personalities seemed inconsistent with what we know of them.  Anne Boleyn was known to be haughty and unpleasant, true; but here she's little more than a spoiled brat, stomping her way from one tantrum to the next.  Catherine is so saintly it's nearly sickening.  Jane Seymour, our witness to events, has a thrilling sexual affair with a working class man that lasts for months, yet somehow passes as a virgin to the coterie of midwives to inspect her body.  Despite the title of the book, there's never any evidence that Jane is a favored queen when she takes the throne; Henry VIII doesn't treat her any better than his previous wives. Most disappointing to me, the author didn't include an afterward where she explained her deviations from the historical record.  As long as the author explains their changes, I'm usually able to live with fictionalized accounts of history.  (This is why I remain a Philippa Gregory fan even though I know her novels take great liberties indeed.)  All Erickson does is throw a sentence or two at the end describing her book as a “historical entertainment” and a “reimagining of the past”.  Perhaps this especially rankles because Erickson has written non-fiction works and describes herself as a historian.  Surely she didn't need to sensationalize her stories to make them exciting; there's enough drama in the surviving records without inventing new things out of nowhere.I give the book two stars because Erickson is an entertaining writer, and her narrative flows smoothly enough.  But if the reader is unfamiliar with the Tudor period, he or she will end up with some very strange and inaccurate ideas about Henry VIII's wives and the English court at that time.

This is a classic fairy tale from China that I've encountered many times in children's books and folklore compilations. Marilee Heyer's version is pretty consistent with the others; I don't see any "modernizing" or attempts to re-spin the story. The illustrations by Heyer are absolutely stunning. It's a beautiful realistic style that focuses on small details. As she describes the suffering of the widow as she weaves her magical tapestry, the image focuses in on her hands hard at work as blood drips down uponthem. When the main hero receives a gift of shoes, she focuses in on the magical boots, not on him or the giver. It helps draw the reader in and emphasizes what he or she should focus on. Her human figures are well-designed, too. Each of the three brothers has a distinct face that reveals something of his personality, and the aged mother still has traces of the beauty that must have made her stunning in her youth. The Chinese fairy is ethereal and beautiful, seeming to float in the image but looking real enough to match the other characters. It makes the story all the more believable to young readers.

I ordered a pair of white gold cubic zirconia earrings so that the metal would match my wedding ring.The earrings were very well packaged.  They came in a black velvet box, which is further protected by a white cardboard box.  So each pair should arrive in perfect condition.When I first opened the box I was pleased by the quality of the earrings. The five small stones are very firmly held in place; no need to worry about one of them popping out and ruining the earring's appearance. The large dangling stone is also well-anchored.  The clasp is very easy to open and close and once in place, the earring doesn't shift or slide around.The dangling stone is pretty large.  The cut is beautiful and catches the light really well, so they are always sparkling.  It creates an elegant look but it is still casual enough that it can be worn daily.  No need to save these for special occasions only!I would definitely buy more earrings by Orrous & Co, because the quality is great and the price is affordable.I received these earrings in exchange for an honest review.

I love matcha.  I try to drink a cup or two every day, both because I enjoy the flavor and to take advantage of the many health benefits of green tea.  When Kiss Me Organics offered me a chance to review their matcha, I couldn't say yes quickly enough.This matcha has a very fresh, grassy flavor that I found refreshing.  There is very little bitterness, which in some matcha powders overwhelms and ruins the flavor.  The flavor also holds up well in a variety of uses: mixed with milk in a latte, blended with fruit in a smoothie, baked into cookies, and even mixed into frosting for chocolate cupcakes.The matcha has also been ground to a very fine powder, so there's no grittiness to the texture of the drink or foods in which I used it.I received a sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

I have fairly dry skin, so skin moisturizers are very important to me and I'm always eager to try the latest and greatest thing.  I received a pot of Neutrogena's water gel in a beauty subscription box, and hoped it would be helpful.The first thing I noticed as I opened the pot was the fragrance.  It has a very fresh, clean scent - the sort of perfume that would be sold under a name like "Cool Water" or "Tranquility".  It's strong enough that I can smell the cream as it soaks in, but after thirty seconds or so the scent has dissipated.The gel absorbs into the skin very quickly, and afterwards my skin smooth and soft.  The sensation doesn't last long, however.  After an hour or so, my skin starts to get that tight, itchy feeling that dry skin has when it is utterly out of moisture, and I have to reapply.  So if you have dry skin, and especially if you have very dry skin, this product will not perform well for you.  For myself, I would only rate it one or two stars because even when used as a mid-day "boost" to the skin, it just doesn't have any sort of lasting effect.But for a friend with oily skin, this was a satisfactory product.  She didn't see any long-term effect to her skin, but appreciated that it gave a little moisture boost without leaving her skin feeling greasy.

I have always liked using glass teaware so that I can watch my tea leaves unfurl as they brew, but it's devilishly hard to use glass teapots or cups when you're on the go!  The Dechunxian tea tumbler solves this problem by encasing a narrow glass cup in a black outer casing that both protects the glass and helps insulate fingers from the hot surface.  With a metal infuser to prevent the leaves from reaching your mouth and a screw on top to secure the beverage for travel, it's very effective.I was a little nervous when I first received the tumbler because there were no English instructions provided.  On a little paper insert found with the product's packaging, Chinese instructions were provided.  Curiously, the titles of each section of the instruction manual had been translated as "Features", "Tips" and so on - but the actual content blocks remained in Chinese.  So I had to guess on the best way to use the tumbler, and since I'm not sure of the care instructions I've been sure to only wash it by hand, and not in the dishwasher.Still, use is pretty straightforward.  Tea leaves go in the glass.  Hot water follows.  Insert the metal infuser, which snaps into place at the top of the bottle.  Wait a few minutes and voila - the tea is ready!I love the sleek and modern design of the tumbler - it looks great sitting on my desk next to my laptop.  I've also tried holding the tumbler upside down and shaking it, and no leaking drops of tea splattered onto my clothes.  I'm very confident in the security of this thing.  I know that if I drop the tumbler and it lands wrong, the glass will crack and that's the end of it.  But I think that with care, this will last just as long as any other glass should.I received a sample of this tea infuser in exchange for an honest review.PS - If you're looking for some great loose tea to use with this product, I recommend Adagio Teas!

After the death of his grandfather, sixteen-year-old Jacob is devastated.  He convinces his parents to let him travel to the remote island off the coast of Wales where his grandfather lived after he was orphaned as a child.  Jacob hopes it will bring him closure, but he's also haunted by stories his grandfather told him about his childhood, tales of children with special powers and sinister monsters.  At the center of all the mysteries is Miss Peregrine, and Jacob is determined to track her down so that he can understand his grandfather's fate.The conceit of this book is interesting: take a collection of vintage found photographs and craft a story around them.  It works really well.  Scattered throughout the novel are reproductions of the images, so as Jacob's grandfather describes his childhood friends and shows his grandson pictures of them, the reader sees them too.  Riggs claims that for the most part, his creepy photos of children haven't been altered (beyond whatever the original photographers might have done) and appear just as he discovered them.The pacing of the story is really, really slow.  The beginning is downright sluggish, even when events should make it exciting.  Eventually, the book finds its momentum, but at that point the reader has had to slog through two-thirds of the story.  I almost quit several times, but I'd heard a lot of praise for this book and its sequel, Hollow City, so I kept hoping things would pick up.  Nope.  Not even magic and time travel could bring energy to the narrative.Jacob is an interesting teenager.  His manner of dealing with grief and loss is very realistic, and the book is his coming of age story.  His growth as a character is worth watching.  Sadly, he's the only character fleshed out enough to have something like a personality.  Most of the `peculiar' children that he meets at Miss Peregrine's orphanage are flat, cardboard cutouts with no nuance or depth to their personalities.  The most intriguing character, Jacob's grandfather, is killed off in the first chapter, but the dribbles of information we're fed about his life make me want to read a book that's all about him.There's some lovely writing describing the beauty of the island and some very atmospheric moments in the orphanage.  I'm happy to praise the book for that.  But in the end, it just couldn't hold my interest for long.

In May of 2001, twenty-six men attempted to cross the border between Mexico and the United States, passing through a desert in Arizona so desolate and deadly that it’s known as the Devil’s Highway.  On foot and woefully underprepared for the harsh conditions, the men were attempting the illegal crossing to better their lives in America.  Instead, guided by a coyote inexperienced in the area, the men walked in circles until, one by one, they succumbed to dehydration and exhaustion and crumpled to their deaths.  In the end, only a dozen men were saved.Luis Alberto Urrea’s report of events is at times almost clinical, but it’s absolutely haunting.  He profiles each man to the best of his ability – some of the men were never identified – and briefly explains why he was making the trip.  Some men were seasoned workers who had been to the United States before; others were young teens, leaving their home village for the first time.  One boy went to help his aging father; later, it is the father left holding his dead son in his arms. Collectively, the twenty-six men are just more cases to add to an ever-rising number of people who die crossing the border.  But with each story, creating personalities and family relationships, they become real people, and the true weight of their deaths can be felt.Urrea is sympathetic to both illegal immigrants and the border patrol tasked with keeping them out.  Again and again, he shows the humane side of the officers, who pay to erect and stock water stations in the desert for migrants to use and rush into the desert when there are reports of dying men.  Excepting a few bad eggs, they aren’t evil men seeking to punish the Mexicans – they’re just doing their jobs.  Blame for the men’s fate falls squarely on the coyotes who led them into the desert without adequate supplies and then, upon realizing he was lost, first refused to turn back and ultimately abandoned his flock to their fates, looking only to save himself.Reading this book is hard.  Graphic descriptions of the way the body breaks down as it is dehydrated and cooked is simply horrific.  Descriptions of the corpses and the pitiful effects they carried as they moved toward a new life in the United States are heartbreaking.  The shocking amount of money the United States and Mexico spend on the bodies of the dead, flying them back to their villages in expensive coffins and with great ceremony, is mind-boggling.  Why can’t some of this money be spent on the men while they’re alive?Of course, the true tragedy is that this incident isn’t an isolated one.  Hundreds of desperate people die each year making the same trek.  Urrea doesn’t offer any solutions, because there is no easy answer, but he forces readers normally isolated from such events to look them full in the face and consider the true human cost of our current border policies.

At first glance, the earrings look lovely.  The stone is clear and a pretty shade of blue.  However, a closer inspection of the earrings reveal some small flaws.The gemstones themselves have no problem.  The cushion cut blue topaz stones catch the light and sparkle beautifully.  They're a nice size and comfortable to wear.  The white gold setting compliments the topaz beautifully.However, the setting is cheap and the earring hooks are terrible.  When I opened the clasp, I could see a sharp edge on the edge of the hook.  It's clear that a pair of wire cutters were used to cut the hook, and the worker didn't take the time to smooth out the rough edges.  It makes the hook very sharp, and when I tried to put the earrings in my ear was scratched just by brushing up against the hook.  I've never had an earring injure me before!Compared to a classic french hook, these earrings can be difficult to take on and off.  The clasp behind the ear gets in the way.  Once the earrings are on, the heavy clasps detract from the delicacy of the stones and the minimal setting they are placed in.  I wish that the manufacturer had gone a different route, because it is a shame that these blue topaz aren't showcased in a better way.

These sturdy blocks provide hours and hours of entertainment.The board book is a great launching point, introducing kids to the pirate life and helping them launch their own pirate adventures.  The set comes with several pirate figures,  boys and girls with multiple ethnicities, and the pieces to assemble their own version of a pirate ship.  In addition to the boat there's blocks for a cannon, a treasure chest, the crow's nest, and all the proper pirate animals: monkey, parrot, shark, etc.The blocks are all wooden, and have been sanded down so that there are no sharp edges or splinters. Images are usually printed on both sides of the block.  On a few of my blocks, the image transfer didn't work quite right, and bits of the picture are missing. It follows the pattern of the wood grain, which makes me think the texture was a problem.  But out of the 34 blocks, only 2 or 3 are really affected, and it's unlikely that it would impact play.The blocks came packaged in a wooden tray they fit into perfectly, although it might take a bit of Tetris-style shuffling to get them back in.  Unfortunately, there's nothing to hold the figures in the tray, so if a kid knocks it over the blocks will go flying in all directions.  I wish that the manufacturers had provided a lid for the box to prevent this from happening.  But again, the kids will still love it and be able to play with the blocks - a lid would have just made things easier for Mom when playtime is over.

NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS SPECIFIC TO THE ABRIDGED AUDIO CD VERSION OF THE BOOK.Talk about one messed-up woman!I'm a little disappointed in the abridgment of this book. The original book was 560 pages in mass market, so a pretty good size - chopping it down to 2.5 hours means that any background about Pat's childhood was totally cut and the rest of the story has very little detail. I wanted to know if there were any indications that Pat was a troubled child, and what exactly happened with her first marriage. (She has adult children by the time she's in her mid-thirties so there's clearly some sort of story there.) Unfortunately, all that information was cut, and the story more or less starts with Pat meeting her second husband while living with her parents. The crimes are detailed pretty well, and the trial at the end is thorough. It's just disappointing that there's so little information about Pat's early life or her husband's relationship with his ex-wife and his parents, because that would have really helped flesh out the story. It's almost enough to make me want to go find the physical book so that I can (hopefully) fill in some of the details.So if you're interested in this story, don't waste time on the audio CD.  Just go ahead and pick up the physical book.An interesting footnote: in 1999, Pat was released from prison after serving her sentence for the crimes covered in this book. She moved in with her stepfather and his new wife, Pat's aunt, and owned a doll shop. (Creepy!) In 2008, she was arrested and charged once again, this time for acquiring pain pills illegally for unauthorized distribution. Not sure if she ended up in prison again; couldn't find record of it online.

When eighteen year old Petronella Oortman arrives on the doorstep of her new home in Amsterdam, she's eager to be a loving wife to her new husband, wealthy merchant Johannes Brandt.  To her surprise, the charming lover who courted her has vanished, replaced with a kind but distant man who allows his spinster sister to run the household.  Nella is further shocked when her husband gifts her an extraordinary dollhouse, an exact miniature of their home.  She engages the services of a miniaturist to furnish the cabinet building, but when the artist sends items Nella didn't request the secrets of the Brandt household are slowly revealed.  Unfortunately, Nella isn't the only one who sees what the Brandts desperately seek to hide, and danger awaits them all if she can't decipher the warning sent by the miniaturist.Something about this novel just didn't work for me, but it took me a while to figure out what it was.  The setting is great.  The atmosphere is great.  Burton works magic with her words to bring the bustling streets and delicate work of the miniaturist to life.  I could picture everything perfectly, and I believed in her version of 17th century Amsterdam.  So that wasn't the problem.The miniaturist was a problem.  Throughout the book, Nella is fascinated by this mysterious woman who makes tiny dolls and objects that seem to predict the future.  Nella becomes convinced that the miniaturist is some sort of gifted prophetess.  The plot thread never really pays off.  By the end of the book, it seems as if every housewife in Amsterdam is obsessed with the artist, but so little is known about her that their attention seems unjustified.  The miniaturist remains elusive, and slips away leaving many questions and few answers.  It was unsatisfying.There's a lot of "oh look what a repressive society Amsterdam was" crammed into the story.  We have a closeted homosexual, a strong independent woman unable to fulfill her desires to run a business and travel the world, an interracial relationship kept hidden, more backlash about women distinguishing themselves outside the home, a secret lovechild, and more.  It seems hard to believe that so many current social issues could converge in a single 17th century household.  At times, all the secrets and drama gives the book the feel of a soap opera.  Some quick Googling shows that some of the stranger events, like a ban on gingerbread baked in the shape of men, really did happen, but events had to be moved around freely in time to create the boiling stew of Burton's Amsterdam.In the end, I found the book to be merely OK.  While some of the descriptions of food or Amsterdam life were beautiful, the unrelenting drama mixed with characters either too predictable or too mysterious left me struggling to finish the book. People looking for art-themed historical fiction sent in this time period will be much happier with Tracy Chevalier's Girl With a Pearl Earring: A Novel.

I ordered a pair of white gold stud earrings so that the metal would match my wedding ring. Since I wear a lot of pearl necklaces, I've been looking for a nice pair of earrings that could tie together the necklace with the sparkle of diamonds.  These earrings looked like just the thing!The earrings were very well packaged.  They came in a black velvet box, which is further protected by a white cardboard box.  So each pair should arrive in perfect condition.When I first opened the box I was pleased by the quality of the earrings. Each earring post was firmly attached to the earring, and the post was straight. On a lot of cheaper earrings I purchased, the posts are applied crooked. The backs don't slide around or slip off, so the earrings should stay in place all day.Shell pearls don't have the shine and luster of real pearls, but for inexpensive costume jewelry they work just fine.  The pearls here are the perfect size for stud earrings - not so small that you can't see them, but not so large that they look heavy and overwhelm the surrounding cubic zirconia gemstones.  The sparkle from the gems and the gleam from the pearl work together beautifully.I would definitely buy more earrings by Orrous & Co, because the quality is great and the price is affordable.I received these earrings in exchange for an honest review.

The earrings were very well packaged.  They came in a black velvet box, which is further protected by a white cardboard box.  So each pair should arrive in perfect condition.When I first opened the box I was a little disappointed by the quality of the earrings. One earring hook was bent to the left, and the excellent packaging could only lead me to conclude that it had left the factory that way, as the damage could not have happened during shipping.  I was able to push the earring back into the proper shape pretty easily, but it makes me a little nervous that the earrings can be misshapen so easily.  The hooks are also slightly smaller than the standard size.Each pair of earrings shipped with small rubber backing pieces provided to help secure the earrings, but I never use these since I've never had a problem with hook earrings falling out.  But for those who like them, the backs are included.Shell pearls don't have the shine and luster of real pearls, but for inexpensive costume jewelry they work just fine.  The size of these pearls was just perfect - they aren't so large they look gaudy, but they are big enough that you can appreciate the drop design.  I like the subtle, classic style, and the accent of a single crystal is perfect.I received these earrings in exchange for an honest review.

The earrings were very well packaged.  They came in a black velvet box, which is further protected by a white cardboard box.  So each pair should arrive in perfect condition.When I first opened the box I was pleased by the quality of the earrings. Each earring hook was firmly attached to the earring, and the front was also decorated with four accent stones so that it became part of the design instead of just a bit of wire keeping the earring in place.  There were small rubber backing pieces provided to help secure the earrings, but I never use these since I've never had a problem with hook earrings falling out.  But for those who like them, the backs are included.I really liked the crown design.  I had ordered the white gold version of these pearl drop earrings to wear as part of a Renaissance costume, and they were perfect.  I was surprised by the density of the shell pearls, but even after wearing the earrings all day they didn't feel heavy at all.  They don't have the shine and luster of real pearls, but most people can't see the difference, especially at a distance.I would definitely buy more earrings by Orrous & Co, because the quality is great and the price is affordable.I received these earrings in exchange for an honest review.

The earrings came very well packaged.  They came in a black velvet box, which is further protected by a white cardboard box.  So each pair should arrive in perfect condition.I ordered a pair of white gold cubic zirconia studs because the metal and stones would match my diamond wedding ring.  When I first opened the box I was pleased by the quality of the earrings. Each earring post was firmly attached to the earring, and the post was straight.  On a lot of cheaper earrings I purchased, the posts are applied crooked.  The backs don't slide around or slip off, so the earrings should stay in place all day.Even better, the earrings look great!  From a distance, the metal and the gems look a perfect match to my wedding ring, and even up close it's hard to tell a difference unless you're an expert on gemstones.  I would happily buy more earrings by Orrous & Co, because the quality is great and the price is affordable.I received these earrings in exchange for an honest review.

Helga Estby, a Norwegian immigrant living in Washington in the late 1890s, was mired in debt and her family of nine were in danger of losing their home when a mysterious sponsor offered her $10,000 if she and her daughter could walk across the United States, from their home in Eastern Washington to a New York City newspaper office, to prove that women were capable of surviving the trek.  Desperate to earn the prize and save her family’s farm, Estby agrees.  She and her eldest daughter set off on the adventure of a lifetime as the rest of the family stays behind.  However, things go terribly wrong, and Estby is unable to return home to her other children.  As tragedy mounts at home, her children become so resentful that after their mother returns, her great journey is never spoken of again, hushed up for generations.  When chance led Linda Lawrence Hunt to hear of Estby’s extraordinary journey, she threw herself into reconstructing the story of Helga and Clara Estby, the first two women to successfully cross the American continent on foot.Two stories unfold here.  The first is the biography of Helga as wife, mother and adventurer, a tale of a brave woman willing to sacrifice much to get the money her family so desperately needs.  Following the railroad tracks so that they wouldn’t get lost, Helga and Clara could only carry a few supplies and had to work along the way to pay for food and lodging.  As word spread of their attempt, people would buy photographs of the adventurers and leave water by the train tracks to sustain the women.  No one thought that they would succeed in their adventure, especially not in the deadline set by the contest’s sponsor.  Unfortunately, events spiral out of control and Helga and Clara are left stranded in New York City.  It’s heartbreaking that no one is willing to help them get home, not the newspapers who were so keen to publicize their adventure or the sponsor who lured them across the country in the first place.The second story is the tragedy that so many amazing stories like Helga’s slide into history forgotten because one generation refuses to discuss it.  In Helga’s case, the manuscript of her memoirs was destroyed by the children still angry that she abandoned them when she and Clara accepted the challenge.  Her grandchildren were only able to reconstruct fragments of the story.Hunt went to great lengths to reconstruct Helga’s life, but there are still great gaps.  Details are scarce about the day-to-day life on the road, and Helga’s true worries and fears can only be guessed at since she and Clara presented mostly cheerful accounts to the newsmen they spoke with.  At times, Hunt seems to be projecting her ideas of Helga onto the story, casting her as a proto-feminist when the evidence of such leanings is quite thin.  But for the most part, she remains fairly neutral.  While clearly sympathetic to Helga’s choices and the rejection she faced when she returned to the Norwegian-American community, the inhabitants of which greatly disapproved her decision to leave her family, Hunt also takes care to show why her children were so justified in their life-long resentment toward their mother and how events shaped their situation.Hunt’s research was able to unveil more of Helga’s quest, which had been well-publicized in newspapers of the day, but the bare bones reconstruction only leaves the reader wanting more.  It may also spark a curiosity about one’s own family tree and the secrets hidden by past generations.  Although Helga Estby’s accomplishments were quickly forgotten in her own lifetime, they are still worth remembering today.

Like any set of short essays, Ray Waddles' collection in "Undistorted Gods" has its hits and its misses.  Each chapter explores some aspect of God as interpreted through Waddles' experiences.  In the best essays, Waddles taps into something universal, a part of the shared experience of humanity that helps reveal the ethereal and holy hidden in every day life.  In the worst, it's glorified naval-gazing.My favorite essay was "Rhythm of God: Mystery Tour".  In this piece, Waddles describes the cultural revolution of the 1960s, in which secular culture became the new focal point of American life, replacing church through mediums like rock 'n' roll music.  As part of the essay, he compares the deep emotional impact of music and of Christianity, comparing how each helps a person form a 'soul'.  It was an excellent parallel exploration.But other chapters were very much focused on Waddles' personal experiences, and these just couldn't capture my interest.  I think he meant to illustrate just some of the many ways that spiritual moments can happen, but something was lost in the process of committing the ineffable moment  to paper.

I had a bit of trouble getting into this one.  Usually, I'm a big fan of retellings of mythology and fairy tales, so when I was offered Odysseus: The Oath I jumped at the chance to pick it up.  I found the beginning of the book very disjointed as it jumped through Odysseus' childhood, and it made it a little difficult to really feel absorbed into the world of Ancient Greece.The text is easy to read, but at times the dialogue can be very stilted. I don't know if that's a translation issue - the book was originally written in Italian - or just Manfredi's style, but the conversations often didn't flow like natural speech.  But that's OK - there's plenty of adventure and action to keep the story moving through Odysseus' life as he crosses paths with Hercules, Achilles, and his future wife Penelope.The story ends with the Trojan War.  Osysseus' adventures continue in Odysseus: The Return.

I love food, but when it comes to cooking I'm a pretty lazy chef so any time I see a cookbook that will help simplify the preparation process, I can't resist it.  The recipes in this book were easy to follow.Some recipes are divided in two: "To Prep/To Store" and "To Finish and Serve".  I really liked having the recipes broken down like this.  On a day when I have a spare hour, I can do all of the prep work.  The food is then ready in the fridge and in 10-15 minutes I can finish the recipe and serve it to my husband and myself.Other sections had meals designed to be both cooked and served on the same day. Some had fast prep times but slow cooking, like baked potato dishes, while others were recipes that could be prepared relatively quickly (pork tacos in half an hour, anyone?).But the emphasis is on doing lots of prep work when you have the time so that you can finish the meal in a rush.  If the problem you have is lack of time, most of the recipes in here aren't all that quick once you account for the prep time.  It's definitely not a "30 minute meals" sort of cookbook.  Even though I'm intrigued by many of the recipes, I still haven't found the time to try them.  However, the dishes I've prepared tasted great so I'm confident that when I finally have the time, I'll enjoy the other recipes, too.

The map reproductions are fantastic, and each page is filled with historical information that introduces the map's creator and the discoveries or major cultural movements that influenced the maps' design.  Each map also has a "visual tour" made up of close-up photos so that readers can better explore and appreciate the details of each map.  It's a wonderful resource, inspiring to artists, historians and anyone curious about how our perspective on the world has changed.

To the French, she spoke to angels, leading their troops to victory over impossible odds.  To the English, she was a witch communing with demons. Few women have captured the public imagination like Joan of Arc.  Countless artists in paintings, books, and movies have explored her life, asking whether she was divinely inspired or schizophrenic, a nave peasant or a calculating warrior.  In each retelling, her legend is embellished and enlarged.  In this latest biography, Kathryn Harrison combines history, folklore, scripture, and scholarly interpretation of Joan’s deeds to create Joan so mythological in scope that her life can be compared to only one other: that of Jesus Christ himself.It’s an unexpected comparison, Joan of Arc and Christ of Nazareth.  The first time Harrison brought it up, I thought she was stretching credulity.  But as the pages went by, and the parallels continued to manifest, I began to agree with her observations.  Whether Joan of Arc intentionally patterned her life after the Gospel accounts of Jesus’ ministry, or her chroniclers structured it that way after her death, or it was all mere coincidence, her narrative mirrors that of Christ in a way most befitting of a Holy Maid.That’s only one aspect of this dense biography.  Kathryn Harrison’s account also weaves together the many fictional Joans that have appeared in the works of Mark Twain, Voltaire, George Bernard Shaw, Robert Bresson, and other artists, revealing what each version said about the time in which she was created. Their fictional words are used to give voice to the thoughts unrecorded by the historic Joan as the book moves through her life.  Yet Harrison also takes care to distinguish the historical facts about Joan, clearly delineating where fiction ends and history takes over to reveal the brave, defiant girl who lived in the 15th century.So it’s a historical biography.  It’s a biography of Joan’s life after death, the evolution of her story through the centuries as it passed through poets and painters and writers.  It’s a critical interpretation of her life and its parallels to Jesus Christ, a spiritual biography of the young woman in communication with angels.  Joan of Arc shines with the powerful faith, courage, confidence, and cleverness that has made her so captivating to so many different audiences.

I always feel a bit nervous when I use Vitamin C products. I have drier skin and there have been times when Vitamin C serums suck every last drop of moisture out of my skin.  Luckily, I didn't experience any such problems with Oz Natural's Vitamin C Serum.The serum is very thin and watery, which makes it easy to apply.  Just apply a few drops and let them dry - it soaks in very quickly so this step doesn't take long at all.Then proceed on to your usual moisturizer.I didn't notice an immediate change the first day or two, but after about a week my skin was definitely looking brighter.  My pores were much less clogged, too.  (I don't know if that is an effect of using a serum much lighter than my previous one, or the direct result of one of the ingredients in the Oz Naturals formula.)So how long does each bottle last?  For me, about two months when I used it once per day.  A little serum really goes a long way!I received a sample of the serum in exchange for an honest review of my experiences with it.

The story of Rapunzel is reinvented in Bitter Greens, interwoven with the story of Charlotte-Rose de la Force, the French woman responsible for recording the version of the fairy tale known around the world today.  As Charlotte-Rose stews in a convent where she was banished by the King of France, one of the nuns entertains her by sharing a story about a powerful sorceress in Venice who imprisoned young women in a tower so that she could draw their life force and attain eternal youth. Charlotte-Rose also muses over her lost life at the French court, her failed romances and constant struggle to afford the lavish lifestyle required to keep up with her fellow courtiers.  As the two parallel stories unfold, the common threads of desire, love, and black magic bind them together.Half of this book is brilliant.  This is one of the best reinventions of a fairy tale that I’ve read in a long time. I love Forsyth’s conception of the witch and how she integrated the character into 16th century Venetian society.  Rapunzel – called Margherita – is sold to the witch by her parents and trapped in a doorless tower.  Her imprisonment is very realistic and her struggle to make her food stores and other supplies last between visits from the witch really drive home the character’s desperate situation.  A gristly discovery in the bottom of the tower further reveals the witch’s obsession with youth and the great lengths she will go to keep it.I love the Rapunzel story.The part that doesn’t work as effectively is the life of Charlotte-Rose de la Force.  While the author of “Persinette”, forerunner of “Rapunzel”, was surely an interesting woman, the frequent detours into her life seem disruptive and tend to really slow down the pace.  Each time she appears, we’re introduced to a new cast of historical figures, and keeping track of the rapidly expanding cast can be challenging after an extended detour into the secondary Rapunzel plot.  Charlotte-Rose’s life also has the chaotic habit of jumping around in time, further adding to the confusion.Still, it’s an enjoyable novel – one of the best I’ve read this year, in fact.  I would definitely recommend it for the revision of the Rapunzel story – if you don’t like historical fiction set in the French court, just skip those chapters completely.  But if you are curious about the life and love affairs of the French poet and authoress Charlotte-Rose de la Force, the way her life is integrated with the work for which she is best known today is a truly lovely accomplishment.

In a desperately impoverished village, Elena Rudina struggles to feed her sick mother.  Her father is dead; her brothers driven away by poverty and the demands of the Tsar.  With no food and allies in the same pathetic position, Elena has little hope of improving her situation.  Then a train breaks down in town, and Elena catches the attention of Ekaterina - "Cat" for short - the wealthy girl being brought by her great aunt to the Tsar's grand ball.  After a sudden accident, the two girls find their roles reversed.  Elena impersonates Cat and settles into a life of luxury while the former princess struggles through the rough life of a Russian peasant child.  Events are thrown into further chaos when Cat stumbles across the lair of Baba Yaga and they discover that one of Russia's great magical beings, the Firebird, has gone missing.  This disaster threatens to unravel Russian and unseat the Tsar if they cannot locate and restore the missing bird, setting in motion a great quest that will either save Russia or destroy the world.Combining The Prince and the Pauper with traditional Russian folklore, Maguire crafts a modernist fairy tale immersed in the weight and beauty of Russia tradition.  This world is one where a house can walk on chicken feet, an enormous dragon sleeps trapped in ice, and matryoshka dolls come to life to dance with toy soldiers.  The trademark lyricism and precision of word choice that hallmarks his writing is in full force, and it suits the fairy tale atmosphere very, very well.  The only nod to modernity is the wise-cracking Baba Yaga, who exists out of sync with time and constantly slips anachronistic slang into her speech.  She's a bit weird and unhinged, but would you want her any other way?  Of course not.The story is narrated by a monk, imprisoned by the Tsar for a crime left unrevealed until near the end of the novel.  He makes little comments and observations to the reader, comparing the lives of Elena and Cat to traditional Russian folklore and his own life experiences.  It honestly doesn't add much flavor or character to the narrative.  No, the monk's asides merely slow the pacing in key scenes in a manner distracting rather than dramatic.If given a choice between reading the novel traditionally on paper or listening to it via audio book, please do yourself a favor and go with the novel.  I read the first few chapters and quite enjoyed them, but when I spotted the audio CDs at the library I decided to check them out so I could listen to the story on the road.  While I'm sure narrator Michael Page will entertain small children with his flamboyant, energetic performance it comes off as too silly and cartoon-like to work for an adult listener.  I ended up going back to the print story because I just couldn't take his strange theatrics.Poor narrator choices aside, it's a decent adventure story.  I enjoyed it far more than Maguire's Wicked series.  The two girls are very realistic, created with the prejudices and attitudes appropriate to their class and then forced to grow beyond their normal boundaries.  Baba Yaga is always entertaining, and her magical world melds so seamlessly in the wild Russian woods with the "real" world that you do end up believing, if only for a few minutes, in ice dragons and firebirds.

In the summer of 1905, entrepreneur Truman Hunt offered 51 members of the Igorrotes the opportunity of a lifetime: come to the United States and make a fortune teaching Americans about the lifestyle of a primitive tribe from the Philippines.  They agreed, and in a few months the Igorrote group was a headline attraction in Luna Park at Coney Island.  At first, things seemed to go well: the Igorrotes built a village like the one they’d left behind and performed the rituals of their tribe before an appreciative audience.  But as time passed, it became clear that Hunt was exploiting the tribe, refusing to pay their wages and constantly uprooting them as he landed bigger contracts with other theme parks.  After charges of bigamy brought the eye of the law upon him, Hunt split up the tribe and took their show on the road, often housing the Igorrote in appalling conditions.  Fearing an international incident, the US government became determined to track him down, but Hunt proved to be a surprisingly cunning and slippery adversary.The exploitation faced by the Igorrotes would be unthinkable today, and it’s shocking to read just how desperate their situation was.  Not only were they unfamiliar with American manners and faced with the racism of 19th century culture, only one member of the tribe spoke English fluently.  Hunt withheld their wages, claiming he would pay them when they were ready to return to the Philippines – but despite their desperate pleading he refused to arrange return passage for any of them.  If they managed to hide some cash from him – visitors would often gift them with coins or pay them for small handcrafted goods – Hunt was not above beating the Igorrotes until he found their hidden stash of coins.  Without federal intervention, he likely would have worked them to death, or abandoned them when their sideshow ceased to draw in the crowds.Hunt himself seems to have been a classic huckster.  Before he brought the Igorrote over to the United States, he had a great reputation in the Philippines.  Hunt was known to be a benevolent doctor who helped care for the natives.  But once he got them over here, he fed outrageous lies to the newspapers to drum up business for his “savages” and made a mockery of some of the Igorrotes’ customs.  One of the passages that really stuck with me was one describing the Igorrote asking Hunt to please reduce the number of “dog feasts” that they must celebrate, as the frequency of the practice seemed disrespectful of their culture and they wanted to go back to their traditional diet.  He refused because the dog feasts were a huge crowd pleaser.  Worse, Hunt spent his money quickly and lavishly, and was often in debt.  If he had wanted to pay the Igorrotes their wages, he lacked the financial means to do so, even though they were the most popular attraction on Coney Island and making money hand over fist.The story of the Igorrote is largely forgotten today, but this obscure history makes for fascinating reading.  A tale of true crime and cultural exploitation, "The Lost Tribe of Coney Island" it was one of the most interesting things I read in 2014.

I like this product because it solves a problem in my home. However, I do have some concerns. This is very easy to install on furniture. Reading the directions you heat the plastic so that you can mold it to the furniture where you need protection. The included screws/pins are inserted into the holes around the plastic and screw into the furniture to hold the protective sheet in place. I had to do several adjustments to make sure this was held securely in place and this is where I ran into a problem. My cat was curious about this when I placed it on the edge of the couch where he likes to scratch. He immediately started chewing on the screws and was able to manipulate them out slightly and I was concerned he would remove it completely and could possible harm himself by swallowing the sharp screw or possibly choking. I removed the screws one at a time and screwed them back in making sure they were all screwed until they were lying flat/flush with the couch. Once I did that my cat could not chew them to get them out.If you have a curious cat/dog/animal watch them carefully when you first install this in your home. It does work as intended and is protecting my furniture well but there were some concerns about safety.I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

Love these socks. I'm wearing a pair now with a black pair of ballet flats and black trousers. These are a little thicker than trouser socks but thin enough to wear with flats. I like them because they keep my feet warmer than trouser socks but are still appropriate to wear to work and if I head to the gym after work I can wear these with my sneakers. They don't fall down/off the back of my heel and are comfortable at the toe. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

This wrist support brace provides excellent stabilization and support for the wrist. I have the Right hand/medium and it fit my wrist well. This support provides several means of adjustment to ensure a proper fit. When wearing it is not too hot or tight and I felt I was able to move my fingers without too much movement at the wrist. There is a fixed support on the underside (I'm assuming it's some type of metal or hard plastic) that holds the wrist in a natural position while preventing much movement. I was able to put this on my right wrist by myself with my non dominant hand easily. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

The first time I used this I noticed my skin immediately felt soft and plump. I wanted to keep touching my face because it felt so nice. As I've continued to use this for the past week I've noticed my skin is much more hydrated and the flakiness I had around my nose has disappeared. I use about half a dropper full in the evening after I wash my face and before I use my regular moisturizer. I don't rub it in all the way, I leave it still moist and it dries quickly. I have had no adverse reactions to this Vitamin C serum. This has little to no scent and once applied there is no smell at all. I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest review.

This stuff is great. It's a thick, creamy consistency that really sticks to your hair in the shower. I glop a bunch of this on my hair and pile it on top of my head to let it sit for a few minutes in the shower. It smells nice too. It rinses out easily and leaves my hair feeling soft and smooth and the smell lingers around which I love. I've used this several times in the shower and my curly hair is much more manageable after using this. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

I've been using this water bottle for a few weeks now. I really like that the main bottle is glass. I'm really sensitive to smells and plastic water bottles tend to retain smells after a while so I like that this has no smell or odor. The bottom is covered with a rubber/plastic material that is easy to grip and provides some protection from bumps and short drops to keep the bottle from cracking or breaking. I also like the handle for carrying. What I don't like is the top. It doesn't screw on well. If you screw it too far it just pops off. When opening the top to drink the entire lid will pop off if you're not careful. Once the lid is on it doesn't leak but it's easy to pull the lid off. The mouthpiece is fine but if you're trying to get a big drink of water the other side of the bottle will bump your nose. Overall I like it and will continue to use this but it does take some practice to keep from popping off the lid. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

Perfect little sewing kit. I am very busy and constantly on the go. After more than a handful of times I wished I had a sewing kit with me I now have added this to my emergency kit in my car. I work two jobs and am always dressed in business attire so if I get a hole or snag or just a loose thread on my clothing I need to mend it asap. This little sewing kit is the perfect size to keep in my car for little accidents and emergencies. I'm not going to be hemming my pants with this but to sew a button or stitch a hole in my shirt this does the trick. There is enough variety in thread color to closely match just about anything I might be wearing. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

I spent a summer in the south of France. I picked lavender from the plant and saw dried lavender in every fashion in quaint little markets. I know what lavender smells like and this lotion captures the smell of genuine lavender perfectly. Closing my eyes I'd swear I was back in France. If you're using lavender to help your children sleep you're going to love this. It's moisturizing and has a light formula so it won't feel heavy or greasy on your skin. I think the smell could be overwhelming so only a little bit is needed. I would combine this with another cream, the unscented Puracy moisturizer is excellent. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest feedback.

This is a great hoodie. I love the heathered black color and the fabric feels very soft. It's not a lightweight yet not heavy weight, I guess that leaves midweight. The fabric does not have much stretch to it so definitely order up a size or even two if you want it baggy. The sizing seems more inline with juniors/young men's sizing. I like the sleeve length, they're long enough to reach a bit beyond the wrist. The overall length is average, it hits at about hip length. The waist on this tapers in so if you're wide around the middle, again, you'll want to size up at least one size. This would be great for working out but is also stylish enough for casual wear. I received a discount on this garment in exchange for my honest review.

Why did I ever start playing this game? I now play it on several different devices and facebook. I can't help but play to try to get ahead of my friends. I'll get stuck on a level and then finally beat it and breeze through several levels only to get stuck again. This game is highly addictive and a lot of fun. I don't ever spend money in these apps. I just keep playing until I beat a level or give it a break for a few weeks and then continue playing. I like playing this on my kindle fire because it's easier to see where pieces are playing than when I play on my phone. Love this game.

This is awesome. I have a cat and he's a character. He's young and mischievous and very energetic at all times. When I first brought him into my home he made a mess around the litter box. Every time I filled the box with fresh litter he would kick it out of the box making a huge mess to clean up. Now that I've added this around the box I'm not as concerned with litter being everywhere because it's much easier to clean up. This also catches all the litter that gets stuck in his paws and prevents my cat from tracking litter all over my house. It's a very large size. First, the hat itself is large and even on an adult would be a baggy/loose style. I actually like that so it's not an issue for me, this would also work well for someone with a large head. The material is soft and stretchy and even after wearing a while is still comfortable. Okay, so now on to the technology. There is a speaker on each side of the hat around where your ears are so you can hear the sound fairly well. I like that the sound isn't in my ear like and earbud so I can still hear what's going on around me when I'm out walking. I didn't have any issues getting the bluetooth to sync with my phone so I could listen to my music. The controls aren't overly bulky on the side and blend in well with the style of the hat. I really like that I can leave my phone safely in my pocket or purse without having the earbud strings hanging out making me a target for theft. This would make a great gift for someone that commutes via public transportation or someone that enjoys being active in the colder months. I received this product in exchange for my honest feedback. I am happy to discuss my experience with this product if you have any questions.

I have curly hair that just drinks up anything I put in it so I need a lot of moisture for my hair. I use conditioner and leave in conditioner and creams and lotions but sometimes I need something with a little more oompf. That's where hair masks and treatments come in and this is a very nice one. I like the consistency of this one; it's a cross between jello and a thick cream. It sticks to my hair once applied and I love applying it then adding heat from my hair dryer ( outside of the shower of course). That added heat really makes my hair feel amazingly soft and moisturized. I actually like using this several times per week. There is a scent to this but it doesn't last after it's rinsed out. The scent is floral/perfume but not too strong. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my unbiased review.

This is a wonderful assortment of essential oil blends. Each one is a unique blend for different purposes. I like the Mellow Mind blend the best. I have it in my desk drawer at work and take a few whiffs when my day gets hectic or I'm stressed. The Dreamy Sleep is very nice as well, relaxing. The Tropical Paradise would be perfect to use the scent your home in the summer time. These would also make a nice gift for just about anyone. I purchased 4 of these to use for my cat. He's picky about the dishes he'll eat out of and he likes these. They aren't too deep so it's easy for him to get all the food from the bottom. I spend almost my entire day sitting on my behind. I work two jobs at two different offices and each has a chair that is supposed to be supportive and comfortable but neither truly are. Over time the chairs sink and sag and are not supportive which causes me to fidget all day and leads to a sore back and even my legs start to feel like jello. As soon as I placed this in my office chair I felt immediate relief. I even sat up straighter. No more sinking into my seat and discomfort in my back and legs. The cushion arrived in a nice carrying bag. The fabric is very soft and the interior material is squishy but supportive. It's not as thick as other cushions I've used but it is comfortable. Time will tell if it will hold up to hours and hours of use everyday but for the time being my back and legs are much happier. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

This is something everyone should have in their bathroom because at some point you're going to need it. Whether you suffer from occasional blemishes or black heads or white heads this is something that you'll appreciate. Squeezing and popping blemishes with your fingers and fingernails can introduce bacteria into the skin causing infections and pain and even worse blemishes - no one wants that. These can be sterilized between uses to keep your face clean and improve the appearance. There are different tools for different uses but they're all easy to use. I use some more than others but I use this mostly for black and white heads, especially on and around my nose. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

I've been using this for several weeks. My skin feels amazingly soft and firm throughout the day. I haven't experienced any oiliness in my skin since using this, in fact my skin seems to be less oil. I love how hydrated my face feels and it looks noticeably brighter. There is plenty in the jar to last beyond  a month because it only takes a little to moisturize the entire face. Now, the smell of this is not pleasant. It's not terrible but there is a definite odor to this when you first apply but it disappears shortly thereafter. I would highly recommend this for oily, dry, or combination skin. You will notice a difference after just one use of this. I received this product in exchange for my unbiased review.

These are the greatest covers for outside patio chairs.  I have 3 of these and from the nip in the air , I got them not a minute too soon.  These are made from heavy duty materials and have a waterproof coating  plus tie downs so you can anchor them to the actual chair.  In my case, this veranda chair cover was so commodious I have been able to put my 4 upright chairs under with plenty of protective covering.  These are so handy because now I don't have to stack and tape down tarps to protect things from the winter to come.They remove in a snap, allowing me to hook them over the back of the chair and put them back on with a minimum of fuss.  Obviously this Veranda chair size can be used for more than one chair  as I have done or just cover one very large chair.  I think these are a good investment as they will last many years and will extend the life of my patio furniture.  A good value and price.

This is an eye catching, sparkling focal point to your yard.  It arrives flat but you can gently move the butterflies to assist in better catching the wind.  As the predominant colors are blues , it looks great in my bed of amorpha canescens ( Leadplant) and the sparkle on the butterflies certainly makes you notice it.  The figures are a bit sharp on the edge and are fairly fragile so be careful when you move the butterflies.I like this sculpture but it is a bit small for my garden.  I am limited in where I can put it due to the gravel.  This is a good price on this and in the right place, it will look fabulous.

From the first page to the last, this book keeps you turning pages.  I loved it and while I had never read this author before, I will definitely remedy that situation.  It's London and England in 1876, where the city and its social circles are abuzz with the mysterious  disappearance of the German pianist Muller.  Charles Lenox and his detective agency are called in by the police to figure out how the pianist vanished without anyone seeing him leave the Theatre.In the meantime Charles' brother Edmund is despondent over the recent death of his beloved wife Molly. Charles feels that his duty is to be with Edmund so he hands over the job of finding Muller to his partners in the agency and travels down to Markethouse. Strange things are happening in Markethouse however.  Small thefts of chickens, blankets and even a spaniel occur and Charles is off on the hunt.  Suddenly the district insurance agent Hadley sees a shadowy face in his window, finds that his house has been gone through by persons unknown and a strange drawing is chalked on his doorstep.This is a riveting tale that kept me up late on more than one night.  Try this one!

I have dry skin and I live in a dry climate so washing my face with soap is out.  I've tried various creams and lotions but most are so very messy and to look at my washcloth afterward, you'd think I'd been wallowing in grime. I decided to ditch the washcloth and see if these wipes would be a good alternative.  They certain are preferable when you are traveling and can't haul a wet washcloth everywhere you go.I like these!  After using them my skin doesn't feel tight, something that has happened with other cleaning products.  The price is reasonable and you can flush them away rather than having to wash and rewash.I travel a lot and in many countries wash cloths aren't provided so I find these the perfect solution.  You aren't reintroducing previous grime to your complexion as you do with a washcloth and once you use them, you pitch them.  I will definitely keep these in the suitcase for my next trip in January and now would like to try other Simple products.  Thank you, Simple ,for being just that.

The more I wear this watch the more I like it.  This is a good choice if you like the style, and need nothing more from a watch than time.Compared with my usual Casio watch, this one feels substantially heavier and will no doubt be more rugged.  So far, the face and links have resisted scratches nicely (a weak point with lighter watches).The style is straightforward and legible, with a solid classic look.This watch has limited functionality -- it tells time, and that's about it (in combination with a smart phone, it may be all you need).  The owner's manual is equally limited, and most of it discussed a higher end, multi-function watch.  You may need to have a jeweler remove the extra links.
Far too predictable.
Merrill is making a whole series of the All Out.... and with problem feet I am very happy with them.  I wish that more stores in our region carried these.

This stuff is fantastic.  I live at 6500 ft in a very dry climate and this stuff makes my face feel supple rather than dry and tight. My dry lines have mitigated and I go through about 1 jar of this a month.
I got bored 1/2 way through and didn't finish it.

This product is an entry level offering for live voice use. Three microphones are packaged in a sturdy plastic carrying case, lined with foam. The list price is a very reasonable $59.00, so at less than $20 per microphone, with stand adapter, this is an exceptional deal from a name maker of audio recording equipment.The good:+ PRICE!+ Nice, hefty metal body which feels substantial, but not heavy, in the hand.+ Covers the vocal range adequately+ Responds to low end equalization from a Mackie 1202 mixing panel+ Output is on par with other well-known dynamic stage microphones+ Mic body is a reasonably standard dimension, so this mic can interchange with many others from E-V, Sennheiser, AKG, Shure in a stand adapter.The bad:- Needs low end equalization to avoid boom.- Does not respond as well to low EQ compared to AKG D5- Does not have quite the range as the AKG D5- Midrange not as clear as AKG D5- diaphragm frame was slightly loose on each unit.The comparison of the CAD D38 ($20) with the AKG D5 ($100) may be a bit unfair to the D38, but it suggests how this product stacks up to an industry standard. While the D5 is the obvious choice where it can be afforded, the D38 serves a lower end purpose better (stage announcement, live performance through PA, entry level band rehearsal and performance, etc.) due to its affordability. I cannot comment on durability since I have not had them for long, but they appear rugged and well made.

I am hooked on this author's works.  They are like being in southern France and are a wonderful window into that world.  The stories revolve around the life and activities of Bruno, the chief and only policeman in the small southern French town of St. Denis.  This author has written 8 of these adventures and all are topical themes reflected in today's news.  The last mystery dealt with islamic terrorists while this one begins with the lavish birthday celebration of Bruno's childhood hero, national famous World War 2 flying ace, Marco Desaix.  Thrown into the mix is conflict between animal rights advocate and the local hunters,along with corrupt politicians both national and international.  Add a pinch of international ( read Russian) intrigue and you have a volatile mix guaranteed to keep you turning pages.Martin Walker knows his stuff being a senior member of a private think tank in Washington D.C and an international affairs columnist for UPI.  These are a great read, fast paced and believable not to mention the cooking recipes that are thrown in...  Now, darn it, I have to wait another year for the next one!  drat!

This is a very handy sunscreen in a stick, easy to carry and  easy to apply.  Obviously I am not a toddler but I seem to be very sensitive to whatever is in most commercial sunscreens except for some of the ones formulated for children.  Since I am a big fan of Burt's Bees products I thought that I would give this a try.  This application stick is a good size that fits neatly into most pockets and it goes on very smoothly which makes for less fuss in usage.  There is no chemical smell as there is in many products and I find that it is kind to the skin.  All in all, what's not to like with this product.

Another five-star vote for this grand book about Capt Robert Trimble, a WWII bomber pilot who "just wanted to fly airplanes," and took an assignment perhaps even harder than his bomber duties: retrieving American planes which had landed in Soviet territory, and then rescuing allied POW's from former Nazi-controlled prisons which came under control of the advancing Soviet "allies."  Trimble used creativity, hard work, courage, and dedication "beyond the call of duty." He risked his life, sanity, and reputation to bring his charges home from the terrors of war (including death threats from the Soviets) and the diplomatic indifference of the US government.  The book also provides a unique perspective into the start of the Cold War, in the very territory where it began as the US and the USSR shifted from informal allies to formal adversaries. Finally, it helps explain why some children of WWII combat veterans may feel their fathers were distant and reluctant to dwell on their past.The book combines excellent story-telling with an emotional flavor which helps us understand what Trimble experienced. The author combined personal interviews with Trimble (his dad), archival research into incidents associated with his dad's career, and editing by Mr Dronfield.  For most of his life, the author thought of his dad as an ordinary (if often indifferent) father. When his dad finally communicated his experiences (which were verified by research), he emerged as a hero with a story worth telling. Trimble suffered from post-event trauma, not only witnessing unspeakable atrocities as a young man, but also feeling guilty he could not rescue even more people than he did. Because of this trauma, his dad nearly committed suicide before the author was even born.  When Trimble finally began talking about his experiences (which were verified by research), his son understood his reticence.The book's remarkable, uplifting epigraph relates how Trimble was recognized for his valor and his humaneness in a way that ordinary medals cannot do, and how he finally opened to his children.

First, the proviso: your  experiences may not duplicate ours, or anyone else's, for this or any supplement reviewed on the web. Use precautions about web reviews, individual side effects or unexpected results, etc. and don't expect research to show any supplement is as good as the body's own natural melatonin. That said ...Our two testers were indeed happy with this product -- this worked well  They say you are getting old if a good night's sleep is more appealing than a good night partying, but good sleep is a precious gift!  One of us is a small person and found the full dosage too strong so half a capsule gave a very good night's sleep, with a bit of hangover the next day but far less than with something like Ambien.  It calmed quite a bit so it isn't needed every night.  The ability to fall back asleep once awakened is priceless and this product does this very well.The other tester also had great results, which was unexpected, because he previously found Melatonin made returning to sleep difficult, and B vitamins increased his energy, so he was skeptical.  The first night he experienced incredibly vivid dreams but woke up well-rested with fewer morning aches and pains than normal, and was able to go on an extended hike without feeling tired or energy-depleted.  It was as if sleep became more relaxed and restorative. He said it was fantastic. Over the next few nights, he concluded it does not work like that every single night, and it works best when taken around the start of darkness, with a normal time for sleeping -- in other words, it doesn't seem to pack eight hours worth of sleep into six and won't compensate for too few hours, but that's "natural."  It does not seem to have a rebound effect -- when he stopped taking it, or took it for several nights in a row, it didn't make his sleep suffer. He found no "hangover" or morning drowsiness IF he gave himself at least seven hours of sleep.
