Now that he has tried it for a couple of weeks, it seems the effectiveness wears off with time (as does nearly anything with a subjective effect) but the product is worth considering for occasional use and it seems to do no harm.I'll be going overseas soon and will certainly take this with me to help with the effects of jet lag.  PS: It worked although it didn't knock me out like Ambien.We've tried it for two weeks. Yes, we bought this again and we will update this review if we find anything changes.

This is certainly the most entertaining theological reading I have done in a long time.  Nadia is funny and profanely profound at the same turn,  her feet are very firmly planted and she is very compassionate while saying that she isn't.  She has certainly been there and done that and her way of looking at Christianity is very appealing to a large number of folks who "don't do Theology".  Her honesty about her personal experiences, her weaknesses, and her beliefs come out clearly and resonate with a lot of common sense.  Obviously she is not your run of the mill preacher.I feel that those who are attracted to her probably don't want a lot of dry theology thrown in but should they want more than she has given  through personal experiences it would be nice to give readers somewhere else to turn for comfort and enlightenment.  Does she like C. S. Lewis? Might there be other theologians that readers could turn to, how about suggested readings.  I liked the discussion questions in the back and the conversation with the author but I feel that there should be more here, guidance, direction.All in all an excellent introductory book that will appeal to those beginning their search or those turned off by theology period.  She certainly makes the Christian experience very personal and appealing.  I hope she writes more.

These are very nice,  very smooth writing and soooo much better than the average ball point pen.  The ink flows well without being messy or bloty and they write over things like greasy areas without skipping.  I wanted these because I always have problems with pens on flights and I have the pocket marks to prove it.  The color is good and consistent and the point isn't bad although I would prefer a finer line.  All in all a good value for the money.

I plugged in my Apple 6 with an 18% charge using this cord instead of my normal one.  An hour and 1/2 later the phone 95% charged.  I was hoping that this lightening braided cable would cut the time to 1 hour.  My cable is just 6" long and it is a pain to use as by the time you get it plugged into the plug in socket, there isn't enough length for the phone/IPad to lie flat.  I don't have room beside my computer to attach the cable and place the phone/IPad to lie flat.  Do yourself a favor and get the longer cable to save the annoyance.  I was expecting better results.

Elliot Carlson has provided a well-documented, well-written examination describing one of WWII's major unsung heroes, Capt Joe Rochefort, and the war he fought against the Japanese and against Naval bureaucracy. As you can see from the many complimentary academic reviews, compared with the few reviews on Amazon, this is more a scholarly book than one for light reading although it's suitable for amateur historians who want a well-developed book on a focused subject. For example, a serious military officer or WWII buff should find this a wonderful way to spend a few hours!At a ceremony posthumously awarding Capt Rochefort the Distinguished Service Medal (the nation's second highest military honor), President Reagan noted "If ever there was a battle ... in which victory was attributable to one man, this one was attributable to Joseph J. Rochefort." The President referred to Rochefort's success leading Allied efforts to decipher Japan's "unbreakable" war code, which helped America win one of history's greatest battles, and was similar to the far better-publicized "breaking" of the German code by the Bletchley Park team. Rochefort's leadership and persistence saved many lives and altered the War's momentum.Rochefort was an unusual Navy officer:  he was not an Annapolis grad (he was not even a high school grad), he was a cryptographer when most fellow officers considered cryptographers strange or practically useless, he cultivated few influential friends but supported his staff tirelessly, he used an avuncular and supportive leadership rather than the strong-handed model the Navy favored at that time, and he was relatively humble in a world full of egos and strongly held opinions.  Nevertheless, the author makes it seem Rochefort always landed on his feet in a situation that truly mattered ("management of good luck"). As a consequence, he excelled at orchestrating a team of highly disparate cryptographers, mathematicians, linguists, cultural analysts, and ancillary staff with creativity and dedicated common sense. Rochefort commanded Station Hypo, which worked out of a clammy and disguised Pearl Harbor basement as his team painstakingly deciphered major parts of the Japanese strategic code. Hypo never really "broke" the code but they peered into it enough to give many priceless pieces of information -- including the Japanese decision to attack Midway Island as their next strategic target. Knowing this allowed the Navy to concentrate its force against an enemy which previously retained the element of surprise with its highly mobile carrier force.Carlson discusses two "wars" Rochefort fought. The first, of course, was the Pacific conflict. The second was the war with the Navy bureaucracy. Much of the book details the internal struggles which took so much of the time and effort that Rochefort should have been able to give to the Pacific war.  Of course, some of those struggles involved necessary (and useful) skepticism for Rochefort's conclusions by higher staff, but much was malicious and counterproductive stupidity by competing agencies.  This is among the first books I've read which goes into so much detail about the regrettable jockeying, turf establishment, stress generation, and backstabbing which can take place in a bureaucracy, even one fighting an active war against a common enemy. The bureaucratic battle often goes not to those who are right, but to those willing to put their own posture forward (including being adequately venal to those who prove them wrong), and sometimes, Rochefort was simply not self-serving enough to do this.Aside from minor glitches not worth mentioning, Carlson has done a thoroughly admirable job of gathering information about a shamefully obscure topic, organizing it well, and making it both educational and entertaining.  His book should prove interesting not only to military history aficionados, but to anyone who wants to observe the dark side of bureaucracy.

This is a lovely bag with a deep rich color and lovely to touch leather.  I have had 3 Le Donne bags and I recommend them.  They are what Coach used to be and at an affordable price.  That being said, I have returned this bag because of the pockets.  This bag has three lovely pockets but with an IPhone 6 I can tell you that none of the pockets fit it.  I tried our 5c ,same deal.  I wish they would upgrade the design by making the pockets bigger as they are well placed and would be so very convenient if they were larger.

I have been a nail biter all my life and have not been able to break the habit.  This stuff really gets my attention so I think it is working well.  I think it does promote nail growth and because it is a nail "polish"  you can't wash it off as had happened so many times when I try other preparations.  The taste will really get your attention and it lasts quite a while( 3-5 days) between applications.  My nails have a nice shine and hopefully I'll train myself to stop this awful habit.  I painted this on my cuticles as well and am pleased to see them starting to heal.All in all I recommend this.A down side is that if you are eating finger food you will taste it where the food comes in contact with your fingers.  I found that after I had used it a week, I could taste the flavor whether I had nibbled or not but I am willing to put up with this if it stops the habit.

Another five-star vote for this unusual story from a genre I'm unfamiliar with. An older man returns to a place which transformed his life when he was an unwanted and lonely child, and he becomes overwhelmed with intense memories he thinks he hasn't had in years. He also finds these memories may be inaccurate, after talking with those who were with him. The ocean forms part of his story, but it has little resemblance to the ocean we consider "normal."  The story ends well, but it ends as unusually as it began.In short, this is a very strange tale indeed, but it has a certain endearing quality that makes me quite happy I encountered it.  At least for now.

Best cushioning I can remember in an over-the-counter insole.  I have a neuroma which is annoying without the Spenco's.  The insole stays in place quite nicely, does not throw off the balance or shoe control, and is far better than the usual standard insole. They go well with my orthotics, and should work well if you have a thinner store-bought orthotic insole.  These can add a spring to your step and (possibly) years to your walking.

I have a love/hate relationship with this product.  I got it from the box and immediately tried it out on my IPhone.  It was lovely and no multiple letters etc which I have experienced with other stylus.  I then put it into one of the divided compartments of my purse, ready for my "typing" assignment.  I did not put the cap on the end...BIG mistake... because the next time I got it out to use, presto, no little disc on the end of the stylus and I can tell you that this lovely, light stylus DOESN'T work without the disc.  Sigh!  If there is a replacement disc in the cap end of this stylus, I can't get it out - have tried long needle, pin, and nothing.  Pity it doesn't come with a wee bag of replacement tips...which I will now go in search of as I really do like this and the feel but sans tip, it is useless.

My regular shaver is too bulky and delicate-looking for extended travel, so I took the HQ40 on a six-week trip. Its performance was surprisingly good -- has a good shave, is quiet, was kind to my face, contains the shaved hairs, cleans easily with a toothbrush and occasional disinfectant, and survived several hard re-packings and jostling without problems.  After six weeks it's on the same set of lithium AA's (you can also use rechargeable AA's).If you are on a budget or have light facial hair, you might consider this as an everyday shaver, although it's a dry shave only.My only qualms are the lack of a travel shut-off switch (I'd suggest packing with the "on" switch protected or putting some paper between the battery contacts so the power switch won't accidentally turn on), and the inability to trim sideburns.

I got this generator to provide supplemental power for our outdoor Jazz shows.  We needed more power than we were able to "borrow" from our building so this is perfect.  The only negative I have about this product is it's rather hefty price tag but it has so many amenities that I still give it 5 stars. Most generators are too heavy for me to lift, move etc but this one comes with its just like luggage trolley built in.  Look between the front wheels and you pull the handle out and you are set to go.  I tested this to see how much I could load on.  I plugged in a drill (5.4amp), a compressor (10.5 amp), a grinder (9 amps) and a sander (2.4 amps) and with a total of 27.4 amps I was still only at 75% capacity.This is the quietest generator I have ever experienced.  It is also the easiest generator to operate with no having to mix oil and gas although it does want premium grade,(91 Oct) and the fuel tank holds 1 1/2 gallons.  I had no trouble with the pull mechanism which is like a gas lawnmower and the owners manual is very good, unlike most that assume you already know it all.  This also has an auto battery charger with cables, a 220 adaptor and USB port coupled with a digital display showing hours of operation and % of capacity.  All in all this does everything I want, I can pull it to wherever I need it and  it is quiet....
this is a wonderful collection of English language prayers that just seem to flow beautifully.  I have to author prayers for various occasions and this hasn't failed me yet.
This is not the riveting read that his other books are.  He details the plans and tactics of WW2 but it isn't that riveting.  Borrow it from your library.
I will definitely continue to buy these.

This is a great stuffed animal!  George is well made and feels cuddly.  I think he is a good size for a 1-3 year old and is a wonderful tie in with the Rey books....a nice "Hook" to get kids reading these wonderful stories about this curious monkey.  George is fairly small but just right for the age groups that the Rey books appeal to.  Gund toys are well made, priced well and sturdy, with non removable clothing.  They have a lovely plushy feel, and even the outfits feel good.  You can't go wrong with fund and George is a natural.

I am a singer and always have a dry throat...what do you expect for having your mouth open for several hours and at 6500 ft?  After several hours of singing, I had problems with dry throat so when I found this, I thought it was worth a try.  I have tried cough drops, throat drops, water and it isn't very lasting.  This stuff, for being made with honey, certainly isn't something you will enjoy swallowing but it works....  I am using it 2X a day and while my problem isn't cured it is definitely better.I give this 4 stars because of the taste....NB:  I have just ordered my second bottle -

My husband bought this case for his new Paperwhite but ended up trading me for the one I had because of the design.  I, on the other hand, like the design which doesn't show the dirt as a solid color does.  It fits the Paperwhite very well and it protects it.  Having spent this much in a reader a bit more is good insurance.

These are such handy little things to have around.  I recently took on a new job and printed up about a dozen of these to hand out to people who want to contact me . Even I can make a nice looking and professional card with these and it is nice to just print a few at a time so when your info changes you aren't left with a box or two with the incorrect info on them.  They make a very professional offering and very quick to do.I also use these around the home to put with casseroles in the freezer to ID with heating instructions etc.  They are handy for notes to oneself.  They tear readily and are neat.

Wheeee, Maisie is back but this is a sadder and perhaps wiser and experienced Maisie than of old.  Since we last heard from Maisie, she has suffered the painful death of James Compton, her new husband and the loss of her unborn baby girl.  She tries to lose herself in traveling but as she sets sail for home, finds that she just can't face the sympathetic faces.  As the ship docks in Gibraltar on the voyage from India, she decides to jump ship.  It is now the year of 1937, the year of the Spanish Civil War, and Gibraltar is right in the thick of things even if it is officially neutral.  The first night of her stay, she discoveres the dead body of photographer Sebastian Babayoff, a Sephardic Jew.  Soon "old" Scotland Yard "friends" start showing up so she knows that the Comptons, both Sir James and Lady Rowan, have pulled strings to find out where she is and what she is doing.  All her friends in England are concerned but Maisie feels that she must solve this death.  She loses herself in the problem of who killed Sebastian and the why as shown in his photographs.In the midst of her investigation of Sebastian's death she becomes aware of snuggling and gun running activities.... which might have been a part of the death.  The description of events of the Spanish Civil War are good and exciting and ultimately tie in with the solution but  I grew impatient with sad Maisie and flipped over the middle to get to the end.  I missed Billy and his perceptive comments.I gave this a four instead of my usual 5 because I felt that it bogged down in the middle.  I admit to flipping pages to get to the ending which was very good; fast paced and satisfying.  I think we'll see more of Maisie but not in England...at least for a while.  All in all it is very good to have her back.

Any review for a book on Israel will inevitably offend someone so I apologize in advance. Given the polarization associated with Israel, it's hard to find much about the country which refrains from emotionalism or polemics, and it's refreshing when one is found. This well-written book is among them, and it's worth examining as a post-1967 history of Israeli national politics, even if it is restricted to politics.The author is obviously pro-Israel, but he develops his arguments with cogency and detachment; it is surely worthwhile to hear his side of the story even if you disagree with him.  He suggests Israel is a deeply diverse (and divided) society which has discovered how to use this diversity as an advantage, that it has genuinely tried to seek peace with security (but perhaps with an intolerable arrogance), and that it has managed to confront terror and anarchy with considerable decency and success (but that it is always on the edge and is always paying a price).  Surprisingly, the book has little insight into how Israelis seem able to maintain their legendary resiliency and spirited optimism despite all the pressures against them, which is too bad since this could have helped us learn something very important.  The book is well-documented and reasonable, even if few primary sources appear in the Bibliography.Prof Stein begins with a brief (and worthwhile) summary of the nineteen years before 1967, and ends by nicely summarizing the goals and status of current Israeli society.  I would estimate about 3/4 of the book discusses Israeli politics at the national level (and Israeli political machinations seem about as unexciting, convoluted, and dysfunctional as politics anywhere else; from the book's descriptions, Israeli political competency cannot explain Israel's survival). Prof Stein does, of course, describe Israeli military events, but generally as an adjunct to politics and without depth (for example, he states during the 1982 Syrian war the Israeli Air Force simply prevailed in a single massive aerial dogfight, when it actually used a notably brilliant and innovative strategy of electronic and drone warfare which is still studied by military tactitians).  The next-to-last chapter contains a summary of social and economic events, but those who want a moderately deep discussion explaining Israeli economic and technological performance, Israel's social resilience, or issues like religion and local politics, will surely be disappointed.I finally rated the book at three stars (still a commendable rating) because I was disappointed in its excessive use of secondary source material, because of inaccuracies, and because I did not think the book strayed far enough from national politics.

There is never a dull moment in this book. The action is nonstop and the plot is very topical, that of Islamists infiltrating a local large Mosque.  Bruno, an orphan, is the chief of Police, in fact, the only policeman of the tiny French town of St. Denis in the south of France.  The action unfolds as a plot to take out a returning autistic child/man, Sammy.  Sammy knows far too many things about jihadis in Afghanistan and is an expert on explosives.  In light of recent attacks in Paris, London and in Belgium, this should be a must read.I love this series and can hardly wait for the next. For a quiet sleepy southern French town, there is a lot going on. I suggest that you read these in order, as they do build on one another. The food will have you drooling and searching for recipes but the action will keep the pages turning until you reach the end.  I am very pleased to see that Walker has a new book coming out in the fall.January 2015 - After I wrote this review for Children of War in September,  I was surprised to see it had been retitled for US publication as The Children Return.  Walker's narrative of how terrorists operate and infiltrate is very applicable in today's world.  It is definitely frightening to see how easily this can be done.  The author has the background as a former State Department employee and knows his subject.  This is a read and heed the message book.

This book didn't grab me.  I found the plot rather uneven, sometimes full of twists and turns, other times, just uninteresting.  I felt that the author really stretched it out longer than need be.  The basic plot line is that Aimee, a single mother trying to run her deceased father's detective agency, is confronted by a gypsy boy who tells her that his mother is dying of cancer and needs to talk to her about how her father died.  When Aimee gets to the hospital she finds that the mother has been abducted by wheeling her out of the hospital through the backdoor.  As we follow the plot, it seems that Aimee grasps at a lot of straws before finally getting close to a solution.  She also seemed remarkably naïve for someone in the detective business.  I will say that unless you peek ahead, it is hard to guess the ending.As this is # 15 in this series, you might want to start at the beginning, getting to know Aimee.  It is fun to read about Paris and the author is good at getting around.

I have a 23 year old large, Panasonic which is 1300 watts but doesn't  fit nearly as well in my microwave slot  as this smaller one.  This oven has a browning unit included and a nice ceramic interior which is a real plus in cleaning.  It is a dark interior which also helps not show splatters.  My previous oven had an off white interior and always looked dirty no matter what.  The Samsung comes with a grilling rack which I tried out with bacon. The rack has tall legs to put what needs to be browned close to the browning element.  I haven't  used real bacon in a long time but this seemed a good test.  It took just a 1.5 min to cook the bacon but 6 minutes to brown it.  I don't know about you but it took all my willpower to not snatch a piece out and eat it then and there.  The browning element is an interesting, and I think, a unique twist that ends pale reheated pizza, anemic bacon, etc.  The oven comes with a browning plate if what you want cooked and browned not work on the grill.  There is also a microwave/browning button to let you just set it and forget it so you don't have to stand there and do it manually .  This is a handy oven.  I wish it had a bit more power and was a bit wider.  My dinner plates just! fit in the oven but I'll need to get a smaller casserole to fit this.  I should also say that the turntable is 11.5" wide so you don't have much lee way.All in all, I think that this is a good value for the price and the browning element makes this oven stand out from the rest.

This is a dicey time of the year to review lawn products as it took 10 days for the snow to melt so I could find my mulch.  I have a front yard that is half wood chips and "gorilla" hair, and it is on a slope.  The weed cloth underneath is fairly slick which means that when the wind blows ( often) or the snow melts on it ( 10 days last month) the mulch shifts leaving bare spots.  I would go out once a week and cover the bare spots etc and this gets very old, very fast especially when it is cold out.We got 2 lovely 50 degree days this week, so I thought I would try this product.  There seems to be few directions but the spray works like most lawn products, pump air into it and spray it on from the applicator.  I would have liked some idea of how thick to apply it etc but the bottle contains just  health warnings.  The  fine print said to spray it on and let it cure for 24 to 48 hours to firm it up so since there was plenty in the bottle I started spraying thinly and then went back over the whole area again. My yard is 120 ft by 5 deep and I had half a bottle left after a generous application.  I noticed that after 4 hours of set up time, the surface felt much more solid and the mulch wasn't shifting as we walked on it.  The application process was very straightforward and easy.I will revisit this review in another month to see how it looks after that time but I think that this is a pretty good product to just keep mulch from shifting around.

I am most impressed with this product.  I hate taking decongestants because I live in a dry climate and don't need to get any drier.  My nose ran like a faucet and after 3-4 months of that, my throat was raw and I was really getting peeved.  I use one spray per nostril and this  lasts all day. The best part is that I don't feel like a desert the way I would with any of the decongestants I have tried so I consider this a win-win.  I would like to revisit this review after I have tried this product for 30 days and see if the effect lasts.As far as I can tell, there seem to be no side effects, no dry mouth, sore nose etc.  I didn't realize that this was available over the counter but am glad that it is.

Great shaver.  I bought this one after my 10 year-old top-of-the-line foil shaver bit the dust. I had also become tired of hearing its loud buzz so close to my ears, so decided to give this one a try, but wondered if a rotary could approach the foil's closeness.First thing I noticed was, this shaver is SO Q-U-I-E-T. This is worth the price of admission, and much better than the new foils I looked at!  Second thing, even though Philips advises a month to adjust to a new shaver design, this shaves nicely (although probably not as well as a good foil), and it also gets hair along curved areas on the neck much better than the foil (which never did that very well). I am a clinical worker and cannot take a chance of bleeding from a razor, and this item fits the bill. The shaver can charge on a cord or the station, and can be cleaned with warm water. I also thought the cleaning station, although bulky and full of curious buzzes and whirrs, worked quite well for occasional disinfection (although I'd suggest Philips investigate a simple drying cycle for people who just want to use water to clean the shaver). I could not compare it with a modern foil aside from the noise, but it does a good job of shaving, especially when used wet.  I also have a smaller portable Norelco to take to work, and that one shaves so well, I don't think you need all the (expensive) multiple angles and floating heads of the more expensive models, but the disinfection stand is worth considering.If you are new to a rotary I would suggest some of the three or four minute You Tube videos to help you get the most from the shaver, since it does take a slightly different technique than a razor or a foil.Drawbacks? The pouch is too small to carry the charging cord and trimmer along with the shaver, and seems too soft to cushion the delicate-looking heads during heavy travel packing (the shaver will probably go into a tupperware container on long trips). You have to carry a separate trimmer for the sideburns, and replacement heads are not cheap. It looks more delicate than my foil, but that just means you have to be careful. That's about it, and they are minor drawbacks.In short, a nice, quiet, efficient shaver.

It took a while for this plot to get rolling as the author had to bring we new readers up to speed on Joe Sandilands and Joe's possible/potential/on again,off again relationship.  Once the plot got rolling you couldn't put it down.  Joe Sandilands is an Assistant Commissioner of Police for Scotland Yard and is conned/summoned to dance attendance for influential minister, Sir James Truelove, possible future Home Secretary.  Cut to new scene of Lavinia Truelove's( Sir James' wife) mysterious death under the hooves of horse.  Accident or murder...ahhh!  Joe finds himself investigating this death at the behest of the same Minister, James Truelove and is called to Sir James's country estate where the murder took place.  It seems that Sir James wants to clear his name to better his political and matrimonial chances.  In the course of the investigation, a Green Man appears, another murdered woman is revealed and after a while, Joe's love interest, Dorcas Joliffe, appears.  Joe finds himself both the investigator and the investigated in this mess.This is a good book and a real page turner.  Personally I am going back to start at the beginning of the series and am very glad to find a writer whose plot twists you can't guess right off the bat.  Don't miss this, it is well worth your time.
Excellent for getting behind a bridge where floss, brushing, or soft-picks never seem to clean.

Any child would love this under the tree.  Boo  is cuddly, soft and a real charmer.  He is about the size of a real Pomeranian dog minus the need for food and walks.  I think that any child receiving this would be very happy with it. I certainly find myself hugging and  patting the lovely hair and plush of this toy.  The toy is well made, (after all  it is a Gund), and  is hand washable in cold water with mild detergent but should be air dried, not in the dryer.  Boo is certainly sized for a child's grip - not too big or heavy, in short Perfect!  This is a bargain at the price.  Grandmothers pay attention!

I received this product 5 days ago and I still have not gotten it installed on my computer.  I am the first to admit that my knowledge of computers is not vast but I do know how to dial for help so when the download process never got off step 1, I called the McAfee help line.  I was put through after a number of holds, to a helpful person who then passed me on to a MAC specialist who told me that the problem was not mine but the product and to please  give McAfee 2 days to resolve the issues and call back to reinstall. I called back after 3 days and went through the same deal ending up with Ganesha.  Throughout the process I found that VERY careful listening was necessary as the accents were difficult.  I have now spent a total of 3 +hours on the phone with Technical support and I still do not have the product installed.Technical help was patient and kind but even they seemed to be swatting in the dark for answers.  They acted in good faith and even taking remote control of parts of my computer.  NB:  The help screen that pops up is very useful in telling you how the remote control will be handled, what to expect and how to quit it at any time.  However, the bottom line is that the product is not installed and I have wasted a great portion of 2 days learning the interior of my computer.  I don't recommend this product.  As I have not been able to install it, I can't speak to how well or effectively this works.

This was fun and so funny.  A middle aged book editor with a deadly book on her hands suddenly finds herself going toe to toe with a powerful tycoon big business type and the police in the form of DI Jake Field.  Samatha "Sam" Clair, is a boring mundane daily routine  book editor who is handed a bombshell of a tell all book by Kit Lovell.  Suddenly Kit disappears and Sam is the only one taking it seriously.  She begins to investigate and hooks up with DI Jake Field who later becomes more to her than just an officer of the law.  Next thing Sam knows, her apartment is burgled, she is pushed down the stairs and is befriended by a mysterious tenant upstairs in her apartment house.  Her life goes from routinely boring business meetings, competition for the best books to edit into non stop action to save her friend Kit, solve a money laundering scheme etc.  Non stop action delivered in a wise cracking dialogue from a funny smart anything but a detective.  This is a wonderful commentary on the publishing business as well as a good story.  I can't believe that the author had previously only written books on aspects of Victorian history but I do hope she carries this on...it is too good to die with a single book.

This is the third in the series and I would recommend that you start at the beginning of the series to keep the characters straight.  Elizabeth I, so far,  has survived all the plots to prevent her assuming the Monarchy but someone wants to have another crack at her chances for being crowned. Elizabeth calls in her favorite investigator and cousin, Brendan Prescott, who has spent 6 years away from his true love,  Kate, a lady in waiting to Elizabeth.  Under the guidance of William Cecil and Lord Walsingham, Brendan foils yet another chance to kill Elizabeth,  who was about to handle a  gift of poisoned gloves.  Before he can get his teeth into the who of this latest attempt, Elizabeth summons him to a private interview and sets him to the task of finding her missing and favorite lady in waiting, Lady Parry, whom Elizabeth had sent on a private mission.  Blocking  Brendan's efforts on Elizabeth's behalf is Lord Dudley, who will book no interference with Elizabeth's favor.  Brendan is delighted to be sent out of London, away from Lord Dudley and all the pitfalls of the royal court.As Brendan struggles to find Lady Parry and why she has disappeared, he arrives at the lonely and shabby Vaughan Hall and the fun begins.  Where is Lady Parry, who is Raff the lonely little boy, and why is Lady Vaughan so abusive?I liked this book but was a bit lost with some of the characters, not having read the other 2.  The plot has lots of twists, turns, and action but I could have done without the steamy scene with which the book opens.  Good historical background and convincing action make this a page turner.  Enjoy

This scanner is lightweight and easily portable with a single cord which is convenient.  Setup was seamless and I encountered no problems.  The scanner controls and the online screen icons and menus are very clear and intuitive.  Scanning speed is satisfactory but slow compared to my 3 in 1 printer.  Output especially the color scans, were impressive - very clear, crisp and vibrant.The " my image garden" feature loaded slowly but is very useful in organizing and editing scans. There are many useful options for creating calendars, cards, etc. but  I was unable to find a way to scan a document and edit it.Overall, the scanner has impressive functionality and is easy to use.  It would be ideal for individuals with low volume scanning requirements who do not have a 3 in 1 machine.I wish Canon would develop MAC- compatible software for this scanner.

When I saw this printer I jumped at the chance to get one printer for the whole house!  Does everything we need: scanning, copying and printing and bless Canon , this one has 4 separate ink cartridges so you can replace only the one that is empty rather than the Entire cartridge that still has other colors in it.  This printer seems a bit slower than the Canon it is replacing.  Please keep the CD that comes with the product, since I misplaced the CD that went with the printer.  I called Canon( make sure you call the number on the Official Canon Website only, and not one of the non-Canon sites listed on your search engine!!!  I didn't and narrowly avoided a scam) and a very kind and patient gentleman walked me through it., a very simple process. Canon printers are the workhorses of the printer world and my set up problems weren't their fault. Note to self: don't put CD someplace safe!  Now husband and I can share a printer and because it is wireless, I can print from anywhere in the house and with my IPhone and IPad.  I am such a happy camper.

This is a lovely Nora Bonesteel novella set in the Appalachians.  Nora is a long time main character in many of McCrumb's novels.  Nora is a "seer", a local wise mountain woman who is sometimes able to see events before they unfold, taking a cake or casserole to a family before tragedy strikes.  In this novella, which is actually 2 stories interwoven, is only 157 pages, but once you pick it up, as I did last night, you won't put it down until you have enjoyed every last page.Nora is consulted by a summer resident who thinks her home is haunted because, for no apparent reason, their flamingo pink aluminum Christmas tree with accompanying Florida themed ornament is twice sabatoged by an unknown hand.  Nora knows the house from of old and realizes that there is an unhappy specter at work.  The other intertwining story is set in the mountains when 2 Sheriffs go up the mountain on Christmas eve to arrest a hit and run driver who ran from the crash after hitting  the Senator's wife's car.Nora is an intriguing character, the writing draws you in and the only flaw I find is that I wanted more.  I was sad when it ended but McCrumb has written quite a few books about this area so there is more out there.

I Loved! this book, and so did a WW II vet who said this book brought back many happy memories of how much books meant to him at that time.  This is a fascinating account of the effort to get reading material to the soldiers and sailors stationed world wide during World War II.  It is also the tale of the birth of our now staple book, the paperback.The Nazi book burning campaign inspired the American Library Association to begin a donation campaign to get books to American soldiers and sailors beginning in 1941.  It was widely recognized  throughout the military that reading was a chance for the military to break out of "do everything together" mode and find personal space.  The ALA , United Service Organization (USO) and the American Red Cross set a goal of collecting 10 million books from the nation for use by the Armed Forces, but by March of 1942 only 4 million were in hand and 1.5 million of those were not suitable for distribution.  Hauling around hardback books along with the rest of military gear was impractical so the paperback, that we know today, was born.I am a Librarian and the grit and determination to get not just one book but a variety of books on every subject imaginable into the hands of the serving military is a wonderful story.  In the back is a listing of the printed titles which were printed throughout the war and makes a dandy reading list for those interested in what was noteworthy reading  during the war.I highly recommend this book not just for the topic but for its readable style and content

Pharrell Williams's first solo album was a success but it was his second album, "Girl," that contained the song that would bring him worldwide fame.  In the spring of 2014, "Happy" spent ten straight weeks in the top position on the charts and was seemingly everywhere--it will probably end up being remembered as one of the standout songs of the decade but is by no means the only great song on "Girl."  "Come Get It Bae" was a mid-range Top 40 hit, and the rest of the album consists of well-written songs and has little or no filler.  "Girl" has a retro sound and will appeal to those who enjoy old-school soul and R&B music from the Seventies and Eighties.

For half a decade "Numb3rs" followed mathematician Charlie Eppes (David Krumholtz) and his FBI agent brother Don (Rob Morrow).  Charlie's phenomenal math insights helped solve more than a hundred crimes over the course of the series, and this DVD set of the sixth and final season contains all 16 of that season's episodes that were originally aired from September 2009 to the series finale in March 2010.Season Six was relatively short, but there were many strong episodes--the team encountered worlds such as Russian roulette, gambling, cloning, and the paranormal, and used Charlie's tips in the mathematical concepts of game theory, ultimatum game, and risk analysis among others to solve crimes involving a sniper, robbery, kidnapping, computer hacking, identity theft, a hostage situation, and more.Henry Winkler guest starred in an episode this season, and this set includes special features discussing the filming of the show.  "Numb3rs" had great chemistry among the lead characters and superb writing, and the final episodes tied up the storylines for the main characters and showed the direction they planned on taking in the future.While fans of the series were disappointed when "Numb3rs" ended, the show's run of 118 episodes was creditable for a show of its type and provided much enjoyment with its unique mathematical spin on police drama.

We hear figures and statistics in the news all the time, and use our mathematical abilities to process them.  We do not always interpret them correctly, though, and this leads to incorrect beliefs about the world.  Author and mathematician Jordan Ellenberg knows the importance of using math correctly--he states that knowing math "is like wearing a pair of X-ray specs that reveal hidden structures underneath the messy and chaotic surface of the world."  In "How Not To Be Wrong," Ellenberg shows us how to avoid misinterpreting the math in our lives and coming to wrong conclusions.In this wide-ranging, erudite book, Ellenberg examines areas in math such as linearity, regression, the Law of Large Numbers, probability, randomness, prime numbers, geometry, and correlation, providing  examples in such areas as economics, war, religion, medicine, terrorism, sports, politics, and state lotteries to help the reader avoid making common mathematical errors.  The author includes scatter plots, graphs, tables, and charts to illustrate the concepts he discusses.  "How Not To Be Wrong" is a great pop math book, and a really fun read for those who like books of the type.

Conservative author Rod Dreher returned to his home parish in Louisiana in his middle age after the death of his sister, and was hoping to renew family ties there.  When that dream turned into a nightmare, it brought on a spiritual crisis that even affected his physical health.  Dreher turned to what he describes as an unlikely source, Dante's "Divine Comedy," to help him get out of the ditch in which he found himself.Dreher's family never accepted him for who he was instead of who they thought he should be, and it became clear to the author that he would never have the type of family life he envisioned.  In "How Dante Can Save Your Life," the author discusses how Dante helped him to see areas in which he was tripped up by his trial and how to move through those issues.It is not necessary to have read Dante before taking up this volume.  The book offers numerous wise insights and much terrific advice concerning losses and ruptured relationships that happen in almost all lives, but you do not have to be going through a crisis as severe as the one Dreher faced to appreciate the book.  Dreher's story intertwined with Dante's verities makes the book really accessible, and I expect that many who read "How Dante Can Save Your Life" through the years will be helped greatly by it.

In his storybook basketball career, Bill Russell won two NCAA championships, an Olympic gold medal, and an unbelievable eleven NBA championships.  He did face numerous difficult challenges in segregated America while young, and in "Go Up for Glory" the man whom many think is still the greatest basketball center ever looks at his life to that point on the hardwood and in American society.The book was written in 1965, most of the way through Russell's NBA career, when the star was in his early thirties.  Russell's family left Louisiana to settle in the Bay Area, and a stellar career at the University of San Francisco and a triumph at the 1956 Olympics followed, and the author reflects on those times early in the book.Russell is most famous for his role in establishing the Boston Celtics as a marquee NBA franchise during the team's dynasty of the 1950s and 1960s.  These pages offer brief sketches of Russell's key teammates, thoughts on his relationship with coach Red Auerbach, interesting vignettes into what it was like to play NBA basketball more than a half-century ago, and recollections of a couple of the pivotal plays that kept the Celtics' streak of titles intact.Civil rights was foremost in the country's attention in the mid-1960s.  The movement had made great (but still incomplete) progress when the book was written, and Russell describes his hopes for the future of civil rights near the end of the book.  "Go Up for Glory" is fascinating whether you read it for the basketball aspect or the sociology aspect, and anyone with a keen interest in the history of the NBA would definitely find it worthwhile.

In American history courses in school, we see that Richmond fell early in April 1865 and that a mere week later Lee had surrendered to Grant at Appomattox.  While it is natural to infer from this that the surrender was a foregone conclusion after Richmond's fall, in "April 1865" author Jay Winik teaches that that was by no means the case, and that there were several points both in that week and in that most fateful month that events could have gone off the rails to the great detriment of the future of America and the world.While the eleven states that formed the Confederate States of America were the only states to secede in American history, Winik notes that the generations of antebellum Americans had always viewed the unity of the nation as fragile and that secession movements, not all of them Southern, were plotted from the earliest days of the Republic.As April approached in 1865, the Confederacy was in increasingly desperate straits, so much so that many Southerners voiced what four years earlier had been unthinkable--giving blacks freedom in return for military service in the Confederate Army.  That measure was taken too late to save the Confederacy, though, and after Richmond fell Lee attempted to join up with Johnston's troops in North Carolina.  Within days, however, Lee's army was surrounded, and Winik rightly lauds the general for making the pivotal decision to surrender rather than attempt guerilla warfare.Winik's portrait of the surrender at Appomattox and its aftermath is superb.  Lincoln and Grant were wise enough to know that knitting North and South back together into one nation called for magnanimity and the refusal to destroy the dignity of the South and Southerners.  Most know that the South was devastated  as a result of the war, but the author's assessment of the total extent of that devastation is truly arresting.Even with the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia, the war was not quite over and there were a few remaining anxious moments for all who hoped for peace, and Winik describes the surrender of the rest of the Confederate forces.Five days after Lee's surrender, President Lincoln was assassinated in Washington, and this volume tells the story of that tragedy in great detail.  Winik notes that precedents for the transfer of power were still not robust in the 1860s and recalls how Andrew Johnson became Lincoln's successor, with the attendant effects on postwar politics."April 1865" also offers biographical sketches of Lincoln, Davis, Grant, Lee, and other figures who played key roles during that month.  This volume as much as any other I have ever read is a refutation of the Marxist doctrine of determinism and control of history by impersonal forces--Lincoln, Grant, and Lee especially show how much individuals and the decisions that they make (as well as fate and good or bad luck) can turn history on a dime and have effects that last generations if not centuries.This book has a great picture section, and it was enjoyable to read and elegantly written, challenging the vocabulary of even serious readers.  For those history buffs who love reading about the Civil War and who want to gain a deeper understanding of key figures of the war and of the importance of the conflict coming to a close in the manner that it did, I cannot recommend "April 1865" more highly.

The 2014 midterm elections saw the Republican Party outperform most expectations.  The GOP captured nine Senate seats and took comfortable control of the upper chamber, while also picking up thirteen House seats--its total of 247 in the lower chamber is its high-water mark since the Roaring Twenties.  The party did well in the governorships, too, even winning a shocker in Maryland.In "The Surge," more than a dozen political analysts examine this historic midterm in a series of essays looking back on what Republicans did to reap the gains that they realized last November and looking forward to the huge 2016 presidential election that will determine who succeeds President Obama.2014 began with the primary season, and one essay recalls how the GOP was more successful this cycle in striking a winning balance between ideology and electability when selecting its Senate nominees.The fall campaign was memorable, and other essayists look back at the races for the Senate, House, and governorships, as well as some of the issues and conditions in the country that influenced the contests.  There were a few key October events that contributed to the Republicans' late surge.  The party won three Senate seats and eight House seats by less than four percentage points, suggesting that if the Obama approval rating had been a mere two points higher on Election Day, the GOP would likely have just barely captured the Senate and not even recaptured all of the House seats that it lost in 2012, a result that would have looked and felt much different.Financing and polling are important topics in midterm as well as presidential elections, and "The Surge" explores the impact of the campaign finance rule changes of recent years as well as some of the challenges that the Internet and cell phones are posing to pollsters as they try to gauge the intents of voters.Now that we are well into 2015 and the country has digested the results of the midterms, those interested in politics are of course looking forward to the presidential contest late next year.  There are essays looking forward to the election as well as at the futures of both the Democratic and Republican parties.Another essay looks at some of the rules changes for the 2016 primary calendar and nomination contest process, and fans of Sean Trende will enjoy that always-superb analyst's look at the Electoral College and whether we can expect any significant shift anytime soon in the coalitions of blue and red states that we have become familiar with in recent elections.One point not fully explored in "The Surge" is the typical performance of the "out" party in elections in which the incumbent party is seeking its third straight term in the White House.  In the last hundred years, there have been nine such elections (1920, 1928, 1940, 1960, 1968, 1976, 1988, 2000, and 2008).  In each and every one of those nine contests, the party not holding the presidency improved its standing in the popular vote by four to fourteen percentage points compared to its performance in the previous election.This phenomenon has occurred not only when the country was in trouble, but also when things seemed well.  In 2000, George W. Bush brought the Republicans' percentage of the popular vote up seven points from the previous election, from 41 to 48.  Twelve years earlier, Michael Dukakis was criticized for a bland, ineffectual campaign, but even in the midst of the peace, prosperity, and thawing Cold War tensions of 1988 he was able to convince enough voters that it was time for a change that he brought the Democrats' share of the popular vote up from 41 to 46.  Mitt Romney took 47 percent of the popular vote in 2012, and if this pattern holds for the tenth straight "third term" election, Republican gatherings on the night of November 8, 2016 will be happy indeed."The Surge" contains raw vote totals for senatorial and gubernatorial contests, crosstabs galore from the exit polls, and tables, charts, graphs, and a scatter plot to help the reader interpret the analysis in the book.  It is a great read for political junkies looking back at 2014 and forward to 2016.

"Miami Vice" was one of the most unique and influential television series of the 1980s.  Viewers were attracted to this police drama that was filmed in Miami with its tropical scenes and that integrated popular songs into the storylines as no other show had before.  This DVD set contains all 22 episodes of the first season of the series that were originally broadcast on NBC from September 1984 to May 1985.Don Johnson vaulted to fame for his portrayal of lead character Sonny Crockett, a vice cop who with his partner, Ricardo Tubbs (Philip Michael Thomas), solved crimes involving drugs, murder, gambling, smuggling, arms dealing, prostitution, kidnapping, burglary, home invasion, and organized crime.  Sonny dressed as no other TV policeman ever had, sporting Caribbean pastels that matched those of some the architecture seen in Miami.  Edward James Olmos played Lieutenant Martin Castillo, the taciturn, no-nonsense head of the vice department.Bruce Willis, Glenn Frey, and Pam Grier guest starred during the first season, and the aforementioned music was stellar, with Phil Collins, Russ Ballard, Tina Turner, the Pointer Sisters, Steppenwolf, The Animals, Autograph, ZZ Top, Glen Frey, Peter Gabriel, Foreigner, Sheila E., U2, and others accentuating the storylines with their songs.The bonus material on this set looks at the filming, style, and music of "Miami Vice" as well as the effect that the series had on the Florida city.  The show was one of the most iconic of the whole decade, and even the theme song was one of the best in television history.  Gen Xers who saw the show and who purchase this set will enjoy remembering some of the classic episodes, and those in younger generations who are fascinated by the Eighties will be treated to one of the most memorable contributions to that decade's pop culture.

The 1960s was the decade of psychedelia, but the Maryland-based United States of Existence recorded songs of that genre from 1978 to 1986.  This collection of songs is strong almost from top to bottom, with a good number of the songs having a very fast tempo and strong beat.  The group blends psychedelia and surf together on several of the songs as almost no other group that I am aware of has done, and the leadoff song, "A Scandal in Bohemia," was regarded enough to be included on the Children of Nuggets boxed set.  This collection would definitely be enjoyed by fans of psychedelic and surf rock.

In the spring of 1991, floral ties seemed to be ubiquitous.  NBA coaches were wearing them during the playoffs, college guys sported them at their graduation ceremonies, and even some in the business world adopted the look.  I remember my mother telling me at that time that floral ties had also been popular around 1967--if that is the case, and fashions really do return every so often, there may again be a time before too long when everyone seems to be wearing them.This floral tie looks sharp, and is made of cotton and feels very durable.  The description above says that the tie is "not-too-skinny," but the prospective buyer should note that it is fairly skinny, more so than you might expect when viewing it here.  If that is not a deal-breaker for you and you like the style, this tie would be a good purchase and something you will want to have on your tie rack the next time floral ties are highly popular.

Most Americans are not fans of our lengthy presidential selection process that begins each cycle soon after the midterm elections are over.  A minority of the country, though, sees the gauntlet that candidates must run as a healthy test of our prospective presidents' characters.  In "What It Takes," Richard Ben Cramer tells the story of six of the men who were first-tier candidates for their parties' nominations in the election of 1988:  George Bush, Michael Dukakis, Bob Dole, Richard Gephardt, Joe Biden, and Gary Hart."What It Takes" demonstrates that the marathon in fact begins years before the candidates declare, if not early in their lives.  Cramer seeks to understand what makes the candidates tick, going back to their upbringings, family lives, and experiences that forged their characters long before they ever hit the campaign trail.  He also tries to fathom the motivations that would drive them to run such an exhausting race, how they overcame adversity, and the strengths and weaknesses of each man and how they came into play during Campaign '88.Strategy plays a part in campaigns, but those who have followed politics for a long time know the far more commanding role that money and organization play in determining the nominees of the two major parties every four years.  Many thought that Dole would upset Bush for the Republican nod, but Cramer illustrates the enormous advantages that Bush enjoyed that enabled the vice president to hold Dole off.  Even though personalities and characters do have an effect on a campaign, "What It Takes" shows why no dark horse has captured a major-party nomination in decades and likely won't in the foreseeable future, either.Most of the book gives the backstory of the campaign that most people (viz. those who aren't political junkies) miss--all that takes place before the Iowa and New Hampshire primaries.  Over the course of this long book Cramer recalls all of the major evens of the campaign, including the exits of Biden (for plagiarism) and Hart (for adultery), Bush's turnaround in New Hampshire, Dukakis outlasting the other Democratic contenders to capture his nomination, and Bush's strategy that turned his summer poll deficits into a 40-state near-landslide in November.Especially poignant is the description of the moments at which the losing candidates knew that their years-long (in some cases, life-long) dream was coming to an end.  Another theme of the book is that prominence is no guarantee against tragedy in one's personal or family life, as each of these six first-tier candidates profiled had to deal with something exceptionally difficult at some point in their lives."What It Takes" has been called by many the best book ever dealing with a presidential campaign.  While there are other contenders for that title as well, and the book's length might seem off-putting, any political junkie ought to read it once in his or her life.

Theodore White had a roaring success with his 1961 release "The Making of the President, 1960."  The retrospective of the presidential campaign was read by multitudes of Americans, and was so well-received that White produced a similar look back after the next three elections as well.The author took a bit of a different tack for the election of 1980.  In "America in Search of Itself," White recalled the 1956 election, his first to cover as a reporter.  He describes what he called the Old Country of the Fifties and early Sixties and then proceeds to explain both the social changes and changes in government that brought the country to its fateful decision of 1980.White looks at a few key states of the Union and recalls the impact that they had on national politics, recalls the shift of voting patterns of important demographic groups during the decades leading up to 1980, and notes the impact that television had made on politics by the time of the Reagan-Carter showdown--however, his stressing of how important the nightly network news was may have been on-target 35 years ago but certainly seems quaint from our standpoint today.The author tracks Jimmy Carter's rise to power and notes the disagreements that he had with the Democratic Congress of that era that led to gridlock and helped lead to Edward Kennedy's primary challenge in 1980.  White looks at the tactical errors of the Carter administration in both domestic and foreign affairs which led to widespread malaise.Near the end of Carter's term, our standing in the world had diminished precipitately and inflation had reached intolerable levels.  The traditional Democratic coalition had eroded, and White recalls the effects of this in the section of the book that recollects both parties' primaries and the general election.  The author examines the Reagan landslide and the results from the 1980 census.White was known as a liberal but made several comments over the course of the book critical of some of the liberal excesses of the Sixties and Seventies, and two key problems that he mentioned that were caused by the liberalism of that era have only gotten far worse in the third of a century since this book was released.  "America in Search of Itself" is a worthwhile look back at the elections of 1956 and 1980 and the huge changes that occurred in America in the interim.

Heading into the 1964 season in Major League Baseball, the New York Yankees had been to the World Series 28 times in the previous 43 seasons.  It was a level of dominance that will never be seen again, and the mid-Sixties saw the long run of Yankee excellence reach its end.  David Halberstam recalls the club's last World Series appearance of the mid-century era in "October 1964."To the casual fan of that time, New York's run likely seemed as though it would go on forever, but Halberstam notes that astute baseball insiders realized that by the mid-Sixties the Yankees' farm system was not what it had been in previous decades.  The team had also not kept up with many other franchises in baseball in signing talented young black players.Halberstam examines the changes that were happening in 1960s America, including changes in race relations and the nature of authority, as well as the impact that television was making on society.  The author notes that the St. Louis Cardinals, the team that would face the Yankees in the World Series in 1964, were far ahead of most clubs in signing and integrating black players--blacks were not merely accepted, Halberstam notes, but the Cardinals had a greater number of genuine interracial friendships than most teams did at the time.This helped the Cardinals immensely in 1964, as did their focus on speed and their acquisition of Lou Brock.  Starting then and for a long time after, St. Louis became known as a team that tried to win with speed.  The Cardinals were involved in an epic National League pennant race in 1964, and Halberstam's recollection of it is superb.Important figures of both the Yankees and Cardinals are profiled, giving the reader important information about their backstories.  Halberstam talks about much more than baseball in this volume, providing great insights into human nature as well as into what happened on the diamond.St. Louis and New York put on a show in a classic World Series, and Halberstam's description of those seven games, including the key plays that swung the Series and won the title for the Cardinals, is outstanding.  It would be the last World Series appearance for the Yankees for over a decade, and the author's epilogue talks about what happened to both franchises and many of the key players on both teams in the years that followed.There is also a good picture section in the book.  Society always impacts sports and sports always impacts society, but Halberstam's volume recalls a moment when that was even more the case than usual.  Baseball fans would enjoy this remembrance of a classic season and classic World Series between two classic franchises.

New England was the cradle of the American Revolution and is unbelievably rich in sites of historic import.  That would be more than reason enough to visit the region, but those who have traveled there, especially in October or May, can attest that New England isn't exactly a slouch in the scenery department either--its mountains and its coast are both awesome.This Fodor's travel guide is a comprehensive guide to our country's most northeastern states.  It opens with an introductory chapter containing information on top attractions and experiences both urban and rural, when to go, air and car travel, travel with children, and suggested itineraries.The other nine chapters in this guide each cover a state or area in New England.  Most of the suggestions that Fodor's makes for restaurants and hotels do tend to be expensive, but there are some more affordable options listed as well.  There is more than plenty to see and do in New England, and this guide gives the reader great vacation planning information in areas such as sports, beaches, shopping, bookstores, arts, nightlife, outdoor activities, whale watching, museums and cultural activities, scenic drives, antiquing, skiing, lighthouses, regional cuisine, Newport mansions, history and historic sites, and, of course, fall foliage.Fodor's guides are a standard in travel, and this guide does not disappoint--there are many pictures of the incredible scenery, and there is even a perforated map of the region and downtown Boston that can be pulled out and used.  Most people would enjoy a trip to this most rewarding part of America, and history buffs should definitely have a New England pilgrimage on their bucket lists.  This travel guide provides a ton of information and suggestions that would help make such a vacation successful and memorable.

The first Bob Ryan writing that I ever remember encountering was in an NBA season preview magazine in the fall of 1987 when I was a senior in high school in rural Texas.  I really enjoyed the piece, and as I became more and more absorbed by the history of the NBA I saw his name pop up many times.  I subsequently always considered it a treat to read anything he wrote or to hear him interviewed on radio or television.So I was enthused when I saw that he was coming out with this memoir, "Scribe," that looks back on his sterling sportswriting career that stretches back to the late 1960s.  Ryan begins by describing his upbringing in Trenton, and sports was a big part of the author's life from its earliest stages.  His account of his time at Lawrenceville School and Boston College is absorbing, as is his personal recollection of being in Boston in 1967 during the Red Sox pennant drive and World Series.Shortly thereafter, Ryan was hired by the Boston Globe, where he covered the Celtics.  Those who are well-versed in Celtics history of the Seventies and Eighties will already know much of the information covered concerning those years, but the author offers enough unique takes and fresh anecdotes to make that section of the book more than worthwhile.While Ryan is best-known for his work in relation to the Celtics and the NBA, it was far from his only assignment during his decades in Boston.  Among other things, he was briefly a Red Sox beat writer, appeared on local television, and went to numerous Olympics--his recollection of the 1992 Dream Team is a good one.Ryan also provides insightful observations about football, hockey, golf, and even music, and the personalities he discusses include John Havlicek, Dave Cowens, Red Auerbach, Larry Bird, Bob Knight, and Chuck Daly.Toward the end of the volume he talks of the drought-ending 2004 Red Sox and 2008 Celtics and compares LeBron James and Michael Jordan.  The book's lone blemish is that there are several errors concerning dates, scores, and the like, but if you have long admired Bob Ryan's work you will not regret adding "Scribe" to your sports library.

Some parts of North America boast of their coastlines and others of their mountains, but almost no other region can boast of mountains and coast juxtaposed like the Pacific Northwest can.  Add a few of our most famous national parks and vibrant cities like Portland, Seattle, and Vancouver, and the region is simply a boffo vacation destination.This Fodor's travel guide covers all of Oregon and Washington and the cities of Vancouver and Victoria in British Columbia.  The guide begins with an overview that provides information on air and car travel, border crossings, traveling with children, and other basic travel tips.  Also offered are suggested itineraries, advice on what time of year to go, and a list of top attractions, both urban and rural.The rest of the guide contains 18 chapters, each devoted to an area in the Pacific Northwest.  The suggestions for restaurants and hotels do tend to cluster toward the more expensive end of the price spectrum, but there are plenty of more affordable options as well.  The top attractions in each area are described.  There is information on general topics like shopping, the arts, sports, bookstores, as well as activities more associated with the region such as whale watching, cruises, outdoor activities, national parks, wineries and wine tasting, beaches, tulip farms, and (this IS the Northwest) coffeehouses.Fodor's is considered one of the standards in travel guides, and this one doesn't disappoint--there are also good city maps and many excellent pictures of the scenery.  This guide would be a good aid to help someone plan a trip to what many think is the most scenic part of the 48 contiguous states.

Those with even a basic knowledge of American history know that the United States saw a huge wave of immigrants in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.  Far fewer know that in the depths of the Great Depression, there was actually an aggregate outflow--remarkable as it may seem, there was a short period where more were emigrating from the United States than were immigrating into it.  Even more unbelievably, many of those who left our shores in search of hope headed to the Soviet Union, one of the few most despotic regimes in history.In "The Forsaken," Tim Tzouliadis tells the little-known story of those who made the tragic mistake of going of their own volition to Stalinist Russia.  Many from all walks of life and from all parts of the country made that journey, including those who worked at a Ford plant that temporarily existed in the USSR and young baseball players in their late teens and early twenties (before the Terror of the 1930s, the author relates that for a brief moment baseball was on its way to becoming a major sport in the Soviet Union, complete with Russian-language radio coverage).As the 1930s progressed, the brief moments when the American emigrants were enjoying their new lives were eclipsed by increasing apprehension and then horror as the Terror set in.  As anyone familiar with Communism knows, it is not in keeping with human nature, so Communist states always end up resorting to violence in order to maintain control ("we're building a perfect society...and if you disagree, you die").Such regimes always think that individual eggs are worth breaking in their (obviously eventually unavailing) attempts to make their utopian omelets, and the author provides a vivid description of the murders and imprisonments of the Terror and of the desperation of the remaining Americans who were trapped in that hell to find a way to escape.After 1937, however, it was virtually impossible to escape the Soviet Union.  Matters weren't helped by American journalists, ambassadors, and politicians who exhibited next to no sympathy for the Americans' plight.  Some Americans looked at the situation with a sense of realpolitik, but other high officials were simply duped by the USSR--Stalin eventually at times had contempt for President Roosevelt's navete concerning his nation, and this volume is a reminder of how horrifyingly close that putative adult Henry Wallace came to becoming president--after the vice president's visit to the Soviet gulag camps, one of the Russian prisoners told one of the U.S. prisoners that "you Americans are really stupid."The gulag was indeed about as close as one could come to hell on earth, and Tzouliadis is unsparing in his description of just how horrifying those camps were.  Unfortunates of many nationalities ended up as prisoners in the Soviet gulag system, including innumerable prisoners of war that ended up in Russian hands.  The author tells the inspiring story of two Americans who persevered for years and against all odds ended up being able to return to the United States.Readers of this book will feel sympathy for all who ended up in the gulag, both the POWs who were taken there by force and those who made the naïve but exceptionally foolish decision to emigrate to the USSR.  Many of the latter who were baseball players were very young.  While few make a decision as dumb as thinking that the Soviet Union would be a great place to live, most if not all of us did a few stupid things and made a few dumb decisions way back in our own late teens/early twenties yesteryears--but virtually all of the unfortunate baseball players never got a chance to live to middle or old age and look back on their youthful mistakes as things long, long lived down."The Forsaken" certainly can't be described as an uplifting read, but it is compelling.  It records an event in history that should be remembered lest it be repeated, and serves as a reminder of how truly hideous Soviet Russia was, of how little bureaucrats in free societies care about those they represent in many cases, and of just how lucky America was to have Harry Truman, whatever his failings, as president instead of Henry Wallace in the earliest stages of the Cold War.

Most Americans today are probably not aware that President Woodrow Wilson sent troops to Russia during that country's civil war in an attempt to nip Bolshevism in the bud.  In "America's Secret War Against Bolshevism," author David Foglesong chronicles our unavailing effort to stop the establishment of Communism in what became the Soviet Union.Wilson rightly saw Bolshevism as a menace to the world, and Foglesong recalls the president's reasoning as to why.  Wilson thought that intervention in Russia passed a cost-benefit analysis, but there was a tension between his general foreign policy belief in self-determination and wisely making an exception in the case of what would ultimately metastasize into world Communism.  The author covers all of the reasons for intervention and the methods, economic and intelligence as well as military, used.The president was hemmed in by factors such as American public opinion and the possible response of the Germans at the close of World War I.  However, troops were ultimately sent to Siberia and North Russia.  Foglesong recalls the role that the British, Japanese, and Czechs played in the intervention, describes the trajectory of events before the ultimate withdrawal of Allied troops, and offers his opinion on the efficacy of the operation.President Wilson was correct in believing that the end of the Bolshevik regime was inevitable, but the Soviet government killed millions, forced the rest of the population to "live" in terror, and remained a purulent blight on the earth for most of the rest of the century.  Winston Churchill was, as was often the case, foresighted and called for greater intervention.While it would have been worth it to strangle Communism before it really got established, it is understandable to see how the war-weary Western nations in 1918 and 1919 might not have agreed.  "America's Secret War Against Bolshevism" is a definitive account of this little-known episode in the history of the twentieth century.

"Cheers" had an unsuccessful first season, but the sitcom was not cancelled, and it gradually gained an audience and became a fixture on NBC's Thursday night schedule.  By its ninth season, it was the top-rated show in America, and this DVD set contains all 27 episodes of that season that were originally aired from September 1990 to May 1991.Ted Danson stars as Sam Malone, an ex-baseball player who owns and bartends at Cheers.  The great characters that comprise the bar's employees and regular clientele come from different social classes and walks of life, but form a community of sorts.The cast gets into all sorts of funny situations during the course of these episodes--a recurring theme this season is the conflict between Sam and the owner of the restaurant upstairs from the bar.  Singer Bobby Hatfield and Boston Celtic great Kevin McHale each guest star in an episode, and Arsenio Hall and Michael Dukakis make cameo appearances.  At the end of the season, Sam expresses a desire to become a father."Cheers" reached the 200-episode mark during Season Nine, and John McLaughlin hosted a retrospective with the main characters that discussed how the show emerged in spite of its inauspicious beginning, showed highlights of episodes in seasons past, and talked about the relationships between the characters.Gen Xers will also recall some of the cool fashions that were "in" during the early Nineties while watching these episodes.  Some episodes touch on adult themes that would not be appropriate for younger viewers, but for those of age these episodes will remind viewers that "Cheers" is one of the best sitcoms of all time with its well-above-average number of laugh-out-loud moments and exceptionally witty writing.

Most who follow politics in America see that Democrats play to win but that Republicans fight back with nowhere near the same level of intensity.  As a result, government has grown to gargantuan levels and we have traveled a long way down the road from liberty to tyranny.  Like millions of other Americans, David Horowitz deplores this development--he wrote this volume that offers a sage plan that the GOP could take into battle.Conservatives sometimes naïvely think that if they offer superior solutions to our nation's problems they will automatically prevail at the ballot box.  Horowitz, however, opines on the factor that he thinks really swings elections and shows where the Republicans fall short in influencing that factor.  The author notes that the standard array of attacks by Democrats has not changed in decades, but, remarkably, in all that time the GOP has never found effective rejoinders.Horowitz points out liberal failures in foreign policy and describes at length how on the domestic front liberal policies have hurt those who the Left claims to help.  In spite of that, liberals see themselves as morally superior to conservatives, and because they do, adopt an ends-justifies-the-means ethos in implementing their plans.  The author provides the all-important tips on how conservatives could effectively and persuasively argue in moral terms themselves and at long last turn the tables.  Also included is a chapter concerning unity between the Tea Party and the Republican Party.Conservatives and Republicans pride themselves on being problem-solvers and solution-oriented, but continually fall down in finding a solution to a (the?) task of prime importance--doing whatever it takes to expose as false the fraudulent Moral Superiority pose liberals and Democrats adopt.  David Horowitz's "Take No Prisoners" should be required reading for all GOP presidential candidates in preparation for 2016.

"The Streets of San Francisco" established itself in its first season on ABC and became even more popular in its second season, finishing 1973-74 ranked in the Top 30.  This DVD set contains the first eleven episodes from Season Two that were originally broadcast in the fall of 1973.In these episodes of this superb crime drama, Lt. Mike Stone (Karl Malden) and his young, college-educated colleague Steve Keller (Michael Douglas) have great chemistry both in spite of and because of their age difference.  The two solve crimes such as murder, bank robbery, larceny, prostitution, organized crime, and a jail break.The series was filmed on location in San Francisco, with great views of the city and surrounding bay and ocean framing the action, and the setting was further enhanced by incorporating period houses, bars, wharves, hospitals, and even the city zoo.
