Alcatraz Island even made an appearance in an episode on this set.Several notable guest stars including Michael Constantine, Martin Sheen, Leslie Nielsen, Tom Bosley, and Ricky Nelson appear on this set, and the Seventies cars and clothes here are cool.  Those who enjoyed Season One of "Streets" would enjoy these episodes as well.

In this film, Colin Firth plays a man who flees his life in Florida and takes on a new identity, that of Arthur Newman.  On his way to Indiana, "Arthur" meets another person living under an assumed name, "Michaela" Fitzgerald (Emily Blunt), and the two become involved.  The premise behind the film was interesting and I wanted to like "Arthur Newman," but was disappointed.I gave it a chance because Firth and Blunt are A-listers who have been great in everything they've been in--both of them did a creditable job considering the script, which I thought was just slow-moving with an underdeveloped plot.  Even the key scenes, exchanges, and attempts at humor fell flat, and it just seemed as though this was only about 60 or 70 percent of a movie.  This wasn't the worst film I've ever seen, but is certainly forgettable.  Rated R for adult content.

David Horowitz was a key figure of the New Left in the 1960s, but had second thoughts about liberalism as many young people do as they grow older.  By 1997, the year he wrote "Radical Son," he was an influential conservative and this autobiography tells the story of his journey across the political spectrum.Horowitz describes his Marxist upbringing in New York City and how even at age 11 he had already worked out rationalizations he used to condemn the inequalities that are baked into human existence.  By his young adulthood he ended up on the other coast, in the heart of the liberal movement at Berkeley in the Sixties, and he speaks of his activism there as well as of the unsavory alliances the New Left made and the illicit drug use some in the movement partook of then.The author provides insights into the liberal mindset he had in his twenties--he and his cohorts arrogantly thought that "the world is cursed by ignorance, and the task of progressives like us is to set everybody right."He eventually realized that the ignorance was on his own side, later comparing modern liberalism to a "quasi-religious cult"--he describes how Leftists don't know how markets work, are utopian, employ double standards, and launch ad hominem circumstantial arguments when they (inevitably) are losing debates.  In the book Horowitz also recognizes the economic destruction wrought by socialism.The murder of a colleague helped Horowitz see that physical violence was endemic to the Left, as you cannot have communism without violence--after he made other observations that made him question the Left's belief that human character and behavior can be shaped without limit, he rejected Marxism completely and left the Left after a long process of soul-searching.The author also talks of more than politics in these pages, providing exceptionally rich insights in his recollections of his marriages, his relationships with his parents and children, and some of the trials in his personal life.Many think that Democrats will dominate the future politically because of the Millennials, but similar predictions were made following the 1976 election, when it was said that Democrats would prosper because polling showed that the young then were even a bit more liberal than they are today.As the story of David Horowitz shows, though, there is hope.  As people get older, they generally become more conservative--it happened in the Eighties as a result of the Carter years, and polls show that it is occurring today with the Millennials, as the implementation of ObamaCare is teaching them that while liberals always try to sell liberalism as the rich being soaked to help the middle class, it is the middle class that always suffers most under redistributionist policies."Radical Son" is simply one of the best biographies I have ever read--it is unbelievably rich in insights into human nature and the human condition, but as Horowitz himself ruefully notes in the acknowledgments, the Leftists who would most benefit by reading it would never consider doing so.

The original version of Hawaii Five-O was regarded as one of the great police dramas ever.  It ended its twelve-year run in 1980, and three decades later CBS brought the series back as a 'reboot.'  This DVD set contains all 24 episodes of the first season of the new version of the series originally broadcast from September 2010 to May 2011.In this version of the show Steve McGarrett is a former Navy Seal played by Alex O'Loughlin.  After his father is murdered, Steve is joined on the Five-0 team by Danny Williams (Scott Caan), Chin Ho Kelly (Daniel Dae Kim), and Kono Kalakaua (Grace Park).  There is great rapport, banter, and humor between Steve and Danny, and the series portrays side issues like Danny's relationship with his ex and battles for custody of his daughter.  The team is based in Honolulu and solves the crimes of murder, kidnapping, gang war, jail break, robbery, and piracy, and also chases arch-villain Wo Fat (Mark Dacascos).The series incorporates high tech into the forensics that the team uses to solve crimes, and the writing in these episodes is great--it is so tightly written that if you let your mind wander for even a minute or two you can lose track of important parts of the storyline.  In many series today men are portrayed as buffoons, but the new "Hawaii Five-0" is old school in that the lead character embodies the traditional masculine traits of toughness, courage, competence, honor, and decisiveness.  The music is also good, and recognizable guest stars this season include Greg Germann and Rick Springfield.  Season One even has a great finale/cliffhanger.Special features on this DVD set include promos, deleted scenes, a gag reel, and features on the show's theme song, on life in Hawaii, on comparisons to the original show, and on the production of the series.It seems that most of the time (we can all think of examples), when a network remakes a show it is far inferior to the original version.  But with its great writing, technology, action, and superb cinematography of Hawaii, this new iteration of "Hawaii Five-0" is even a little bit better than its predecessor, great as it was.  One thing both versions have in common, though, is the best theme song in television history.

The subject of dreams is one that interests almost everyone, and we have all had dreams that seem incomprehensible.  This 2014 page-a-day calendar features interpretations of dreams by Gustavus Hindman Miller.  Hundreds of topics are covered in areas as diverse as clouds, singing and music, parachutes, types of food, types of animals, and much more.I've never heard of Miller and don't know his credentials--some of the interpretations seem believable, but others seem counterintuitive and skepticism should be especially reserved for the offerings here that assert that dreams can predict your future.  Even the weird interpretations here make entertaining reading, though, and I look forward to working through this calendar this year.

2014 marks the centennial of World War I, a cataclysmic event in European history still viewed with great regret in the early twenty-first century.  This calendar looks back on that conflict--each month of the calendar features a black-and-white picture related to the war.  Also, each date contains a "this day in history" factoid about events that happened during the war, but there is still ample room on each date to jot down birthday, anniversary, and appointment reminders, making the calendar a great choice for history buffs.

Claudia Hammond notes that the word 'time' is used more frequently than any other noun in the English language.  The concept of time is central to how we live in Western culture today, and "Time Warped" is a look at how we perceive time and at the impact it has on our lives.Hammond looks at the role of the brain in time perception, noting effects such as the perceived slowing of time during episodes of fear or illness.  She notes the differences in how people organize time in their mind--some people view the months of the year in circular fashion as with a clock, while others view them in the form of a line; some see themselves as moving through time, while others see time as moving toward them.It is frequently observed that time seems to speed up as one gets older--the author examines this phenomenon and why most people can recall their lives from ages 15 to 25 more vividly than they can any other period.  Time perception can also be skewed by vacations and periods of sickness, and the author also covers the topic of why we often underestimate the amount of time that has passed since events from the past.It is a mark of human nature to be too optimistic with respect to our futures, and Hammond brings up the example of our underestimating the amount of time we will need to finish projects.  The author notes how much wonderful or catastrophic events have on our long-term happiness and opines on whether we recall positive or negative events from the past more vividly.Hammond even takes up the topic of whether animals can remember things, and closes this fascinating volume by offering suggestions to problems that the issue of time poses in people's lives.

We live in an era of 24-hour cable news and instant news via the Internet.  Pundits and journalists are more likely than ever to assert that even minor events during presidential campaigns are "game-changers" that will decide the contest.  But in "The Gamble," authors John Sides and Lynn Vavreck demonstrate that most elections are quite stable, proceeding according to the underlying fundamentals of campaigns that to a great extent are baked in the cake many months before voters head to the polls.The authors take a "Moneyball" approach to primaries and general elections, describing what does and does not move votes and using many tables, charts, graphs, and scatter plots to illustrate their assertions.  Sides and Vavreck rightly note that conditions in the country matter infinitely more to the outcome of elections than do campaign tactics, but they may assign a bit too much emphasis to the state of the election-year economy--one can think of exceptions such as 1968, when the economy was churning along but a quagmire in Vietnam, social unrest at home, and a deeply divided party cost the incumbent Democrats the White House.Sides and Vavreck recount the 2012 Republican primary race, discussing the "invisible primary" that takes place long before Iowa and New Hampshire and the role of endorsements of candidates by party leaders--I never really thought that such endorsements mattered much, but the authors look at history to show what having a great number of endorsements tends to predict for a candidate.  They also note that primaries operate according to fundamentals just as general elections do."The Gamble" shows that general-election campaigns do matter, but because both parties typically nominate decent candidates with professional campaign personnel, the efforts of the two campaigns tend to cancel each other out for the most part.  Elections operate according to fundamentals--the authors use math to show just how little gaffes, advertising, debates, the number of campaign offices across the country, and even events like Hurricane Sandy really move the needle, and appendices at the back of the book show the math the authors used to arrive at their conclusions.  The last true game-changer for the 2012 election was likely the capture of Osama bin Laden 18 months prior to Election Day.It is commonly thought that Romney lost mainly due to demographics, but the authors again use math to show just how little some of the events that were said to mobilize certain demographic groups on Obama's behalf really mattered.  Also shown is why some of the Dutch-uncle advice offered to the GOP in the days after the election is simply off-base and why long-term realignments do not really exist, the latter point also made in Sean Trende's brilliant The Lost Majority.The message of "The Gamble" is reassuring in that it shows that voters are adept at filtering out much of the "noise" of campaigns and for the most part focus in on large issues.  It rebuts many of the hoary myths concerning how elections work and is vital reading for anyone seriously interested in presidential elections.

1991 was one of the wettest years in Texas history, and it was capped off in mid-to-late December by one of the worst flooding events ever in the Lone Star State.  Thirteen lives were lost due to the floods, and property losses totaled $100 million.  Large areas of the state received 5 inches of rain from December 18 to 23, a few areas saw 10 inches, and one location near San Antonio was deluged with 17.This report of the disaster compiled by the National Weather Service contains abundant maps and tables and describes the meteorological conditions that led to the heavy rains.  Different forecast models made different predictions about where the rain would be heaviest and about river and crest forecasts, and the report shows how the models fared.There is an appendix that contains all of the flash flood statements, watches, and warnings issued by the local NWS forecast offices across the state, so the reader can follow the flood event area by area.  There are also accounts of some of the fatalities, including an unbelievable story about how many stalled cars one woman passed before she still decided to cross multiple barricades and drive into a flooded area in Bosque County.The media gave the National Weather Service high ratings for disseminating timely warnings, and the report states that there was a great degree of professionalism in the coordination efforts between the NWS and television and radio stations and newspapers.  NWS officials met after the flood event and discussed data collection and other issues and made recommendations on what could be done better in similar events in the future.Also included is a map showing which counties were declared disaster areas--I either forgot or never knew that my home county was so declared.  The rains didn't seem life-threatening in my immediate area, although I recall driving from Tolar to Granbury during the event and seeing asphalt on U.S. 377 start to be chipped away from the road due to the water.  Things were certainly worse elsewhere in the state, and Southeast Texas was plagued by river flooding even into January 1992.  This thorough report contains just about anything someone would want to know about this historic Texas flood event.

Late in 1991, "Smells Like Teen Spirit" began blasting from CD players, boom boxes, and car radios all over America and all around the world.  It was the initial song of "Nevermind," the Nirvana album that was a true landmark of the rock era in that it changed the music scene as few if any other albums of the last four decades has.But this collection of pop-punk-metal is strong from top to bottom and much more than its most famous song.  "Come As You Are" was another Top 40 hit, "On a Plain" is three-plus minutes of concentrated joy and power, "Something in the Way" is a great ballad that sounds like something (the music, if not the lyrics) the Beach Boys might have written had they hung out for a few rainy winter days in the Pacific Northwest, and the cool distortions on "Drain You" even hint of psychedelia.Rolling Stone named "Nevermind" one of the 20 best of albums the rock era and even the Library of Congress recognized it as significant.  "Nevermind" continues to be discovered by teenagers today and to be viewed as a classic more than two decades after its release.

I have bought a lot of mattress pads over my lifetime.  Most of them are practically what you would have to call "disposable" since they often don't even survive one washing and rarely two washings.  The sides are usually made from non-woven fabric, similar to what is used for interfacings and the bottoms of box springs.  The top portion is usually also polyester, and certainly is unpleasant to touch if you have dry, calloused hands like mine.This one is nothing like those mattress pads, even though it is still what one would call a budget-wise mattress pad.  It's cotton, and while it may not be high thread count fabric, it still is much more pleasant to touch than those polyester ones are.  It's quilted, and not super plush, but I'm not buying mattress pads for their cushioning ability--I want one to protect the expensive mattress below it.I didn't want to spend a lot on this mattress pad, as the mattress itself will be going away as soon as we finish some home renovation projects and put up our new bed.  It didn't make sense to spend a lot on a mattress pad that we won't use over a few months at the most.  At the same time, we have an aging dog that sometimes manages to get onto the bed, and that usually results in all of the bedding, including the mattress pad, needing to be washed.  The old pad died, and we had to have a new one to protect the mattress.  (The dog is very old and in failing health.  Mattresses don't have the same emotional ties that our aging pet has.  At the same time, she isn't supposed to get on the bed, and tends to leak from one end or the other...so I need to be able to wash everything.)I'm super impressed with this mattress pad.  It does the job it is supposed to.  It's not waterproof, but we have a waterproof layer--this is to make sure we're not sweating with just a sheet between us and impervious layer.  We're comfortable, I feel as though things can be safely washed and dried, and life is good.  It keeps things on budget and simple.  At its current price, it is VERY budget friendly.I did purchase this with a small promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest opinion, and this one is no different.

This is a very nice size wok, and it is HEAVY.  It's a wok to make a statement with, and nobody will ever even think they can take it lightly.I've used a lot of cast iron in my life.  I love the stuff, and usually prefer to haunt flea markets and antique shops for the old stuff.  It's smooth and dense.  This isn't that kind of cast iron, but then again, not many cowboys were cooking with woks on an open fire either.Modern cast iron arrives with a rough surface.  It may SAY it is pre-seasoned, but I have yet to find one that really was.  Seasoning takes time, and this wok comes with directions on how to do just that.  Even better, the directions are clear and easy to understand, and that is nearly an amazing achievement in itself these days.That seasoning that will turn this into an awesome wok will take months, most likely.  Essentially, it's like a cooked on layer of old oil, which sounds gross but really isn't.  I'll cook a lot of oily things in this, washing it only with water, and reseasoning it often until it gets "pretty good".  Then, my personal favorite way to go from "pretty good" to totally awesome is to bake a loaf of bread in the cast iron.  Since this wok is pretty big, that's going to be a pretty big loaf of bread!Good cast iron is expensive.  I haven't used this enough to know if I will call it "good" or not yet, but it shows every sign of having that potential.  It's the seasoning that ultimately makes the cast iron work, and that is my responsibility.  There is also no quick fix to get it, no "Instant Seasoning Spray" either.  Everybody has their own favored methods of doing it--mine happens to favor shortening or lard for the job over soybean oil.  I think it does a better job with less "gunkiness".  A new pan also takes repeated seasonings before it gets truly thoroughly seasoned, and until it reaches that point, only oily foods are going to work or everything will stick, requiring scouring to remove it along with previous coats of seasoning.So, if you want instant non-stick, forget cast iron.  Buy a coated pan that you throw away in 3-9 months because it is peeling.  If you want a pan to last decades (or longer) and are willing to spend the time taking care of it, then buy cast iron.  This wok is a great shape for stir frying or deep frying.  It has handles to make lifting and moving it easier, as well as a solid disk on the bottom to make it more stable on traditional stoves than a curved bottom is.  If you have ever used a wok, you know how the heat varies from the center up the sides (hot to cooler).  The rough surface makes the foods that you push up the sides stick to the cooler area to cook it more slowly or just keep it hot while other pieces are cooking in the hotter portion, which helps everything be done and hot at the same time.  If you are deep frying, the shape concentrates the oil in the center, so you actually need less oil to achieve the same effect.  I use a wok for a LOT of things, not just Asian style cooking.  It's also my go-to all purpose pan for camping--the shape manages everything from scrambled eggs to fried chicken to a creamy sauce and on over to fry bread.I haven't ever seen a better cast iron wok than this one from Utopia Kitchen.  I've looked at about every style of cast iron pan, hoping to find one similar to one that belonged to my granddad and dated from the 1800s.  It was deeper than a wok, but had the same curved bottom, as though a wok and a dutch oven had a child, but nobody makes one, and I've not found one at an antique shop either.  This is as close as I can get, and I am pleased with it even though I haven't had it long.  The price is VERY reasonable for a cast iron pan of this size and quality.  I was fortunate enough to be offered a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews always are my honest opinion, but this has to be one of my favorites of the year.  Just remember to read the directions, as well as realizing that seasoning is an ongoing process, even though this is "pre-seasoned", that doesn't mean you don't have some work to do before it's fully seasoned, and that it will require upkeep for its entire life.

In the past, I had only used manual pepper grinders.  The idea of a battery powered one was intriguing, as some days, it's pretty tough to manage the grinding of pepper/salt with a manual grinder.I like this grinder, but I'm not ready to get rid of my manual grinders.It just doesn't grind much pepper at a time, which probably helps to prevent over-seasoning things, but it totally sucks when I need a half teaspoon right now for a recipe.  I would go insane if I had to use this for cooking in the kitchen.So, it's a nice looking grinder, guests love it, and I don't have to love it all the time.  It makes me crazy that it takes SIX batteries to operate it.  It's large, easy for them to spot on the table, and it apparently impresses.  Since I'm not impressed often when it's just my hubby and I for dinner, I can use my favorite hand operated mills and grimace at the pain.My overall opinion is that it is probably great for people  who aren't crazy users of pepper and don't mind that it is a miser when it comes to dispensing pepper.  It is attractive, and both peppercorns and batteries will probably last a fair amount of time.I purchased this with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.

These are very nice rather orangish red silicone muffin pans, one in regular size, and the other in mini size.  the mini size is a bit wider and shallower than the mini-muffin metal pan I have, but seems to hold about the same amount.  The wider but shallower shape is a great boon to those who love the muffin tops--there is more top per muffin this way.From what I have learned about silicone pans is that one should never use non-stick sprays on them, as it causes them to get a build up of something we'll use the not-so-scientific term of calling "gunk".  Baked goods seem to pop right out of the pans without anything so why bother anyhow?These pans bake muffins nicely, and they remove easily.  If I do have any that seem reluctant to separate from their silicone cup, I simply let them stand on the counter for a few minutes, which helps the muffin/cupcake steam some, and then it will pop out nicely.  It's also a good idea to use a baking sheet under them, mostly because they lack the structural strength to support themselves and the batter or cakes inside of them.These aren't my first silicone muffin pans, but my old ones had been ruined by the non-stick sprays I had used on them.  Since I know better now, I anticipate a longer useful lifespan for these cupcake pans than I had for my previous set.I purchased these cupcake pans with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews always reflect my honest opinion, and this one is no different.

This is absolutely the best made shoulder sling bag I have seen.  It's rather unisex, so I think it would work as a man-bag as well, and if nothing else, shouldn't give any male an overdose of estrogen to carry it for someone.It has a ton of zippers with compartments, giving you ample locations to sort things, and the clip is metal, not plastic, to hold the upper flap in place.  It's adjustable, so it can fit anyone from a petite female to a burly guy, and that includes well rounded grandmas like me.  Made of nylon, it will likely repel most dirt and moisture without effort too, which will add a great deal to the bag's longevity.  I could sling it over one shoulder to have it hang in the front, or the opposite shoulder to have it on my back, or just carry it by the handle--it's fairly versatile in how you choose to use it.All of the seams seemed well stitched, the materials from which it was made appeared to be of very good quality as well.  It is marked as made in China, but seems to be well made with good  quality control.  Overall, this is a very nice bag, whether you are purchasing it to keep or as a gift for someone else.  It has a certain fashion flare with its pseudo-military decoration and imprint, as well as its color.I purchased this bag with a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review.  Since all of my reviews are always my honest opinion, this one is no different.  This is genuinely a very well made bag.

I've bought other frothers before, since I happen to despise cleaning the spouts on the steam frothers that most home espresso makers have.  Since I now use an Aeropress for my coffees, I obviously don't have that option.  If I wanted frothy tops, I was stuck with the canned whip cream option.This little frother has a much slimmer handle/motor section than any I had had in the past.  It also came with a neat little bracket to hold it, along with two screws, to allow it to be mounted on the wall or cabinet.  That was unexpected--I hadn't noticed that when I had purchased the frother.  I just have to wait--we're midway through our kitchen renovations and it's NOT a good time to add anything that I want to keep.  (Demolition will continue later this week.)With two AAA batteries (we use Amazon Basics rechargeables) I had instant frothy milk, at a much lower calorie level than canned whipping cream too.  I can also make some frothy hot chocolate for my granddaughter, scoring many "cool" points in the eyes of a five year old.  Even strawberry flavored milk can be frothed in the glass, increasing its visual appeal and therefore its drink-ability in the eyes of a child.  Overall, this is an easy way to add a bit of whimsy and fun to our drinks.I did purchase this with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest opinion, and this one is no different.

We are huge coffee drinkers, but despite our addiction, our usual blend is Folgers, in Black Silk, 100% Columbian, or Classic Roast.  We do indulge in the occasional bag of whole bean coffee, which on our budget, is outrageously expensive.  (Pre-ground name brand coffee is about $8 per pound in the larger cans, while gourmet beans run about $15+ per pound.)  That means when we buy coffee beans, they had best be good.Of course, buying the beans is the least of it.  They need to be used before they become stale too.  They need ground properly, without overheating them to destroy the flavor.  Then, they need brewed.We're prepared for that too.  I have a beautiful little hand mill that is ideal for grinding enough coffee for us each to have a large cup.  We have our preferred single serve brewers too--me & my Aeropress, hubby & his silicone drip pour over coffee maker.  We use a T-Fal cordless tea kettle for our hot water, it's faster than even a microwave!  So I opened the bag, filled the little grinder (that's the hardest part!) and started cranking.  For the record, one full load of beans in our coffee grinder is more than enough for two large mugs of strong coffee.I then measured out the usual amount of coffee for each brewer, and poured in the water to brew as usual.  In a minute or so, I had two beautiful mugs of freshly brewed coffee.On the aroma front, this was incredibly aromatic from the moment I opened the box it arrived in.  I didn't crack the seal on the bag until I was about to grind and brew our coffee though, and when I did, the aroma filled the entire kitchen.  It was that quintessential wake up kind of smell, intense and dark, full of expectations.  In the drip brewer, I could actually see the oils rising up from the grounds on the top of the mixture.Freshly brewed in the mug, it didn't have any of that.  In fact, the aroma was anything but enticing, and that was a bit perplexing.  I then added my creamer, sugar, and milk as usual, stirring it to blend, and doctored the hubby's coffee the way her prefers it with just creamer & milk.  The aroma improved, which was even MORE confusing.I delayed that tasting until I was sitting down with my mug, sticking to my normal post-dinner routine.  Then, the tasting started.  it is a dark, rich coffee, although the coffee seemed lighter in color and weaker bodied than what I was accustomed to seeing.  It's smooth, and I did really like it.But that was it.I didn't get rich quick.  I didn't even get richer.  Nothing happened at all.  I just sat there and enjoyed an evening cup of coffee that was very good.  I really enjoyed it, and it was a decadent kind of pleasure, since I knew that this was freshly ground coffee that I had just brewed for our evening coffee.  I yawned several times as I sipped the brew though.I'm not sure that it has any more caffeine than our usual coffee does, but thankfully, coffee does not give either of us insomnia.  We often have coffee before bed, and then sleep like logs all night.  I don't use coffee for more energy, although I do think it helps me be much more focused.All I can say is that it is a delicious coffee, although I was hoping for the side effect of wealth to occur, I'm really not surprised that it didn't.  I feel good about drinking it because it IS shade grown, organic and fair trade.  Those are all great features that I'm reasonably sure that I'm NOT getting with a can of Folgers.  It's a reasonably priced bag of coffee as well, running about the same as other premium whole bean coffees, including some that aren't Fair Trade or organic.I was fortunate enough to be able to buy this with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my unbiased and honest opinion, and this one is no different.  We really did like this coffee a great deal, and we really didn't get rich quick by drinking it.  Still, it was a lovely coffee experience that we have enjoyed immensely, and will continue to enjoy until the bag is empty.

This was a rather disappointing kit.  It comes with a small bottle of distilled white vinegar, a packet of flaked cheese salt, a small package of citric acid, a thermometer, some sisal twine, and a piece of cheese cloth, all in a small box with some straw-like stuff at the bottom.  The cheesecloth has a lot of threads and straw bits stuck to the outer side, which makes you wonder how much cleaning you'll have to do of the fabric before using it.  There is also a laminated card with the directions, which are very minimal.  Nothing tells me what to do with the citric acid, leaving me wondering  what it was included for.  I could actually get the directions online in a better written form.I haven't made the cheese, which calls for two quarts of milk, as I just got the box and opened it anxiously.  I really expected something more, I guess.  This was one of the most disappointing DIY kits I have ever bought.I had originally intended this as something to do with my 5 year old granddaughter, who loves cheese.  I'll probably do this cheese with her, but I'll look for another brand for more elaborate cheesemaking projects, and I certainly wouldn't give a kit from this brand after this one disappointed me.  (I have given cheese making kits, along with other kits catering to the DIY spirit in the past, as gifts for a variety of occasions.)I purchased this kit with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest opinion, and this one is no different.

I am not an expert artist.  I do like to do the occasional drawing, as well as use adult coloring books.  I wasn't sure about these pencils, as I had been using cheap *Mart ones, and was uncertain about buying more expensive ones.I love these, once I confiscated them back from my husband, who immediately hauled these off into his private stash of drawing supplies.  He obviously liked them too.  I can't compare them to "good" pencils, since I'm relatively new to the whole colored pencil world.  I just like them, both as just a plain colored pencil and in conjunction with some water for the water color effect.I purchased these with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I read silicone tea kettle, and I was absolutely certain that it was a poorly written description.  There was no way a tea kettle could be made of silicone, I thought.I was wrong.This has a metal base, which allows it to be used over a flame to heat the kettle.  I'd not want to have flames shooting up the sides onto the silicone, but it does work.  That makes this a fantastic camping/road trip companion to use in conjunction with a camp stove.  I wouldn't recommend using this over a campfire, btw.  It's too hard to control where the flames and heat hit with an open fire.  I did try this with a propane and a butane stove.  I'd also feel comfortable using this with an alcohol or other liquid fuel stove.It's not ultra-light by any means.  It IS ultra compact, however, and sometimes, space is as important as weight.  It holds enough water to prepare a couple of average freeze dried meals or a couple of mugs of coffee/tea/cocoa.  I absolutely love this thing, and hope it lasts a long time.I did purchase this with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.  I really DO love this thing!

There's a lot to love with this set.  They are easy to hang onto, even if you have arthritis in your hands.  They are very sharp and do the exact task that they are intended to do.  There's a lot to love and no cons at all.  They are even reasonably priced.I tested them out on peeling sweet potatoes, which are the most difficult thing I know of to peel.  They peeled like paper off of butter.  I was amazed.  If they can manage a sweet potato, other vegetables won't even be a challenge.I purchased these with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.

I'm not sure what the problem is, but either the directions are inaccurate or the device is not working correctly.  I have tried many times over a period of days to set this gadget, and failed miserably.  I haven't even been able to set the time yet.  I'm so frustrated with it that I'm going to take it to my daughter, with the directions, and see if SHE can figure out how to set the danged thing.Maybe I'm having a "senior moment" but I honestly don't think it should be this complicated to try and set a pedometer.  It's been years since I have used one, but I sure don't remember it being this difficult in the past.Setting the device aside, it comes with a lanyard that is easy to attach.  It also has a cute little clip that it can slide into to attach it to your waistband or belt.  I like the thing, if I could figure out how to work it.  Apparently, more expensive brands are a lot less complicated to set up.  I may just have to give up the idea of using an inexpensive one.I purchased this with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion and this one is no different.

I got these for my husband to use as lounging/sleeping pants.  As jersey goes, these are very heavy weight, much heavier than most of the inexpensive ones that I have bought in the past.  For him, that's a good thing, as he is always cold.I got these in the charcoal gray, and they seem well made.  We haven't had them long enough to know how durable they will be after being washed a number of times or whether they will end up pilling like many jersey pants do.  If there are any problems, I'll update the review to indicate that.  So far, we're thrilled with them, mostly because if HE is happy, so am I.I did purchase these with a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, as is this one.  They are genuinely well made pants for lounging in, and reasonably priced as well.

These are brightly colored, just like in the photo with the description.  Lightweight, fairly shallow, they are made of plastic like many ash trays.  I suspect that like others of this type, they will break if they get knocked off of a table and hit a hard floor.In the meantime, they are compact, cute ash trays.  They are small enough to not make a huge statement about smoking, brightly colored enough that they are easy to pick out whether they are being used inside or outside, and easily cleaned.  We haven't had these long enough that I can say that they are extremely durable or not.  Their light weight makes me rather dubious about that durability.They could be a five star product, but at the current price, with an imprint of "Classic Star Products" on the side of the ashtray, I think they are over priced and too similar to dollar store products.  I purchased these with a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review, but if I had paid full price, I would have been less-than-happy.  The imprint makes them look like a cheap promotional item.

I love this "blanket"!For those who are familiar with them, the mats sold to RVers and often used by those attending outdoor events such as dog shows are very similar to this "blanket" only those mats are larger than this blanket.  I didn't buy this blanket with any intention of using it as a "picnic blanket".  I wanted it to serve as a rug inside our tent, and for this purpose it is ideal, while the larger ones sold in RV stores are too big for using in the tent.  I'm no expert on manmade fiber, but my description of it is that it is a plastic fiber that has been woven into a mat.  This mat is impervious to dirt and water, and cleans by just hosing it off and letting it air dry.  Don't even think about putting this into a washing machine, as it will ruin it.As for our using it inside the tent, it will act as both a cushion and an insulating layer, so even when we are camping in cold weather, our feet won't instantly turn into foot-cicles when we go to get up out of our cots.  It also protects the floor from damage (we use a tarp under the tent as a foot print to keep moisture migration to a minimum too.)  When using portable furniture with small feet, it's best to stick a square of cardboard or something under the feet to prevent them from damaging this blanket.For using it outside, it is a great item to use to sit or lay on to keep the grass, dew, and dirt away from you.  It's a great floor under a shade too, for the same reasons.  The size of this blanket means that it is a much smaller bundle to take along than one of the large mats, and it has much more convenient velcro-and-strap closure, along with handles.  The convenient stakes that are included with it will keep it from shifting position when outdoors as well.Our granddaughter LOVES going to the beach, but grandma & grandpa just aren't so crazy about sitting in the sand, and it ends up in everything, from our shoes to a can of soda.  Forget even thinking about eating there--everything ends up gritty.  As for carrying large, bulky, and heavy items from the parking area to the beach, we just aren't so thrilled with that either.  Enter this compact and lightweight blanket--it's perfect for those beach events when we grab a fast food meal and make one little girl VERY happy.  I'm happy because we scored "cool" points with our pint-sized princess too.  When the beach trip is over, the sand shakes out without any problems, and if it's really persistent, a blast from the hose when we get home takes care of it in short order.I can't say enough good stuff about this miraculous little blanket except it would not work well to wrap up in after a swim in the water--it really is best used strictly as a mat to sit or lay on.I did purchase this picnic blanket with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this review is no different.

This is a really cute retractable lead.  It's easy to hold, works well with the 15 lb. dog I use it with too.  My only complaint is that the clip on the lead is a bit large for small dogs' collars, ,which makes it tricky to attach to the collar with a bouncing dog that is anxious to get out the door.When we're outside, she can move around without the lead dragging on the ground, getting caught on her legs, or worse yet, getting peed on.  It extends out easily to let her feel as though she has plenty of room to roam, yet when I need to stop her from going any further, the button presses easily to lock the lead.  I am really pleased with the ease of using this leash, although it won't replace the traditional kind entirely.  This type of leash is fantastic in our familiar yard, where it's unlikely that someone is going to suddenly approach us.  I've found that retractable leads aren't as much fun or as easy to use when walking in a park where there are lots of pedestrians and other dogs, mostly because of safety concerns.  In campgrounds, with the leash restrictions of 6 feet (the usual length allowed) this leash also fails to meet the approval of rangers, and it's just a lot easier to use a traditional 6 foot lead.  Still, this one is fun when we're playing in our unfenced yard, and it is compact, does not tangle, and the bright color makes it easy to spot even if someone has failed to put it where it is supposed to be.

Nylabone products are always high quality, but not all dogs like all of their chewing products, despite the additional safety of using a Nylabone instead of a traditional product such as antler.  We presented this antler to a devout 10 month old dachshund mix chewing machine.  She chews it, but still prefers furniture, clothing, bedding, etc. over this chew toy.  The biggest advantage of offering her this toy is that it is less likely to present a choking hazard.She's got a lot of other chew toys, but most of them require supervision, as she is apt to chew off chunks.  When she doesn't have one of these chew toys, she's going to be chewing something else that she has managed to get access to, such as bedding (our bed, not hers) or clothing or furniture.  Even in her crate, she has what I swear is a prehensile muzzle and manages to get things that I would have sworn were impossible for her to get access to.  Desperation means that she has to have SOMETHING in there to chew on when we have to leave the house, and I'd far rather take my chances with a Nylabone than whatever that prehensile muzzle manages to reach.This is a large Nylabone product, suitable for larger dogs.  She's a 10 lb. puppy, so I'm reasonably confident that she won't manage to chew off a chunk to choke on, even when she is crated when we have to be away all day.  (No, crates are not cruel when used appropriately--imagine what kind of injury she could inflict on herself if she had free run of the house all day!)I just wish she was a bit more enthusiastic about this chew.  Right now, quilts are rating high on their chewing pleasure in her book (maybe it's the batting inside?) along with electronics wires (let's not discuss how many sets of earphones, ear buds, etc. she has eaten)  If she had even a tenth of the enthusiasm for this antler that she does for "unauthorized" items, I'd be thrilled.  However, the only thing she has chewed enthusiastically without having it taken away because of potential choking has been cow hooves.  I'm just hoping that over the next few days, she gets a bit more enthusiastic about this antler toy.  It's sort of if-that's-all-i-can-reach-then-i-will-chew-on-it thing right now.  She's the most enthusiastic and persistent chewer I have ever had.This isn't a "cheap" chew toy.  I just wish she was more enthusiastic about it, as I do generally like Nylabone products and regard them as far safer than many so-called "edible" chews such as rawhide.  They are also more sanitary than raw bones, with fewer odors to offend the humans.  Oh and less slimy--many natural chewing products are slimy to the touch, and this one doesn't get slimy after she has chewed on it for a while.I'm going to have to keep looking for a chew toy that she isn't going to quickly destroy but that she really likes to gnaw on.  I have no idea what will thrill her in the end, but I hope its not a collar, leash, harness, etc. since I'm getting tired of purchasing new ones to replace the ones she has eaten.

I really LIKE these pillow cases.  They are smooth and feel very soft & cool to the skin.  I like the feel of cotton, and these feel like the high thread count ones I have, but at a far lower price than those were.They are snow white, and while they may not match your linens, there is something cloud like about sleeping with a pillowcase that is snow white.  They are also very spacious in size.  I haven't tried them with a king size pillow, but they look like they may well fit a king pillow as well.  They really DO seem large, whether on a My Pillow pillow or another brand of pillow.I have not had them long enough to know how they will withstand the normal stress of being a pillow case in our house with repeated washings.  They seem well made and with high quality fabric, which goes a long ways towards washing well over time.  If they fail at some point, I'll update my review.  As for my initial opinion, they are very nice pillow cases that are comfy to sleep with .I did purchase these pillow cases with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews always reflect my honest and unbiased opinion, and this review is no different.

This pillow arrives rolled up in a compact bolster-like roll.  Once opened, it's a rather floppy underfilled pillow, but the magic has yet to occur.The directions have you putting it in the dryer for fifteen minutes, and when it comes out, it's a fluffy, well filled pillow.  It's also supposed to be a machine washable and dryable pillow, a great asset to extending a pillow's life.  I paired it with My Pillow's pillow case and was impressed at how comfortable it felt.I haven't had it long enough to make a determination about how well I will like it to actually sleep with on a regular basis.  That's going to take a few weeks, so I will have to update the review later.  My initial reaction was that it WAS comfortable, but I am a devout fan of feather/down pillows so that they can be scrunched into the perfect shape.  My complaint about those pillows is that sometimes I wake up during the night with a flat pillow that has to be refluffed/scrunched to support my head and neck.  This pillow may alleviate that complaint during the night.  (I'm hoping anyhow!)I hate a "hot" pillow, especially in our long steamy summers.  That has had me discard many pillows in the past, allowing them to migrate to my husband's side of the bed (he's always cold) or the spare bedroom.  Even feather pillows will often need flipped during the night to allow me to use the "cool" side.  I'm curious about how I will react to this pillow over time, but so far, it seems comfortable.I did purchase this pillow with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.UPDATE: After using this for several nights, I still like the pillow, but I do have some additional things to say.  It is very cool to sleep on, and in cooler weather, almost uncomfortably cool.  I've never had a pillow that breathed this well, and I'm accustomed to the level of warmth a feather/down pillow gives.  This is great on hot flash occasions though!  The other observation that I have made is that it lacks the necessary firmness for a side sleeper like me.  I have awakened during the night several times to find that my neck was aching and the pillow was just too flat to support my head and neck while sleeping, although it is wonderful when I am laying on my back.  I suspect that this pillow may end up on the other side of the bed with my husband because of this.

There is a lot to love with this utensil set.The spatula, spoonula, cooking spoon, and ladles are all entirely smooth surfaced, with no nooks, crannies, or seams to hide bacteria or fungi.  That's great news when you are trying to make sure you aren't going to make anyone sick with your cooking too!  It also means that they are easy to clean.  The tongs do have seams, as only the tips are coated with the silicone.  That should be just fine, as tongs are typically used to pickup or turn foods, rather than mixing, stirring, or serving liquid-y foods.  It means that for the first time, I have tongs that are safe to use with non-stick cookware!Silicone means that these utensils are heat/cold resistant, won't melt with normal use, and can be safely washed in the dishwasher or even sterilized in boiling water.  That means that these are safe to use, even when preparing food for someone with an impaired immune system.  It means that they will last far longer than the cheap nylon ones that melt at about 300 degrees F.They are more expensive than the dollar store versions, but they are much higher quality and will last hundreds of times longer.  I can't count the number of times that a dollar store utensil has failed within a week and landed in the trash!The turning spatula is a bit straight for my tastes, as well as a tad thick at the edge.  I haven't tried it with pancakes, crepes, etc. yet, so I'm not sure how well it will actually perform when put to the test with that type of food.  The spatula and spoonula are both full sized, capable of handling the average bowl of cake or cookie batter.  The ladles, which another reviewer stated were small, are a bit smaller than the usual sizes seen.  They seem ideal for ladling out sauces and gravies, even if they are a bit undersized for big bowls of hearty soups and stews.  Maybe they will encourage us all to eat a bit less?The bright pink color is radically different from most utensils.  It's cute and different.  It's a touch of whimsical femininity in an unexpected place, and I like that.  I usually use a sturdy plastic planter pot for a utensil container--I may have to find one in white and do a bit of DIY trimming on it with a hot glue gun and some ruffled lace or ribbon just to build on the whimsy these bright pink utensils have brought into my very utilitarian kitchen.I did purchase these utensils using a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.  These are genuinely good utensils that I am proud to use and have in my kitchen.

This absolutely was not met with a great  deal of excitement from our dogs.  Maybe it was the density of my skull, but I actually thought this was pouches of food similar to the canned foods of the same flavor.It's not.It's pouches of soft chewy kibble.Our dogs looked at us when they were presented with this mixed with their regular kibble, convinced that we had lost our minds.  They ate it, but it didn't meet their expectations of wet canned food mixed with kibble.  We have three dogs, all different sizes, and a granddog that happens to be staying with us that is still yet another size.  Not one of them were thrilled with it.  One actually had a tantrum and dumped her food dish upside down (that's her thing when meals are disappointing.)While some dogs may like this and find the addition of these "soft meaty" pieces appealing, ours did not.  We would not purchase this again as a food additive.

I really like these cups, except for one issue.  They are just too small.Like many other people, I see the measurements, and it doesn't really create an accurate mental picture.  I had thought that these would be ideal for cocoa, tea, and coffee when camping, and best of all, we'd no longer have burnt lips from a scalding hot metal cup rim.Since we use an Aeropress for our coffee, I knew I'd have to carry at least one rigid cup to use for brewing, as these cups obviously cannot withstand the pressure from pressing down on the Aeropress to brew our coffee.  That isn't a real big deal--I often carry a metal cup to use for that purpose when we are on a road trip.  The real problem is found in that one cup of brewed coffee would probably fill two of these folding cups.  They just aren't going to hold a cup of anything.It's a great idea.  It works well if you brew your beverage in a different container and then dole it out.  They are a great size for little hands, but we just don't have a lot of kids (only one very spoiled granddaughter) to take on camping trips with us.  So leaving the size alone, let's move onto their great qualities.They aren't going to cool off as fast as a metal cup, so that means your hot beverage will stay hot longer, even without a lid or any thermal qualities.  They also aren't going to get hot as fast, so if your drink is cold, it will stay cold long enough to finish it for the same reason.  They are lightweight and compact too.  These collapsible cups also will clean well, don't absorb odors and flavors (that's very important since spiced chai flavored coffee is never going to win awards with me!) and are able to resist both cold and heat while remaining flexible and usable.  The handle is ingenious and really makes the difference in ease of use.To unfold them is an easy and intuitive process, and then the handle flips around to press against a small raised area on the cup's lower ring, creating a reasonably sturdy handle connection.  There is a small square of stiffer silicone material that forms the base, and it seems reasonably secure when standing on a table with liquid in the cup.  Obviously, since they are made of a single piece of silicone (except for the handle), they don't leak either.If they were about twice as big, they'd be a five star product.  That is literally their sole negative, that they don't hold enough for most adults.I purchased these with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.  These are really convenient cups, although they are very small for most adults.

The description of this holder is not particularly clear, so I'm going to start off this review with some clarification.The base is like a small steel bearing with a base that can be attached to your dash or desk.  Then, there is a magnetic disk that sticks to that bearing like nothing I could believe.  Each of  your devices that you wish to use with this then gets a metallic disk, which allows you to use the mount to hold them securely on the mount.  The magnet can be slid around to get the perfect angle, but is darn near impossible to pull off of that bearing.  Like a ball-and-socket joint, there is a LOT of flexibility in position so you get that perfect angle.There is nothing to dislike.  It works and works well.I did purchase this with a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.

These are absolutely lovely silicone utensils.  Completely coated (and not a thin coat either) so that there are no hidden crevices or obscure joints to hold molds, mildew or bacteria.  The handles are substantial, so that they will stand up to the job of scraping, scooping, mixing or stirring.  They are an ideal set to use with non-stick cookware to ensure that there will be no nicks, scratches, or scrapes on your expensive cookware.  The only one that I'm a bit uncertain about yet is the turning spatula.  It may be a bit thick to use with things such as cookies or pancakes, etc.  I haven't made them recently, so I can't say yes it does work for those or not.Silicone ladles are almost unheard of, and cooking spoons are the same thing.  I have a number of nylon ones, but the handles are suspicious sources of potential bacterial contamination of our food, so I have been wanting to replace them.  (We have a family member with a compromised immune system that is hoping to get an organ transplant so we've become germ-phobic lately.)  I have been looking at kitchen equipment and tools with a whole new perspective lately, and a number of things have had to go away.  I can't even begin to stop gushing how much I love this ladle and cooking spoon.The spatula and spoonula are also full sized, big enough to use with a two or three layer cake batter and not seem ridiculously small.  I have some other silicone utensils that are petite sized, and really are inadequate for many cooking and baking tasks.  These are ALL of substantial size, suitable for use by the family cook.These utensils are a germ-phobic person's friend.  Smooth surfaces without joints means that they can actually be thoroughly cleaned.  Their heat resistance means that they can safely be sterilized too, and also safely make a trip through a dishwasher.  For the aspiring gourmet cook, they are also fantastic utensils for everything from mixing to dividing among dishes.I purchased these with a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this time, I consider myself to have really "scored" on the utensil front.  I sincerely love this set!

I wasn't sure about "mid-rise" panties.  As a granny, my days of preferring hip hugger or bikinis are long gone, and the famous granny panties have taken over my lingerie drawer.  These days, it's all about comfort and I really don't care about "cute" in regards to my underwear anymore.  I was afraid that these would be too low cut for someone who has had her waistline expand to far larger than she would have had  nightmares about in her youth.I was entirely wrong.  For me, these are about ideal, as I don't have a wad of underwear extending above the waist of my pants.  I may not be as stylish as I once was, but at the same time, I have enough sense that I don't want my underwear hanging out of the waistband of my pants.The fabric is VERY thin and cool.  While some may find that a negative, I live in the South where it's usually very hot and humid.  I also do not do well with heat and overheat easily.  These are surprisingly light and cool--it's almost like you have forgotten to put your panties on, they are that comfortable.The waist band is narrow.  Far narrower than my usual preferred brand uses, it's closer to the waistband of my granddaughter's little girl panties.  I'm not sure about that yet.  It hasn't ever "dug in", but it still seems quite narrow.  I would probably prefer a wider band, but this still seems "okay" at least.  The cut of the panties seems to provide "full coverage" without creeping to become wannabe thongs or bagging so that you feel like  you are wearing a diaper.  The crotch is also of sufficient size that it fits well no matter what kind of movement you are indulging in.Overall, I do like these panties.  They are comfortable and wash well.  I'm not sure how they will be in terms of durability yet, but if they start fraying I will revise my review.  In the meantime, I think I may have found my new preferred "granny panties".

When this pizza stone brush arrived on my doorstep, it was packed in a box that was about twice its length.  Before opening it, I'm questioning why anyone would make such a gigantic pizza stone brush.Thankfully, this is not 3 feet long.  It's a large brush, but not that large.  It's bigger than my old one though, which is not a bad thing.  This one also has a scraper blade at the end of the brush to make removal of baked on cheese a bit easier.  It has a loop to hang it, which is a much easier way to store it than by a drawer, as it would have to store diagonally in most drawers because of its length.Brushwise, the brushes are exactly like my old brush, and is a natural fiber.  They are stiff, and do the job well--scouring off bits of baked on dough, burned cornmeal, etc.  Unlike our original brush, this one didn't require us to put in a screw to fix things more firmly.  It's much better made, and costs roughly the same.  That definitely makes it a much better purchase than the one we bought before.The longer handle means that when I'm cleaning the stone and the oven is still hot, my arm is not being cooked.  For me, that's great, since that means that once the oven is cooled completely, it is ready to put away.  (Pizzaque--great oven for the  money, btw.)  I love this new brush!

I got these to work with a iPhone 5 that my son in law uses.  He has hearing issues, but does not use a hearing aid.  He also likes music, mostly older rock and country, and needs to be able to actually hear conversations on his phone, which he depends on for his work.  He's not used headphones, bluetooth devices, or ear buds much in the past, plus he is a real devout cheapskate, so this was a new experience for him entirely.He loves these earphones.  They are comfortable, provide him with very clear audio whether it is music or a phone call, and he is heard well too. He was really impressed with how much better these earphones were compared to the cheap ones from dollar stores or that small town Mart. He actually admitted that there was a noticeable difference, which almost knocked me over to begin with.  (Yes, we have the classic stereotype mother-in-law/son-in-law relationship, which is to say we can conflict over the weather.)Believe me, if he admitted that they were good earphones when I was the one that gave them to him, they are really that good.I did get these with a promotional discount, which meant it was a reduced price or free, in exchange for my honest and unbiased review, which probably contributed to me being generous to my son in law.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different other than my test subject was my son in law.  If you use an iPhone or iPad, they are wonderful.  I did not test them with any of my android or Windows devices, so I don't know if they would or would not work with them.

I got these for my husband, who likes to use Skype on his tablet & phone, his cell phone, and a variety of programs on his laptop, as well as watch movies and listen to music.  In the name of marital peace, with our tastes being radically different, especially late at night, I thought these might spare us some growling about his movie or music.So, he was grinning ear to ear like a 5 year old on Christmas morning when I handed him this small package.  Best of all, these don't come in a ridiculously complex and large package.  (We have obtained some that were really ostentatious, as though we were about to access the crown jewels, not a pair of ear buds!)  He had them open without needing any tools in just a minute and immediately put them to work.He loves them.  His first comment was that they had better volume and sound than most ear buds do.  Considering that these are budget friendly earbuds at just under $12 right now, and we have earbuds that retail for $100 or more, that's a huge compliment!  He also protected them from possible use by me as though they were his most prized possession (okay, it was partly in jest, but he really doesn't want to give up this pair.)They are apparently very comfortable.  He's had them in his ears for some time without complaint, and if they weren't comfortable, I would have heard about it too.  Ear buds, while they may not be as comfortable for long term use or provide as good of an audio experience, are much more convenient to take with you than a pair of earphones.  They are also less obvious to wear when in public, when you may opt for using them for a phone call or to pass the time waiting for an appointment by listening to music or watching a video.While I purchased these with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review, these are well worth the full purchase price too.  It's an excellent pair of ear buds for the money, making them a good choice for a gift too.  They would be ideal for teens and young adults, as well as older adults such as ourselves.  They work well with our android devices, our Kindle Fire tablets, and our laptops.  They are definitely a 5+ star purchase!

I got this in purple, and I liked it.  I put it on our grand dog, and while it wasn't a great fit, I thought it was a workable fit.  Unfortunately, she liked it too, but she liked to chew on it.Within thirty minutes, it was completely in shreds.  Literally nothing more than a few inches long was left of the harness.So, I can't say that it would actually secure a dog for walking on a leash, especially a youngster that is prone to chewing.  I certainly do not suggest letting the dog get out of your line of sight with it on--we should have gotten suspicious when she was  quiet for a bit.The harness has no adjustments for the neck, which meant the harness we bought (size large) was a bit too loose.  She couldn't wiggle forward out of it, but apparently, she could turn around and start chewing in it.  It didn't take long for her to destroy it beyond any possibility of repairing it either.  Granted, she is a 9 month old puppy (dachshund mix), and very agile but she isn't the most houdini-like of dogs either--I have known worse.  Even so, the short life of this harness was a bit disappointing, even if it wasn't the fault of the harness.I did purchase this with a promotional discount in return for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion and this one is no different.

This is a very sharp and easy to use peeler.  As for slicing and julienne cutting of vegetables, I just don't have the patience to do that by hand, so I have no idea as to how well it would perform.  I normally do that type of task in my food processor or with a mandolin.This is so much better than the old style of peeler that they aren't even in the same category.  It's easier to hold and peel without cutting myself.I purchased this peeler with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.

This is the most dreadful and useless product that ever had a label slapped onto it.  I'not sure what sells it on tv, but in person, it still continued the masquerade.It's hard as a rock.  It doesn't transform into anything other than other forms of hard-as-a-rock.  I haven't used it enough to give it an opportunity to split, but I can see that happening.  I have tried to give it away, but so far, nobody would take it.  It's a total waste of money.

If you like lilac, there is absolutely nothing to dislike about these dish washing cloths.  They are not too thick & plush to be efficiently used for hand washing of dishes and kitchen surfaces.  They are not too large either.  Everything about these dish cloths has been well thought out, from the finished edges to the fabric chosen.  One side is slightly rough, the other is fairly smooth, giving you a choice about which side is used for a particular purpose.As for the color, it was accurately represented on my computer screen, and it really IS a lilac color.  Half are lilac with white grid marks, the other half is white with lilac grid marks.  I hate washing dishes, so having a pretty colored cloth helps make a disliked chore a little bit nicer.  These are definitely a cheery color.These are also very reasonably priced via Amazon for the quality as well, making them a budget-wise choice for your kitchen.  I definitely recommend them!

Like a lot of people, as I hit middle age, I was also stricken with a long list of health problems.  Unfortunately, they also interfere with getting a good night's sleep, which is the first line of defense to reduce puffiness and lines around the eyes.  After too many nights with too little sleep, I was desperate to find something to reduce the puffiness around my eyes and the oversized luggage beneath them.This Purista eye cream was what I chose as I resolved to remedy this;  It was also a huge challenge, despite the fact that I fully understand that it is not an actual salve with supernatural powers.  It takes time for a skin are product to start repairing the damage wrought by over a half century of haphazard skin care and sun exposure, and nothing is going to truly erase the years.I've been using the eye cream for about a week.  While it is showing improvement, it isn't a miracle cream.  I would say that it will take at least a month before I see maximum improvement.  I'm pleased with the level of improvement I have seen so far, and anticipate more over the coming weeks.I did purchase this eye cream with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.

Skin care products are an important part of looking as youthful as possible, and there are an incredibly diverse selection of products that promise to be the next best thing to the fountain of youth.  It's really hard to decide what is best for your skin from that very confusing array of products, whether you are standing in the beauty products aisle at a department store or searching online.In my case, I was searching for something to help my skin regain its smooth texture more than anything, as it had become somewhat coarse feeling.  Wrinkles are actually the least of it, my face just felt more like a flat tire than anything resembling "youthful".  To make it even worse, my husband has a baby face, and without his usual beard, looks like he's about to finish puberty.  It made me feel that I looked even older standing beside him, and it wasn't helped with the frequent assumptions by clerks that he was my son rather than my husband.  (Grrrrrrrrrr, as if I needed THAT, right?)At the same time, I am smart enough to know that skin care products are not going to create a miracle.  I have a lot of scar tissue on my face, which I was told long ago would cause me to age faster.  (I highly recommend seat belts and avoiding exiting a vehicle via the windshield.  It really does put a damper on your day.)  I don't have a lot of wrinkles, beyond a few laugh lines around my eyes and mouth.  I also have some health problems that contribute to poor skin texture and dry skin.  It also takes time for these skin care products to start improving your appearance.I have been using this for a week.  While it isn't the fountain of youth and it can't magically erase scarring, my face does seem noticeably smoother without making it feel oily or causing a post-menopausal acne outbreak.  (That is some kind of cruel joke.  I battle it more now than I ever did as a teen!)  It's added just a few minutes to my daily routine.  As for my laugh lines, it hasn't erased them, but they aren't my big "worries" either.  I was much more looking for something to help my skin texture, and this seems to be doing the trick.I did purchase this with a promotional discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.  All of my reviews are always my honest and unbiased opinion, and this one is no different.  I really do think this product is improving my overall skin texture on my face without any negative effects.

I had never used a ScanNCut before, although I had used a Cricut machine at work several years ago.  That means my only comparison is to the Cricut machine as it was then--I don't know if they work the same way now.With that said, this ScanNCut was leaps and bounds ahead of the Cricut.  I had found the Cricut so frustrating and expensive to use that I had never been interested in owning one myself.  For every design, you had to buy another expensive cartridge, which would have just a handful of patterns you were actually interested in, with a lot of things that you were never going to use.  In addition to these expensive purchases of cartridges, there was also the expense of blades and sticky mats that seemed to need replacing far too often for the price.  The final issue with those Cricuts was that there was an immense amount of paper waste because of how it would lay out patterns on the mat.  It was just a very limited set of software instructions.I have used the Brother far less so far--it does take a bit of time and effort to learn how to use a tool like this effectively.  It's also much more complex than many crafting tools or even that older Cricut ever was.  It has a LOT of features that simply blow away the older cutter too, from the ability to scan a design to being able to create your own design from scratch.After spending the equivalent of a day with the machine, I'm even more excited about the possibilities for creative crafting and sewing it offers.  I'm already contemplating some reverse applique projects for a quilt using this machine's abilities to cut fabric (even though I have not tried cutting fabric with it yet!)  For paper crafting, whether doing a poster for a kid's school project or making a sign for a more adult crowd, it's a fantastic asset as well.I can really see this machine in the classroom (or the teacher's home) for using to create some visually impressive designs for bulletin boards and wall decorations too.  I'm not a teacher, but I had a number of relatives who were, and I know how excited they would have been to have a tool like this at their disposal.Another big asset, especially for people such as teachers who may want to bring a machine like this to and from school for projects, is that it is not a massive piece of equipment.  I no longer work where I was using the old Cricut cutter, but my memory has it being far bigger than this one is.  That's always a plus for others such as myself as well--I live in a house, but it is a fairly small one, and my crafting/sewing space does double duty.  That means I have to put away materials and equipment between uses, and having efficiently sized machines really goes a long ways towards making that easier.I'm far from an expert, and wouldn't even call myself a somewhat experienced novice at using this machine yet.  I'm still at the "playing" stage, learning about its features and how to use them.  In other words, I'm at the same place that most buyers will be when they purchase this machine, especially if they have not owned a ScanNCut before.  Just don't expect to become an instant expert and be prepared to spend time with your owner's manual, the Brother website, the ScanNCut, and making some simple test projects as you learn how to use it.  If  you expect to sit down and instantly be creating pieces that have the entire PTA drooling over your creativity, you may be setting yourself up for some frustration and irritation.  I highly recommend my route--brew a pot of my favorite tea, and sit down with the machine and learn about it, with the hopes that it will be my best friend by the time the holiday season is here.  (I do have some big plans for some paper ornaments for the holidays.)  If I haven't mastered it by this holiday season, well, there is always next year, right?  Maybe I'm too old to set impossible time frames for this friendship, and maybe I'm just old enough that I realize that it takes a bit of time to acquire the skills I want.Overall, I can see this machine as being a very useful tool for a long list of people.  I can see it becoming a favorite crafting tool in many families too.  It offers a host of possibilities for very professional looking results whether you are working on a 4H project or a big civic one, as well as for making a lot of memories or even just embellishing scrap books.It isn't a cheap tool, but despite the costs, it can deliver some really impressive results.  It will have ongoing expenses, from replacing cutting blades and mats to purchasing the paper or fabric you want to make your cut-outs out of.  Being "older", this machine replaces very time consuming tasks of cutting things out with an Exacto knife.  A single sheet of paper, using that old fashioned hand method, could easily consume all day, only to have it ruined with a slip of the knife as  you neared completion.  (I know all too well how that goes, since Murphy's Law seems to be my personal law.)  This will reduce that type of effort to a mere few minutes, and even if something tears and is ruined for its intended use (it can happen when you are removing the paper from the mat after cutting)  it doesn't take all that long to have the machine cut out a second one.So far, I'm in love, even if that love affair is in the early stages yet.  I'm already budgeting to allow the mats and knives to be replaced as needed.  That is about the only negative to this, but it is an unavoidable one.  I'm going to need a lot more "fancy" paper too!If you enjoy paper crafting of any sort or sew decoratively either by embellishing garments or quilting projects, I can imagine a long list of justifications to get this machine.  If you are a DIY grandma sort (that's me!) then this offers a lot of opportunity to bond with your grandchildren as you impress them with your technical abilities.  (All of those learning curve "oops" bits and pieces, placed in a large pencil box, can become a source of fascinating art projects with a glue stick and some construction paper at the kitchen table too.  Kids can have a lot of fun with those brightly colored errors, whether they are letters, numbers, or some other shape.)As the ScanNCut & I become friends, I'm sure I'll have further updates to add to this review and maybe even a few hints.
