Great movie, one of my all time favorites. I owned it on DVD so I needed to get it on Blu-Ray as well just because.The quality is decent, not perfect blu-ray quality, slightly grainy but still better than DVD and it's a good version of it.

I got this as I needed  second controller for my Xbox One and it's fine, it works, I've had no issues with it in the 2+ months I've owned it.The controller has gotten a lot of use by myself and my three kids and so far so good.I do like the fact that it's microUSB so I can use any of my cables with it and not just a special one like the original Xbox 360.I just don't agree with the price, it's just too expensive, it's just too much to pay on top of the cost of the Xbox One.

The bracelet just ships in a plastic bag and that’s fine as it’s not exactly breakable, it’s just nylon essentially. The bracelet is black in color and has plastic clasps or buckles on each end. One end has a magnesium bar and whistle in it and the other has a scraper/knife built-into it.The magnesium bar does have black paint on it so you’ll need to scrape it off before trying to use it to expose the magnesium and it will produce sparks with the included scraper with a bit of work. The scraper is very small and it’s not sharp at all, I would sharpen it but being so small it can take a lot of work and patience.As far as fit, for me it was a perfect fit, not too big and not too small. I’ve purchased inexpensive paracord bracelets before and they were too small for me, but this on is fine. The clasp locks well and holds firm.So I have a lot of paracord floating around, expensive and inexpensive versions as I like to use it and make things from it. I had to cut this bracelet open to check the insides of it to make sure it was real and it is what it says it is, it isn’t. The listing says it’s 7 strand paracord but it’s not, it’s only 6 strand. Real 7 strand paracord should have 7 individual strands inside of the outer sheath but I only found six when I cut it open. They may consider the outer sheath as part of that number, but that’s not correct at all.The cord seems decent overall though, it’s thick and slightly stiff like paracord should be. It’s real paracord, so that’s a plus there as some inexpensive bracelets like these aren’t.I did fully unravel the bracelet  and measure the cord length and it’s slightly over 120 inches or a bit more than 10 feet in length which can be useful for lots of things surely.I have bought inexpensive paracord bracelets before and I can say this one is better quality overall than those are so for the price it’s worth it even though it’s not 7 strand paracord.Yes it’s not 7 strand paracord, but it’s advertised as 7 strand so I’m not sure what to do with that little fact as it’s not a bad product in spite of being only 6 strand.Pros:+Fits well, good size+Good quality overall+Can be useful surelyCons:-Not 7 strand paracord-Blade/scraper is not sharp at allDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The packaging for the O2 Hurricane is a nice sturdy box and inside you’ll find the Hurricane, power supply/charger, accessory bag and two straight plastic tubes. One thing you’ll notice is missing is the instructions, not sure why they didn’t include instructions. I should also note that I’m not sure the accessory pack was supposed to be included or not, so you may get one, or you may not.The O2 Hurricane I bought was the Industrial version in the color yellow that is supposed to be able to produce over 220 MPH wind speeds. I do have an anemometer but it only goes up to 99.9mph and the Hurricane does at least that according to my anemometer. The Hurricane is about the size of a regular can of compressed air, it’s 8 inches tall and about 3.5 inches at the widest part measuring from the back to the front of the nozzle and it’s about 2 inches thick. It is much heavier than canned air at about 18 ounces, but that’s to be expected as it does have a battery and blower inside of it. I’m not sure of the battery capacity, the specs only list that it’s a 12v NiMH battery.On the bottom of the back is the charging connection and then the front has a nice large trigger to activate the blower.It does need to charge for at least 10 hours before the first use which I found out by going to the O2 website. The charger has an LED on it that will turn green when charging is complete. Charging can take between 4-6 hours, but it all depends of course as to how much battery is left as to how long it will really take.As far as noise levels, it’s much louder than canned air is. I measured it and got about 77db at one foot distance which isn’t really that loud, like an alarm clock or loud music, but it can be annoying using for long periods and I wouldn’t want to use it at night when people in the house are sleeping.The accessory pack includes a small angled nozzle to compress the airflow to allow for greater force which works well. The brush attachment is very useful, I’ve found myself using it frequently. There’s also a flexible extension so you can get into hard to reach areas which can be useful. They’re all mad of plastic but they feel well mad and sturdy for what they are.As far as the attachments, I only really use the brush and the nozzle, every one in a while I use the flexible extension but I don’t think I’ve ever used the two tube ones at all besides just trying them out the first time, they just don’t do much at all.The O2 Hurricane is a useful product for sure, but it’s not going to totally replace canned air sadly. I was hoping it would, but maybe someday something will.In my time with the O2 Hurricane I’ve come to like it and use it as a supplement to canned chemical compressed air. It won’t replace canned air, but it can help you use less of it. I still buy and use canned air, but I use both as I’ve found the O2 Hurricane does have its uses. I use it for bigger things and I especially like the brush attachment to help get dirt and dust out and off of things. The O2 Hurricane can’t really clean things like a CPU heat sink or a video card heat sink, it just doesn’t move enough air and it won’t fit between the fins so I have to use the canned air for those types of jobs.The point is that you can save money with the O2 Hurricane, I buy less canned air now as I use it less since I got the O2 Hurricane.So there’s really one question to ask here and that’s will it replace canned air? The answer is no it won’t, but it can save you money overall though if use in conjunction with it.Pros:+Well made product+Includes useful attachments+Can save you money+Moves quite a bit of air overallCons:-Rather loud-No instructions included-Won’t replace canned chemical air-ExpensiveDisclosure: I purchased this product for my personal use and thought a review would benefit other consumers in making an informed purchasing decision.

The packaging is just a plastic bag which is fine as it’s just a piece of cloth and it’s not exactly fragile. The bag has numerous examples on it of how to wear or use the wrap.It is large at about 19 inches by 9 1/2 inches in dimensions and it’s tube shaped to go around your head and neck. There is no seam which I like a lot, it’s solid and one piece. The material is thin yes but I found that it’s actually warm. The skull design is located about half of the way down the warp, the bottom of it is at about the halfway point in the cloth overall. The wear it as a skull over your own face you’ll need to fold down the top half inside and this works to double to layer to keep you warmer but you can still breathe through it.The skull design reminds me of a vampire with the fanged teeth. It also remind me of the mask from the video game Call of Duty, so it can be a few things really.So I wore it as you’re supposed to. When you fold it down to the top of the skull design it should then line up with your nose it looks like you’ve got a skull face. Not much else to it really.I like this product a lot, it’s got a great design and it’s large enough to keep your face and neck warm.The material does seem thin but it’s actually quite warm especially since it’s basically double layered on your face. It’s already started to get cold here off and on and one day was 32F with wind chill in the upper 20’s and I made sure to try it that day and it did keep my face nice and warm and it kept the cold wind out.I see nothing wrong with this product myself, it works as advertised and looks good.Only time will tell if it’s made to last though.Pros:+Skull design+Thin but yet warm material+Big enough to keep neck and face warmCons:-None that I could findDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The toy comes wrapped in plastic for shipping and when you open it you’ll find a cardboard tag attached to it.The Foxy Dog toy is pretty big at about 23 inches long and about 5 inches across the body. The body is just one big air bladder or the squeaker and the tail crinkles like cellophane so it has two noise makers in it really. The tail is very soft and furry while the body has what feels like corduroy material over it.I think the Foxy Dog is cute, it really does look like a Fox and it seems well made. There is no funny smell to it like some toys have I’ve noticed.I have two Pit Bulls and they love toys but you never know what they’re going to do with it.Samantha is a smaller one, she’s dark brown, and she loves toys, she’s like a little kid really and she was very happy to play with it and with me with it.Casey is Sam’s sister and she is bit more laid back and relaxed and I never know what she’ll do with a toy. She has some stuffed animals in her sleeping cage that she has had for about two years now as she protects them and sleeps with them but she has this thing about squeakers she has to get them out and at first it didn’t seem like she was going to do that with the Fox but about ten minutes later the fox was dead, she ripped the squeaker out and chewed it apart.So we now have the fox minus the squeaker and I can still play with it with Sam as she likes the crinkly tail and likes to chase it with me pulling it. She’s weird as she kind of acts like cat almost chasing things around but the fox might be down but he’s not out, he’s just a lot thinner now.So did my dogs like it? Yes they loved it.Will it hold up to a Pitt Bull? Nope, not at all, but I didn’t expect it to as there’s not much that can hold up to one.I was hoping this might be one of those toys that my dog Casey would like and want to snuggle and protect but she couldn’t resist the squeaker, she just has to get them out for whatever reason.The Pheenx Pets Foxy dog toy is a cool toy, I like it and so do my dogs but depending on your dog it might not last long.To be fair it’s not sold as something rugged and indestructible and it was an experiment on my part to see how my dogs would react to it. They liked it yes, but sadly Casey liked it a bit too much. I spend a lot of money on dog toys for my dogs and sometimes it lasts for ten minutes like the Foxy Dog and some they have for years, you just never know how they'll react.I think the Foxy Dog is a five star toy myself, and yes my dogs love it, they loved it a bit too much obviously though. Even though the squeaker is gone they still do play with it and like it. Casey doesn't care much about it now that the squeaker is gone, but Sam is more than happy to still play with it as she does like the crinkly tail.Pros:+Very cute+Well made+Inexpensive+LargeCons:-Doesn’t stand up to a Pitt BullDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The package for these clips is just a heavy duty zip style bag which works fine.The clips themselves are white in color and remind me little seashells really. They are open on both ends and have a wavy line going across the top center. On the back you’ll find squares of 3M adhesive tape so you can mount the organizers permanently if need be.The clips open up in the center and they snap shut with an audible snapping sound. They close tightly but not very tight, more then tight enough to hold a cable in place though. To use the clips you just open them up, put a cable in and then snap them closed. Very simple to use.I don’t have enough room on my desk so I actually have a table next to my desk for overflow. I’ve been using a binder clip for my cables and it sits between the desk and table and rests in that space. It’s worked for years for me, but it’s not the nicest system.I decided to do something similar to my binder clip by sticking two Mudder clips together with their adhesive tape back to back. The clips are nice and fat so they will not fall between my desk and table and it looks a  lot nicer than the binder clip for sure. That’s off to my right side where the computer is. I’m going to do it again with two more cables as soon as I get around to running the cables back  behind my computer and under the table.I recently got a very nice 10 foot micro USB cable for review and I decided to use that on the left side of my desk as I keep my tablet over there normally. The cable was just sitting there loosely on my desk but I decided to use one of the clips and attach it to the bottom of the shelf I have there. Now the cable hangs from the shelf and it’s out of the way. When I need it I just pull it down and then I can tuck it back up there when I’m done and it’s out of the way. The adhesive is fine for mounting the clip upside down, it seems to be staying there just fine and it’s been there for a couple weeks now.  The clip closes tightly enough to hold the cable in it just fine and the opening is wide enough that the cable easily slides in and out of it as I need it.I love using things other than what they’re for. These clips are most likely made to be stuck to a flat surface on your desk and they just stay there permanently but I decided to do something different with them and it works fine for me.These clips can be used for lots of things. You could stick them to your desk and they’ll hold your cables. You could stick them to a wall to hold a networking cable for example, or you could do what I did and do something different.The clips seems well made, the spring is good enough to hold the cables in place and the holes are large enough to allow the cables to easily slip through them.I love these, and I think I need to get some more.As of right now these are ten dollars for five of them and that’s about two dollars each. It might seem expensive, but it all depends on how useful you’ll find them. I think they’re worth it, I like them, they do what I need them to do and they look nice.Pros:+Easy to use+Well made+Good adhesiveCons:-None that I could findDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

Packaging is just a zip style bag with a label on it, nothing special.It’s  simple product with metal connectors and a plastic center. It seems well made for what it is, I’m been using it for a while now with no issues. I keep it in my desk drawer actually so it’s always handy. One side is a standard female USB connection like you would find on your computer for example. The other side is a male micro USB connector.I tested the adapter with my Samsung Galaxy S6 Android phone, an Android tablet and a Windows 10 tablet and all three recognized it and could read and write to and from USB drives so I would have to say it works just fine.It’s a very simple product that is very handy for me.It works with the devices I tested it with, I could read and write to and from USB flash drives and that’s what I wanted it for.I also used it as an adapter with my Windows tablet to use a wireless mouse with it and it worked as well. The mouse is RF and uses a tiny USB adapter as the receiver which plugs in via USB and then the mouse connects to it and it works perfectly fine with my Windows tablet.Pros:+Very inexpensive+Works with Android and Windows phones/tablets+Small and well madeCons:-NoneDisclosure: I purchased this product for my personal use and thought a review would benefit other consumers in making an informed purchasing decision.

The cases comes packaged in bubble wrap and then each one is individually wrapped in a plastic bag and they have cardboard inside of them to help them keep their shape.The colors in this pack are pink, blue, yellow, gray and clear. Each case has cut-outs for the ports and camera along with protrusions where the buttons are to make it easier to feel them.All of the cases are slightly textured on the inside to make sure your phone stays put and it’s not scratched. The tops or backs of the cases are very smooth and glossy while the inside is more of a semi-gloss finish.These cases are for the Samsung Galaxy S6 specifically but Pvendor does have cases for other phones as well.The cases fit very well on the Galaxy S6 and they allow easy access to all the ports, buttons and camera. The cases slightly come up over the edge of the phone to protect the edges and the camera area is cut open wide to make sure it’s not obstructing the camera at all.  The cases are very thin and don’t really add much bulk or any weight really to the phone. Even though they’re thin they should do a decent job of protecting the phone from daily life and keep it looking nice and new.The Pvendor Silicone cases for the Samsung Galaxy S6 are very inexpensive. If you’re looking for a cheap case you could pay as much for a single one as you would for this five pack so it’s a great deal really and you could have one for every day of the work week so you don’t wear them out and for something different.I could complain about some tiny extra bits of silicone here and there on the cases but for this price I don’t expect perfection and it just comes right off very easily.These aren’t bad cases overall, they do offer a basic level of protection, just don’t expect them to protect your phone if you drop it.Pros:+Very inexpensive+Really doesn’t add bulk to the phone at all+Decent basic protection+Multiple colors in one pack+Access to all ports and buttons is unobstructedCons:-None reallyDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. The packaging is just a heavy duty zipper style bag which is fine as they’re not exactly fragile. There are multiple colors available and I got black, yellow and pink in the pack for review.The ends or connectors are stainless steel and the microUSB end is small so it should fit fire with most phone cases that have charging ports in them.The cables are a nylon braiding making them rugged and durable. These are 6.6ft or about 2 meters in length.For testing I charged things and I’m happy to report that the small connector worked great with the Otterbox case I have on my Samsung Galaxy S6 phone. I was charging my phone over the fast charring port which supplies 2.1amps and the cable handled it with no issues and the phone charged nice and fast.The Boxeroo microUSB cables are very well made, they’re a simple product that is needed. Most cables that come with out devices are short, 3 feet and under, and that isn’t always the best for a lot of uses. Having a longer cable is nice sometimes and these are a good choice I think. I’ve been using them a couple weeks now with assorted devices with no issues.Pros:+Small ends to fit most cases+Rugged nylon braided covering+Nice and long+InexpensiveCons:-NoneDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The packaging for the microUSB cables is just a heavy duty zipper style bag that is white on one side and clear on the other. In the pack are three 3.3 foot long cables and two 1 foot long cables making them useful for various things surely. Long cables are nice but sometimes you need a really short one and you get two is this pack for a low price.I charged my phone, the Samsung Galaxy S6, using a battery that provided 2.1amps of power so you can fast charge your devices and there were no issues. The cables worked just fine and I had no issues with charging, the cables didn’t get warm or anything like that. I charged my phone and tablet via the battery and via the AC adapter and again, no issues there.So it’s just a quick review yes, but these aren’t exactly complicated products, they’re just USB cables basically. They’re a bit different than others but they work just the same.It’s nice having choices and this pack gives you two different sizes so you can choose what’s best for the job.The cables seem well made, they’re tangle free which is a nice bonus.All in all not bad for the price for sure.Pros:+Different sizes+Tangle free+Work fine+InexpensiveCons:-NoneDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The Lux Essentials French press kit ships in an attractive box and indie you’ll find the press well protected by lots of bubble wrap and on the side you’ll see the extra screen and basic instructions for usage. The measuring spoon ships inside of the press and it’s just black plastic but it’s fine for what it is and what it needs to do.The press itself is two pieces essentially, the top and plunger combination and the carafe section. The carafe section is made of borosilicate glass to withstand the heat and it’s see through which is something I just love so you can se the coffee inside being brewed. On the outside of the carafe is a stylized black handle that goes all the way around it, it makes for a great looking French press really. The handle is attached to the carafe and I’m not yet if I like that or not as cleaning might be an issue.The top is solid except for the strainer or pouring section which is actually fairly tightly spaced so it will also help to filter out any coffee grounds that might get through the screen.The bottom of the plunger is the screen and spring section. The screen isn’t just flat, it curves up along the sides of the spring and the spring keeps tension on the screen against the glass sides of the carafe to keep the grounds where they should be, not in your coffee.According to the instructions you need to use two tablespoons of coffee per eight ounce cup of water, more or less depending on taste preferences. I like my coffee strong so I used a little more. The water should be hot but not boiling, you can boil the water on the stove and then let it sit for 20 to 30 seconds and then add it to the coffee in the carafe.Once the hot water is in you just put the lid on making sure the strainer opening is towards the back to keep the heat in and then you just let it sit for about four minutes. Here again you can let it brew for a longer or shorter amount of time depending on your taste preferences.Once the time is up you slowly push the plunger down to separate the coffee grounds from the now brewed coffee and then it’s ready to drink.It’s a great cup of coffee. The first thing you’ll notice is the taste, there’s just a huge difference in taste between using a French press and using an automatic drip coffee maker. The first time I used a French press I was honestly amazed, I didn’t believe that what people said about them, I didn’t think there could be that much of a difference but there really is. It’s a totally different cup of coffee, taste and even the texture it seems like is different.Clean up is easy overall, it’s glass so the grounds just come out easily enough, but it’s still a bit messy, at least messier than a drip coffee maker is.Sometimes grounds can get stuck between the metal plate and the screen on the bottom of the plunger and you just hold the base and unscrew the plunger handle slightly to loosen it to make a gap for water to flow through to remove the grounds. This is also how you change the screen as well, just unscrew the plunger all the way and the whole thing comes apart.The Lux Essentials French press makes a a great cup of coffee and that’s all you need to know! Seriously though this French press is excellent is pretty much every way I can think of.I’m not sure about the fact that the glass carafe is attached to the handle as far as cleaning it, but only time will tell I guess, for now it works fine, but I just thought it was worth mentioning.I love the glass carafe, I really like being able to see what’s going on inside, it just makes the whole process more interesting really.I don’t think I’ve ever seen any other French presses that come with an extra screen, but then again I really didn’t look either, but it’s nice they included one and the spoon is a nice bonus as well.If you want a good cup of coffee then you need to try a French press and this one from Lux Essentials is a great place to start.Pros:+Makes a great cup of coffee+Well made+Comes with extra screen and spoonCons:-None reallyDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The packaging is bright and colorful and there’s instructions on the back for you if you’ve never used a whetstone. Once you unpack the box you won’t find anything except the stone and a rubber non-slip base for it. The stone is 7 1/16” long by 2 5/16” wide and about 1 3/16” tall. It’s a stone so it’s rather heavy at about 1.4 pounds but that’s to be expected.The stone is divided in half horizontally in beige/yellow and gray. The top layer is 1000grit or fine for just honing your knives and the bottom layer is a rough 240grit for repairing and/or putting an edge on very dull knives.For testing I sharpened my knives, chef and pocket knives and it worked great.Yes the nice white or beige side of the stone will get dirty looking, but that’s just how it is and for the most part it’s fairly to clean off with just a little water and a soft cloth.To use a whetstone, the main thing is patience and then practice and yes if you’ve never used on there is a chance you may mess up the blade on your knives but it can be fixed so no need to panic.A whetstone is spelled with an ‘h’ in there but you actually do get it wet, the best thing to do is soak it in water for about five to ten minutes or so before using it. The main reason you do it is lubrication, you can use oil on a whetstone but if you do you never can use water again. Water is more readily available and it’s just cleaner to work with I think, less mess, less oily residue on things, so that’s always what I use.It may seem like a daunting process and I know a lot of people don’t like them because they’re basically afraid of them because they require more work but in the end it’s very much worth it.I have two steels for honing and sharpening my knives and I do have another stone but just single grit. A dual grit stone is nicer to have, especially one like this as it has fine and rough right there for you ready to go.If you’re a chef or if you’re serious in the kitchen and have decent knives then you owe it to yourself and your knives to get a good whetstone to keep them at their best.The Priority Chef whetstone is an excellent choice for keeping your knives maintained and sharp as it offers both rough and fine grit in on stone. Yes it won’t last as long as a single grit stone will since it’s basically just half, but you’ll still get a few years out of it surely.Some of my knives are over twenty years old and they’re still great knives and that’s because I take care of them by maintaining them and this whetstone from Priority Chef will help me keep them for hopefully another 20 yearsPros:+Dual grit+Non-slip base+Well madeCons:-None that I could findDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

The packaging has a rugged look to it with a window on the front and inside you’ll find the speaker in a plastic tray for protection. Once you get everything unpacked you’ll find user guide, cloth drawstring carry bag, microUSB cable and a 3.5mm audio cable.The speaker is green and black in color and it looks virtually the same on both sides except the front has the AYL logo on it. The green goes all the way around the outside and it’s actually rubber to help protect it from falls. The front and back have metal grills protecting the five watt speaker inside.Attached to the speaker is a thick heavy duty rubber wrist strap that actually held on by a screw so you could take it off it you wanted to.On the top edge of the speaker is the control panel where you’ll see buttons for power, volume down, play/pause/answer call and volume up labeled buttons.  The volume up and down buttons actually work to skip forward and back tracks too, you need to hold them in for it to activate.On the left side of the speaker thick rubber door that covers over the microUBS charging port and the 3.5mm audio input jack.The bottom actually has a threaded hole for mounting on a bike or wherever if you wanted to.In the top corner of the front of the speaker is a small LED that lights up blue for Bluetooth and red for charging.I used the speaker with my Samsung Galaxy S6 Android phone and it worked perfectly fine, I had no problems connecting it over Bluetooth.The controls worked for all the functions, I could skip tracks and adjust the volume easily.The sounds is actually very good for most all music I tried. The speaker can get very loud, I mean very loud and it actually vibrates when the volume is up. For most music the sound was very clear even at max volume, it was only when I played music that was very bass heavy that the sound started to get slightly distorted, but it wasn’t very badly distorted. I just lowed the volume ever so slightly and it was fine. Overall the sound is very good.This AYL speaker is IPX5 certified meaning you could  shower with it if you wanted to, IPX5 means protected from water jets essentially according to the official code. This also means you can take it camping, hiking, bike riding in the rain and still have music while on the go. No it’s not submersion proof but if you did drop in water you just need to let it dry fully before using it again.The speaker is Bluetooth 4.0 enabled and that means more features and more range basically. The range you get varies on what types of material are in the way so theoretically you can get up to 33 feet of range with nothing blocking the signal.The battery inside is 1500mAh and according to specs it should provide up to 12 hours of play time at 80% volume.The AYL speaker is a great product for outdoor use surely, I can see myself taking it with me camping or hiking with no worries about something happening to it. So no matter where you day takes you this speaker should survive most any situation.Pros:+Very well made+Great sounding+Very loudCons:-Slight distortion at high volume with heavy bassDisclosure: This product was given to me for review by the company for review purposes only for free or at a discounted price, and is not considered by me as payment for the review. My reviews are honest and unbiased regardless of how I received the product. I never have and will never accept payments for reviews from companies, for me there is no difference in reviewing a free or purchased product since all products are treated the same.

Don't believe this was a filled with toner all the way.  Previously had a Canon brand and it lasted me over 3 years.  This product lasted me less than 1 year.  The Canon brand on Amazon does not cost 3 times as much, so this is not a good deal.

I started this book with some hesitation.  This book is a bundle of 3 novellas in a series.  There were some negative reviews on the first novella that made me pause: attack and takeover of a human spaceship purely for enslaving the human women, the men are killed and the older women put out to pasture as house servants, younger women unwilling to mate are to be forced into prostitution.  In other words, with that kind action I was wondering how I could find anything redeeming in the "hero."But, I am a sucker for the Mars Needs Women storyline and generally enjoy Mina Carter's works, so I took the plunge and bought this book.  By the way, I do recommend waiting until the whole storyline on a character has come out rather than reading piecemeal; I think he frustration factor over cliffhangers and feeling unsatisfied over too little story will be resolved.  Any way, the hero's race of Lathar warriors do redeem themselves - they quickly realize that humans are equally intelligent and fierce as themselves and in the end are seen as equals.  Also, I didn't read detail that the Lathar ruthlessly killed the men but rather just sent them away.  BUT  despite this, there are a few troubling aspects to the Lathar race which prevents me from giving this a full 5 stars:- the Lathar kidnap females from a less intelligent race for procreate and sexual relief.  The less intelligent race is cow like looking.  There's some major wrongs and ick factor there:  preying upon and enslaving another race, having sexual relations with another being that it feels kind of like bestiality - ugh- so if there aren't enough human females to go around I can only guess that they'll continue to enslave the above race or seek other races to do the same - this is deplorableHopefully the author can quickly turn around the two points above, cuz it ain't pretty.  Cloning does make more sense and it's brought up in the storyline so why wasn't it more pursued?

Very rarely do I give such a low review, but this was so disappointing.  I was looking forward to reading about a romance that started with a translator and a Russian hockey player.  I was looking forward to funny conversations/incidences as a result of translations as well as hearing some Russian words for that added mysterious romantic feeling.  Uh no, turns out the guy is fluent in English so while there were a few incidences of learning Russian culture, it felt like a regular American NA romance.As another reviewer noted, the author didn't follow-up enough with characters and situations which she would introduce and she introduced too many on top of that.  This could have been a much more interesting story if the author hadn't tried to introduce so many angles to the h's life....spoilers starting so stop reading if this bothers you----------Here are all the elements that are introduced into the heroine's life- ex soccer superstar- mother murdered but murderer never found, plus heroine was present during murder?- heroine always feels abandoned although her grandparents seemed to be loving, caring albeit unwilling to discuss her deceased mother- discovers she has a biological brother- becomes a lead singer for a band- currently studying to be a social worker and has started one community outreach center and trying to start a 2nd- does Russian translation as a side job for her grandfather which is how she meets the hero- full time college student- part-time waitressIn other words, the heroine has way too many activities.  It's like the author wanted to stuff the storyline with every fantasy or scene she thought would be interesting, but wasn't vested enough to write about these activities/interests/situations comprehensively.  I think if she did, it would have made for an extremely long book.  Really, if she had just played up the translation aspect with the heroine being a full time student that would have been plenty and the story would have been more realistic and interesting.  Okay throw in the band part as you need a reason for jealousy.  I became particularly annoyed with the half-axxed approach to fleshing out a scene when you read about the heroine getting roofed by someone she can identify - not cool to blow something like this off so casually, the perpetrator should have been identified to the police or in the very least, there should have been more reaction by the heroine not just a "ooh ick" response.The reason for the hero breaking up with the heroine was lame.  He professed to being so head over heels in love with her and he drops her because of a poem she wrote where she disses him but the poem was written way before they even started dating/expressing an interest in each other.  And he stays away from her for 2 months!  Come on, that's a combined wuss/jerk move.I had such hopes for this book and really wish I had given more credence to the 3 star and below reviews, but I was relying so much on an endorsement from an author whose NA books I had really enjoyed.  Guess she must have been a pal or maybe they share the same publisher and she was compelled to write a good review on her blog.

The heroine and hero in this story were very interesting and 3 dimensional.  The heroine is good natured, constantly hungry, brave, and quick thinking.  The hero is caring, brave, smart and believable.  Unlike the first book in this series, this story was a mystery where the h/H spent time trying to find out who committed the murders which the hero is being suspected of.  You do have to suspend your belief a bit about how the heroine from the first book is able to hack so easily into security cameras, but hey, it's fiction so I'm okay with this NA modern version of Nancy Drew.I loved the depiction of the heroine's hippie mother and that the author brought back the heroine from the first book as a side character.  I think you should read the first book of this series though to totally appreciate this one.

This is my first book by this author and definitely not my last.  She did a fantastic job of keeping true to the nerd (read female Sheldon Cooper of Big Bang Theory) girl who can't help but voice her logical thoughts over being tactful.  I also liked the introduction of the friends she makes.  A lastly, I really enjoyed reading about her prank playing family - very cute and endearing.Reason for just 3 1/2 stars:  ehh, the hero.  I never felt his personality.  He felt very much of a side character who just reacted rather than initiated action.  He felt very bland to me and thus not interesting.  I found it very unbelievable that he had been a virgin at 21 and supposedly being so hot that all the girls on campus were drooling for him.Despite the hero feeling lackluster and unbelievable, there's enough good about this book that makes we want to read more from this author.

Penny Reid was a co-author so I had high hopes, but no such luck.  The intelligent, original humor of Reid wasn't present.  The biggest problem with this book was the heroine - she doesn't have an endearing personality quirk like Janie, but more of a personality disorder that cries out for her to have therapy.  While a child, the heroine has been abandoned twice in her life and as such has never formed personal ties with anyone for fear of future rejection.  The hero is amazingly patient and unfathomably interested in her.  I say unfathomably, because she doesn't strike me as that special.  In fact, I found her judgemental and desperately in need of growing up.  She is depicted of having this incredibly successful blog, a la gossip column style, where she takes snaps of celebs or celeb lookalikes and pokes fun at them - all doing so anonymously.  Taking potshots at people without supplying your real identity? Uh, that's a combination of cowardice and bullying in my POV.  There's supposed to be this saving grace to her blog in that she helps raise money for charity - don't care, it doesn't make it right.The story started off as 4 star, then went to 3 star as I couldn't believe the hero would be interested in her.  Aside from being good at her job (uh, how does a recluse become so smart about PR?  that's another loss of a star for me), you don't see any evidence of her being charming, engaging, or interesting.  I kept waiting for her not to come across as a pathetic shut-in and the way she is such a hypocrite in her dealings with the hero towards the end  - I wanted here not to be a HEA as she is so unworthy.I do disagree with the criticisms of some reviewers about the amount of sex and BDSM.  Eh, for romances these days, the amount of sex written I didn't find excessive.  I really dislike BDSM and was happily surprise to find out that the hero just likes to secure her arms and thankfully there is no hitting or weird toys involved between the two of them.Anyway, please don't judge the author, Penny Reid, by this book (oh and avoid her Friends with Benefits book too) all the other books I've written by her are "intelligent romantic comedies."  You can't always bat a 1000.

I first came upon this author in a terrific anthology "Twelve Shades of Midnight" which for some reason is no longer being sold on Amazon, but anyway, since then, have been anxiously waiting for more books in this series.  The heroine is fantastic and not cookie cutter - she's heroic and funny but not boringly goody two-shoes.  There is a developing romance between her and "The Magician" who so far is more of a side character in the story.  This is a fascinating and original world built by the author.

I've read the other books in this series and actually read this one out-of-order as I always found Elizabeth the least interesting of the knitting group.  Should have clued into that as well as the low starred reviews from fellow Reid fans.  Yikes, where is the Reid humor and endearing heroine?  Elizabeth is a major B.  I wanted Nico to kick her to the curb.  The guy tells her how he honestly feels early on and she just keeps stomping on his feelings.  Maybe if his bullying behavior had been more recent, but not only was it 10 years ago but during their last summer together, he was incredibly loving to her and so to me  they moved beyond his mean boy high school behavior.She doesn't even strike me as a particularly good doctor.  She doesn't first try to communicate with her patient, Nico's niece, but instead talks to the people around her - terrible bedside manner.The only good thing in this book was when Sandra appeared, but not enough to overcome the unlikable heroine.

I had read almost all of Penny Reid's knitting series and thought I'd give this NA romance a try.  I think parts 1 & 2 represent Reid at her apex for writing a smart, honest, quirky, original female character coupled with a growling, over-the-top rich, handsome alpha.  Kathleen, the heroine, says the most endearing and funny things.  I loved her best friend, Sam who was supportive but never meddling.  Reid really excels in writing comedy and heroines whom you want to cheer for in addition to their supportive female BFFs.  There are the some unbelievable parts to her characterization such as the hero not being more screwed up as a result of his appalling parents and  Kaitlyn not being more savvy/experienced about life and wealthy people since she is the daughter of illustrious parents.Stop reading if you don't want to read anything spoilerish:If parts 1 & 2 hadn't started with a certain characterization of Kaitlyn being so smart and funny, then I wouldn't have been so disappointed by part 3. Kaitlyn isn't cute/quirky/smart but rather too self-absored and quite frankly epically stupid to all of Martin's signal flares indicating he wants to get back together. I know some reviewers expressed discontent. that Kaitlyn and Martin were apart for so long in part 3, but thought that made their HEA much more believable.  They did need time to develop some crucial personal life interests while apart from each other and I don't think it would have happened if they were still together.  But aside from that, I agree with the other reviewers that Kaitlyn is aggravating in her blindness.  Also, I felt she should have been much more sympathetic to Martin's desire for revenge - if you had the devil for the father, maybe the only way to exorcise him is to take away his power.  An epilogue where you see the couple say 5 years in the future would have been nice a nice way to bring closure to this romance.  It's such a pity that this story, which started off with such a witty, interesting heroine, becomes a more angsty "finding herself" and at times self-righteous heroine for most of part 3.I hope the next elements book is on Sam, she sounds really interesting with her tennis background as well as her quick wit.

I'm rounding up my rating to 4 stars because overall, the quality of this author's writing (style, vocabulary, imagination, scenery) is of such a high order, that I can't bring myself to just rate this book at 3 stars.  It's a solid 3.5 for me.What I liked:- the heroine.  I liked how she developed herself as a person which you learn over flashbacks- the scenes with the brothers, particularly their, ahem "bathroom schedules"- the setting- the love you see between the heroine and her mother- the gal pals of the heroine, they really added color to the storyWhat I didn't like:- the hero.  He was just too artist like moody for me.  I realize he had his reasons, but he just felt like such a downer.  Also, the way he's physically described, he sounded like a cast member for Duck Dynasty which I don't find attractive in a hero (commenting on looks only)- the romance.  It just felt so fits and starts and took a long time to progress.  It was an uncomfortable reading for me when those two were together as there was so much conversational fumbling- I found the 180 degree turnaround with some of the brothers, such as Jethro unbelievable.  You're supposed to believe that a guy who actually tried to pimp out his younger sister to his friends turned over a new leaf in 3 years.  His story, as well as how the other brothers' lives were so quickly changed by the hero, seemed too good to be true.- I wish there had been more background on the brothers and the heroine when they were kids and supported each other as it would have made their closeness after an 8 year separation more believable.- the way the brothers and the heroine just accepted the hero paying the bills so easily - uh, they all had jobs, so why were they okay with that?- it would have been nice if there had been a paragraph or two about how winning a beauty pageant changed her life (I assume that's how she afforded college) or her brothers (one of them talks about her winning made it hard for them but why?)

Every now and then I think I'll try my hand at writing a romance and then I read something this well written and say, "nope, the bar has been set, and I can't even touch the bars."  I loved the concept of the heroine who is bombshell hindered by Tourette's like spouting of Wikipedia.  She is incredibly intelligent and endearing, but due to a lousy family, she has always held herself slightly away from romantic relationships, never going fully into them with her heart.  At first I had a hard time with her character as it seemed like too many bad things were happening to her at once and the author was just making her life too sad, but it quickly passes and she is given a chance to shine.  I loved her cluelessness and her spouting of facts.  And more importantly, I loved how the hero was fascinated by her knowledge and valued her mind as well as her looks.Usually I find the gal pals of the heroine overly interfering, nosy, and quite frankly enabling of bad habits.  But I really liked these gals, particularly when they take on the bad guys.The reason for not giving this a full 5 stars is that I thought what happened with the heroine's sister could have been brought more to a conclusive end (or maybe it's in the next book?) and I have to say that the wealth of the hero was too over-the-top to be believed.  But aside from that, really the writing style is very sophisticated and this romantic comedy stands above the usual trope.

I enjoyed the previous book (or serial) of the Ice Planet world.  Appreciated that the author didn't do the usual "everything is rosy" when you're kidnapped by aliens.  I really felt the author stood out for depicting how traumatizing, humiliating, and physically hard it would be if someone were kidnapped.  Even when the human women find another race of alien men, it's not easy peasy.  So intrigued by a new take on the familiar men are from Mars theme, I decided to continue with reading about this world.Unfortunately, this one is a real step back for me.  The female lead was just too foul mouthed and not in a clever, snarky way, but more in a pouty low class, style.  I appreciate that she wants to stand on her own two feet and that she's feeling physically and mentally lousy after all she's suffered, but sheesh, when you voice your opinions, do so in a more thoughtful way.  It's like she had Tourette's syndrome and you just wanted her to shut up.I almost gave this story 2 stars, but there is a scene where she puts on her big girl panties and learns to take care of herself and her mate without incessantly making crude comments.  Unfortunately, that was only a brief reprieve before she went back to imitating an elementary school kid who learned their vocabulary from a XXX movie.

Another great sci-fi read from this author.  I wasn't sure how she would pull off a heroine who is so naive but she did it!  Lara, daughter of a diplomat, is the type to foolishly hurl herself into an adventure.  Likely she's done this multiple times because she always had her sister, Nori, to bail her out, but now that she's on her own, you feel like she quickly learns more to think on her own.  I really liked how her character's gift with languages combined with empathic abilities enabled her to reach out to others.This is very much a romance of opposites, but it works.  I look forward to future books by this author.

The background of the watch face is a very light grey so the contrast against the numbers isn't as high as I'd like.  I think this watch is trying to evoke the style from the 40s/50s.  The watch band is more brown than orange (in the photo it looks orange) which I consider a step in the right direction.I agree with other reviewers that the watch band is too long for most women.UPDATE:  After owning this for less than three months, the watch stopped!  I can only hope that a battery replacement will fix it.  Certainly the watch should work without problems for at least a year!

You definitely need to read book 1 of this series to have a full appreciation and understanding of "Fighting Shadows" but that book is the one that got me hooked on this author, so it's all good.  With regards to writing ability, I feel like the author advanced even further with this romance.  This is not a formulaic NA.  At first you may find yourself not liking the heroine as she's been raised to be a grifter and she shows signs of immaturity.  On the other hand, those faults are what make her character realistic and unique.  She does mature over time and you do like the person she becomes.I think Flint's bitterness over his paralyzed condition makes sense.  And I think pairing him with the oddball Ash makes total sense as she's the only one, with her "out-of-leftfield" sensibility that can shake him out of his doldrums.  Coupled with Ash's caring nature, the romance worked for me.The only reason why I don't give this a full five stars is that I would have liked a bit more variety, action, change of scenery throughout the story.  I felt like there was maybe too much time spent on the two characters trying to overcome their insecurities.

Wow, not understanding the high starred reviews.  I read another of the author's freebies "Ready to Were" and thought it was okay but wanted to give this author another chance.  Very glad I did not pay for this.This book features dubious humor around old people's toilet moments, scenes of cannibalism, foul mouthed guardian angels whom I don't find witty (instead of calling the heroine by her name (Astrid) it's always Axx + another noun).  This is not clever humor, this is the poorest excuse of comedic writing I've ever come across.  Even the world building got to be too much.  It was this weird jumble of throwing in famous people's names for other paranormal creatures.  This is seriously a mess.

A funny tale of a female werewolf who is in the equivalent of the Werewolf FBI, returning to her hometown after a year's absence.  She left her hometown in order to get away from her fiancé whom she believed to be unfaithful.  The fiance is the alpha of the pack as well as the town sheriff.  He has never stopped loving her and wants her back.  She is joined on her hometown return by her gay BFF a vampire.  Together, along with her grandmother they make a funny trio.The humor made me grin, but not laugh out loud funny like a Tara Sivec book.  Maybe because it was slightly on the forced side?  I did like the heroine and how much she had grown as a person.  This book is part of a series but I didn't feel like there was such a cliffhanger that I had to go out and buy book 2.  I'm kind of on the fence with this author so will check out another of her freebies to see if I like her writing style.

What a great start to a series.  It's not often that you get to read a PNR where both the h and the H are both demons. I really love the fact that the h, while she can be quite the kick-axx  doesn't feel the need to flaunt it, only does so when needed such as when she stands up for her cousin or she needs to get herself out of a bad situation.  In other words, this is a smart heroine who, while not taking guff from anyone, doesn't needlessly antagonize anyone but is never a doormat.  She had lousy parents, but she doesn't feel sorry for herself and sees some of the good that came in her life from a nomadic upbringing.  Best of all she's very independent but not to the point of TSTL.  For this, I give a huge thank you to the author.  So many times I groan in romances where the heroine is a wannabe or delusional warrior and she does causes more trouble for everyone.  Not this heroine - she knows when to stay by the sidelines or when to fight with all she's got.I really loved how despite this being PNR, it was not instal-love for these two.  They did get to know each other and realize how much they meant to one another.  The romance was believable because they were both so honest with each - no communication problems.  Again, another big thank you to the author for writing a "big misunderstanding" event between the two of them.  As a romance book addict, I'm so tired of seeing people simply not talking to each other, particularly if their love is so strong for each other - it makes me really wonder about their long term viability.Lastly, the world building was interesting.  I really appreciate how the author gives the details of the demon world - through events, actions, conversations, internal thoughts.  This really shows the level of sophistication of this author how artfully she weaves the details of the world into the story - a lesser author would have huge info dumps or drawn-out internal monologues.This is a standalone book, but if you enjoyed it then definitely recommend her Vampire series which is of similar calibre.

Enjoyed this short story which was a space thriller.  Daughter of the president? of a planet escapes her home planet during a time of civil strife.  She is placed on a military ship where she is pursued by a lecherous captain.  She also runs into an old high school flame.  Liked both the hero and the heroine - brave and smart.  No TSTL moments in the story.  I liked how the author didn't have too much sex in the story which too many romance authors use as a substitute for story.Just small complaints that keep me from giving this a full five stars:- I never really got a good idea of what the hero or heroine looked like.  Would really have liked to known what the heroine did for a living.  I didn't get the feeling that she was a princess so, uh what was her life besides fleeing from civil unrest?- felt like she and the crew were able to get away from the pirates too easily- felt like there should have been more exchange between the hero and heroine before becoming so serious.  yes, they had a history but it was a high school romance and there was a big gap in betweenOkay this didn't make me lower the rating, but the author really needs to use more appropriate covers.  If I hadn't discovered the author previously through an anthology, I don't think I would have thought to pick-up her books.  With the exception of the Iron Admiral books, her covers always make me think that they're non-fiction books about space or for Star Trek geeks - I would never have guessed by the artwork that this was SFR.Anyway, this author writes well and definitely I will continue to be on the lookout for more.

This is the 4th sci-fi action/thriller I've read by this author and they've all been great.  This one also has romance in it which I enjoyed as well.  The author does such a great job of world building.  The hero and heroine are both brave, resourceful and yay, no TSTL moments for them.  I appreciate how the 2ndary characters are more complex - they have their pros and cons.I'm surprised this author isn't read more widely.  It's a shame as she really has a talent for story telling.

Oh wow, who doesn't want a Nick as the man in their life.  I really liked his combined personality of pragmatism, protectiveness, and devotion/worship for Daisy.I would say the synopsis is a little misleading.  It implied more of a thriller aspect and really this novella was a snapshot of Daisy and Nick's life as they try to adapt to leading normal lives.  Agree with the other reviewers that you need to read  "Last Hit" in order to understand this novella.I really appreciate how the authors avoided the formulaic alpha hero-Russian hitman and the inexperienced gal.  They are both fish-out-of-water types when it comes to relating to every day society and that is what makes the story interesting plus their utter understanding and devotion to each other.  I really, really liked how between the two of them there was this incredible, understanding connection on how to deal with each other's idiosyncrasies.The reason why I don't give this 5 stars is that I think the authors went a little overboard about Daisy's desperation for a friend.  I realize in having Daisy befriend Christine it was also to show Daisy's understanding nature and big heart BUT sorry, Christine isn't worthy.  Spoilers to follow, so stop reading if you don't want to read them..........................  I can understand Christine being under the thrall of clearly a junky, abusing boyfriend who takes her money and beats her up.  Christine is literally starving as the money she earns from the two jobs is going towards her boyfriends lifestyle.  Abusive relationships like that I would not judge but hope someone would offer help as Daisy does.  What I am not understanding about is how much Christine uses Daisy - constantly copying her answers - what is the point of her choosing to be in college if she's not willing to study?  I guess someone could say she doesn't have time because she's working two jobs, but again, college is a choice, so why bother paying for it and taking the time to attend classes if you're only constantly going to cheat?  The worst though about Christine was when Daisy tells her that her boyfriend tried to rape her, Christine's only thought was "my boyfriend isn't here?"  No thought, apology, or care did she send Daisy's way about the attempted rape.  I just thought Daisy should have thrown her hands up on Christine even at the beginning when the cheating began and said "you're toxic and I don't need a friend this badly to have to buy them with my homework."  I also thought the authors went a little overboard with making Daisy so socially awkward that she couldn't make friends easily - I didn't like her looking so pathetic although it did provide scenes where it showed Nick trying to make friends for her as he just wants her happiness.Anyway, to end on a positive note, Nick and Daisy are one of the best couples I have ever read.  Despite the use of the ever popular Russian hitman theme, this story contains original, uniques characters and a powerful romance.  I can't wait for more in this series!!!

Loved how I was transported back to the world of dragons and mages.  Here the story focuses on Asha a fire mage/dragon seer hybrid.  During the story she comes more into her powers and and develops her relationship with her mate, Braedon, a very powerful fire mage.  Brandon fights alongside her for both her right to choose her own path in life as well as aid the dragons in their fight against a corrupt dragon (her stepfather).  There is wonderful world building of dragon society and the author certainly drops bread crumbs for future relationships which I can't wait to read.I think what I really appreciate about this author's writing is that she really knows how to spin a tale, make the reader feel like they are in a totally different realm.  People talk differently, dress differently, behave differently - there is no jarring 20th century, whiny teenage like voice I often encounter with other fantasy romances.  The heroine is brave and smart and the hero too, but not an alpha a-hole.  Most of all, the author does not overdo the sex scenes which too many romance writers rely upon as a basis for a book.

Once I pay for a book, I feel an obligation to finish, but this one broke the rule.  I'm so disappointed as I had high hopes based on the author's story in a Sci-Fi anthology.The story started out 5 stars for me, but then after the H/h's insta-lust (which I was okay with since it's one of those instant mate recognition themes) the next scene skips 3 months ahead!  You know that they are getting along and the relationship is growing but just a few instances are told rather than shown, of how the H endears himself to the h.  By skipping over the early days of the relationship, the author missed out on building a key part of the romance for the readers.Spoilers ahead-------------The h's character I found to be increasingly TSTL and high school immature.  She takes it upon herself to seek aid from the US military and thus exposes her mate's race and operations to the government.  She is surprised and disappointed that a former military friend places tracking devices on her and has brought others to take her in.  And to top it off, despite this personal betrayal, she still wants to treat the guy as though he'll instantly be an ally by telling him classified information and letting him walk into her mate's camp without restraints (uh, this is just minutes after the "friend" was chasing you down with his military squad).  For someone who supposedly was experienced in clandestine operations you'd think she would have been smarter.  You then read how since her arrival at her mate's encampment she's indulged in being rebellious simply for the fun of it and is addicted to playing video games.

I'm surprised other reviewers haven't noticed that with the exception of the 1st story, each author manages to insert the words "Max Midnight" somewhere in the story AND they very cleverly allude to the next story.  I was reading the stories out of order (zeroing first on my favs) and once I figured out how the authors were doing this, I really got into paying attention to the details and went back to rereading the stories!  Even the last story of the anthology, "Getting Wilde" drops a hint about the 1st story.  Some of the foreshadowing clues are very subtle - loved it.  It was like a game of Myst, trying to find out how the authors would hint about the the story.  Hats off to Darynda Jones, both for the excellent story and how clever she was in alluding to the next one.I imagine coordinating this type of linkage was an incredible headache amongst the authors.  Not sure why the 1st author didn't try to use the phrase "Max Midnight" and give a clue to the next story... oh well.As you expect with any anthology some of the stories are stronger than others.  The standouts for me:Darynda Jones - A Lovely DropWoman with the ability to go back in time uses her skills to try to help an FBI agent.  Not as much romantic but definitely thrilling.Shea Berkley - Dark Secrets:  Stone Cold DeadA paranormal (don't want to spoil it by revealing what type) warrior type woman comes to the aid of a couple of children (I love reading about kids in PNR) and hooks up with a vampire slayer.  I understand this is part of a series and I'm looking forward to the next one.Trish McCallan - Spirit WoodsThis one felt very Twilight Zone like to me.  A female veterinarian reconnects with an old lover in her hometown.  He's a cop who helps her figure out how a dog she cares for is the living embodiment of her childhood dog as well as who vandalized her old childhood home.  Definitely got the feeling there will be a follow-on to this story as there were unanswered questions.  Look forward to the sequel.  I'm a real Trish McCallan fan and she is the reason why I originally bought this anthology.Jenn Stark - Getting WildeA Robin Hood type heroine who uses her magical gifts to steal ancient artifacts and then uses the money to help magically gifted children.  She is hired by a past lover who is magically powerful, to steal something.  I sooo want to read more about this heroine and have added Stark to my TBR list.Based on the quality of writing on the above stories plus the very interesting linkages, I definitely felt this anthology was worth the $4.99.

The four star rating is rounding up from 3.5 stars.- I did like the story but the book needed editing so badly that every other page I found myself stopping to reread a passage to figure out what the author really meant.- In the beginning, the book feels choppy but it definitely improves as the story progresses.  More background information on the children and the brothers earlier on would have been helpful.  It's been a while since the previous book and so I was confused as to who was who in the beginning scenes with the 6? adopted children.- Story could have been much fuller if there was more background information on the villain and his motivations.- It wasn't clear to me how the heroine was being instructed by the bad guys to spy on the hero's family.  You know she is being controlled by drugs but there is never any explanation as to what information they expected her to uncover.  Also, what was the hero's reaction/thoughts to her father prior to the drug addiction discovery?Good stuff:- The author is fantastic on creating an imaginative world.- Love how the heroine isn't a deadweight in the relationship but demonstrates brains and quick thinking.- No TSTL moments.- I really liked the idea of how their relationship began and evolved (society couple that grew to love each other).- I liked how the author introduces a same sex relationship but doesn't stand on a soap box about it.I really think this book had the potential to be a solid 5 stars with better editing and more filled out scenes.  Overall, it's strong enough that I look forward to the next one in the series.

Top reasons why I rated this 5 stars:1.  Smart, plucky, witty, strong (okay smart axx) heroine.  Loved the hilarious characterization of her as this positive energy person (but not annoyingly so) who disarms people by making them think she's an airhead.  She's the perfect opposite match for the brooding hero2.  Love the opposites attract romance3.  No TSTL moments AND the H/h communicate with each other4.  Great dialogue between the characters both major and minor5.  In addition to the romance, there is a very interesting investigation into evil vampiresTo enjoy this book fully you do want to read the previous 3 books, but the author has done such an outstanding job with this series that you don't want to miss out on the fun

Great price and nice looking, but not worth it when you can't sleep with it next to you as the ticking noise is too loud.  If you're okay with not having the alarm clock next to you while you sleep, say across the room, you might be okay with this.

Lynda Chance is a great erotica writer and usually is one of the best with writing a swoon worthy alpha, but I have to say, I really didn't like the alpha nor the female lead in this story:- I didn't like it when Garrett kept pushing Maria sexually when she said "no" and "stop" to him.  She doesn't say it in the most forceful way, but it doesn't matter, he should have backed off, particularly when she utters it more than once.  I would have been okay if he just tried to seduce her with words but stop touching her once she tells him to back off.- Garrett is supposed to be this incredibly smart businessman.  I know the point of the story is that his attraction to Maria drives all common sense out of his head, but seriously, a smart businessman of his calibre would not have gotten so aggressively physical with an employee.  I like that Maria points out the liability at the beginning, but am disappointed that she didn't have the spine to walk out on the job (and join one of the fancier/swankier hotels she is so confident she can find a place at)  and the sex fog didn't immediately clear from Garrett's head once she mentioned suing him.- Maria has two major TSTL moments at the beginning of the story that just did not make sense with the overall characterization of her as a top notch hotel employee ready to take on a general manager's position.  TSTL #1:  background info tells you that she is a major pain to Courtney, an executive sent in to revamp the hotel, merely because she is professionally and personally jealous of Courtney.  She is such a major pain that Courtney is forced to recommend firing her.  I really thought it was one of the lamest parts of this story when Maria reflects back on her behavior:  "hey she's just human."  Uh no, it's more like "get over yourself" and stop committing career suicide.  Being a major B to someone who is just doing her job is evil, not to mention if you want to work in the hotel industry in the same area, word gets around of your bad behavior and you'll find yourself job hunting in another state.  This leads me to TSTL #2:  when she meets the owner of the hotel in person, she is again a major B.  Even though she thinks she's getting fired anyway, uh again , hello someone this high up could get you blackballed from not only any of the hotels in the area but in other parts of the country as well.  Her entire work history is with this one hotel and now she is risking not having any positive references from the folks who can really make a difference.I think this is the first time where I was disappointed in both the h and the H of a Lynda Chance book.  The sex scenes are incredibly written as always, but if I don't like the main characters, it can't overcome the nagging feeling in my head of "who cares."

Interesting world building, great heroine.  It's an apocalyptic future with zombies causing the mayhem. The heroine is brave, resourceful, independent.  The cyborg heroes didn't strike me as particularly different from regular guys other than being tall.  Their characterization I thought could have been more unique/other worldly.I'm fine with M/M but wish it was either solely M/M or just concentrating on her.  I was fine if the heroes were lovers in the past, but once they met Emma, I just wanted them to be into her - I know that's a greedy female perspective.I am a huge fan of this author's Grabbed series.  Can't tell you how many  times I've reread them because they're so good.  Highly recommend her Skyport Virgin book as well and hope the inner muse nudges her to write another sci-fi as I think she's at her best in that genre.

Karyn Lawrence's writing is really a cut above the pack.  If you're a Lisa Marie Rice fan, you'll really love Lawrence's writing style  and storyline.  Her heroines are interesting, compelling, independent and matched against alpha type men.  However, I personally find Lawrence's stories more enjoyable because they don't feel as formulaic and over-the-top in characterization as Rice's.There is a depth to Lawrence's leads which I don't often encounter in the romance genre.  Her leads aren't perfect, for instance the male lead has already been twice divorced and I have to say I was reluctant to buy this book based on that.  The way the hero's alphaness is displayed is more clever than other alpha's I've read about - he mentally manipulates rather than just yells/screams.  The heroine is no wilting lily and really shows her smarts, particularly when facing off against the bad guy.  Even the characterization of the bad guy/psychopath was well done.  The author drew a 3 dimensional character with the bad guy making you wonder what his next move will be and why.I think the only reason why I take off 1/2 a star is that I wish there had been more conversation/interaction between the hero/heroine before they fell into bed with each other.  Prior to the sex, it's just flirting and a feeling like the hero just likes the chase and this makes him seem too shallow for my taste.  Of course, he's not, but would have liked a better foundation for their attraction.Anyway, this is a great read that you will find a hard time putting down.  I read her previous book, "Stay",  which I absolutely loved and recommend reading before this one so that you can get a more complete idea of the entire storyline.I look forward to the next book this very talented writer comes out with.

I'd say this is 2/3 thriller and 1/3 romance.  I was fine with this combination.  The author spins a wonderful page turning tale.  I particularly enjoyed how she gave voice to minor characters - it really made the story that much richer.  I agree that it would have been nice to have learned  the H's POV or more interaction (other than mercenary action) between the H and h so that you understood more what she saw in him.You can definitely read this book without having read the previous book.  Pope really has a talent at sci-fi and I look forward to reading more in this series.  So far, I've read the 3 Zhore books and highly recommend them.

Great story telling. This is a wonderful sci-fi intrigue/romance.I loved how the romance developed between the two junior ambassadors as they trek across the planet.  Lirzhan, the Zhore ambassador knows instantly that Alexa is the one, but proceeds cautiously as he knows she doesn't share the same feelings in the beginning.  At first I thought Alex was a little on the immature side, but as I read more about her, I liked her and how she was a survivor.  Unfortunately she does have a major TSTL moment which while quickly resolved, it did really tick me off with the characterization.  She previously came across as mature, capable, courageous and granted she was under pressure and sleep deprived, I thought her traitorous turn on Lirzhan really made her unworthy of him.  If not for this, I would have given this story 5 stars.

I love to read Cajun romances and there are some nice elements to the world building here, but as much I've tried to stick with this series I'm giving up.  This storyline bugged me not only for the incompleteness of the final relationship but also the whole love triangle - the heroine was too much able to call the shots and for once, I felt like the male leads were really being led by the nose - this isn't alpha behavior.Something else that bugged me, the math being off:  whether it was how old she should have been (uh no way are you 22 when you're a year out of law school) or the number of nights she was with Luc (the storyline said she spent 7 but the narration indicates 4).  It's like the story needed an alpha reader who wasn't a friend of the author's and thus more likely to have a critical eye.

It took a while, but the author definitely delivered on book 2 of this series.  It's been so long since I read book 1, that I can't remember if I had any pet peeves about it, but certainly with this story, I didn't find any.  Zoey is probably the most kick-butt heroine I've ever read.  She ruthlessly goes against Cambions who kill innocents.  She has no time for the politics of her supernatural community and is all about the action.  This is a very thrilling read and what I really like is that there aren't any PC "oh I'm not going to kill the serial killer cuz whatever."  Bad guys get handed their axx and I love that.There does seem a slight TSTL action on the hero's part where he could have closed the gap with Zoey earlier by texting her  about what happened in book1.  He did try calling her every day and felt if she didn't pick-up then she wasn't ready to listen.  But seriously, couldn't he have tried texting to get his side of the story across and extend the olive branch more effectively?

I bought this last year based on the the higher reviews I saw.  I should have waited for more reviews to come in.  As the more recent ones indicate, this mattress offers zero support.
