Heavy sigh, $300+ wasted.  Makes me wonder about the earlier reviews - were they planted by the seller or did the manufacturer change the design slightly after the initial offering on Amazon?

Another great one!  I love this author's sci-fi and fantasy stories, but I think she really outdid herself on this one.  The world building was great as was the building of the relationship between the H and h.  I always find the opening of her stories unique and not at all formulaic; there is something very creative about the characters back stories.

I went in with expectations that this would be a case of opposites attract and the comedy would draw from that, but didn't find myself chuckling that much.  This felt like a high school romance to me with the dialogue and actions more suited for teenagers rather than grown men and women.

This is the 2nd Rock Chick book I have read.  I read the first one as I was hoping to fall in love with a whole new series from Kristen Ashley, but the 1st Rock Chick book didn't grab me like some of her other books.  I picked Regret to read as I noticed it was the highest rated book of the series on Good Reads.Unfortunately, I can't echo the high ratings.  I found the story to be filled with repetitive description of how hot looking the hero is and how all the women and men encountered in the story are gorgeous in one form or the other.  The story felt so removed from reality - with the exception of the cafe owner, do any of these women have jobs?  They seemed to live these almost high school level lives where they hang out at the cafe, shop, and do each other's make-up.What I found the most off-putting was the lack of sensitivity and respect towards keeping the heroine's rape confidential.  The Rock Chick gang and their men just share this intensely private information to any and all - it doesn't matter if they think the listener is someone sympathetic to the heroine; it's not their story to tell.  Also, a doctor would be confronted by an ethics panel for blurting this out in front of a dozen people whom he knows aren't the victim's family - it doesn't matter how much he feels intimidated, he'd be in serious trouble.The whole different personality types of the heroine:  ice princess, new Sadie, sarcastic Sadie, etc., just felt silly.  I understand the reasoning behind the heroine putting up a facade and just the ice princess one would have been fine, but all the others made her seem mentally unstable although I think the author was trying to go for charmingly kooky.Maybe if the story had been cut down more, I too would have succumbed to the magic of the Rock Chick gang.  Perhaps just enough detail to chuckle rather than rolling my eyes over the rinse/repeat of girl bonding, danger to the heroine, and personality changes.

I am so glad that Jan Karon returned Father Tim's character to Mitford.  I certainly enjoyed his adventures outside, but it's nice to get the latest on the town characters.  I don't know if there are really places like Mitford, but I'd certainly like to find such a community for myself.I am amazed at the quality of writing in this series.  It would be understandable if it started to feel formulaic after so many books, but the author keeps it fresh and interesting.  I actually think the author has reached a higher plane in her writing when I look back at the first book (which I enjoyed) and compare it to this latest.  Father Tim's character, the life of a retired priest, the lives of the working poor, etc. are depicted much more realistically - their flaws are more apparent and yet living in a small town, they know to forgive them and mush on and find happiness in the little things and be generous wherever possible.I do want to caution people who pick-up this book, that you do need to read the whole series in order to understand and enjoy the story fully.I read in an interview that Karon plans to continue the series and I really hope the next one comes soon!

Overall, I really like Lynda Chance's books featuring hot alpha males.  She's definitely on my "favorite authors" list.  Unfortunately, this one wasn't as good as the first book in this series, "Rule's Obsession" which I do highly recommend.I did really like how the male/female quickly come to their "I love yous" and are very up front and honest about their feelings.  I wasn't super crazy about her still carrying the v-card at the age of 24 - that just seemed unrealistic, particularly since she wasn't a socially awkward wallflower.I was really into the story and was wondering how the big misunderstanding would evolve (all of these romances have something where the h/H temporarily come apart) and was very disappointed that it came about due to the heroine's concern over kids potentially becoming orphans.  Also, the hero could have made his argument about how their potential kids would never be alone, much sooner in the story.  It was just so unbelievable how after coming together, they were then able to be distant towards each other while living in the same space over a couple of weeks.  If the heroine was dead set on separating from him, why the heck didn't she immediately move out?  She seemed incredibly insensitive to keep herself around.  If she was really in earnest about making a break, she should have considered hightailing it out of her job to avoid even more contact with him.I did like that this heroine, similar to the author's "American Millionaire" was financially secure in her own right.  Most of Chance's heroines are at such a financial disadvantage to the hero and I dislike that being such a constant element.  I also liked how the hero was very patient in waiting for the heroine to grow up, before he made his move on her.  And I really, want to praise the author for the honest sexual health discussion the hero/heroine have with each other; it makes the h/H come across as smart and the sex scenes more realistic.On the strength of the first book in this series, I'll still check out Garrett's story, the 3rd in this series.

Not much of a murder mystery.  More of a thriller.  A small amount of backstory.It really lacked depth.  While it was mildly interesting, there wasn't anything to figure out.  You don't know too much more about the characters and the world than you did at the beginning.Still, nice enough as a momentary diversion.
There's a lot of sex.  Graphic sex.Then under that there is a fun story with Pele and surfing and pineapples.The story was fun.  The sex was...graphic.
I read this when it came out.  The whole comedy-of-errors routine is great fun.  for a modern read it is a bit stilted and crude, but it has some staying power.

If you haven't been reading all along, you need to start at the beginning...or at least with the book before this one.  The set-up is all based off events in the previous book.That being said, it is really easy to jump right in.  Toby ^has^ learned from her previous mistakes.  Use your allies; be careful who you trust; background info is critical.  Unfortunately, when dealing with truly long-lived beings background gets complicated.the big takeaway is a sublte but fundamental change.  What is going to happen when elf-shot is no longer a 100-yr sleep?

Early on there is a disjointed feeling that is in keeping with the main character's understanding what is going on.  A clever way to make current slang useable in the far future.I will buy the next in the series now.

I was enjoying the writing, but the characters don't remain true to their roles.  When the deadly female assassin complains about being rousted out of bed...I stopped taking it seriously.  And stopped reading.You may enjoy the modern feel, but the inconsistency of the characters bothered me and I cannot recommend this book.

Highly sexualized, but limited graphic sex.  At certain points in the mystery I felt like I was ahead of the game - a bit of a pacing problem.  Kit was less helpful than I expected at those times.I enjoyed the read.  Good copy-editing.  The end was a little anticlimactic.Overall, three and a half stars rounding up.  I WILL buy the next in the series.

Every man she meets seems to be either an object of unbridled lust or evil.  The book doesn't have an ending, it just stops.  Very little of the world building is pulled together cohesively.  The author would have been better served having Sara run several missions before getting into the Las Vegas scene.  The plot tries to grow up too fast.I will not be continuing with those series.  Which is a shame because the short story was very good.

If you haven't read anything in the Wine of the Gods series...book 18 is not a good place to start.  I really like this universe (multiverse?), but there are so many characters and so much about the world(s) that is hinted at it becomes a bit overwhelming.  Unless you have read the whole series and have the background.That being said, for those of you who are fans this adds a wonderful new group of magic users to the mix.  Having some new blood to add to the already defined groups should shake things up nicely.  We also see more action by mage compass's, which is a nice change from the usual witches pyramids.  Some of the first hints of a coming tech/magic revolution that may make the industrial revolution look like a minor upgrade.  A whole new pyramid also is peeking around the edges.Now for the bad:  Much as I like this world ^and^ the writing, this is not a good short story.  This is more of a chronology of what happened.  While some of the characters learned new skills or information, we did not.  More about filling in the blanks and backstory than developing a character.There is a teaser at the end of the book showing the next(?) in the series that gives me a lot of hope.  The Sea Kings!!  An almost unexplored area.In closing, I liked it.  Fans will like it.  Everybody else needs to start earlier in the series, if not at the beginning, and develop a love for this world in order to appreciate this story.
I struggled a bit with reading this.  Wheels within wheels and double agents backing triple agents.  It just wasn't really to my taste.

The first chapter revealed some flaws in the structure.  An info dump hidden within an action sequence.  Worse, the characters doing all this dumping die at the end of the chapter.  So most of it is largely irrelevant.  I don't like books where you can skip the first chapter and still read the book.  Why put all of that there?  You just wasted my time.When the first chapter is poorly written I have no interest in investing more time.

An interesting SF read with some cool tropes on display.  The Romance side is a little odd.  Very stalker-like with impulse control issues.  The story flows well and the writing is good.  I just don't think this is very romantic.I do look forward to the next in the series, though.  A deeper examination of the virus and its impact would interest me.

Urban fantasy with a very visual component and a good eye for absurdity.  An effective, low cost entry to a new universe.  Some things I didn't understand, but adequate world building for a short story.Other authors should take note.  This is how you build an audience.

A little sloppy.  Needs proofing.  The world building is a little haphazard.Some unique ideas about magic systems.  I liked the Familiar design, but it wasn't really developed as well as it should have been.  A few too many plot points were glossed over with 'magic'.Entertaining, and Rudy is awesome.  I don't feel I can recommend this to a casual reader.

This is feels very YA, but it deals with some complex ideas.  I always enjoy books by Mr Dahner, as he takes a small number of technological breakthroughs and shows both how they would disrupt the world and how they could save it.  There is, however, a certain naveté and simplicity to some of the personal interactions.  For instance, a family that has been kidnapped previously and is now quite wealthy waits until another kidnapping attempt to upgrade security.  Then they hire cheap.  That doesn't scan well for me.I pre-order everything I can get from Mr Dahner.  His writing engages my imagination in very enjoyable ways.

You need to start with book one to get the full impact, but this was a heck of a lot of fun.  I don't know what it is about having the hero get the 'Bruce Willis' treatment just to get back up and do it all again the next day.  A little disappointed in the epilogue...did we have to go in that direction?  Ah, well.Finally meeting Merlin was interesting.  Too bad he's such an @$$.  The good news is there are even more people who want Nate dead.

My only quibble is...they really brought out the big guns.  Death, War, Pestilence, and Famine were in the last book for good reason: they were the warm-up act.  The archangel Michelle (Michael was a misprint), the Adversary, and then the supreme being all make appearances.This whole series has been well crafted.  Lunacy and hi jinks combined with danger and death.  Everybody from the earlier books gets a moment or mention.  Most long standing questions are answered.And warrior gnomes ride attack poodles into battle against Giants.For that alone, I will pre-order the next book J C Nelson writes.This is the third book.  Read them in order, otherwise you will be playing catch-up.

At one point Kevin is talking with John and refers to a part of John's character and past that he maybe shouldn't have known.  It made me stop for a second.  It happens when they were making cupcakes.Also, the Navy does not have battleships.  So maybe his brother was serving on a carrier?Otherwise a very good read.

Starving on a space station, yet the ship is allowed to depart.  No common language and no effort to learn one.  A 'dream machine' that she has a compatible interface for.The concept was good, it just needs further development.

I like the universe and the writing style.  I didn't like the fact that it was basically void of conflict.  By that I mean 2/3rds of the book is reasonable people doing reasonable things to reach a mutually agreeable conclusion.  There are a few minor points of conflict that may become interesting in the next book, but nothing really bad happens.  The final resolution is bland bureaucratic decisions.I will probably purchase the next book because I like the universe and the author, but I hope there is a better design to the pacing and structure.  Some conflict to resolve at the end that doesn't end up feeling almost anti-climatic.

A very good addition to the Ring of Fire series.  The story moves well from the outset and builds throughout.  Paris is the focal point of the plot with most of the mainline characters offstage or in subordinate roles.  Rebecca and Agustav have brief scenes, but mostly it is about France.  A few events I did not expect have now been added to the histories.Two complaints: wading through almost an entire Latin Mass plus English translation got a little pedantic.  I will say that the frequent use of Latin quotes brought a good deal of power to the prose, but at times it got a little clunky.  Secundus, it almost felt like the events found in 1634: The Bavarian Crisis did not happen.  Or I was unclear on how things turned out.Overall, I found this to be a very enjoyable read.  Some of the previous novels had me questioning my loyalty to the series, but this renewed my faith.  For fans of the series, this is quite a good addition.  For newcomers...I advise you to start at the beginning, but this actually works pretty well as a stand alone.  I did not feel the need to go back an re-read the series to figure anything out...but I did feel the desire.

I was disappointed in the last few books in the series.  This renews my interest.  Short stories that give you a vision of what is happening in the world without trying to drag in the cast of thousands.  Most of what happened in the last two books would have better been told through short stories.If you liked the Change series in the beginning, you will enjoy this collection.

I am not sure why.  The sex is still there, but it seemed to be less of a focus.  There was more purpose.  Anita was stronger and more confident.  Less apologetic about the weirdness.  It worked somehow.

I enjoyed some of the stories involving Rikiki and Granny, but there were others that...I respect the skill and insight that went into their crafting, but I did not enjoy reading them.  I was more conscious of the craft than I prefer.Amusing, but not top shelf.
And a little weak on plot.  More of a short story than a full novel in the series.  Good for fans; not so good for newcomers.

Half way through I got bored with the characters.  Here we have a widow who is also a genius mechanic and strong willed to boot, and she doesn't make a point of asking to fix the engines on the boat.  The ship has a six man crew which indicates a high level of automation, but the INVENTOR OF AUTOMATONS shows no desire to get busy after the ship was attacked by pirates.  Nope.  Here's a mop.

Once the plot got moving everything falls into place.  Early in the book, however, there is a lot of wandering and some bad editing.  Three consecutive sentences all starting with the same word can be used to good effect when you are trying to emphasize something.  This was NOT the case.Several tie-ins to the Sookie Stackhouse series.  This book focused mainly on Manfred and Olivia, although Olivia remains a bit of a mystery.For true fans...like you weren't going to buy it?  Who are we kidding?  But I would not recommend this as a sample of Ms Harris' work.Perhaps it is the multiple viewpoints that makes the early part seem to drag.

Vicky has found her purpose.  My problem with the first novel was a lack of direction.  While there was conflict, it lacked focus and the resolution was weak.  This book has much of the same scramble, but the Grand Duchess seems to be more refined or reforged by the chaos.  There is no big catharsis at the end, but the series has direction and motion now.The only danger is that Vicky will become too much like Kris.I look forward to the next in the series.

This is a bit coming of age with a hint of romance.  But it is more about realizing what you are meant to do and not simply learning to do things the way they have always been done.Our heroine is unexpectedly chosen by Dragon to be his companion/servant when she demonstrates a wisp of magical talent.  Her calling is vastly different from his methodical reasoned approach and his lack of civility (Salieri to her Mozart) makes her miserable.  Then there is the Wood.  An evil place that requires constant struggle to resist...and they are losing.  It gets bad before the end.This is a complete stand alone novel.  Another reviewer called it YA, but I am not so sure;  the sex scene isn't shy.

Three consecutive sentences using the same words...in the same place...and it was not for emphasis.  It seemed to be a fear of pronouns?  The twentieth time you start a sentence with "The general..." is maybe the time you should consider playing with word order or actually giving him a name.  Especially if we are talking about three pages of text.  I stopped reading quite soon after that.How can there be 93 people who think this is worthy of FIVE stars?!?!?  Bad writing, poor understanding of the military, and a stunning underestimation of the heart of the American public.

Mr James, your publisher is doing you a disservice.  $1.99 for 41 pages; your next novel is listed at 448 pages.  Thank god (and Amazon) your novel is not priced on the same scale as your short stories.Your writing is good.  I could be convinced to cough up 99cents for a short story from your pen.  Two dollars is a whole bunch of 'nope'.

130 pages, but the character list is three pages long.Way too many modern moments in a book set over 1,000 years in the future.Scenes that are done more for a giggle with friends than to advance the plot.Characters are named, vengeance is declared...wait, who is he again?  Why the hell should I care...It all adds up to a confusing mashup with no direction.  I stopped after chapter six (20%) and have no idea what was happening in the epilogue.  Each scene was amusing, but there was no coherence.I suspect some other reviewers are giving 'friend' reviews.

I think it's great.  My dog is not impressed.  The few times I convinced her to play with it, the rubberiness had her chasing the ball quite a bit.  She did seem to like the squeak.  I think I like it more.Very solid feeling ball.  Loud squeak.  But she likes her rope better.
You can almost see the end from the beginning.  The short story trips along quite rapidly but there is little substance.

Take R Lee Ermey; mix with Gunny Highway; a double shot of "Jarhead";  bake until there is barely anything intelligible left.No one with rank exhibits anything even remotely resembling leadership.  The suits are just magic - they actually refer to Butler as 'the chosen one'.  There is no logic to the plot.  The enemy has spaceships, but apparently the A-10 Warthog is a viable weapons platform.  And the hero's gun jams...you know, the one that is connected to the self-repairing armor?If you want good suit warfare, Armor, Starship Troopers, or Gust Front.  This is not it.As a retired Marine, I feel this load of crap does a dis-service to my beloved Corps.

Turn of the (last) century England.  Aspiring apprentice female magician.  Assigned to what appears to be a useless form of magic, which of course is nothing of the sort.The magic form is clearly inspired by origami, but I don't recall having read anything like this.  The whole Excision magic is not well described, but it IS the evil form that no good people use, so...  The trip through the actual heart of her teacher/Master is another point I haven't seen before.I am going to buy the next book in the series.  The magic system is interesting and innovative.  The romance aspect is barely present until near the end and it is very clean and family friendly.
Up to chapter five you feel like it's not a real novel; more a collection of snark and humor stitched together in a bizarre format.  Then a storyline starts to emerge.

The book moves at a VERY fast pace.  The characters are mostly issue driven with artificial depth.  Later plot twists end up being almost too convenient and heavily foreshadowed.  The whole is quite libertarian.A decent book for a light read, but I don't feel I can recommend it.

It felt too modern for a true fantasy.  Governmental institutions and policies that were unsupported by the character of the environment.  There were inconsistencies in what some characters knew or believed that pushed me out of the story.  Motivations were repeated for certain goals to the point of annoyance.Proofreading was lacking.  Several instances of scrambled word order or doubled words.  Spelling and punctuation seemed clear.It's not terrible. Just not good.The mass down vote in retribution was amusing.  Even funnier was the reviewer who CLEARLY stated she did not read the book, but was giving it five stars anyway...because feelings.  Or the one who called the author a "world class" storyteller...but gave it four stars.As to my 'modern' comment:  if the setting is medieval and then modern social and cultural stuff is thrown in, it ceases to work for me.  It has nothing to do with Tolkien or high fantasy and everything to do with consistent writing.

I liked it.  As a part of the universe, it is an interesting backstory.But...it doesn't stand alone as a good short story.  And it's not meaty enough for a full novel.I look forward to the next regular installment. But, much like "Big Pete", you can get by just fine without reading this.  I wish it had been numbered X.5 instead of 6.The Loose Nuts team makes cameos but don't star.

This is book three.  Make sure you read books one and two for full understanding and enjoyment.The final battle is awesome.  Great characters and a very full world.The bad news is the early part...or maybe the middle.  I felt like there were too many side quests built in to the story.  For me it bogged down a bit around the library.  Which was tough because the library bit was awesome.I bought this book and am disappointed there won't be more in the series.  All of the major plot lines were resolved, although Lug never got his crossbow back.I whole heartedly recommend this series to anyone who likes their magic with a bit of modern sensibility mixed in.

The magic system is interesting.  The characters are plausible.  Everything is going along fine with a moderate fantasy feel and a little bit of romance-ish moments (heated glances, risque talk between sisters).  Then it happens.The twin sisters have to marry...the same man.  And they have to have sex simultaneously.  Using magic to multiply the number of penises available.yeah.  Just a bit too weird for me.

Tired old tropes given new life.Humanity is the backward stepchild of the Galaxy and barely tolerated except for a benevolent 'species' that looks out for less-developed planets.  The Earth ambassador at a massive space station run by robots is under-qualified and over her head as she deals with the pressures of her mother to get married and various people (alien and otherwise) to make decisions on behalf of Earth.Very light hearted.  But still with some bigger concepts about freedom and children hiding around odd corners.I am going to get the next installment now.  At 167 pgs, I would pay up to $3 for this without feeling cheated (it was free during a promotional push).

This is real SF.  Big concepts, hard questions...things that make you re-examine how you view the world.  Commander Kresnov manages to be more human than many of the 'organics' and faces real tests of her character.I don't really recommend you start here if you have never read from the series.  But it does fill in the blanks as you go along.I don't anticipate another book in this universe, but I would pre-order today if one was offered for next year.

Better than the first in some ways.  Her boyfriend keeps whispering sweet French endearments to her...with the problem being that his French is horrible.  "There is a gopher in my pants" made me LOL.If you like a sarcastic underdog, read this series.

I liked, really I did.  The characters held true and the addition of some Austrailian incryptids and the horrifying level of death possible from normal animals ther was fun.But...The world was shallow.  It may have been the pace of the action, but it rarely felt like anything was happening outside of what might happen at an American outpost.  I'm not looking for a bunch of "shrimp on the barbie ", "g'day mate" moments, but there was a lack of authenticity to it.I still liked the book.  I will pre-order the next one because it is still entertaining and I love the writing.  I just didn't feel like it was Austrailia.

Wow.  And then...wow.  But they...wow.I don't like giving 5 stars to a book in a series.  There are often weaknesses due to backstory and too many characters.Yeah.  This one spoke to me.  A deep plot with several threads that didn't get in each other's way and...If you have been reading Ms Briggs' work and enjoying, don't wait.  Start this one right now.If you haven't read anything else by Ms Briggs and this one looked interesting, drop what you are doing and start reading.This is actually a fine place to enter if you are new...and now I need to figure out what I was supposed to be doing instead of reading.  Totally worth it, but I just lost a few hours.

I like the characters.  I like the universe.  The story was nice.  But...This was more of a short story with a couple of REALLY explicit and involved sex scenes.  The plot was well thought out and a lot of ground work was laid for the coming series, but there was very little in the way of subplots.I will probably get the next book when it comes out, but I don't recommend this as your introduction to the world of Shifters.

Or fire the one that was used here.  Extra words that don't fit the sentence in every chapter.Real good writing.  Fun characters and interesting plot.  But so messy you are having to mentally edit as you go along.I'm going to read the next in the series, but I can't guarantee I'll finish if the problems persist.

I like Ms Shearin's writing and the dialogue is clever, but there were a few instances where the need for a snappy riposte drove the book out of character.  When the witty banter or turn of phrase is what drives the plot instead of vice versa the flow of the narrative breaks.  It felt as if Mackenna's character was not held true throughout.I will probably purchase the next book by Ms Shearin, but more work needs to be done on developing a solid main character before I would recommend this series to others.

Oh my gosh, I couldn't stop laughing the entire time I was reading this book! I think the author wrote this for fellow teachers, but even as a mom with kids in common core I found it highly entertaining. This would be a perfect book to read when you feel like throwing common core homework across the room! It would also be a great gift for any teacher in your life.Highly recommend!

I love quotes and I actually run a twitter and facebook account where I send several quotes out a day. While looking for new material I ran across Islamic and Arabian Quotes and Proverbs. It occurred to me that I know absolutely nothing about the quotes or proverbs from Islam or Arabia. I couldn't wait to download it and read them.On top of a ton of amazing quotes I have never read before, the illustrations and translations in its original language was a nice touch. My new favorite quote is:"Prepare for this world as though you will live forever, prepare for the next world as though you will die tomorrow" - Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Azaz

A Deal With God has one of the most unique story-lines I have ever read. It is loosely based in fact, as the people really existed and really died at very young ages. Of course everything else is a work of fiction.The way the women's lives intertwine is very strange. One dies, leaving behind three sons and a husband. The other is brought back from a coma by making a *deal with God*. The how and the why their lives come together are what really make this book worth reading though, and I don't want to spoil that for you.It is portrayed as a Christian romance novel. If you are looking for a clean cut, probably doesn't actually happen in real life type novel you should probably skip this one. As a Christian from birth I can tell you that this is a more accurate representation of how it really is this day and age. The good news is that this book highlights how forgiving God is.I think anyone would enjoy this, religious or not. Highly recommend!

Aegis Rising was recommended to me by a fellow mom for my 15 year old daughter. We are both constantly on the lookout for good YA books as both of our kids love to read.This is by far one of the best YA books I have read in a long time. There are five main characters: Aari, Mariah, Kody, Tegan and Jag. They are mysteriously brought to a hidden valley after their plane crashes somewhere in Northern Canada. They soon find out that this valley is inhabited by a secretive people with amazing capabilities. These people believe that the five teenagers are a part of their ancient prophecy.One of the main things I liked about this book is that each character is depicted so well and the setting of the forest and the hidden valley is described so beautifully that I felt like I was right there! The dialogue was never awkward, which is a pet peeve of mine. The action scenes were truly gripping. Overall this is a very well written novel. It is a fast paced sci-fi adventure novel that will take you on an amazing journey. Highly recommended!

My family will be traveling a lot this summer and when my friend told me how prevalent the MERS virus is, it freaked me out. I have young children and the thought of them catching it is pretty scary.I'm so glad I found this book. I feel so much more prepared. I know exactly what it is and how to (hopefully) prevent it. Worse case scenario I feel like I can make it less severe if we do catch it. The author has clearly researched the subject in depth and shares this wealth of information with us. Highly recommend to anyone worried about MERS.

Constricted is the first dystopian romance I have read. It was a dark read, that touched on many subjects that tend to make any human being with a conscience uncomfortable. Unfortunately they are real issues, even if this novel is a work of fiction. The book took several pages to get going. It doesn't have a "hook" that grabs your attention right from the start. Definitely stick with it though because once it does get going, it doesn't stop!The main characters, Korrigan and Petre were well developed and easy to relate to. The pace at which their relationship develops is very believable. Relationships that start out completely far-fetched is a huge pet peeve of mine that I usually have to endure with most romances. I have no doubt that this will be one of my favorite series and I can't wait for the next installment!

This book reminds me of a movie I watched several years ago. It also had a serial killer with an alternate personality. Both were in the horror genre and gross and disturbing at times but also also absolutely hilarious. I know those two things shouldn't go together, but when they do it's awesome.One thing I really loved about Simon Says is that the main character, David, is relatively normal until his wife cheats on him. Then he completely snaps and does whatever atrocious acts "Simon" tells him to do. It really makes you wonder about the people in your own life. You never know what could make a person play a dangerous game of Simon Says.

Hunter Fairchild had a rough childhood. As an adult he concentrated more on his accomplishments and outward appearances than his inward thoughts and interpretations of himself. Basically he was all shiny on the outside and dull and hollow on the inside. Finally at the peak of his career and when he had the big impractical house and trophy family his demons came back to haunt him. He decides to go back to his hometown to face them head on, even though he swore he would never go back.No Man's Land is a fast paced thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very last page.

This is one of the most unique books I have ever read. A cross between romance, mystery, and suspense Entrusted will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end. Actually I have been thinking about it even thought I have already finished it!I have never read anything with Native American history in it before, and I had never heard of the Raven either. I think it made the story all that more interesting. I love learning new things about other cultures.Emma, Luke, Soloman and the rest of the characters were very well developed. The pace of the story is great, and there are enough plot twits to keep you guessing the entire time. Highly recommend!

This is a great book to read if you feel like you are called to a certain trade. It is written specifically for hairdressers/beauticians, but anyone who wants to learn a trade would benefit greatly from this information.It covers everything from choosing the right teachers to gaining customers to reinvesting in yourself. Even more importantly it tells you what to do with the extra money you make to attract even larger sums of money. I bet the advice will surprise you. It's definitely not something I would have thought of myself.I would highly recommend to anyone looking to take control of their financial destiny.

I bought this book without realizing that it was based on a game. The cover sucked me in and the blurb finished me off. I couldn't pass it up!Garland is a well fleshed out character and I enjoyed following him along on his adventures even though I had never played the game. I highly recommend An Elder Scrolls Epic to everyone, fan of the game or not. It is a well written fantasy novel.

I have been suffering with TMJ problems since as far back as I can remember. Of course I don't know the exact cause of my pain, but I do know that I tend to clench my jaw when I am tense, mad, or stressed. This leads me to have painful headaches and tooth pain. Sometimes even neck pain.Unfortunately I can rarely afford to go to a chiropractor so I have been trying to find ways to treat it on my own. This book is amazing. My husband was hesitant to try to the techniques on me at first, but the pictures and directions were so well written that he was confident he could do it. I have been doing it once a day for about a week now and it has helped immensely.Highly recommend!

My good friends husband has unfortunately just been diagnosed with prostate cancer. My friend has confided in me how nervous she is for her spouse's surgery, recovery, and their future as an intimate couple.Having no experience with it myself, I tried to find something with more information than we had. I am so glad I ran across this book! Sex After Prostate Cancer is written by a women who has first hand experience with everything and goes on to share that knowledge with her fellow warrior wives.The entire book is chock full of helpful information you wont get anywhere else and it is also highly inspirational. If you, or anyone else you know, is suffering from prostate cancer please get them this book.

I am a sucker for true stories, so when I saw Duplicity I knew I needed to read it. A true life deceit/crime story. Almost like a "Snapped" episode, minus the murder. It was better than I expected. The book starts out with the main characters, also the person writing the book, finding a Russian wife. They have a child together named Johnny but then she leaves him high and dry.As a single dad he tries to find someone new to spend his life with. However, since he wants love so bad he is blind to certain flashing red lights. Aubrey pretends to be taking care of her elderly grandma, which is supposedly the reason she can only be home a few days a week. What she is really doing is lying, stealing and leading a prostitution ring that ends up being an International ring.Instead of getting mad (well, he probably did get mad at first) Goldman got even. He brought down his second wife and made the world a better place. Through tragedy he found his life's passion and lucky for us, made it into an amazing story for us to read.Highly recommend!

Tales from the Palace of the Fairy King takes a boy falling in love with a princess to a whole new level. Tom is desperate to be noticed by the princess he has only seen from afar. Unfortunately meeting her is not easy as he knows in his heart that he will have to prove his love to her by some valiant act. Unfortunately no danger is close at hand.A cunning imp takes advantage of his yearning and turns him into a beautiful tree that he promises the princess will love. Of course, there is a catch. The tree will only live one year....Tom was a well fleshed out character. you could really feel his longing for the princess and his despair when his plan doesn't work. Will the princess be able to save him from his dark fate after he risked everything to have her?

I heard great things about Garcinia Cambogia, but after trying a few different products I was less than impressed and had pretty much given up.My friend told me about these pills, and said how much energy they gave her and how she was dropping the extra lbs so easily on it. I decided to give it a try, but I didn't have much hope.I am so glad I decided to listen to her! These pills are amazing. I don't know what was in the other ones I tried, but it definitely wasn't as pure as this brand.Highly recommend!

Even as an adult, I still love well written YA books/series. However, now I have an even better reason to keep an eye out for them. My daughter loves reading and I love finding great books we can read together.Ascension was everything I look for and more. Usually I steer clear of novels that have so many characters, it just gets confusing and I never really feel connected to any of them. Not true with this one! All of the characters were amazingly well fleshed out. They all had their flaws and their strengths and blended together seamlessly. The romance wasn't just thrown in as an after thought, it went with the story perfectly.The writing was descriptive enough that you felt like you were right there with Charles, Clark, Donnie, Chloe and the rest of them. The action scenes were particularly good and kept you on the edge of your seat while you read them. About the only flaw I can think of is that there wasn't enough focus on the main characters parents. I felt like they should have been a bigger part of the story. Maybe they will be in future books.Highly recommend and I can't wait until the next installment!

I have been struggling to go gluten free. I can really tell a difference when I stop eating it, but sometimes it is SO HARD to find good recipes. Inevitably I give up and just go for some easy pasta and bread.My friend recommended this cookbook. She absolutely loved it and since we both try to cook as much in the crock-pot as possible in the summer she said it was a must read. I'm so glad I listened! I've tried a few recipes already they are so tasty. The whole family loved it. I also love how easy the book is to read. Sometimes I give up on recipe books because they are just too confusing.Overall I highly recommend to anyone who is gluten free, or struggling to go gluten free.

I bought this book for my three and five year old daughters. They absolutely adore cats and I loved that it was a rhyming book, as that is what my five year old is supposed to be working on as her next skill.This was our first jaunt with Cassie, but it definitely won't be the last! The story flowed smoothly, even though it was a rhyme and my girls have been asking for it as their bedtime story for a the past week or so. The illustrations are also really cute and the kids love looking at them.Highly recommend!

I love Historical Romance. Every time I read a novel in this genre I wonder why I don't read them all the time. Dream Time was the first one I have ever read set in Australia and I loved it! I hope there are more of them. If you add to that the well fleshed out characters and a plot that won't stop twisting you have a real winner.All (well most) of the characters were great and I loved them, but my favorite has to be Nan. The interactions between all of the characters was great and the dialogue was never awkward. A pet peeve of mine, and it seems to rear its ugly head in romance novels more than anywhere else.Overall a solid five stars ,and I can't wait for the next book.

This is one of my husbands favorite games. When I saw this *unofficial* guide I knew I had to get it for him. It has basically become his gaming bible, and has earned me huge brownie points. According to him it is absolutely awesome and he highly recommends it.Maybe a good Father's Day gift for all the gamer dads.

Cash Chronicles is the type of book you never knew you would absolutely love. The story-line is unique, but it isn't trying so hard to be unique that it loses itself in the process. We follow Samson in a post Civil War era. There is a bit of timeframe jumping to his past but luckily it is never confusing. There are Mutants in this wild west and it is all the more interesting for it.The characters are well fleshed out, the writing is witty and flows well, and the entire novel will leave you drooling for the next installment. Pick it up, you won't regret it!

For a long time I have suspected that a close friend has an eating disorder. I wanted to be able to understand it better before approaching her about it, so I bought Freedom From Eating Disorders so I could be better equipped to deal with her situation. I am so glad that I picked this book. It was so helpful, explaining each common eating disorder in detail, how the personal suffering from it feels and thinks, and what it can look like on the outside. It even showed a link between a certain vitamin and anorexia! Who would have thought?Very well written and researched. Highly recommend.

I have one of those marriages where everything is going really amazingly well, or we are at each others throats for days on end. We have been together for 10 years, and I still can't figure out the *why*. Why we get along so well when we do, and what goes wrong when we fight so much.The Relationship Triangle goes over the three most important things in any relationship: respect, trust, communication. He shows examples of those things when they are working.....and more importantly, when they go wrong.Overall it was a very informative read, and on top of taking notes (which I did) I'm sure I will be re-reading it when my relationship is going through a tough time. Highly recommend!

John Mack is the type of person that everyone wishes they knew personally. Well, at least those of us who realize that some form of a breakdown of civilization is almost guaranteed. If we did know such a person, we would be able to sleep better at night!Last Stand, and other prepper books, are basically the horror genre. More and more people are waking up to the many threats that are lurking just around the corner. This book shows a town right after an electromagnetic current is let loose and it thrusts everyone back a few centuries in time. No computers, no satellites, no cell phones. Will John be able to save his friends and neighbors? Will he even be able to save himself?One thing I really liked about this novel is how much legitimate prepper techniques were incorporated into the story-line. Very educational.Highly recommend!

Two good friends of mine and I have a pact. When one of us finds a particularly amazing erotica story, we immediately tell the others about it. So when my friend called me up and told me I absolutely had to read The Visitor Arrives I got it immediately. She didn't let me down!This bundle comes with four different stories, but they all have Lea and her amazingly hot (firefighter!) roommates Sean and Andy. The sex scenes are very well written and flow very naturally. I also love that even though they are super steamy, they don't have that *ick* factor that some of the more hard core erotica does.Loved it! Don't pass this one up!

I absolutely love Georgia O'Keeffe and since I have already read so many biographies on her I was super excited to find this book. Instead of being a biography it is an in-depth look on how her work became what it was.I am ashamed to admit that I never knew the tie between her and Zen Buddhism and never dreamed that it had influence on her work. In fact, I honestly didn't even know what Zen Buddhism WAS until reading this book. I found the entire book to be very well researched, both when it came to the religious and cultural references as well as everything about Georgia O'Keeffe.The list of the biographies at the end was very thorough and there were some that even I had not read, which was surprising to me. Solid five stars!

I love horror stories. However my torture of choice is short horror stories, because if they are too long and involved I feel like the horror element gets lost...and I can't sleep at night. One of the main reasons I enjoy anthologies is because there is a little bit of everything. Even if I don't have the same favorite as my friend, we usually both still have a favorite and enjoyed all of them.I felt like Rite of Passage was the most horrific. There was nothing about it but darkness and it just oozed creepy. Loved it! Don't worry, if you are more into horror stories with better endings, this has quite a few of those. The Mushroom Man was my favorite in that category.Overall this is a solid five stars. Excellent, descriptive writing and spine tingling stories.

I absolutely love the re-telling of classic tales. I am a HUGE fan of the t.v. series Once Upon a Time and it's spinoff OUAT in Wonderland. It is so much fun to discover hidden parts of the story that make so much sense. Yet never in a million years would you think of them yourself.Holy Ghost Writer took up a formidable task when writing this novel, but accomplished it with flying colors. It was true to the original story with lots of added *bonus features*. Highly recommend to any fan of a great story. Young and old alike will enjoy this one!

The author's bio is what initially intrigued me enough to purchase this book. I just knew it would be entertaining and break all the rules, in a good way, and I love reading books like that. Not the kind where spelling and paragraphs are thrown to the wayside, but where you just feel like you are a close friend of the main character and they let you into that locked away part of their brain that very few people get to see... Does that make sense? Probably not, but that is how I feel!Forced Entry didn't let me down. It was a small glimpse into the deep and dirty south. Coming from a state that has recently legalized "ganja" I can definitely understand the *criminal* side of things and how it really shouldn't be a crime in the first place!A quick and entertaining fast paced read. Don't pass this one up!

Being married for ten years, my sex life has had its fair shares of lulls and we have had to resuscitate it more than a few times. And who hasn't wondered what it would feel like on the other *end* of things? Both of those elements are what prompted me to get His WIsh, but whatever the reason I'm glad I did.The story line was well thought out and executed and the characters were well fleshed out. A very entertaining and well written erotica story. Highly recommend to any fan of the genre. I'm sure this one will be read more than once.

What an amazing and inspiring read Soul Skin is! It is so well written and I am almost certain that everyone will be able to relate to the main character Navi, even if they themselves haven't been in her exact situation. Navi is in the middle of a mid life crisis. Trapped in her mundane day to day life, she escapes at night. How? By going on amazing *Dream Journeys". The places and events she travels to are enough of a reason to buy the book.Overall this is a very well written novel. The plot is well thought out and the pace will keep you turning pages late into the night.Highly recommend!

The Former World is such a unique and engaging book. Combining mystery, suspense, and the paranormal, along with an engaging plot and well fleshed out characters.The main character Beth is the average small town girl, wanting to get away and go on to bigger and better places. Her escape is all planned but ends up never happening due to some unforeseen circumstances. However, the small town of Little Forest is much more interesting than Beth ever imagined. So much so that she might not survive what lies just under the surface of the town.Can't wait for the next installment!

What a great start to a series! Draconis' Bane has all the elements of a great fantasy. The hero, Prince Tristan, is young and flawed and will have to go through some major changes before reaching his full potential. The Seven Kingdoms suffer from lack of Dragon magic and they have to figure out a way to bring it back before it is too late. However, there are those who will stop at nothing to sabotage their quest. Will they succeed in time?Overall a great novel. There were some grammatical errors and pacing problems, but it didn't detract from the overall story. I will definitely read the whole series!

I absolutely loved this book! I'm sure there are others out there like it, but I have never read one. The fact that the main character, Tressa, is an author who writes por - errr erotica while also being a haggard worn down mother who, as her daughter puts it, has gone past her expiration date is just the perfect set up for hilariousness.If you think you know where this book is going, I can almost guarantee that you don't. It is original, funny, quirky, and I absolutely loved it! Of course it is on the shorter side, because it is clearly a short story and I can't wait for the next installment.

After reading the first book I couldn't wait to get me some of my Chase fix. I'm not ashamed to say that I have a serious book boyfriend crush on him. I love how he is so sexy, honorable and loyal yet so dark at the same time.This book pretty much starts right where Stand By Me ends. Chase's younger brother, Will and his girlfriend Cassie are a good addition to the story. They were well fleshed out characters and you could really feel how much Chase loves his little brother and how he would do anything for him. Unfortunately *anything* includes some unsavory things since Will and Cassie have a past that is not letting them get away. Through all this Kay is right by Chase's side, but will Chase go so far down the wrong path that not even she can bring him back?I love Kay and Chase so much that I honestly can't decide which book I like better, but it really doesn't matter because everyone needs to read both! Can't recommend highly enough. I hope I can convince my book club to read both of the books.

I usually stay away from the shorter erotica stories because I like to get lost in longer story and get to know the characters. However, when I read Cowherd's description I just had to buy it. I'm so glad I did. It is so well written and provocative. Usually in fetish books it is awkward and *so* not believable.Anna is not only very like-able and believable, but the entire story-line flows smoothly and it's almost like you yourself are being hypnotized. Highly recommend.

A great story with a strong romance at the center of it. I loved the book's setting in the New York City classical music scene and how the characters all came to be members of the orchestra at the same time. The description of Li Hua's childhood really spoke to me since I also grew up around classical music. The scenes with Tony were definitely my favorite since they got me laughing and (later) got me feeling emotional. I really sensed their love for one another as time went on.I realize that the dramatic scenes were instrumental to telling the story, but reading about her bad decisions was sometimes hard. The fact that these  scenes were unconventional and gave the plot some twists and turns was a nice surprise. I also liked how the story changed as the plot unfolded. Tony was probably my favorite character and I found myself laughing out loud at his antics and the things he said. If anything, I would have enjoyed reading more background about orchestral players and why they do what they do. This is a hot romantic suspense kindle book and very well told. Good story.

I was lucky enough to have parents who were willing and able to take me lots of places growing up. I can definitely appreciate how much your horizons are expanded when you travel and exactly how important it is. Now that my (four!) kids are getting older and will now be able to remember the trips I want to start taking them at least one destination every year.I already have a few options set in place for this summer, but my husband and I have really been stressing. We are the type of people who like to have everything planned and the kids completely entertained if at all possible. I decided to see if I could find some kind of guide to help me the first few times.I can't begin to tell you how happy I am that I found this book. It is basically the traveling with kids bible and I will be recommending this to everyone I know who has kids.Solid five stars.

My best friend told me about this boxed set and that I absolutely had to get it. She had read all of them and told me that on top of having very well written sex scenes, the actual story-lines and characters were interesting as well.I had a hard time believing it, and I usually stay away from the shorter erotica because of that reason. I love to get lost in characters and stories and short stories/novellas just don't do it for me. Not true for this box set! Every single story was interesting and had well fleshed out characters. My favorite was definitely "Cuff Me". I guess I must have a thing for police officers.Highly recommend to any fan of erotica. Even if you usually aren't into the shorter stories.

I bought this in the hope that it would be a beneficial book for my sixteen year old daughter to read. She lost a very good friend to a tragic car accident a few months ago and she has been having a really hard time with the "why does God let things like this happen". I decided to read it first so I could make sure it was what I was looking for. My Beauty for Your Ashes surpassed any expectations I may have had.The story and characters are believable and relatable. All the characters were amazing and had incredible stories behind them, but Victoria's story touched me the most.My daughter has read the entire book and it has helped her tremendously. Of course not all is healed, but I have hope for the first time that they might be able to. She has even re-read some parts in the short time since we found it.Highly recommend even if you aren't currently going through a hard time.

I have scoliosis (a curvature of the spine). When I was sixteen I was lucky enough to have parents who took me to the chiropractor once a week for over a year. It definitely helped a LOT. Especially since I was still growing and developing my muscles and bones.Unfortunately, over 10 years later I am a stay at home mom of four girls who can't afford to go to the chiropractor regularly. I've been getting headaches more and more regularly and my right hip starts to hurt because my right leg is shorter when my spine is off. I knew I absolutely had to find a solution.Luckily I found this book! Since I have started implementing the techniques my hip pain has great decreased and my headaches have gone from lasting days to lasting a few hours. I'm hopeful I will be able to eliminate them soon.Highly recommend to anyone not able to make regular trips to the chiropractor.

I try to make sure to read at least one new self help book every month and re-read one a month. Optimal Living 360 was my *new* read this month, but it will be my *re-read* next month. As someone who makes a lot of decisions based on emotions this book was particularly helpful. The author isn't kidding when he says it contains a LOT of information, but its all really really good.I also loved the *power-points* at the end of every chapter highlighting the most important things covered. I actually took screen shots of those so I can reference the golden nuggets of information quickly.Highly recommend!

Reading a book like this makes you want to hug your loved ones a little tighter. The scenarios that happen in Armageddon and the 4th Timeline are not far fetched. In fact you can easily imagine it happening. And soon!The plot has a lot of Christianity woven into it. As someone who has been a devout Catholic from birth I can assure you that the author is well versed in Christianity and everything is spot on. Even if you are not a Christian I would not let that deter you from reading the book, as it is still an amazing read.I also want to point out how well the time travel aspect was done. If done correctly it's one of my all time favorite elements in a book, but very very very few authors can pull it off effectively. Much to my happy surprise this novel was probably the most well done I have ever read.Overall this book is a solid five stars and I will be telling everyone I know about it.

I am the branch manager for a mortgage company and between all of the branches we are pretty competitive. When a fellow branch manager started being number one again and again I had to know his secret. He said that he read The Decoded Company and applied what he learned.It sounded simple enough so I bought and read the book immediately. Let me tell you, I have never had so many "aha!" moments in such a short time. The Decoded Company goes over three basic things to implement and I can guarantee that if you actually take the time read the book and do what it says you will see amazing results.Seriously, if you own your own business or manage a company you absolutely need to read this book. I can't recommend it highly enough.

This is one of those rare books that is almost impossible to explain in a way that does it justice. Anything I seem to come up with just doesn't seem like it explains it in a way that comes close to how I felt reading it. I have never personally read a book like this before. I'm not sure if there are many out there, but I can't imagine them being half as good.NOW is written in first person, and that was probably the best decision. Ever. It really helped me feel a connection to the main character. Reading this book puts you on your own personal thought provoking and emotional journey right along side the protagonist.Overall the book is written very well. The plot is well thought out and executed. Highly recommend.

Whew - what a ride! My friend highly recommended The Rainy Day Man to me, and I am so glad she did. Danny was the most unique character I have come across. That is saying something because I read a LOT. The way the book starts just hooks you right in and doesn't let you go until the end. Even then you will find yourself thinking about this book long after you turn the last page.I don't want to say too much and give away something, but you do NOT want to pass up this book. It is an amazing espionage/thriller. Even that description does not really do it justice. Solid five stars.

There are thousands (probably, I've never actually counted) of financial self help books. So why did I decide to get this one? Because the description jumped out at me. I am a huge believer in positive thinking and laughing at yourself. This book concentrates on both of those traits.On top of it being an easy read because of the way it is written, it is chock full of practical advice. If you are interested in learning how you can LITERALLY find money every day (including how you can increase your paycheck without getting a raise) then do not pass up on this amazing book.I loved the affirmations at the end. Some of them are practical, some of them are awesome, and some are funny. Which really just sums up the book in general.Highly recommend!

This work is labeled as a Science Fiction novel. It certainly does fit some of the criteria for that, but it is definitely not *hard core* sci-fi. In fact, it is kind of ominous in the sheer fact that anything and everything in this book could actually happen!In the not to distant future, science and technology determine who is the ultimate world power. The United States is in a constant struggle with the Middle East to stay ahead.We follow Kantak Johnshon, a native Alaskan as he studies at MIT and eventually goes back to his long distance girlfriend back home. Things really go to a head when the two world powers disagree on oil prices. That causes a huge electromagnetic burst of energy to be used as a weapon….we all know what kind of devastation that would bring about in a world so heavily dependent on technology and electricity.Will the men in power stop destroying the world before it’s too late?Great, fast paced read! The only thing that brought it down to four stars is the fact that the characters all had the same *personality*. I really, really, REALLY have a hard time keeping characters straight when they all have the same voice and reactions. Overall not too much of a detraction from an otherwise great novel.

I love reading books with unique story-lines, but sometimes they can be a bit overkill with the originality. That is why I LOVED Spirit: Reckoning. It was completely original without any weirdness. Just my kind of book.Adele was a well fleshed out character. You can't help but fall in love with her fighting spirit and her journey will have you on the edge of your seat.I don't want to say too much for fear of giving something away! Overall the plot is solid and the pace will keep you turning the pages well into the night.Solid five stars.

If you are looking for a great read that has a little bit of everything, then look no further than Heads Off. Murder, mystery, romance, and even some humor. This book has it all!Lisa Becker is a homicide investigator who has some serious body issues. She can only see what the scale tells her is true, instead of seeing her true inner beauty. What will happen when she is sent on a particularly gruesome murder investigation with her sexy co-worker Fabian?The writing is smooth, the dialogue is never awkward and I can guarantee you won't see the end coming. Don't miss this one!

I have two girls - ages 5 and 7. I have been looking for a good kids book that I can read to them or they can read themselves. I really like it when books incorporate folklore and legends into the story so when I saw Flying Elephants and Other Stories I knew it was going to be the perfect fit.It has six stories. Handsome Prince, Broken Pot, Barber and Ghost, Flying Elephants, Six Blind Men, Tailorbird and Monkey. They all come with wonderful illustrations that fit the stories perfectly.I also really liked how at the end of every story, the *moral* was pointed out in a bold way. It is a really good way to teach the basic principles of life to kids in a way they will understand and enjoy.Highly recommend!

I am a huge believer in positive thinking and although I'm not newly married, my marriage has been suffering lately. We have been fighting a LOT and really just *lost that loving feeling*.When I saw Better Early Marriage Life I figured that good advice is applicable to anyone even if you aren't newly married. I was right. The advice in this book is applicable even if you aren't married at all and just want help relating to your friends/family. I also really enjoyed how the advice was broken up into manageable chunks.This is definitely one of those books that I will be keeping nearby to reference anytime I am feeling down. Highly recommend.

Recently I've run into some health problems, mostly brought on by stress. I'm trying to handle it in the most natural way possible and I learned that planning getaways (even if you never actually can take them) releases oxytocin and improves your mood.Normally I plan exotic getaways in my scrapbook that I can revisit anytime I feel down. However, when I saw The Ultimate North American Train Travel Guide it just spoke to me. Ten years ago I traveled by train and I LOVED it. I never thought of utilizing trains for a trip, but I could immediately see the appeal.This book is so jammed packed with good information that I am finally planning a REAL family vacation with it's help.Highly recommend!

I am a sucker for a well written romance novel, and Night Games was one of the best I have read in recent memory. The characters were flawed, but beautiful. The plot was well thought out and the writing was well executed. What else could you possible want?I fell in love with Grey. Chase was a little rough around the edges and at first I couldn't see what was so likable about him. Grey has been infatuated with the baseball player since the first time she saw him play baseball. On TV.As fate would have it, Chase gets injured and much to his displeasure he is sent to play in the majors. Where else but in Grey's home town!Will Chase let down his walls long enough to let Grey in? Will Grey be able to open to Chase about her checkered past?Highly recommend to any romance fan.

I had to take a last minute flight (family emergency) and I was in a bit of a panic. I detest flying and I usually find at least two amazing books to read on the flight to help distract me.I didn't have very much time to look, but I knew I wanted a thriller to suck me in. When I saw Assault on St. Valentines it just jumped out at me and I decided to give it a try.I definitely picked the right one! I was about half way through the book when the plane landed and I didn't want to get off so I could finish reading. That is something that has never happened before.This is a very fast paced (also very gruesome, so keep that in mind if you are sensitive to such things) thriller. If you like a book that immediately hooks you and doesn't let go until the last page then this is the novel for you.Hicks is an ex-mercenary living in London. Suddenly his world is turned upside down when a sect takes it upon themselves to murder as many innocent civilians as possible.He finds an adorable, newly orphaned, girl named Bethany. As a mother of four girls she absolutely stole my heart. Loved her character. We also get to know Hicks old friend, Singh, who knows that survivors of the attack are seeking *Sanctuary* at a nearby church. St. Valentines.Will they be able to survive the Assault on St. Valentines?Highly recommend!

I've always been infatuated with aliens, but haven't read many books with them in it. The really crazy thing is my brother and I have actually talked about aliens having to intervene to save humanity from itself. I can't wait to tell him about this series.The books are set in the future, at a time when our world is in a definite downward spiral. It definitely has a "left-wing" vibe to it, but as I agree with most of what is predicted it didn't bother me at all.All of the characters were well fleshed out. I particularly loved Baby. The writing was also superb and the dialogue was never awkward. Which is a huge plus in my book.Highly recommend to any Sci-Fi fan.

Amish Romance is an amazing collection of 45 short stories. My friend and I have been somewhat obsessed with with the Amish culture lately. However, the reality TV shows and other glamorized things are starting to get to us. We want to know what they are truly like!When my fellow Amish junkie recommended this book to me I couldn't get it quick enough. Usually I'm not much into short stories. I am a huge fan of falling in love with the characters of books, and short stories rarely give me my fix.Luckily Amish Romance was an awesome read, and despite the fact that the stories are shorter I still managed to grow attached to the characters.Overall I loved it and it was very well written. A great insight into the Amish way of living.

This is one of those book reviews that are so hard to write, for fear or saying to much and giving something away. I shall try my best anyway, because the book was too good not to write a review for!Small Digit: Thunder is about a boy named Phillip. Life isn't so great for him, due to the fact that he has a smaller than average *body part*.We follow him as he deals with his life problems, both real and imagined. Then there is a plot twist. When I say you won't see it coming, I'm not exaggerating.This is the first book in the series and I loved the ending. It left me satisfied while also looking forward to the next installment.Highly recommend!

'Testimony Tulip' is an adorable children's book. It was much better than I anticipated. The pictures were very artistic and the way the flowers and plants are drawn really attracts the little ones. My three and five year old loved the book and looking at all of the colorful pictures.The story is about Tess the Tulip who decides to help her friend Billy the Bush find his younger seedling. Even though she would rather play with her friends, and her friends themselves don't think it is their responsibility to help.Will she be abel to convince everyone to do the right thing?Overall this is a great book to read to the 2-6 year old age group. Very cute story.

This is one of those books that literally blindside you. It's so unique that you aren't sure what to expect in the first place. Then, what you get so far exceeds what you thought.'There Be Dragons' brings myth and reality together in a particularly amazing way. Who would have ever thought that the Vietnam War and Dragons would go together? Not me. I guess that is why I read books and not write them.In this book the main character, Jacobs, heads off to fight in the Vietnam War. He goes for all the right reasons and worries about all the normal soldier stuff. Things like, will his wife wait for him and how will he be able to handle killing enemy soldiers. Never in his wildest imaginings can he prepare for what truly awaits him.This is a very fast paced and well written novel. The characters are flawed and raw. There is quite a bit of blood and gore, but that is only to be expected in this genre.Solid five stars.

Recently I have decided to start getting serious about my blog. I love it, but unfortunately it's just not getting very much traffic. I don't really have a lot of money to pour into advertising so I figured that learning how to generate traffic myself was the way to go.Thanks to this book, I am well on my way to getting traffic (and money!) to my blog. *Online Marketing 101* is a literal gold mine of information. Even if you do some of the basics, this is very helpful.I really enjoyed the author's '5 Principles' and the sections on SEO. I never understood SEO and it always intimidated me. Now I feel like I have a much better understanding of how to utilize this amazing tool.Highly recommend!

I seriously can not get enough of Zaydee. She is so amazing! Probably one of my favorite female characters. Ever. That's saying something because the competition is pretty fierce since I read so much.This installment finds Zaydee in jail, going to great lengths to protect Steven, and you guessed it. Starting her own country! It's only a small island, but still awesome.The pace is very fast. Anyone who loves thrillers and/or crime/mystery will have a hard time putting this book down once they get started.Highly recommend the whole series!

Even though I had already read the NON-anniversary edition, I couldn't pass this up when I saw it! I absolutely love this series and highly recommend it.This book will hook you right from the first few sentences. Something about the writing just draws you in. Once I downloaded the sample it was all over, I wasn't able to put it down. I don't recommend reading it before bed!The Risen is anything but predictable. You will find yourself reading super fast just to se what happens next. No one is safe either, so don't become overly attached to any of the characters!The zombies (Risen) are horrifying. Add in the descriptive writing and you have yourself a genuine horror novel.Highly recommend to any avid reader!

I'm pretty sure that this is the very first YA dystopian type novel I have ever read. Either way, I LOVED it and will be on the lookout for others like it.This book follows Michael, who has special powers. The world he lives in is very different from our own. Chaos rules and he joins forces with a group called Trifecta to help restore peace.Unfortunately he soon finds that he can't trust anyone and nothing is as it seems.The story was never boring and there were enough twists and turns to keep you guessing until the very end. THEN you will be left anticipating the next book in the series!Michael is also a great role model for the younger readers to look up too. Highly recommend!

My husband has always wanted a huge, glorious, fish tank. I was apprehensive because all I could see was a bunch of dead fish floating in it. We have never had very much luck keeping fish alive. He was insistent so we went to the store.We were both pretty overwhelmed at all of the choices so we decided the best thing to do would be to research first so we wouldn't waste a fortune for nothing.Luckily I ran across this book. It is a literal gold-mine of information. On top of answering all our questions, as well as some we didn't even think to ask, it goes over the many benefits of having a fish tank. I had no idea how awesome it was to have an aquarium in your house!Now I'm on board with my husband and can't wait to get started. Thanks to this book I know exactly where to begin.Highly recommend!

I love reading books with unique story-lines. When I saw that Crucifix was a mix of sci-fi, romance, mystery, and suspense I couldn't pass it up.I'm glad I didn't, because it was very *off the beaten path*. In an awesome way!The characters are very well fleshed out. Stefan and Madeline were complex and lifelike. Some of their decisions had me shaking my head in disbelief, but in the end it only added to the story.The pace was flawless. It kept you wanting to keep reading and finding out what happens next. Which, by the way, you can never guess! As soon as you think you know what's going on, you find yourself right back at square one.Crucifix is the first book in this trilogy, and I will be waiting with bated breath for the next installment.

This book was amazing! My brother and I are very into questioning things and taking nothing at face value. I saw this book and knew we needed to read it. I was right, because we both loved it.The writing style was unlike anything I've read before. It was very character driven. The characters were very well developed and almost seemed like they were all real people I knew by the end of the book.The plots are definitely out there, but for me that was a bonus. All of the stories were very well presented and believable.Last, but certainly not least, there were illustrations throughout the novel. When I put it that way, it doesn't sound cool, but trust me! The book is worth getting JUST to look at the pictures. I caught myself staring at them in awe more than once.Definitely added to the story.Overall, anyone who loves mystery and horror will love Crash and the Revelations from Big Sur

This book initially caught my attention because of it's uniqueness. I had never read a book that was set in England. However, being of english heritage I couldn't pass it up.Felicity's Beaus ended up surpassing every expectation I had. This is much more than a petty revenge novel. Felicity is impossible not to fall in love with! She is such a fun character. She really wasn't meant to live back in those times, that's for sure.As I mentioned before, the setting was 1600 England. To be honest I don't know much about that time in history, but this novel seemed to be very well researched and genuine. It was also very interesting and educational!Overall I highly recommend to any romance fan.

Personally, I love YA. Even though I am definitely NOT a young adult anymore. In fact, I have my own YA daughter and I am always on the lookout for good books/series for her. The fact that I enjoy them just as much? That is just a bonus!*A Myth to the Night* is exactly the kind of series I've been looking for. I can't wait to read the rest of the series with my daughter. I'm sure she will love the first book just as much as I did, and we can anxiously await the next installment together.The characters were great, and I especially loved Hugh. Initially I wasn't sure about the phantom being the main character, but it worked out very well.Highly recommend to anyone looking for a new YA series. It's very unique and has a ton of mystery and intrigue. The ending will have you drooling for the next installment.

My bunnies didn't digest this as well as their other food.  They did eat it but the "end results" were less than pleasant.  Normal bunny dropping are firm and easy to sweep/vacuum up.  When they ate this their droppings were not firm and most def were very messy to clean up.It might be my rabbits being used to a different type of pellet, but we had to switch them back.Your results may vary.

I have the Wolo Bad Boy in my MX-5 and my wife's Jeep Cherokee horn was just not cutting it anymore in NYC.
