She was rather jealous of my uber loud horn and wanted one of her own so I bough this for her.It is really loud.  The quality of the materials made me take off a star, nothing special and if anything feels a little bit cheap and flimsy.  But, that is all made up for in the noise it makes and the low price.It is not a deep tone, more of a bugle noise than a tuba, but it will get their attention.  In fact it is so loud it may violate noise level laws, so be careful laying on your horn if the police are around.

Read the reviews thoroughly before you decide to purchase this.  It is not a miracle diagnostic and depending on your dog you can get extremely varied results.  I bought it for my parents who had just adopted a new dog.  It was obvious that he had boxer in him (brindle and the typical boxer rear leg stance) but the rest of him nobody could figure out for sure.  I knew from looking at him that he had one or more of the Pit Bull breeds mixed in there, but no idea which or how much.He is an amazingly sweet dog, so swabbing his cheek and gum was easy.  Definitely easier if you wait until they are relaxing/sleeping and then sort of give them some lovings and do the swab.  Try not to do it soon after they have eaten and be careful to keep the sample as clean as possible.Basically you'll get back a report that shows the dog's ancestry if they have enough DNA in the appropriate breeds.  In our case he came back with 6 distinct identifiable breeds out of a possible 8.  The report you get will show the breed(s) of the parents, grandparents and great grandparents, but from what I have read this is purely a representation and not actually the true breeds of their individual relatives.  It is more of a visual reference for us, the humans who want to know their breed and how they got to be the mix that they are.In our case they were able to identify American Staffordshire Terrier, Boxer, Chow Chow, German Shepherd, Mini Bull Terrier, and Staffordshire Bull Terrier.  As mentioned above, the Boxer and the 3 pit bull breeds were obvious to me (Am Staff, Mini Bull and Staff Bull).  He has the typical pit bull ears (un-cropped) and face but not quite the wide jaw, he is also quite muscular and strong and can be picked up off the ground by a rope he is holding it with his teeth (he loves playing tug of war).  He also has the sweet, loyal, intelligent, stoicism that so many pits have.  He shows almost no physical characteristics of a Chow or German shepherd, he has very short hair, no black spots on tongue, etc.The attached photo to me represents the most important part of the report.  There is a lot of info in the report, but this one section to me contained the info that was most helpful.  Wisdom panel has some great videos on you tube that explains a lot about recessive genes and why your dog may have something like Chow Chow in their DNA but not display any of the physical traits.

This is my second purchase from PS.  The first was a batch of the low cut green socks.  I loved the green ones, they were amazing.  Thick, comfortable, breathable, etc.  So with the colder boot weather fast approaching I bought a set of the full length Heather/Navy socks.  I still really like them but they just don't seem as thick as comfy as the low cut greens.  I'm not sure if it is a color thing, possibly the dye used affects them, or if it is a size issue, or materials issue but they don't feel the same on the feet.Regardless, these are excellent socks, especially for the price and I wish I could give 4.5 stars.  But if I were to order again I'd most likely try full length green to see if they were thicker and if not stick with the low cuts.

Great item if you need super high arches.  The arch and heel area are reinforced with hard plastic made to look like carbon fiber.  I need them because I have plantar fasciitis and a high arch is needed.  Beyond that I can't say there is anything special about them.  Actually I am a bit disappointed in the lack of overall thickness and comfort.  I've bought Sof Sole before and was always pleased.  These are really thin and somewhat generic in regard to support and comfort beyond the high arch.  Sort of a 1 trick pony if you will.  So if you need them for high arch support they are great, beyond that nothing really good to say.

What a life saver.  My wife and I own two rabbits.  We usually let them roam around our 2 BR apartment in the mornings and evenings.  Although they are litter box trained, when they free range they tend to drop pellets randomly.  It happens.  Not a big deal as bunny poo is easy to clean up.  But it does get annoying constantly stepping on it, especially when guests come over and you have to vacuum the entire apartment.I got so tired of it that I put down the money and got a Roomba.  What a miracle.  Significantly less bunny droppings.  I run it couple times per week and it works miracles.  The first few times it pulls up a lot of dirt you may not have known you had.  It only gets stuck in one area of  the apt, under an Ikea chair, but I put a pillow under it and that fixes the problem.PET OWNERS WARNING - The first few times I ran this the rabbits were out.  It is a robot and does not care about your pet.  Unfortunately, your pet is not a robot and may care about the Roomba making them move.  In my case my male rabbit's response was to plop down a rather nasty bit of excrement that wasn't the normal hard pellet.  The Roomba also does not care what it picks up.  In this case the pile of wet excrement left by my rabbit got smeared under the Roomba (thankfully missing the brush) and then smeared more on the carpet.  Not a nightmare to clean up but definitely not fun and left a rather unpleasant aroma in the apartment.  If this were a dog or cat I cannot even imagine how much worse it could have been.  Also, google pets attacking Roomba and you'll see quite a few $$$ Roombas chewed to pieces by dogs.  So, before leaving your pet alone with one of these, give it some test runs or you may not like the results.

Love this hat.  All my male friends love it, wife hates it.  It is a small hat, which is great for me as I have a small head relative to my body.  I'm 6'3" and I have friends who are 5'6" - 5'9" and their fitted hats are usually bigger than my head.  Normally caps look weird on me as they dominate my head.  This one is perfect.  So be forewarned, if you have a big dome this hat is going to be very small.  If you have a small head it will fit perfect.PS - I shave my head too, so great for people with no hair.

Works great in my Ikea desk lamp.  $0.60 for each bulb is quite the deal, honestly I thought I was buying one and got a 10 pack, enough to last a lifetime.  Arrived on time, easy to install, bright.  Even if they don't last very long at this cheap a price who cares.

Six month ago I had a dental cleaning that led to a bi-lateral penicillin resistant middle ear infection.  A full course of Augmentin had almost no affect which is how it was determined to be AB resistant.  The pain, discomfort, lack of hearing, dizziness, and a list of other horrible symptoms which I won't bother to list was awful. Suffice it to say I was in misery 24/7.  Multiple ENT visits and two different 10 day courses of Bioxin AB along with two round of Prednisone finally got rid of about 90% of the issue.  I barely avoided having a hold cut in my ear drum and a tube inserted to drain.  But, my ear continued to bother me.  There was a constant discharge, blockage, mild pain, and a feeling of discomfort in the ear.  It just didn't feel right.  I was constantly having to equalize pressure, constantly clearing my sinuses, and there was a persistent discharge of mucus draining from my Eustachian tube down the back of my throat, very annoying.ENT's determined that it was just residual affects from having such a bad infection.  But the problems didn't go away.  Original infection and treatment with AB's lasted about 2 months.  But 4 months after that I still had symptoms all day and night and was very unhappy.A friend of mine suggested colloidal silver.  At this point in the process I was willing to try anything.  Research online was mixed to say the least.  Traditional medicine said it is a hoax and dangerous.  Personal experiences spoke otherwise.  So I tried it.For two weeks I took it orally, in a nasal spray, and via ear drops.  At first I noticed no change at all.  None.  Then after about 2 weeks things seemed better.  I wasn't sure as it was still bad, but it didn't seem quite as bad.  After 3 weeks almost all of my residual symptoms are gone.  No more constant discharge, very little need to equalize ear pressure, no more pain or discomfort or loss of hearing.For the first time in over 6 months my ear feels 100% normal again.Full disclosure this info is technically anecdotal.  I don't have any data to back this up beyond my personal experience.  No idea if it was helped by taking it orally, ear drops, or via nasal spray.  No real proof it fixed anything beyond the fact that I took it and now my ear is better.  I know correlation does not equal causation, but I also don't believe in coincidence.Bottom line, if you have any sort of a lingering infection or after affects from one I cannot suggest strongly enough to try this.  I would never take this in place of an anti-biotic if there is a real internal infection.  But I will also always take if i'm ever on an anti-biotic again.I believe in a blend of traditional and holistic health care.  When you have a middle ear infection and AB comes in real handy, but apparently this does too.  I'm a convert.  Will definitely be using colloidal silver from now on for any anti-microbial needs.

I get really bad DOMS in my legs whenever I do squats.  Like really bad.  It usually kicks in full about 36 hours after my workout and last for at least 3 days.  I get very mild DOMS everywhere else, only my hips/thighs are affected adversely.  Sitting down or standing up (chair, couch, etc) requires the use of both arms and a lot of grunting.  After my last leg day I was so sore for 4 days that I was seriously considering cutting way back on squats or eliminating them all together.  I did some research online and saw that BCAAs can help and figured it was worth a try.  I've tried almost every supplement under the sun and believe the vast majority of them are snake oil so I was very skeptical about trying BCAAs.I did my regular leg day (including squats) on a Wed afternoon, including doing higher weight and more sets than I did the previous leg day that left me sore for 3 days.  This product arrived on Thurs afternoon just as I was beginning to feel the effects of DOMS in my legs.  I was worried that my weekend was going to be spent shuffling around like an old man.  So I opened this package and took a dose in the evening.  I woke up this AM and after taking my regular hot shower realized not only did my legs not hurt worse than when I went to sleep, they actually felt better.  Not 100% normal, but better than when I went to sleep.  I took another half dose this morning (Fri) and am now typing this at noon and can say my legs feel 100% normal.  No pain, no soreness, no tightness, no DOMS.I am well aware of the placebo effect and how it works.  But I do not believe for a second that it could have this much of an impact on me physiologically.  My legs feel completely normal 48 hours after a leg workout.  That has never happened in my entire life.  I've done more leg days than I could possibly even attempt to count and I've always been significantly impacted 48 hours after a normal (not light) leg day.I'm a convert and will continue to use this until I see a different results.Oh and the watermelon flavor tastes just like a Jolly Rancher of the same flavor.  It does contain an artificial sweetener, which I wish it did not, but you cannot have everything.  The flavor was excellent, just a slight artificial sweetener after taste, and it dissolved easily in a cup of water.  It does foam up a little before it settles down too.If anything changes (good or bad) I will update this review.

Full disclosure:  I am male, 6'3", 220lbs, and 46 years old.  I recently began working out again 6 weeks ago doing free weights 3 times a week and walking about 6-8 miles per day.  I eat well, mostly pescatarian, no junk food, soda or desserts/snacking.I took these as part of a shotgun approach to supplements (forskolin, carnitine, fiber and a thermogenic fat burner) over 30 days.Results - no weight loss.Your results may vary, thus I'm giving 3 stars.  It may work for you, but it did not work for me.

Love love love these socks!  OMG I have been looking for thick comfy socks at a reasonable price for years.  These are them!  The fact that they are also made out of wool is straight up bonus and should net these socks 6 stars if I could.  I wish they made a low cut version but whatever, I cannot complain.  They are thick, light weight and super comfortable.  I wear them in the summer and my feet never feel wet and heavy.  Everyone says "how can you wear wool in the summer"?  Easy, wool is much better than cotton and wicking away moisture.  Buy these and you will not be disappointed.  Made in the USA too.  Too many things to list in the pro column and no cons.I used to buy 5.11 socks which are also great socks but way way over priced.  I'm a sock nut, I have very specific likes and dislikes and these socks are all like. Solidly made, comfy as hell, keep your feet dry and cool/warm as needed.
Cannot beat them for the price.  They are small, but hey, for the price they are really nice...wife loves them.

I have a thing about cotton swabs/q-tips.  I only like them with wooden sticks.  I hate water in my ears, hate hate hate it.  Cannot stand having any water there.  That being said, only wood sticks get all the water out.  In the past, I only used the q-tips brand wooden sticks but amazon no longer carries them and I cannot find them anywhere in the stores.  I've tried other brands (swispers and such) but none of them have been on par with the Q-Tips brand.  These are close.  Solid stick that does not break easily and a good amount on cotton on the ends.  They are almost as good as the Q-Tips brand but not 100% as good.  But hey, for the price and availability you cannot beat it.

Just OK.  Nowhere near the quality of the original on my 02 Miata.  It fits and it works, but not nearly as thick or solid as the original oil cap.  It is slightly thin, but hey, for the price it is OK.

Pros-Neutral flavor-Eventually dissolves fully in water (see cons for clumping)-Works smoothly, no bad side effects like bloating or gassy-Smooth, no gritty or unpleasant texturesCons-Clumps when you first put in water, then dissolves-PriceNotes-Each container is half full so you can combine them-Have not tried mixing in something besides water-If my math is correct it works out to 6.6 cents per gram of fiber.-Given how well it dissolves in water I'm guessing it is mostly soluble fiber.

This is basically a combo of the ingredients in Tucks and the main ingredient in Prep H.  It is 50% Witch hazel and .25% Phenylephrine HCL in a gel base.First the good news.  It works very well.  Easy to apply and stays on as it is a little sticky.  Very useful as you don't need Tucks and Prep H, you get both in 1 shot.  The effects last a long time, relief was quickly and sustained.Now the bad news.  For the first 20 seconds it felt a bit like I had put kerosene on instead of Prep H.  Literally.  It burns a lot.  Full disclosure I was a bit raw when I put it on, was not have a "good day" so to speak.Despite the initial reaction, it did significantly cool things down and each subsequent application was less intense.  In the end (no pun intended) I bought a 2nd tube and now use it a preventative maintenance.Overall a very good product but depending on the severity of your symptoms and the location of your rhoid(s) you may want something a little less potent.  A good test would be if you are having any discomfort from a Tucks pad I'd stay way far away from this product.

Wow doesn't even come close.  My wife loves grapefruit and is always looking for grapefruit seltzer or grapefruit soda, most of which is hard to find or full of sugar. So I figured I would give these a try.They are amazing.  We add them to water and they taste like fresh squeezed citrus juice.  I went from drinking 1-2 liters of water a day to drinking 3-4 liters a day.All 4 flavors taste great and taste like fresh fruit.  One packet in a liter of water will provide a mild flavor.  I normally use 1-2 per liter depending on which flavor.  Lemon and lime are stronger than orange and grapefruit.I also use the lime in a gin and tonic and the flavor is great.  Honestly I think you could substitute these for real citrus and you'd have a hard time telling.I will be a life time customer of these, they are that good.  Just glad I found them and bought them.

My bunny is getting old and was having serious issues with his hind legs.  Vet said it was lower back arthritis and suggested putting him on Metacam  a RX NSAID.  We did that but he still had issues, barely could use his hind legs and was becoming very incontinent.  Vet said that glu/con for rabbits was difficult but I figured it was worth a shot.He will not eat these directly but he is a picky eater.  So I soak a few of these in water overnight, then mash them, then add fruit juice and puree them.  He still won't eat them but since I have to give him Metacam from a syringe every night a second syringe of this is no big deal.  A large syringe is very handy as these don't really liquify fully.When I first started giving him these he was losing weight and would not even struggle when I feed him with the syringe.  Slowly over a few weeks he got a little stronger each day.  First he struggled a little bit, then he started kicking, and now it take two of us to give him his medicine and with one person he will jump out of your hold.Suffice it to say he is back to his normal self, is gaining the weight back, and seems to have full strength back.

Overwhelming taste of ginger.  I am giving 3 stars as this product is not bad, but labeling it as a Tonic Syrup is really not an accurate description.  Bitters sure.  But the flavor is really a mix of citrus and a whole lot of ginger.  If you are looking for a quinine tonic taste this is DEFINITELY not it.  I was looking for a better tonic to make G&T without using high fructose corn syrup or having to pay a ton for real tonic like Fever Tree or ToniQ.  Sadly this was not the answer.You may like the taste of this product, personally I do not.  I am not a huge fan of ginger and that was about all I could taste in this product.

Don't know why but this stuff works much better than the regular stuff.  I've used NM with my dogs and now was using it with my rabbits.  Believe me when I tell you rabbit urine is far worse than dog urine.  It is not quite as bad as cat, but it does have a rather pungent eye watering scent and rabbits use it to mark territory.  So I figured I would try this version of NM and I am extremely satisfied.Not only does it do a better job at removing the aroma, but it also does a better job of removing any stains.  The only downside of this product is that it is very strong and if you use it in large amounts the smell will linger for a little while as it breaks down the urine, but it definitely works.Having used NM more times than I would like to remember, I can definitively say this works better on urine than the regular NM.

My wife purchased these as she has thyroid issues and wanted to supplement her prescription.  Unfortunately, this product caused her extreme stomach cramps and pain, even if she took it with a full meal.  After 3 days she gave up and we dumped the rest of the pills in the garbage.They may work for some, but for my wife, she couldn't find out as the discomfort they caused was too severe to continue using them.

Love these, but with a big big caveat.  These are not a cracker you will eat plain or if you do you may have a penchant for consuming cardboard.  That being stated, they are amazing as a dietary supplement for fiber.  Eating one plain is like chewing on wood chips, literally.  But, with something very simple, like a light cheese spread they become easy to eat and really quite enjoyable.  Personally I use a wedge of laughing cow cheese (low fat and low calorie and readily available) on each cracker and they become quite tasty.I've been using these as part of a high fiber diet and try to get 3-5 at dinner.  Usually I substitute whatever carb side dish we're having and use these instead.  Or as stated prior, I'll spread some laughing cow cheese on them and use them as the side dish if the main course isn't something they match with well.They are very filling and I find I do not have nearly as many late night cravings.  They work especially well if you drink lots of water with them.  You won't feel bloated but you will feel very very full.On the plus side I have not noticed any negative side effects of ingesting so much fiber in one meal.  In fact I've had nothing but great results.These are great if you're looking to supplement your fiber intake.  Just be aware that they don't do well when eaten plain.

OK product but not going to buy it again.  The price was a bit high, was expecting a bigger container.  Also the seeds are a major pain to deal with, with the drying process they become even more pronounced and brittle and really get caught in your teeth.  I'd strongly suggest anyone avoid eating these if you don't have dental floss around.Probably a good item for long term storage or camping, etc, but not something I'd suggest for regular daily use.  They tasted fine, but between the cost and the seeds getting stuck in my teeth I doubt I will buy this item again.  I'm sure their other products are good, this might just be an issue specific to blackberries.

Love it.  Perfect gym bag, has everything I could ask for.Very sturdy and well made, lots of zippers for easy access.  Has a side shoe compartment that fits my size 11.5 Nike Air 180 running shoes with a little bit of room to spare.  Not sure how well this compartment would do above a size 12-12.5.  Other end pocket is great for holding small items like deodorant or q-tips .  Main compartment is roomy enough that even with shoes in the side pocket you have enough room for shorts, socks, shirt, water bottle and a few other items.This is hardly a hockey bag or one for sports where you have lots of equipment, but for the daily gym rat who isn't hauling around extra equipment it works out perfectly.

Really nicely designed bottle.  I go through about 2-3 liters of water a day and needed an on the go bottle.  My biggest problem, most of them leak.  I commute on the subway in NYC so I have a messenger bag I use to carry my water bottle.  This is my 3rd one as the first two would leak regularly.  They were the old school "bicycle" water bottles.  So I thought I'd give this a try.  The flip top and twist top opening looked great and work great.  Makes carrying the bottle easy and cleaning a breeze.Just one thing.  It leaks.  Not once, not twice, but on a regular basis.  I'm 6'3" and 215lbs and I have to tighten this bottle with all my strength to keep it from leaking, literally as hard as can squeeze it shut, otherwise it leaks if it is left on its side.The safety latch is great to keep it from accidentally opening in your bag or whatever, but be prepared to really crank down on the top if you don't want it leaking into your bag or car seat or wherever you have it where it isn't standing upright.  The leak isn't from the sip top but from the main top.Beyond that I'm very happy with it.  Easy to use at the gym or on the go.  Very well made and designed.  Just that leak is annoying.

Love these.  I hate wearing glasses because I'm always losing them or getting them scratched and I cant stand having them on my forehead.  These are perfect.  Now I don't have to bother with a case or losing them or carrying them in a bag or pocket.  Pop them around my neck and use them when I need them.  Love that they come in clear plastic, makes them much less noticeable.My only complaint is they don't make a 1x.  So had to go with 1.25 but whatever.

I use these in a wood fired stove that my wife and I use to heat a soaking tub.  They are great and provide a nice even boost of heat.  Overall the stove aims for high heat but I throw one or two of these in now and again to maintain a prolonged heat.  Best part is the almost complete lack of ash.  All that remains is a light powder.They burn well, sort of a medium heat and long burn.  Personally my wife and I love the smell.  Be warned, however, your neighbors may not appreciate it.  One neighbor asked us if we were burning rubber or plastic.  No idea where she got that idea, but if you've never smelled peat burning it is possible that you could mistake it for a rubber product burning.For the price and weight and quality they are great.  I will definitely be ordering more.

Fit perfectly.  Had a rubbermaid garbage can with the rounded top and the wind blew it off and it got run over by a car.  Well, thought i'd try this one out and it fits perfectly.  It is flat and not rounded so it does gather some rain, but it stays on tight.  I drilled a hole thru a side handle and tied it on to the can just in case.  Great price and great fit.

If you want to really clean out your fuel system this is the way to go.  It contains the most PEA of any cleaner on the market and PEA is what you want.  As quoted in Road & Track:"PEA is the cleaning agent found in any truly effective complete fuel system cleaner. It is the strongest cleaning agent available in fuel additives. It cleans better and cleans more parts than PIB and PIBA. PEA is in a league of its own and in some cases it is the only detergent that can get the job done."This product contains 30-50% PEA as per the current MSDS.  Google it and you'll see.Techron used to contain PEA but now uses Stoddard Solvent instead, which is basically paint thinner.Lots of debates out there in the auto world on what additives are worth while and which are snake oil.  When in doubt, do some research and then look at the MSDS and find out exactly what is in the additive you buy.As an example, Royal Purple's equivalent which costs about the same ounce for ounce contains 5-15% PEA.  Lucas Oil's Deep Clean 10-30% PEA.Bottom line is know what you are paying for when it comes to any automotive additive.

Hey it is a Maglite, their reputation speaks for itself.  Item is rock solid, great color, bright light, and if a pinch you can use it crack someone in the head if you have too do so.  Honestly I think that is why so many Police Officers carry them.  Thick metal case with 2 D batteries packs a whallop.  Well worth the money.  Well made.  Oh and the red color is great.

Very good read for the beginner/novice to someone with a small amount of knowledge.  If you know about medium to advanced tuning you really will not learn much than you already know.  But as someone with an aftermarket ECU and an aftermarket supercharger this did help fill in a lot of the gaps.  Definitely was a worthwhile read.  My only complaint was that I would have preferred more information regarding ignition timing.  It was one of the areas that the book still has not completely cleared up for me.  There are a few other flaws as well, areas that sort of get glossed over without giving full explanations, but it will give you a solid foundation to build upon.
Good product for a good price...well made and sturdy...thick gauge wire and insulation is thick too.

These work OK...as noted by another reviewer the plastic wrap package actually contains 4 individual starters which you need to split apart...These are not the easiest things in the world to light, fine if you are indoors, but can be a pain if you are outdoors...they burn fine but there are bette options out there...Fat Wood being one of them and my first choice...they are all natural and light with one match and burn hot and intensely.
Used this at work on a white wall to hang my jacket, bag, hat etc.  Didn't want to draw a lot of attention, so the color was perfect.  Holds everything firmly.  Great product.

Perfect fit, front and rear.  Recently had to replace both CCV elbows, not PCV.  If you are replacing the elbows on a Jeep 4.0l do some research and make sure you get the right ones.  On certain 4.0l the flow is critical as some use a CCV system.  See diagram below.  You'll need a low flow elbow in the rear of the valve cover and high flow in the front.  Just make sure you get the right ones for your engine.  The Grommet itself was well made and easy to install.  Getting the old ones out, not so easy.  It does help if it is a warm day or a warm engine.  Regardless, these fit very well and tight.Front Elbowhttp://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000JZIXIWRear Elbow (Amazon said this didn't fit my 2000 Cherokee but they were wrong)http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000JZI1U2/

This is the elbow for the FRONT of a Jeep 4.0L engine with a CCV (not PCV) set up.  I have a 2000 Cherokee w/ 4.0L.  This engine has a CCV and not a PCV.  The rear elbow is low flow and the front elbow is high flow, this is the FRONT ELBOW which goes to the intake box.  The low flow pulls from the intake manifold.  Very important to get these two correct or you could end up with too much pressure or venting high flow to manifold and the air intake.  See attached picture to get a better idea.  The front elbow is this part:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000JZI1U2/You can see the difference as it (47057) has a small hole at the bottom.  This item being reviewed (47079) is wide open and has no restriction.Lastly, if you are replacing this, spent the extra money and get the grommet as well.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000C5I49C/

Finally, finally, finally...I no longer have to go freeze my hind parts off to check the temp on the hot tub.  My wife and I have a wood wired soaking tub which can take from 30-90 minutes to reach 104F...needless to say it is really annoying to a) constantly have to run out to check the temp, b) go out in a bathing suit and find it is too cold, c) go out in a bathing suit and find it is too hot.Now that is no longer a problem.  Not only does this tell you the current temp, but it also shows you whether it is staying stable, rising, falling and how fast it is rising or falling (it has a small icon in the upper right with an arrow that points up, horizontal, or down) and if it is rising/falling fast the arrow points at a higher angle.Since our tub is wood fired it has no electronic flow, it uses thermal siphoning which usually leaves a very hot top layer of water and cold layer beneath.  Solution was to buy a low end sump pump and leave it running when were firing it up.  Obviously we pull it out before going near the water.  This keeps the water stirred and even and helps give an accurate temp.This is also really helpful as you can track how fast the water is heating.  For us that is critical so we can add wood accordingly.  We don't want it too hot or have too much wood left and end up in 108F water.It also is great as you can see how much the water is cooling off and how quickly.Literally I could not have designed a more ideal product.  This does everything I want it to do and eliminates a trip into the cold every 15-20 minutes to "check on things".One of the best products I have purchased in a long time.
It works.  It is a cable.  Well made and decent price.  Cannot ask for much for or say much more.

Love these things.  Used them to mount an axe and shovel to the inside back hatch of my 2000 Jeep Cherokee.  The hold the weight well and are super easy to open and close.  Very handy and easy to use.  Well made and good price.
It works.  Decent price.  Easy to use.  Construction is good.  Not much more to say.

It is a cable and it works.  One thing to note, if you are using this for a powered device via the serial cable it won't work.  Didn't realize this so in the end I did not use the cable.  But it did work, just not as a power supply cable.

Love em.  Not only do they look amazing, but they sound great as well.  The red wires contrasted with the dark wood really make them stand out.  Sound quality is good to very good.  Don't expect miracles but for $25 this is an extremely well made, good looking, and good sound quality item.Buy with confidence.

Low this stuff...use it daily, usually two times in a liter of water each time...really helps with getting your daily water intake and the Vitamin C is a huge added bonus.  I'm a firm believer in Vit C helping prevent colds if you take it daily.  This stuff really helps with that.

I was seriously surprised at how much water this thing moves.  My wife and I have an outdoor wood fired soaking tub that can take between 30-120 minutes to get to full temp.  All the while we have to stir it every 15-20 minutes with a paddle.Well that got old fast, especially as it is getting colder.  So I invested in the smaller pump I could find thinking I'd get a nice low flow to do the work for me.  Well when they say 25 Gallons per minute I don't doubt it.I attached a small 8' hose to this pump as I was trying to get the water to flow faster to the wood stove.  I placed the open end of the hose into the water inlet that leads to the stove. When I plugged in the pump the hose literally flew out the opening and started spraying water everywhere, I was shocked at how much water it was moving.So we ended up just using it to mix the water in the tub and it literally reduced the heating time by about 25-30%.On top of that I was shocked at how quiet it is.  I makes a low audible humming sound that is deep but not loud.

These things just plain work.  Not sure if I'd use them to light coals for a BBQ but for a wood fired stove or a fire pit they work exceptionally well.  No paper ash to deal with and yes you can literally light them with one match.My wife didn't realize what they were and threw a dozen of them into our wood fired stove that was already lit.  Suffice it to say there was a whole lot of burning going on very fast.We have a wood fired stove for an outdoor soaking tub and 3-4 of these things will get the whole thing going.  Realistically it probably would only take 1-2 to start things up but at the price an extra one or two who cares.Suffice it to say you won't need newspaper, fluids, etc anymore.  These things light fast, burn hot, put out a lot of flame, and last a decent amount of time.

I just had my D3 levels checked by my primary care physician, and we're heading into the winter months in Minnesota (hello darkness, my old friend) so supplementing with D3 is imperative. And with the amount of new research being conducted on Vitamin D, it seems it is involved in so many more cellular processes than previously thought (it helps regulate the synthesis of serotonin, for example), and thus should really be taken year-round.VIva Labs makes taking Vitamin D simple, with one small 5000 IU cap. Very easy to swallow, no strange odors, and no broken capsules in the bottle. Very happy with this!

It has been years since owning a watch (thank you, cell phones), but always missed having an attractive piece on my wrist. In the past, I have had the gamut of Timex, Fossil, Casio and the likes -- nothing too extravagant, but good watches nonetheless. This is my first Invicta, though I have heard plenty about their products, so I had no reservations about getting this watch. And I'm glad I did. This is by far the nicest watch I've owned.PROS* Looks impressive. The Roman numerals are very classy and attractive* Big dial is very easy to read* The mini dials (calendar, weekday and hour) are a nice touch and add to the appeal* The blue hands offer a nice contrast to the white face and silver band/bezel* Easy to set up (although, in my case, it actually came set correctly)* Very well packaged, making for a great giftCONS* Watch is fairly heavy* Only a one-year warranty from Invicta. When a watch approaches a $100 price tag, I would expect at least 3 years of coverage* The clasp feels a little cheap, and makes me wonder about long-term durability* I have smaller wrists, so the watch face seems a little large on me, so keep that in mind when making your decisionBOTTOM LINELovely watch and Invicta has a great reputation, so despite the limited warranty I suspect it will last for years. Though not cheap by any stretch, at its current price it seems well worth the value.

My wife really likes this lip gloss palette. Once applied, the colors are lighter than would seem, but look very natural. The application sticks makes, well, applying the gloss very easy. The texture is smooth, not clumpy, and has no discernible odor. The variety of color options is great for matching different moods/occasions. The only down side is that the gloss doesn't last all that long -- maybe a couple of hours -- thus needing reapplication.Overall, a great product and highly recommended.

I'm really a t-shirt and jeans guy, and as such, I have a roster of favorite tees in my drawer. This is my first experience with Oxford NY -- in any piece of clothing -- so I had no preconceived expectations. Here are my thoughts on the v-neck tee:COLORTrue black. Time will tell if the color will fade to a dull brown, as is the case with most black tees, but for now it's very sharpSTYLEThe v-neck is very nice, and looks both casual and stylish.FITI prefer an athletic cut, where the shoulders are a bit broader and the lines stay tight down the body to the waist. This tee is very short and wide, almost boxy. The arms are about the only area that fit well.VALUE$10 for a tee is fine, if it fits well and is guaranteed to last. Many tees are available for much less, so given the ill fitting, I have to say these are overpriced.BOTTOM LINEWhile a great looking shirt, comfortable fabric and stitched well, the fit and price make it a miss for me.

I don't eat chocolate often, especially when below 85% cacoa (I try to avoid added sugar), but Cailler L'Ecorce seemed very intriguing so I gave it a try. Here are my brief impressions:TEXTURESmooth. Not brittle at all. Melts in your mouth almost immediately. Very creamy and rich.FLAVORDefinitely dark, almost fruity. A little on the sweet side, but it balances the bitterness well.VALUEA little on the expensive side, especially considering the amount of other chocolates (such as Lindt, which is also excellent) that are much cheaper and equally delicious.BOTTOM LINEThere will always be a debate over whose chocolate reigns supreme. Nestle, who seems to be targeting more up-scale customers with the Cailler line, has produced an excellent dark chocolate. If price is no concern and you want to try something new, you can't go wrong here.

I have a modest home studio with fairly basic equipment, but a solid mic stand is necessary for good recording. I am currently using a Blue Yeti microphone (which is a sizable mic, as shown in photo), with a pop filter, but no shockmount. I do have another mic stand, On Stage Stands MS7701B Tripod Boom Microphone Stand which functions really well, but wanted to see if the Gator Frameworks stand offered any additional benefits.PROS* Adjusts very easily* Three cable clips for harnessing your XLR or USB cable* Folds flat for easy transportation/storage* Very well balanced tripod legs, with soft rubber feet* Solid metal construction should withstand years of useCONS* Pricier than other stands (twice the cost of my other stand)* When the boom arm is fully extended, there is a loss of support at the pivot point -- especially with heavier micsBOTTOM LINEWhile this is a nice microphone stand, there are plenty of other options, at cheaper prices, which offer much of the same benefits. I can certainly recommend this product, but shop around first.

PROS* Great price for the set of 5* No shedding/excess lint* Very soft cotton* Easy to care for* Smaller size makes for convenient storing in linen closetCONS* Not the most absorbent towels, but they do the trick* Small size/surface area means it gets used quickly during big clean upsOverall, very good quality, even if they don't hold a lot of moisture. Highly recommended.

I have an assortment of foam rollers/massage balls/massage sticks, and have used other SPRI products. I lift weights and run several days a week, so my quads and IT band are notoriously tight, necessitating daily foam rolling.This is, by far, the hardest density roller I have used, to the point of almost being unbearable. It's definitely made for DEEP tissue massage, so for anyone sensitive to pain, you may wish to refrain from this roller and go with something softer. You have been warned.The dimple surface is a nice idea, as it helps zero-in on specific knots and work them free.Quality is excellent and feels like it will withstand years of constant use.The size is great, making for easy travel.Price is on the higher end, which is a big demerit. As of this writing, it's still listed at $59.98, which is about twice what I normally pay for my rollers.Overall, a great idea, but with the density being as hard as it is, and the price as high as it is, I can't say I'd recommend this roller.

My wife really likes these and says they're very comparable to other brands she has tried. The wipes do a good job removing make-up, though it may take more than one wipe to remove it completely.I use them, as well, after getting home from a long day, to wipe the dirt and grime from my skin. I have also used other brands of facial wipes, and many get shredded on my stubble. The Simple brand is pretty tough and stays intact, so ladies, let your guy know these have been beard-tested.Price is excellent, so even if it takes more than one wipe to do the job, these certainly won't break the bank. Recommended.

We have one very hard to please cat, and one cat that will eat tuna-flavored lint if given a chance. The cats are given canned and dry food, rotated throughout the day, and they really enjoy Authority Grain Free Adult Cat Food for their dry food (this was after trying close to a dozen different brands/varieties).I like that the Rachel Ray Nutrish is a no grain, no filler recipe, using very well-sourced ingredients. The size of each grain is pretty small (smaller than a green pea), making the food easy to consume. And the price, though on the higher end, is justified by the quality.That being said, neither of our cats liked it. We even tried mixing the Authority brand with this, but they somehow (leave it up to cats) managed to pick out the pieces they liked, leaving the Rachel Ray Nutrish pieces in the bowl.Bottom line: cats, being cats, are finicky by nature. Based on the ingredient profile, I would recommend this food to other cat owners, but be aware that your cat may still not like it. I will not be purchasing this in the future.

Getting a new bed was LONG overdue. I had been using an old Select Comfort (Sleep Number) bed for years, which I absolutely despised. Quite possibly the most overrated, uncomfortable, glorified, overpriced air mattress. I kept putting off getting a new bed because a) cost, and b) with so many different types of beds available, it seemed daunting to even begin shopping. I had been considering Tempurpedic, but could not justify spending the equivalent of a used car (I know, I know, 1/3 of your life ...). And although I do prefer a harder mattress, when I had the chance to get the Serta Hemmons Gel mattress, it was too good to pass up.The first night on the mattress was pretty magical. It's very soft and you sink right into the top. I move around a lot, from back to side to stomach, but I think I stayed in one position the entirety of the first night. I have since experimented and found that the mattress is ideal for side or back sleepers, but not so much for stomach sleeping.Despite its memory foam structure, you do still feel some movement from your partner, but to a much less degree than with other beds. My wife used to wake me every time she moved on our old mattress, but I haven't really been disturbed since switching to the Serta.The mattress is also nice and thick, so make sure you get deep-fitted sheets.The biggest demerit is the lack of "coolness" that is promised. I get warm very easily in bed, which leads to terrible sleep. This mattress is designed to help keep you cool, but I have not noticed this at all. In fact, I think it's actually warmer than my previous bed.It's hard to say if the price is justified, as I've only had the mattress for a few weeks, so my experience is limited. But the Warranty is 10 years, which is reassuring.Overall, I'm really happy with the bed and would certainly recommend checking it out. If anything changes over time, I will update this posting.

This was a gift for my 2-year-old niece (yes, she is under the suggested age, but she is well-supervised), and just in time, as summer comes and goes quickly here in Minneapolis.Assembly isn't terribly difficult, but it is time consuming. My brother and I took turns with the myriad plastic screws. Overall we finished in about an hour, and left the decal work to the kids, who were more than happy to slap stickers on anything BUT the Jeep.The Jeep is of a surprising build quality. The frame, wheels and extra parts feel solid and durable, most likely able to withstand a few years of youngster abuse.Battery charge time is pretty lengthy (14-18 hrs), which for the time invested, offers very little usable time in return (maybe 45 minutes overall).The radio is super basic but functions relatively well. The mp3 jack is a nice touch, though no real place to set the player. The rollbar with lights is cool, but fairly impractical; I don't know many parents who'd want their kids riding this well past sunset.Price is pretty steep, and without really knowing long-term durability, it's hard to gauge if the price is justified. The replacement batteries are also fairly costly, at about $50.The bottom line, of course, is my niece really enjoys the Jeep. So despite any negatives, the positives definitely win out. This is a really fun toy with which kids will not likely grow bored. If price isn't a concern, don't hesitate to pick this up.

I have never owned, nor to my recollection, even used a sewing machine before, so I can offer no real comparison for the SINGER 1304. But being just an ordinary dude with basic needs, this machine very much fulfills its purpose. I had long been putting off making curtains for my bedroom's french doors, as the thought of laboring with a needle and thread, along with yards and yards of fabric, seemed far too tedious. My wife even recoiled at the thought. Suddenly a light appeared, Amazon opened its arms, and bestowed upon us the SINGER 1304.The first thing I noticed was the feel of the machine, which is very solid. Stands up to any real power tool in terms of durability and seems capable of long-term use with minimal maintenance.The Quick Start guide (yes, I read instructions) was very handy with the initial setup. The controls, even if you don't have a need for the variety of stitch types, are essentially dummy-proof. Just turn the dial and you're in. The thread loads relatively easy from the top. And the pedal kind of makes it feel like you're using a big machine press. Kind of.The unit operates fairly quietly, too, perfect for when you need to sew your crotch at 2 am without disturbing your neighbors.I haven't had a chance to play around with all of the functions, such as the buttonhole makers, but it seems fairly intuitive.The curtains for the french doors turned out really well, so now my wife and I are looking for other projects to do. Based on the price point, I'd say this is a real value buy. Does everything you need, easy to use, and it (according to me) counts as a power tool.

Good, but not balanced assortment of cereals. There were far more Original flavor than Fruit & Yogurt and Red Berries. But the cereals themselves are great tasting, if not a little too sweet. Serving size varies from cup to cup, as does nutritional value, so pay attention to the labels if watching calories. Price comes out to just over $1/cup, so there is economic value here. Recommended.

Really pleasing scent. It is more floral than I'd like, rather than musky or woody, but it is definitely a cologne and not a perfume. I usually use Grey Flannel by  Geoffrey Beene, which is a far "darker" scent, so this "lighter" scent is a nice contrast. Goes on smoothly, the bottle has a nice feel to it, and the spray nozzle delivers a fine, but wide spray, so only one squirt is needed. It is on the pricier side for cologne, which may deter some, but overall it is definitely recommended!

I have two other mats at home: one thin, easily portable by Gaim, and the other is a thick, high density by Manduka. Both are excellent and serve their purpose, and the new Athletic Yoga duraMAT is a blend of both. The mat is a solid density and feels durable. But it's also remarkably light weight easy to carry. Each sides (the reverse on mine is blue) has a different surface style, yet both have surprisingly good traction. I've used this in several different types of yoga (hatha, vinyasa, and ashtanga) and it works well for all variations.And the extra length is a huge plus for those with long limbs.For the price, I think this is a solid value. The blue version (as of this writing) is about half the cost of the black, making it even more appealing. Recommended.

I have a fairly oily nose, and regularly use pore strips as part of my regimen. As with any nose strips, application of the Biore Charcoal Pore Strips is very simple and easy to use. Just clean, wet, apply, let set for 15 minutes and remove. But in terms of effectiveness, I don't see how the added charcoal offers additional benefits. The amount of oils/skin deposits was the same or even a bit less than what I normally achieve with standard nose strips. My pores didn't appear nor feel any clearer than if charcoal had not been present.Additionally, every time I peeled off the strip, black residue was left on my skin, requiring further cleansing. This shouldn't really be a multi-step process.Overall, while these may work for some, I will continue using regular nose strips.

I waited a little over two weeks to review this 5-HTP supplement, as one or two days is far too short a duration to glean any real benefits. About me: troubled sleeper -- lifelong troubled sleeper. Generally very positive outlook, not prone to depression, very even tempered. As such, I was looking for something to help induce a sense of relaxation, so as to improve my sleep quality, but not necessarily to help with mood enhancement. I have tried every concoction one can think of: melatonin, Valerian root, l-tryptophan, GABA, glycine, hot tea with honey, and on and on. I have even tried 5-HTP in the past, but only found it mildly beneficial.Doctor's Best is a little different in that vitamins C and B6 are added to aid in the conversion and uptake of 5-HTP into serotonin. I was dubious, yet hopeful, that this 5-HTP supplement would produce any noticeable results, but I have been sleeping so much better.I am now falling asleep relatively quickly, hit REM sleep (very vivid dreams) and wake up more refreshed. I do still wake up periodically throughout the night, so this is not a cure-all by any means. I'm stacking this product with Choline & Inositol, which seems to be a great combination for me.The pills are small and easy to swallow, and have no odor or foul taste if you burp.Cost-wise, these are a great value. Even if I take two per day, one bottle still provides a two-month supply.Overall, an excellent option for those in need of additional support with sleep and relaxation, and I would definitely recommend it to others.

My wife works in a rougher part of the city and she commutes by bike, so her safety is always on our minds. Rather than carry a small weapon, we decided pepper spray would be more suitable. The Sabre Compact Pepper Spray is perfect for her, for a few reasons:* Key ring attachment is very convenient, as one can attach the bottle to a bag or jacket to keep it easily accessible* The canister is housed in a tough, plastic casing, which withstands outdoor weather and accidental drops on the ground* This pepper spray has a range of 8-10 feet, which is excellent, so one can remain a safe distance from a would-be attacker* Practice canister is a really smart idea, as most people will never have used pepper spray until they NEED to, which could lead to mishandling the device* Safety switch/lock prevents unintentional release of the sprayOne can't put a price on safety, but this pepper spray seems very well priced, offering convenience and peace of mind for those who need it.

PROS:* Convenient! Very easy to stuff in a gym bag* Flavor is pretty good (French Vanilla). Not too sweet, but I do taste a lot of salt* Well-packaged* Solid 20g of protein per serving, with added vitamins and minerals to help with recovery* Only 170 calories, so it should fit most dietsCONS:* Use of corn maltodextrin as the carb source. I'm all for replacement shakes, where there is a balance of carbs/protein, so long as the carb source is nutrient-dense and not a cheap, highly-processed GMO* Milk protein concentrate isn't the most bio-available form of protein, and it's a slower digesting protein, which means it isn't the most ideal for a post-workout recovery shake* A little sodium-rich for my liking, which comes through in the flavor* Some of the vitamins and minerals are inferior forms, which means the body won't utilize them efficiently (vitaman E is synthetic, B-12 should be methylcobalamin, for example)* At about $2/serving, these are a little more expensive than I'd like. A high-quality protein powder will generally run about $1/servingVERDICT:Convenient, yes. But given the availability of higher quality shakes, at a similar or better price point, it's unlikely I will be recommending this or using it again.

I don't do a lot of gaming (which this router seems to market towards), but when at home I do stream a signal to my blu-ray player (for Netflix, Amazon Prime, etc) and laptop, and even my cellphone. This is an upgrade to my Linksys E2000, which I thought was a great router, but started to get a little glitchy in recent months (signal drop, long-buffering times, etc). The E8350 seemed like a perfect next step, and I couldn't be happier.If you have experience setting up routers, the E8350 should be a breeze to install. The Linksys interface is one of the better ones on the market, which makes setting up the system pretty easy, and actually offers a lot of customization options (parental controls, guest connections, etc) -- which I don't really need, but nice to have.Once set up, I connected my devices and tested the signal speed and strength. File loading and streaming content were lightning fast -- far faster than with my older router. The only limitation I can see thus far is with range. At about 20-25 feet from the unit itself, the signal starts to wane a bit. The 4 antenna units are adjustable, which does help, but for a router with so much under the hood, I would expect a bit more.An odd design note is the lack of indicator lights on the unit. Not a big deal by any stretch, but checking connection status is a little tricky if just looking at the router itself.If you want to plug in for wired connections, the four Gigabit ports are a very nice (and blazing fast) feature.The price point is higher than a lot of models currently available, but I think the features justify the cost -- especially if you have a need for high-end performance. The only real question is long-term reliability, but for now I'm happy with this upgrade and definitely recommend it to others.

0:50 MinsI have been using an old Espon Stylus CX7400 for the past 7 years, and it was getting time to take it out to pasture. I like having an all-in-one unit, so I wanted to find something comparable (print, scan, copy) but with wireless capabilities. I didn't have to look long when I came across the Epson Workforce 2660. I snatched it up and so far, it has yet to disappoint.SETUPOut of the box, setup was pretty simple: take off strips of blue tape (used during shipping to hold components closed), connect AC adapter, power up unit and follow the instructions on the color screen. After the initial set up screens, you're then asked to install the software, which brings you through another series of firmware installations/setups, resulting in a Print Test page. The printer was fluid and responsive right out of the gate, and I was surprised by the speed with which the test page printed.CONNECTIVITYUsed the USB connection to get everything up and running which is the simplest option. After initial setup, I then connected to our Wi-Fi, which was pretty easy. The printer looks for available signals, select your network, enter passowrd, and connection is established.The Start Guide also has a QR code to install the Epson iPrint app, for iOS or Android. I REALLY dig this. I tested the app by printing a photo from my phone, and within seconds the image printed. The app not only allows you to print, but also perform maintenance tasks, such as head cleaning and firmware updates, and even shows current ink levels, negating the need to open the Device Panel folder on the PC. Nice.SCAN/COPY/FAXThe scan and copy features are smooth and accurate, and with scanning you have the option of storing the image on the Cloud. Boss. I have no need for the Fax feature, and therefore did not test this out, so I cannot comment on how well this works.PRINT SPEEDI have uploaded a video showcasing just how fast this unit prints. Black & white pages are mere seconds, with color being just a few moments longer. The printer also runs pretty quietly, so you won't have to soundproof the office.INKInk cartridges are small and easy to install, and seem competitively priced (as of this review, between $9-12). The colors are true and bright, and the black is solid (no browning or graying, like with my last printer). Since I haven't been using the printer for long, I cannot comment on how long each cartridge lasts, but will update once I am able.ON-BOARD COLOR TOUCHSCREENThe color touchscreen is pretty slick and responsive. From the screen, you can Copy, Scan, Fax, as well as establish a wireless connection. Very nice feature.CONSThe only real knock I can find at this point is some components feel a little cheap/flimsy, which makes me question long-term durability.FINAL THOUGHTSOverall, I definitely recommend this unit for anyone in need of a printer with a host of capabilities. As I continue to use and explore its features, I will post updates, but for now I'm loving it!

Ever since I gave up sugar, this has been my go-to sweetener. It's incredibly clean with no additives/fillers, and the taste is awesome. As with most pure stevia, it does have a slightly bitter aftertaste, but not to the degree of others I've tried.I use the stevia in coffee, almond milk, veggie shakes, even baking, and have always been satisfied with the results. A little certainly goes a long way, so start with a small amount and add from there.BulkSupplements is also an excellent re-seller, so feel confident you'll get a great product at a great price. Highly recommended!

I've been clinging to the same beat up Dirt Devil Vibe Upright (with Power Brush attachment!) since I bought it on clearance ten years ago. The suction is terrible, it's as loud as a cement mixer, and it weighs about as much as that cement mixer. Needless to say, I have been in need of a new vacuum for quite some time, but never did I think that vacuum would be a Roomba.Truth be told: I always thought robot vacuums/sweepers were a bit of a gimmick, something for tech-junkies or, well, the lazy. So when it arrived in the mail, I opened it with both skepticism and cynicism, thinking, if nothing else, the Roomba would serve as a fun new  torture device for our cat, Sherlock. As much as it pains me to admit, I am now eating crow. The Roomba 870, despite a few limitations, is an incredible appliance and I will (probably) not speak ill-ly of them again.My home set up: one-bedroom apartment, about 700 sq ft, tile in the bathroom and kitchen, carpet and throw rug in living room, bedroom and closet. One short-hair domestic cat who loves to shed, and one imported wife with long black hair, who also loves to shed. After spending some time with it, here is a list of Pros and Cons for owning the iRobot Roomba 870:PROS:* Solid construction. The Roomba is built like a tank, but has soft edges, so if it does collide with an object (which rarely happens anyway), no damage will be incurred* Surprisingly quiet. I can still hear the TV/stereo/conversation while the Roomba is running* No more spinning brushes that get clogged with debris! I didn't realize what a pleasure this would be (specifically, it doesn't choke on the tassels at the ends of the throw rug! Genius)* Fairly intuitive, easy setup. I'm certainly not ignorant of technology, but for time's sake, I'll always prefer simple programming. Can set up multiple, scheduled cleanings with relative ease* Long battery life and self-charging. The battery has yet to die mid-cleaning, as I don't have a ton of square footage, but this is still a a great feature. The Roomba will find the nearest dock and park itself until fully re-charged* Collects a great deal of cat hair and dust, so it lives up to the pet/allergen claims* Strong suction. We have an issue of our cat trailing litter everywhere, which we're constantly sweeping. The Roomba is easily able to suck up the litter granules* Transitions pretty smoothly from the tile to carpet. It only got hung up once, but only because it hit a warped part of the rubber carpet stripping.CONS:* Warranty. Comes with one-year limited standard, but with an appliance with this much technology, and at this price point, I would expect at least 5, if not 10, years of coverage.* Can't use it on furniture, like our couch, which still necessitates owning another vacuum or handheld device* See above, for carpeted stairs (I mean, you COULD use the Roomba on stairs, but you'd have to manually lift it onto each step, thus defeating the purpose)* Dust bins are a little small, meaning they need to be changed after every cleaning, but I am willing to concede the overall size of the unit will limit thisIf you're on the fence about buying a Roomba, take it from me that it's worth the plunge. I'm now thinking of getting one for my mom and step-dad, who also own a cat, and just don't have much time or energy to vacuum their place. And if you're curious, besides functioning as a high-tech cleaning device, it definitely delivers as an entertaining torture machine for pets.

I came across this pitcher at just the right time, as I needed a new pitcher in which to brew some fresh iced tea. Normally, I drop ice cubes and/or lemon wedges into the tea, but the Contigo takes a painfully easier and cleaner approach, offering an infuser stick and ice core. But is the pitcher's high price justified?PROS:* Durable, thick plastic that will resist drops* Seals really well. Lemon wedges lasted well over 5 days* Lifetime Warranty coverage* Quality, BPA-free materialCONS* Somewhat difficult to maneuver with one hand, as the pour-release button is tough* Lid can be tricky to pull off* High priceVERDICTThe Contigo is definitely a premium pitcher, with plenty to satisfy most users, but in the end it really is just a pitcher. Is the sealing quality really that important when sitting in the fridge? And how often will one utilize the infuser stick? For my money, I recommend sticking with the $10 range of pitchers, such as Rubbermaid, and let those lemon wedges float freely.

Really dig these. At home my wet wipes are never out of reach, but they don't always travel well. The TP+ Cleansing Foam bottles are a great alternative, allowing me to be hygienic wherever my butt ends up. I keep one in my gym bag, and one in my everyday backpack.Application is about as basic as it gets: one or two pumps on your TP, and wipe away.No flowery, heavy perfumes or dyes, dries quickly without leaving residue, and the cost is on point. Highly recommended.

This one took me by surprise. There will be obvious comparisons to OxyElite Pro, which isn't quite fair, as OEP was a different kind of beast, but I'll admit I was definitely comparing/contrasting my experience between the two. The ingredient profile for EpiBURN Pro isn't all that unique, with maybe the exception of Nelumbo Nucifera, which may have appetite suppression and lipolytic properties. Other than that, Ashwagandha root, Olive leaf extract, forskolin, yohimbe and caffeine have all been used in various weight-loss products. But so far, I've had good luck with it.Tried one capsule at first, which didn't seem to have much effect (the only reason for a one-star demerit). But at a two-cap dose, the sweating really began. Energy is smooth and long-lasting, with no crash. And even a surprising amount of mental focus. I have yet to need a third cap, as two generally gets me through the day. Taken pre-workout, plenty of energy with some left over, and moderate appetite suppression.One final point is that each capsule only has 100 mg of caffeine, which is great for those with low tolerance, or if you want to stack with other stimulant-based products.So, is it OEP? No, but it is a great product by its own merits, and I'll definitely keep it in my arsenal.

This review is subject to future editing, as I have yet to travel with the suitcase, so all observations are based on initial impressions of the luggage itself. For now, my stupid cat crawls inside every time I open it up to show it off. Get out of there, Sherlock!PROS* Ridiculously light. My lazy cat weighs 5 pounds more than this baby!* Solid construction. Stitching seems durable, and the material feels like it will withstand some abuse. Unlike my cat ... wuss.* 360 degree spinning wheels. Like when I toss my cat off the counter and he spins across the room.* Vibrant, attractive color (blue, in this case). My cat looks attractive ... in the right light, after a bath, from a distance, if you squint your eyes really tightly.* Retractable handle that actually extends and locks to a usable height. My cat extends too, when he stretches before a 12-hour nap.* Multiple front pockets seem handy for housing passports, e-tickets, photos of my cat, etc.* Limited 10-year warranty. If only I could return my damaged cat. How long do they live?CONS* The zippers aren't the smoothest, which concerns me with repeated use. Might the teeth get gnarled and lock up, or do that weird middle-split thing?* Retractable handle feels a teensy bit flimsyFINAL THOUGHTSIn all honesty, I think this is a very worthy entry in the carry-on market. As I mentioned at the top, I'll likely do a follow-up posting when I have actually traveled a few times with this, but for now I think the Helium Sky carry-on is pretty slick. And the price seems just about right, offering a good value for those in need of budget-friendly luggage.

I usually have 4-5 different protein powders on-hand, as I work for a supplement retailer and have access to numerous products. At this point I have probably tried 50-60 different kinds of protein powders, some good some garbage. Lean Body by Labrada was a brand with which I had no prior experience, so I had no expectations. Here are my thoughts:PROS:* Fairly clean profile, taking a more natural approach to the ingredients and sweeteners* Mixes up pretty well with a shaker cup, and not too gritty* Taste is excellent. This is really the high-point of the product. Not overly sweet, not too bland, with a bold chocolate flavor* Easily digestible, with no subsequent cramping or boatingCONS:* Price per serving is far higher than it should be -- as of this review, over $1.50 per scoop* Given the overall caloric value and lack of satiation, not an effective meal replacement* Some questionable ingredients, like non-dairy creamer (provides a smooth mouth-feel, but invaluable as a nutrient) and polydextrose (a very cheap, fiber-like ingredient)* No full-disclosure as to what their "Natural Flavors" areBOTTOM LINE:If you're looking for a well-balanced protein powder (the macros are 50/30/20 proteins, carbs, fats) without a lot of additives, Lean Body Hi Protein is definitely a viable option. But if in need of a true meal replacement, especially given the cost, look elsewhere.
Very simple side-scroller game, the object of which is to keep the cat afloat and avoid hitting objects. Fun, frustrating, funny. Get it!

I've never been one to really respond well to creatine, but I thought I'd give BUILD-HD a shot and I am blown away. On non-training days, I take one scoop in the morning, on an empty stomach, and on training days I take one scoop post-workout.Within the first few days of using, my muscles already felt fuller, recovery time improved drastically, and strength increased by quite a bit. I don't know if it's the blend of supporting ingredients enhancing the creatine monohydrate, but it is definitely working for me. Mixibility is pretty good, with only a few undissolved grains floating in my shaker, and the flavor is really nice.The major knock against the product is the price point, considering creatine on its own is very inexpensive. But if you're looking to try a new creatine, give BUILD-HD a try.

I have fairly weak wrists, especially since having surgery on my left wrist, so certain exercises (barbell bench press, military press, etc) cause undue stress, limiting my ability to lift heavy weight. After using the new HumanX Wrist Stabilizers for several workouts, I can say they are quite effective at aiding in wrist support/strength, but do come with some negative points as well.PROS:* Very thick, cushy padding feels good against the skin and compresses the wrists well* Adjustable to fit a broad range of wrist sizes* Very strong and really stabilizes the wrists, allowing one to increase the weight load of a given exercise* Stays in place/no shifting, so no need to readjust during the workoutCONS:* Padding is not extended all the way around the straps, leaving a gap of no protection* Takes a little adjusting to sit comfortably on the wrists* The metal buckle can rub against the wrist bones if not positioned correctly* No breath-ability, so wrists get sweaty* Price point a little high, especially given the Chinese manufacturing tagOverall, HumanX Wrist Stabilizers are a good, not great, product. There are plenty of other brands that offer similar support at a lower price, but if you want good, strong stabilization and are willing to pay a little more, these are certainly worth a try.

As an avid gym goer looking to maximize joint health and recovery, I have tried numerous combinations, concoctions, elixirs, witch's brews, etc for my joints, each of which certainly has its own merits, but nothing that I can definitively say has been effective. Chondroitin, glucosamine, MSM, fish oil, white willow bark, boswellia, and turmeric have all graced my supplement cupboard, but always willing to experiment, I have implemented a newcomer: NeoCell Hyaluronic Acid.First off, it's hard to quantitatively measure the effectiveness of this type of product, as it generally takes time to build in the body, and even then results can be quite subtle. And one's anecdotal evidence is obviously not the best tool by which to measure whether or not a product will work for you, especially given that we all respond differently to ingredients/products. SO, to determine whether or not the hyaluronic acid was effective, I took it exclusively without the aid of other joint supplements for the first two weeks, then added in other supplements for the remainder of the supply.From what I can gather, the hyaluronic acid seems to be more salubrious when used in conjunction with other products; in my case, I added turmeric (Curcumin) and MSM. On its own, my joints certainly had a reduction in inflammation and my post-workout recovery was pretty solid, but the results were far more dramatic when used in a regimen of products. My knees, normally my most bothersome joints, felt particularly strong.As for the pills themselves, they are small and easy to swallow, gentle on the stomach, with no disagreeable odor. The price point seems to be about right, though, considering the pills are more effective when used with other supplements, the monthly cost could quickly add up.Overall, a good, not great, product for joint health, but certainly worth looking into if you have exhausted other options, or are looking to get that little extra boost from your current joint program.

PZ Myers is a breath of fresh, godless air. As much as I enjoy reading the works of the "new" atheists (Daniel Dennett, Richard Dawkins, Sam Harris, etc), the tone of their efforts is generally of a much more serious, often times combative nature, an urgent call to action against primitive beliefs that hold back the progress of humanity. While Myers does address many serious topics, his humor pervades within The Happy Atheist, offering an alternative, light-hearted perspective on why the belief in god(s) is silly and antiquated.The Happy Atheist is broken up into short, easily digestible chapters, each focusing on different issues that arise in the "to believe or not to believe" debate. Myers uses his sharp scientific mind to great effect, poking copious holes in the arguments and defenses laid out by believers, many of whom respond to Myers with nothing less than death threats. Some of the various topics covered in this short book are abortion, evolution, morality, and perhaps my favorite chapter, the desecration of a communion wafer.My only real grievance with the book (pamphlet?) is the overall lack of cohesiveness. There does not seem to be an overarching point or message, other than the belief in god(s) is no longer relevant in our modern, scientifically-learned world.An enjoyable read offering wisdom and compelling arguments on every page, The Happy Atheist is sure to polarize its readers, but will ultimately satisfy those on the godless side of the argument. I'll end with my favorite passage from the book:(P. 28) [Referring to the desecration of "sacred" items] "Nothing must be held sacred. Question everything. God is not great, Jesus is not your lord, you are not disciples of any charismatic prophet. You are all human beings who must make your way through your lives by thinking and learning, and you have the job of advancing humanity's knowledge by winnowing out the errors of past generation and finding a deeper understanding of reality. You will not find wisdom in rituals and sacraments and dogma, which build only self-satisfied ignorance. You can find truth by looking at your world with fresh eyes and a questioning mind.And it was finished."

I sweat a lot. Even sitting here, typing this out, I can feel beads trickling. As such, I need a good deodorant to mask the activity of my underarms. Some time ago, I switched over to aluminum-free deodorants and antiperspirants, because I realized aluminum was blocking my pores and irritating my underarms. My mainstay deodorant has been Herbal Clear Sport Deodorant Stick 1.80 Ounces, which I really like, but I wanted to try something new with a different scent.Baxter of California -- though not an antiperspirant -- is an excellent alternative for me. I like that it rolls on clear and smoothly, and is a cylindrical shape, rather than the traditional oblong shape of most deodorants (why did that shape become the standard, anyway??). The scent is great, being very light and not overpowering, but still masculine (though my wife has actually borrowed it!).The odor protection seems to last a quite a while, even under heavy, sweaty conditions, such as after a good workout, so no need to reapply throughout the day. The only major downside is the cost, which is a little hard to justify, considering there are much less expensive alternatives.But if you're looking for a more natural deodorant that's free of aluminum and the other typical chemicals found in many brands, I certainly recommend giving Baxter of California a try!

As a runner and occasional cyclist, tracking my workouts has been aided immensely by the use of heart rate monitors -- of which I have owned several. Prior to GPS technology, I owned the Timex Ironman Men's Road Trainer Heart Rate Monitor Watch, Black/Orange, Full Size -- which was spotty, but got the job done; then upgraded to a GPS-enhanced Garmin Forerunner 405CX GPS Sport Watch with Heart Rate Monitor (Blue), which was an awesome GPS HRM. And now I'm back to Timex, with their new Run Trainer 2.0, loaded with plenty 'o bells and whistles.PROS:* Despite all appearances, the watch is not too obtrusive or bulky and sits comfortably on the wrist* Big display screen that presents a ton of training data: heart rate (when wearing the chest strap), distance, pace, intervals/splits, etc* Comfortable HRM chest strap that fits well and doesn't slide around when running; and maintains good communication with the watch* Fairly easy-to-use functionality and set-up (took maybe 5 minutes to get familiar with the features and user info fields)* Better-than-average GPS synch with accurate data* Solid battery life (Timex states 8 hours, which seems to be about right) and quick recharge time* BUTTONS -- ACTUAL BUTTONS! (Garmin Forerunner users will understand my frustration)* The ability to upload data to several websites is awesomeCONS:* Can take a little time to lock onto a solid GPS signal, and has (only a couple of times) lost the signal during a run* The unit will occasionally lose my heart rate signal, but the seems to occur mainly when the temps are a little lower* For some reason, when the battery is completely drained, the watch will reset the field data to January 1, and the time gets screwed up. It does fix itself once recharged and a GPS signal is reestablished, so more of a minor nuisance than anythingHave not used this in water to test its ability there, nor do I own a foot pod, but both features are definitely nice to have. The hydration reminder seems a little unnecessary, as I think most athletes know when to fuel during a workout, but again, nice for those who need it. Price seems fair for what you get, and is more-or-less in the range of most GPS HRMs of the same caliber.Overall, a great contender in the GPS HRM category, and a vast improvement over many other models. I'd definitely recommend the Run Trainer 2.0 for those in need of a reliable HRM with an abundance of features!

Over the years, protein bars have become better and better, with companies utilizing excellent ingredients in order to maximize taste and nutritional value. My go-to bars are by Quest Nutrition, which have to be the best on the market, but thinkThin bars are certainly a worthy option when I want to munch on something different.The texture is a unique chewy/crispy blend that some might consider on the dry side, but I personally enjoy it. The flavor, in my case dark chocolate, is definitely a big selling point: not too sweet, definitely indulgent, with the right amount of bitterness.The nutritional profile is better than most bars, being gluten-free, low(er)-carb, but the high amount of sugar alcohols might cause digestive issues for some.
