While the translator has done a good job reflecting on Manolito's person, his expressions may, at times, go beyond the reader age group. The talented illustrator has done a superb job to engage the kids visually.

****Mister Max: 'The Book of Lost Things' is the first volume in a new series by Cynthia Voigt, the Newbery Medal winner. Here pops mysterious circumstances to propel the story in a colorful setting. The hero is a preteen boy, with several non conventional friends and a single trusted older, but cranky person to consult with. The tale is based in the particulars of a fully realized world of Max's irresponsible parents, within a later British Victorian port.The young, theatrical couple is swiftly invited by an Indian maharajah to play Shakespeare for the monarch's pleasure. Max goes to the port to join them on board the Flower of Kashmir, and discovers that ship is illusion, and that his parents are missing, leaving just an obscure note.  He returns to his trusty old friend, and begins to assume a role in the locale, to find where it may be that his parents were kidnapped.In this story, life is harshly interrupted for Max when his parents were kidnapped, and one might think that the goal would be to find them. Max seems from the start detached from his parents to make their disappearance feel shocking. Max's uniqueness is of a quiet inert kind, that may not excite the young readership. Albeit, he didn't solve the mystery, he declares himself a professional Sherlock Holmes!

****1/2Bingo and J'miah are two raccoons, who keep watch over their layer of earth home, As True Blue Scouts of Sugar Man Swamp, it is their major job to awaken the long-sleeping Sugar Man, in emergencies, to protect the swampland. Chap Brayburn, whose family runs a Pies Cafe, loves Sugar Man Swamp; those sugar pies are made from wild sugarcane. There exist two main threats to the swamp: foreign hogs who are rushing the swamp to consume the sugarcane.Meanwhile, wrestling alligator Jaeger Stitch plans to turn Sugar Man swamp into an Alligator Wrestling Arena. While the sugarcane is protected by a big number of venomous snakes, the  scouts need to wake up the Sugar Man who does not submit to being awakened even as danger approaches, to defend the swamp  against the pigs and developers by enticing him with the smell of sugar. This is how the story develops into an engaging puzzle.My grandson fell in love with the raccoons Bingo and J'miah, and wished the large snake could be of real help. Starting with their first mission, these two raccoons capture his admiration. I also was drawn into the political plotting, with a sweet tooth for the sugar pies, and Noah's hope and excitement by this tale of daring rescues, alligator wrestlers, and devouring hogs. The scene is set for struggle, mystery, and danger, it is just getting exciting right now.

Olwen Mellory, who writes children's books, is invited to an intensive retreat at Dunesfort House in the Outer Hebrides (Scotland). It turns out to be far more challenging than she imagined, and she has grave doubts about staying. Powerful techniques are invoked such as prolonged hyperventilation and walking on hot coals, and intense exploration of dreams and fantasies. Difficult enough but then a catastrophic event changes everything and it seems doubtful the program can even continue. Will Olwen be able to stay till the end, or, would she be wise to run away as fast as she can? What will she learn about her inner self? And what is the secret story of the inscrutable and menacing Director, a man known only as Rose? You will have to read the book to find out.The book is hard to classify. Novel or memoir? Or fictionalized memoir loosely based on real life experiences? Beautifully written, in lyrical, colorful prose, the book is not easy reading. There is so much intense instrospection, so much free-floating emotion, so much inner pain to be worked through, that this reader found it necessary to take frequent breaks from the text. Not to mention the author's describing every bite of food Olwen ate and every garment she  wore during the week. I kept imagining what kind of enormous steamer trunk she would have needed to carry all those clothes.  The book is sprinkled with expressions in Scots Gaelic whose pronunciation and meaning are not well explained.If you like to read about  inner Work, the exploration of the Unconscious, soul healing, and profound psychic transformation you will love this book. If not, you should probably skip it. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Buck Hawthorne is a private investigator in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. Business is pretty slow till the latest group of clients arrives one rainy day--and a strange group of characters it is. A centaur out of Greek mythology heads up the group--an attractive young woman with the body of a horse and four agile hooves. And others equally strange.  It seems these clients are visitors from another world, a magical world coterminous with our own, but operating by different rules. What they have to say is even more shocking than their fairytale world appearance. The case they want help with involves family secrets, a terrible crime, and a breakdown of social order in the magical other world. Will Buck get involved? Should he? Should he follow these oddly assorted visitors into their world? And if he does, can he ever return home? Will he succeed in the heroic mission that is offered to him, or will he be eaten by the dragon? Well, ha ha, I won't tell you, you'll just have to read the book for yourself. You'll love it!Author Steve Vassey is one of the most creative, imaginative writers you will ever encounter. He has created a fantasy world that is unbelievably believable, with characters you can love or hate, heroic struggles, earthy conversations, romantic encounters, a fair amount of lust, anger, and white-knuckle fear, and the possible breakdown of civilization. The writing is accessible, colloquial, fast moving and engaging. I recommend Centaur with enthusiasm. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Bjorn had high hopes for his new job at The Authority (a  bureaucratic enterprise of uncertain function), but the early signs were not auspicious. Bjorn found his co-workers irritating at best, undisciplined, poorly dressed. He in turn came across as pompous and controlling. Things took a downward turn when the fellow workers noticed him standing, trancelike, in the corridor leading to the toilets. He maintained he was visiting a room there, a room that no one else could see, a room where he felt re-energized, creative, better able to think.Was Bjorn mentally ill or prophetic? Was he seeing things that didn't exist, or things that others could not yet see? In any case, an administrator's nightmare. Karl, the boss, tried various strategies to keep Bjorn functioning and the office staff from outright rebellion, but nothing seemed to work for long. Would he have to fire Bjorn? Or would he find that this odd-ball employee was on to something important? What would you have done?Author Jonas Karlsson writes simple, unadorned prose that is easy to read and very engaging. You can finish this short volume at a sitting, but may wish to pace yourself to prolong the enjoyment. What a stunning experience--like Office Space turning into magic realism. It raises so many interesting questions--and--as a bonus, the author includes a study guide for exploring them.  This is one of the most enjoyable books I've read this year and I recommend it highly! Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

The Nasmertov family of Odessa, Ukraine, now live in Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, except for Uncle Pasha, the eccentric poet, who still lives in Odessa, but flirts with the idea of relocating to America. The family lives in a state of low-grade chaos in both countries, eternally ruminating about this and that but unable to make decisions. That is the plot, as far as I can tell. Reading this book was like taking a prolonged vacation with this family, as though one had mysteriously found oneself living with them, trying to figure out who they were and how they were related. It wasn't easy.The story, such as it is, takes place in different time frames and different countries. Some of the characters became differentiated from the perpetual confusion--like Frida, the surly daughter and reluctant medical student. Or Pasha who enjoys a certain level of literary fame, but is almost unable to function in practical matters. Some of the characters become a bit more likeable, at least familiar, as the story progresses, but the reader will have little desire to know them any better.Author Yelena Akhtiorskaya writes in a rambling, disjointed style, with long, confusing sentences, odd turns of phrase, and unusual metaphors. At times she shows flashes of wit, vivid depictions of family interactions, striking descriptions of nondescript, oddly dressed characters, poignant moments of failed communication. If you like that sort of writing you might enjoy Panic In A Suitcase. For this reviewer, the book was almost unreadable. I did manage to finish it with some effort. I'd give it a weak recommendation. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Zal was rejected by his mother and raised in a  cage with birds, without human contact. Later he is adopted by the eccentric Hendricks, treated by the psychologist Rhodes, involved with the impresario of illusions, Silber, and struggles to become human. He learns human language and simple social skills, but like other feral children remains horribly damaged. He forms a doomed relationship with Asiya, damaged in her own way. Trying to save each other they are drawn inexorably to a disaster which somehow involves the  events of 9-11-2001. More than that I can't tell you. The plot is complex, with many levels, and leaves much to the reader's imagination.The writing is spectacular, engaging, beautiful and captivating. Author Porochista Khakpour is incredibly imaginative, and keeps the reader engaged even as the story becomes more and more unbelievable. Not an easy feat. The characters are vividly realized. I cared for these people and related to their emotions. I felt personally connected to Zal, doomed to live life as a freak, never quite human. What finally happens to Zal and Asiya I can't explain. You'll have to read it yourself.If you like speculative fiction with a very different view of reality you will love The Last Illusion. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Jonah Daniel Jacobstein is a thirty-something corporate lawyer, driven to succeed no matter who gets hurt. He is also incapable of a committed relationship. His life begins spinning out of control after a series of visionary experiences. With his life and career in shambles he begins a rambling search for meaning that takes him from Manhattan to Amsterdam and finally to Las Vegas. Judith Bulbrook is a driven young woman, raised in an intellectual hot-house by professor parents, groomed for admission to Yale and spectacular achievements. Her life disintegrates into meaninglessness when her parents are killed in the attacks of 9-11. She also turns up in Las Vegas, using her talents in the service of an egomaniacal, ruthless developer. Are Judith and Jonah meant to be together? Will their paths even cross? What is the meaning of all that has happened to them?Of course, I won't tell you, so you'll have to read the novel for yourself. I promise, you'll love it. Author Joshua Mark Feldman writes rich, exquisite prose, creating a series of unforgettable characters and their misadventures. Such a delightful assortment of fascinating, troubled, talented, needy and somehow charming individuals. What ties all these characters and events together is the metaphor of Jonah, the reluctant prophet, sent on a mission he didn't understand or believe in.The book is easy to read and hard to put down. I kept wanting to tell Jonah, "Don't do it," at some critical juncture, but of course he never listened to me. You'll enjoy meeting him too, although he won't listen to you either. I recommend this book most highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Callie Morgan is a Boston police detective, and a good one, but after she tangles with the Russian mafia and they kill her husband, her life begins to fall apart. Hoping to retreat and regroup, she moves with her teen-aged son, Jeb, to Edisto Beach, South Carolina. A place where she can feel safe, right? Wrong, of course. On the very first day, her neighbor and old friend, Henry Beechum, is murdered. And that's just the beginning. Every day brings new horrors. Someone is breaking into homes on her street, making it clear that no one is safe. But who is it? And what do they want?Callie has family ties in the area, but still feels like an outsider. Is there anyone she can trust?  The police? The quirky new-age neighbor? The local handyman? The wealthy businessman who hosts extravagant parties? Certainly not her elderly mother--their relationship has always been strained. The situation becomes ever more fluid and complex. Good guys turn into bad and bad into good, none are as they seemed. Will Callie figure out--in time--who the real villain is? Will she be able to convince the local police? Will she be able to save herself and her son? You'll have to read the book to find out. You will love it.Author C. Hope Clark writes in a fast-paced, relentless style, pulling the reader into the tangled community where Callie is fighting for her life. The book is easy to read and totally enjoyable, with richly developed characters in complex relationships, and the charming background of the South Carolina coast. Fans of author Clark have come to expect great reading from her and they won't be disappointed by Murder On Edisto. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Leonardo was once a noted writer and University professor, but then an affair with a student destroyed his career and his marriage. Now, a few years later, society itself is collapsing. We are not told exactly what happened, but one by one the props of modern civilization are disappearing--banks, postal service, radio, gasoline, law enforcement. As the nation descends into barbarism, Leonardo finds himself in charge of two young children and a puppy, responsibilities he is ill-equipped to handle. Things go from bad to worse. The fantasy of keeping a low profile and living quietly in his village becomes unsustainable. People flee from their villages hoping to find refuge in France or Switzerland, but those options are also untenable. Gangs of drug-crazed youth roam the countryside pillaging what little is left of civilization. Leonardo suffers unspeakable losses and humiliations.Will he survive? Will anyone survive? Will Leonardo be able to save his children? Will some seedlings of civilization sprout again in this dystopian landscape? Will Leonardo find anything within to sustain him? Is there any possibility of redemption for him? You'll have to read the book to find out.Author Davide Longo writes in beautiful, simple prose, describing the systematic breakdown of a comfortable world order into absolute chaos. He constructs and deconstructs his world skillfully, making everything that happens believable. It is a long, sad, horrifying journey, but well worth reading. If you are a fan of dystopian future fiction you will love this, but be warned: some of it is really ugly, disgusting, and horriffic, as of course it would be. I recommend this one highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Linda is a woman in her thirties, a respected journalist, with a loving husband and two wonderful children. She lives a more than comfortable lifestyle in the comfortable Swiss city of Geneva and has everything she could possibly want. She is also bored out of her mind. Everything changes when a chance encounter leads to a riotous but meaningless affair with a man she knew as an adolescent. As the affair plays out Linda takes unbelievably stupid risks with her life and marriage, makes some terrible decisions, and finally...but you'll have to read it yourself to find out what happens.The novel is well-written, but not up to the author's usual standard. The characters are cardboard figures, the plot is hard to believe, and the ending, though enjoyable, is absurd. Much of the book consists of philosophical digressions about the meaning of life and love, and the need to take risks. Still, if you're a fan of Paulo Coelho, it might be worth reading. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

In 1987 Gary Hart, good-looking, brilliant, and a visionary political thinker, seemed likely to capture the Democratic nomination for the presidency, and quite possibly the presidency. Then in little over a week his candidacy imploded and his career was reduced to a one-liner. People still remember Hart, not for his political skills or his visionary ideas, but for an ill-fated excursion with a gorgeous young woman on a boat called Monkey Business. What really happened on that boat? What was Hart thinking? And why was his fall so catastrophic and permanent?Author Matt Bai takes us through the episode, the times, the characters, and the changing political landscape to try to understand what happened. He doesn't actually reveal anything new about the incident. The players, those who are still alive, are sticking to their stories. More importantly he discusses what has changed in the political process as it merges with entertainment: inaccessible candidates who try to say as little as possible, while the press hounds them for missteps, gaffes, or personal failings (everyone has some), under he rubric of "character." Does this lead to better candidates and better office-holders? Probably not. The book is a fascinating account of this societal transition to what he calls tabloid politics.Matt Bai writes a gripping account of the Hart meltdown and the changes that have followed. He has access to many of the key players and documents, and what he writes is both believable and profoundly disturbing. He writes in a clear, direct style which is easy to read. He left this reviewer both intrigued and saddened. The quality of political discourse in America has been changed in a fundamental and very destructive way. You may or may not agree with Author Bai's conclusions but he will hold your attention. If you are at all interested in American politics, you should read this book. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Jason Padgett was, by his own account, a shallow, pleasure-seeking goof-ball, until the night he was viciously beaten after stumbling out of a karaoke bar. He suffered severe traumatic brain injury from which he has never fully recovered. His symptoms have been mainly psychiatric, including PTSD, OCD, and spells of depression. He also developed a remarkable new interest in mathematics, geometry, the significance of pi, and fractals. He began to see mathematical concepts in visual forms, and expressed his discoveries in detailed drawings. There was nothing in his previous background or training to explain these interests and abilities.This book is a detailed memoir of Jason's journey through hell and back and into his new life as a mathematical savant who also experiences synesthesia (the blending of sensory modalities). These abilities are uncommon, and to acquire them in adult life is extremely rare indeed. Jason's experience raises difficult questions about the brain and its workings, and about consciousness itself, and Jason meets many fascinating people as he seeks answers to these riddles. He takes the reader on an amazing journey of discovery--still unfinished as of the writing of the book.Author Jason Padgett and co-author Maureen Seaberg have written an interesting and moving memoir about experiences that most of us can barely understand. The writing is not polished, often repetitious, and sometimes rambling. Still, I managed to finish it in a day. If you liked Treffert's "Islands of Genius,"  or if you have any interest in the savant syndromes or synesthesia, you will surely want to get hold of his book. I recommend it. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Tenzing Norbu may be one of the more unlikely characters in contemporary fiction--a  successful private investigator who is a former police officer and former Buddhist monk. His lifestyle now is very un-monk-like, but with occasional flashes of insight from his former life. Things get complicated when he takes on a missing person case that rapidly turns into something much bigger. Something that involves Mexican drug cartels, weapons of mass destruction, and a drug boss of bosses who is the personification of evil. Meanwhile Tenzing tries to put his personal life on hold and avoid dealing with his fear of intimacy. It all gets very tangled, with one life-threatening crisis after another. That's all I can tell you about the plot. You just have to read it.Authors Gay Hendricks and Tinker Lindsay write amazingly engaging prose that draws you in and won't let go. Beautiful descriptions somehow don't slow down the action. The characters are fascinating, with distinct voices. Each of them has personal issues, issues of good and evil. An occasional snippet of Buddhist teaching illuminates these issues without being preachy.An amazing book. It sounded implausible, but I couldn't put it down. If you're looking for a detective thriller with nonstop action, life-threatening adventures, and psychological depth, this is just the book for you. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Michael Murray is a precocious eleven year old boy living in a small island community in Scotland. Life changes when something terrible happens to his mother, something the family covers up with lies and evasions, something shameful and unspeakable, but what? Michael lurks around doorways, listening and trying to piece together what happened and what it means. Whatever it was, the fissures that open up in the little family seems to radiate into the surrounding community, into all the family's relationships. For Michael it is the start of a painful maturation process. That's all I can say about the plot without spoiling it. You'll have to read this one yourself.Author Lisa O'Donnell writes a poignant, lucid account of a family trauma as experienced by a terribly innocent young kid. When I first began the book I thought it was going to be an Adrian Mole type of book, the foibles of the adult world through the cute perceptions of a child; it soon became apparent that this is a much darker and more serious work, even if it has to be told piecemeal, through the glimpses of a child, in a family that is desperately trying to hide the truth. The writing is delightfully simple, clear, even with a bit of local dialect and a few unfamiliar slang expressions. The story carries you along. You really want this family to find some healing, and you want Michael to regain his footing.The novel is not perfect, repetitious at times, and a bit too cute at times. Still, it's powerful, poignant, and engaging. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

This novel starts off with a bang. Carolina Slade is thrust into an assignment which goes way beyond her usual bureaucratic duties at the Department of Agriculture, an assignment which involves illegal drugs, the governor's family, the VA hospital, and some really nasty people. This assignment is off-the record, and when Slade runs into unexpected, life-threatening complications, she finds that no one has her back. Meanwhile she is trying to raise two challenging teenagers, settle into her new home, and work things out with her love-interest, Wayne Largo. Enough about the plot--it's complicated with many levels. You'll just have to read the book.Author C. Hope Clark writes an offbeat thriller with fascinating characters. The pages crackle with energy, the heroine ever struggling to balance her job, her family, and her emotions. She doesn't like being told what to do, and repeatedly gets herself in hot water by challenging authority. She makes mistakes, any one of which could be fatal. Will Slade get out of this alive? Will she find the real bad guys before it's too late? Will Wayne make a commitment to her, or go back to his ex? Wait and see!This is the third book in the Carolina Slade series and in my opinion the best. Author Clark is maturing as an author, her writing becoming more complex, deeper and richer. Her characters are more lifelike, her plots more intriguing. You would never figure out where this one was going without knowing in advance, but in the end it all makes sense. Looking for an unusual thriller with a South Carolina setting and a marvelous cast of characters, this is one novel you need to get hold of. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

John Lago is an assassin for hire, working for a man named Bob. His job is to infiltrate large organizations as a lowly unpaid intern, develop trust in this almost invisible role, and kill some high-level executive. As he gets started on his last case, before mandatory "retirement" at age 25, he leaves a memoir and pointers for the "interns" who will come after him. He's very, very good at what he does, but in this case he makes some major mistakes. For one thing he develops some human emotions, a bad thing in this line of work.Of course, John is a classic psychopath without a trace of normal feeling or  empathy, but all this is about to change as his path crosses that of Alice, the very hot and very savvy lawyer who works with him. And then there is Marcus, the biological father he manages to track down and actually form a relationship with. He starts to make mistakes, and things begin careening out of control. Will John be able to pull off one last assassination? Will he be able to retire? Will he even survive? I won't tell you, of course, so you'll have to read this novel for yourself. You will love it.Author Shane Kuhn writes brilliantly, with a wickedly dark sense of humor. He has created a marvelous spoof of every violent, testosterone-drenched novel and movie you've ever encountered. None of this stuff could possibly happen, but still you'll keep turning pages, shuddering and laughing at the same time. I think author Kuhn may have invented a new genre--the black spoof we might call it--and he has certainly given a new meaning to the term "intern."  Warning--if graphic violence turns you off, you might think twice about reading this one. If not, get hold of it as soon as you can. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Jon Grady is a brilliant scientist who has come up with a way to manipulate gravity. Unfortunately you won't get to see his discoveries applied, or his accomplishment recognized. He's been suppressed, worse than that, imprisoned and tortured by a shadowy government agency. The Bureau of Technology Control was supposed to maintain social stability by controlling the influx of new technologies so they wouldn't be too disruptive. Over the years it has grown ever more secretive and powerful, so that the legitimate U.S. government has completely lost control of it. Now it is holding some of the world's most brilliant minds in a prison with no possible escape and is systematically deconstructing their brains for its own evil purposes.Well, that's the basic story, and it raises many fascinating questions. Will Grady survive? Will he escape? Will anyone ever escape from the ultra-high tech prison called Hibernity? Will Jon Grady ever again live a normal life? Will he find love? And what will happen to the diabolical Bureau of Technology Control? Of course I'm not going to tell you, so you'll have to read Influx for yourself.Author Daniel Suarez is noted to be a New York Times best-selling author, but in this massive (400+ page) novel, he falls a little short. The writing is not polished, repetitive, filled with cliches. The first half of the book is mostly narrative, setting out the premises of the story and its fictional world. Huge amounts of scientific-sounding jargon are thrown at the reader, but the actual underlying science is never clearly explained. There's a lot of playing with gravity--falling up, falling down, falling sideways--and with brain science, but again, the author doesn't give the impression of understanding this science well enough to explain it. A lot of stock science-fiction characters fill the pages with stilted, improbable dialog. On the other hand, it moves fast once you get past the half-way point, and you will keep reading just to see how the author will pull it off.If you love sci-fi thrillers with brilliant scientists and evil government bureaucrats, you should probably read this one, but I don't recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber

In this thinly veiled autobiography (or is it fictionalized memoir?) Sara Barron recounts a life of awkwardness, embarrassment, humiliation, social mistakes, and family baggage. Stuff you wouldn't even tell your therapist. Stuff about body parts, bodily fluids, and bodily gases. About some of the creepiest room-mates you ever heard of, and that doesn't count her imaginary dog. I kept waiting for the author to say, "I'm not making this stuff up." I'm pretty sure she made some of it up, at least I hope so. Eventually, in spite of everything, she grew up and became an author.And what an author! Sara Barron is a genius with words, uses  language to brilliant effect, creates scenes, events and characters that are impossibly believable. She is great with dialog, even when the characters are giving each other the silent treatment. She is able to talk about some of the most embarrassing and humiliating events (thoughts, inner monologs, fantasies) without quite crossing over the line into filth. She is incredibly funny.Should you read this book? That depends. If you're squeamish about body parts and graphic language, probably not. Seriously. If you're open-minded about such things and old enough for R-rated movies, you will love it. With that in mind, I recommend it. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Brian McGrory had it made, working his dream job as a columnist for the Boston Globe, walking the streets of Boston, and sharing life with his beloved retriever, Harry. But then his marriage fell apart and his dog grew old and died, Major changes took place, not always graciously accepted. Brian found  new love with his dog's charming veterinarian, Pam. But that meant uprooting himself to the suburbs, trying to fit in to a new family, and most of all, learning to get along with his nemesis, a fluffy white rooster named Buddy.Author Brian McGrory has written a charming, if slightly fluffy, memoir about this period of his life, and how he transitioned from a self-absorbed, Seinfeldian thirty-something, to a real family man, thanks in large part to the relentless badgering of the rooster. It's well written, but a little overdone. If there's any flaw to this story, I would say the author dragged it out too long. Too much introspection, too much self-absorbed whining. Still, it's enjoyable. If you're looking for a light-hearted but touching memoir packed with animals, feelings, and personal growth, you will probably love this one, and I recommend it. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Agnes Gilbert is a fiftyish woman living marginally as a hypnotist's office assistant and taking care of her elderly, perennially kvetching mother, when she has the first of her visitations from an entity called Elias, the archangel. She is not the type of person to seek or expect such an experience. She is of no religious persuasion, with vague spiritual leanings, carrying on a torrid but loveless affair with her apartment manager, the maniacal street-evangelist, Lucas Beeler. Elias the archangel tells Agnes to simplify, divest, detach herself from worldly things, and promises to visit her again on the last Sunday of each month. As people learn about Agnes' visitations, crowds begin to gather for these monthly seances, a motley crowd of seekers in search of wisdom, enlightenment, healings, miracles, whatever.But Elias is a testy archangel, easily offended, who makes it clear that he does not provide "services," and is not to be asked for angelic healings or other such favors. The townspeople are not happy at the crowds gathering in their quiet neighborhood. The invalid mother is not pleased at sharing Agnes' attention with the angelic visitor. Things begin going downhill in many different ways. Of course I won't tell you what happens, you'll have to read it for yourself.The book is packed with interesting, colorful characters with distinctive voices, entangled in interesting and complex ways. Author Patricia Halloff writes in a hectic, overwrought style with penetrating if dark humor, vivid dialogue, sparkling flashes of ethnic dialect, and a piercing way of looking at spiritual questions. No, this is not the usual quest for enlightenment, but something else entirely. Something dark and challenging. Something disturbing even as it makes you laugh. I can recommend this book but warning: if you're looking for something sweet and uplifting, this isn't it. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.Note: a copy of the book was supplied to me by the author.

On the night of March 8, 1971, the regional FBI office in Media, Pennsylvania, was burglarized by an unlikely group of citizen-activists, and all its files were stolen. Later, as copies of the files were sent in successive mailings to the news media, an amazing new picture of the FBI began to emerge--an agency spending most of its energies on investigating and suppressing dissent. The revelations shocked the American public and caused massive upheaval in the FBI. Amazingly, the eight burglars were never caught.The book is an in-depth account of the burglary, the times, the social unrest and dissension around the Viet Nam war, the antiwar movement, the conceptualization of the burglary as a way to re-invigorate that movement, the recruiting of the burglars, the stories of the burglars themselves, the planning and execution of the burglary, and the revelations that developed of an FBI out of control and obsessed with spying on American citizens. In the book's final section the author studies the aftermath of the burglary, the changes that were made (and sometimes not made) to the FBI, and the continuing American tension between freedom and security.Author Betty Medsger writes a gripping stranger-than-fiction account of this bizarre episode and its meaning for America. This is a page-turner, written in novelistic style, but packed with facts and profound analysis. At 536 pages, plus bibliography and notes, this is not light reading. For old codgers like this reviewer the Viet Nam era is still vivid in memory. I remember those times and the profound divisions that developed in our country, but I was not aware of the Media burglary. Therefore the book was profoundly enlightening. It was also disturbing, because it reflects something more amiss than the personal obsessions of J. Edgar Hoover. It describes a recurring mind-set in America, celebrating freedom of speech in the abstract while trying to suppress and/or punish those who express unpopular views. The author doesn't preach, but she forces the reader to think deeply about the issues raised. The story is not over.The Burglary is great reading, but it's also an important book, a book that needs to be read. I cannot recommend it too highly. Get hold of it as soon as you can and read it, just make sure  you have plenty of free time before you start. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Anyone doing counseling or therapy in a Christian context would do well to peruse this remarkable work. In an evolving field rife with controversy, the author presents a calm, reasoned, and inclusive overview of Christian therapeutics. While the basic orientation is to cognitive therapy, psychodynamic principles are not slighted. Subjects such as praying with (or for) the client, the use of Scripture, confession, forgiveness and redemption are all explored. Needless to say, it's not light reading, but it is accessible and understandable. The author presents different theories and points of view, treats all of them with respect, and offers a way for clinicians to think through and reason about clinical dilemmas.Author Mark McMinn uses a delightful method of presenting brief clinical vignettes, with different possible approaches, different therapists, and different assumptions, and invites the reader to reason through each situation. There are, of course, no simple answers, but there are pitfalls to be avoided and lessons to be learned. The writing style is clear and lucid, with a gentle touch of humor. Ethical issues are discussed in depth. Beyond the techniques and  vignettes, Author McMinn explores the foundations of Christian counseling, the underlying theology that must support any therapeutic efforts. The approach is not a bag of tricks. The vital ingredient must be the spiritual growth of the counselor/therapist.This reviewer, now retired, would love to have had McMinn's book in hand when he was treating patients. For anyone doing Christian counseling now, I cannot recommend this book too highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

A bright, ambitious kid doesn't get accepted to college--any college--and finds himself delivering pizzas, when, things get really weird. A teacher who wants to be liked finds an unflattering review of herself on grademyteacher(dot)com. A respected pediatrician faces divorce and personal ruin after one unbelievably stupid night of revelry. And so it goes. Each of the protagonists in these ten exquisite stories, an ordinary, flawed human being, faces disaster, their world coming apart at the seams. And while things may never quite get right after that, the character soldiers on, struggles, finds some kind of redemption, however tenuous. These are heart-breaking stories about believable characters, but they sparkle with humor and end up being strangely uplifting.No, I'm not going to tell you what happens. You have to read this book for yourself.Author Tom Perrotta writes in lucid, colloquial style, without pretentiousness. In fact, without a wasted word. He doesn't describe the characters or the weather or the surroundings. He just tells the story. He gets the reader's attention, and never lets go. He favors the present tense which gives added immediacy to the story-telling. If you like short stories you will love this book. I not only recommend it highly, I plan to order more of this author's work. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

America's first president has become an almost mythic figure, but to the author of this powerful biography, he was first and foremost a military man. In this densely written, scholarly book, Stephen Brumwell presents an intriguing portrait of the man who would come to be called, the father of his country. Not a complete biography, the work concentrates on Washington's military career, from the French and Indian wars to the American revolution, and a little beyond. Washington began his career as a hot-headed, overly aggressive young officer who had much to learn about leadership, but who gradually evolved into the wise and charismatic leader of revolutionary times. It was quite fascinating to this reader to follow the gradual transformation. No, Washington was not perfect, made some strategic blunders and suffered losses, but he learned from them. With an army of volunteers, happy coincidences, and his French allies,  he managed to humble the British empire of his day. He soldiered in a difficult political environment, with troops constantly on the verge of defection. Victory hung by a thread.This is an ambitious book, mostly readable, but, with long sentences and numerous names to remember, sometimes it's slow going. It fleshes out the sketchy picture of Washington acquired in grade school with a fascinating adult portrait of the man. It is not meant to be the complete story of his life, and should be supplemented by further reading. Author Brumwell develops a fascinating picture of the times, the culture, and the attitudes of Washington's America. I must admit, I learned a lot from this book, and I recommend it, but it's not always easy reading. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

When a computer can beat Kasparov at chess, is the human mind doomed to obsolescence? Maybe not, but, what if a computer could win game after game of Jeopardy? Where will it all end? Are we getting smarter in the new technological age? Or dumber? Will we end up exchanging cute pictures of cats as our last remaining intellectual activity? Author Clive Thompson tackles these questions and many more in this delightful, stimulating and thought-provoking book. The new technological devices are tools and they can extend the reach of our brains. Like every technological advance, from the invention of writing, to the printing press, the telephone, television, computers, and the internet, they can be used for good or ill. And like all these earlier advances, we tend to fear them, at least initially.The author doesn't endorse a doomsday scenario for the human mind, but sees a bright future for using the new tools. Computers can do things humans cannot, and vice versa. Exciting possibilities are beginning to emerge, applying the new technologies to such fields as medicine, politics, governance, and education. Yes, we may waste time on Facebook, but we may also develop a remarkable background awareness of the people in our lives. And no, teachers will not be replaced, but they will have more time to work with the students who need help, while other students are blasting ahead at their own pace. Governments are beginning to listen to the governed, at least on occasion, even in the most tightly repressive countries, as knowledge itself becomes more democratic than ever before.Author Thompson writes a scholarly but completely accessible book, sparkling with good humor and optimism. If you've ever wondered where technology might be taking us, if you've ever wondered whether social media are turning our brains to mush, or if we might actually be getting smarter, this is one book you MUST READ. It's a pure delight, and I recommend it most highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

This remarkable history links the great Benjamin Franklin to his little-known younger sister, Jane Franklin Mecom, and in doing so explores the meaning and scope of history itself. The brother and sister, one of whom is justly celebrated for statecraft, diplomacy, and science; the other who toiled in obscurity raising (and mostly losing) children, grand-children and great-grand-children, maintained a remarkable camaraderie  throughout their lives. Drawing on the few surviving letters of Jane (and the many of Benjamin), the author attempts to reconstruct the life of this spirited and intelligent woman who has been so overshadowed by her brother.The book is not exactly a biography of Jane Mecom; in fact it's hard to classify. It is also a history of the colonial era in America, the American revolution, the culture and way of life in those times, the hardships experienced by most people, the few opportunities for women to express themselves, their limited education, the poor state of medicine in those days, the outrageous infant mortality, and the sad fate of the mentally ill. And, the author says, that's what history is really about--people who were more celebrated in fiction than in what was thought of as history. All that, rather than the names, dates, battles, and accomplishments of a few giants.Author Jill Lepore has written a work of vast scholarship, drawing on a range of sources, that is also interesting, entertaining, and endearing. The characters come vividly to life, with all their struggles and suffering; and the emerging nation, the United States, as well. In fact author Lepore has created an amazing work from the scant historical traces of her subject, Jane. If you are at all interested in the founding generation of Americans, their lives and their times,  you will love this book. It's not always easy reading, and I must admit I had difficulty keeping all the names straight. At times the author becomes just a  bit preachy about the unfair treatment of women. A vast scholarly apparatus is included for those who want to pursue the material in more depth. I recommend this one highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

The book begins with Mom, Glen Finland, trying to teach her son to navigate the Washington, DC subway system. Endless hours of practice, following different routes, buying the tickets, trying not to get lost or distracted. This is important because her son, David, is autistic (with a variety of other impairments as well). He doesn't follow social cues well, he doesn't do abstract thinking well, he is outgrowing childhood, and he has no prospects for employment. Even when David gets it right, Mom has trouble letting him go. David is straining at independence and Mom suffers every step of the way.This is a powerful memoir about a young man with autism, about parenting, about the lack of social support for children who are different, about the limited help available from the army of doctors, counselors, and all of what David calls "professional strangers." If the book reveals a lot about David and his struggles (as inferred, because he doesn't talk about them and doesn't like to be asked questions), it probably says even more about Mom, author Glen Finland, and her struggles with parenting. She writes extremely well, drawing her readers into the pain, the frustration, and the occasional moments of triumph, how she survived, and how her marriage helped her survive. This is not a feel-good book with a happy ending, because David will never be "cured." It is, however, a hopeful book, and leaves us at least seeing possibilities, opportunities, openings, and moments of grace.This is a book to be read slowly, with much reflection. I recommend it most highly. This is a book you must read. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

The book starts with a horrifying and bloody murder. Jacob Christianson is asked to investigate, but finds himself blocked at every turn. The story takes place in the setting of a breakaway Mormon sect, still practicing polygamy. Jacob's sister, Eliza, is about to be forced into an arranged marriage with a most undesirable partner. Meanwhile the entire community is being rocked by a vicious struggle for power.The novel is packed with colorful detail, desert scenery, and the inner workings of a cult-like community. People burst into King James English, threaten each other with damnation, expel and shun those who break the group's taboos, and yet are able to countenance some truly mind-blowing evil schemes. So what will happen? Will Jacob solve the murder, will Jacob even survive? Will Eliza have to go through with an intolerable marriage? Will cooler heads prevail before the community implodes? You'll have to read the book to find out.Author Michael Wallace writes a fast-paced, gripping, sometimes hard-to-believe mystery thriller. After I read the first chapter I was so horrified I had to set the book aside for a few days. But once I started back reading I couldn't stop. If this book has any flaws it may be--too much. Too much information, too many characters, too much to learn about the community and its folk-ways. Sometimes it was hard to keep believing in the premise of the story. Still, a great read, and one I recommend. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Humans have always been fascinated with animals and their antics. Author  Vint Virga, veterinarian and animal behaviorist, believes there is a deep unity between animals and ourselves, and that we can learn a great deal about ourselves by studying them with open minds and with respect. Dr. Virga has spent many hours observing and studying animals, both at home and at the zoo where he consults. In this short book he uses case studies from his practice to illuminate such profound concepts as Mindfulness, Adaptability, Presence and Forgiveness, and many others. In the course of the book he shares from his vast wealth of clinical experience, reading and study, information about animals and their behaviors we might never have known.Unfortunately the book is not easy reading. Author Virga writes in long, complicated sentences, and digresses too often into well-worn paths of Buddhist philosophy. Many of the parables he quotes are too well-known and told at too great length. This reviewer would have liked to hear more about the animals themselves, and less of Dr. Virga's speculations about their possible feelings and motivations. Still, there's a lot of value in this book and I'm glad I read it. I recommend it, but if you're looking for short colorful anecdotes about cute animals, you may be disappointed. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

The aspiring writer of today confronts a rapidly changing landscape, where authors have to do most of their own promotion. Within the last few years the would-be author has started hearing about this mystical thing called "platform." It means something like one's built-in audience, or fan base, or followers. Those who will buy the book without much encouragement from the publisher. This short book goes a long way toward explaining exactly what platform is and how one goes about building one. Good thing because having one is almost mandatory now if you want to get published.This compact 244 page book falls into three sections: principles of platform, mechanics of platform, and interviews with authors who have used the principles effectively. It's hard work and takes an investment of time and commitment, a willingness to give without immediate reward, and openness to constant change. Platform building starts early, long before the book is published or even finished. When the book comes out, the platform, the followers, the potential buyers, must already be in place.Author Chuck Sambuchino knows his stuff and speaks from a rich vein of experience. The writing is a bit dry, the material is almost overwhelming. My favorite part of the book was the author interviews, with each of twelve successful authors speaking of their own journey and how they utilized the principles of platform effectively. Their accounts were believable, and they made it clear that no single method works for every author. I enjoyed this book and it sparked a lot of ideas for my own writing career. I wish the author had offered more of the nuts and bolts of social media and how to use them, but this is more of a big-picture kind of work. If you are a beginning or aspiring author Create Your Writer Platform is a book you need to read, and I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

Kevin is struggling to hold on to his dead-end job at the meat packing plant, trying to support his widowed mother and get through school, but then things get worse. Seems that Kevin's life has pursued a downhill course since he was ten years old, when gangsters murdered his father and little sister. He is about to lose this job, too, but the kindly intervention of Mr. Balducci, an old family friend, keeps him employed, although constantly humiliated and degraded. He's a plucky and resourceful kid, though, and a surprisingly good boxer, and begins clawing his way back up the social ladder. Then he learns that Mr. Balducci, the old family friend, is actually running a powerful crime syndicate and the meat-packing  company as well. Things get ever darker and more complex, and Kevin learns that Mr. Balducci was the brains behind his father's murder. After that it's war--Kevin sets himself the unlikely goal of taking down Balducci and his organization.Well, how does a loser who can barely hold on to a job fight a powerful crime boss? Can he do it? And can he win back the only girl he ever loved, the mythical goddess, C.W.? Does he succeed? Does he survive? Does he get the girl? Will he make it through school? Will he go to prison? And who is really the genius behind this world of crime? Naturally I won't tell you, so you'll have to read this book yourself.Author Ben Lieberman writes in a hectic, breathless style, which will keep you frantically turning pages. If the book starts out with a somewhat believable premise, it soon takes a turn into sheer escapist fantasy. It couldn't happen this way, but somehow author Lieberman keeps his readers engaged, and half-believing. The characters do the impossible, the illegal, the unforgivable, and the felonious, but still keep fighting, joking around, talking trash, getting wounded or killed, and drinking themselves silly. So, that's the kind of book it is, and, if you like that kind of reading you will love "Odd Jobs." It ain't great literature, but it's great fun to read. I recommend it highly. Reviewed by Louis N. Gruber.

This is a fine tuner; easy operation, good construction and functional design, making it easy to position. I found it to be about as accurate as the other electronic tuners I own. The ability to adjust the frequency is a nice bonus.The only reasons I don't give it five stars are because I feel like it's larger than it needs to be, and I don't care for its appearance or the graphic style of the readout. It's also priced a bit higher than other comparable tuners.

The Adonit Jot line is probably the best line of Styli for touchscreen devices that aren't Wacom-powered or comparable.The difference is that devices like the Wacom line or, say, the Surface line are specifically designed to replicate a pen-and-paper experience, whereas an iPad or Android device is designed with human fingers in mind, and is thus not responsive enough to register input from something as small as a pen tip. Such responsiveness would require those devices to be bigger and more expensive.The Jot concept is the most effective workaround to at least get the experience CLOSER to pen-and-paper. The concept works for two reasons:- because the disc is attached to the stylus via a joint, it is less sensitive to small movements- because the disc is transparent, the user has the subtle experience of writing on the device with a pen tip, which influences user perception, such that he/she intuitively 'feels' like he/she is writing with a penIt works viscerally and is quite effective, and the size of the Jot Mini is ideal; it's less unwieldy than most styli,  but it still feels like a pen in use.These cost a bit more than other styli, but their increased effectiveness justifies this.

I snagged this for my nephew, because I had a stuffed Peter Rabbit toy when I was small and I loved it.The style and details are on-point here, as is the craftsmanship, but I wouldn't expect any less from Gund, whose toys I grew up with. No hard parts on the eyes or buttons, either, so it's all soft.Perfect for small kids who love Peter Rabbit or who just love lovable stuffed animals.

I'm not one to get particularly excited by something like a new vacuum cleaner, but as a tech junkie, I AM inclined to be excited by new tech of any kind, so the Air Cordless Lift has held my fervor far longer than a vacuum cleaner probably should. Its design is fantastic, its ease-of-use is off the charts, its features are top-shelf, and most importantly, it does its job well.Unboxing and setup are a snap and usage/maintenance instructions are covered entirely in about three short manual pages; it's designed so intuitively and simply that all you need to do is charge up the battery and start vacuuming.It has a slim, minimal profile and only weighs about 12 pounds, and along with functional accents like the swiveling head, the design makes vacuuming nearly effortless. Even better, the canister assembly detaches for hand-held spot-work and increased portability and accessibility (it comes with a few attachments for corners and upholstery with other specialized attachments available separately), and the slim/light profile maximizes this functionality. Other design accents, like a floodlight on the base of the canister that illuminates the area being cleaned (and that serves as a sort of spotlight in handheld mode), are well-implemented and reinforce the sense that effective simplicity was the watchword at every juncture of design.Maintenance is equally simple and intuitive: emptying the canister takes a few seconds, and the only other upkeep required is the occasional cleaning of a small filter, which is done in a few seconds under a tap.Most importantly, it cleans quickly and effectively on carpets, upholstery, and hard floors, and the profile makes it easy to address all three applications with their assorted trappings (corners, crevices, etc.). Features like the extension arm and the spin-brush toggle (for work on finished/delicate hard floors) make this a true all-in-one vacuuming solution.The whole package comes together really well, and it illustrates how much a well-designed implement can elevate a chore like vacuuming from a big hassle to a minor task. Having the right tools makes all the difference.Supremely recommended.

I've owned several nosehair trimmers, all of which conform to the 'standard' cylindrical trimmer design. One was cheap and broke, one worked okay until the blade dulled (it wasn't replaceable), and one works pretty well, but it takes a few minutes to operate and clean and I don't like the associated hair 'pulling.'The NT3355/60 is a welcome change. The design is brilliant- effective but faster, and without the 'pulling'. It's also easier to maintain and clean. The eyebrow brushes make it effective for precision brow-trimming, too, which isn't/wasn't possible with my other trimmers.My only concern is that I'll have to replace the entire blade assembly whenever it loses sharpness/effectiveness, but this will be a small price to pay for the ease, speed, and comfort I enjoy every time I use it. Highly recommended.

Cellusculpt is an effective moisturizer, but my experience didn't yield any other effects- no detectable toning or tightening. As such, I can't defend its high price- especially since I think it's predicated largely on the roller-ball application mechanism, which isn't really necessary for application (rubbing the lotion in manually works equally well).As I said, it DOES moisturize well, but equally effective moisturizer products can be purchased for much less. Your results may vary, but I didn't see any tightening or toning effects.

Supplements are a bit of a gamble, in that there's no guarantee of the intended effects manifesting themselves. I got the 5-HTP to help me sleep better (and possibly get an energy boost during the way), but after running nearly the full bottle as directed, I've noticed no changes.Your results may vary, but if you're typically highly-tolerant to supplements, this may not do much for you.

This is a great option for a box-less platform frame because it's very reasonably priced considering its sturdiness. It's also lightweight and mobile without compromising that sturdiness.Assembly was pretty straightforward. My only issue was with the four outer plastic corners, which buttress the outer frame during assembly; they need to be placed just right in order for everything to align properly, and getting them to do this was a bit tricky. Also, I found the included tools (a non-adjustable wrench and an allen wrench) less effective than my own.Once assembled, though, the bedframe is great- sturdy yet easy to move, as I said. It fits a queen mattress perfectly and provides a nice bit of storage space underneath.

I don't have an issue with acne as a recurrent condition, but my face started to break out when I began using probiotics (apparently, a semi-common temporary issue) and I got this to minimize/treat the breakouts.It really worked well, drying up the breakouts without drying my skin out, and my face looks generally clearer and healthier after using it. Application is simple, and as a bonus, I greatly enjoy the sandalwood fragrance.I can't speak to its performance against persistent conditional acne, but as a general solution against breakouts or for clearer skin, I recommend it heartily.

The water in my area tends to be a bit hard and carry a bit of that tap-water 'flavor'. I typically buy bottled, but figured I'd give filtering a try in the interest of convenience.I'm very pleased with the Aqua Optima pitcher, both in terms of ease-of-use and performance. The water is clear and flavorless and I can't tell a difference between it and bottled. In addition to being easier to filter than to haul bottles around, it's also very cost-effective, with each filter only costing me about $14 and lasting about a month (I use about four liters of water per day).I'm very happy both with the pitcher and with the filtering performance and will continue to use this instead of buying bottled.(Other reviews have made mention of some incongruity between Aqua Optima's anti-bacterial claims and recognized standards for anti-bacterial filtering, but I can't speak to that issue, so if you're concerned about it, please consult those reviews.)

The Aether Cone is a difficult product for me to review. As a music junkie and a pseudo-audiophile, I'm very particular about how I listen to my music, in terms of playback, organization, and accessibility, and the cone is very different from what I'm used to.I feel it's best to evaluate it through two criteria:- how well it does what Aether claims it does- how well it stacks up to more standard music access/playback optionsAether calls Cone a 'thinking music player' that plays whatever you tell it to and gradually learns to 'know' what kinds of music to play based on your listening patterns. Because it's intended to function as an 'A.I. DJ companion' (my phrasing), it's not necessary to do anything other than tell it what to play and use three simple controls (a 'listen' button, which stops whatever's playing and prompts Cone to listen for your next request, a 'short turn' of the front of the device, which skips to the next song, and a 'long turn', which tells Cone to randomly choose something altogether different from what was just playing).It's an interesting design, and it's pretty nice when it works, but it doesn't always work well. In the first place, although Cone has pretty robust voice-recognition ability, it's far from perfect, and many's the time I had to request something numerous times before it understood. Additionally, though Cone (powered by the Rdio streaming music service) has an impressive array of music at its employ, it doesn't have everything. Additionally, you'll find some issues with, say, different renditions of a work (this pertains to concert music and some jazz), as well as the occasional mix-up with a live or alternate recording of something. None of this is to say that it's a bad experience: indeed, I'd estimate that 85% of the time, it worked just fine, and it's neat to be able to cue up a song just by saying what I want to hear.In terms of it 'learning' what I like, this was hit-or-miss. I was occasionally mystified/amused by what it thought I wanted to hear, but I was also impressed occasionally by how well it was able to predict music it thought I'd enjoy; there were a couple of instances where it guessed right on some fairly obscure music.In consideration of my first criteria, then, I'll say that Cone performs as-advertised pretty well- an A-minus.Will it replace my standard music-listening tools, then? Not by a long shot. Cloud-streaming media technology certainly has its place, but it can't touch either physical media or local storage for quick-access that doesn't rely on network connections. Not only that, but I don't have access to any sort of transport controls (fast-forward, rewind, repeat, etc.) or any sort of playlist tools.Perhaps the biggest drawback for me is that if I want to hear what Cone's playing, I have to hear it on Cone. I can't kick the signal to my home-theater speakers or my studio monitors, or even to a set of headphones. While the Cone speaker sounds very nice and has a very nice maximum volume without a lot of distortion, it just isn't in the same league as any of the permanent playback setups in my house. In Aether's defense, Cone wasn't intended to replace these things, so I can't deduct anything from my final evaluation, but I think it's worth noting for prospective buyers.Who is Cone ideal for? It's ideal for someone who:- doesn't own a large music collection but wants access to one- needs a music playback solution that's easy to move or transport- doesn't have a lot of space for speakers, monitors, amps or receivers- values ease-of-use over control and customizationIf you fit one or more of these descriptors, it's worth considering. I DO feel the price is perhaps prohibitive for some, and it bears repeating that you WILL need wireless internet access to use it, as well as a computer to set it up for the first time. Rdio has a free option that includes some advertising and limited song-skipping, and an unlimited subscription is $10 monthly, which is quite reasonable.In summary, Cone is an intriguing concept that's carried out pretty well, but it's also something of a niche solution, and given the price, prospective buyers will want to consider its benefits against other options.

Over the last 15 years or so, there's been a natural and anticipated shift in the agressive-athiesm/antitheism (hereafter 'AAA'... ha ha) movement away from demonstrating religion's many shortcomings, toward instead trying to justify the validity and value of concepts like moral absolutes and the good/evil dichotomy in ethical terms without having to resort to the values-systems that function as part of religious worldviews."The Moral Arc" is the latest work by a 'big name' AAA writer to assert not only that the shifts toward rationalism and empiricism have actually aided human morality, but that they are sufficient to sustain and improve it, even as the traditional moral guides of religion and philosophy continue to erode.As someone firmly in the theist/deist camp, I'm convinced neither by the premise nor by Shermer's articulation of it (though I acknowledge that my viewpoint colors my skepticism, just as Shermer's atheistic viewpoint colors his evaluation of the validity of religion's truth-claims). However, I appreciate that he isn't nearly so militant or antagonistic toward the institution as some of his peers are in their work, and there are two aspects of his presentation that demand serious consideration and reflection, even/especially by theists:- he demonstrates that humanity's most influential moral codes all contain the same strains of fairness and justice- the implication being that notions of, and desires for, justice and fairness are intrinsically human, rather than being simply extrinsic standards learned from custom or culture (though to my way of thinking, this begs the question about where those intrinsic notions come from in the first place)- he reminds that religion, like any other human convention, is bound to its origins and milieus- pointing out how often atrocities and injustices (in retrospect, clearly functions of what those cultures and milieus demanded or preferred) have been justified in the name of their corresponding religious/cultural componentIf I had to single out one aspect of Shermer's position that I find most untenable, it's the insistence that the ways in which the world is getting better owe their emergence to the evolution of humanistic trends in thought. While it's beyond the scope of a summary book review to really unpack this position, it should suffice for me to say that some of the parallels he draws for these two developments are tenuous, in my opinion.Shermer frequently oversimplifies and presents his perspectives on nuanced issues as though they were factual or complete, but this isn't a major grievance; he doesn't misrepresent himself as someone coming at the subject objectively. Nevertheless, how compelling you feel his presentation is will likely be a function of your position on the subject going in. I think it will do what most works in this vein do: it'll bolster the like-minded, but it won't convert many from the other side.Having said all that, it's well-written and pretty easy to read, though it drags a bit in a few places and could have been shorter without losing its impact. He's a good writer, though, and the subject matter is engaging for people on both sides of the issue, so I'll give it four stars as a reading/ thinking experience, and three stars for the central premise, of which I am no more convinced than I was when I began (I'm sure Mr. Shermer will be distraught when he finds out).

The health benefits of chia seeds are well-known, and NutriGold makes first-rate products- I've used their oils for a couple of years, with great results. Needless to say, then, I'm very satisfied with NutriGold's seeds.They're organic, which is a major selling point for me. The packaging is fine, and it comes with a scoop measuring two tablespoons.I enjoy eating the seeds straight, though sometimes I garnish salads with them instead. They have a mild, nutty taste and a nice texture.NutriGold's price is a bit higher than that of other brands, and that's the only reason I'm not giving these five stars. For my money, though, their being organic and coming from a reputable brand justifies the extra cost.FULL DISCLOSURE: I was provided with a complimentary container of the item for review purposes

I used this after suffering a few mild isolated breakouts, and though it smells great and feels clean, it didn't really do anything to clear up the breakouts.Results tend to vary with products like these, so my recommendation is to canvas the available reviews and determine how probable it is that it might work for you, but for me, it wasn't terribly effective on breakouts.

The StriVectin facial toner is graced with a simple design and easy-to-use interface. It's pretty evident, both sensationally and visually, that the targeted facial muscles are being stimulated.We haven't used it long enough to determine if it produces the intended noticeable facial toning, as the manufacturer-specified usage period for results is 12 weeks, so I'll update this review after that amount of time has elapsed. However, build, design, and functionality are all very good.

To be candid, I haven't owned or regularly used a toaster in about twenty years, so I have little knowledge about what modern toaster technology has to offer. Having said that, I'm greatly enjoying using this one.It's a sturdy design with a nice-looking, soft-industrial aesthetic. Control is digital, which is very cool to a guy coming from toasters with the old 'dark/light' sliders. Once I know what settings work for the things I toast, I never have to guess again.I actually bought this primarily for bagels, so the 'bagel' specialty function, predictably, is quite welcome, as is the 'defrost' function (I buy my bagels by the dozen from local delis and freeze them). Auto-shutoff prevents burning in case of jams (which does occasionally happen with non-uniform-size items like real deli bagels).In summary, it's a great modern toaster that's easy to use and well-performing, with bagel-lover-centric features that add value.

I'm comparing this product to Omega-3 Fish Oil - NutriGold Triple Strength Omega-3 Gold, 180 Softgels - 1000 mg EPA + DHA with 85% Omega-3s in 1,250 mg Liquid Capsules, Molecularly Distilled Fatty Acids, Pharmaceutical Grade Pills That Are NOT Enteric Coated for Best Absorption But ... and Controlled Labs Orange Oximega Fish Oil, Citrus Flavor, 120 SoftGels, which have been my go-to brands.The big sell here is the size of the pill, and it does indeed come in a bit smaller, but it's also a little fatter than more other omega-3 pills I've seen. Still, it goes down easily and doesn't have any detectable odor. I get a little of the fish aftertaste, but I've never used a fish oil supplement with which I DIDN'T experience that, even among products that are designed not to taste or that others report being aftertaste-free, so I think I'm just unusually sensitive to it.The important thing here is the nutrition profile, and Nature's Bounty nails it. Per-pill, this product contains slightly more fish oil than either of the two aforementioned competitors, and the price per-mg is slightly lower.There are some who will talk about varying qualities of fish oil and promote a certain brand or product thusly, but I don't know enough about that issue to comment. My only concern is the amount of fish oil/omega-3s in the products I use, and the Nature's Bounty product is a great value in this regard.

To my way of thinking, the measure of a great stroller is its ease of breakdown/setup, and the InVenture Pro is aces in this regard. I'll admit to not having a great deal of stroller familiarity, but in my limited experience, I've not used a stroller that has a better combination of light weight, easy breakdown, and value-adding features.Assembly is pretty easy- relatively quick, with no special tools needed. The build seems good and sturdy and, as noted, is lightweight.The seat is reversible, so the kiddo can face either way. The stroller is designed for one of the manufacturer's carseats to fit into the frame, but it's sold separately (I didn't feel the Amazon page communicated this clearly enough, so potential buyers need to understand that the included seat won't function as a carseat).The baby isn't here yet, so I can't give you his opinion, but all the design cues for an easy-to-use, functional stroller are present.My only critique is the price, which is a slight bit higher than other, ostensibly comparable, strollers. However, if one is inclined to purchase the sold-separately carseat, that totally justifies the price of each item, in my opinion.

I grabbed this for my nephew to play with. When I was his age (about three years), the two things I loved most were deep, bright, bold colors and building things out of blocks, Legos, Lincoln Logs, etc... so this building set caught my eye right away, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy playing with it also, probably more than an adult should.The tiles are very attractive and eye-catching, with a little more pop in the colors than the pictures capture. The magnets work great and are balanced nicely between fairly strong adhesion and easy separation.Especially for smaller kids, the emphasis will be on two-dimensional building, but the three-dimensional building potential is pretty robust here, for when their creativity begins to expand a bit. For that reason, the applicability is scalable and they'll offer several years of interest as the kids grow.The only reason I'm deducting a star is due to the price- although it's a high-quality building set, it IS a little steep. It's a fantastic toy for stirring creativity, though, and is highly recommended.

This is a very nice calcium supplement. The dosage is twice the daily recommendation, which is ideal for people whose nutritional needs surpass those daily guidelines (almost everyone, in my opinion) and for people who have other needs related to calcium deficiency. The stack includes other ingredients to help with absorption, and it didn't give me any stomach issues, which other calcium supplements have.Some have complained that the pills are large, but I suppose this depends on the person; in my opinion, they're fine. They're gelcaps, which makes them easy to swallow.Given the price, this is an excellent value, as it's an all-in-one calcium stack. Highly recommended!

I've not noticed a lot of difference among the different carpet-cleaning products I've used, so this one gets standard marks because it works as well as any of them. It's the first time I've used the BISSELL brand in my carpet cleaner, and the price is a bit higher than the bran I normally buy (Hoover) for what appears to be the same level of cleaning performance. However, the smell is really terrific- it's called 'spring and renewal', and though I don't know what either of those things actually smells like (haha), I CAN tell you that this stuff smells great... floral, 'perfume-y', but very understated.I can't comment yet on the prolonged stain-fighting performance of the Scotchgard Protector, but if it works at all, that'll bump this to a five-star product, in my opinion. As it stands, the fabulous smell justifies the higher price.

Whitening toothpastes have never done much for me; I don't have super-white teeth, just average, but I've never noticed a huge change in using them. Rembrandt is about the most effective one I've tried.Unfortunately, this toothpaste continues that trend, so if you're looking at it because you need the whitening effects, read as many reviews as you can, since everyone's experience differs. For me, there wasn't a noticeable effect. Nevertheless, I don't expect too much from toothpaste at this price point, and the flavor was very nice- enough that I'll probably buy this again because of it. Minty and sweet, but not overpowering or harsh.

'Evolution Revolution' is basically a positive primer to the concept of complexity theory as it applies to biological evolution, with built-in responses to some of the points where it disagrees with or challenges alternate theories.Complexity theory is that theory that life has an intrinsic tendency to become more complex over time. Author Alan Bennett maintains that this is a better explanation than natural selection for how certain complex mechanisms in nature have come to be.His arguments and case studies are compelling at points, and he does an effective job of vetting them with input from notables in various fields. The book reads well and is laid-out in such a way as to keep the reader interested in seeing what comes next.In terms of the book's thrust, there is a mildly evangelical tone to it, in the sense that Bennett seems very much awestruck by complexity theory and wants you to be, also. Fair enough- one wants an enthusiastic presentation when one is being presented with a potentially profound new idea. Just understand that the presentation ends up being a little one-sided. In other words, don't go into 'Evolution Revolution' expecting it to settle all the relevant issues. For what it is, though- an intro and selective application of complexity theory-, it's well done.FULL DISCLOSURE: I was provided with a copy of the book to write an uncompensated review.

This food chopper is simple to operate and clean, seems to be sturdily-built, and most importantly, works well for cutting things like peppers, onions, squash, and carrots- basically, any fruit or vegetable that has a little firmness to it.I was initially concerned about having to reduce the size of what I chopped before chopping it, but as long as it fits on the square chopping space (a little under 3" square), this will chop it.As a bonus: though the manufacturer seems to intend this for fruits and vegetables along the lines of the ones I mentioned, it's GREAT for quickly chopping potatoes for french fries. I halved russets and chopped each half, and it worked flawlessly. Using the broadest of the three surfaces yielded fries that were the PERFECT thickness for my taste.

The pendant on this necklace is very sparkly- a function of the stone layout and how the many tiny stones grab the light. Resultantly, there's a lot of light 'motion' on the surface of the stones when the necklace is in bright light. It's attractive and makes the piece stand out in a pleasing way. The diamonds are matched well and have good clarity. They watch the setting and metal very nicely.The necklace seems to be well-made and is pretty lightweight, given the size.
