My only potential criticism is that the pendant isn't removable from the chain, so potential buyers just need to determine if the chain style and/or length is to their liking before purchasing.

These earrings are attractive without being excessively eye-catching; subtle. The diamonds seem to be of good quality- white, even clarity, and they and the metal complement each other. The blue tanzanite stones also complement their setting nicely and have an even, subdued complexion. The color scheme creates a nice gentle gradient going from the center of the stones to the edges.My only criticism of these earrings is that the leverback mechanism seems to be a little longer than it needs to be, which creates maybe a longer 'hang'- a little more distance between the ear and the stone setting than necessary, but this will be a function of preference.

Despite being a ubiquitous element of much of modern music, sound synthesis remains a quantity unknown to most people. The littleBits kit is a perfect entree into that world for ANYONE who's interested.Audio synthesis is the art and science of taking raw electronic signals and manipulating them to create different kinds of sounds. The littleBits kit breaks the essential components of a synthesizer out into discrete 'bits', allowing dabblers to understand how each component factors into the finished aural product.Though this seems to be designed with a younger audience in mind (it'll make a great school project or something along those lines), the kit and the literature it comes with will be useful for ANYONE who wants to learn the basic concepts. As a bonus, it's actually a fairly versatile synth for the price, so adventurous musicians and producers may find they can create some useful sounds with it.There's really no precedent for this, so my five-star rating is predicated on two factors: the educational value and the practical value for musicians.

I'm on a long cut and normally allot myself a cheat day once a week or so, to cure the insatiable appetite I have for all things unhealthy. However, since discovering Quest bars, I've not cheated once, and I haven't missed it at all.I've tried a number of the flavors and almost all of them are outstanding, but the chocolate chip cookie dough is truly unreal. it is so delicious and decadent and satisfying that I honestly would rather eat it than almost any of the treats I'd normally cheat with.The nutrition profile is on-point, too... no junk in this thing. There's a tiny bit of sucralose (less than 2%), but I'm not tracking that stuff too hard, so that's not an issue for me. The bottom line is that this is, far and away, the best protein bar I've ever had, and if you told me it was just a regular junk-food snack, I wouldn't doubt it at all.An absolute must-try for health-conscious people who fight junk-food cravings like I do.  A million stars.

This is a cool playset that encourages the culinary instincts of the little ones. I can't speak for anyone else, but I used to 'cook' 'food' with Play-Doh all the time, so to my way of thinking, making a playset that cultivates this scenario makes sense.The only thing I lament is that we could have used more colors; perhaps a few more cans of Play-Doh should be thrown in. Small gripe, though...the stuff is cheap and readily available. Great toy!

As a kid, I always dug the Play-Doh, and as an adult, I always dig the sweets, so this was a natural fit- maybe I even got it for myself more than for the kids. Haha.Anyhow, I got it for my nephews and niece, and they're digging it (it's hard to keep them focused on anything for long- haha). For what it's worth, you don't get to MAKE a giant cake here; instead, you get to DECORATE a giant cake and make SMALLER Play-Doh cakes. I doubt the three-year-old target audience will nitpick over the difference. It's colorful and they get to play with Play-Doh. That's pretty much all I need to keep them happy.For the record, their uncle also enjoyed playing with it quite a bit.

Just got this kit today and I love it!  I've had separate tools before, and lost them, so really needed a new set.  The scraper closest to the mirror wasn't useful as I don't have anything to scrape...but it would be good for people/pets who have a build-up across the teeth.  The tool to the left of the scraper...I LOVE it!  It's a bit coarse, on the sides of the tip, and it helps to scrape fine gunk from under the gum-line.  I did it all by feel and after a few hours, while on the computer, it feels like I've just left the dentist. The far-left tool is thin and sharp tipped, good for getting in-between crowded teeth and picking off what is hidden in nooks and crannies.  I have braces and hate to floss so this is a life-saver.  I also have a water-pick but these tools do a much better job at deep cleaning.  Glad I bought these.

We've never used any product like this before. Told 'the stinker' to use 2-3 drops, please.  It's hard to tell if it's working, I think it is as the combustible cloud doesn't hit as hard...and we really don't notice the invisible weapon hitting us like it used to with a blast to our senses.  When this runs out we may try something else.  Works better than just the bathroom spray afterwards that only adds a sick flower edge to the sonic boom cloud.  It's ok for now.  Leaves a pine scent.

I've worn only Birks for the past couple of decades. I wear Birks, Papillo, and Betula, cheap to expensive.  These are cheap. Flimsy, very flexible sole, all plastic/rubber man-made.  Feet don't breath in these and start to sweat the minute I put them on, even under the top strap. My foot angles kind of strange in this foot-bed; toes leaning towards the sides of the shoes instead of being held towards the front...hard to explain. It's like the foot-bed near the toes are angled inward so my toes angle sidewards. Not very comfortable for Birkis since my feet are accustomed to wearing anew pair right out of the box with comfort...not so with this pair. I'll try walking in them to hopefully have them adjust to my foot shape.  The good thing about these is you can wear them at the beach, in water, mud, what-ever and rinse them off. Good throw on shoes for when you don't care about wrecking them.ETA: Sent this pair back and ordered one size larger (which I never had to do in all the Birks I've bought).  This larger size still has a some-what funky fit, a tad too long, but at least I can wear them around the house or going out in rain or mud.  I wish we still had a Birkenstock Outlet close enough to drive to...this one closed and the others are many hours away.I'll post again after the break-in period and hopefully they will turn out to be a good shoe.

I didn't receive this for free or a discounted price like some reviews.  I am a consumer looking for a good pair of nail clippers. I am disappointed in these.  First off, it is a very weak cut, the mechanics of these cutters don't pack strength behind the cut whether cutting straight-on or turning them at a different cutting angle. Second, the cut isn't a clean cut; maybe the blades aren't sharp.  Seems to take a lot of effort to cut through a thin nail and then doesn't leave the cut clean...needs to have a nail file clean it up.  Not happy with these but I'll keep them in case I lose my cheapy Walgreen's ones again.

I bought the bulk Orange and the bulk Lime.  I love the Lime in my pho as well as my water.  The orange has a fresher, less tart taste than the lime or lemon (obviously).I was told by my doc to drink a ton of water...I hate drinking anything.  He wants me to drink Lemon or Lime water...lots.  I am tired of slicing lemons and limes (and oranges to give it a sweeter flavor) so I started using the plastic squeeze bottle of lemon juice.  I use 3/4 oz of lemon juice to 16 oz of water.  Tart.  I try to drink water without anything and I gag now.  So I need my citrus.Enter in these packets...so easy.  3 packets to 16oz gives me the ratio I need. I will continue to buy these so I can have my citrus water anywhere I go.***Here is the breakdown for recipes or conversions:One (1) packet of True Lemon equals the taste of 1 large lemon wedge and 2 packets of True Lemon is the equivalent of 1 tablespoon lemon juice. This is the same equivalency for True Lime and True Orange.A medium lemon has approximately 2 to 3 tablespoons of juice which equates to 4 to 6 True Lemon packets.A medium or average lime has approximately 2 tablespoons of juice which equals 4 packets of True Lime.

Tried my first pack today.  If you add the whole chili packet it is hot.  Hard to find noodles that are rice that are also spicy.  My lips and throat are burning.  Feels like I ate some good Thai soup.Add your own veggies and/or meat to this.  I only found a few green specks in the broth.  Poured boiling water over the spice and noodle packet, covered with a lid, ready in a few minutes.  I use this noodle bowl: Sistema Microwave Noodle Bowl 940 ml, 32 oz.

This is delicious.  Not much chili to it but plenty sweet.  I put it on fried chicken and it went perfectly.  It also mixed in with some fried cabbage, tasted great...and mixed with some rice, yum!  Can't go wrong what-ever you put this on.

Really nice scent.  Light and airy.  This is almost the only powder I use, except for White Shoulders scented powder on special occasions.  I haven't had any bad Shower to Shower scent, I like them all.  Smaller sized container vs the 13 oz - didn't notice until it arrived.  Seems Shower to Shower keeps going up in price.

Best tasting tomatoes for the price.  Not a pure San Marzano tomato grown in San Marzarno, Italy but the same tomato grown in a different area.  Good taste without the high price.For pasta sauce, quickly fry a bit of zucchini, onions, garlic in olive oil.  Add a can of these tomatoes and chop/smash coarsely with a wooden spoon.  Cook for about 5 minutes or until your pasta is done (al dente) and add the drained pasta into this sauce, mix a couple of minutes and serve with freshly grated romano cheese.  Instant meal.

These work great for the Dixie paper plates 10-1/2 inch size.  A bit of overhang of your plate edge (not much) but they add extra strength to your plate.  Glad I picked them up, we use them every time we use paper plates.
Love these bowls for oatmeal.  2 packs of instant oatmeal fit in this size bowl, easily.  Eat and throw away. Breakfast doesn't get easier than that.
I love this scent.  I like it much better than frankincense even though it does have a hint of frankincense to it...this could easily replace it.  More cost efficient, too.
Beautiful Crucifix. Looks much more expensive than it actually is.  Looks substantial on the wall of the bedroom next to the door. A reverent  reminder every time I look at it.
I  love this.  These are the HARD nougats so don't expect soft torrone like others...this is very crunchy and teeth breaking hard. Delicious.
Very Nice.  Beeswax has a lovely scent. Even comes with the glass holder which I was surprised.  Very nice quality.  Came well packaged without blemish.

Tastes great!  Very crunchy, slightly sweet. Rolls hold together well.  I like this flavor even though it's very mild.  Like these so much better than regular rice cakes - they are not even in the same playing field...these are higher quality.

Elegant!  Bought these for Bento Boxes to hold wetter items.  They are greaseproof so oils and moisture won't leak through the paper.  Greaseproof also means when you bake in them the pattern won't get discolored.

I didn't realize this bento was so tiny.  It would be great for a pre-schooler or young child.  I don't have a measuring cup with markers to tell you how much this holds.  My guess is the bottom will hold 2 scrambled eggs and the top is probably twice the size.  I can see using this for breakfast or snacks and using another bento for your main meal.Fits together nicely, has its own bento band to hold it together. This has 3 lids total - 1 for each tier and a final top to close everything.  You can fit a small, flat utensil or napkin under the top lid.  This is the smallest bento I own, by far.ETA: I just found the size written: Bottom tier is a tiny bit over 1/2 cup and the top tier is a tiny bit under 1 cup.  So a total of 1-1/2 cups for both tiers.

This has a stainless steel bottom, single tray.  Love the ease and cleaning of it.  No stains. On the medium side for a bento at 700 mil. (this means it can hold about 700 calories (packed full).Love the clean lines.  The bento fits well into the zippered jacket.  The rectangular design makes a pretty presentation, all foods easy to see and only one tray to clean (vs a double tier).  I like the larger, single tiered bentos best - easy cleaning and packing.When packing for a day out this is the one I use for a man and I use smaller ones for me.  Packed correctly, a bento can hold a lot of food. Look up YouTube videos on packing Bento.You get the bento band to hold the lid closed and plastic chopsticks but I use a plastic fork instead, it fits under the top lid.

Felt ill a few days ago...tummy not feeling right.  Took a packet of this for the first time.  Slight hint of flavor - kind of citrusy, lots of small bubbles.  Drank it and rested a bit.  This did the trick, cleaned out my insides, felt so much better afterwards.I like the taste of Alka-Seltzer Gold better and the number 1 antacid I like is Brioschi but can't find it for a decent price anymore.I like that this doesn't have aspirin, easy to carry, dissolves quickly and not a bad taste.  Would use again.

Bought 2 of these, one yellow and one orange.  So far the yellow screws on well and no leaks.  Easy to put the fruit basket in and close the lid.  Making cherry/lemon water for my first time.  Holds a good amount of fruit vs water.  I think I'll eat the fruit when I've drank the water.  Love the cherry color against the yellow.  Orange is for my lemon/lime water.  Want to try cucumber with the lemon/lime combo also.  Never made fruit waters so this is new to me.  Cut the cherries in half so more fruit hits the water. On my list is cantaloupe, watermelon, cucumber, peaches, will be keeping my eyes open for new fruits.I would purchase these again.  Easy to use, easy to clean.  My docs are getting on me to drink more water (kidney stones at a young age/female) so until they find out what is causing them, I'm to drink tons of water every day but I'm not a fluid kind of person.  My guess is dehydration is the cause. We'll see.  I hope this will get my fluid intake up.If these hold up, without leaking, don't discolor, etc...I'll raise my stars to 5.

Love this for tummy upsets.  No Aspirin!  This is the closest to Brioschi that I have found (cheaper price).For a mild tummy upset I'll eat Peppermint Pillow Candy, or drink Tonic Water or Peppermint Tea. For stronger upsets, I use this Alka-Seltzer.

Most Chocolate/Cocoa mixes have sugar as the first ingredient.  This one is 'sweet ground chocolate' and 'cocoa'.Mixes quickly in the hot chocolate machine that I love: Mr. Coffee BVMC-HC5 Cafe Cocoa Hot Chocolate Maker, Black.I usually add a few chunks of a bitter chocolate bar to my hot chocolates.I'm the only one drinking this (don't judge :)) so it should last a while.
I received 4 bottles of Nori KOMI Furikake...not Fumi that is shown here.It tastes like Nori...fresh, then a bit of sweetness/saltiness, then sesame flavor.  Over-all, tastes good.

This is one of my smaller bento boxes I own.  For lunch I had a grilled cheese sandwich with a thin layer of pesto, on gluten-free bread, cut into 4 squares.  The squares were put in the box on their crusts.  There was enough room for a cupcake liner (greaseproof) filled with green olives.  Perfect light lunch.This is a single tier box. Thin plastic.  More of a kid's box, or a light appetite.  Be sure to pack your foods tightly into your bento boxes.  Generally, a 500mil box can hold about 500 calories...not sure if this is even 500mil, could be smaller.  No measuring cup to measure for you, sorry.For travel you would need to secure the lid with a large rubber-band, bento box band or tie a bandana or other fabric around the box to keep it closed.

This is one good looking Bento Box!  The black is a matte finish.  The plastic is heavy duty and seems it will hold-up well.  This would be a perfect choice for a man.  It's a bit heavier than other plastic bento boxes I own, thicker plastic doesn't bend...not a cheap looking plastic.The container with the white plastic lid is smooth inside, its lid is vented so steam can escape.  The slightly bigger container is rough-textured inside, would help keep things from slipping around, I guess.This comes with a black elastic band.I would purchase again for a gift.Haven't used it yet but will report back if I find anything wrong.
One of the best olives I've ever eaten.  Rich, buttery texture, mild flavor, beautiful green, no bruising.  Wonderful Olives.
I wanted straight cutting nail clippers but these are curved...my fault.  The person I bought them for won't use them.Will test it out and see how it holds up.

I bought this for a birthday present - the recipient loves it.  So far we've eaten lots of chicken, pork country ribs, pork shoulder, pork butt, shredded pork and even more chicken.  He hasn't done beef on it yet...or candied salmon jerky.  He cooks, I get to eat...perfect gift. He uses this smoker every chance he gets.  Bought all of the bbq goodies to go with it, and plenty of different woods to try. Best gift I ever bought someone.

I had no idea what to expect or what halva is supposed to taste like, or the consistency of it.This was a dryish powder after spooning some out of the container. I guess the oil from the sesame holds it together.  I love sesame seed so this tasted good to me.  Not too sweet for a candy.  This reminds me of a sweetened dry tahina powder.  Not gritty at all.  The powder melts in your mouth...you can feel a bit of oil on your tongue.I can see sprinkling some on top of ice cream, a sliced apple...maybe banana.  I don't know how else one would use this.

This was a perfect OEM replacement knob for my 2007 Salem Forest River travel trailer window knobs.  This is a low profile knob, so there is ample clearance for the blinds.  The knob comes with the appropriate attachment screw, but I reused the old screw since there was nothing wrong with it.  I am purchasing two more to have on hand as spares in case another one of my old knobs strips out.

I get this monthly via the Amazon Subscribe and Save option.  This is my first month of using the product, but I am satisfied.  It doesn't, as other reviewers claim, leave my face dry or burn.  I find the soap pleasant, but I am not a fan of the scent (think bathroom hand soap).Everyone's skin will react differently, so take this review with a grain of salt.  I will continue using this until I find something I like better.

I am normally a huge fan of Nite Ize products.  They're innovative, they're affordable, and they are outstanding quality.  ...Maybe that's why I was so disappointed by the Hands-Free Flashlight Holder.PROs:Holds a flashlight to your headGreat workmanship/materialsCONs:Not the slightest bit comfortable to have a mini mag light strapped to the side of your head.  Very cumbersome.Elastic band that holds the flashlight is too tight for an acceptable fit on anything but a mini mag diameter flashlightVelcro closure, while secure, tends to shift around.  Elastic would have been a far better option.  I kept struggling trying to keep this thing positioned in one spot on my headDifficult to aim the light and keep it where you want itWith all of the great, affordable LED headlamps out there, I'm still kicking myself for buying this.  I just don't like it.  It is not comfortable, not very functional, and will spend the rest of it's long life (it is durable) as a Velcro strap hanging an extension cord on the wall.

I purchased 10' lengths each of purple, pink, red, blue, and black to replace the shoe laces on my kids' shoes.  I use a double drawstring cinch to tighten and loosen the shoes, and it was worked great.  The bungee has maintained it's color in spite of some series exposure and hard play.  I certainly recommend this to anyone.

I bought these in both pink and purple to use for each of my daughters' shoes.  I replaced their shoelaces with elastic bungee cord, and used the barrel locks to cinch them tight--no more untied shoes!They are 5/8" in diameter and hold the bungee paracord securely.  They are also a great fit for the standard 550 paracord and grip securely.  I am pleased with this purchase and have ordered read and blue to do my sons' shoes, as well.

I tried Meguiar's Carpet and Upholstery cleaner on a whim in order to get out some rust stains inside my truck.  I tried Turtle, Resolve, and Scotchbrite with no luck.  I sprayed the stuff on, let it sit for a few minutes, scrubbed it with a moderately stiff brush, and it looks like new.  Great Product.  I started keeping it handy and made it part of my normal car cleaning routine (I have kids, so there's always carpet to clean).  It has a nice scent to it and doesn't smell like chemicals.I highly recommend.

This was a great find on amazon.Kit Contains:50 X 1/8x2"30 X 5/32x2 1/2"20 X 3/16x3"25 X 1/4x2"15 X 1/4x3"10 X 5/16x2 1/2"I don't think they're stainless, but they've held up just fine on my trailer wheels and since I grease my bearings often, I go through a lot of cotter pins.

These goggles are OK. I bought them for my kids to play military, but they are a bit too big to comfortably fit a six-year-old, although he loves them anyway.These goggles are extremely durable and scratch resistant. They have held up to abuse, the elements, and kids. I tried them on with my old MICH and they aren't very comfortably when worn with the helmet. Still, for the price, they can't be beat.

I purchased a 250' spool of Kelly Green Camo to make a bunch of St Patrick's Day themed paracord bracelets and I couldn't be happier.PROs:-Durable, comparable MILSPEC quality-Spool was perfectly sized for my projects (one continuous spool, not 5X50' pieces as some other reviewers have noted)-Color was great and hasn't faded at allCONs:-At $25, I thought this was a little high.  I would expect to pay $17-20 for a spool like this, but I needed it in a hurry.Shipping was fast and the spool was well packaged.  I highly recommend.

This is a great case.  I purchased mine over two years ago in camo and have been extremely pleased.PROs:-Holds up to 15 Churchills-Durable.  I beat the crap out of this thing on the water and in the woods-Floats and is air/water tight, so your sticks won't get ruined-Crushproof-2 Removable/Replaceable Locking Clasps are high quality-Stainless Steel Hinges-1 Humidifier Disc in Lid, but I prefer throwing in a Boveda pack_Custom Urethane Foam Protects Cigars-Lanyard with clip for easy transportationCons:-Paint has faded a bit, but I have used this outside near daily for more than two years, including two deployments.  Ice fishing to Surf Casting.  I always have this handy filled with sticks at the ready.  I can't recommend this caddy highly enough!!Dimensions (Inside): 7.88" x 3.97" x 3.64"Dimensions (Outside): 8.80" x 5.18" x 4.18"

This was a great fit for my LOWRANCE ELITE 4X (did not fit my LOWRANCE HDS5).-Swivel's in the x-axis to allow for multiple viewing angles-Durable--this thing would probably stop a bullet-Secure tight fit with other Scotty mounting optionsI highly recommend this for anyone needing a versatile mount for their fishfinder.

I may have been lucky, but my net measured pretty close to 13'x5'.  I purchased this to cover a jon boat and to use as a privacy screen for my camper.  I liked the first one so much, I purchased a second one a few weeks later.  After over a year, both nets are going strong.PROs:-Same style of netting that we used in the field-Great cover/concealment-Doesn't degrade when wetCONs:-Definitely NOT MILSPEC quality, but passable for my needs-Pricey.  For what I got, spending $35 each was a bout twice what you should pay for this.Even considering the cons, this is the best netting I found out there without paying for MILSPEC quality.  I'm happy with my purchases and would buy them again.  I would definitely recommend this for all but the most rigorous use.

This is an exact fit replacement of the bearings on my Harbor Freight 600lb boat trailer (Model #5002).  After smoking the old bearings on a long road trip, I purchased these as a spare set.  VXB was such a great company to work with.  I received the bearings quickly and upon initial inspection I could tell they were much higher quality than the replacement Harbor Freight bearings I ordered.After replacing the HF bearings with the VXB I have put over 3000 miles on my boat trailer with no issues and no signs of wear.  Keep your grease fresh, and these things will last forever.  I highly recommend

I purchased a 20 pack of these to use to cinch up some laundry sacks that were previously just tie-shuts.  The Bluecell cord locks are fantasticPROs:-Hold the nylon string securely--spring is quite firm-Durable.  Each cord lock has withstood dozens of washings and dryings and not a single one has broken in the 6 months since I purchased them on amazon-Versatile.  I was also able to use these for paracord projects.  One end of 550 cord will fit easily.  Two ends of 550 cord is an extremely tight fit, but workable-Much cheaper through amazon than at both my local craft stores and home centersCONs:-None to speak of.I highly recommend.

Some carb/choke cleaners are too harsh for cleaning modern coated throttle bodies.  CRC Throttle Body and Air Intake Cleaner is safe for cleaning the throttle body on my 2006 F-150 5.4 Triton.  Cut through some pretty heavy carbon deposits (133k miles and never cleaned by previous owner).  Made cleaning the air intake and throttle body a quick, painless job.  I also used it to clean up some spark plugs on my 2-cycle outboard with great results.  I highly recommend.

This is a great item.  I was going to buy it on amazon, but found it for about $35 cheaper at my local Sears.  The model number is #40789.  My kit included:-Compression gauge (reads up to 200psi) with hose attached-14mm long reach hose-14mm short reach hose-18mm long reach hose-18mm short reach hose-14mm-18mm adapter-10mm adapter-12mm adapter-Pressure Hold Adapter-Field Service Kit (Extra O-rings and stuff)-Instruction Manual and CaseFor the money, this was the best kit out there and it suited my needs.  I used it on a 2006 F-150 5.4L to diagnose a rough idle.  I also used it on a 1967 Mustang to diagnose a leaky valve.  The case is durable and the gauge is easy to ready.  I highly recommend this, but I would save your money and get it directly from Sears.

Purchased several of these Bundle Pack Refills to go with our other Real Construction packs/tools.  My kids (ages 2,4,6,8) love building in Daddy's workshop.  These planks encourage creativity and breed a familiarization with fitting pieces and design.  They have also helped foster in my kids  a love of working with their hands and seeing a project through from visualization to execution and completion.  For the price, we treat these boards like the real thing--measure twice, cut once.  My kids love them.  Great Purchase!

Purchased several of these Large Plank Refills to go with our other Real Construction packs/tools.  My kids (ages 2,4,6,8) love building in Daddy's workshop.  These planks encourage creativity and breed a familiarization with fitting pieces and design.  They have also helped foster in my kids  a love of working with their hands and seeing a project through from visualization to execution and completion.  For the price, we treat these boards like the real thing--measure twice, cut once.  My kids love them.  Great Purchase!

Great Bus Bar.  I used three of these in a recent boat build.  They have held up to mor ethan a year of heavy use and some pretty high current draws.PROs:-Corrosion resistant brass looks as good as the day I installed them-4 1/2" length is perfect for small space applications-Plastic seems to resist heat and doesn't conduct current into the aluminum hull of  the boat-Can be used as two separate bus bars (eg one side positive, one side negative) or as a single bus bar by connecting both sides with a jumper wireCONs:-At over $12 on amazon, I was able to buy my third one for a few dollars cheaper at a local Outdoor chain storeI highly recommend this for your marine electronic install.  Great Quality.

I bought one of these a few months ago and after loosing power it worked flawlessly and I purchased another one.  At only 8 Lumens, it's not the brightest flashlight out there, but it is enough light to help you find your way in the event of an outage.PROs:-Always ready to go and charged up-Doesn't heat up when left plugged in-Night Light feature is great when we have guests in the house and isn't too bright-Can be plugged in with the light facing up or down-Plug folds out of the way when using as a flashlight-Plenty of battery life (mine lasted for over 3 hours)-Put it where you need light during an outageCONs:-Only 8 Lumens, but it is bright enough to help you get the long-term lighting plan in place (candles, lanterns, bigger flashlights)This is a great purchase and I may get a third to keep in the garage.  I highly recommend.

The Easter Bunny brought this for my Son.I have five kids and this book was a gift for my 3-year-old son.  It is a favorite at story time for my three youngest (1.5, 3, 6)The included stickers, trading cards, and poster made this an instant hit!The story is cute and the illustrations are high quality.  I would definitely recommend this for kids up to age 7.  A great gift!

Really happy with the M-Pro 7 Copper Remover Solvent.PROs:Removed some pretty bad copper fouling in a friend's used and abused AR with a light bore scrubbingI started using it as my normal go-to cleaner for some of my older rifles like my Nagant and an older ARCONsMaybe I'm used to Hoppe's #9, but I didn't like the smell of the M-Pro 7.Still, this stuff works great and I keep a bottle handy near my smithing bench.  I highly recommend.

I'm not sure if the ionizer does what it's supposed to do--my car was never all that dusty to begin with, and I generally keep it pretty neat and smell free.  However, it greatly exceeded my expectations as a charger.Charger is 5V Dc, 2AmpIt is the same size as the dual Amazon Basics 2Amp charger I use in my other vehicle (roughly 1 3/8" wide, 1" tall, and 2 3/8" longIt fits my F150 lighter adapter securelyThe blue power light is visible during the day, but is dim and barely noticeable at nightBoth USB sockets can be used simultaneously with no noticeable drop in currentCharger is silent and draws very little current on its ownI have power to my lighter adapter even when the truck is off, so this is always running.  I have left it plugged in for a few weeks and it did not drain my battery when I returned from a trip.  I'm not all-in on the ionic purifier thing, but I figured it couldn't hurt.  I haven't noticed any difference in air quality inside my truck, but I am extremely happy with the charger.  The workmanship is outstanding and the quality of materials is excellent.

Great Sharpener.  The item is shaped like an extra large pencil sharpener.  The item specifies the color is random, but mine was orange.  On the backside of the sharpener blade is a standard vegetable peeler.  The sharpener opening is roughly 1.5", which is largeenough for all but the biggest carrots,PROs:Works great.  The shavings are thin and even.  Perfect for fun or as a garnishSharpBonus peeler attached to underside of sharpenerCONs:Peeler is uncomfortable to use.  Due to the bulkier size of the sharpener versus the ergonomic handle of a dedicated peeler, it was uncomfortable.  Still, not having to dirty an extra dish to make a few peels is a nice touchI would recommend this to a friend.  We are going to give a few out as Christmas presents this year as well.  A great purchase that arrived quickly and well-packaged.

This seemed like exactly what I was looking for and I purchased it in spite of some the negative reviews.  Your experiences may vary, but I was extremely pleased.After reading about the leaking problem, I opened the top and filled scalding hot water completely full.  I left it overnight in my garage stored horizontally on top of some paper to detect any leaks and not a drop of water leaked by the next afternoon.  Undeterred, I emptied it, refilled with hot water, and left stored in the vertical position.  This time I noticed some weepage around the large opening.  I applied, as one review suggested, some Vaseline and no more leaks the next day.  Still I'm going to store in the horizontal (flat) position to be safe.PROs:-No more mess.  After you drain the oil, just put the cover back on and store.  I hated cleaning my old drain pans [the bowl style and the pan-on-top style]-Carry handles are great when this thing is filled-Capacity.  I did a 5qt and 7qt oil change and did not have to take time to empty the drain pan in between-Materials.  Plastic is beefy and well-constructedCONs:-No gasket included.  For piece of mind, a large rubber O-ring or gasket around the large opening would have made many of these 1-star reviews much higher-Size.  I would prefer a larger opening.  The opening is 8", but when you're used to a larger pan, this is small.  With my F-150, I may have to move it as much as a foot when the oil drains just to keep the flow in the center of the opening.-Wheels.  They aren't needed and don't work well.  I honestly wouldn't have listed these as a con, since they are totally unnecessary, but they don't roll well (molded plastic)I would definitely purchase this again.  I would water-leak test yours immediately and return before finding out yours leaks oil.  Shipping was quick.  I highly recommend this Drain pain.

Great tool for removing stubborn hoses.  I used this to remove a lower radiator hose on a Ford 289.  Just place the hook between the hose and the mating surface and shimmy it around until the hose is loose.  Since it's hooked, this tool gives you access a screwdriver or prybar could never provide.  Likewise, it's thin tip slips easily under the hose.  The tool is sturdy and is great to have in the toolbox anytime I flush my cars' cooling systems.  I highly recommend this tool.

I heard a few tracks from this album on XM radio's Real Jazz channel and was blown away.  I purchased the mp3 version from amazon, but this is certainly an album worth owning. This is my first Monty Alexander album, so I am by no means an expert.  A few thoughts on "Uplift 2:"Battle Hymn of the Republic.If you're feet aren't stomping by  the end of this classic, seek medical attention immediately.  This group epitomizes swing.  Monty Alexander's exuberance and joy on this tune remind me of Clark Terry throughout.  The bass and drums do more than keep time, they set a joyful rousing good-time sentiment that will keep you humming all day.  This is my favorite track from the album.You are my SunshineMonty Alexander and the gang offer a great take on a favorite childhood tune.  The interplay between the musicians is top-notch and will have you out of your seat if you're not careful.St ThomasI was surprised by this tune.  Monty Alexander's piano really reminded me of Max Roach's solo on Sonny Rollin's version of St Thomas on the Saxophone Colossus album.  This was great musicianship on display and I keep coming back to this tune.I like the blend of island music with straight ahead swing.  It really works.  There are several gospel style songs.  This really allows Monty Alexander to show off his chord-prowess and command of the keyboard.I would recommend this to any jazz enthusiast.  This would even make a great gift for the non-jazz fan.  How could listening to his version of "Battle Hymn" not make someone happy.

Great tool for removing the rear wiper arm from my 2007 Dodge Grand Caravan.  I also tried using it to remove a stuck battery terminal with success, saving me from needing another tool.  Tool did not mar the wiper arm and arrived quickly.  I highly recommend.I did not use the washer fluid tool, but I am impressed by the quality of materials and the workmanship.

Pretty flimsy as far as vent mounts go and did not support my holder for a Samsung Galaxy S3.  Springs are far too weak for the mount ro maintain steady position in my 2007 Dodge Grand Caravan.  The price is nice, but I'm already looking for a better mount.  I can't recommend this.

The net arrived quickly and was simple to install.  It is longer than the stock net that came with my rim, but the rope used is much thinner.  It has held up well over the winter and hasn't faded or torn from heavy use.The quality isn't what you'd expect from an all-weather net, but I'm pleased with the purchase and would recommend ot to anyone who needs an outdoor net for recreational use.

I had one of these mounted on my kayak Scotty Bait Board for over a year.  I liked it so much that I purchased two additional bait boards and cup holders for use in my jon boat.  These things could probably stop a bullet, and they hold every size drink from a 12 oz can to a Super Big Gulp.  Plus, with scotty mounts there are a ton of mounting options available to get your cup holder in just the right spot.  Buy these and you won't be disappointed.

Completely exceeded my expectations.  I originally purchased one about a year and a half ago for use on my fishing kayak.  I liked it so much that I added one to my jon boat.  They are great for a little extra room.  I like that I can keep my lure, sandwich, drink, or whatever up off the floor and seats.  As for durability, this thing could probably stop a bulletPROS:-Durable-Versatile...with all of the Scotty mounting options out there, you can find a way to put this table on anything-Tool holes and table mounted options like cup holdersCONs:-cost.  You're paying roughly $20 for a piece of plasticStill, this is a great item.  From large craft to small, buy this and you won't be disappointed.

Honestly,  Im not sure how I ended up with this app.  I wanted to watch a video, installed multiple apps like the app store, had to modify app settings on my tablet, and after 15 minutes of installing apps and updates...viola!  I can't watch the movie on my tablet.  Epic waste of time.Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 (purchased on amazon)Insanity Update:  recieved an app notification for an update.  Went to go update in case it fixed my tablet issue, but instead the update informed me that I needed to uninstall the app in order to reinstall and update...pure insanity.Insanity Update 2:  Went through the multi-step install on my Samsung Galaxy S3 phone and after nearly an hour of installing apps and updates, I found out Bosom Buddies isn't even available for rental.  However, I was able to watch an episode from Season 1 of COPS--best $1.99 spent EVER!!Insanity Update 3:  Even on my phone, Amazon wants me to uninstall the Prime Instant Video app in order to install an update.  Probably won't do it, but I am able to watch movies on my phone, but not my tablet...Baby steps.

I purchased the St Louis Cardinals ball last Summer and much like our rival Cubs, it was falling apart by the end of August.  I only used this for catch with my daughter in the backyard a few times before it started falling apart at the seams.  I bought another one as a display item, but it is not meant for even light use.[Edited to include photo]

I was hesitant at first, but after a few months, I am all in.  This was a neat purchase to include in my truck tackle box.  I like the fit and finish of the container.  It's slightly larger than an altoids tin and slides open vice hinged.  I have used it many times over the past few months...more than I expected.The kit includes:-6 regular sized Band Aids 1" x 3",-4 smaller Band Aids-2 small circular Band Aids-1 Knuckle Band Aid-3 Antiseptic Wipes-2 Sting Relief Wipes,-1 2" Safety Pin-1 1" Small Safety Pin-2 doses of Antibiotic Ointments-1 standard square razor blade-The tinI also added a few weights, hooks, a few more band aids, a dose of Vitamin "M" (Motrin for non-Navy folks), a Splinter Out, and a small ferrocium rod and I replace/restock items as necessary out of my home first aid kit.I thought this was a bit expensive for what you get, but I really am pleased with the functionality of the container and the retro look.  I would definitely purchase this again.  While it does not replace my normal First Aid kits, it is a great way to add a few essentials to your tackle box for an outing in the woods or on the water.

I've used these on numerous camping trips and hikes and keep both bottles in my truck just in case.  I do think the PA+Plus helps improve the taste, but not significantly.  I don't mind the iodine taste.  I have found that once I purchased a Lifestraw, I rarely use these tablets any more.  The lifestraw, while bulkier than the two bottles of tablets is quicker, easier, and does not require any container to hold water.  Still, these are a great stand by and I've never gotten sick after using them.  I recommend.

This is a great case.  I've had it for nearly a year now and I am extremely pleased.  The case is lightweight, rugged, and has protected my phone to my satisfaction.I am very hard on my cell phone and it is a regular fixture on my outdoor escapades and this case.  I like that it is easier to remove than my old Otterbox in case I need to remove the battery.  It also is thinner, so I'm able to use a wireless charger.  It has survived drops, falls, and scratching better than cases I've had in the past.  This was a great purchase.

I purchased these to keep in a small glove box tackle box to have on hand whenever the fancy to fish strikes me.  I've owned it for over a year and it finally bit the dust when the pliers snapped.PROS:-Includes:  pliers, cutter, small flat head screwdriver, phillips head screwdriver, large flat head screwdriver, saw, knife, awl, nail file, ruler, bottle opener, scissors-Compact and Lightweight-Knife sharpens easily, but does not hold an edgeCONS:-Pliers are weak and too narrow to be effective for all but the smallest flies and hooks-Phillips head is ineffective.  I thought it would be ok for small reel repairs, but it was not up to the task of screwing/unscrewing any of the Phillips head screws I tried-Saw is too small to really cut anything.  If something is small enough to be cut by the 2" saw, then it is small enough to be sliced with a knife-Scissors were unable to cut braided line even after sharpening due to deflection of the blades/weak metal-No Sheath-Lanyard ring is too thin to trust and item is too flimsy and bulky for a keychain EDC itemAs another reviewer said, I would save your money and purchase a small leatherman or a gerber mini tool instead.  This was too small and poorly made to really be effective.  My recommendation is to skip this purchase and find something better.

We rented this from Amazon for a family movie night.  A huge fan of the other Tinker Bell movies, my daughters eagerly awaited the Legend of the NeverBeast.  They weren't as pleased, though, with NeverBeast as they were with the Fairy's previous installments.The movie seemed slower paced than the previous movies.  A few new characters were introduced, but they didn't really add to the story.  There was no depth and background like in previous movies.  The story does focus more on Fawn, the animal fairy, but similarly ignores most of the other fairies.  Even Tinker Bell plays a minor role--much to the disappointment of my youngest daughter.Still, with five kids ages 1-10, this was a good renter.  If you're out of movie ideas, then this is good filler, but it lacks the charm and fun of the previous movies.

The Easter Bunny brought this for my 6-year-old son.  The kit was delivered quickly and well-packed.The set has 85 pieces and includes:-4 figures--a foreman and 3 workers (2 men and 1 woman)-Awesome front loader (about 3" long) and a building section with toilet, water and pipes-2 cones, jackhammer, sledgehammer and a megaphoneThe front loader rolls and the bucket articulates.  This was a great set.  The sledgehammer and toilet (go figure) are the most popular accessories, but this has overall been a huge hit with my five kids.  I highly recommend this set.

Sort of a twisted, black comedy version of “About a Boy” (with elements of “Bad Santa“ thrown into the mix), “Bad Words” tells of an unlikely relationship between a cynical, child-hating adult and a gregarious  ten-year-old who insists on being his friend.Guy Trilby is a single, hyper-obnoxious 40 year-old elementary school dropout who, much to the consternation of children, parents and contest organizers around the country, has decided to force his way into spelling bees where he competes against - and invariably bests - groups of brainiac youngsters.  Chaitanya Chopra is the relentlessly cheery and upbeat child-whiz who tries to befriend - and defeat - Trilby at the Golden Quill Spelling Bee right there on national television for all the word to see.It’s awfully hard to like Trilby at times, as he smugly sabotages the other players’ chances at taking home the trophy. Yet, Jason Bateman (who also directed the film) manages to make a potentially repellent character both amusing and oddly endearing. Perhaps that’s because Trilby always says what he thinks, cutting through all the BS, skewering social norms and puncturing balloons of political correctness as he goes. What he doesn’t count on is meeting his match in the form of Chaitanya, who ultimately wears the middle-aged man down with his open-hearted honesty and frankness. And young  Rohan Chand matches his older costar moment-for-moment and scene-for-scene.Allison Janney, Kathryn Hahn and Phillip Baker Hall round out the cast.Unsurprisingly, the script by Andrew Dodge does go a bit “soft” at the end, but there was probably no way of avoiding it given the arc this type of story naturally follows. Plus, it provides the context that makes all that comes before it suddenly make sense.You may be put off by the movie at times, but that’s just what makes it so much fun to watch.

Even those with little or no interest in ballet will be moved by "Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq," a documentary about one of the finest dancers ever to grace the stage, one who, like Lou Gehrig, was struck down by a disease of unspeakable awfulness in the prime of her life (though, unlike Gehrig, she managed to live to almost 80 despite her illness).A favorite pupil of famed choreographers George Ballanchine and Jerome Robbins, Tanaquil, or "Tanny" to her friends. stood out from her ballerina contemporaries due to her unusual tallness and angular frame. The film chronicles her rigorous, sheltered youth, her tumultuous marriage to Ballanchine, her phenomenal success on the stage. And, then, just as she was on the top of the world professionally, tragedy - of a particularly cruel nature for a person used to making a living and perfecting her art with her body - befell her in the form of a severe case of polio, a case so severe, in fact, that she was forced to endure time in an iron lung and ultimately to spend the rest of her life in a wheelchair.Through an abundance of stills and kinescope recordings, we get to see a great deal of Tanaquil's work. These are supplemented by interviews with those who knew Tanny both on a professional level and as personal friends. Most poignant are the recitations of the letters Tanny wrote at the height of her illness, many of them from a rehabilitation center where she was receiving treatment. Her resolve and inner strength, along with and her almost nave hope for the future, pour forth in great abundance from the writings.One thing that strikes us most in Tanny's post-polio life is her determination to remain independent in the face of her disability. And, indeed, the movie ends on a high note, as we learn that Tanny spent the better part of her life imparting her priceless wisdom and insight to young dancers from her wheelchair.The movie provides an inspiring portrait of an inspiring person.

Wes Anderson’s latest cinematic confection, “The Grand Budapest Hotel,“ is a quirky, surrealistic comedy set at a mountain resort run by a concierge named M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes)  and a “lobby boy” named Zero Mustafa (Tony Revolori), whom M. Gustave has taken under his wings to train in the art of service.Set in a fictional country, the movie begins in 1968, when the Grand Budapest Hotel is just a shadow of its former self, having been allowed to fall into disrepair and currently inhabited by a small contingent of eccentric tenants.  One of them is a writer (Tom Wilkinson) who discovers that Mustafa (F. Murray Abraham) is now the owner of the once-proud establishment. The elder Mustafa regales him with stories of an earlier time in the hotel’s history - the 1930s, in fact - when the palatial inn played host to only the richest and most aristocratic of occupants and guests.Through dual-narrated flashbacks, then, Anderson weaves a smart and cheeky tale of an enduring friendship that triumphs over class division, a tale that combines wit with imagination and social commentary with visual elegance, set against the writer/director’s trademarked air of heightened unreality. When he isn‘t fulfilling his duties as hotel concierge, the foppish M. Gustave, fastidious in manner and with a poetic quote for every occasion, offers his “personal” services exclusively to blond, fabulously wealthy and emotionally insecure dowagers, one of whom bequeaths to him a priceless painting upon her sudden death. This surprising turn-of-events puts him at odds with a veritable army of the deceased woman’s outraged relatives. This leads to a stolen art treasure, a false conviction for murder, a daring prison break and a mad race to stay one step ahead of the pursuing authorities, as M. Gustave endeavors to prove his innocence.To enhance the dreamlike nature of the material, the look of the film is marked by whimsical art direction and ultra-stylized framing. Even the dimensions of the screen change with the time period of the story - traditional square for the scenes set in 1932 and widescreen for those that take place in 1968.In addition to the splendid deadpan performances of Fiennes, Abraham and newcomer Revolori in the key roles, the movie provides a veritable sea of familiar faces in supporting and bit parts, many of them members of Anderson’s repertory company: Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe, Jeff Goldblum, Harvey Keitel, Jude Law, Bill Murray, Edward Norton, Tilda Swinton and Owen Wilson, among others.“The Grand Budapest Hotel” finds Mr. Anderson in peak form.

"300: Rise of an Empire" is less of a sequel to the 2007 original and more of a companion-piece, since much of what it chronicles overlaps, rather than follows, the events of that earlier film. The jumbled chronology leads to a great deal of confusion on the part of the viewer, helped not one whit by the fact that all the actors look pretty much the same in their Greek warrior attire, so that one is never quite sure who is fighting where or against whom. And, in all honesty, I'm not really sure it's worth the effort trying to figure it all out.As far as I can tell, the set-up goes something like this: the effete and cowardly Athenians, who are always going on and on about things like philosophy and democracy, turn to the bellicose Spartans for help in defeating the Persians led by Xerxes (Rodrigo Santoro), son of the late King Darius (Yigal Naor). Yet, although Xerxes has been transformed into a gold-plated demi-god, he's really just the puppet of the far more ruthless and conniving Artemisia (Eva Green), who French kisses decapitated heads and has dreams of bringing arrogant Greece to its knees once and for all for killing her family and turning her into a sex-slave, though she herself is of Greek extraction. The Athenian leader is (the almost unpronounceable) Themistokles (Sullivan Stapleton), who killed King Darius with a very well-aimed arrow through the heart and was rewarded with command of the army in grateful recognition of that feat. Beyond this synopsis, you're on your own.In an attempt to visually replicate the as-yet unpublished Frank Miller graphic novel that is its source, the movie employs a mix of live action and computer-generated imagery that puts the film in a kind of never-never-land of legendary pseudo-history.This garish spectacle of stiff acting, gleaming pecs, passionate hate-sex, pop psychology, two-bit philosophizing and slow-motion bloodletting is indeed something to behold, but, frankly, you've seen it all before - only better - in the original film.

Usually when movies use Paris as a romantic backdrop, it’s a young couple who gets to occupy the foreground. Not so with “Le Week-End,” a tale of two aging tourists - he a professor of philosophy, she a teacher - who’ve chosen to “celebrate” their 30th anniversary in (where else? ) the City of Lights.Like many couples who have been together for a long time, Nick and Meg Burroughs often seem to have more things that are driving them apart than bringing them together. Not only have they grown tired of each other’s all-too-predictable habits and quirks, but Meg, in particular, feels that now, with the kids grown and gone, it may be time for the two of them to move on and to spend what little time they have left getting to know themselves as individuals rather than as a couple.Because the screenplay by Hanif Kureishi is clearly focused on an older couple, the film captures the paradox that exists at the core of lasting romantic love: that the very same predictable patterns and dull routines that, over time, work to deaden love are also what enhance intimacy and bind us inexorably to one another over the long haul.Though Meg and Nick are still clearly sexual beings, even that fact has caused some tension and division between them, namely in an affair Nick had awhile back and for which he is perpetually atoning. Yet, the script is smart enough to know that what is said in the heat of the moment is not always indicative of what is in the heart.Much of the second half of the film takes place at a posh and pretentious dinner party thrown by an old college buddy of Nick’s, an American author and intellectual played by Jeff Goldblum.Director Roger Michell keeps the tone serious and intimate without becoming heavy-handed or preachy. He allows the characters to reveal their depth through conversation and the way they interact with the world and each other. He is aided immeasurably by the skilled and incisive performances of Jim Broadbent and Lindsay Duncan, who make us truly believe that they are a couple who have grown both comfortable and complacent with one another over time. Above all, “Le Week-End” acknowledges that relationships are tricky and complex things and come with no pat or easy instructions to make them easier to navigate our way through.After “Le Week-End,” it may not be necessary for Richard Linklater to make another “Before…” movie, after all. I think Kureishi and Michell might have done it already.

From the war-is-hell department comes “Stalingrad,” an old-fashioned World War II movie chronicling the famous siege that devastated that city in 1942 and 1943. This dubbed-into-English Russian film tells of five heroic Soviet fighters who commandeer a shell-shocked woman’s apartment out of which they wage their own battle against the Nazis.With its clear-cut delineation between good guys and bad guys, heroes and villains (except for one momentarily ambiguous Nazi), it’s clear that subtlety is not exactly the movie’s strong suit. In addition, its complete lack of character development turns the viewers into dispassionate observers of all the brutality and carnage taking place on screen.Running an overlong 2 hours and 10 minutes, this static and talky and occasionally corny movie seems designed to provide modern-day Russians with a morale boost by giving them a chance to focus on their heroic past. And while the Russians have just as much of a right to engage in this sort of self-congratulatory exercise as anyone else (goodness knows, American moviemakers do it often enough), it still doesn’t make for very compelling filmmaking or drama.If you want to see this sort of thing done right, check out the beautiful 1957 Russian classic, “The Cranes are Flying,“ a true work of art for any season or nationality.

**1/2A high-octane action flick on the order of the "Fast and Furious" franchise, "Need for Speed" features the less-than-impressive first big-screen headliner role for Aaron Paul, the brilliant young star of TV's "Breaking Bad." In it, he portrays Tobey Marshall, an unassuming mechanic by day and by night a street racer whose recently deceased dad was not only the owner of the body shop that Tobey is now trying to rescue from the old man's years of mismanagement but a legend among the die-hard racing crowd. Daddy issues much? Before he knows it, Tobey is wrongly convicted of the death of his best friend in a fiery car crash and, when he's finally paroled, dedicates his life to exacting revenge on the actual culprit, a snooty rival from Tobey's past. And what better or more fitting way than by besting said villain in an illegal cross-country race sponsored by an underground radio announcer played by Michael Keaton?The plot, such as it is, doesn't require much more in the way of elaboration, other than to say that it's basically just an excuse for a bunch of testosterone-fueled, speed-busting outlaws to careen through the city streets and around the countryside in their fantastically expensive race cars with zero regard for the lives and safety of themselves or anyone else around them. This cavalier attitude is supposed to make the characters somehow cool and charming when what they really are is obnoxious and appalling. And while we're asked to weep when one of their own number gets inevitably killed in an "accident," that same courtesy isn't extended to any of the innocent motorists or law enforcement officials who might get taken out during their high-stakes "playtime." They're all just "collateral damage," I suppose.One understands Paul's need for a little R&R in the acting department after the intense rigors required by five seasons of "Breaking Bad." Still, one hopes that he'll soon get back to doing what he does best now that he's gotten this little career detour into commercial movie-making out of his system.Director Scott Waugh pumps up the action scenes efficiently, but he's had far less success with the quieter expository moments. No surprise, given that the movie is based on a video game of the same name.The supporting cast includes Dominic Cooper, Imogen Poots, Ramon Rodriguez ("Gang-Related"), Rami Malek and the aforementioned Keaton, but, like Paul, they too play second fiddle to the cars, chase scenes and stunt work. And that, I guess, is as it should be when it comes to a movie with a title like "Need for Speed."

A familiar face in Britain but a virtual unknown in the States, comedian Steve Coogan has made his name in his home country portraying a fictional radio talk show host by the name of Alan Partridge. Since 1991, Coogan has performed his act on both radio and TV, and now he's branched out to his first feature-length movie entitled "Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa" (just "Alan Partridge" in the United States).In the film, the station where Partridge works is facing serious cutbacks due to a corporate takeover, changing audience tastes, a drop in listenership and bailing advertisers. Though Partridge himself survives the ax, the same cannot be said for his fellow broadcaster, Pat Farrell ("Hell on Wheels' Colm Meaney), who, upon learning of his dismissal, completely flips out, holding his co-workers hostage at gunpoint while the goofy and inept Partridge is sent in by the authorities to help negotiate a peaceful resolution to the crisis.Maybe with our history of gun violence, we're a trifle more sensitive to this sort of thing here in America than they are in Britain, which may explain why some of the laughs tend to catch in our throats at times, particularly when Farrell is threatening to take out a bunch of his own innocent and understandably distraught colleagues as retaliation for the wrong that's been done to him. That being said, the stylish mix of satire, slapstick, black humor and social commentary that Coogan and his various co-writers have come up keeps us chortling through most of the movie.Coogan makes Partridge a likable everyman character, bemused and skeptical without being hard-edged and cynical. The supporting cast is engaging as well.Offbeat and funny.

“Repentance” starts off as a reasonably sincere tale of a best-selling author/life coach (Anthony Mackie) who tries to help a grieving man (Forest Whitaker) come to turns with the death of his mother. But at the 35 minute mark, the movie suddenly jumps the tracks, turning into a bizarre, yet strangely conventional, hostage drama, with the psychologically disturbed client kidnapping and torturing the psychologist in an effort to prove which of the two is actually most in need of help.The movie seems to be making the case that people like the Mackie character are just glib, overpaid shysters, taking advantage of people‘s suffering by offering them little but shibboleths and bromides to help them cope with their problems - but any message the movie might be trying to convey is subsumed by the unpleasant melodramatics that come to dominate the second half. Yeomen that they are, Mackie and Whitaker work valiantly to overcome the various roadblocks that the script throws in their path, but even these two fine performers eventually have to concede that they’re fighting a losing battle here. Even the “surprise” ending and moralistic message can’t ultimately redeem this cinematic turkey.

***1/2Those with a fear of flying might want to skip “Non-Stop,” an airliner-in-jeopardy thriller that could have you taking trains and buses for quite some time to come.In another of his increasingly frequent action-hero roles, Liam Neeson plays Bill Marks, a U.S. air marshal who discovers that someone aboard a flight from New York to London is threatening to kill a new passenger every 20 minutes until $150 million is deposited into an account that has been set up for the occasion. The twist is that the mystery culprit is making it look as if Marks is the actual extortionist and may even be making Marks carry out some of the killings for him.“Non-Stop” works well enough within the limited confines of both the setting and the hostages-held-for-ransom genre of which it is a part. The whodunit plotting unravels at an appropriate pace, with a whole host of possible suspects for us to choose from, including fellow passengers Juliette Moore, Anson Mount (“Hell on Wheels”) and Corey Stoll (“House of Cards” ), as well as Michelle Dockery (“Downton Abbey”) and Lupita Nyong’o (“12 Years a Slave”) as flight attendants who demonstrate grace and ingenuity under pressure.The holes in the plot are probably large enough to fly a 747 through, but you really won’t notice or care while you’re strapped in for the ride.  And to think, most airlines just provide movies as in-flight entertainment.

*1/2"The Legend of Hercules" is a $70 million cheese-basket loaded with ho-hum special effects and a low-voltage cast of Hollywood back-benchers (Kellan Lutz, Gaia Weiss, Scott Adkins, etc.).The movie purports to tell the story of the famed demi-god/son of Zeus, who also happens to be the strongest man in the world, but very little that makes its way to the screen has anything to do with the actual myth of Hercules as it has come down to us through the millennia.What we're left with finally is a dull, witless affair that fails to engage either as spectacle or as drama. Where's the magic Disney touch when you need it?

At 58, Gloria is in the midst of a midlife crisis. Divorced and with a seemingly strained relationship with her adult children, Gloria is also coping with a mundane job, a potentially psychotic upstairs neighbor, and days on end of perpetual loneliness (and, oh yes, a creepy hairless cat that keeps coming over for a visit). Until, that is, she meets Rodolpho, a divorced ex-naval officer, who has the opposite problem from Gloria: he’s TOO intimately involved with the lives of his grown daughters, so much so that he is unable to devote the time needed to nurture his relationship with Gloria.On the surface, “Gloria” feels like most of the other midlife crisis films we’ve seen, but the strength of this Chilean/Spanish co-production lies in its naturalism and in its focus on revelatory detail. Writer Gonzalo Maza and writer/director Sebastian Lelio provide enough specifics to make this a very particular story about a very particular woman. That manages to keep Gloria a sympathetic figure even when her understandable unhappiness begins to slide over into self-pity. The movie also refuses to tie its story up in a nice, neat little bow at the end to cater to audience expectations.Paulina Garcia won a number of awards, all richly deserved, for her nuanced, fully-developed portrayal of a woman whose life is all but put under a microscope for all the world to see. Yet, Garcia meets the challenge with a bravery rare for actresses her age. Sergio Hernandez matches her as the man who comes into Gloria’s life but who may be bringing plenty of his own baggage right along with him.Yet, for all its insight into late-in-life romance, the movie ultimately reveals that middle-aged lovers are often every bit as petulant, jealous and overly sensitive - not to mention, clueless - as the greenest teen when it comes to affairs of the heart. Some things just never change, I guess.

Like any trio of college buds who are now making their way in New York City (any trio of young men in the MOVIES, that is), Mikey (Michael B. Jordan), Jason (Zac Efron) and Daniel (Miles Teller) are having trouble with women. When Mikey is served with divorce papers, Jason and Daniel agree to remain single and uncommitted till such time as their cuckolded buddy feels like returning to the field.With screenplay and direction by Tom Gormican, “That Awkward Moment” treads upon some mighty shopworn territory at this point, but the general likeability of the stars helps to mitigate some of the familiarity. Ditto for Imogen Poots, Mackenzie Davis and Jessica Lucas who play the various women in their lives who come along to tempt the boys to break their pact. And at least when the movie is indulging in one of those only-in-the-movies scenes that are so endemic to the romantic comedy genre, it seems slyly aware of that fact.Not particularly distinguished or memorable, but enjoyable enough while it’s going on.

“The Suspect” has all the polish and professionalism of some grad-school student’s final project for a PhD in Cinema.The premise of the movie is so improbable and loopy that it requires a complete suspension of disbelief even to get through it. However, I won’t reveal what that premise is, for to do so would be to engage in the biggest plot spoiler since “The Crying Game.” All I can tell you is that it involves two African-American men who may have robbed a bank in a rural Midwest community. “May” is indeed the operative word here, for it turns out there is far more to the story than what appears on the surface.If all that sounds somehow intriguing, then I’m doing more justice to the movie than it actually deserves. I don’t question the good intentions of those who made the film, but it so ineptly directed and so badly acted, so filled with screeds and bromides about racism and justice, and so bogged down by over-earnest plotting and a confusing time-shifting narrative, that even the best of intentions can’t make a silk purse out of this particular sow’s ear.I’ve deliberately avoided identifying the individuals responsible for “The Suspect,” both those in front of the camera and those behind it, and I wish them nothing but the best in their future careers in moviemaking. But I doubt anyone will be rushing to claim credit for this underwhelming, if well-intentioned, cinematic misfire.

Will Arnett, Brendan Fraser, Gabriel Iglesias, Jeff Dunham, Maya Rudolph, Liam Neeson, Stephan Lang and Katherine Heigl provide some of the voices for “The Nut Job,” an animated film that has, for its characters, an assortment of rodents and human mobsters, all fighting over a supply of nuts during a shortage.The little ones might be entranced by the bug-eyed critters and pretty colors (though I wouldn’t count on it), but a weak, humorless and confused script, along with indifferent animation, makes it an uninteresting affair for viewers over the age of, say, seven-and-a-half.Even though the movie runs only 86 minutes, through some inverse law of physics, it seems to last an eternity.

Paul W. S. Anderson's "Pompeii" is a throwback to all those sword-and- sandal epics of yesteryear that combined period-piece spectacle with generous dollops of bloodletting, action and romance. This 1st Century soap opera just happens to take place in the shadow of Vesuvius, the volcano that famously erupted in 79 A.D., burying much of the city and its inhabitants in tombs of molten rock and ash.Looking like he barely needed a change of wardrobe from his day job, "Game of Throne's" Kit Harrington plays Milo, a Celtic boy who, after he witnesses his family being slaughtered by Roman troops in the northernmost region of the empire, is forced into slavery and raised to become a gladiator. When he's brought to Pompeii to fight in the arena, he catches the eye of Cassia (Emily Browning), a thoroughly anachronistic, sassy, forward-looking, freethinking type who finds the officials in Rome to be all uncouth barbarians and who has no taste for such popular blood-soaked pastimes as fight-to-the-death battles in the coliseum. A ludicrously miscast Keifer Sutherland plays a foul Roman senator who tries to come between the noble woman and the slave.As befits the genre, "Pompeii" is just chockablock with stock characters, cheesy dialogue and corny plotting, though the movie does earn a few points for its unlikely and, dare I say it, even quite brave finale.But, of course, anyone who checks out "Pompeii" will be doing so strictly to witness, albeit vicariously, all the death and destruction visited upon the city and its thousands of inhabitants when Vesuvius finally blows its top. Apparently, overproduced, CGI-infested disaster movies are our milder, modern-day equivalent to gladiatorial contests. And in that respect, at least, the movie delivers the goods.There's one thing that "Pompeii," fortunately, doesn't have in common with those toga-wrapped spectacles of the past - and that is their extraordinary length. So clocking in at a relatively brief 104 minutes, "Pompeii" has at least one thing going for it.

**1/2So what do we have here? Nothing but another unnecessary remake of an ‘80s film. This time it’s “About Last Night,” the romantic drama starring Demi Moore and Rob Lowe, which was itself based on the highly acclaimed play by David Mamet, provocatively entitled “Sexual Perversity in Chicago.” In this version, it’s Joy Brand and Michael Ealy who play the young urban couple who meet, fall in love, move in together, then begin to have doubts about the efficacy and durability of their relationship.Brand and Ealy are appealing and attractive performers, and both have done fine work on TV, Brand in “Parenthood” and Ealy in “Almost Human.” But here they have been let down by screenwriter Leslye Headland, who proves herself incapable of getting past all the timeworn tropes and cliches that have become so much a part of the romantic comedy genre. The movie becomes just another men-are-from-Mars/women-are-from-Venus-type scenario, filled with girl-talk and guy-talk and all the predictable sturm und drang soul-baring and commitment issues (mainly on the part of the man, of course) that such narratives are prone to. Too often the things pulling the couple apart feel scripted and manufactured rather than organic and real. Under the slick but lackluster direction of Steve Pink, everyone just seems to be going through the motions, without any real passion or conviction.The movie also comes replete with the requisite smart-aleck, comic-relief couple (well-played by Kevin Hart and Regina Hall) to serve as a foil for the one on center-stage. Yet, even the humor tends to aim low when it should be aiming high.I like the way the story hits the re-set button in the final scene, but by then it’s a case of too little too late and we’ve already moved onto the next movie.

Based on an event that garnered worldwide attention in 2009, “Captain Phillips” tells the tale of two total strangers, both hailing from opposites corners of the earth, who are brought together by circumstance and fate.One of those individuals is Richard Phillips, the captain of an unarmed cargo ship sailing through international waters off the coast of Africa en route to Mombasa, and the other is Abduwali Muse, the leader of a band of Somali pirates who are determined to board the ship and hold its captain and crew hostage for ransom.Billy Ray has based his screenplay on the book “A Captain’s Duty” by Steven Talty and Phillips himself. The movie, directed with his usual taut precision by Paul Greengrass, relates the story in step-by-step detail, exploring the relationship between these two wildly disparate but equally desperate captains, as a thrilling real-life drama plays itself out on the high seas. While Phillips’ self-sacrificing heroism - and that of the Navy Seals who successfully took out three of the four pirates - takes center stage in the drama, Ray is still able to give Abduwali his due, making it clear that the young man has been driven to this action as much out of desperation as out of greed or criminal intent, since illegal fishing and the dumping of toxic waste on the part of foreigners in that area have pretty much depleted the Somali fishing grounds, leaving men like Abduwali without any viable means of supporting themselves and their families. Sadly, piracy becomes the next obvious step in the struggle for survival. It would have been easy to have turned Abduwali and his cohorts into one-dimensional villains, but, to their credit, Ray and Greengrass have chosen not to do so.This complexity of character is attributable in no small measure to the outstanding performances by veteran Tom Hanks and newcomer Barkhad Abdi, who earned an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his work here. Together, they create a human dynamic that carries the film far beyond the heart-stopping, race-against-the-clock surface aspects of the drama. Not that the visceral is in any way slighted, for in true Greengrass fashion, the film moves along at a breakneck pace, rarely slowing down to give the audience a chance to catch its breath along the way.By far, the most effective scene in the movie comes right near the end, after Phillips has been rescued and is taken to the ship’s trauma center to ascertain his physical and mental condition. Unlike the vast majority of movies and TV shows in which characters who are subjected to horrifying circumstances seem to bounce back from them almost immediately, “Captain Phillips” shows us the true human response to a life-shattering, traumatic event (thanks in no small measure to Hanks‘ magnificent acting).It is just this type of insightful verisimilitude that informs each and every moment of “Captain Phillips.”

**1/2There’s something almost refreshingly old-fashioned about “The Monuments Men,” one of those Very Important Pictures that Hollywood used to produce with such abundance in its heyday. It’s one of those World War II pictures in which a motley group of strangers is recruited by the United States Army to carry out a mission behind enemy lines. Dubbed the Monuments Men, this group of art experts was assigned the task of rescuing some of the world’s greatest art masterpieces from the grasping hands of the Nazis who were busily absconding with the works with the intention of displaying them in a museum of their own after the war.Lt. Frank Stokes, who spearheaded the mission, is portrayed by George Clooney, while the men he recruits are played by Matt Damon, Bill Murray, John Goodman, Jean Dujardin, Bib Balaban, Dimitri Leonidas and Hugh Bonneville (“Downton Abbey”). Cate Blanchett co-stars as a curator who is also a Resistance fighter working for the French Underground, and who is initially suspicious of the Monuments Men’s motives for rounding up the treasures.The movie is interesting enough as an unusual slice of history, I suppose, but the screenplay by Clooney and Grant Heslov, based on the book by Robert M. Edsel, never finds a way to make this true life tale come alive as drama. The characters are dull and under-developed, and, as a consequence, we find ourselves strangely uninterested in their back stories and unmoved by their fates. There is also way too much emphasis placed on the comical and the sentimental, and the movie comes replete with a gratingly frivolous score that seems woefully inappropriate to the subject at hand.Despite the all-star cast, the movie is weighed down by over-earnest acting, with Murray and Balaban seemingly on hand mainly for the comic relief they provide.Clooney has directed the film with hollow competence, and there’s some discussion about whether or not lives should be risked for the sake of inanimate objects, no matter how valuable, but it’s hard to make anything particularly memorable out of a story where the artwork has more personality than the players.

**1/2“Ride Along” isn’t technically a “cop buddy” comedy - seeing as one of the characters isn’t actually a cop - though the movie follows the basic formula almost to a tee.Ice Cube plays James Payton, an Atlanta police officer who doesn’t much care for the man his sister (Ika Sumpter) is currently dating, one Ben Barger (Kevin Hart), a ne’er-do-well goofball who works as a security guard at a high school when he isn’t sitting at home on the couch playing video games. Ben does, however, suffer from delusions of grandeur when it comes to what he plans to do with his life, which is to use his skills as a gamer to become one hell of a real life crime fighter. James agrees to take Ben on a “ride along” in his squad car to see if he has what it takes to be a cop. Hilarity ensues.Or at least it would if the one-joke premise didn’t run out of steam about a half hour into the movie’s running time. Actually, “Ride Along” starts off on a promising note, with breezy, fast-paced dialogue and a genuine rapport established between Hart as the comic cutup and Ice Cube as his requisite straight man (think of them as an African-American version of Martin and Lewis).But the concept begins to pall early on, as too many of the scenes run on well past their sell-by dates as far as generating any further laughs is concerned. A pity, in that, given better material, Hart, especially, might have made something decent out of “Ride Along.”

Disclaimer: I am not a chef, I am not a knife expert,and I cannot cook much of anything fancy.
